Title: Germany's Lower Coronavirus Death Rate Attributed to Early and Widespread Testing

Article:

Germany, despite having the fifth-highest number of coronavirus cases globally, has a remarkably low fatality rate of 0.5 percent, making it the country with the world's lowest death rate from COVID-19. This contrasts sharply with countries like Italy and France, which have fatality rates of around 10 percent and 5 percent, respectively.

According to Christian Drosten, director of the Institute of Virology at Berlin's Charité hospital, Germany's low fatality rate is due to the country's ability to test early and often. Drosten, whose team developed the first COVID-19 test used in the public domain, estimates that Germany has been testing around 120,000 people a week for COVID-19 during the month-long period from late February to now, when it reached epidemic proportions in the country. This extensive testing regimen is believed to be the most extensive in the world.

Drosten attributes Germany's extensive testing to the country's decentralized diagnostic system, which allows for a more open market for testing. Unlike the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Germany's equivalent, the Robert Koch Institute, makes recommendations but does not control testing for the entire country. Instead, Germany's 16 federal states make their own decisions on coronavirus testing, as each is responsible for its own health care system.

When Drosten's university medical center developed the test recommended by the World Health Organization, they rolled these tests out to their colleagues throughout Germany in January. This created a situation where testing was already in place, broadly, by the beginning or middle of February.

However, not everyone in Germany is as confident as Drosten. Nizana Nizzi Brautmann, a Berlin resident, was worried when a teacher at her son's school tested positive for COVID-19, and she and her son woke up with fevers and persistent coughing. She said she could not get through to Berlin's coronavirus hotline, which was continuously busy. She finally got through to the city's emergency medical service number, but was told they did not perform tests and advised her to stay home and drink tea.

Drosten believes such experiences are probably an exception, not the rule. He said the supply of tests is still good, and the country has had a robust response to the coronavirus pandemic. However, he is most worried about countries in Africa that are not well-set up for this pandemic, as they will find it more difficult to flatten the curve once the crisis reaches them.

Title: Black Lives Matter Global Network's Funding Structure and Transparency Under Scrutiny

Article:

In a recent investigation, FactCheck.org and Politifact confirmed that the Black Lives Matter Global Network is not a recognized Internal Revenue Service (IRS) charity. Instead, the organization raises funds through a fiscal sponsor, global nonprofit Thousand Currents. This arrangement, while common in the nonprofit sector, has sparked discussions about transparency and the legal obligations of the involved parties.

According to FactCheck.org, ActBlue, a fundraising platform, helps to raise funds for the Black Lives Matter Global Network by directing donations to Thousand Currents, their fiscal sponsor. The partnership between ActBlue and Thousand Currents was announced in 2016, with the latter providing "fiduciary oversight, financial management, and other administrative services to BLM."

Caleb Cade, a spokesperson for ActBlue, confirmed to the fact-checking site that "donations made through ActBlue go to Thousand Currents for Black Lives Matter." Jenesha de Rivera, director of finance and administration at Thousand Currents, stated that the foundation has applied to become its own 501(c)(3), but the Black Lives Matter group did not return their request for a Form 1023, the form used to apply for 501(c)(3) status.

Benjamin Leff, a professor specializing in nonprofits, told the fact-checking site that both ActBlue Charities and Thousand Currents have a legal obligation to make reasonable efforts to ensure that the funds they receive are spent consistent with 501(c)(3) restrictions.

However, Tom Fitton, president of Judicial Watch, suggested that the fiscal sponsorship route blocks full transparency, particularly when it comes to its partnership with ActBlue. "Transparency? So if you want to make a tax-deductible charitable donation directly to Black Lives Matter, you can't. You donate to Act Blue Charities. Act Blue Charities sends this money, allegedly, to another charity, Thousand Currents, which runs BLM as a 'fiscal sponsorship,'" Fitton tweeted.

As reported by FactCheck.org, a Thousand Currents audit for 2019 shows that, as of June 2019, the organization held nearly $3.4 million in net assets for Black Lives Matter. It had released nearly $1.8 million to the group in the last fiscal year. The audit also provides a breakdown of how the foundation spent that $1.8 million, including on consultants and salaries.

This arrangement and the transparency surrounding it have become a topic of debate, with some critics suggesting that the financial arrangement blocks full transparency. The Black Lives Matter Global Network continues to operate under this fiscal sponsorship arrangement, and the question of transparency remains a point of contention.

Title: The 491st Sin: Racism in American Politics and the Trump-Clinton Rhetoric

Article:

In the political landscape of the United States, the accusation of racism has become a potent weapon, akin to the Gospel's "seventy times seven" forgiveness, with the 491st sin being considered unforgivable. This was evident in the recent exchange between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, as they courted the African-American and Hispanic communities.

Clinton, in an attempt to discredit Trump, implied that the "alt-right" supporters, who she claimed back her opponent, were racists. While she did not explicitly label Trump a racist, her insinuation was clear. This tactic, reminiscent of the McCarthyite smear campaigns of the past, has been effective in stirring up opprobrium and demanding moral isolation of the accused.

However, it is crucial to examine the nature of these accusations and the individuals they target. In the case of the "alt-right," it is not accurate to label them as the biggest racists around. If one is looking for racism, one might find it in the Black Lives Matter movement or in the actions of some political figures, including Hillary Clinton herself.

In the political right, it is not the nationalists, but the libertarians, who might be accused of harboring racial biases. These individuals, often white friends with an unhealthy fascination with IQ scores, take a guilty pleasure in books like "The Bell Curve" by Charles Murray and Richard Herrnstein, which seems to validate their belief in their intellectual superiority.

It is essential to differentiate between racism and nationalism. A nationalist accepts all fellow citizens as peers, while a racist does not. The nationalist judges policies based on their benefits to American citizens, not foreigners. They are not indifferent to people in other countries, but they prioritize their own, including Americans of every race.

In the case of Trump and his supporters, they are nationalists, not racists. The accusation that Trump supporters are racists, especially among Trump-haters on the right, remains to be seen. As the political landscape continues to evolve, it will be interesting to observe who takes up this accusation and how it will shape the discourse moving forward.

Title: Four Cities Vote to Legalize Marijuana, Signaling a Shift in American Attitudes Toward Pot

Article:

In a significant development for the marijuana legalization movement, four cities in the United States voted to legalize marijuana in Tuesday's elections. The cities include three in Michigan and the first East Coast city, Portland, Maine. While these votes are largely symbolic as the states of Michigan and Maine still consider marijuana illegal, they mark another milestone in the ongoing push for legalization.

According to a Gallup Poll released in October, 58% of Americans support marijuana legalization, a 10-point increase from a year earlier. This figure represents the highest level of support for marijuana legalization in American history, with a majority of Americans backing the measure for the first time in both polls.

Analysts and advocates attribute the sudden surge in support to several factors. The legalization of marijuana in Colorado and Washington has brought the issue to the forefront of a national conversation, and during a time of tight federal budgets, people are increasingly questioning the need for robust law enforcement spending, which experts say leads to high incarceration rates.

Additionally, the federal government is allowing states to move forward with legalization and is not aggressively enforcing federal marijuana crime laws. According to Allen St. Pierre, executive director of the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Law, the country is moving closer to legalization.

In addition to the two states that have legalized marijuana, 21 states allow medical marijuana, and 17 have decided to decriminalize it. In the next two elections, voters in five states, including California, Maine, Oregon, Massachusetts, and Alaska, are expected to have a say in the issue.

The legalization of marijuana has taken a similar trajectory as same-sex marriage, which has also seen a flood of public support in recent years. In both cases, the same groups of people are opposed: those who are most religious and those over 55. Additionally, liberals and young people are most likely to support the issues.

However, William Galston, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, cautions against too closely linking the two issues. Republicans and conservatives are much more likely to oppose same-sex marriage, and those against are strongly opposed. As for marijuana, this group tends to be "ambivalent," Galston said.

Despite the differences in the two issues, support is growing for both. Interestingly, the liberalization of the issues comes at a time when the country remains mostly conservative. In 2012, a Gallup survey found that 40% of Americans identify as conservative, while 35% identify as moderate. Only 21% call themselves liberals. Moderates have been declining since the poll began asking the question in 1992 as more are identifying as either liberal or conservative.

"It's perfectly possible for a country to become more conservative about economic policy and more liberal on issues affecting personal liberty," Galston said. "I just described libertarianism to you." And that could explain the increase in support for marijuana legalization, an example of an issue where the liberal and libertarian-minded conservatives are on the same page.

Title: Four Key Insights from New Hampshire Primary: Marco Rubio's Debate Impact, Clinton-Sanders Race, and GOP Field Shrinkage

Article:

As New Hampshire voters head to the polls on Tuesday, the primary will provide valuable insights into the state of the presidential race. Here are four things the first-in-the-nation primary will reveal:

1. The extent of Marco Rubio's debate damage: After a strong start in New Hampshire, Rubio's performance in the ABC debate on Saturday has raised concerns. His repetitive responses and perceived lack of depth have been criticized, and his campaign has since been downplaying expectations. The results of the New Hampshire primary will indicate the impact of the debate on Rubio's standing.

2. The margin of Hillary Clinton's defeat to Bernie Sanders: Clinton's narrow victory in Iowa has not translated into momentum in New Hampshire. A significant victory for Sanders could provide a boost for his campaign ahead of the Nevada caucuses, while a closer race could signal Clinton's ability to maintain her campaign.

3. The size of the GOP field post-New Hampshire: Before the debate, the Republican field was expected to narrow to a three-man race (Trump, Cruz, and Rubio). However, the results of the primary could determine whether governors such as John Kasich, Jeb Bush, and Chris Christie remain in the race, depending on their placement.

4. The intensity of voter turnout: New Hampshire is known for its unpredictable results, and the level of voter turnout could significantly impact the outcome of the primary. A high turnout could favor candidates with strong grassroots support, while a lower turnout could benefit candidates with a strong establishment backing.

The results of the New Hampshire primary will provide valuable insights into the direction of the presidential race, as well as the potential shape of the remaining Republican field.

Title: Trump's Tweet Delays House Immigration Bill Vote, Raising Doubts on Compromise Bill's Future

Article:

WASHINGTON—President Donald Trump's tweet on Friday has delayed a House bill on immigration overhaul, as he suggested that Republicans should wait until they have more solid majorities in Congress to pursue the issue. The tweet has cast doubt on the future of the compromise bill, which has been delayed until next week.

Republicans currently hold majorities of 51-49 in the Senate and 235-193 in the House. Some election watchers see Democrats making gains in the House in the midterm elections this fall, and perhaps winning back majority control.

Rep. Patrick McHenry (R-NC), the chief deputy whip, said Friday that the planned immigration vote will move ahead despite the flagging support for the effort, citing party leaders' promise to GOP moderates.

Speaker Paul Ryan (R-WI) had agreed to hold the vote on what Republicans called a compromise bill to head off a special maneuver called a discharge petition that would have allowed centrist Republicans to join with Democrats to bring their own immigration bills to the floor.

"There's no significant dynamic shift in our conference on immigration," Mr. McHenry said, when asked if there was sufficient support to pass the consensus bill. As for Mr. Trump's tweet, he said: "The president is speaking truth. If you want to fix immigration crisis in a holistic way, you're going to need Democrats to participate in this process."

Rep. Nancy Pelosi of California, the Democratic leader, has rejected labeling the bill a compromise, saying its provisions on Dreamers—young immigrants brought to the country as minors and living in the U.S. without authorization—and the zero-tolerance policy of charging adult illegal immigrants are too harsh for her party to accept. No Democrats were expected to support the measure.

House Republican leaders had seen Mr. Trump's salesmanship as essential to pushing an immigration plan through the House. The Republican president shifted his position on the compromise bill several times over the past week, first rejecting it, then supporting it, and now saying it should be put off until after the November election.

Mr. Trump also moved this week to change a policy that had resulted in thousands of children being separated from their parents at the border. Mr. Trump issued an executive order that keeps his zero-tolerance stance on arresting illegal border crossers in place but directs that families be kept together. While welcomed by many lawmakers, it again shifted the playing field for the legislative negotiations.

The president's support of the compromise bill had given some Republicans political cover, particularly from conservative critics who charged that granting protected status to young immigrants amounted to amnesty. With that support now gone, the bill's future was more in doubt.

"I would say his tweet doesn't help," said Rep. Don Bacon (R-NE) who is supporting the compromise bill. "I just feel like this is an opportunity to get something done and I feel like we owe it to do our part in the House."

Rep. Louie Gohmert (R-TX) said the president was under pressure to back the compromise bill to bring hard-line immigration conservatives like himself on board and was glad to see Mr. Trump push back.

"The president realized that this is not a bill that we ought to be dying on because it's time to move on. We'll get a better bill later," he said.

The compromise immigration bill would provide $23.4 billion for border security—including a wall and surveillance technology—and would cut family-based immigration and eliminate a diversity-visa lottery program. It would also provide six years of legal status to the young immigrants.

The vote on that plan was delayed Thursday after rank-and-file House Republicans pressed leaders to make additional changes to the measure. Some conservatives complained that the compromise omitted a requirement that employers use the E-Verify system to check workers' immigration status, while other lawmakers wanted reassurances on how the legislation addressed the parents of Dreamers.

Several Senate Republicans have introduced their own, narrow, legislation that focuses on how asylum cases are handled at the border. That bill would codify Mr. Trump's zero-tolerance policy for border crossers and keep families seeking asylum united in detention centers. It would authorize 225 new immigration judges and require the Department of Homeland Security to prioritize resolving family cases. Sens. Ted Cruz (R-TX) and Dianne Feinstein (D-CA) are also working on bipartisan legislation.

Title: "Dennis Prager Challenges Leftist Narrative on Racism: A Closer Look at Conservative Values and Preferences"

Article:

In a thought-provoking piece, nationally syndicated radio talk-show host and columnist Dennis Prager questions the widespread labeling of Trump supporters and conservatives as "racist" by leftists. Prager, in his latest book "The Rational Bible," argues that this label is a "big lie" and challenges leftists to confront the truth about conservatives.

Prager proposes a series of questions to test the validity of the leftist narrative:

1. Do you have more in common with, and are you personally more comfortable in the company of, a white leftist or a black conservative?
2. Would you rather have nine white leftists or nine black conservatives on the U.S. Supreme Court?
3. Would you rather your child marry a black Christian conservative or a white non-Christian liberal?

Prager asserts that a white racist would prefer the whites in each case, but he claims that his interactions with thousands of Trump supporters have never yielded a response favoring whites over blacks or non-Christians over Christians.

Prager draws a parallel between this situation and the medieval Christian world's anti-Semitic attitudes, suggesting that the charge of "racism" against conservatives serves a similar purpose as the blood libel charge against Jews. He argues that, just as every Jew knew the blood libel was a lie, every conservative knows their responses to these questions are heartfelt and true.

Prager concludes by stating that this exercise can help conservatives come to see the left's charge of conservative racism as a lie, much like medieval Jews came to see the anti-Semites' blood libel charge as false.

It is essential to note that the opinions expressed by columnists are their own and do not necessarily represent the views of ███.com. This article aims to provide an unbiased, factual, and informative account of Dennis Prager's perspective on the ongoing debate regarding conservative values and the labeling of Trump supporters and conservatives as "racist."

Title: Trump Reverses Campaign Pledge, Says He Will Not Pursue Prosecution of Hillary Clinton

Article:

In a significant departure from his campaign rhetoric, President-elect Donald Trump has stated that he will not recommend prosecution of Hillary Clinton, his former rival in the presidential race. This decision marks a stark contrast to the chants of "lock her up" that were a common feature of Trump's rallies during the campaign.

During a meeting with reporters and editors at The New York Times, Trump expressed empathy for Clinton, stating, "She went through a lot and suffered greatly in many different ways." He further clarified, "I do not want to hurt the Clintons. I really don't."

This change in stance was first reported by New York Times reporters Mike Grynbaum and Maggie Haberman, who attended the meeting. Trump is quoted as saying, "I think I will explain it that we, in many ways, will save our country."

Trump's comments suggest that the Trump administration will not pursue further investigations related to Clinton's private email server or the Clinton Foundation. This decision was preceded by a statement from Trump's former campaign manager, Kellyanne Conway, who suggested that Trump's decision not to pursue charges sends a strong message to fellow Republicans.

At the second presidential debate in early October, Trump had threatened Clinton, stating, "If I win, I am going to instruct my attorney general to get a special prosecutor to look into your situation."

Steve Vladeck, CNN legal contributor and professor at the University of Texas School of Law, noted that it is unusual for a President-elect to take such a public position on whether to pursue an investigation. Vladeck stated, "Even though the attorney general reports to the president, the Department of Justice is meant to exercise a degree of independence from the White House entirely to avoid the perception that political considerations, rather than legal ones, are behind decisions to (or not) prosecute."

This decision has drawn criticism from both sides of the political spectrum. While some Trump supporters may view this as a broken campaign promise, Democrats have expressed concern over what they perceive as executive overreach. Senator Chris Murphy of Connecticut tweeted, "That's not how this works. In our democracy, the President does not decide who gets prosecuted and who does not."

During the election campaign, chants of "lock her up" became a recurring theme at Trump rallies, as he criticized Clinton over her use of a private email server as secretary of state and accused the Clinton Foundation of corruption and "pay to play" politics. Trump's choice for national security advisor, Michael Flynn, also led a high-profile chant at the Republican National Convention of "lock her up."

Trump repeatedly brought up the possibility of jailing Clinton during his rallies, often at raucous campaign events over the summer and into the fall. However, in interviews with the Wall Street Journal and CBS' "60 Minutes" after the election, Trump refused to commit to appointing a special prosecutor.

This development marks a significant shift in Trump's stance on Clinton, and it remains to be seen how this decision will be received by the American public.

Title: San Francisco Mayor Edwin Lee Passes Away at Age 65

Article:

San Francisco Mayor Edwin Lee, the city's first Asian-American mayor and a former civil rights attorney, passed away Tuesday at the age of 65, his office confirmed. Lee suffered a heart attack while shopping at a Safeway grocery store on Monday night, according to US House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, who represents San Francisco in Congress.

Lee was rushed to Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital in critical condition shortly after 10 p.m. on Monday and died at 1:11 a.m. Tuesday, the hospital's CEO, Dr. Susan Ehrlich, said. The cause of death has not been released.

London Breed, president of San Francisco's Board of Supervisors, has become acting mayor following Lee's death. Breed is the city's first black female chief executive.

"Our mayor was a good man with a good heart," Breed said Tuesday morning. "He believed above all else in building bridges and solving problems."

Lee was expected to conduct meetings Tuesday at City Hall, according to his official schedule. On Monday, he attended a city event promoting a recycling program and was seen smiling and shaking hands, CNN affiliate KGO reported.

Born in Seattle and the son of Chinese immigrants, Lee graduated from Bowdoin College in 1974 and earned his law degree at the University of California, Berkeley, in 1978. After becoming a civil rights attorney, he began decades of work in city government in the late 1980s, serving under four mayors.

In 2011, the Board of Supervisors appointed Lee, then the city administrator, to fill the rest of the term of Mayor Gavin Newsom, who left to become California's lieutenant governor. Lee was elected to his own term later in 2011 and re-elected in 2015 as mayor of the consolidated city-county government.

Lee unabashedly trumpeted San Francisco as a sanctuary city for undocumented immigrants and opposed President Donald Trump's executive order aimed at stripping such cities of federal funding.

Pelosi told CNN on Tuesday that Lee was a "man of the people," and that his death was heartbreaking.

"All who knew Mayor Lee understood him as a true gentleman of great warmth, positivity, and kindness," Pelosi said in an official statement. "His passing is not only a tragic official loss for our city but also a profound personal loss for all who were fortunate enough to call him friend."

Laurence M. Baer, the CEO of the San Francisco Giants, saluted Lee's service and called him the professional baseball team's top fan.

"He was a true San Franciscan who devoted his life to serving our great city and to supporting those most in need," Baer said. "He was the Giants' No. 1 fan, and we are blessed to have shared so many wonderful memories together."

Voters will elect someone to fill the rest of Lee's term on June 5, City Attorney Dennis Herrera said. The term expires on January 8, 2020. Until the vote, Breed would remain acting mayor unless the board of supervisors decides to replace her with an interim mayor, Herrera said. Breed still retains the board presidency, Herrera said. The board does not have to replace Breed as acting mayor, and the panel had no plans to address the matter on Tuesday, Herrera said.

Title: State Department Delays Release of Hillary Clinton's Full Meeting Schedules, Election-Related Criticism Arises

Article:

The State Department has announced that it will not release the entirety of Hillary Clinton's daily meeting schedules from her tenure as Secretary of State before the upcoming U.S. election. The department's lawyers have stated that all the schedules will be made public by December 30 of this year, a date that falls more than a month after the election.

This development comes after the Associated Press (AP) analyzed a portion of the released schedules, finding that most of the meetings with private individuals in their sample were with individuals who had, in some capacity, contributed to the Clinton Foundation. The AP, which initially requested the schedules in 2010 and again in 2013, and then sued the State Department to obtain them, has faced criticism from media reporters for basing their report on a relatively small data set. The AP's analysis only considered meetings with individuals outside of government, and Clinton has contested the report's findings, stating that the analysis is flawed because it does not take into account the full context of the meetings.

In an interview with CNN, Clinton said, "These are people I would be proud to meet with, as any secretary of state would have been proud to meet with, to hear about their work and their insights." Clinton further explained that whether or not these individuals were going to give money was not a factor in her decision to meet with them.

Clinton's campaign spokesman, Brian Fallon, criticized the AP for focusing on a "limited subset" of the data, suggesting that the analysis provided a skewed perspective. By the time the AP published their findings, they had only analyzed 154 of the meetings.

Jason Miller, a spokesman for the Trump campaign, released a statement on Friday, stating, "It is unacceptable that the State Department is now refusing to release her official schedule before the election in full. Voters deserve to know the truth before they cast their ballots."

According to the Clinton Foundation's official website, the charity "convenes businesses, governments, NGOs, and individuals to improve global health and wellness, increase opportunity for girls and women, reduce childhood obesity, create economic opportunity and growth, and help communities address the effects of climate change." Last week, Bill Clinton stated that, if Hillary is elected president, the foundation will stop accepting foreign or corporate donations.

Title: Treasury Department Warns of Looming Debt Ceiling Crisis as Short-term Measures Exhausted

The Treasury Department has issued a warning that the U.S. government could reach its debt ceiling in the middle of October, marking the end of short-term measures used to avoid hitting the borrowing limit. In a letter to Speaker John Boehner, Treasury Secretary Jack Lew stated that the government is running out of accounting maneuvers and urged Congress to act promptly to allow the Treasury to continue paying its bills.

Lew cautioned that it is impossible to predict the exact date when the debt ceiling will be reached, but warned that if no action is taken soon, the government could be left with approximately $50 billion in cash by mid-October. This amount would not be sufficient to cover Social Security payments, military personnel salaries, Medicare, and other programs for an extended period.

The Bipartisan Policy Center, in its analysis after the last short-term debt ceiling deal, predicted a similar scenario. Forecasting government cash flows is inherently uncertain, especially many months in advance. Unexpected changes in economic conditions or policy changes could affect the estimate. One unknown factor is whether Freddie Mac will release its $30 billion deferred tax asset, which would result in a larger-than-usual dividend payment to the U.S. Treasury by September 30. However, a $30 billion increase in federal revenues would not be enough to change the BPC's projected "X-Date" window.

John Boehner has signaled a willingness to use the debt ceiling as a bargaining chip for spending cuts, potentially in the mold of a "grand bargain" with the White House. President Obama, on the other hand, has repeatedly stated, "We are not negotiating on the debt ceiling."

In a possible indication that Republicans may not be as serious about using the debt ceiling to extract concessions from Democrats, the push to defund Obamacare is being tied to a budget resolution rather than the debt ceiling. In general, the debt ceiling is not a matter to be taken lightly - while it is not true that the government would default if it hits the debt ceiling, markets would react as if it had.

Title: Supreme Court Declines to Hear Cases on Defunding Planned Parenthood, Leaving Lower Court Rulings in Place

Article:

In a significant development, the Supreme Court has declined to consider efforts by Republican-led states to defund Planned Parenthood, allowing federal appeals court rulings that maintained the reproductive health organization's eligibility for Medicaid funds in Louisiana and Kansas. This decision marks a setback for conservative interest groups in several states that have sought to restrict funding for Planned Parenthood and abortion providers.

Three of the court's conservative justices – Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito, and Neil Gorsuch – dissented, expressing their disapproval of the court's decision. In a statement, Associate Justice Clarence Thomas questioned the court's rationale, stating, "I suspect it has something to do with the fact that some respondents in these cases are named 'Planned Parenthood.' That makes the court’s decision particularly troubling, as the question presented has nothing to do with abortion."

The court's refusal to hear the case comes amidst a series of defunding attempts in various states, with similar efforts being blocked in Arizona and Indiana and contested in Ohio and Texas. In Arkansas, a federal court has allowed the state to deny funds. The laws were passed by state legislatures opposed to Planned Parenthood's provision of abortions, although abortions are already denied federal Medicaid funds. The laws targeted the funding for other services, including contraception and cancer screenings.

The federal Medicaid Act allows patients to seek out any qualified provider, with the key word being "qualified." Louisiana and Kansas sought to block Planned Parenthood's funding based on various allegations, including disputed claims that the group sold fetal tissue and body parts for profit.

Opponents of abortion rights have expressed disappointment with the high court's inaction, but have noted that other cases are pending in lower courts that could provide the justices with another opportunity to address the issue. Catherine Glenn Foster, president of Americans United for Life, stated, "We will continue to fight to protect states from being forced to use their limited public funds to subsidize abortion businesses."

Dr. Leana Wen, president of Planned Parenthood Federation of America, hailed the court's decision to uphold the lower court rulings. "As a doctor, I have seen what’s at stake when people can not access the care they need and when politics gets in the way of people making their own health care choices," Wen said.

The Supreme Court has historically upheld abortion rights in a series of decisions dating back to 1973. Its most recent ruling struck down restrictions on abortion clinics and providers in Texas two years ago. Planned Parenthood is the nation's largest provider of abortions, with more than 2 million women using its clinics for a variety of reproductive services, including many on Medicaid. More than 70 million people – 1 in 5 Americans – are enrolled in Medicaid.

Title: New Pediatric Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome Emerges Amidst Ongoing COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

In the midst of the ongoing global coronavirus pandemic, parents are now grappling with a new health concern: a mysterious inflammatory disease that shares similarities with Kawasaki disease, particularly in its symptoms and prevalence among children. This new ailment, known as pediatric multisystem inflammatory syndrome, has been reported in various parts of the world, including the United States, United Kingdom, Spain, and other countries.

During a Senate hearing on Tuesday, Dr. Anthony Fauci, a member of the White House coronavirus task force, warned against hasty decisions to reopen schools in the fall, citing the potential risks of this new disease. He referred to "children presenting with COVID-19 who actually have a very strange inflammatory syndrome, very similar to Kawasaki syndrome."

Doctors are investigating the link between this new syndrome and the coronavirus. The symptoms of the new disease, such as prolonged fever, a rash, conjunctivitis, swelling of the palms or soles of the feet, sometimes peeling of the skin in those areas, and lymph node enlargement, are similar to those of Kawasaki disease. However, the age range for this new disease extends into adolescence, unlike Kawasaki disease, which typically affects children under 5 years old.

New York Governor Andrew Cuomo reported that the state is investigating about 100 possible cases of the new disease, with at least three reported deaths. New York-based pediatricians have seen about 40 cases since mid-April, with the majority showing antibodies similar to the coronavirus, indicating previous infection, but no symptoms of COVID-19.

Though a causal connection between the virus and the new illness has yet to be proven, Dr. Charles Schleien, chair of pediatrics at Northwell Health in New York, stated, "The relationship seems pretty strong." He added, "We never see these many kids with Kawasaki. Usually we ’ ll see a few kids a year. We won ’ t see three dozen over a period of a few weeks. So, given the numbers and given the fact it ’ s not acting exactly like Kawasaki, it looks like it ’ s probably a post-COVID-19 infection inflammatory disease."

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is studying the rare disease and does not have statistics about its incidence. The CDC plans to send out an alert in the next couple of days, advising doctors to be on the lookout for the syndrome.

Researchers are working to understand the link between the virus and the new syndrome. Dr. Yvonne Maldonado, a professor of pediatric infectious diseases at Stanford University, hosted a webinar on Friday to discuss the case of the first reported case of the new disease in a 6-month-old baby in the United States. Maldonado and other researchers are investigating whether the virus precipitates the syndrome.

Parents are advised to seek medical attention if their children exhibit symptoms such as a prolonged fever, rash, conjunctivitis, swelling of the palms or soles of the feet, peeling skin, and lymph node enlargement. The good news is that, like Kawasaki disease, the new syndrome is treatable with intravenous immunoglobulin and sometimes steroids, followed by aspirin. Hospital stays for patients may last two to four days.

As more data emerge, researchers hope to better understand the new syndrome, its prevalence, and risk factors. The CDC is working with domestic and international partners to develop a case definition that will allow them to keep track of the syndrome.

In conclusion, the emergence of this new pediatric multisystem inflammatory syndrome adds another layer of complexity to the ongoing global health crisis. While the link between the syndrome and the coronavirus is still under investigation, parents are advised to remain vigilant and seek medical attention if their children exhibit symptoms. The good news is that, like Kawasaki disease, the new syndrome is treatable, and with proper medical care, most children are expected to recover.

Title: Senate Silences Elizabeth Warren During Debate on Jeff Sessions' Nomination, Incident Sparks National Outcry

Article:

In a dramatic turn of events, the United States Senate, led by a majority of Republicans, silenced Senator Elizabeth Warren during a debate on the nomination of Jeff Sessions as Attorney General. The incident, which occurred on Tuesday, has sparked a national outcry and elevated Warren into a Democratic hero.

The controversy began when Warren read a letter written by Coretta Scott King, the widow of Martin Luther King Jr., opposing Sessions' nomination for a federal judgeship in 1986. The letter was read during a debate on Sessions' nomination as Attorney General, a position he now holds under President Donald Trump.

Warren, a Massachusetts Democrat, quoted from King's letter, stating, "Mr. Sessions has used the awesome power of his office to chill the free exercise of the vote by black citizens in the district he now seeks to serve as a federal judge."

Republicans argued that Warren violated Senate rules against impugning another senator. A vote along party lines upheld the decision, turning what could have been an ordinary partisan floor speech into a national story.

In response, Warren told CNN's Don Lemon, "They can shut me up, but they can't change the truth." The incident immediately galvanized the Democratic base, providing a new rallying point following the women's marches around the country.

The apparent hypocrisy of the incident was further fueled by the fact that Warren's male colleagues were able to read from the letter uninterrupted. Senators Tom Udall of New Mexico and Jeff Merkley were allowed to read from King's letter, though they couched their remarks as only reading portions of the letter and with the context to be in line with Senate rules.

As a result of the incident, Warren is forbidden from participating in the floor debate over Sessions' nomination ahead of a confirmation vote expected Wednesday. "I literally can't be recognized on the floor of the Senate," Warren told Lemon. "I have become a nonperson during the discussion of Jeff Sessions."

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell defended invoking Rule 19, a rarely used chamber regulation that prohibits senators from impugning each other. "She was warned. She was given an explanation. Nevertheless, she persisted," McConnell said on the Senate floor, delivering an instantly classic line.

The incident comes at a crucial time for Warren, who is up for re-election in 2018. On Tuesday, she announced she hired an aide who is an expert on national security, a move that could help burnish her expertise in that area, as well as the publication of a new book, which will become available in April.

Liberals had been frustrated with Warren's vote in committee in favor of Ben Carson, Trump's nominee for secretary of Housing and Urban Development. By Tuesday night, the hashtag #LetLizSpeak was trending on Twitter, and millions of people had watched on Facebook as Warren read the letter outside the Senate chamber.

MoveOn members contributed $250,000 to Warren's re-election campaign in about 12 hours. "I will not be silent about a nominee for AG who has made derogatory & racist comments that have no place in our justice system," Warren wrote on Twitter. "I will not be silent while the Republicans rubber stamp an AG who will never stand up to the @POTUS when he breaks the law."

The incident has become a rallying cry for fellow Democrats. California Sen. Kamala Harris took to the Senate floor to call the vote to silence Warren "outrageous." "I never ever saw a time when a member of the Senate asked to put into the record a letter -- especially by a civil rights icon -- and somebody objected," said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vermont.

The Senate descended into a series of complaints about declining decorum on both sides. "We have to treat each other with respect or this place is going to devolve into a jungle," said seven-term Utah Republican Sen. Orrin Hatch.

As the incident continues to unfold, Democrats are bringing out examples of Republicans who have crossed similar lines and not been shut up the way Warren was forbidden from participating. The Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer's office highlighted Texas Sen. Ted Cruz's accusation that McConnell had told a "flat-out lie" about the future of the Export-Import Bank in 2015. Warren sat on the Senate floor, though, silently, having already had her moment.

Title: Henry Kissinger Expresses Optimism for Trump's Foreign Policy Potential

Article:

In a recent interview on "Face the Nation," former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger, who served under Presidents Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford, expressed optimism about President-elect Donald Trump's potential influence on the international community. Kissinger, who is known for his extensive experience in foreign affairs, acknowledged that Trump's unexpected victory has surprised many, but he believes the president-elect could present an "extraordinary opportunity" for the nation and its foreign relations.

Kissinger stated, "Donald Trump is a phenomenon that foreign countries have not seen. So it is a shocking experience for them that he came into office. At the same time, extraordinary opportunity. I believe he has the possibility of going down in history as a very considerable president."

Despite concerns from many seasoned politicians and experts about Trump's brazen rhetoric and lack of political experience, Kissinger remains optimistic about Trump's potential influence. He hopes the president-elect can harness the same appeal he used to start his own political revolution to shape a foreign policy plan.

Kissinger explained, "In the first appearances, I thought it was a transitory phenomenon. But I give him huge credit for having analyzed an aspect of the American situation, developed a strategy, carried it out against the leadership of his own party, and prevailed."

As the world grapples with Trump as the new leader, Kissinger believes other nations will have to reassess their relationships with the United States. He stated, "One, their perception that the previous president, or the outgoing president, basically withdrew America from international politics, so that they had to make their own assessments of their necessities. And secondly, that here is a new president who's asking a lot of unfamiliar questions. And because of the combination of the partial vacuum and the new questions, one could imagine that something remarkable and new emerges out of it."

Kissinger also expressed hope that Trump will shift his tone somewhat as he enters the Oval Office, especially when it comes to complicated and dense issues like the relationship between the US and China, which he believes has an opportunity to be mutually beneficial if properly maintained. However, he acknowledged that this might depend on Trump becoming less of an instinctive actor.

"I think he operates by a kind of instinct that is a different form of analysis as my more academic one," Kissinger said. "But he's raised a number of issues that I think are important, very important. And if they're addressed properly, could lead to good—great results."

Title: RNC Chairman Threatens Non-Supportive Republicans, Including John Kasich, with Potential Party Roadblocks

Article:

In an interview on CBS's "Face the Nation," Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus has threatened Ohio Governor John Kasich and other Republicans who have refused to support the party's presidential nominee, Donald Trump. According to Priebus, the party may take steps to ensure it is not "that easy" for non-supporters to seek the White House in the future.

Speaking on the matter, Priebus stated that every Republican who ran in 2016 needs to get behind Trump. Those who have not, including Kasich, former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, and Texas Senator Ted Cruz, could see diminished support from the party moving forward.

"People who agreed to support the nominee, that took part in our process, they used tools from the RNC. They agreed to support the nominee. They took part in our process. We're a private party, we're not a public entity. Those people need to get on board," said Priebus.

He further added, "And if they're thinking they're going to run again someday, I think we're going to evaluate our process, the nomination process, and I don't think it's going to be that easy for them."

Governor Kasich stated it is "very unlikely" he will vote for Trump, citing "too much water under the bridge." In an interview with CNN that aired Friday, Kasich expressed similar sentiments as Bush and Cruz, who withheld an endorsement of Trump during the Republican National Convention and instead told Republicans to "vote their conscience" in November.

Priebus denied that he was threatening Kasich, Cruz, or anyone else, yet he clearly suggested the party would put roadblocks in front of the electoral hopes of anyone who hasn't offered a full-throated endorsement of Trump.

"People in our party are talking about what we're going to do about this... It's not a threat. It's just a question," the RNC chairman said. "What should a private party do about that if those same people come around in four or eight years?"

Kasich, a former 2016 GOP presidential candidate himself, emphasized the importance of getting out the vote for Republicans like Senator Rob Portman, who is running for re-election in Ohio.

"We want to get people out to vote. We want to re-elect Senator Portman, and we want to re-elect people down ticket," said Kasich. "I'm not voting for Hillary [Clinton]."

Kasich was in Cleveland during the Republican National Convention in July but did not attend the convention itself. When asked about Libertarian nominee Gary Johnson, Kasich stated, "I haven't even gone there yet. It's a long way [until] Election Day."

Title: Trump Accuses Comey of Lying, Alleges Perjury in Tweet Amidst Ongoing Investigation

Article:

In a series of tweets on Friday morning, President Donald Trump claimed "total and complete vindication" while seemingly accusing former FBI Director James Comey of lying under oath and leaking information. The tweet, which raised eyebrows in the White House, is just one part of the counteroffensive against Comey, who testified before the Senate Intelligence Committee the previous day.

Trump's tweet, which followed a bellicose statement from his lawyer, Marc Kasowitz, on Thursday, accused Comey of lying under oath and inappropriately disclosing the contents of his conversations with Trump. The accusation, essentially alleging that Comey committed perjury in his congressional testimony, is just the latest broadside Trump has launched against his former FBI director.

The president's tweet also hinted at a forthcoming complaint to the Department of Justice inspector general about the so-called leak, in which Comey handed off memos describing his conversations with Trump to a friend who in turn passed them onto The New York Times.

Trump's team has been quick to push back against Comey's testimony, with a main thrust of their strategy being to discredit Comey, painting him as disgruntled and untrustworthy. The process began with an RNC-coordinated counter-messaging effort, and was followed by Kasowitz's prepared statement at the National Press Club, near the White House.

While Trump and Kasowitz have directly refuted the substance of Comey's accounts, many of Trump's fellow Republicans sought to frame it as a misinterpretation by Comey rather than a total fabrication. House Speaker Paul Ryan said on Thursday that the president "is new at this. He's new at government."

Trump's allies are also eager to shift the conversation to Comey's conduct. Former Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski made the president's case in three separate appearances on ABC, NBC, and Fox News, emphasizing Comey's statement that Trump had never been under investigation while at the same time calling into question the FBI director's credibility to dispute other portions of his testimony.

The president is also expected to address the controversy further when he holds a joint news conference with the president of Romania on Friday afternoon in the Rose Garden.

Title: ISIS Takes Control of Ramadi: A Setback in Iraq's Anti-ISIS Campaign

Article:

In a significant turn of events, ISIS forces have taken control of the Iraqi city of Ramadi, the capital of Anbar province, marking the biggest victory for the militant group in Iraq in nearly a year. The fall of Ramadi, which has been under siege by ISIS for some time, highlights the fundamental weakness of the Iraqi military and its reliance on radical Shia militias.

The battle for Ramadi, a predominantly Sunni city, has been a long and arduous one. ISIS has shown an unusual level of success in Anbar province, thwarting Iraqi army attacks and even pushing forward in some instances, despite setbacks in other parts of the country. The recent shift in the balance of power in Anbar, as evidenced by the fall of Ramadi, is a testament to ISIS's resilience.

The Iraqi army's contingent in Ramadi has been under-resourced for over a year. As reported by Liz Sly, the Washington Post's Beirut bureau chief, Iraqi troops had held out for 16 months, with little help, before succumbing to the ISIS onslaught. The Iraqi army's core problem lies in its profound weakness due to corruption and mass defections during last June's ISIS offensive. With the Iraqi army lacking enough effective, battle-hardened units, it is forced to rely on allies, such as the Kurdish peshmerga in the north and violent sectarian Shia militias in the rest of the country.

The reliance on these allies, however, has its challenges. The militias, while effective on the battlefield, are also politically divided. Some of the most influential Shia militias have political wings that are political rivals of Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi's Dawa party. These factions were not present in Ramadi when it fell, as Abadi wanted the army to beat ISIS without the use of Shia militias, and the United States was concerned about the militias' track record of brutalizing Sunni civilians.

Now, Anbar's Sunni-dominated provincial council has formally requested militia assistance, which is on its way. Michael Knights, the Lafer fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, states, "More forces, including local forces, is the only solution" in Ramadi. The militias, according to Knights, are "the only speedy mechanism left."

Despite the setback in Ramadi, the fundamentals of the conflict remain unchanged. ISIS is still likely to lose its territory in Iraq. The militant group remains outnumbered, surrounded by enemies, vulnerable to American airstrikes, and facing increasingly competent enemies. However, the anti-ISIS campaign will not be easy, nor will it be short. ISIS has a remarkably effective combat force given its size and resources. The Iraqi army is more competent than it was during its disastrous performance early in the conflict, but it still has a long way to go.

The deep political divides between the Iraqi army forces and the militia leadership are not going away, and could lead to a different sort of conflict after ISIS. The fighting will continue to devastate Iraq and potentially deepen the Sunni-Shia divides that gave rise to ISIS in the first place. Even with ISIS's fundamental weakness, Iraq remains in a very bad place.

Title: Private Prison Companies See Surge in Business Amidst Expansion of U.S. Immigration Detention Centers

Article:

The Trump administration's plan to double the capacity of America's immigrant detention centers has sparked controversy, with the potential for further expansion if the administration intends to carry out its promise of deporting millions of undocumented residents. This development has ignited a wave of national outrage among many, but there is at least one group that appears to be celebrating this new era of xenophobia: private prison companies.

As of November, a staggering 65 percent of ICE detainees were housed in facilities run by private prison companies, whose business model revolves around earning a fee per detainee per night and minimizing costs to maximize profits for their shareholders. Since President Trump's election, private prison stocks have experienced a significant increase, and two new, for-profit detention centers are set to open in Georgia and Texas. Furthermore, private prison company Management & Training Corp. is reportedly seeking a contract with ICE to reopen the Willacy County Correctional Institution, a troubled detention camp that once held up to 2,000 ICE detainees in Kevlar tents between 2006 and 2011.

"Historically, ICE has relied heavily on the private prison industry every time the detention system has expanded," says activist George Takei. "There's little doubt in my mind that they will continue to rely on the private prison industry in what's going to be the biggest expansion of the agency in history."

The private prison industry's growth is fueled by the potential profits to be made in building and operating detention centers. While the individuals being rounded up may be guilty of minor offenses such as overstaying visas, they may find themselves in private detention facilities that have been terminated by other federal agencies due to patterns of abuse and neglect.

This expansion of the detention system is likely to result in larger detention centers, as the administration moves aggressively to fulfill its campaign promise of deporting millions. The increased capacity will undoubtedly provide a significant boost to the private prison industry's bottom line.

Title: Scalia Criticizes Obama's Immigration Policies, Questions Framers' Response

Article:

In a strongly worded dissent, Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia questioned Monday whether the Framers of the Constitution would have reacted negatively to President Barack Obama's recent immigration policies.

Speaking in dissent of most of the court's rulings on Arizona's immigration law, Scalia took a clear swipe at the Obama administration's new policy ending deportations for many young adults brought into the country illegally, which was not part of the Arizona case.

"The president has said that the new program is 'the right thing to do' in light of Congress's failure to pass the administration's proposed revision of the immigration laws," Scalia said. "Perhaps it is, though Arizona might not think so."

Scalia suggested that the Framers would have left Independence Hall if presented with the idea behind Obama's policy shift. He questioned whether states would have entered into the union had the Constitution included a clause enacting immigration laws but stipulating that the president had a choice on whether to enforce them.

"The husbanding of scarce enforcement resources can hardly be the justification for this," he said of the new Department of Homeland Security directives, "since those resources will be eaten up by the considerable administrative cost of conducting the non-enforcement program, which will require as many as 1.4 million background checks and biennial rulings on requests for dispensation."

The court upheld a key piece of Arizona's law—requiring police to check the immigration status of those they arrest or stop for questioning—but struck down other pieces of the law, arguing the state had stepped into the bounds of federal law.

"To say, as the Court does, that Arizona contradicts federal law by enforcing immigration law that the president declines to enforce boggles the mind," Scalia said.

The problem that Arizona faces, Scalia said, is not that scarce resources are being put toward enforcing immigration laws elsewhere and not in that border state, but the Obama administration's policies.

Title: GOP Faces Tough Choices as Government Funding and Debt Ceiling Deadlines Loom

Article:

As the month of September approaches, Republican lawmakers are bracing for a challenging few weeks, with the possibility of being asked to vote on two contentious issues: a continuing resolution to keep the government open and a bill to raise the debt ceiling.

The continuing resolution, which would maintain current spending levels, is likely to be tied to the debt ceiling increase, a measure that is unpopular among congressional conservatives. The deadline for preventing a government shutdown is September 30, while Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has set a September 29 deadline for raising the nation's borrowing limit.

Mnuchin has stated that the debt ceiling hike should be "clean," meaning it should not be tied to spending cuts or reforms demanded by conservatives. To get the bill through the Senate, Republicans will need support from Democrats, giving the minority leverage.

Republicans are traditionally opposed to funding the government through a continuing resolution because it blocks or delays their priorities, such as funds for President Trump's border wall, significant increases in military spending, and cuts to non-defense discretionary spending.

"We'd be against a continuing resolution because that wouldn't allow us to fund those priorities," said White House budget director Mick Mulvaney in June.

Republicans could avoid the continuing resolution by reaching a deal on a broader spending bill, but this would also require Democratic support in the Senate, and time is running out. So far, the House has only managed to approve four spending bills, while the Senate has not approved any, and most have not even made it out of committee.

This means a continuing resolution is a more likely outcome and one that would buy time for a longer budget deal at the end of the year. Several prominent conservative leaders, such as Rep. Mark Meadows, the chairman of the House Freedom Caucus, have already expressed their resignation to a continuing resolution.

Congress will still be under pressure this fall to secure a spending deal, even with a continuing resolution. New budget caps under a previous long-term budget deal are set to kick in in January, which would reduce spending below existing levels unless Congress passes a new law.

Raising the borrowing limit is a difficult vote for most members of Congress, but particularly for Republicans. A Harvard–Harris Poll in June found that an astonishing 69 percent of voters were opposed to Congress raising the debt ceiling, even though the failure to do so could lead the United States to default on its debt.

Under former President Barack Obama, conservatives tried to use the must-pass legislation to get spending reforms or other Republican priorities made into law. With Trump in the White House and Republicans controlling both the House and Senate, however, the dynamics have shifted. Democrats may try to turn the tables and extract concessions from Republicans, who will need Democratic support to pass the debt ceiling.

"To ensure that we have robust economic growth and promote fiscal discipline, the Trump administration believes it's important to raise the debt ceiling as soon as possible," said White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders on Tuesday.

Even so, some Republicans are still pushing for some sort of policy reform to hitch to the debt ceiling. "I've been raising the issue of the debt ceiling for months now, and certainly what I'd like to see is some meaningful, structural control enacted in conjunction with increasing," said Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.).

The difficult decisions come as Republicans grapple with a narrative that they are unable to govern. In the first six months of the Trump administration, they have yet to finalize a major piece of legislation, including the healthcare bill that failed in the Senate last week. Come autumn, the GOP will likely have to choose between allowing the government to shut down and default on its debt and making politically difficult, unpopular decisions.

Title: California's Largest Preventive Blackout Affects Over 800,000 Residents Amid Wildfire Danger

Article:

In a bid to prevent wildfires, Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E) initiated a massive power shutdown affecting over 800,000 customers in Northern, Central, and coastal California counties on Wednesday. The utility company had already cut power to more than 500,000 customers earlier in the day, with plans to gradually turn off electricity to nearly a million customers.

PG&E's decision comes in response to a forecast of hot, dry, and gusty weather, with winds of up to 72kph (45 mph) sweeping across the state. The utility aims to reduce the risk of trees falling onto power lines during these conditions, particularly in areas prone to wildfires.

The utility's Community Wildfire Safety Program head, Sumeet Singh, described the move as a "last resort." However, California Governor Gavin Newsom expressed dissatisfaction, stating, "No one is satisfied with this, no one is happy with this." He emphasized the need for PG&E to upgrade and fix its equipment to prevent such widespread outages in the future.

Restoration of power could take up to five days, as each power line must be inspected to ensure it is not damaged or poses a fire risk. The outages are not limited to fire-prone areas, as the utilities must turn off entire distribution and transmission lines to wider areas to minimize the risk of wildfires.

The outages have disrupted normal life, with schools cancelling classes, and universities such as the University of California, Berkeley, Sonoma State University, and Mills College closing. The California Department of Transportation is installing generators to avoid closing the Caldecott Tunnel and the Tom Lantos Tunnel.

The outages come as residents in the region's wine country north of San Francisco mark the two-year anniversary of deadly wildfires that killed 44 and destroyed thousands of homes. To the south, Southern California Edison may cut power to over 106,000 customers in parts of eight counties as early as Thursday due to Santa Ana winds.

The outages are a result of a plan instituted after deadly wildfires, some blamed on PG&E transmission lines, destroyed lives and homes in recent years and forced the utility into bankruptcy over an estimated $30bn in potential damages from lawsuits.

Authorities have urged residents to be prepared, with supplies of water, sensitive medicines, full petrol tanks, and checked food in freezers and refrigerators after power is restored. PG&E has set up community centers offering air conditioning, restrooms, bottled water, and electronic charging stations during daylight hours.

Mayors of affected cities have expressed mixed reactions, with some appreciating the proactive approach, while others, like Melanie Bagby, Mayor of Cloverdale, find the situation inexcusable. The situation has highlighted the need for reliable power and the potential consequences of relying on a monopoly utility.

Title: The Unprecedented Re-election of President Obama: A Reflection on Self-Reliance, Dependency, and the Expansion of Government

Article:

In the political landscape of the United States, it is a remarkable occurrence that a president who has overseen a significant increase in government spending, a rise in entitlement programs, and a controversial foreign policy can be re-elected. This is the reality that America now faces with the re-election of President Barack Obama.

The re-election of President Obama is a testament to the truism observed by Thomas Jefferson and Alexander Hamilton, who, despite their political differences, shared a common understanding of the public's response to the perceived role of the government as a public trough. As the voters recognize the government as a source of cash handouts, they tend to elect individuals who promise to distribute more funds, thereby fostering dependency. This attitude, though present in some localities during the colonial era, was amplified at the federal level by presidents such as Woodrow Wilson, Theodore Roosevelt, FDR, LBJ, and has been a consistent feature of modern-day Democrats and contemporary Republicans.

Mitt Romney, a Republican, is one of those who can be classified as a proponent of federal entitlements. He promised to maintain the status quo, with entitlement costs to taxpayers amounting to approximately $1.7 trillion annually. Under President Obama, these costs have increased, as have the number of recipients. Half of the country is aware of this reality, and has chosen to re-elect Obama to continue sending federal funds to the other half.

President Obama's tenure has been marked by a centralized approach to the economy and federal regulation of private behavior. His handling of the Libya incident, in which American government employees were killed, has been criticized, and he has shown a reluctance to admit error. His interpretation of the Constitution is flexible, treating it as a guideline rather than a set of principles intended to protect personal liberty and a diffusion of power. He rejects the fundamental American value that our rights come from our Creator, not the government, leading to an expansive view of the federal government's role in regulating behavior and taxing events.

The practical implications of Obama's second term are daunting. ObamaCare is now a permanent fixture, with federal bureaucrats directing medical treatment and access to medical records. The national debt is projected to reach $20 trillion, with an estimated $1 trillion in annual interest payments if the Republican-controlled House of Representatives continues to cooperate. Taxes are set to increase on January 1, 2013, as the Bush-era tax cuts expire. The vision of a populace dependent on a central government and a European-style welfare state is now a reality.

Though the election was perceived as a choice between big government and bigger government, with the focus on the extent of private wealth to be seized and redistributed and the degree of private behavior to be regulated, rather than the constitutionality of such actions, the re-election of Obama is unsettling. The fear is that, freed from the need to cater to the electorate, Obama may become the authoritarian figure who will curtail personal freedoms.

Title: Wisconsin's Political Dichotomy: A Microcosm of American Polarization

Article:

Madison, Wis. — Wisconsin, a state known for its picturesque landscapes and progressive history, has long been a political enigma, defying traditional political trends and exhibiting a unique political personality. This dichotomy, as Rutgers University political science professor Ross Baker observes, is a testament to the state's ability to surprise politically, not just occasionally, but consistently.

The state's political history is a fascinating tapestry, weaving together the threads of iconic figures such as Robert "Fighting Bob" La Follette, a populist senator and Progressive Party presidential candidate in 1924, and Joseph McCarthy, the hard-line conservative senator who led the Communist witch-hunts of the 1950s. This broad political disparity is not limited to the past; it extends to the present day, with conservative Republican Ron Johnson and liberal Democrat Tammy Baldwin representing the widest ideological gulf of any state's senators, according to a 2013 National Journal ranking of voting records.

The current political landscape of Wisconsin is a testament to the state's ability to elect politicians from opposite ends of the political spectrum. Baldwin, the Senate's first openly gay member, is listed as the 5th most liberal, while Johnson, the 9th most conservative. This political schism is further underscored by the fact that the state has a history of electing liberal politicians such as William Proxmire, an early anti-Vietnam war opponent, and Democrat Russ Feingold, the champion of campaign finance changes, only to see them replaced by conservatives like Johnson.

The state's political climate, according to Michael Wagner, a political science and journalism professor at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, appears "schizophrenic" both to outsiders and insiders. Wagner attributes this to the long-standing political polarization that has become more pronounced in the last decade. He notes that the state's voters are sharply divided, and a small swing vote can determine whether a conservative Republican or liberal Democrat wins.

Wisconsin's political landscape is also unique in its demographic homogeneity, with whites accounting for 88% of the population. This narrow electorate, when combined with the state's political polarization, means that a small minority vote—or its absence—can swing an election.

Political scientist Wagner notes that both sides have become adept at winning elections. However, the cost of this political acumen is a lack of consensus politics that serve the greater good. Compromise, he says, is no longer possible due to such polarization. This bitter divide means that politicians elected to statewide office represent the interests of those who got them there, often at the expense of the greater good of the state.

This political divide in Wisconsin offers a chilling insight into the current political climate in Washington, D.C., where compromise is a dirty word, and winning is the only objective. As the 2024 presidential race heats up, with native son Gov. Scott Walker casting himself as Ronald Reagan's heir, understanding Wisconsin's political history and its implications for the nation's capital is more important than ever.

Title: The Lack of Political Guardrails: A Reflection on the Current Political Climate

Article:

In today's political landscape, the concept of "political guardrails" has taken on a new meaning, as many politicians seem to be operating without any constraints or safeguards, according to Kimberley Strassel of The Wall Street Journal.

Strassel's article highlights the tendency of some politicians, such as former President Barack Obama and potential presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, to bypass Congress and implement policies unilaterally when faced with opposition. For instance, Obama altered the Affordable Care Act without congressional approval, while Clinton has promised to impose gun control laws and new taxes on corporations if Congress does not support her proposals.

This trend is not limited to one party, as Donald Trump, another potential presidential candidate, has also made headlines for his controversial statements and promises, such as his proposal for a Muslim travel ban and his assertion that he will make Mexico pay for a border wall.

The public's response to these bold, often unconstitutional, moves seems to be positive, with many people appearing to favor a strong, decisive leader who will take control and make changes. However, this desire for a "big, strong" leader overlooks the importance of constitutional restraints and the role of the president as a presider, not a controller, of the country.

The Constitution was designed to limit political authority, allowing individual Americans to manage their own lives and fostering a free and prosperous nation. Today, both major parties seem to be off the rails, with some advocates demanding the use of the IRS against political rivals and others quietly undermining government reform efforts, such as the reauthorization of the Export-Import Bank.

This lack of political guardrails not only distracts from the smaller, routine violations of constitutional rules but also threatens the very foundation of our democratic system. It is crucial for citizens to demand accountability and adherence to the Constitution, ensuring that our leaders act within the bounds of their authority and uphold the principles of limited government and individual freedom.

Title: US Political Climate Deteriorates Ahead of 2013 Elections as Gridlock and Approval Ratings Plummet

Article:

The political landscape in the United States is facing a significant downturn as the nation heads into the 2013 elections on Tuesday. According to the George Washington University Battleground Poll, a national survey of 1,011 registered likely voters, Washington's gridlock is the nation's most pressing problem, and approval ratings for Congress and President Obama are both on a decline.

The poll, conducted jointly by Republican pollster Ed Goeas of the Tarrance Group and Democratic pollster Celinda Lake, paints a grim picture of the current political environment. Goeas, a Republican campaign consulting firm strategist, states, "It is the worst political environment we have seen in a long time." He notes that the Battleground survey found that 73 percent of voters believe the country is on the wrong track.

The survey reveals that the No. 1 problem in the country is the dysfunction in Washington, according to the voters. This issue is rated higher now than jobs and the economy combined. Some 26 percent of voters cited government gridlock as the most important problem versus 18 percent for the second-most-cited top problem – government spending and the budget deficit.

When voters are asked to rate the job Congress is doing, 87 percent say they disapprove versus just 9 percent who approve. "The thing that I think is most interesting is that people blame their own Congress person," Lake says. In the Battleground survey conducted Oct. 27-31, 50 percent of those polled disapproved of how their own member of Congress was doing versus 39 percent who approved and 11 percent who were unsure.

Republicans in Congress had worse ratings than Democrats, the survey found. Some 65 percent of those polled had an unfavorable view of Republicans in Congress, while Democrats were viewed unfavorably by 53 percent. The government shutdown last month clearly played a role in these numbers, both strategists said.

"What I don't know is how much of this data is driven by the shutdown or offset by what has happened in the last three weeks," Goeas said, referring to the trouble-prone launch of the Affordable Care Act website and complaints that consumers are having health insurance policies canceled as a result of Obamacare coverage requirements.

In the poll taken almost a month after a government shutdown largely driven by the demands of tea party activists, only 54 percent of those polled said they had an unfavorable impression of the tea party – 11 points lower than the disapproval level for Republicans and a statistical dead heat with Democrats.

While Republicans in Congress have reason to be concerned about their standing, this latest poll also contains bad news for President Obama. The president's approval rating now stands at 44 percent, with 52 percent disapproving. Obama's personal ratings are also down, with 47 percent of those surveyed saying they had a favorable view of him and 50 percent holding unfavorable views.

This is the first time in the Battleground survey that Obama has had both a majority unfavorable image and majority disapproval of his job performance, Goeas says. "The key question... is has Barack Obama lost the ability to lead in this country," he adds. Goeas further notes that, "In a second term of the White House, once a president's numbers decline, they never come back up... More importantly, what we see is that once a president loses the trust of the American people in the second term, they never gain it back. And I think what is going on with health care right now has the potential of Barack Obama losing the trust of the American people."

Title: White House, Congress Grapple with Corporate Tax Rate in Ongoing Tax Reform Negotiations

Article:

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - President Donald Trump's recent comments about a potential increase in the corporate tax rate for the upcoming tax reform bill have sparked debate within the U.S. Congress, with a White House aide attempting to downplay the president's remarks on Thursday.

The U.S. Capitol Building is seen from the Congressional Visitors Center in Washington, D.C., on December 6, 2017. (Photo by Aaron P. Bernstein)

Two rival tax bills, passed separately by the Senate and the House of Representatives, propose reducing the U.S. corporate tax rate to 20 percent. However, they differ in other areas that Republicans are trying to merge into final legislation.

Speaking to reporters after the Senate approved its tax bill on Saturday, Trump said the corporate tax rate in the final legislation, expected soon from lawmakers, "could be 22 percent... it could also be 20 percent."

This comment has piqued the interest of some Republicans who see a slight increase in the proposed corporate tax rate as a potential source of federal revenue to address other issues with the legislation, according to lobbyists.

"The 20 percent rate ought to be our goal," said House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady, who is expected to head a bicameral House-Senate negotiating committee. "My view is the president is giving us flexibility in that area if it's needed. No decision's been made on if that's needed," the Texas Republican told reporters.

However, White House legislative affairs director Marc Short told Reuters on Thursday that Trump was not expressing support for a higher proposed corporate rate. Instead, he may have been reflecting views conveyed to him by Republican senators.

"I think he was just reflecting what conversations he had heard from them, but that... wasn't intended to signal: this is an endorsement of raising the corporate rate," Short said.

"We believe that 20 percent is the right number... 20 percent is about as high as we feel comfortable going," he said in an interview.
