Trump and his Republican allies have a lot at stake in the outcome of the tax reform bill. A sweeping U.S. tax overhaul, which has not been achieved since 1986, would give Republicans their first major legislative victory of 2017, after their failure to overturn former President Barack Obama's healthcare law. Without a win, Republicans fear they could lose their control of the House and Senate in the 2018 congressional elections.

However, it may be too late to avoid confusion over priorities as the tax debate moves forward in Congress. Lobbyists said many perceive that Trump and his advisers would accept a corporate rate higher than 20 percent.

White House economic adviser Kevin Hassett said on Thursday that a 22 percent corporate rate would not undermine the economic boost that Republicans say tax cuts will create.

Analysts say the corporate income tax rate could be a ready source of revenue for lawmakers, as they move toward a final bill that can lose no more than $1.5 trillion in revenue over the next decade under Senate rules.

Republicans are considering a more costly deduction for state and local taxes than the $10,000 property tax deduction contained in the House and Senate bills. One version would allow taxpayers to choose a $10,000 deduction for either property or income taxes.

House lawmakers also want to adopt the House bill's repeal of the corporate alternative minimum tax, which would cost about $40 billion in revenue over a decade, according to the Joint Committee on Taxation. Senate retained the tax.

A House limit on the amount of debt interest payments that businesses can deduct from their income would also cost about $136 billion more than the Senate version, the JCT said.

Analysts say a one percentage point change in the corporate rate equals about $100 billion in revenues over a decade.

Title: President Trump Vows Immediate Negotiations on Border Security Measures Following Government Shutdown

Article:

In the aftermath of the recently concluded partial government shutdown, President Donald Trump has announced that negotiations with congressional Democrats over border security measures will commence immediately. The President, in a series of tweets on Saturday, expressed caution about the difficulty of reaching a compromise within the next three weeks.

Trump signed a bill on Friday evening to fund the government until February 15, marking the end of the longest shutdown in U.S. history. The bill did not allocate funds for the President's long-standing campaign promise of a wall along the southern border. However, Trump has indicated his intention to secure the necessary funds in upcoming talks with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.).

The President seems to be using a new caravan of Central American migrants approaching the U.S.-Mexico border as a justification for his proposed wall. In a tweet, he stated, "If we had a powerful Wall, they wouldn’t even try to make the long and dangerous journey. Build the Wall and Crime will Fall!"

Prior to 10 a.m. ET on Saturday, the President tweeted seven times, discussing border security five times, Roger Stone's indictment for lying to Congress, and the RNC's pledge of support for the President in 2020.

Later in the day, the President tweeted, "Only fools, or people with a political agenda, don’t want a Wall or Steel Barrier to protect our Country from Crime, Drugs and Human Trafficking. It will happen - it always does!"

In a tweet late on Friday, the President had stated, "I wish people would read or listen to my words on the Border Wall. This was in no way a concession. It was taking care of millions of people who were getting badly hurt by the Shutdown with the understanding that in 21 days, if no deal is done, it’s off to the races!"

Title: Jared Kushner Takes Center Stage in White House Coronavirus Response, Draws Criticism for Lack of Public Health Expertise

Article:

In a rare public appearance, Jared Kushner, President Trump's son-in-law and senior adviser, criticized governors on Thursday, stating they lack control over their own supplies of masks and ventilators needed to combat the coronavirus outbreak. During a briefing at the White House, Kushner urged governors and some senators to be more self-reliant and resourceful in their own states rather than relying on the federal government for assistance.

Kushner, a real estate executive with no public health expertise, has emerged as a central figure in the administration's efforts to address the coronavirus pandemic. He has been working with the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to oversee the distribution of critical medical supplies to hospitals and healthcare providers.

Kushner's lack of experience has drawn scrutiny, particularly when he referred to the national stockpile of medical supplies as "our stockpile." In response to this, Kansas Gov. Laura Kelly, a Democrat, told NPR's Here & Now, "That is absolutely not the way it is supposed to work." Kelly stated that the national stockpile was intended to serve as a backup for states, and the Trump administration should have done more to fill it.

A day after Kushner's remarks, language on a government website about the national stockpile was updated to reflect his description. However, a spokesperson for the Department of Health and Human Services stated that the department had been using the new language for weeks. The assistant secretary for preparedness and response explained that efforts were made to update the website text a week ago to more clearly explain the role of the Strategic National Stockpile to state and local agencies and the public.

When asked about his son-in-law's remarks on Friday, Trump said Kushner was "talking about our country." He added, "We need it for the government and the federal government, not just the states."

Kushner's proximity to the president has been a significant factor in his role, as he has been Trump's point person on issues ranging from the Middle East peace process, immigration, and now the response to the coronavirus. Kushner, a real estate developer and scion of the Kushner family, which operates the Kushner Companies, is well-connected and is using those connections to facilitate the response to the outbreak, working with FEMA and the U.S. military.

On Thursday, Kushner recounted a conversation with Dr. Mitchell Katz, who runs the New York public hospital system, about critical shortages in the system. Kushner secured N95 masks for the system by contacting Admiral Polowczyk, the director of fleet ordnance and supply at the U.S. Fleet Forces Command in Norfolk, Va.

However, some experts question Kushner's lack of experience in overseeing responses to emergencies of this scale. Craig Fugate, who ran FEMA during the Obama administration, stated, "My experience in disasters is the burn rate is always greater than what anybody anticipates." Fugate added that if the federal government had waited for states to identify their needs, they would have been behind and not there fast enough.

Ethics groups have also raised concerns about Kushner's role in the response, with Noah Bookbinder, executive director of Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, stating, "If there was ever a time we need records and transparency, this is it." Bookbinder called for understanding who in the White House is making policy decisions, who from private industry is influencing those decisions, and how decisions to address the pandemic are being made.

Andy Slavitt, the Obama-era administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, described the current crisis as an all-hands-on-deck effort. He appreciates Kushner or anyone else in government sharing their expertise, but he emphasized that roles need to be clear and execution much more coordinated. Slavitt stated, "The issue should be, we don't need five generals. We need somebody in charge." He added, "We need a top-down structure where we get decisions made quickly." Slavitt also noted that the military is best positioned to lead the effort.

Title: Obama Visits Orlando, Urges Gun Control Measures After Deadliest U.S. Shooting

Article:

In the aftermath of the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history, President Barack Obama met with survivors of the Orlando nightclub attack and relatives of the 49 victims on Thursday. The shooting, carried out by a U.S.-born gunman, Omar Mateen, who pledged allegiance to various Islamist militant groups, left 49 dead and 53 injured.

During his visit, Obama laid flowers at a memorial for the victims and urged Congress to pass measures to make it harder to legally acquire high-powered weapons like the semi-automatic rifle used in the attack. He expressed his condolences to the grieving families and emphasized the need for the U.S. to address gun violence and homegrown terrorism.

Obama and Vice President Joe Biden arrived in Orlando, Florida, four days after the attack. During the shooting rampage, Mateen exchanged text messages with his wife, Noor Salman, as well as posting on Facebook and placing a phone call to a television station. Police killed Mateen, a 29-year-old U.S. citizen born in New York to Afghan immigrants.

The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack, but U.S. officials have stated that Mateen was not assisted from abroad. CIA Director John Brennan told a Senate Intelligence Committee hearing on Thursday that the agency had "not been able to uncover any direct link" between Mateen and militants abroad.

The attack sparked a new debate over how the U.S. responds to Islamist militant violence at home and abroad. Republican Senator John McCain stated that Obama is "directly responsible" for the Orlando attack due to his failure to prevent the rise of Islamic State. However, McCain later clarified that he was referring to Obama's national security decisions, "not to the President himself."

Mateen carried out the attack with an assault weapon and handgun that had been legally purchased, despite being investigated by the FBI for possible connections with militant Islamist groups twice. Obama reiterated his frustration over the failure of Congress to pass any gun control measures in more than two decades.

The massacre put pressure on Congress to act, and after a series of speeches by Democrats, a Democratic senator said Republicans had agreed to hold votes on measures to expand background checks and prevent people on U.S. terrorism watch lists from buying guns. No formal deal between the parties for votes was announced, and it remains unclear when and how the Senate will proceed with the votes.

Senator John Cornyn of Texas, the No. 2 Republican in the Senate, said the chamber would most likely vote on four gun control measures on Monday. The Republican-controlled Senate has previously blocked a number of Democratic-backed gun control measures, citing infringement on Americans' constitutional right to bear arms.

Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump also joined the gun debate, announcing on Wednesday he would meet with the National Rifle Association to discuss barring people who are on terrorism watch lists from buying guns.

Title: Bipartisan Activity Marks a Resurgence of Deal-Making in the 113th Congress

The 113th Congress, following the least productive 112th Congress in over 60 years, is showing signs of increased productivity, despite the ongoing political rancor. The year has seen a series of bipartisan initiatives, including the resolution of the controversial Senate filibuster issue, the passage of the long-delayed Violence Against Women Act, and the avoidance of government shutdowns.

In March, a bipartisan group of senior senators managed to head off a potential "nuclear" showdown over the filibuster, a controversial Senate tool. The Violence Against Women Act, which had been stalled for years, was signed into law in March. More recently, House and Senate lawmakers have worked diligently to keep the government funded through the end of the fiscal year, without the protests that have characterized such measures in recent years.

On major legislative initiatives, at least some bipartisan activity is underway, even if it is not yielding everything its sponsors would like. From strengthening firearm controls to immigration reform to renewed discussions of a "grand bargain" on taxes and entitlement programs, Congress is once again alive with the possibility of compromise.

The obstacles to congressional deal-making are not unique to the current political climate in Washington. The deep divide among lawmakers reflects the polarization on a wide range of policy and cultural issues that exists among the voters who sent them to Congress. The positions are hardened by deep-pocketed advocacy groups with intense ideological focuses and narrow agendas. Such groups make departing from the party line more dangerous than ever.

The increasing amount of money needed to run for Congress also means lawmakers spend more time fundraising and less time studying issues or forging relationships with colleagues, the foundation on which deal-making is built. Complicating the impulse to compromise today is the frequency of "wave" elections, which have created cliques of lawmakers with seemingly narrow mandates to an extent rarely seen in US history.

Members elected in such waves "are really not going to make deals that go against what the people who put them there want [ them ] to do," says former Rep. Steven LaTourette (R-OH), a centrist. "On 'Obamacare,' you do not hear a lot of the 2010 class say, 'Well, let's save the good parts and jettison the rest.' It's'repeal, repeal, repeal,' because that was the war drum on the campaign trail."

Given the tough constraints, today's congressional deal-makers are not coming from either party's moderate wing, as many of them have in the past. Instead, it's up to lawmakers respected on both the left and right, like Republicans Sen. Tom Coburn of Oklahoma and Rep. Paul Ryan of Wisconsin or Democrats like Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-NY) and Rep. Chris Van Hollen (D-MD), to get things done.

"If you're waiting for the moderates to compromise," says former Sen. Joe Lieberman (I-CT), "you're going to be waiting quite a while. There are not enough left."

Getting those on either end of the political spectrum to sit down together can be aided by political entrepreneurs, like Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC), legislators willing to tackle sensitive issues such as immigration and Social Security before their parties are willing to do the same. However, bringing disparate politicians together on new ideas is another matter. That is now often done through old-fashioned bargaining in the backroom, where lawmakers can make the kind of concessions key to compromise.

"Part of the value [ of such groups ] is they are working on the outlines of what a bargain on any issue would be before it hits the media," says Julian Zelizer, a congressional historian at Princeton University. Bipartisan groups "give some kind of signal to other party members that it's OK" to depart from orthodoxy.

The public's general disdain for gridlock and voters' outspokenness on individual issues are other factors that may force more compromise. "Sometimes deal-makers gain strength when there is some kind of social pressure to do something," says Mr. Zelizer.

Title: Bipartisan Divide: Four Republicans and an Independent Break Ranks, Condemning President's Remarks in House Vote

Article:

In a significant turn of events, only four Republicans and one independent broke ranks to join the Democrats in a House vote on Tuesday, condemning the President's controversial language. This development serves as a stark reminder of the evolution of the Republican Party, once known for its broad tent approach, welcoming to Latino and African-American voters.

The political landscape, however, has shifted, with party leaders emphasizing messages of patriotism. Some leaders attempted to sidestep the racial implications, while others seemed less concerned about potential backlash.

Kellyanne Conway, counselor to the president, spoke out on Fox News, stating, "Forget these four. They represent a dark underbelly of people in this country. We are sick and tired of people denigrating that American flag, the American military, veterans, and America."

Other party members were quick to follow, but sought to reframe and soften the message. Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming, the third-ranking House Republican, offered a tutorial in offensive counterattack, saying, "Our opposition to our socialist colleagues has absolutely nothing to do with their gender, with their religion, or with their race. It has to do with the content of their policies."

With the election still over a year away, the Democrats will eventually have a standard-bearer to define the party in opposition to the President. However, some Democrats express concern that criticism of the four congresswomen may resonate with a segment of their voters and independents, who may share unease with the policies they support and some of their rhetoric, as they do with the President's own bombast.

The Democrats who performed well in the midterms were those who played down the President while focusing on issues like protecting health insurance for people with pre-existing conditions. Many strategists rallying behind former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. believe the party cannot rely on increased turnout among young people and minorities and needs to win back voters it lost to the President.

Title: GOP Struggles to Gain Support for American Healthcare Act as Vote Nears

Article:

The American Healthcare Act (AHCA), the Republican Party's attempt to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA), faces an uncertain future as GOP leaders struggle to garner enough support for a vote, initially scheduled for Thursday but now rescheduled for Friday morning. President Trump, according to Office of Management and Budget Director Mick Mulvaney, has urged House Republicans to act swiftly, stating that the time for negotiation is over and if the bill fails this time, they will be stuck with Obamacare.

The AHCA has faced opposition from both sides of the aisle, with no Democrats expected to support the bill, and detractors within the GOP, particularly among moderates and conservatives. Some conservatives reject the bill due to its failure to deliver a clean repeal of the ACA, with nicknames like "Obamacare 2.0" and "Obamacare Lite" reflecting their dissatisfaction. Moderates, on the other hand, are concerned that the bill's accelerated timeline for rolling back the ACA's Medicaid expansion could leave too many uninsured.

Critics also argue that the bill does not do enough to address rising premium costs. Over the past week, GOP leaders and the president have offered changes to the bill, including a manager's amendment that tinkered with Medicaid and the IRS code. On Thursday, Republicans discussed removing Obamacare's "essential benefits," such as maternity and prenatal care, preventative care, and other mandatory insurance provisions since the passage of the ACA.

The stakes are high, with President Trump "100 percent" supporting the bill and spending the last few weeks making a hard sell. He has warned Republicans that their seats and the Republican majority are in danger in 2018 if they don't pass the bill. However, reluctant House Republicans may also be considering the Senate's stance, as at least three senators - Rand Paul, Mike Lee, and Tom Cotton - currently oppose the bill. Ted Cruz has also expressed his inability to support the bill as it stands, and four other senators have objected to the bill's treatment of the Medicaid expansion. If three Republican senators vote against the bill, the AHCA will fail in the Senate, which has a slim 52-48 Republican majority.

Republicans need 215 votes to win passage in the House, due to the absence of Rep. Bobby Rush, a Democrat from Illinois. They can lose no more than 22 votes. The list of House Republicans who have expressed opposition to the bill in its current form is subject to change, with negotiations and potential deals expected in the lead-up to the vote. This article will be updated regularly as members decide on their voting position or change their minds.

Title: House Republicans Abandon Health Care Replacement Bill: "Obamacare Remains the Law of the Land"

Article:

In a significant setback for the Republican Party, House Republicans have abandoned their long-awaited health care replacement bill, effectively leaving the Affordable Care Act, or "Obamacare," as the law of the land.

House Speaker Paul Ryan admitted defeat on Friday, shortly after he pulled the bill, stating, "We're going to be living with Obamacare for the foreseeable future." He further added, "I do not know how long it's going to take us to replace this law."

President Trump, while acknowledging the setback, termed it a "learning experience." He also expressed optimism for a potential bipartisan bill in the future, stating, "Both parties can get together... and have a better bill."

Health care has been put on the backburner, with both Trump and Ryan shifting focus to tax reform. The failure of the health care bill is a significant blow to Trump's leadership and Ryan's ability to control his conference, a challenge that eluded his predecessor, John Boehner, eventually leading to his ouster.

Trump, who entered office without any political or legislative experience, seemed to admit there was a learning curve. He stated, "This was an interesting period of time... We learned a lot... Certainly, for me, it was a very interesting experience, but for me, it'll be an experience that leads to an even better health care plan."

Ryan, in a more somber tone, admitted that fulfilling the GOP's pledge to repeal the Affordable Care Act was tougher than expected. He stated, "Moving from an opposition party to a governing party comes with growing pains, and, well, we're feeling those growing pains now."

The way forward for Republicans on exactly how to replace Obamacare remains unclear. It's uncertain whether they will try again. Ryan had already delayed the bill a day to try to muster support. Trump had delivered an ultimatum to House Republicans—pass the GOP replacement, the American Health Care Act, or Obamacare would stand.

Democrats, meanwhile, were quick to take a victory lap in the GOP's defeat. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, whose caucus was decimated in 2010 after the health care bill was passed, appeared flanked by Democratic leadership to gloat just a day after the seventh anniversary of the signing of the Affordable Care Act.

The inability of Republicans to reach consensus on a bill, given their control of the House, Senate, and White House, badly hurts the GOP's image as a party that can govern. The risks were high for Trump on the bill. His inability to get this through, after giving an ultimatum to congressional Republicans, raises questions about his deal-making abilities and underscores his lack of legislative and policy experience upon entering the White House.

Title: Trump Digs In on Government Shutdown Over Border Wall Funding, Viewing Himself as a "Border Warrior"

Article:

In the midst of a series of turbulent events, including a government shutdown, a stock market rout, and Cabinet shakeups, President Donald Trump is resuming his role as a unifying figure for the right, adopting the mantle of a "border warrior."

The ongoing government shutdown, Trump's third, is a situation he appears to accept, with White House aides reporting that he is willing to let it drag into the new year. This stance is a reflection of his determination not to be perceived as reneging on his central campaign promise to build a border wall, a promise he views as crucial to his reelection bid.

Mick Mulvaney, the acting White House chief of staff, set the tone for the prolonged standoff during an interview on Fox News, stating, "I don't think things are going to move very quickly here for the next couple of days."

Republicans are not uniformly falling in line. Sen. Bob Corker of Tennessee criticized Trump for failing to avoid the shutdown, dismissing his hardening negotiating posture on immigration as "a made-up fight so that the president could look like he’s fighting."

Trump's aides have attempted to blame the Democrats for the shutdown, despite the president's earlier statements suggesting that he would be proud to shut down the government for border security. However, the president's campaign has seized the opportunity to capitalize on the stalemate, painting him as an authentic promise-keeper.

For Trump, the border wall is more than just a physical structure. The White House has long seen his "Build the wall" promise as an indicator of the extent to which his early pledges could resonate with voters he needs to secure reelection.

"The wall is important, but it's more the underlying anti-immigrant message that's the key," a former White House official said. Trump's team has identified the potential for supporters to doubt his ability to deliver on the wall, and the ongoing shutdown serves as a test of his political will.

Though the wall has yet to be built, the president has been filling the void with words, repeatedly boasting about how much of the wall has already been constructed, even though little, if any, building has occurred during his presidency. The government-funding exercise is one area where Trump has the ultimate say, and for now, it seems to be a function of leverage, which the Democrats currently hold.

Title: House of Representatives Gathers Enough Support for Discharge Petition on DACA, Pushing for Immigration Action

Article:

In a significant development, the House of Representatives has garnered enough support to force votes on several legislative fixes for the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, potentially compelling Republican leaders to take action on immigration.

Rep. Jeff Denham (R-CA) has spearheaded the move to secure a majority of House members' signatures on a discharge petition, which, if successful, would bypass Speaker Paul Ryan's (R-WI) opposition and bring immigration bills to the floor for a vote. As of Thursday, Denham reportedly has enough support for the discharge petition, but he continues to negotiate behind closed doors to find a compromise bill that leadership can bring up.

House Republican leaders have made it clear that they do not want their members to sign on to the discharge petition. They argue that the process will lead to chaos, guaranteeing that no bill that can pass will become law, and potentially reveal deep discord within the party, especially during a contentious election year.

However, support for the petition is growing, with Denham, a California Republican in a Hispanic-heavy district this fall, driving the process. Interestingly, this is not the only instance this week where members have pushed past leadership's timeline.

On Wednesday, a bipartisan group of senators defied Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) and voted to overturn the Federal Communications Commission's (FCC) controversial ruling to dismantle net neutrality. The vote to reinstate the Obama-era net neutrality rules won the support of 49 Democrats, as well as three Republican senators: Susan Collins (R-ME), John Kennedy (R-LA), and Lisa Murkowski (R-AK).

The fight to reinstate net neutrality will have a difficult road ahead, as it must be voted on and passed in the House and signed by the president (or gain a veto-proof majority). President Trump has expressed opposition to net neutrality.

In another sign of frustration, Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY) invoked an obscure Senate rule on Thursday to try to put a House-passed sexual harassment and discrimination bill on the Senate calendar without McConnell's support. The bill would overhaul how harassment complaints are made in Congress and make lawmakers personally accountable for paying settlements.

The legislation, a version of which the House passed 100 days ago, has been stalled in the Senate while negotiators iron out some details in the language. However, many, like Gillibrand, have grown impatient.

These events demonstrate that regular members can take control and force leadership's hand, but it is not always easy. In the past week, we have seen three different methods put into action: the Congressional Review Act, Rule 14 in the Senate, and a discharge petition in the House.

While these methods are at lawmakers' disposal to buck leadership, they don't always happen. The reasons range from strong top-down party control, a desire to show a unified front, and a message that anything pushing the envelope could put the majority at risk.

"Members who theoretically want to advance an agenda aren't doing so, because they think the majority is very important," said James Wallner, a political scientist and former executive director of the Senate Steering Committee. "But at a certain point, that all comes to head."

"You can't bottle up stuff forever," Wallner said. "It keeps getting worse. At some point, things have to change. There is always another election—and then when that happens, we are not going to get it, we are never going to get it, because the parties aren't unified."

Title: Lori Lightfoot Makes History as First Black Woman and Openly Gay Mayor of Chicago

Article:

In a historic victory, former federal prosecutor Lori Lightfoot has been elected as the new Mayor of Chicago, becoming the first black woman and openly gay individual to lead the third-largest city in the United States. Lightfoot defeated Toni Preckwinkle, a longtime political insider and Cook County Board president, in Tuesday's mayoral race.

Lightfoot, who has never been elected to public office, delivered a commanding victory over Preckwinkle, who served in the City Council for 19 years. The former prosecutor ran on a platform of ridding City Hall of corruption and addressing the needs of low-income and working-class residents who, she argued, had been neglected by Chicago's political ruling class.

At her victory party, Lightfoot pledged to break the city's cycle of corruption and ensure that a resident's zip code would no longer determine their destiny. She also emphasized the importance of racial equality, stating that Chicago was a city where race and sexual orientation no longer mattered.

Lightfoot emerged as the front-runner in the first round of voting in February, when 14 candidates were vying to succeed Mayor Rahm Emanuel, who decided against running for a third term. Chicago will become the largest U.S. city to elect a black woman as mayor when Lightfoot is sworn in May 20.

The election took place just days after Chicago state prosecutors dropped charges against actor Jussie Smollett, who was accused of faking a hate-crime attack that implicated supporters of President Trump. The decision to drop the charges has sparked controversy, with some criticizing the prosecutors' decision and others accusing Smollett of exploiting the incident for personal gain.

Lightfoot seized on the shooting of black teenager Laquan McDonald, which led to the conviction of white officer Jason Van Dyke, to launch her campaign. The incident, which occurred before Emanuel announced he would not seek a third term, was a significant factor in the election.

The campaign between Lightfoot and Preckwinkle was marked by personal attacks and negative advertising. Preckwinkle's advertising focused on Lightfoot's work as a partner at Mayer Brown, a large law firm, and portrayed her as a wealthy corporate lawyer. Preckwinkle also tried to cast Lightfoot as an insider for working in police oversight posts under Emanuel and former Mayor Richard M. Daley.

In one ad, Preckwinkle criticized Lightfoot's oversight of emergency communications in 2004 when a fire killed four children. The ad noted some of the 911 tapes were destroyed, prompting a judge to rebuke Lightfoot. The ad sparked a backlash from the family of three of the children killed, with their sister accusing Preckwinkle of trying to take advantage of her family's tragedy.

Despite the contentious campaign, both candidates expressed similar ideas to boost the city's finances, including support for a casino in Chicago and a graduated income tax system. They also shared a focus on addressing neighborhood growth, investing in schools, affordable housing, and criminal justice reform.

Joyce Ross, a 64-year-old certified nursing assistant living on the West Side, cast her ballot for Lightfoot, citing the former prosecutor's potential to clean up the police department and curb the city's violence. Ross also expressed concern over Preckwinkle's association with Alderman Ed Burke, who was indicted earlier this year on charges he tried to shake down a restaurant owner who wanted to build in his ward.

As Chicago's new mayor, Lightfoot will face numerous challenges, including addressing the city's financial problems, high levels of gun violence, and restoring the public's faith in government. However, with her commanding victory and the support of voters from every part of the city, Lightfoot is poised to make history and lead Chicago into a new era.

Title: Kentucky Senator Rand Paul Stages Record-Breaking Filibuster on Drone Strikes

Article:

In an unprecedented move, Kentucky Senator Rand Paul staged a nearly 13-hour filibuster in the Senate on Wednesday, voicing concerns over the potential danger of drone strikes on U.S. citizens on American soil. The filibuster, which began at 11:47 a.m. and ended at about 12:39 a.m. on Thursday, disrupted the Senate's agenda, preventing a potential vote on President Barack Obama's nominee to run the CIA, John Brennan.

Senator Paul, a self-proclaimed libertarian, seized control of the Senate, leading a bloc of conservatives in a successful bid to delay the confirmation vote for Brennan. Paul's prolonged speech forced the Senate to postpone the vote, effectively removing it from the day's agenda.

In his impassioned speech, Paul expressed his concerns about the potential use of drones against American citizens on U.S. soil and the lack of transparency regarding drone policy. As the day progressed, several of Paul's colleagues, as well as one Democrat, joined him in voicing their concerns.

By nightfall, Paul's effort had garnered the support of more of his colleagues, including Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, who joined him on the floor. Other senators, such as Ron Johnson of Wisconsin, Tim Scott of South Carolina, and Jeff Flake of Arizona, used their time to discuss issues ranging from the dysfunctional Senate and the national debt to the essential issue of liberty and the question of drone policy.

Despite the long hours on his feet, Paul admitted to reporters that he had not prepared extensively for the filibuster. He joked about his lack of comfortable shoes and his need for water, but he did employ some strategy, such as frequent visits to the candy drawer to keep his energy up.

The filibuster, while surprising to many senators who were prepared to confirm Brennan earlier in the day, ultimately served to highlight the growing concerns about drone policy and the need for transparency in government operations. The Senate is expected to reconvene to discuss the matter further in the coming days.

Title: Trump Proposes $8.6 Billion for Border Wall in 2020 Budget, Sparking Potential Funding Standoff with Congress

Article:

President Donald Trump has announced his intention to request $8.6 billion for his long-promised border wall with Mexico in his 2020 congressional budget, a move that could ignite another funding standoff with Congress. The proposed budget is set to be submitted on Monday.

According to a senior administration official, the $8.6 billion would be used to build or replace approximately 700 miles of barriers along the U.S.-Mexico border. The figure was confirmed by Reuters, who also reported that the funding for the wall would pull $5 billion from the Department of Homeland Security budget and $3.6 billion from the military construction budget at the Pentagon.

The budget proposal also includes $3.6 million in military construction funding to help fund projects affected by the wall. In addition to wall funding, Trump's proposal calls for the hiring of an additional 2,800 law enforcement and other personnel to reinforce the border and 100 immigration judge teams.

The proposal is expected to face stiff opposition in the Democrat-held House. Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer (D-N.Y.) indicated in a statement that the president's $8.6 billion ask is a non-starter.

"President Trump hurt millions of Americans and caused widespread chaos when he recklessly shut down the government to try to get his expensive and ineffective wall, which he promised would be paid for by Mexico," the Democratic leaders said. "Congress refused to fund his wall and he was forced to admit defeat and reopen the government. The same thing will repeat itself if he tries this again," they added.

Congress must approve funding for fiscal 2020 by Oct. 1, or funding could lapse, and the government could shut down. Trump's requests for border funding have shifted during his time in office as he seeks to fulfill a signature campaign promise.

The administration's proposal for fiscal year 2019 sought $18 billion for the wall, including $1.6 billion to construct 65 miles in south Texas. The president in December triggered a partial government shutdown when he demanded $5.7 billion in wall funding. Trump agreed after 35 days to reopen the government without wall funding, but continued to press lawmakers for $5.7 billion for the structure. Congress ultimately approved $1.375 billion for border barriers, and the president issued a national emergency to bypass Congress and spend roughly $8 billion to construct his long-desired border wall.

In making the emergency declaration, the president said he planned to redirect $3.6 billion in military construction funding toward the border project. He also said he would take separate executive action to repurpose about $2.5 billion from the Defense Department's drug-interdiction program and $600 million from the Treasury Department's asset-forfeiture fund.

The national emergency has drawn pushback from Congress, with the House voting to approve a resolution that would terminate the emergency, and the Senate expected to do the same this week. The Senate vote would set Trump up for the first veto of his presidency, with neither chamber likely to override it.

Trump has made construction of a wall along the southern border a key agenda item since he launched his campaign in 2015. His inability to complete the task has prompted criticism from immigration hard-liners, though Trump has insisted the wall is being built, and he has transitioned his mantra from "Build the wall" to "Finish the wall."

Larry Kudlow, Trump's top economic adviser, acknowledged on "Fox News Sunday" that the request for wall funding is likely to spur yet another fight with Congress, but he depicted it as a necessary one.

"I would just say that the whole issue of the wall and border security is of paramount importance," Kudlow said Sunday. "We have to be much tougher and have more constructive immigration policy, which we will be developing. (Trump) is going to stay with his wall. He's going to stay with the border security theme. I think it's essential."

Title: Democrats Kick Off National Convention in Charlotte, Emphasizing Middle-Out Economic Approach

The Democratic National Convention commenced in Charlotte, North Carolina on Tuesday, with the party's leaders emphasizing a clear plan to restore the nation's economic stability. Antonio Villaraigosa, the convention's chair, stated during a press briefing that by the convention's conclusion on Thursday, the Democrats will have defined their platform and presented a stark contrast between their candidate's middle-out economic strategy and the top-down approach of the Republican nominee.

Villaraigosa's remarks echoed themes expressed by President Obama in recent interviews, such as his conversation with Time magazine, where he underscored the importance of articulating his policies and the contrasting approach of the Republican presidential candidate, Mitt Romney.

Alice Germond, the Democratic National Committee Secretary, reiterated the party's pride in Obama's accomplishments during her remarks at the media briefing. In response to perceived GOP secrecy regarding their platform, Germond noted that by the end of the convention, everyone will have a copy of the Democratic platform.

Villaraigosa indicated that the upcoming days would serve to remind the nation of Obama's first-term achievements, such as preventing an economic catastrophe, saving the auto industry, and passing the landmark healthcare law.

Ben LaBolt, the Obama campaign's National Press Secretary, addressed a recently released Gallup poll indicating tepid responses to Romney's acceptance speech. LaBolt stated that the American public is seeking solutions to secure the middle class, and the GOP convention's attacks against Obama were merely recycled and debunked.

LaBolt expressed that the Democrats would use the convention to address these concerns and engage in an honest conversation about the nation's state in 2008. He emphasized that the Democrats have made progress and that the president will outline his plans to continue this progress in his Thursday evening speech.

Title: Obama's Controversial Last-Minute Actions: A Look at the Commutation of Chelsea Manning's Sentence and the UN Resolution on Israel

Article:

In the final days of his presidency, Barack Obama took actions that were met with surprise and criticism, with two of the most notable being the commutation of Chelsea Manning's sentence and the passing of a UN resolution critical of Israel.

The commutation of Manning's sentence, a former Army intelligence analyst who was convicted of leaking classified documents to WikiLeaks, was a move that was widely criticized as a finger-in-the-eye willfulness. Manning was sentenced to 35 years in prison for stealing and releasing almost half a million military reports and another quarter-million State Department documents. The documents were said to have jeopardized the lives of American troops, allies, and interests.

The other controversial action occurred four weeks earlier when the United States, for the first time in nearly a half-century, abandoned Israel on a crucial Security Council resolution, allowing the passage of a condemnation that will plague both Israel and its citizens for years to come.

The Obama administration's actions have been criticized as hypocritical, given the president's previous stance on WikiLeaks and the harm inflicted by its release of stolen materials during the election campaign. The release of Manning's documents was said to have caused harm to American troops, allies, and interests, while the material released by WikiLeaks during the election campaign was primarily campaign gossip, backbiting, indiscretions, and cynicism, with no national-security secrets or classified material.

The other last-minute Obama bombshell occurred four weeks earlier when, for the first time in nearly a half-century, the United States abandoned Israel on a crucial Security Council resolution, allowing the passage of a condemnation that will plague both Israel and its citizens for years to come.

The Obama administration's actions have been interpreted as a move to curry favor with the international Left, given the president's potential future role as a leader on the international stage. However, a more likely explanation is that these are acts not of calculation but of authenticity, with Obama being true to his political beliefs and values.

The actions taken by President Obama in his final days in office have sparked debate and controversy, with critics arguing that they were hypocritical and harmful, while supporters argue that they were authentic and in line with the president's political beliefs and values.

Title: US Secretary of State John Kerry Pursues Coalition to Counter Islamic State in Middle East and Europe

Article:

US Secretary of State John Kerry is currently in Saudi Arabia, engaging in talks to form a broad coalition of partners in the fight against the Islamic State, as part of a strategy unveiled by President Obama in his national address on Tuesday. The talks, which include a diverse group of Middle Eastern nations, aim to secure support for establishing military bases and overflight for airstrikes, as well as improved coordination to halt the flow of funds to extremist groups.

According to a senior US State Department official, Kerry will focus on stopping ISIL oil smuggling through the Jordanian and Turkish borders, where authorities have pledged to take action, but the US will work closely with them over the next few weeks on intelligence sharing and border control.

However, the formation of this broad partnership to combat militants in Iraq and Syria faces several challenges. One of the main questions is whether all countries can be persuaded to join, and what the potential unintended consequences of such a coalition might be. The talks today involve leaders from Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Turkey, Jordan, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, Oman, and Qatar.

President Obama stated last night that the US will be joined by a broad coalition of partners, and Secretary Kerry will travel across the Middle East and Europe in the coming days to enlist more partners in this fight, particularly Arab nations who can help mobilize Sunni communities in Iraq and Syria to drive the Islamic State from their lands.

Saudi Arabia's agreement to host training camps for "moderate Syrian rebels" is seen as a sign of support, given Saudi Arabia's religious significance among Sunnis, and the Islamic State fighters are also Sunni. However, the challenges do not end there. Many of the countries crucial to the coalition are deeply skeptical of the US's commitment to follow through on its promises to eliminate the Islamic State, after it hesitated to launch airstrikes last year against Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.

The US's coalition-building efforts are complex, as these countries have favored various anti-Assad rebels, but also Islamist groups that have spawned the Islamic State and other jihadi groups that are now beyond their control. This complicates any US-led coalition against radicalism.

As Secretary Kerry moves on to Europe, he should receive a warmer response from governments concerned about the fact that hundreds of Europeans have left to fight in Syria. At the NATO Summit in Wales last week, the US had support from Britain, France, Germany, Canada, Australia, Turkey, Italy, Poland, and Denmark.

France has been the most public in its support so far, pledging to act in an international coalition if international law is followed. French President François Hollande and Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius will travel to Baghdad tomorrow, before France hosts a conference in Paris on Monday to coordinate efforts to tackle the Islamic State.

"An international mobilization is necessary to respond to this trans-national danger that can reach our territory," Mr. Fabius said, according to Reuters. "In Iraq, the government and minorities have called for help, and we answered with deliveries of military equipment and humanitarian aid."

This week, the UK announced it would send a limited amount of arms to Kurds in Iraq to fight the Islamic State. Germany also agreed to do the same. In a Guardian opinion piece, Hayder al-Khoei, an associate fellow on the Middle East and North Africa program at Chatham House, argued that "the UK should be an important player in the international coalition that Obama is trying to set up to confront the most dangerous terrorist organization of the 21st century."

Title: George Papadopoulos Labeled as "Proactive Cooperator" in Mueller Investigation Sparks Speculation of Undercover Work

Article:

In a recent court filing, George Papadopoulos, the former Trump campaign adviser who pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI about his contacts with Russians, has been identified as a "proactive cooperator" by federal investigators. This term, as explained by a 2001 federal court case, generally implies that the defendant will engage in undercover work on behalf of the government, such as wearing a wire and/or meeting face-to-face with persons suspected of involvement in criminal activity.

At a plea hearing held on Oct. 5, Aaron Zelinsky, a prosecutor in the Office of the Special Counsel Robert Mueller, shed light on Papadopoulos' cooperation. Zelinsky stated that at Papadopoulos' sentencing, prosecutors would make note of his "efforts to cooperate with the Government" as long as he continued "to meet with and provide information to the Government on request."

Papadopoulos was arrested on July 27 on charges that he lied to FBI agents during a Jan. 27 interview. Agents met with Papadopoulos as part of the bureau's investigation into possible collusion between the Trump campaign and the Russian government. As part of his plea deal, Papadopoulos acknowledged that he lied to agents during that meeting about his interactions with three Russian nationals.

Papadopoulos discussed arranging meetings between Russian government officials and the Trump campaign. One of Papadopoulos' contacts also told him in April that the Russian government had obtained "thousands" of Hillary Clinton's emails.

The White House downplayed the revelations, stating that Papadopoulos played a small part on the campaign and that the Trump team did not collude with the Russian government. The revelation that Papadopoulos was serving as a "proactive cooperator" has sparked widespread speculation about the extent of his cooperation with the Mueller team.

Ron Hosko, a former assistant director of the FBI's criminal division, suggests that it is possible that Papadopoulos wore a wire as part of his cooperation agreement. "I think it's a fair assessment that it means Mueller and Co. might have been working with [Papadopoulos] to engage other subjects in conversation along the lines suggested in the article," said Hosko, referring to the possibility of Papadopoulos wearing a wire.

Legal analyst Jeffrey Toobin also believes that the government's disclosure strongly suggests that Papadopoulos was wearing a wire or recording conversations with Trump associates. "What this says to me is that Papadopoulos between July and October was wearing a wire. He was recording conversations secretly with people who are subjects and targets of this investigation," said Toobin. He added, "If he was wearing a wire, this summer and fall, think about that, just weeks ago, that is a whole new chapter of possibilities in this investigation and potentially a very, very big deal."

Title: Senate Judiciary Committee Prepares for Barr's Attorney General Confirmation Hearing Amidst Focus on Mueller's Russia Investigation

As the Senate Judiciary Committee prepares for the confirmation hearing of William Barr's nomination for attorney general, the special counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation will likely take center stage. Several Senate Democrats on the committee plan to question Barr on his views regarding Mueller's investigation, particularly a controversial memo Barr wrote last year criticizing Mueller's investigation into possible obstruction of justice.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer on Wednesday stated that Barr should be disqualified from leading the Department of Justice due to the memo. Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.) has expressed concerns about political interference in the special counsel's probe and has stated that Barr should recuse himself from overseeing the investigation if he cannot provide an "ironclad" commitment to protecting Mueller and disavow statements made in the memo.

The nomination battle for Barr comes at a critical juncture in Donald Trump's presidency, with the Justice Department in transition and Mueller's probe entering its 20th month. The investigation has resulted in seven guilty pleas and a conviction of the president's former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort. Trump has repeatedly denounced the Mueller investigation, labeling it a "witch hunt."

A bipartisan group of senators is also reintroducing a bill to protect Mueller, though Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has refused to bring the bill up for a floor vote. Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) and Sen. Mazie Hirono (D-Hawaii) have expressed concerns about Barr's views on the Mueller investigation and the departure of Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who is reportedly leaving the Justice Department after a new attorney general is confirmed.

Democrats on the Judiciary Committee don't appear to have a unified strategy for the nomination hearing, with some senators focusing on meeting with Barr and asking their own questions. Despite potential Democratic attacks, Senate Republicans remain confident that Barr will be confirmed, particularly given that they expanded their majority during the midterm election.

Barr met with Senate Judiciary Chairman Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) and former Committee Chair Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) on Wednesday. Graham stated that during their meeting, Barr reassured him of his respect for Mueller. Graham also expressed support for bringing up the Mueller protection bill in his committee if the probe is still ongoing next month.

Not all Republicans are on board with Barr's nomination, with Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) expressing concerns about Barr's views on civil liberties. However, Sen. Thom Tillis (R-N.C.) doesn't see Barr's memo to Rosenstein on the Mueller investigation as disqualifying, noting that Barr wrote the memo as a private citizen.

Title: Health Insurance Renewal Process for 2015: What Consumers Need to Know

Article:

As the 2015 health insurance enrollment period approaches, individuals who renewed their policies last year may face unexpected changes, including higher premiums and altered federal tax credits. The enrollment period begins on November 15, with those renewing their policies required to sign up by December 15 to ensure coverage by the new year.

The specifics of the renewal process are yet to be determined, according to Paula Steiner, chief strategy officer for Health Care Service Corporation, which offers Blue Cross plans in five states. "We're still waiting on the details of the process," Steiner said. "We haven't gone through any testing yet of any changes to the system for 2015."

Andrew Slavitt, principal deputy administrator for Medicare, which oversees the insurance marketplaces, expressed optimism about the renewal process. "We're putting in place the simplest path for consumers this year to renew their coverage," he said. Those who prefer to stay with the same plan will be able to renew automatically, as many do with employer coverage. Renewal can be done with "absolutely nothing," he added.

The federal online marketplace is being continuously improved, according to Slavitt, who stated that the government was updating the website to allow renewals. "We're in a very different position than we were last year," he said.

Compared with the previous year, 30 carriers have requested entrance into the marketplaces for 2015, and 1.6 times more plans are being offered, according to McKinsey & Company's Center for US Health System Reform. Prices for 2015 are expected to remain varied, with some plans increasing by about 30 percent while others decrease by the same amount, depending on the market and policy. "We are definitely seeing a lot of volatility in pricing," said Erica Hutchins Coe, a McKinsey expert.

Title: Ferguson October: A Wake-Up Call for America

Article:

This past weekend, protestors and activists, including students, clergy, and concerned citizens, descended on Ferguson, Missouri, for a weekend of marches, protests, sit-ins, and civil disobedience, collectively known as Ferguson October. Yesterday, as one activist, Patrisse Cullors-Brignac, an organizer with Black Lives Matter, tweeted exultantly from the inside of a St. Louis County jail cell about having taken over a Wal-Mart, I waited to hear news of her safe release alongside rapper-activist Tef Poe, attorney and legal observer Justin Hansford, and Palestinian activist Bassem Masri, who handled live streaming for the Organization for Black Struggle.

The actions of these activists have sparked debate on social media, with some questioning the appropriateness of disturbing the peace in a private business. However, the message is clear - we are no longer content with business as usual. The tragic shooting of John Crawford in a Beaver Creek, Ohio Wal-Mart, who could not expect to come out alive while shopping, suggests that it is time for a change.

This nation has long proclaimed Black America as backwards, stuck in the past, and obsessed with race rather than racism itself. However, Black people are the hands on our national clock, controlling the timing of America's social progress. This time, both hands are up, pointing to the sky. It is high noon in America, the deepest midnight in our hearts. But, as Lucy A. Delaney proclaimed in her 1891 autobiography, "from the darkness cometh the light."

Young people are on the ground dreaming new dreams, and in doing so, they are inspiring elders. They are creative, taking over public spaces not only with signs and chants but with impromptu games of twister and double-dutch. From them, we learn that play can be political, that there is joy in struggle, that there is no justice without pleasure.

They are lining up, linking arms, and being locked up for justice. They are listening to those who have something to say and shutting down events when forced to listen to anyone who doesn't. They are choosing their leaders, their griots, their truth-tellers, their strategists, their elders. Showing up matters most. Putting one's body on the line is the order of the day.

This weekend, they took over four Wal-Marts, in solidarity with John Crawford who was murdered in an Ohio Wal-Mart. Prosecutors have cleared officers of wrongdoing. Protestors took signs to the St. Louis Rams game, and confronted angry fans who yelled, "I am Darren Wilson." Two weeks ago, they disrupted the symphony. Exploding dreams cause disruptions. They should be expected to continue.

More than 3000 new registered voters move among them (Update: This number has since been revised downward to 128). They have collected these new registrations like so many arrows in a quiver. Still, they remain skeptical of the vote. And since the presence of Black faces at the voting booth scares white people, they should be.

Take Tef Poe's surly response to Senator Claire McCaskill at a PBS townhall in late September. She argued that we needed new pipelines of local African American leadership. He replied, "I voted for Barack Obama twice, and still got tear-gassed."

We could mince words about the vast differences and expansive power of local governments in these matters, over against the apparently limited power of federal jurisdiction. But that's kind of beside the point. Movements are as much about symbols as about substance. Barack Obama is a broken symbol, a clanging cymbal, unable to say and do anything of use. His silence is the sound of imploding dreams, his words mere distractions and detours from the future we want.

He has become a prime example that being the leader of the free world in a Black body is still no match for entrenched, local, systemic, committed racism. It's sad that it has come to this. But this is bigger than Barack Obama. Just like it was bigger than King and his dream. We have awakened from sleep. We have been startled out of it by nearly 30 gunshots ringing out insistently from the heart of America. Jay-Z might call it "a moment of clarity."

In Obama's place, Cornel West has re-emerged, the wise and fearless elder, the one who we tried not to listen to, as he screamed into the wind for six years, the one whose approach chafed my hide on more than a few occasions, the one who is - despite all of our collective quibbles and begrudgements – right.

This moment is about all of us. About what kind of America we want to be. About what kind of America we are willing to be, willing to fight for. About whether we will settle for being mediocre and therefore murderous to a whole group of citizens. About whether there are other versions of ourselves worth fighting for.

Don't sleep. Millennials, it seems, are the ones we have been waiting for. Fearless and focused, the future they are fighting for is one I want. It is high time to awake out of sleep. Stay woke.

Title: Mayorkas Denies Allegations of Improper Visa Aid at Homeland Security Confirmation Hearing

Article:

In a heated confirmation hearing on Thursday, Alejandro Mayorkas, President Obama's nominee for the No. 2 spot at the Department of Homeland Security, unequivocally denied allegations that he improperly helped a company run by Hillary Clinton's brother obtain a visa. The hearing was boycotted by Republicans, who called for a postponement due to an ongoing investigation into Mayorkas' actions.

Mayorkas, the current director of U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, testified before the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee. He stated that he "made no orders" in these cases and that he only offers guidance based on the "facts" and "the law."

"I have never, ever in my career exercised undue influence to influence the outcome of a case," he said. Mayorkas also claimed he had "no idea" he was under investigation and "quite frankly, I still don't understand it."

The investigation, led by the department's inspector general, is examining Mayorkas' role in helping secure a foreign investor visa for Tony Rodham's Gulf Coast Funds Management, even after the application was denied and an appeal rejected. The international investor visa program run by USCIS, known as EB-5, allows foreigners to get visas if they invest $500,000 to $1 million in projects or businesses that create jobs for U.S. citizens.

In a statement, the inspector general's office confirmed that it is investigating Mayorkas' role in the visa case, but initially, he was not a target of the investigation. As the probe progressed, the office stated that "subsequent allegations have been identified involving alleged conflicts of interest, misuse of position, mismanagement of the EB-5 program, and an appearance of impropriety by Mayorkas and other USCIS management officials."

The hearing was largely friendly towards Mayorkas, as he dealt with questions from Senate Democrats. Republicans boycotted the hearing, after having tried unsuccessfully to get it postponed. In a statement, Sen. Tom Coburn, R-Okla., said, "I cannot participate in a hearing I believe to be unfair and improper to all parties involved."

Republicans, in a letter to committee Chairman Sen. Tom Carper, D-Del., claimed the news of the investigation took them by surprise. They said neither the White House nor Mayorkas had disclosed the existence of the probe to them before. The letter was signed by Sens. John McCain, R-Ariz.; Rob Portman, R-Ohio; Ron Johnson, R-Wis.; and Coburn. They argued that lawmakers would be hamstrung in asking about an ongoing investigation during the hearing, yet would need to know those details in order to fairly consider the nomination.

Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, also wrote committee leaders asking for a postponement "until the facts are more fully developed." The White House is standing by Mayorkas, with White House Counsel Kathryn Ruemmler assuring that the nominee underwent a "thorough" FBI background check before the nomination, and they have no concerns about his suitability for the position.

The investigation does not appear to have any direct ties to Clinton's tenure as secretary of state. However, any connection to Clinton, who is a possible 2016 Democratic presidential candidate, is likely to become fodder for Republican super PACs. The nomination took on new importance earlier this month when Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano announced she would be leaving the department in September to take over as president of the University of California. If approved by the Senate, Mayorkas would likely lead the department until a permanent replacement for Napolitano is named.

Title: Congress Explores Legislative Options to Halt President Obama's Immigration Executive Action

Article:

In a move that could potentially alter the course of President Obama's executive action on immigration, the Congressional Research Service (CRS) has concluded that Congress has the power to halt the president's proposed actions by denying him funding. This development comes as Congress prepares for a two-week sprint to conclude its current session, with the annual spending bills, the response to Mr. Obama's immigration moves, and the annual defense policy bill being among the key issues lawmakers must address.

Representative Tom Cotton, an Arkansas Republican who recently ascended to the Senate, has emphasized the need for Congress to assert its authority. In a recent appearance on NBC's "Meet the Press," he argued that the employment situation alone should motivate Congress to block the president's executive action.

Cotton stated, "The president just lost an election, in no small measure because wages for working families are declining and unemployment is still too high in too many places, and the first big action he took after the election was to make it easier for illegal immigrants to get jobs, not for working families to get jobs."

Cotton suggested several strategies for lawmakers to employ against the president on immigration, including tying all of this year's spending bills to a decision to block the deportation amnesty, tying only homeland security money to the deportation amnesty, and pushing the issue into next year, when Republicans will control both the House and Senate.

The CRS, in its letter to Senator Jeff Sessions, acknowledged that while the annual spending process may not be able to curb the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), a fee-based agency handling most of the president's amnesty, it does not mean Congress has no power over fee-based agencies. The CRS stated that the Supreme Court has established that Congress can dictate how an agency spends, as all government revenue, even when collected by a fee-based agency, technically goes to the overall fund and is reappropriated to the agency.

With the December 11 shutdown date looming, Republican leaders are grappling with decisions over which issues to address now, while Democrats retain control of the Senate, and which issues to defer until the next Congress, when Republicans will have at least 53 seats and control of the Senate and a larger House majority. The upcoming tax and spending deadlines, as well as President Obama's call for expanding the war in Iraq to combat Islamic State terrorists, also pose significant challenges for Congress. The House Republicans are also seeking to pass a bill to grant tax incentives allowing the disabled to stow money tax-free. The House and Senate may also confront the thorny issue of detainees at Guantanamo Bay when Congress tackles the annual defense policy bill.

Title: Analyzing the Presidential Debate: A Closer Look at the Economic Narratives of Obama and Romney

Article:

As the presidential race heats up, the economic narratives of both candidates, President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney, are taking center stage. In an interview, former President Bill Clinton and Charlotte Beers, a Democratic strategist, discussed the Democratic narrative that Obama is being held to impossibly high expectations when it comes to jobs and economic growth.

Clinton argued that Obama inherited a disastrous economic situation and kept it from getting worse. He emphasized that the economy is improving, and no one could have done better under the circumstances. This narrative, Clinton stated, is not just his, but a consensus view that even Romney, the Republican candidate, cannot refute.

Romney, on the other hand, has been criticizing the Obama administration's handling of the economy, arguing that the economy is in terrible shape. Clinton suggested that Romney's strategy is to focus on the economy, as the incumbent always owns the economy, and he will criticize the president's economic policies.

One point of contention is the idea that Obama made the economic situation worse, a narrative that has been circulating for over a year. Clinton argued that this narrative is incorrect, as Obama's actions have made things better, not worse.

Another point of discussion is the high unemployment rate, which includes those who have given up looking for work. Critics argue that this statistic should be taken into account when evaluating Obama's job creation record.

Clinton also pointed out that the upcoming presidential debates, starting in October, will be Romney's best opportunity to turn things around. He suggested that the debates will be closely watched by undecided voters and will provide an opportunity for Romney to surprise and demonstrate his Likability.

In conclusion, the economic narratives of both candidates will be a significant factor in the upcoming presidential debates. The debates will be a crucial opportunity for Romney to change the current narrative and present his vision for the economy. The debates will also provide a chance for voters to evaluate the candidates' Likability and make their decision before the election.

Title: Senate Republicans and Democrats Negotiate Stimulus Package Details as Coronavirus Aid Bill Progresses

Article:

In a bid to alleviate the economic impact of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, Senate Republicans released a $1-trillion economic stimulus plan last Thursday. The proposal includes a $1,200 payment for each individual or $2,400 for joint returns, with an additional $500 for each qualifying child. However, Senate Democrats have blocked the bill, expressing concerns over its corporate-friendly provisions and insufficient support for working families.

As negotiations continue, Senate Democrats have outlined several key requirements to pass the bill. These include:

1. Invoking the Defense Production Act by President Donald Trump to compel private companies to manufacture essential medical equipment such as respirators and masks.
2. Allocating nearly $40 billion to help states maintain school funding and support colleges during the crisis.
3. Providing billions in grant funding to states for holding elections, with a focus on expanding early, absentee, and mail voting.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer expressed optimism about reaching a deal, stating, "We're very close to reaching a deal... Our goal is to reach a deal today. And we’re hopeful, even confident, that we will meet that goal." However, Schumer emphasized the importance of getting the details right.

The current proposal suggests individuals would receive up to $1,200 (or $2,400 for joint returns) with no less than $600 (or $1,200 for joint returns). Families would receive an additional $500 for each qualifying child. The income limit for individuals is set at $75,000, and $150,000 for joint returns. The amount individuals receive would be reduced by 5% for every dollar of income exceeding these thresholds.

The federal government is expected to use tax filings to determine eligibility for stimulus checks. Filing 2019 taxes is encouraged, and receiving a refund or owing money to the Internal Revenue Service will not affect the stimulus check. The current proposal is for a one-time lump sum payment, but a second stimulus check could still be considered if economic conditions do not improve.

Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin has stated that, once Congress passes the bill, the payments will be distributed within three weeks. However, specific dates are subject to change during the appropriations process in Congress. Individuals with direct deposit set up with the IRS can expect their payments sooner than those who receive checks by mail.

The last time the federal government sent checks to Americans was in 2008, under President George W. Bush, with the Economic Stimulus Act providing tax rebates of up to $600 for individuals and $1,200 for married couples, with additional rebates for families with children. The payments did not start until late April.

The aid package signed by Trump on Wednesday, known as "phase two," includes paid sick and family leave, free coronavirus testing, and enhanced unemployment insurance. Student loan interest payments are also on hold, with payments suspended until further notice. The Department of Housing and Urban Development has also announced it will suspend foreclosures and evictions on FHA-insured mortgages.

As the situation evolves, it is essential to stay informed about the latest financial assistance efforts from the government. For updates on your money and personal finance advice, sign up here.

Title: California's AB5 Bill Threatens to Reshape Gig Economy, Heads to Governor's Desk

Article:

California lawmakers have passed a significant bill, Assembly Bill 5 (AB5), which could potentially transform the business models of companies like Uber and Lyft. The bill, which was passed in the state Assembly on Wednesday and now heads to Democratic California Governor Gavin Newsom's desk, aims to reclassify gig economy workers as employees instead of contractors.

The legislation, authored by Assemblywoman Lorena Gonzalez (D-San Diego), passed in the state Assembly in a 61-16 vote. It follows the bill's passage in the state Senate on Tuesday.

Uber and Lyft, however, maintain that AB5 will not immediately change the status of independent contractors to employees. Tony West, Uber's chief legal officer, stated on a call with reporters that the bill builds on legal tests already established in California regarding worker classification. West suggested that drivers may not necessarily fall under the new rules outlined in AB5.

Under the three-part test, companies must prove that contractors are doing work "outside the usual course" of their business. West explained that several previous rulings have found that drivers' work is outside the usual course of Uber's business, which is serving as a technology platform for various digital marketplaces.

West stated that Uber intends to comply with AB5 should it become law next year, but the company will continue to argue that it does not fall under the bill's legal framework. He warned that unsuccessful challenges to AB5 could result in costs to Uber's business.

Uber and Lyft have informed drivers that they may need to implement shifts if workers are classified as employees. This would limit when ride-hailing drivers can start and stop accepting rides. In a notice to drivers, Lyft also stated that drivers might only be allowed to work for one ride-hailing service at a time.

West noted that there would be significant changes in the way drivers interact with the platform, and these changes are not ones that drivers would welcome, according to their feedback. He added that he was encouraged by Governor Newsom's efforts to negotiate a solution on the bill.

Newsom told The Wall Street Journal on Wednesday that he is still engaged in talks with Uber, Lyft, and other gig economy companies about possible negotiations around the bill. Newsom is expected to sign the bill, after voicing support for it earlier this month.

The bill has received broad support from Democratic presidential candidates, including Senators Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.), Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), and Kamala Harris (D-Calif.), as well as South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg.

AB5 has the potential to change the employment status of more than 1 million low-wage workers in California, not just gig workers at companies like Uber, Lyft, DoorDash, Postmates, and Instacart. The bill aims to make it harder for gig economy companies to prove that their workers are not employees, while ensuring key benefits and protections, such as minimum wage, insurance, and sick days.

AB5 has faced strong opposition from gig economy companies, as it could disrupt their traditional business model of hiring inexpensive contractors. In an attempt to counter the bill, Uber and Lyft proposed establishing a $21-an-hour minimum wage for drivers in California. The ride-hailing companies, as well as DoorDash, have also pledged $90 million on a ballot initiative for the 2020 election that would exempt them from AB5.

West stated that Uber is open to investing more in the initiative and is working to include other businesses facing similar issues with AB5. The $90 million will be used to "hire the best campaign team and best advisors we possibly can to run a successful ballot initiative," he added.

Lyft spokesperson Adrian Durbin stated that the bill has the potential to negatively impact drivers who prefer a flexible work schedule.

Title: Possibility of New Charges Against Paul Manafort as Mueller's Team Reveals Alleged Lies

In a significant development, Special Counsel Robert Mueller's team has left open the possibility of filing new charges against former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort for alleged lies during his interviews with the special counsel's office. Manafort's legal team has stated that he maintains his honesty during these interactions.

The filing, signed by Andrew Weissmann, a prosecutor known for his aggressive approach, was made on a busy week for Mueller's team. On the same day, they also filed a recommendation for the sentencing of Michael Cohen, President Trump's former lawyer, accompanied by a scathing attack from prosecutors in Manhattan who accused Cohen of using his power and influence for deceptive ends.

The prosecutors sought a prison term of approximately four years for Cohen when he is sentenced next week for lying to Congress about the extent of President Trump's business dealings in Moscow, as well as for campaign finance violations and other charges.

Manafort, convicted in August of eight counts of financial fraud in a Virginia court, initially agreed to a plea deal on the brink of a second trial. However, the special counsel's office later declared that he had violated the plea agreement.

The filing also revealed that prosecutors have previously accused the Russian, Konstantin V. Kilimnik, whom Manafort is alleged to have been in touch with, of ties to Russian intelligence. Kilimnik, a Russian Army-trained linguist, served as Manafort's right-hand man in Ukraine for over a decade, working on behalf of the country's Russia-aligned former president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, his party, and the oligarchs behind it.

In Friday's filing, prosecutors blacked out much of the information related to Kilimnik, but they did reveal that some of it had been uncovered in emails and testimony. They claimed that Manafort lied about various interactions and meetings with him, as well as about his involvement with witnesses who might testify against Manafort.

Title: DNC Steps in to Assist Iowa Democratic Party in Caucus Result Verification Following App Malfunction

Article:
