In the aftermath of Monday's botched Iowa caucus count, the Democratic National Committee (DNC) has taken an active role in verifying the results, as state party officials continue to grapple with the fallout from the malfunctioning app designed to streamline the caucus result reporting process.

According to a report by ABC News, DNC staffers have been contacting leaders of each precinct to verify the results. Polk County Democratic chairman Sean Bagniewski and Des Moines precinct chairman Carl Voss, among others, have confirmed these contacts. They stated that this level of DNC involvement in the caucus process is unprecedented.

DNC chairman Tom Perez addressed the situation in a series of tweets on Tuesday evening. He stated that DNC staffers were "assisting" the Iowa Democratic Party (IDP) in an effort to release the results as quickly and accurately as possible. Perez emphasized the importance of accuracy and the need to ensure that all votes are counted.

The IDP has been in disarray since Monday night, when the app commissioned by the IDP and developed by Shadow Inc. failed to function properly, causing problems for precinct chairs as they attempted to download or log into the app to report their caucus results. As of Wednesday afternoon, only 71 percent of results had been released by the IDP, and IDP chairman Troy Price has refused to provide a timeline for the release of the remaining 29 percent of results.

"We're going to take the time we need to get these results done," Price said Tuesday.

A spokesperson for the DNC could not be reached for comment by The Post. The ongoing situation in Iowa is a significant development in the Democratic primary race, as it is the first contest in the nomination process. The delay in releasing the full results could have implications for the frontrunners in the race.

Title: Ohio's White Male Voters Favor Bernie Sanders in Democratic Primary

Article:

In the ongoing Democratic primary race, Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders has garnered significant support from white male voters in Ohio, a trend that could potentially propel him to victory in the state's primary election. This demographic played a crucial role in Sanders' win in Michigan last week, and if he manages to secure a victory in Ohio, their support will likely be instrumental once again.

Jim, a union member who asked to remain anonymous due to his union's endorsement of Hillary Clinton, expressed his support for Sanders. "We're pissed off," Jim said. "We haven't gotten raises. Our pensions have been cut. Our healthcare's increased." He added, "Bernie, he speaks from the trenches."

In Michigan, Sanders won the support of 62 percent of white men, who made up one-third of voters, according to exit polls. In the 2008 Democratic primary in Ohio, white men turned out in strikingly similar proportions. However, black voters could make up a smaller proportion of the electorate and may not be enough to secure a win for Clinton. In Michigan, Clinton won more than two-thirds of black voters and they were 21 percent of the electorate. In 2008, Barack Obama won nearly 90 percent of black voters in Ohio, and they were 18 percent of the electorate. Clinton won the state with the support of white voters, including white men.

Ryan, a member of a building trades union in Cleveland, also expressed support for Sanders. He, too, asked not to use his last name because his union has endorsed Clinton. "She's [Clinton] seen as the centrist candidate," Ryan said. "And she's a big-money candidate. And big money and centrism hasn't been working for middle-class America for the past 30 years."

Sanders' appeal to working-class men is evident in his stance on trade deals and healthcare costs, issues that resonate with these voters. In Michigan, Sanders overwhelmingly won voters who thought trade deals cost American jobs, and he won them 2-to-1. Jim, the union member from Michigan, has only received one raise in eight years.

The money issue is also a concern for Dave Passalacqua, executive vice president of the Communications Workers of America Local 4340 in Cleveland. His union has endorsed Sanders, but he is still undecided. "There's that old saying: politicians should be like NASCAR, everyone wear their patch," Passalacqua said. "You know, let's see what the patches are, and [Sanders] doesn't need to wear a patch, because it's his own thing."

Passalacqua, Jim, and Ryan discussed these issues at a union hall in Cleveland. Despite their support for Sanders, they are realistic about his chances of winning the presidency. "It's pie in the sky," said Jim Goggin, a labor community organizer. "I mean, everything Bernie says, I think would be fantastic. But the fact of the matter is, that I am also a realist, and I know that you can't do that."

All four men agreed that they would support the Democratic nominee in November, regardless of who wins the primary. Passalacqua, however, expressed a struggle between his head and his heart, unsure if Sanders can deliver on his promises. "Whoever I think is going best for me and my family is the bottom line," Passalacqua said. "Whoever is going to make—not to steal Donald's line—but America great again, because in order to make America great again, we've got to make the middle class great again. So whoever's going to do that, I think's going to be the best person. And that's who I'll end up having to vote for."

Title: A Balanced Approach to COVID-19 Reopening: The Controlled Avalanche Strategy

Article:

As the United States grapples with the question of how to safely reopen society amidst the COVID-19 pandemic, a clear divide in opinions has emerged. However, the majority of Americans, according to polling data, are not advocating for a swift reopening or a prolonged lockdown, but rather a measured, considered approach. This article explores the concept of a controlled avalanche strategy, a potential solution that balances public health concerns with economic recovery.

The controlled avalanche strategy, coined by Israeli scientists, suggests a phased reopening of society, prioritizing the protection of vulnerable populations while allowing less vulnerable individuals to develop immunity. This approach aims to reduce deaths, conserve resources, and accelerate the return to normalcy.

The strategy hinges on making assumptions about the progress of therapeutics, vaccines, and the economic impact of social distancing measures. If we assume that no significant therapeutics will be available in the near future, that vaccines may take 18 months or more to develop, and that the economy cannot function at reduced capacity, then a controlled avalanche strategy may be the most viable option.

The strategy's proponents argue that by prioritizing the protection of the elderly and vulnerable, and allowing herd immunity to develop among the least vulnerable, overall mortality could be significantly reduced. For instance, data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows that, as of late April, only 1,036 of the 37,308 recorded COVID-19 deaths in the U.S. were individuals under the age of 45, and just 51 were below the age of 25.

Furthermore, the strategy could reduce the maximum number of people requiring intensive care units (ICUs) by over 60% and shorten the time needed to allow low-risk populations to return to normal activities by several months. This strategy is not foolproof, but it offers a potential path forward that balances public health and economic concerns.

In conclusion, the controlled avalanche strategy is a considered approach to reopening society that prioritizes the protection of vulnerable populations while allowing herd immunity to develop among the least vulnerable. This strategy may offer a more balanced solution to the COVID-19 pandemic, striking a delicate balance between public health and economic recovery.

Title: Trump Administration's Decision to Abandon ACA Could Affect Pre-Existing Condition Protections, Intensifying Healthcare Debate in Election Year

Article:

The Trump administration's decision to abandon the Affordable Care Act (ACA) in an ongoing court challenge could potentially impact some of the most popular aspects of the law, further escalating the contentious debate over healthcare during an election year. This move could particularly affect provisions that ban insurance companies from denying coverage to individuals with pre-existing conditions, a component that is widely regarded as the most popular part of the 2010 health care law.

The lawsuit, led by Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, was initiated in February by 20 states against the federal government, claiming the individual mandate is unconstitutional following the elimination of the tax penalty for not having health insurance in the 2017 tax cut law. The lawsuit argues that without the individual mandate, the entirety of the ACA, commonly known as Obamacare, is unconstitutional.

According to the Department of Health and Human Services, as many as 130 million adults under the age of 65 in the U.S. have pre-existing conditions that could potentially prevent them from obtaining insurance coverage in the private market. The Kaiser Family Foundation estimates that about a quarter of the country's under-65 population has pre-existing conditions. A Kaiser tracking poll in June 2017 showed that 70% of adults want Congress to maintain pre-existing condition protections.

Before the ACA became law, insurance companies frequently denied health insurance coverage to individuals with ongoing medical conditions or recent illnesses. Even when insurance policies were offered to those with health problems, they often excluded those illnesses. Furthermore, insurance companies could cancel coverage for individuals who became ill once the policy year ended. The ACA made all these practices illegal.

By withdrawing from defending the law in court, the Trump administration is effectively stating that it no longer supports these consumer protections, which are popular with voters. This move could disrupt insurance markets for the upcoming year and alter the dynamics of this fall's elections.

Larry Levitt, senior vice president at the Kaiser Family Foundation, stated, "This suit comes as insurers are proposing individual market premiums for 2019. The lawsuit injects more uncertainty into what is already an uncertain environment for insurers. Insurers hate uncertainty, and they respond to it by hedging their bets and increasing premiums."

Nicholas Bagley, a professor at the University of Michigan Law School who was previously a Justice Department lawyer, expressed concern over the department's move. "The Justice Department has a long-standing, durable, bipartisan commitment to defend acts of Congress. It's a cornerstone of what they do," he said. "For the Trump administration to crumple that up and throw it out the window is galling."

Just hours before the Justice Department officially withdrew from the case, three of the staff attorneys who had been working on it withdrew. Bagley noted that these attorneys are civil servants who are not political and are dedicated to defending federal programs. "They believed they could not, in good conscience, consistent with their professional obligations, sign the brief. These are people who defend programs they disagree with all the time," Bagley said, adding that he has not spoken with any of them about the case.

The Justice Department has opted not to defend existing law in court in other matters as well. For instance, in 2012, the Obama Justice Department stated it would not defend the Defense of Marriage Act, which legally defined marriage as a union between a man and a woman for federal purposes.

America's Health Insurance Plans, the trade association for health insurance companies, supports the pre-existing condition protections under the ACA. "Removing those provisions will result in renewed uncertainty in the individual market, create a patchwork of requirements in the states, cause rates to go even higher for older Americans and sicker patients, and make it challenging to introduce products and rates for 2019," AHIP said in a statement.

AHIP plans to file an amicus brief in support of the law that "provides more detail about the harm that would come to millions of Americans if the request to invalidate the ACA is granted in whole or in part."

On Capitol Hill, congressional Republicans' reaction to the Trump administration's decision was muted, with many lawmakers expressing skepticism that the courts would ultimately rule against a law already upheld by the Supreme Court.

"We need to let that go forward and see if it goes anywhere," said Rep. Tom MacArthur, R-N.J. "I do not know if that legal logic will fly or not." MacArthur worked on legislation to continue pre-existing condition protections during the GOP's unsuccessful effort to repeal Obamacare last year.

Healthcare is already a significant issue in this year's elections, with voters regularly citing it as a leading determinant for how they will vote. "There is no doubt that Republicans are responsible for the rising cost of healthcare premiums and the high likelihood that many will no longer be able to afford basic care at all, and they will face serious blowback in the midterms," the House Democrats' campaign operation said in a statement.

Title: CNN's Brian Stelter Critiques Republican Candidates' Media Bashing and Political Polarization

Article:

In a piece aired during Thursday's AC360, CNN's senior media correspondent, Brian Stelter, discussed the tactic of Republican presidential candidates attacking the liberal media to deflect tough questions and cause further political polarization in the electorate.

Stelter began by acknowledging that the claim of media bias is a tool often used by Republican politicians to shield themselves from difficult questions. He suggested that this is not because the liberal media is inherently biased, but rather a strategy to deflect unwanted inquiries, display strength, and put the press on the defensive.

During the CNBC debate on Wednesday night, Stelter noted, several candidates demonstrated the effectiveness of media bashing, making it an easy applause line for conservative audiences.

Stelter argued that while most journalists strive to eliminate any bias from their stories, many conservatives remain skeptical. He further criticized conservatives for contributing to political polarization in America by refusing to engage with the media.

According to Pew, the more conservative an individual is, the less they trust mainstream media sources. Fox News and some candidates have benefited from this distrust, Stelter pointed out. On Thursday, several candidates declared war on the liberal media, soliciting funds while mocking the moderators.

Stelter questioned whether CNBC's questions were harsher than those from Fox or CNN. He concluded by quoting University of Virginia's Larry Sabato, who defended the CNBC moderators for attempting to uncover the truth. Sabato stated, "Some of the criticism is for show. What those moderators at CNBC were trying to do was to get candidates to tell more of the truth."

The relevant transcript from CNN's Anderson Cooper 360 on October 29 can be found below.

Title: North Korea Conducts Most Powerful Nuclear Test to Date, Escalating Tensions with U.S.

Article:

North Korea has conducted its most powerful nuclear test to date, marking a significant escalation in tensions with the United States. The test, which took place on September 3, was confirmed by the US Geological Survey following a 6.3-magnitude earthquake at North Korea's Punggye-ri testing site.

Experts estimate the device yielded approximately 100 kilotons, making it around seven times stronger than the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima in 1945. This was North Korea's sixth nuclear test and its first under the Trump administration.

Hours before the test, the Korean Central News Agency (KCNA), North Korea's state-run media organization, released images of the country's leader, Kim Jong Un, overseeing the loading of a hydrogen bomb onto an intercontinental ballistic missile.

Following the test, KCNA stated that the test was conducted to "examine and confirm the accuracy and credibility" of the weapon. Jeffrey Lewis, an expert on North Korea's missile program at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies, told reporters that North Korea's goal is to target the United States.

"North Korea wants the ability to target the United States," Lewis said. "A thermonuclear weapon does more damage. This bomb can do quite a bit of damage." Vipin Narang, a nuclear expert at MIT, concurred, stating that with relatively inaccurate intercontinental ballistic missile technology, North Korea could destroy a significant portion of a city with this yield.

President Donald Trump expressed his displeasure with the development via Twitter, stating, "North Korea has conducted a major Nuclear Test. Their words and actions continue to be very hostile and dangerous to the United States."

Secretary of Defense James Mattis offered a stern warning to North Korea after a meeting of national security leaders with the president. "Any threat to the United States or its territories, including Guam, or our allies, will be met with a massive military response—a response both effective and overwhelming," Mattis said.

Regional allies South Korea and Japan also responded strongly to the test. South Korean President Moon Jae-in convened a meeting of his national security team, and his national security adviser, Chung Eui-yong, stated that Seoul wants the "most powerful sanctions" placed on North Korea at the United Nations.

Japan issued a statement of disapproval, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stating, "It is absolutely unacceptable if North Korea did force another nuclear test, and we must protest strongly."

On August 29, North Korea launched a missile into Japanese airspace, which eventually landed about 733 miles east of the country. "We have to say that this morning's launch by the North is the most serious and grave threat ever to us," Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga said afterward.

It remains unclear if the Japanese government finds North Korea's latest nuclear test more threatening than the missile launch.

While Trump could respond with a military strike, it is still unlikely. The Trump administration still prefers a diplomatic approach toward Pyongyang in hopes that it would give up its nuclear weapons. However, it is unclear what incentive North Korea has to stop its nuclear program, especially now that it has tested a powerful hydrogen bomb. This will make it much harder for Trump to strike a deal with the North.

Title: Federal Aid to States: Ensuring Fiscal Responsibility and Protecting Taxpayers

Article:

In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, Illinois state workers received an automatic pay raise on July 1, a move that will cost taxpayers $261 million. This decision comes as nearly 1.4 million Illinoisans have filed for unemployment since the economic shutdown in March.

While other state governments have recognized the need to pare back demands on taxpayers amid major revenue shortfalls, Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker has signed a budget that increases spending by $2.4 billion over last year and relies on $5 billion from a nonexistent federal bailout to partially close a $6 billion deficit.

This continued disregard for basic fiscal responsibility has raised concerns about the potential for state bailouts. Congress is currently considering further aid to state and local governments, with another coronavirus relief package expected to move this month.

The debate over state aid has polarized many, with some on the right philosophically opposed to offering any aid, while the left advocates for pumping in as much as $1 trillion without regard to the amount of money actually needed or how those funds are safeguarded.

However, there is a compromise solution that would avoid rewarding irresponsible behavior in troubled states. Congress can offer more aid, but if—and only if—it’s conditioned on sound financial management to protect taxpayers from tax increases or service failures.

Attaching "strings" to financial rescues is already the norm across the world, as seen in the relief packages that followed the 2010 Greek debt crisis, the 2007-2009 U.S. bank bailouts, and most recently, the corporate financial assistance under the recently passed CARES Act. Without conditions, there's no way to ensure good money isn't thrown after bad to be squandered by those with a history of misusing funds.

The federal government should follow this best practice as it debates further support for states such as Illinois, New Jersey, and Connecticut, which have built up crushing debt burdens through decades of bad decisions unrelated to COVID-19. Funding should be conditioned on three hallmarks of healthy state finances: sound pensions, truly balanced budgets, and sufficient rainy-day savings.

First, states must be on a path to fully eliminating unfunded pension liabilities over no more than 25 years, in line with generally accepted actuarial principles. If a state can't achieve this, pension liabilities should be reduced to the level the state can afford without increasing employer contributions, i.e., taxpayer costs. States where legacy systems are unsound should be required to close those systems to new employees in exchange for more sustainable models such as a defined contribution plan or Wisconsin-style risk-sharing system.

Next, any state receiving funds should be asked to maintain a truly balanced budget, meaning the fiscal year ends in the black and no deficits are carried over. Illinois is one of just 11 states that doesn't require end-of-year balance by state law or constitution. The requirement calls for the planned budget to be balanced on paper, but what actually happens is irrelevant. Balance should also mean only money actually coming in gets counted as revenue, rather than allowing for Illinois-style gimmicks such as sweeping money from other state funds or relying on short-term borrowing to paper over deficits.

Lastly, states should have restrictions on rainy-day fund withdrawals to ensure they're only used in an emergency and have rules for automatic deposits when the economy returns to growth. The federal government should not be expected to bail out states in every future recession, and that means states must have sufficient emergency savings of their own.

Without these reforms and proof of effort by state governments, fiscally irresponsible states would use aid money in an inefficient and ineffective manner—just as they've done with their own mismanaged funds for decades.

Federal lawmakers have a tremendous opportunity in front of them: They can provide aid to ensure the people have access to essential government services while encouraging mismanaged states to fix their tumbledown fiscal houses.

Title: Minneapolis Business Owner's Dream Turns to Ruins as Protests and Looting Sweep Through City

Article:

In a heart-wrenching turn of events, Korboi Balla, a black firefighter who had invested his life savings into opening a sports bar in Minneapolis, found his dreams shattered as widespread rioting and looting in the city destroyed his life's work.

Originally planning to open his bar in March, Balla had been preparing to finally open his bar after Minnesota gave the go-ahead for restaurants to begin reopening on June 1. However, by Friday morning, Balla's bar was little more than a pile of bricks following protests sparked by the death of George Floyd, an unarmed black man who died in Minneapolis police custody on Monday.

"I don't know what we're going to do," Korboi Balla told CBS News on Thursday morning, fighting back tears. "It hurts, man. It's not fair, it's not right. We've been working so hard for this place. It's not just for me, it's for my family."

As CBS reporters were interviewing Balla on Thursday morning, looters attempted to break into his bar to steal the safe. Balla's wife, Twyana Balla, shared this harrowing experience in a Facebook post on Thursday.

"As we were standing in front of the restaurant, people were in the back trying to steal the safe!" she wrote. "This just happened an hour ago in broad daylight!"

Twyana Balla added in the post that they do not have insurance for their business.

"I'm hearing people say F*** the business they have insurance, well, we don't, and this is all out of pocket," she wrote. "Let someone come run in your home and loot for the cause then let's see you be ok with it!"

"Justice for George Floyd but not this kind of justice," she wrote.

By Friday morning, Twyana Balla reported in a video posted to Facebook that her husband's restaurant had been reduced to a pile of bricks.

"There must have been an explosion because the whole front part of the building is gone," she said.

In response to the devastating loss, Balla launched a GoFundMe campaign on Thursday to raise funds to rebuild his bar. The crowdfunding campaign has brought in over $173,000 for the small business owner in its first 24 hours.

Over 170 businesses in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area have been damaged or looted since Floyd's death on Monday, police told the Twin Cities Pioneer Press.

Title: "Clinton Campaign Faces Unexpected Challenge as Email Scandal Resurfaces, Threatening a Smooth Election Path for the Democratic Nominee"

Article:

In the final week of one of the most unpredictable and contentious presidential campaigns in modern history, Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton finds herself on the defensive as the FBI revisits the issue of her private email server. The discovery of new emails on the computer of her longtime aide Huma Abedin's estranged husband, Anthony Weiner, has brought the issue back to the forefront, potentially altering the course of the election.

The FBI's review of the emails has revived a controversy that has dogged Clinton since the beginning of her campaign. Democrats are furious with FBI Director James Comey for reopening the investigation, while Republican nominee Donald Trump is seizing the opportunity to unite a GOP that has been divided by his controversial candidacy.

The latest polls suggest a tightening race, with Clinton leading by a margin of five points according to CNN's Poll of Polls. However, the email scandal has cast a shadow over Clinton's campaign, and her plans for a smooth run-up to Election Day have been disrupted.

Clinton's campaign is now focusing on turning the spotlight back on Trump, in line with her campaign-long effort to brand him as unfit for the presidency. Clinton's campaign chairman, John Podesta, has called on Comey to explain why he took the unprecedented step of reopening the investigation.

In the coming days, Clinton will travel to Florida and Ohio, where she is in a tight race with Trump, and North Carolina, where she is leading. By winning any one of those states, Clinton can block Trump's path to the presidency. She will also make a foray into Arizona, a traditionally red state that appears competitive a week out.

Clinton will also lean on her superior ground game and polling that suggests she still has several routes to surpass the 270 electoral votes she needs. She will dispatch former President Bill Clinton, President Barack Obama, and First Lady Michelle Obama to battleground states, leveraging her advantage over Trump, who lacks such high-profile surrogates.

However, there are nervous days ahead. Clinton will now live in fear of another damaging twist to the email saga, more campaign inside gossip from the WikiLeaks hack of John Podesta's email account, and the release of more Clinton emails from the State Department scheduled for Friday.

Many Democrats believe the character issue is already baked into polls that show Clinton is the favorite to win the election. But her plans for a smooth run-in to Election Day are in tatters, and her campaign has been forced into a tactical shift, unleashing its full fury on the FBI chief.

For the moment, Clinton is using the move as a rallying cry to drive up Democratic turnout. "There have been ups and downs in all that we have gone through over the years and even in this campaign, but I want you to know I am focused on one thing: you," Clinton told supporters in Florida on Sunday. "There's a lot of noise and distraction, but really comes down to what kind of future we want."

Trump, on the other hand, must also improve his position on the political map to mount a stunning comeback on November 8. He must forge ahead in Florida and Ohio, cut his deficit to Clinton in North Carolina, capitalize on an advantage in Iowa, then find a way to put states like New Hampshire and Nevada, that went for Obama, in play. He could carve out a decisive edge by making a big blue state like Pennsylvania or Michigan competitive, though polls suggest that is a long shot.

But Trump's team must also be wondering, even as they salivate over Clinton's woes, if there is one last big shock awaiting Trump, following October Surprise controversies over claims he sexually assaulted women and an "Access Hollywood" tape exposing his lewd language that left him so far behind his rival that he starts the campaign's last week possibly too far behind to catch up.

Title: Terrorism and Cultural Tensions: A Comparative Analysis of the U.S. and France in the Wake of Recent Attacks

Article:

In the aftermath of the Orlando shooting, the U.S. and France find themselves grappling with the devastating consequences of terrorism, with the former experiencing Islamic extremist terrorism in San Bernardino and Orlando, and the latter suffering from a series of ISIS-coordinated attacks. This article aims to provide a neutral, factual, and informative analysis of the current state of terrorism in both countries, focusing on the unique challenges they face and the cultural tensions that have arisen as a result.

The recent wave of Islamic extremist violence has left a profound impact on both societies, instilling a sense of unease and insecurity. The U.S., having experienced 9/11, San Bernardino, and Orlando, is grappling with the aftermath of the most catastrophic terrorist attack in history. Meanwhile, France, which has been the epicenter for ISIS-coordinated terrorism, is in the midst of a homegrown Islamic terrorism crisis.

While the U.S. has a history of mass killings, the current threat of Islamic extremism is a new and chilling development. Terrorist attacks, whether perpetrated by lone wolves or extremist groups, are becoming increasingly common, targeting civilians as they go about their daily lives. The recent attacks in Paris, Brussels, and Nice are stark reminders of this global phenomenon.

France's history in the Middle East, particularly in Syria and Algeria, and its traditional cultural intolerance have contributed to the current crisis. The country's large Muslim population and its insistence on strict cultural assimilation have created a combustible mixture in a dangerous time. In contrast, the U.S., despite its history of xenophobia and nativism, has generally been successful in assimilating immigrants, with Muslims being an integral part of American society for many decades.

However, the post-9/11 era has seen a shift in public perception of Muslims, with profiling, investigations, and protests against the building of mosques becoming more common. The U.S. has not experienced the same level of organized radicalism as France, but the underlying commitment to diversity remains, albeit hanging by a thread.

France's response to its homegrown Islamic terrorism crisis is a matter of concern, with some advocating for draconian solutions. In the U.S., the political landscape is dominated by figures like Donald Trump, who has proposed a ban on Muslims and the construction of a wall to keep out immigrants from Mexico and Central America.

The future of both countries hinges on their ability to navigate these cultural tensions and address the threat of terrorism without resorting to draconian measures. The key to ending this violence lies not in military intervention or increased authoritarianism, but in fostering a global sense of solidarity and empathy, as the world comes together in the face of shared tragedy. The more violence these extremists inflict, the more they sow the seeds of their own demise, as the human population unites in the face of their divisive tactics.

Title: "Political Divisions and Internal Strife: A Look at the Potential Future of the Democratic and Republican Parties"

Article:

In the aftermath of the 2016 presidential election, political analysts and pundits have been discussing the future of both the Democratic and Republican parties. In a recent appearance on Meet the Press, New York Times columnist Thomas Friedman suggested that the Republican Party might need to "crash and burn" to give way to a more moderate, sane version of the party.

However, this idea of encouraging a Republican civil war is not without its critics. While it is true that the GOP's internal divide is large, particularly following the Donald Trump campaign, some argue that such a divisive approach could lead to further chaos and destruction within the party.

But what is often overlooked in these discussions is the potential for a similar civil war within the Democratic Party. If a Democrat resides in the White House, especially an unpopular one like Hillary Clinton, their own chaos could be at least as messy, public, and internally destructive as anything the GOP might face.

One of the main sources of this potential internal strife is the ongoing tension between Hillary Clinton and her primary challenger, Senator Bernie Sanders. Sanders and his supporters feel that the Democratic National Committee rigged the primary process against him, and this belief was reinforced by the WikiLeaks revelations that pointed to this fact. The resignation of Debbie Wasserman Schultz over the first revelation, and the likely forced resignation of Donna Brazile over the second, are indicative of the deep-seated dissatisfaction within the party.

Sanders has also announced that he will be "vigorously in opposition" to government action, including laws or policies not sufficiently leftist, which could put him at odds with Clinton on a number of issues. This tension could be further exacerbated by the presence of Senator Elizabeth Warren, who has a strong following among the furthest-left part of the Democratic Party base and has a similar economic policy agenda to Sanders.

Another area of potential conflict is the selection of Supreme Court nominees. If Democrats take control of the Senate in January, Hillary Clinton might face the difficult task of finding a nominee who can garner the support of both the Sanders-Warren wing of the party and enough Republicans to gain confirmation. This could result in a nominee who is further left than desired, leading to a filibuster, or a nominee who is further right, leading to a contentious confirmation process and potential backlash from the progressive wing of the party.

Finally, it is worth noting that a vocal minority of the Democratic base, including many who supported Green Party candidate Jill Stein, are ideologically opposed to much of Clinton's agenda. This group is likely to be a source of opposition and conflict throughout Clinton's presidency, particularly on the issues they care most deeply about.

In conclusion, while the idea of a Republican civil war is a popular topic of discussion among Democratic elites, it is important to recognize that the Democratic Party could also face significant internal strife if a Democrat is elected president. The potential for conflict between Hillary Clinton and her primary challengers, as well as the ideological divisions within the party, could lead to a tumultuous and divisive presidency.

Title: New York Governor's Remarks on Human Life Value Sparks Debate on Abortion Policies

Article:

In a recent press conference, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, while discussing the state's gradual reopening, posed a thought-provoking question: "How much is a human life worth?" This question, though initially in the context of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, has sparked a broader discussion on the value of human life, particularly in relation to abortion policies in New York.

During the conference, Cuomo stated, "That is the real discussion that no one is admitting, openly or freely. That we should. To me, I say the cost of a human life—a human life is priceless. Period."

This statement has led to a renewed focus on the inconsistencies in New York's policies, particularly regarding abortion. The discussion has highlighted issues such as nursing home practices, the continued operation of abortion clinics, and the state's recent expansion of legal abortion.

The governor's comments have also prompted reflection on the value of human life from various perspectives. Some argue that the inconsistencies in policies, such as the operation of abortion clinics during a pandemic, undermine the governor's assertion that human life is priceless.

Organizations like the Sisters of Life, based in New York, have long been advocates for the sanctity of human life. They emphasize the priceless nature of life, a gift from a Creator who loves and values each individual. The Sisters of Life have been approached by women, including those inside abortion clinics, who feel they have no choice but to terminate their pregnancies.

The debate has led to calls for open and honest discussions about abortion, with some advocating for an end to euphemisms and a focus on the real-life experiences of women. The Sisters of Life, in particular, have urged for a shift from a culture of death to a culture of life, where every human life is valued and protected.

Governor Cuomo's question has indeed sparked a conversation, and it remains to be seen how this discussion will shape New York's policies moving forward. The debate underscores the complexities and nuances surrounding the value of human life, and the need for open, honest, and consistent discussions on these issues.

Title: Dreamers Express Disappointment as Democratic Leaders Delay Immigration Legislation Until January

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Dreamers, undocumented immigrants who were brought to the U.S. as children, have expressed their disillusionment with Democratic leaders for failing to force a government shutdown showdown this week over demands to pass the Dream Act by the end of the year. Congressional leaders signaled Wednesday that they will revisit the immigration issue early next year and vowed to complete legislation in January.

Hundreds of Dreamers, some risking arrest, took to the halls of Congress to march and conduct sit-ins in office corridors to express their frustration that they have been overlooked. "We want Dream Act," protesters chanted, referring to a bill that would grant temporary legal status to more than 2 million illegal immigrants and allow 1.7 million of them to earn green cards, signifying permanent legal presence, according to the Migration Policy Institute.

Final negotiations were ongoing late Wednesday over the shape of a year-end package of bills. Democratic leaders insisted the Dream Act is still part of negotiations, but Republican aides said Democrats signaled days ago that it wasn't one of the major sticking points. The pieces that are in play include an extension of the government's chief foreign intelligence communications surveillance program, disaster relief for states and U.S. territories affected by this year's hurricanes, and a renewal of the Children's Health Insurance Program, a federal-state health program for children whose parents are too wealthy to qualify for Medicaid but too poor to afford their own insurance.

The biggest moving part, however, is a year-end spending bill needed to avoid a government shutdown when current funding expires Friday. House Republicans have proposed full-year funding for the Defense Department coupled with a four-week extension of current funding for domestic needs, known as a "continuing resolution." That continuing resolution would force all sides to revisit the domestic programs in January.

Democrats have said they won't accept that and insist on parity between defense and domestic programs in order to dole out money for veterans' health, a pension bailout, opioid-fighting programs, and medical research. As of late Wednesday, House Republican leaders were still trying to figure out a path forward. Democrats said they were waiting for Republicans.

"Unless we see a respect for our values and priorities, we continue to urge a strong NO on the continuing resolution," House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, California Democrat, wrote in a letter to her troops.

Rank-and-file Republicans complained that Democrats were pushing Congress toward a government shutdown by threatening an all-or-nothing Senate filibuster. "The American people sent us the Republican majorities in the House, the Senate, and the White House. And we have to get eight votes on the Democrat side, and we should compromise, right? But it should be proportional to Democratic Senate votes," said Rep. Dave Brat, Virginia Republican.

"That is the crux of the issue," he said. "They get a fair compromise, but they don't get to control the Republican agenda."

Usually, it's Republicans facing calls for a shutdown showdown from their right flank. But the Dreamers flipped the script, forcing Democrats into a tight spot by demanding a permanent fix after President Trump announced a phaseout of the Obama-era Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals deportation amnesty. Mr. Trump's phaseout kicks in March 5, but Dreamers set an artificial end-of-year deadline, and Democratic leaders initially agreed that, though some of them have backed off their red line.

Rep. Luis V. Gutierrez, an Illinois Democrat who has been a leading voice for Dreamers, said he believed his party's leaders in the House were holding firm in their DACA demand and that some Senate Democrats were also adamant. But he was less sure about Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer, New York Democrat. "I believe that at this particular moment, the onus is on Sen. Schumer," Mr. Gutierrez said.

Dreamers were more pointed, saying Mr. Schumer was betraying them. "Time and time again, politicians have failed to stand by our community," said Cata Santiago. "Now, at the peak of the Dream Act fight, Chuck Schumer and the Democrats won't hold their promises to protect us."

Ms. Santiago was arrested last week while protesting in Mr. Schumer's congressional office and stayed in custody by refusing to identify herself to police. She and a handful of other Dreamers who were also arrested staged a hunger strike in jail.

Mr. Schumer said Wednesday morning that he has been trying to find a DACA answer for weeks. "Because of the particular importance of all of these issues, especially the Dreamers, we can not do a short-term funding bill that picks and chooses what problems to solve and what not to solve. That will not be fair and will not pass. We have to do them all together, instead of in a piecemeal fashion," he said.

Dreamers and their defenders did not blame only Democratic leaders; several dozen Republicans said they wanted a DACA solution this year. Mr. Gutierrez said if those Republicans had joined forces with Democrats in refusing to vote for any year-end bill that doesn't include the Dream Act, then they could have forced Republican leaders' hands.

Sen. Jeff Flake, an Arizona Republican who has been pushing for the Dream Act, said Wednesday that he has assurances the DACA issue will be taken up in January. He said Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, Kentucky Republican, "has committed to bring the bipartisan DACA bill we are currently negotiating to the Senate floor" next month.

Mr. Gutierrez said Dreamers can't bank on another promise. "It's very easy for Sen. Flake to send out a tweet this morning and say, 'Dreamers in January.' His kids aren't getting deported. He's going home to his wife. He's celebrating Christmas," he said.

Title: Obama Administration Announces New Gun Control Measures, Focusing on Military Surplus Weapons and Corporate Gun Registration

Article:

In a surprise move, the Obama administration announced two new gun control measures on Thursday, aimed at curbing the import of military surplus weapons and tightening regulations on guns registered to corporations and trusts. The announcement, made while Washington was preoccupied with the Syrian crisis and looming fiscal battles, signaled President Obama's continued commitment to the issue despite Congress's failure to pass any gun control legislation earlier this year.

Vice President Biden unveiled the new measures during a morning event in the Roosevelt Room. The new rules, added to the list of 23 executive actions the White House had previously determined the president could take unilaterally, come in response to Congress's refusal to pass gun control legislation following the shooting massacre in Newton, Conn.

One of the new policies will end a government practice that allows military weapons, sold or donated by the U.S. to allies, to be reimported into the U.S. by private entities. Under the new policy, only museums and a few other entities like the government will be eligible to reimport military-grade firearms. The U.S. has approved 250,000 of these guns for reimport since 2005.

The Obama administration is also proposing a federal rule to prevent individuals who would be ineligible to pass a background check from skirting the law by registering a gun to a corporation or trust. The new rule would require people associated with these entities, such as beneficiaries and trustees, to undergo the same type of fingerprint-based background checks as individuals if they want to register guns.

However, the National Rifle Association (NRA) criticized the administration, stating that neither measure would reduce crime, as neither the re-importation of firearms nor the corporate gun registration is known to be a source of weapons for criminals.

The types of surplus weapons that have been re-imported under this provision are all more than 50 years old and fall under the definition of "curio" or "relic" firearms. They include M1 Garand rifles and several other models. As such, it is safe to assume that few are used in crimes.

The event also marked the ceremonial swearing-in for Todd Jones, whose confirmation to head the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) after six years of political wrangling to fill that position was another of Obama's post-Newtown priorities.

Although Obama and Biden have said the fight is not over, there is scant evidence that there is more support for gun control legislation than there was in April, when efforts died in the Senate amid staunch opposition from the National Rifle Association and most Republican senators. The new rules for guns registered to corporations will follow the traditional regulatory process, with a 90-day comment period before ATF reviews suggestions and finalizes the rule. Last year, ATF received 39,000 requests to register guns to corporations and trusts.

Title: China Steps into the Void Left by U.S. Withdrawal from Paris Climate Agreement

Article:

In the aftermath of President Trump's decision to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement, the world has witnessed a significant shift in global dynamics, with one notable exception: China. As the U.S. steps back from its role as a leader in the global fight against climate change, China is poised to take the lead, both diplomatically and economically.

This is not the first time President Trump, who campaigned on a platform critical of China, has inadvertently provided Beijing with an opportunity to expand its global influence. After the U.S. withdrew from the Trans-Pacific Partnership, China moved to fill the void, inserting itself into trade talks among nations disappointed by America's reversal. As Canada and Mexico have felt spurned by Trump during the runup to renegotiating NAFTA, China has emerged as a more reliable trading partner.

At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Chinese President Xi Jinping chided the West for its flirtation with protectionism and painted a picture of China as a champion of free trade and an attractive destination for foreign investment. As the U.S. withdraws from the global community's effort to curb carbon emissions, China's profile as a forward-thinking world leader will only grow. It is set to become closer to the U.S.'s allies that feel abandoned by Trump's recent actions, as well as take a more aggressive lead in building a green economy.

Alex Wang, an environmental law professor at the University of California Los Angeles, observed, "While the U.S. is breaking these ties, China — which has traditionally been more reserved in international affairs — is building them at breakneck pace. As the U.S. loses goodwill, China is building it."

The reshuffling of the world order in the wake of Trump's announcement could be seen almost immediately, with top Chinese and European leaders criticizing the U.S.'s withdrawal side by side on Thursday. Standing next to German Chancellor Angela Merkel, Chinese Premier Li Keqiang said that "fighting climate change is a global consensus" and pledged that China would remain committed to the Paris agreement. Merkel said, "The cooperation of the European Union with China in this area will play a crucial role, especially in regards to new technologies."

In a statement to the press, Miguel Arias Cañete, the European Union commissioner on climate action and energy, made the point even more forcefully: "No one should be left behind, but the EU and China have decided to move forward. Our successful cooperation on issues like emissions trading and clean technologies are bearing fruit. Now is the time to further strengthen these ties to keep the wheels turning for ambitious global climate action."

As Europe and China's enhanced cooperation is quite likely to go beyond coordinating on climate change, it could potentially build a better relationship for navigating conflicts over trade. If Europe and China are actually able to grow closer through their coordination on climate change, it could potentially build a better relationship for navigating conflicts over trade.

In the meantime, the U.S. and Europe are going through the roughest patch they've had since they split over the Iraq War in 2003. Even before Trump pulled out of the Paris agreement on Thursday, he had already alienated Europe during his trip abroad last week, when he, among other things, refused to reaffirm America's commitment to NATO and accused Germany of being a trade cheat.

Trump's America First agenda has been a huge gift to China. Consider how, on his first full working day as president, he withdrew from the Trans-Pacific Partnership, an agreement that would have boosted trade ties between the U.S. and 11 countries along the Pacific Rim and generated the largest trade bloc the world had ever seen. The accord would have strengthened ties between the U.S. and a number of China's neighbors and would have served as a counterweight to Beijing's increasing influence in the region (China was not part of the deal).

Now, Trump's move means that Beijing has a major opportunity to step into that vacuum and negotiate a regional trade deal that basically serves as a China-centric version of the TPP. It's already making efforts to do exactly that. China has generally been eager to capitalize on Trump's protectionist tendencies. In his World Economic Forum speech, Chinese President Xi warned against rising nationalism in the West and defended free trade. This is China lecturing the U.S. and Europe about free trade. China's economy has liberalized significantly in recent decades, but it's a country that flagrantly disregards all kinds of global trade rules, from denying market access to foreign companies to subsidizing many of its key industries. But when you have the most powerful politician in the world calling for 45 percent tariffs against other countries, Xi doesn't look so preposterous.

If there's one realm where China is set to best the U.S. in the wake of Paris, it's in developing a sustainable economy. It's already investing more than the U.S. in clean energy—in 2016, it invested more than $88 billion to the U.S.'s $59 billion—but the gulf between the U.S. and China will grow as the U.S. decides that renewable energy investment isn't a priority. And it will grow fast. America First is turning out to be anything but.

Title: Federal Judge's Ruling on ACA: What It Means for Healthcare and the Future of Obamacare

Article:

In a significant development, a federal judge in Texas has struck down aspects of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), often referred to as "Obamacare." The ruling, which is expected to be appealed, has left the fate of the healthcare law and the insurance for millions in limbo.

The ruling, handed down by U.S. District Court Judge Reed O'Connor in the Northern District of Texas, declared the individual mandate, a key provision of the ACA, unconstitutional. The judge agreed with a coalition of Republican-led states that it was unconstitutional to mandate individuals buy health insurance or be taxed for not complying.

The ruling is likely to be appealed by California and other states to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 5th Circuit, which is dominated by Republican-appointed judges. The expected lengthy court fight between Republican and Democratic state officials over the ruling is likely to end up at the Supreme Court, which has twice voted to uphold other challenges to the ACA.

President Donald Trump, who has long been critical of the ACA, hailed the ruling as "great news for America" and called on Republican and Democratic congressional leaders to pass a "STRONG law that provides GREAT healthcare." However, the White House acknowledged that the ruling was expected to be appealed and that the law remains in place while the appeal process unfolds.

The ruling has no immediate effect, and consumers who buy insurance through federal or state marketplaces can still purchase 2019 coverage through Saturday. If the ruling is upheld after the appeal process, however, subsidies that people collect to buy health coverage would no longer be available, and Medicaid, which has extended insurance coverage to millions of low-income and working-class Americans, could also be in jeopardy.

The latest challenge stems from Congress' elimination of the penalty for not purchasing health insurance, part of the $1.5 trillion tax overhaul approved last December. The penalty will disappear in 2019 under the tax law.

The Trump administration sided largely with the states that brought the lawsuit but argued that only some provisions of the law should fall if the individual mandate were struck down. That would include coverage for pre-existing conditions, a popular aspect of the ACA that Trump has pledged to preserve.

The annual penalty for those who refuse to get health insurance is $695 or 2.5 percent of income, whichever is greater. The latest ruling could potentially throw the individual insurance market and the entire healthcare system into chaos, according to experts. However, the case still has a long legal road to travel before that becomes an immediate threat.

Title: The Urgent Need for Active Participatory Democracy in the United States

Article:

The presidential election cycle, much like the holiday shopping season, seems to arrive earlier each round. As the nation gears up for another round of political engagement, it is crucial to reflect on the state of participatory democracy in the United States.

While active participation in the democratic political process is evident through voting, the majority of political engagement happens online, in social media circles, and through printed press editorials. The current state of participatory democracy is an online argument rife with name-calling and political polarization.

The American voter is generally more engaged during presidential races, with an average of 55 percent voter turnout for presidential runs and even less during midterm elections, averaging around 45 percent. This leaves many voices in the political spectrum unheard.

The political process in this election cycle has become similar to reality television. Instead of a respectful discourse of ideals and values, the electorate is subjected to a media circus. The solution to this issue lies not in looking to a presidential candidate to solve the nation's problems, but in the active participation of the voter.

The voter should be just as invigorated around congressional, midterm, gubernatorial, and local elections. The populace of this country has the ability to influence their communities through participatory democracy, which extends beyond showing up to polls.

Participatory democracy involves encouraging thoughtful discussion on important issues, donating time and money to organizations that support a healthy democratic process, and entering into a dialogue with neighbors in hopes of achieving a bipartisan society and political process.

After the presidential election, serious matters of economic prosperity, national security, environment, and the unification of a people divided will remain. No one candidate for office will solve all the issues at hand — instead, these issues are relegated to the American populace, proving that more than ever participatory democracy is the only way to find a collective solution to societal ills.

Barrio, a native New Mexican and recent NMSU graduate, has been covering Southwest music culture through several online music publications and has a passion for political activism and public discourse. His work underscores the urgent need for active participatory democracy in the United States.

Title: House Energy and Commerce Committee Rejects Climate Change Acknowledgement Amendment, Receives Funding from Fossil Fuel Industries

Article:

The House Energy and Commerce Committee on Tuesday spent a significant portion of its time debating an anti-environmental bill, H.R. 3826, also known as The Electricity Security and Affordability Act, which aims to suspend the Environmental Protection Agency's proposed climate rules for power plants. In a surprising turn of events, the committee rejected an amendment that would have acknowledged the reality of climate change.

The amendment, proposed by Rep. Jan Schakowsky (D-Ill.), simply stated that greenhouse gas pollution "threatens the American public's health and welfare" by contributing to climatic changes. ClimateProgress reported on the Republicans' response to the amendment, which failed to pass despite the bill's approval. Twenty-four Energy & Commerce Committee members, all Republicans, voted against the amendment. Among them were E&C Chair Rep. Fred Upton (R-MI), who has previously expressed doubts about human-caused climate change, and Joe Barton (R-TX), who also questions the role of human activity in climate change.

This is not the first time House Republicans have rejected amendments acknowledging the reality of climate change. In 2011, House Republicans voted down amendments that called on Congress to accept that climate change is real, man-made, and a human health threat.

The question arises as to why House Republicans continue to deny the scientific consensus on climate change. ClimateProgress reported that the Republicans who voted to deny climate change have collectively accepted about $9.3 million in career contributions from the oil, gas, and coal industries.

This revelation raises questions about the potential influence of these industries on the committee's decisions, as they stand to gain financially from the continued use and production of fossil fuels. The rejection of the climate change acknowledgement amendment further underscores the need for transparency and accountability in political decision-making, particularly when it comes to issues as critical as climate change.

Title: "Americans United for Life Advocates for Comprehensive Regulation of Abortion Clinics in Virginia and Beyond"

Article:

In a bid to ensure the safety and well-being of women seeking abortion services, Americans United for Life (AUFL) has been at the forefront of advocating for meaningful and comprehensive regulation of abortion clinics across the United States. This push for regulation has gained momentum in the past three years, with at least 15 states launching investigations into substandard care in abortion clinics, some of which have resulted in women's deaths.

AUFL's efforts have led to the enactment of new comprehensive abortion clinic regulations in eight states over the past three years, and the introduction of the "Abortion Patients' Enhanced Safety Act," model legislation mandating that abortion clinics meet the same health and safety standards as facilities performing other outpatient surgeries.

Recently, Alabama Governor Robert Bentley signed legislation inspired by AUFL's model legislation. In Virginia, the Board of Health approved final regulations for abortion clinics, which are now considered a subset of "hospitals" and are required to meet rigorous and protective standards for patient care. AUFL testified twice in support of these regulations.

The debate over Virginia's abortion clinic standards is emblematic of the ongoing battle to force abortion providers to prioritize women's health and safety over profit margins and the promotion of unrestricted and unregulated abortion on demand.

Virginia officials and pro-life advocates argued that abortion clinics in the state should, among other requirements, be licensed by the state health department, inspected regularly, have operable emergency equipment, and maintain sanitary and safe facilities. Pro-abortion advocates countered that if required to abide by these medically appropriate standards, abortion clinics would be coerced into spending significant amounts of money to come into compliance and might even be forced to close their doors.

In seeking to advance their own financial and political interests, Virginia abortion advocates ignored evidence of substandard conditions in Virginia abortion clinics, refusing to acknowledge or contradict evidence presented to the commonwealth's board of health. Instead, after hearing testimony about recurring health and safety violations at some Virginia abortion clinics and the failure of a number of these clinics to fulfill "plans of correction" for previously documented violations, a representative from NARAL Virginia wrongly and stubbornly insisted that there was no demonstrated public health need supporting the regulations.

Contrary to NARAL's claim, documentation obtained by the Family Foundation of Virginia from the Virginia Board of Health confirms that the continued health and safety violations at Virginia's abortion clinics are widespread. "These reports from more recent, follow-up inspections of abortion centers continue to show dozens and dozens of deficiencies, some worse than before," said Victoria Cobb, president of the Family Foundation of Virginia. "Not cleaned up. Not fixed. Ongoing. Even after submitting plans to correct these deficiencies, they have not done so. The abortion industry continues to claim that it is safe, but these inspection reports are indisputable evidence that nothing could be further from the truth."

Denise M. Burke, vice president of legal affairs at Americans United for Life, emphasized that the "right" to abortion does not give rise to a corollary "right" for abortion providers to practice without meaningful oversight and regulation. "Big Abortion does not — contrary to its apparent beliefs — have a constitutional right to maim and kill women in unlicensed, substandard, and dangerous clinics," Burke stated.

Title: Analysis: Healthcare and Busing: A Tumultuous Start for Sen. Kamala Harris' Presidential Campaign

Article:

In the political arena, imitation is often considered the sincerest form of flattery. This seems to be the case as several Democratic candidates, including California Senator Kamala Harris, strive to replace President Donald Trump. However, Harris' approach to key issues such as healthcare and busing has raised questions about her ability to communicate effectively with the American public.

Seven days after announcing her presidential bid in January, Harris endorsed the concept of "Medicare for All" and was asked about private insurance. Her response, which suggested the elimination of private insurance, has been a point of contention for her campaign. In the following weeks, Harris seemed to "waffle" on the issue, only to reaffirm her support for private insurance in a debate moderator's question about government-run plans.

The inconsistency in Harris' stance on private insurance has been a topic of discussion, with some critics pointing out that her policy could affect the 217 million Americans who currently have private insurance. This issue is particularly significant as it touches upon a core function of organized labor, which negotiates employer-provided health care as untaxed compensation.

Moreover, Harris' decision to use the contentious issue of school busing as a political weapon during her debate with Joe Biden has been met with criticism. In the 1970s, busing was a divisive issue, with a 1973 Gallup poll showing that only 4% of whites and 9% of blacks supported it. Yet, Harris used busing as a cudgel against Biden, a move that some argue was politically unwise and lacked nuance.

The healthcare and busing issues are not the only points of contention in Harris' campaign. Her evolving stance on private insurance and her use of a divisive issue like busing have raised questions about her ability to communicate effectively with the American public. As the primary season progresses, it will be interesting to see how Harris and other candidates navigate these complex issues and connect with voters.

Title: Trump's Plastics Boosterism Clashes with Corporate America's Environmental Shift

Article:

In a stark contrast to the growing environmental concerns of corporate America, President Donald Trump has been vocal about his support for plastics, positioning himself as a proponent of the material in contrast to Democrats. This shift in policy, however, comes at a time when major corporations, from Google to Coca-Cola, are attempting to align themselves with environmentalists, reducing their plastic footprint and increasing their recycling efforts.

The latest example of progressive change, despite the White House's stance, is the new plastic manufacturing plant being built by Royal Dutch Shell in Pennsylvania. Contrary to Trump's claims during a recent visit, the plant's construction plans were initiated in 2012, with over $1 billion in tax credits from state taxpayers.

At a rally, Trump touted the plant's contribution to the economy and used it as a platform to promote his reelection, stating, "Virtually every leading Democrat has vowed to eliminate fossil fuels." He urged Pennsylvanians to "get out there and make sure we win."

The plant will utilize a byproduct of fracking to produce pellets used in various plastic products, including those that make cars lighter and more fuel-efficient and in wind turbines. This aligns with the Trump administration's stance on the benefits of plastics.

However, the excessive use of plastic leads to significant waste, with single-use items like bags and straws contributing to pollution in the ocean and landfills. When asked about the issue before speaking at the new plant, Trump pointed the finger at other countries, particularly China, for their lack of plastic waste management.

Trump's anti-plastic waste accomplishment is the Save Our Seas Act, a bipartisan bill signed in 2018 to combat ocean garbage and plastic. Despite this, the President did not mention the word "plastic" when he signed the bill.

Meanwhile, Trump's reelection campaign is selling 10-packs of plastic Trump straws on its official website, with the campaign raising over $450,000 from them, according to Politico. The campaign's website states, "Liberal paper straws do not work. STAND WITH PRESIDENT TRUMP and buy your pack of recyclable straws today."

Corporate America, too, is making efforts to reduce its plastic footprint. Companies like Coca-Cola and Pepsi are aiming to improve their environmental images and reduce plastic bottle production. In 2017, Coca-Cola alone produced over 3 million tons of plastic packaging, according to its commitment to transparency on the issue of plastic and waste.

Both companies have announced plans to sell their water in aluminum cans, in addition to plastic bottles. Starbucks has developed a new recyclable lid for its iced drinks, and companies in the UK, where plastic straws will be banned by 2020, are adapting to the change. McDonald's moved away from plastic straws in its UK and Ireland stores, but found the new paper straws were not recyclable, though the old plastic ones were.

Google has announced plans to include recycled plastic in its products by 2022, and Amazon, responsible for a significant amount of packaging, has moved toward paper-padded packaging that it claims is recyclable. Amazon also has a portion of its website dedicated to its sustainability and environment efforts.

Support for plastic-bag bans, where they've occurred, is bipartisan. A Siena College poll of New Yorkers in April found bipartisan support for the state's ban on single-use plastic bags in grocery stores. However, these bans can only do so much, as demonstrated by China's continued contribution to plastic waste in oceans, despite having laws limiting single-use plastic bags.

Title: Comedian Challenges Senator Warren on Single-Payer Healthcare and Middle Class Taxes

Article:

In a recent appearance on Stephen Colbert's CBS late night show, the host grilled Senator Elizabeth Warren on the issue of single-payer healthcare, a policy she supports. Colbert pressed Warren on the question of whether middle-class Americans' taxes would have to increase significantly to fund the program she and Senator Bernie Sanders have proposed.

During the interview, Warren attempted to explain that costs would rise for the wealthiest Americans and big corporations, while hardworking middle-class families would see their costs decrease. However, Colbert pressed her on the issue of taxes, stating that he wanted her to be more transparent about the tax increases that would be necessary.

Colbert's questioning marked a rare moment of hostility towards a Democrat on national entertainment television. The comedian, who supports the idea of single-payer healthcare, offered Warren advice on how to make the argument for middle-class tax hikes more effectively.

The political challenge for Warren is that admitting to significant tax increases is politically risky. A poll conducted by Robert Blendon, a professor at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, found that if voters were told that a government-run system could lead to delays in getting care or higher taxes, support plunged to 26 percent and 37 percent, respectively.

Another challenge for Warren is that her plan would eliminate private healthcare plans for nearly 180 million Americans, making such coverage illegal. At the last Democratic debate, Warren tried to downplay this issue by claiming that few Americans love their insurance companies. However, polling suggests that many Americans value their coverage and providers, making such uprooting a significant political liability for single-payer advocates.

According to Gallup polling from late last year, 82% of Democrats said the quality of health care they received was either good or excellent. A large majority, 71%, believed their health care coverage was either good or excellent. Even when it comes to health care costs, 61% of Democrats said they were satisfied with what they paid in health care. The same poll also notes that the vast majority of all Americans are satisfied with the quality of their health care – rating it ‘ excellent’ or ‘ good’ (80 percent) – and their level of coverage (69 percent).

In addition, a recent Kaiser poll found that 86 percent of Americans with private coverage were satisfied with it. Healthcare disruption is deeply unpopular, as both parties have learned in recent years. Warren may try to "here's the thing" her way out of addressing these facts, but she cannot deflect away from the higher taxes, illegal private coverage, and long, bureaucratic wait times for care.

Title: The Tragic Death of Kate Steinle and the Need for Smarter Immigration Enforcement

Article:

In the midst of the July Fourth weekend, a tragic incident occurred in San Francisco, where Kate Steinle, 31, was fatally shot while walking with her father on a busy pier. A Mexican immigrant, Juan Francisco Lopez-Sanchez, was arrested in connection with the crime. Lopez-Sanchez, who was in the country without documentation, had been previously deported five times and had seven felony convictions, including four for drug offenses.

However, it is crucial to separate Lopez-Sanchez's actions from the broader issue of undocumented immigration in the United States. He does not represent the estimated 11 million undocumented immigrants in the country, the majority of whom are productive members of society. The Washington Post recently analyzed Donald Trump's comments about Mexican immigrants being drug dealers and "rapists" and found them to be incorrect. Being in the country without authorization is not a crime; it is a civil infraction.

Most undocumented immigrants come to the United States to work and provide a better life for themselves and their families. It is a myth that increased illegal immigration leads to more crime. Research from the Immigration Policy Center shows that crime rates fell in the United States as the size of our immigrant population, including undocumented immigrants, grew from 1990 to 2010.

It is essential to remember that the actions of one individual should not be used to vilify an entire group. The same news outlets that are now highlighting Wednesday's murder as proof that undocumented immigrants are criminals often overlook or ignore other stories of undocumented immigrants who are genuine heroes. In 2013, for instance, an undocumented immigrant rescued a mother and her child on Staten Island, New York, amidst the storm surge of Superstorm Sandy.

Deporting as many undocumented immigrants as possible is not the answer to our immigration problems. Lopez-Sanchez had been deported five times, and yet he was still in the country without authorization. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) announced last week that it is rethinking its deportation priorities to focus on recent arrivals and serious criminals. This move is a step in the right direction, as it is time to start seriously targeting those immigrants who are a real threat to public safety.

The government will be focusing its enforcement efforts on three categories of people: convicted criminals, recent border crossers, and terrorism threats. True, Lopez-Sanchez should not have been in the country, or he should have at least been behind bars. However, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) erred in not seeking a warrant or court order for his arrest and he was released in accordance with city law in March.

President Barack Obama's proposed executive action on immigration, currently tied up in a legal battle, might also have made a difference because it would have freed up resources to go after people like Lopez-Sanchez. The executive action would have given deportation relief to parents of DREAMers, while allowing DHS to zero in on criminals.

In conclusion, the tragic death of Kate Steinle is a reminder of the need for smarter and better immigration enforcement. The government should focus on recent arrivals and serious criminals, rather than wasting time, manpower, and money chasing after people working productively in their communities. The system failed Kate Steinle, but it should not fail the millions of undocumented immigrants who contribute positively to our society.

Title: New Hampshire Senate Debate Moderator Apologizes to Scott Brown for Geography Error

Article:

In a surprising turn of events during a New Hampshire Senate debate on Thursday, moderator James Pindell, a reporter for WMUR, apologized to Republican candidate Scott Brown for incorrectly disputing him on state geography.

During the debate, Mr. Brown, a former Massachusetts senator, was asked about his views on the "right" and "wrong" in Sullivan County, a county located on the western border of New Hampshire, as reported by Fox News on Friday.

Mr. Brown responded by discussing economic challenges faced by areas north of Concord, the state capital. "Geography plays a role along the southern border. We have more jobs, we have more opportunity, infrastructure, and other opportunities up north are difficult," Mr. Brown said. "One of the biggest opportunities is tourism. One of the biggest opportunities are ski areas and trails for snowmobiles—I support those efforts."

However, Mr. Pindell interrupted Mr. Brown, reminding him that the question was about Sullivan County. "I think you were talking about the North Country," he said.

Mr. Brown responded, "I'm talking about any place past Concord, actually, and the challenges of our state."

The debate continued, with Mr. Brown listing more economic challenges facing northern counties. Mr. Pindell interrupted him again, clarifying that Sullivan County is west of Concord, not north of Concord.

"Sullivan County is west of Concord. It's not north of Concord, Senator Brown. So what do you see as going well and what's not going well there?" Mr. Pindell asked.

Mr. Brown, however, stuck with his initial answer, maintaining that "the challenges are the same in every county in our state."

The state Democratic Party posted a video of the exchange online, labeling Mr. Brown as "clueless" in the description.

Later that night, Mr. Pindell admitted his error in a tweet, noting that Mr. Brown was referring to Mt. Sunapee, a ski resort in Sullivan County north of Concord.

"I said that Sullivan County was west of Concord, not north of Concord. The truth is, it's both. So on this point, Scott Brown was right, I was wrong, and I apologize to Scott Brown and to both campaigns," Mr. Pindell tweeted.

Title: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu Indicted in Three Corruption Cases, Marking First Time a Sitting Israeli Head of State Faces Criminal Charges

Article:

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, also known as "Bibi" Netanyahu, has been indicted in three corruption cases, making him the first sitting head of state in Israel to face criminal charges. The indictment was announced on Thursday, following a four-day hearing last month with the prime minister's defense team.

The indictment includes charges of bribery, fraud, and breach of trust. The most serious charge, Case 4000, alleges that Netanyahu engaged in a quid pro quo deal with businessman and media mogul Shaul Elovich. During his tenure as communication minister, Netanyahu is accused of spearheading regulations that helped Elovich gain roughly $500 million.
