In return, Netanyahu and his wife allegedly sought alterations to Walla News, which Elovich ran, to serve their political interests and undercut their opponents.

The Netanyahus have argued that the deal does not constitute a bribe and that they only sought balanced coverage.

The second case, Case 2000, accuses Netanyahu and Arnon Mozes, the publisher of the Yedioth Ahronoth newspaper, of trying to limit the circulation of a rival paper in return for favorable media coverage.

The final case, Case 1000, accuses Netanyahu of fraud and breach of trust for allegedly using his public role to receive gifts from Hollywood mogul Arnon Milchan and billionaire James Packer.

Netanyahu could face up to 10 years in prison if he is convicted of bribery and a maximum of three years for fraud and breach of trust.

Netanyahu, Israel's longest-serving prime minister, is not required to step down as a result of the charges. He can ask the parliament for immunity, though that request would have to be considered by a special committee that has not been established due to ongoing gridlock.

The indictment casts further uncertainty over Netanyahu's political future. Israel appears to be headed toward an unprecedented third election in less than a year after Netanyahu's chief rival announced Wednesday he would miss a deadline to form a ruling coalition.

The parliament now starts a 21-day period in which it can try to nominate any one of its 120 lawmakers to try and establish a coalition. Should that effort fail, an election would be triggered within 90 days.

If Netanyahu were to win a new election, Israeli President Reuven Rivlin would be forced to decide if he can give Netanyahu the mandate to form the next government given the criminal charges against him.

Title: Republicans Push for Reduced Unemployment Benefits as Economy Shows Mixed Signs of Recovery

Article:

The June jobs report has been released, and the Republican party is once again claiming victory, with payrolls growing by 4.8 million, according to government surveys, and the official unemployment rate dropping to 11.1 percent. President Trump took to Twitter, proclaiming "HISTORIC JOBS NUMBERS!" as Republicans begin to coalesce around a second round of economic rescue payments, which includes a reduced super-unemployment benefit and a smaller round of more strictly means-tested checks.

While the increase in jobs is a positive development, there are reasons to be concerned about the underlying economic conditions. Economist Jed Kolko calculates a "core" unemployment rate, which includes permanent layoffs or quits, and the "marginally attached" people who express a desire to work but have not searched for a job in the past four weeks. This kind of unemployment has increased steadily since February and accelerated in June to 5.9 percent.

Moreover, the June numbers are already outdated, as the surveys are collected during the first two weeks of the month, and they will necessarily miss events that occurred during the latter weeks. The last two weeks have seen a surge in coronavirus cases across the country, and private economic activity indexes have shown a stalling out of spending. In states with high infection rates, such as Texas and Florida, economic activity is going into reverse. Weekly unemployment claims have also leveled off over the past month or so, at levels many times higher than during the Great Recession.

It is likely that the restoration of temporary layoffs will slow down or even reverse over the coming months, and the economy will fall short of its pre-pandemic levels. The U.S. needs more government aid to prevent a worsening economic situation and potential bread riots. The boost to unemployment benefits, small business grants, and the one-time rescue payment are keeping tens of millions of people from starvation, but these programs are set to expire, and super-unemployment will end in July.

Republicans argue that super-unemployment pays lower-income workers more not to work, but there are not enough jobs to go around, and it is not advisable for people to work during a pandemic. The U.S. government can borrow without limit as long as the economy has not recovered, and once the pandemic has passed, the government can address conservative complaints about labor incentives by making the universal checks bigger to compensate for taking a job.

However, it appears that Republicans are not primarily concerned with labor incentives. They view the state's main duty as pushing people into the labor market, regardless of the consequences for public health or the business class. The outcome of the 2020 presidential election may hinge on this ideological divide, and if the current trajectory continues, the economic situation will worsen, and the Trump administration may be a casualty of its refusal to prioritize public health and economic recovery.

Title: California Senator Dianne Feinstein Introduces Comprehensive Gun Control Legislation, Aiming to Reinstate Assault Weapons Ban

Article:

California Senator Dianne Feinstein is set to introduce new gun control legislation today, aiming to re-establish the "assault weapons" ban of the Clinton era. However, Feinstein's proposed bill extends beyond the restriction of so-called "scary look" guns, encompassing a wide array of handguns, rifles, and shotguns.

The bill, to be introduced today, targets specific semiautomatic firearms, including rifles and handguns that can accept a detachable magazine and possess one or more military characteristics, as well as semiautomatic rifles and handguns with a fixed magazine capable of holding more than 10 rounds.

In an attempt to strengthen the 1994 Assault Weapons Ban and various state bans, the bill eliminates easy-to-remove bayonet mounts and flash suppressors from the characteristics test. It also bans firearms with "thumbhole stocks" and "bullet buttons" to address attempts to "work around" prior bans.

Moreover, the bill aims to ban large-capacity ammunition feeding devices capable of accepting more than 10 rounds. To accommodate legitimate hunters and existing gun owners, over 900 specifically-named weapons used for hunting or sporting purposes are exempted.

Grandfathered weapons, however, must be registered under the National Firearms Act. This registration process requires certification from local law enforcement of the owner's identity and compliance with State or local law. Fingerprinting for firearms lawfully purchased is also a part of the proposed legislation.

It is essential to note that the term "assault weapon" is a political term with no specific weapon association. The term is typically used in reference to semi-automatic rifles, but any weapon can be used to assault someone. Feinstein's new legislation includes handguns and shotguns, expanding the definition of "assault weapons."

The qualifications for being considered a "legitimate hunter" remain unclear, potentially creating a gray area as many people may not hunt annually but occasionally. The hunting argument is often employed by pro-gun control advocates as a means of finding common ground, but the Second Amendment is not directly related to hunting.

The success of Feinstein's legislation is questionable, as it reflects extreme stances on the Second Amendment that many Democrats have already deemed outdated, misguided, and ineffective in preventing school shootings.

Last night, conservative columnist Michelle Malkin discussed the latest gun control measures proposed by far-left Democrats on Hannity.

UPDATE: According to CNN, Feinstein has received permission from DC police to be flanked with semi-automatic rifles during a press conference today at 11 a.m. when the legislation will be officially introduced.

Title: Clinton and Sanders Accuse Each Other of Political Games Ahead of Wisconsin Primary

Article:

In the final days leading up to the Wisconsin primary, Democratic presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders have been engaged in a debate over the scheduling of a debate between the two candidates. Clinton has been accused of avoiding a debate in her adopted home state of New York ahead of its April 19 primary, while Sanders has challenged Clinton to a debate in delegate-rich New York.

Clinton told NBC's "Meet the Press" that she is open to a debate, but has suggested a few dates that the Sanders campaign and others see as less than optimal for viewership. Sanders, who has won five of the last six primaries or caucuses, has proposed several dates for a debate, including April 10, 11, 12, or 13.

Sanders campaign spokesman Michael Briggs accused the Clinton campaign of playing "silly political games" and disingenuously announcing a debate date when they knew Sanders had already secured park permits for a major rally in New York City. "Let's stop the silly political games, let's get on with debating the candidates' stands on serious issues affecting New York and the United States," said Briggs.

Clinton had no public events Sunday in Wisconsin, where some polls show Sanders with a slight lead. Clinton also made clear that Sanders remains a political threat, stating, "I certainly have not moved on. I know that I still have work to do to win the nomination."

Meanwhile, the top two Republican presidential candidates, Donald Trump and Ted Cruz, were also campaigning in Wisconsin. Trump doubled-down on his comments that the US should "do a better deal" with Japan, South Korea, and other allies, suggesting they should pay more for America's protection while taking a greater role in their defense, including building their own nuclear weapons. Trump also discussed his plans to change the nation's tax code by "simplifying" it, stating that the very rich would likely pay more, but there would be an incentive for them to invest and create jobs in the country.

Ohio Gov. John Kasich, the other Republican candidate, told ABC's "This Week" that the Republican convention, which could happen in July without a clear nominee based on delegate wins, could be a civics lesson for the country. "Kids will spend less time focusing on Bieber and Kardashian and more time focusing on how we elect presidents," said Kasich, who has won only Ohio.

Trump called for Kasich to drop out of the race, arguing he should not be allowed to continue accumulating delegates if he has no chance of being the nominee. Trump has 736 pledged delegates, followed by Cruz with 463, then Kasich with 143 -- with 1,237 needed to secure the nomination. Trump trails Cruz in Wisconsin, after some polls showed him leading by double-digits several weeks ago. Trump said Sunday that Kasich could be considered as a nominee at the GOP convention in July even without competing in the remaining nominating contests.

The Kasich campaign tried to flip the script, contending that neither Trump nor Cruz would have enough delegates to win the nomination outright going into the convention. "Since he thinks it's such a good idea, we look forward to Trump dropping out before the convention," said Kasich spokesman Chris Schrimpf. Republican concerns grew about the prospect of convention chaos if Trump fails to lock up his party's nomination -- or even if he does.

Title: Military Deployment to Puerto Rico: A Closer Look at the Pace and Challenges

Article:

The deployment of military personnel to Puerto Rico, currently standing at around 5,000 National Guard forces and active military, is falling short of the needs of a population of 3.5 million in crisis. This is in stark contrast to the 22,000 troops deployed to Haiti after the 2010 earthquake, as pointed out by meteorologist Eric Holthaus on Twitter.

The initial pace of military deployment for the disaster in Puerto Rico has been slow, but it appears that the relief effort is now gaining momentum. In the first six days after Hurricane Maria made landfall, the Navy had deployed just two ships, citing concerns that Puerto Rico's ports were too damaged to accommodate numerous large vessels. However, harrowing reports of U.S. citizens struggling without electricity, food, and water have prompted the Pentagon to accelerate the relief effort, even though territorial officials have not specifically requested assistance.

The issue of port congestion has been a point of contention, with some attributing military inaction to this factor and the reluctance to waive the Jones Act. However, it seems that a lack of preparedness may also be a significant factor. For instance, the hospital ship USNS Comfort, which was announced to be on its way to Puerto Rico, is still not en route, despite being ready to deploy as soon as the call comes.

The Comfort, a mammoth ship, was docked Tuesday in its home port of Norfolk, Virginia, with a minimal crew. It requires up to five days to stock up and prepare for departure. When reached on Tuesday afternoon, the commanding officer of the ship's hospital, Capt. Kevin D. Buckley, stated, "The Comfort is ready to go, if the call comes."

The order to move the Comfort finally came a week after the storm, but the ship is still not underway, a delay that could have been avoided had preparations been made a week before Maria hit Puerto Rico, as soon as the power and course of the storm became clear. In comparison, during the Haiti disaster, the Comfort was ordered on its way immediately following the earthquake.

While the White House has decided to allow foreign-built or flagged ships to deliver supplies during the emergency, it has restricted members of Congress from making official visits as official delegations to the hurricane-battered U.S. Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico. Congressional sources from both parties stated this on Wednesday. The office of Sen. Bob Menendez (D-N.J.), who had been organizing a visit to Puerto Rico by several representatives and senators from both parties, is now trying to find alternatives to assess the federal response thus far.

The San Juan Airport is open, though the speed of flights going in and out is severely restricted by the damaged infrastructure. The restriction on Congressional flights has some validity, though it has the notable side effect of preventing any Congressional oversight or evaluation of conditions on the ground.

Title: Hillary Clinton Discusses High Expectations for Women in Public Eye, Acknowledges Different Styles and Approaches

In an interview on MSNBC's "Morning Joe," former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton discussed the high expectations placed on women in the public eye, particularly high-achieving women. Clinton, the 2016 Democratic presidential front-runner, stated that these expectations often lead to the assumption that women must perform at a higher level all the time.

During the interview, Clinton commented on the unique challenges faced by women in politics, stating, "I think Mika and I understand this, and maybe it's because still today, when you are a high-achieving woman—particularly one in the public eye—you really are just expected to perform at a higher level all the time."

Clinton went on to say, "And there are not enough experiences with different styles or different approaches that women make. Men, my goodness—you know, there's a million different ways you could be successful, you could communicate and all the rest of it. And look, I'm not telling you anything you don't know."

Host Joe Scarborough had been discussing how his co-host, Mika Brzezinski, was doing more preparation for the interview than he was and asked Clinton if she ever looked at how her husband did things and thought "it's not fair." Clinton responded, "I am not a natural politician like Bill Clinton or Barack Obama."

Clinton explained that her approach to politics is rooted in service and a deep conviction to ensure opportunities for all. She stated, "So for me, it really came through the root of service; it really came from my deep conviction that we had to make sure that this country we all love kept producing opportunities for everybody, and I see that narrowing, and I see people being left out, and it upsets me."

Clinton also acknowledged that her emotional investment in her work sometimes makes her approach more nerve-wracking, stating, "And so I invest a lot of energy and a lot of my own emotion into what I do and I think sometimes, instead of that being as easy to understand as I would like it to be, it sometimes is a little nerve-wracking."

Title: "America's Progress and the Question of Comparative Normality: A Reflection on Spears' GLAAD Vanguard Award Speech"

Article:

In the heart of Philadelphia, a city known for its historical significance, a sign at a march outside a Starbucks on April 16, 2018, serves as a stark reminder of the ongoing discourse surrounding societal norms and individuality. This discourse was further highlighted by Britney Spears' acceptance speech of the GLAAD Vanguard Award last week, which touched upon the emphasis society places on 'normalcy' and the uniqueness of each individual.

Spears' speech, while heartfelt and sincere, sparked a thought-provoking question: "Those who only know one country, know no country," as political scientist Seymour Martin Lipset once observed. This statement underscores the importance of understanding the unique characteristics of one's own country, as opposed to making comparisons that may not accurately reflect its true nature.

In the case of the United States, the discourse often revolves around allegations of deep-seated racism and sexism. While it is undeniable that discrimination exists, it is crucial to differentiate between acknowledging the presence of injustices and labeling the country as the most racist or sexist in the world. A quick search on Twitter for "most racist" and "America" reveals a plethora of such assertions.

However, a closer look at the data paints a different picture. In 1958, 44% of white Americans said they would move if a black family moved in next door. Forty years later, that number had dropped to 1%. This significant decrease in racial prejudice is a testament to the progress made in American society.

Moreover, the increasing rate of interracial marriages serves as a tangible example of this progress. In 1967, only 3% of newlywed marriages were interracial. By 2015, this rate had risen more than fivefold, to 17%. These statistics suggest that people willing to spend their lives with individuals of another race are not lying about their feelings.

When considering America's racial dynamics, it is essential to ask, "Compared to whom?" By no plausible objective standard is America the most racist or bigoted country in the world, even among industrialized countries. In a 2014 study ranking countries by opposition to having a racially different neighbor, America ranked 47th (with 6% of the population saying they were opposed).

Furthermore, the United States admits more immigrants than any other country and has democratically elected a racial minority head of state, a feat unparalleled by any other major power in the world.

The discourse on America's attitude towards homosexuality mirrors the racial discourse. While there has been a history of discrimination, it is important to remember that quick comparisons to countries without such a history may not be accurate or fair. Attitudes towards homosexuality have followed the same trend as race, with a significant decrease in prejudice over time.

In conclusion, while America is not without its problems, it is essential to question the comparative normality of societal attitudes. The progress made in race relations, as well as other areas, should not be overlooked or underestimated. Acknowledging and addressing injustices does not mean that America is the worst offender; rather, it means recognizing the need for continued growth and understanding the unique characteristics of our country.

Title: Senate Holds Briefing on Election Security Amidst Ongoing Opposition from GOP Leadership

The United States Senate will hold a private briefing on election security this Wednesday, a move that has been long-sought by Democrats and comes amidst growing concerns about foreign interference in the 2020 elections. The briefing, which is expected to include officials from the Department of Homeland Security, the FBI, and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, is set to take place amidst Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's ongoing opposition to the consideration of election security legislation.

While both parties have expressed concerns about potential interference by Russia and other foreign powers, the Republican party has been more reluctant to take up concrete measures. This reluctance is partly due to McConnell's resistance, as he views these laws as potentially giving the federal government too much control over state and local elections, and as a means to benefit the Democrats.

The briefing, while viewed as a victory for Democrats, may not lead to significant changes in Republican stances on election security. The actions of the Republican-controlled Senate up until this point suggest they might not be moved to take further action. Despite repeated warnings from high-level government officials, McConnell, in particular, has seemed relatively immovable on the issue.

The Senate has allowed several bills addressing election security to fall by the wayside, including the Protecting American Votes and Elections Act, the Defending the Integrity of Voting Systems Act, and the Foreign Influence Reporting in Elections Act. As a result, the US Senate, which allocated $380 million in election security funds last year, is now effectively promoting a do-nothing approach to a subject that special counsel Robert Mueller and countless national security officials have raised as a serious threat that requires additional action.

The inaction of the Senate, under McConnell's leadership, is not just a political message, but could have major consequences. Democrats are hoping an in-depth briefing about the risks the US faces might push Republicans to change course. The FBI Director, Christopher Wray, has gone so far as to call 2018 the "dress rehearsal for the big show in 2020."

Title: Trump's Iran Nuclear Agreement Critique: A Final Chance for Congress and Allies

Article:

President Trump's sharp criticism of the 2015 Iran nuclear agreement on Friday, calling for stricter conditions on Iranian behavior to prevent the U.S. from withdrawing from the pact, has set the stage for a potential renegotiation or termination of the agreement.

In his speech, President Trump emphasized the need for a more stringent agreement, stating, "As we have seen in North Korea, the longer we ignore a threat, the worse that threat becomes." He also made it clear that the agreement is under continuous review and that his administration has the power to cancel U.S. participation at any time.

While some may have preferred a clean withdrawal from the nuclear agreement, the president's decision to give Congress and European leaders a final chance to address its flaws is commendable. The president's call to action was met with immediate endorsement from the Israeli and Saudi governments.

The president's ultimatum, in which he announced that he will terminate the agreement unless its flaws are fixed, was the most significant part of his speech. Given the low probability that Congress, U.S. diplomats, or European officials can devise and implement any substantial changes to the nuclear agreement, the deal's future is uncertain.

Congress now has 60 days to decide whether to reimpose severe economic sanctions on Iran that were lifted by the nuclear agreement. Congress will also consider legislation addressing the agreement's shortcomings and "triggers" imposing sanctions in response to Iranian behavior.

Any legislation or renegotiation of the nuclear agreement must address its three major flaws: allowing Iran to enrich uranium, operating a plutonium-producing heavy-water reactor, and the deal's weak inspection provisions. Other issues, such as Iran's missile program, support of terrorism, and meddling in regional conflicts, should also be addressed.

While there has been some talk of extending the deal's "sunset" clause, such a fix would be meaningless without addressing the above changes concerning Iran's nuclear program. However, none of these vital changes is likely to be approved by Congress in legislation or agreed to by other nations who signed the Iran deal.

Congress is unlikely to pass legislation with any substantial fixes to the agreement due to the opposition of moderate Republican senators and the need for bipartisan support. The Senate would require 60 votes to pass such legislation, making it challenging to secure the necessary support.

Furthermore, based on a statement by a senior European Union official on Friday, European states plan to resist any efforts by U.S. officials to fix the nuclear deal. By not withdrawing from the pact immediately, President Trump is attempting to work with Congress and follow the law.

It's worth noting that President Trump can reimpose most sanctions on Iran himself if Congress fails to act. The president could take such action and impose additional sanctions as part of a withdrawal decision.

In the coming weeks, expect to see many pundits and members of Congress discussing various schemes to fix the nuclear deal. However, the nuclear deal with Iran appears to be all but dead, and in about two months, President Trump may put the Iran deal out of its misery.

Title: HHS Reverses Obama-Era Rule, Defines "Sex" as Biological for Obamacare Nondiscrimination Policy

The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has announced a new rule that defines "sex" as biological for the purposes of nondiscrimination under the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). The rule reverses a regulation implemented during the Obama administration that redefined "sex" to include "gender identity" and "termination of pregnancy."

The new rule, which takes effect immediately, brings federal policy into compliance with court rulings that deemed the Obama-era interpretation of "sex" as unlawful. The U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas had previously enjoined and vacated the Obama-era provision, citing violations of the Administrative Procedure Act and the federal Religious Freedom Restoration Act.

Roger Severino, director of the HHS Office for Civil Rights, explained that the new rule "updates the books to reflect the reality that 'gender identity' and 'termination of pregnancy' have been deemed unlawful interpretations of civil-rights law." The rule also maintains the Obama administration's decision not to include "sexual orientation" as a protected category under the definition of sex discrimination.

Opponents of the Obama-era regulation had expressed concerns about its implications for health care and religious freedom. The policy required medical professionals to treat individuals according to their gender identity rather than their biological sex, which could lead to improper health-care decisions. The policy also raised religious-liberty and conscience rights concerns, particularly for health-care workers.

The decision to reverse the Obama-administration regulation is likely to be met with criticism from progressive activists and their allies in the media. The New York Times, for instance, had previously claimed that the Trump administration could "define transgender out of existence."

However, the move aligns with a key promise made by President Trump during his campaign and throughout his time in office, to undo Obama-era policies that redefined "sex" to include "sexual orientation" and "gender identity." This move, though it comes near the end of his first term, is another step in showing his supporters, especially social conservatives, that he is willing to follow through on his promises.

Title: James Carville Discusses 2016 Presidential Election and the State of the Republican Party

Article:

In an interview with * ███'s Hive, political strategist James Carville, a longtime confidant of the Clinton family, discussed the 2016 presidential election and the current state of the Republican Party.

When asked about the election's outcome, Carville expressed his belief that the Democrats were poised for a significant victory. "It's hard to look at it right now and come to any other conclusion than it is going to be a pretty sizable win for the Democrats," he said.

Carville attributed the Democrats' advantage to demographic changes in the country, which he described as unfavorable to the Republican Party. He also pointed out that the Republicans' focus on non-college whites had not been successful in presidential years.

Beyond demographics, Carville highlighted the negative impact of the last Republican presidency and the economic downturn on the party's prospects. "The last time we had a Republican president, we had a disastrous war and a disastrous recession," he said. "To the extent that peace and prosperity matter to anybody—which have traditionally been the two biggest drivers in American politics—they do not bode well for the Republicans."

Carville also addressed the rise of Donald Trump and the shift in the Republican Party's base. He noted that Trump's appeal to ethnocentric, nationalistic sentiments resonated with at least half of the Republican Party, which he described as a significant departure from traditional Republican views.

Carville also touched on the concerns within the Republican Party about losing an entire generation. "There are a lot of people in the United States that genuinely—and with some validity—think their influence is shrinking," he said. "Their lives have not turned out as they expected or hoped. Trump comes along and says, 'Of course this happened to you because of stupid politicians and immigrants.' He is appealing to people who look around, and their constant refrain is, 'This is not the same country that we grew up in.' And it's not."

The interview took place before the latest chapter in the Clinton email scandal broke, which has since prompted fresh accusations of preferential treatment to major Clinton Foundation donors and a "pay to play" culture during her tenure as Secretary of State. The scandal has added another layer of complexity to an already contentious election cycle.

Title: President Obama Highlights American Resilience and Unity in the Face of Challenges

Article:

In the aftermath of the recent natural disasters, President Obama emphasized the American spirit of unity and cooperation, stating that in times of hardship, Americans put aside their differences and work together. He highlighted the country's progress in recovering from the economic recession and the wars, with prosperity now on the rise.

The President underscored the importance of a thriving middle class, stating that America prospers when everyone gets a fair shot, does their fair share, and plays by the same rules. He emphasized his commitment to being the champion for the aspirations of all Americans and encouraged voters to cast their ballots on Tuesday.

Reflecting on the past, President Obama pointed to the administration's achievements, such as the end of the Iraq war, the death of Osama bin Laden, and the creation of nearly 5.5 million new jobs in the last two and a half years. He also highlighted improvements in home values, 401(k)s, energy independence, and the revival of the American auto industry.

Looking ahead, the President outlined his vision for real change, emphasizing investments in education, job training, research, technology, and healthcare. He highlighted his administration's efforts to make college more affordable, recruit math and science teachers, and train community college students for high-demand jobs.

President Obama also emphasized his commitment to manufacturing and innovation, stating that he is not the candidate who said "let Detroit go bankrupt." He pledged to create a tax code that rewards companies creating jobs in the U.S. and supports clean energy jobs and technology.

The President also emphasized his commitment to reducing the deficit through spending cuts and asking the wealthiest Americans to return to the income tax rates they paid during the Clinton administration. He pledged to work with anyone, regardless of party, to move the country forward.

In conclusion, President Obama emphasized that the America he believes in is within reach, and the future he hopes for is within sight. He urged voters to cast their ballots on Tuesday to continue the progress made in education, job creation, energy, and opportunity for all Americans.

Title: Florida High School Shooting Survivors Lobby for Assault Rifle Ban in Tallahassee

Aritcle:

In the aftermath of the deadly shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida, dozens of students and parents from the school traveled to Tallahassee on Tuesday to lobby for a ban on assault-style rifles. The mass shooting, which claimed the lives of 14 students and three educators, has sparked a national debate on gun rights and stricter firearm controls.

Students from the high school were emotional as they arrived in Tallahassee, greeted by waves, cheers, and somber applause from fellow teens. Diego Pfeiffer, a senior at Stoneman Douglas High, told the crowd, "We're here to make sure this never happens again."

On Tuesday, less than a week after the shooting, the Republican-controlled Florida House of Representatives rejected a bill to block sales of assault-style rifles in the state. Tyra Hemans, a 19-year-old senior who traveled to the state capital, said, "I am not going back to school until lawmakers, and the president, change this law."

Student and parent activists from the high school in Parkland were expected to stage a rally on Wednesday at the statehouse. Fourteen students and three educators were killed, and 15 other people were wounded in the Feb. 14 attack. Nikolas Cruz, 19, a former student expelled from Stoneman Douglas High for disciplinary problems, was arrested and charged with 17 counts of premeditated murder.

The year before, Florida's Department of Children and Families had opened an inquiry into Cruz after he was reported to have been cutting himself. However, the case was closed in November of that year with the finding that he was receiving sufficient support.

The youth-led protest movement that emerged in the wake of the shooting attracted prominent celebrity supporters on Tuesday. Film star George Clooney and his wife Amal, a human rights lawyer, pledged to donate $500,000 to help fund a planned March 24 gun control march in Washington. Hollywood director Steven Spielberg and media mogul Oprah Winfrey later joined in contributing $500,000 each toward the march.

A Washington Post-ABC News poll released on Tuesday showed 77 percent of Americans believe the Republican-dominated U.S. Congress is doing too little to prevent mass shootings, with 62 percent saying President Donald Trump has not done enough on that front. Trump signed a memorandum on Tuesday directing the attorney general to draw up regulations banning devices that turn firearms into machine guns, like the bump stock used in October's mass shooting in Las Vegas.

Students and parents elsewhere in Florida and in other states, including Tennessee and Minnesota, staged sympathy protests on Tuesday, according to local media reports. Funerals continued for the young victims of Wednesday's attack. The U.S. Military Academy at West Point on Tuesday said it made a rare posthumous letter of acceptance to Peter Wang, a student of the school killed in the shooting. A Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps cadet, Wang had aspired to attend the elite academy.

Gun violence on public school and college campuses has become so commonplace in the United States during the past several years that education officials regularly stage drills to train students and staff about what they should do in the event of a mass shooting on school grounds. Gun ownership is protected by the Second Amendment of the U.S. Constitution and remains one of the nation's more divisive issues. A federal ban on assault weapons, in force for 10 years, expired in 2004.

Title: Lobbyists Push Back Against Potential Alterations to Mortgage Interest Deduction and Carried Interest Tax Breaks in Upcoming Tax Reform

Article:

In the final 15 days before the Senate Finance Committee's deadline for justifying tax provisions in the Tax Code, two significant tax breaks are under scrutiny: the mortgage interest deduction and the carried interest tax break. These tax breaks, which are among the most contentious in the current tax system, could face significant changes or elimination in the ongoing tax reform discussions.

1. Mortgage Interest Deduction

The mortgage interest deduction, which allows homeowners to deduct up to $1 million in mortgage interest annually, including for vacation homes, is a substantial tax expenditure, making it a prime target during tax reform. The Congressional Budget Office projects the break will cost over $1 trillion over 10 years.

Critics argue that the deduction, often considered the epitome of popular tax breaks, may undergo significant changes to reduce its value while still being accessible to middle-class homeowners. President Barack Obama has proposed capping all deductions, including the mortgage interest write-off, at 28 percent. Lawmakers could also focus the write-off more on lower-income homeowners by capping it at $500,000 and replacing the deduction with a credit, saving $213 billion, according to the Tax Policy Center.

Lobbyists, such as the National Association of Realtors, are emphasizing the positive impact of the mortgage interest deduction on the housing market, particularly in vacation communities. They argue that curbing the break could harm housing prices during a time when the U.S. is slowly recovering from a years-long housing crisis.

1. Carried Interest Tax Break

The carried interest tax break, which allows hedge fund managers, private equity executives, and other Wall Street professionals to pay a special tax rate on profits-based compensation known as carried interest, is another contentious issue. Instead of paying ordinary income taxes, which top out at nearly 40 percent, carried interest is taxed as a capital gain, generally at a rate of 20 percent, with an additional 3.8 percent tax on investment income this year.

The carried interest tax break costs approximately $17 billion over 10 years. Democrats have long argued that the break is unfair, as Wall Street executives' pay is taxed at a lower rate than ordinary income. With tax reform underway, they may finally succeed in taxing carried interest as ordinary income if lawmakers decide it's not worth spending time on the tax concerns of hedge fund and private equity managers.

Industry lobbyists, such as the Private Equity Growth Capital Council, have consistently fought off Democrats' efforts to eliminate the carried interest tax break, arguing that higher taxes would negatively impact the economy. They claim that increasing taxes on carried interest would harm partnerships that support thousands of companies across the country.

As the Senate Finance Committee works to overhaul the tax system, these two tax breaks, along with hundreds of others, will likely face significant changes or elimination. Lobbyists and industry groups will continue to advocate for their preservation, emphasizing the positive impact they have on the housing market and the economy.

Title: FBI Fails to Act on Tip Regarding Florida School Shooter Nikolas Cruz

Article:

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) admitted on Friday that they had received a tip more than a month before the Parkland, Florida school shooting, in which 17 people were killed, that Nikolas Cruz owned guns, expressed a desire to kill people, and could potentially carry out a school shooting. However, the tip was not passed on or properly investigated.

According to the FBI, a person close to Cruz called in with concerns about him on January 5, 2018. The tipster described Cruz's gun ownership, his erratic behavior, disturbing social media posts, and the potential of him conducting a school shooting. The bureau stated that the tip should have been forwarded to the Miami field office and investigated, but that didn't happen.

"Protocols were not followed," the FBI said in a statement, adding that the Miami field office did not receive the tip, and "no further investigation was conducted at this time."

The FBI's failure to act on this tip is likely to generate scrutiny on how law enforcement handles its investigations in such cases. FBI Director Christopher Wray said, "We are still investigating the facts. I am committed to getting to the bottom of what happened in this particular matter, as well as reviewing the processes for responding to information that we receive from the public."

Florida Governor Rick Scott called for Wray's resignation, stating, "We constantly promote'see something, say something,' and a courageous person did just that to the FBI. And the FBI failed to act."

In addition to the call to the FBI tip line, Broward County Sheriff Scott Israel said at a press conference Friday that his department had received about 20 calls regarding Cruz in the past few years. He did not give details about the calls but said he would investigate each one to make sure it was handled appropriately.

President Donald Trump, in a tweet, appeared to blame "neighbors and classmates" for not reporting Cruz to authorities. However, the FBI's statement is the latest piece of evidence that many people not only saw red flags in Cruz's behavior but tried to report them, and those warnings were not thoroughly pursued or fell on deaf ears.

This failure on the part of the FBI comes after questions over a YouTube comment posted last fall by someone named "nikolas cruz" that read "Im going to be a professional school shooter." A man in Mississippi saw the comment on his YouTube channel and flagged it to both YouTube, which removed it, and the authorities.

At a press conference Thursday, FBI special agent Rob Lasky said that agents had spoken with the man who made the complaint, which tipster Ben Bennight confirmed with the New York Times. Lasky also said the FBI conducted database reviews and checks but was unable to identify the commenter.

"No additional information was found to positively identify the person who posted this comment," Lasky said.

This article has been updated with comments from Governor Rick Scott and the Broward County sheriff.

Title: LGBT Uninsured Rate Among Low- and Middle-Income Americans Decreases by a Quarter Since Affordable Care Act Implementation

Article:

A new report from the Center for American Progress reveals a significant decrease in the uninsured rate among low- and middle-income LGBT Americans since the implementation of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). The report, which relies on surveys of LGBT individuals earning less than 400 percent of the poverty line, shows a drop in the uninsured rate from 34 percent in 2013 to 26 percent in 2014.

The decline in the uninsured rate among LGBT individuals is slightly faster than the drop among the general population, where the uninsured rate fell by about a quarter. The gains were particularly large among lower-income groups, which were eligible for bigger insurance subsidies or the Medicaid expansion. The uninsured rate for LGBT individuals earning between 139 and 200 percent of the poverty line fell by 18 percentage points.

The report shows that 26 percent of LGBT Americans under 400 percent of the poverty line are uninsured, while among the general population, the number is 20 percent. LGBT people can face unique obstacles in gaining coverage, such as the lack of a federal law requiring companies to offer health benefits to their employees' same-sex partners. The report also suggests that anti-LGBT bias in hiring may push many LGBT people into unemployment or low-wage jobs that do not offer benefits such as health insurance coverage.

Only 38 percent of LGBT people under 400 percent of the poverty line have an offer of insurance through either their own or their spouse's employer, while among the general population, that number stands at 58 percent. The report also highlights disparities in coverage rates within the LGBT community, with gay and bisexual individuals having higher insured rates than lesbian women, and the uninsured rate among transgender populations being especially high. The report suggests that the uninsured rate among transgender populations has come down significantly under the Affordable Care Act, although the 2013 survey only included a smaller number of transgender individuals.

A correction was made to an initial version of this story, which misstated the size of the decline of the uninsured rate for LGBT people. The correct figure is 24 percent.

Title: Historic Flooding in Texas: Catastrophic Rainfall and Swift Government Response

Article:

The state of Texas is currently grappling with catastrophic flooding following the remnants of Hurricane Harvey, with the situation expected to worsen in the coming days. Houston, the fourth-largest city in the US, has already experienced a record 30 inches (75cm) of rain, turning roads into rivers. Forecasters predict that the total rainfall could nearly double by the end of the week.

US President Donald Trump has promised swift action to aid those affected, with a visit to Texas scheduled for Tuesday. He stated, "Recovery will be a long and difficult road, and the federal government stands ready, willing, and able to support that effort." Trump is also dealing with Congress on funding, warning that the situation will be "very expensive."

At least nine deaths have been reported in incidents related to the storm, with more than 3,000 people rescued in and around Houston. The area is expected to have received a year's worth of rainfall within a week. Officials expect half a million disaster victims to seek assistance in Texas, and 30,000 people to be housed in emergency shelters.

The National Hurricane Center has warned of "catastrophic and life-threatening flooding" in south-eastern Texas, with additional rainfall of 15 to 25 inches expected. Army engineers have begun releasing water from two dams controlling water flowing along a major river into the heart of Houston to prevent water from spilling into neighboring communities, which could cause further damage.

Many schools are closed, and Houston's two main airports have been shut down due to flooded runways. The Texas Gulf Coast, a key center of the US oil and gas industry, has seen some of the largest refineries in the country halt operations.

Residents in the suburbs west of Houston have been wading through waist-high flooding for miles to reach shops, schools, and work. Many have been forced to form makeshift armadas using boats, jet skis, and inflatable rafts to navigate the treacherous waters.

Comparisons have been drawn with the disastrous evacuation of homes in New Orleans ahead of Hurricane Katrina in 2005, which left thousands of people stranded in squalid conditions at the city's stadium. Tens of thousands of people have been ordered to leave parts of Fort Bend County, about 35 miles south-west of Houston, where a river is set to crest this week.

Dallas, 240 miles north of Houston, will set up a "mega shelter" at its convention center to house 5,000 evacuees, city officials said. However, Houston authorities have not issued a mass evacuation order. Mayor Sylvester Turner defended this decision, citing the "crazy" logistics of planning an evacuation of 2.3 million people.

Police Chief Art Acevedo stated that officers are focused on protecting the city from looters, with four people arrested on Monday.

For those willing to speak to a BBC journalist, please provide a contact number. Alternatively, you can contact us through the following methods: [contact information].

Title: Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren Declines 2020 Presidential Run, Addresses Native American Heritage Controversy

Article:

In an interview on "Fox News Sunday," Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren, a prominent figure in the Democratic Party's progressive wing, announced that she will not be running for president in 2020. The interview also saw Warren addressing the long-standing controversy surrounding her Native American heritage, a topic that has been a point of contention in her Senate campaigns and could potentially complicate a presidential bid.

When asked about the calls for genetic testing to resolve the heritage controversy, Warren shared a family history as recounted by her parents and grandparents. She stated, "It's a part of who I am, and no one's ever going to take that away."

Senator Warren, who is running for a second Senate term this year, has been accused of claiming Native American heritage to secure jobs, including a position as a Harvard law professor. She has acknowledged identifying as a minority, but denies using her status to further her career.

President Trump has frequently referred to Warren, a Wall Street critic and potential White House rival, as "Pocahontas," a notable Native American woman in colonial history, to highlight the controversy.

In the interview, Warren shared personal anecdotes about her family. "My mom and dad were born and raised out in Oklahoma," she said. "My daddy was in his teens when he fell in love with my mother. She was a beautiful girl who played the piano. And he was head over heels in love with her, and his family was bitterly opposed to that because she was part Native American."

Warren went on to describe the hardships her parents faced during the Great Depression and the Dust Bowl, and their resilience in raising their children, including Warren and her older brothers, all of whom served in the military. She concluded, "I know who I am because of what my mother and my father told me, what my grandmother and my grandfather told me, what all my aunts and uncles told me and my brothers."

Title: Supreme Court Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Ruth Bader Ginsburg Align on Prisoner's Supervised Release Case

Article:

In an unexpected turn of events, Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg joined her conservative colleagues in a decision regarding a prisoner's supervised release case on Monday. The liberal justice, alongside Justices Clarence Thomas, John Roberts, Samuel Alito, and Brett Kavanaugh, ruled that a criminal defendant, in this case Jason Mont, can be sentenced for violating his supervised release, even if the release expires while he is incarcerated ahead of facing new charges.

Mont, who had been indicted by a grand jury for multiple drug and firearm offenses, was released from federal prison on March 6, 2012, but was found guilty of two counts of cocaine trafficking and tested positive on several drug tests. His supervised release date was set for June 28, 2017.

In this case, Mont challenged the jurisdiction of the District Court, arguing that his supervised release had initially been set to expire on March 6, 2017. The court, however, concluded that it had authority to supervise Mont, revoked his supervised release, and ordered him to serve an additional 42 months' imprisonment to run consecutive to his state sentence.

In her dissent, Justice Ginsburg argued that time in pretrial detention should not be considered supervised release unless the charges against the defendant are dismissed or the defendant is acquitted. This, she stated, ensures that the defendant is not faulted for conduct he might not have committed, while otherwise giving full effect to the lawful judgment previously imposed on the defendant.

This surprising alliance between Ginsburg and Thomas comes a week after a tense argument over the case Box v. Planned Parenthood of Indiana and Kentucky Inc. The Court decided against taking up the question of the Sex Selective and Disability Abortion Ban, which, as Justice Thomas described it, bans abortions in which "the mother is seeking the abortion solely because of the child's race, sex, diagnosis of Down syndrome, disability, or related characteristics."

In his 20-page opinion, Thomas wrote about the potential for eugenic manipulation in abortion, citing Planned Parenthood founder Margaret Sanger's openness about the use of birth control for eugenic purposes. Ginsburg, in response, described Thomas's diatribe as "displaying more heat than light." She reasoned that "a woman who exercises her constitutionally protected right to terminate a pregnancy is not a'mother.'"

Today, the justices managed to find an issue on which they have common ground. The decision in the Mont case is a reminder of the complex and nuanced nature of the cases that come before the Supreme Court, and the often unexpected alliances that can form among the justices.

Title: Bipartisan Immigration Bill Includes Pet Provisions for Specific Industries

Article:

In the 844-page bipartisan immigration bill, a historic shift in policies such as a path to citizenship for 11 million unauthorized immigrants, there are provisions that cater to the interests of the senators who crafted it. These pet projects, or industry-specific provisions, are designed to address the needs of key sectors in their respective states.

For instance, South Carolina Republican Sen. Lindsey Graham has advocated for more visas for the meat industry, a significant employer in his state. New York Democrat Sen. Charles Schumer, whose state has a large Irish population, has pushed for special treatment for Irish workers. Florida Republican Sen. Marco Rubio has sought assistance for the cruise-ship industry, a significant business in his home state. Colorado Democratic Sen. Michael Bennet has included a boost for ski areas in the bill.

One of the most contentious additions to the bill is the provision that sets aside up to 20,000 additional visas for meat cutters and trimmers. This move was spearheaded by Sen. Graham, according to sources familiar with the negotiations. The meat industry employed 158,480 Americans nationwide in May 2012, according to the Labor Department.

In South Carolina, broilers (chickens raised for meat) are the number one commodity, generating $698 million in 2011, nearly 27% of all agricultural cash in the state, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Turkeys were the second-largest commodity in the state.

The United Food and Commercial Workers International Union is not in favor of the visas to bring in more foreign workers, citing a lack of labor shortage in the industry. "The way we view this is it's an earmark for meat and poultry, and we strongly, strongly oppose it," said Tim Schlittner, a spokesman for the labor union.

Sen. Bennet, working with an association that represents most of Colorado's ski resorts, has crafted a provision to make it easier for them to hire foreign ski instructors. Instead of using a visa program for temporary, low-skilled workers, ski instructors would be eligible to come to the U.S. under the same program that professional athletes use.

Ski areas are hiring fewer foreign workers for jobs such as housekeeping and lift-operating since the recession, but finding certified ski instructors, especially those who speak other languages and can communicate with foreign tourists, has been a problem. "The perfect example of this is a certified ski instructor who speaks Portuguese," said Melanie Mills, president of Colorado Ski Country USA, which represents 21 of Colorado's 25 ski areas.

For Sen. Schumer, the immigration bill was an opportunity to weave in an extra 10,500 visas for Irish people with at least a high-school degree. Sen. Rubio, from hurricane-prone Florida, has inserted an opportunity for foreigners to come to the U.S. for 90 days to work on relief operations after state or federal disasters. He has also given a nod to the recently embattled cruise industry with a provision allowing certain foreigners to repair cruise ships made abroad, as well as other transportation equipment.

Few business sectors have been more critical of immigration-bill provisions than the construction industry, but even it fared better than expected. Sen. Rubio and Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.), who both advocated for the construction industry during negotiations, were not able to get a cap lifted that limits construction visas to 15,000. However, they did include a provision, which many in the construction industry had feared dead, allowing foreigners to work in higher-skilled jobs such as electricians, plumbers, and welders.

Despite the victory, various construction groups said in interviews they would fight the overall cap on construction jobs. "Obviously, this is just the first step of a long road," said Marco Giamberardino, executive director of government affairs at the National Electrical Contractors Association.

Title: Martin Family Urges President Obama to Investigate Trayvon Martin's Shooting Death, Calls for Peaceful Protests

Article:

In a television interview on Thursday, Sybrina Fulton, the mother of Trayvon Martin, called on President Barack Obama to thoroughly examine the circumstances surrounding her son's shooting death, stating that the verdict has sent a troubling message to American teenagers.

Appearing on "CBS This Morning," Fulton, accompanied by her husband, Tracy Martin, was asked what action she expected from the president. "At least investigate what happened," Fulton said. "At least go through it with a fine-tooth comb and just make sure all the T's are crossed and all the I's are dotted, because this is sending a terrible message."

The interview marked the first time Martin's parents had given television interviews since the verdict was announced last weekend, which found George Zimmerman not guilty of murdering Trayvon Martin. Obama released a statement urging calm following the verdict, but has not publicly commented on the decision.

The Department of Justice is currently investigating whether it will bring a civil rights case against Zimmerman, although the White House has stated that Obama will not be involved in the decision-making process. Martin's family attorney, Benjamin Crump, indicated that they were considering legal options for a potential civil suit and were seeking the Justice Department's input.

"We're asking the Department of Justice to answer that question for us," Crump said. "Can a private citizen with a gun profile and follow our children home? Because the United States Supreme Court doesn't even allow the police to profile people based on race, so this is an issue – we need to know because we got to know what to tell our children."

Tracy Martin also spoke on NBC's "Today" on Thursday, stating, "Obviously, any time you have a person that makes an assumption that a person is up to no good, there's some type of profiling there. Was he racially profiled? I think that if Trayvon had been white, this wouldn't have ever happened. So obviously race played some type of role."

The Martin family also urged protesters to maintain peaceful demonstrations, with Fulton stating on NBC, "We have always maintained to do things decent and in order, and we think the protests should be peaceful protests."

Emotionally affected by the verdict, Martin's parents discussed the impact of the case on them. "As parents, understanding how they reached that verdict, I'll never grasp that concept," Tracy Martin said in another interview on "Good Morning America" Thursday. "We feel that the verdict, we didn't feel it was fair. And of course it's devastating."

Fulton also responded to one of the jurors who, anonymously speaking with CNN, placed some of the blame for Trayvon's death on him. "I don't think she knows Trayvon. Trayvon is not a confrontational person. So instead of placing the blame on the teenager, we need to place the blame on the responsible adult. There were two people involved. We had an adult that was chasing a kid, and we had the kid, who I feel was afraid," Fulton said on CBS.

Title: Bush and Obama Share Stage in Rare Display of Bipartisanship at White House Portrait Unveiling

Article:

In a rare display of bipartisanship, former President George W. Bush and current President Barack Obama shared the stage during the unveiling of Bush's official portrait at the White House. The event, attended by Bush's family, including his daughters Jenna and Barbara, as well as former President George H.W. Bush and first lady Barbara Bush, was marked by humor and camaraderie.

Bush, known for his jocularity, jokingly compared his portrait to that of George Washington, stating, "I am pleased that my portrait brings an interesting symmetry to the White House collection: It now starts and ends with George W." He then turned to First Lady Michelle Obama, quipping, "If anything happens, Michelle, this is your man."

The audience, comprising former Bush administration officials, family members, and friends, erupted in laughter. Bush's next line, advising Obama to "gaze at his portrait" whenever he had a significant decision to make and ask himself, "What would George do?" drew even louder laughter.

Retired and living on his ranch in Crawford, Texas, Bush charmed the audience with his trademark humor, while the Obamas, in the midst of a heated re-election campaign, were tasked with playing gracious hosts and focusing on shared experiences and the pressures of the presidency.

"We may have our differences politically," Obama said, "but the presidency transcends those differences." He thanked the Bush family for their assistance during the transition in late 2008 and for the advice the Bush daughters gave to Malia and Sasha.

Observers would never guess, based on Obama's tribute to Bush in the White House State Room, that he had spent a significant portion of his presidency blaming Bush for numerous challenges, including the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, the economic downturn, and soaring deficits.

Despite the political differences, the White House maintained that there was mutual respect and appreciation between the two presidents. White House spokesman Jay Carney stated, "There were differences, I'm sure, in the past when incumbent presidents have presided over these ceremonies. But there is so much in common for the men thus far who have occupied this office and for their families who have lived in the White House, that I think there is a great deal of respect and appreciation held by everyone who is participating."

Title: The Balance Between Privacy and Progress: A Modern Dilemma

Article:

In the digital age, the balance between privacy and progress is a delicate one, as individuals grapple with the implications of voluntary and involuntary data sharing. The latest revelations highlight the issue, with Scarlett Johansson's nude photos being leaked, a Pennsylvania high school's remote activation of students' laptop cameras, and the tracking of internet users' activities by favorite websites.

Johansson's case underscores the potential consequences of data breaches, as a hacker obtained and disseminated nude photos of the actress without her consent. In a similar vein, a Pennsylvania high school's decision to remotely activate students' laptop cameras while they were away from school has sparked controversy, raising questions about privacy and surveillance.

Meanwhile, the tracking of internet users' activities by websites is becoming increasingly common, with programs like Disconnect revealing the extent to which personal data is being collected and analyzed. This information includes browsing habits, reading preferences, and purchasing history.

In response to these developments, some argue that individuals should be more concerned about their privacy. However, others contend that the distinction between voluntary and involuntary data sharing is crucial. Voluntary sharing, such as with Amazon or Facebook, is often seen as less problematic because individuals have the option to check privacy policies and make informed decisions. In contrast, government agencies, such as the National Security Agency (NSA), may access personal information without explicit consent.

The NSA's data mining activities have been a source of controversy, with concerns about privacy and potential misuse of information. However, the author argues that the important difference is not whether they know one's name, but rather whether the data sharing is voluntary.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration's push for black box recorders in all cars is another example of this dilemma. While the bureaucrats argue that the data is needed to improve road safety and infrastructure, concerns about privacy and potential misuse persist.

Ultimately, the author suggests that individuals value the freedom to choose when they share personal information, and are willing to give up some privacy in exchange for progress. However, the line between voluntary and involuntary data sharing is increasingly blurred, and the implications of this trend are a topic of ongoing debate.

Title: Police Use of Non-Lethal Weapons in U.S. Protests: A Closer Look at Tear Gas, Pepper Spray, and Rubber Bullets

Article:

As demonstrations against the police killing of George Floyd continue to escalate across the United States, law enforcement agencies are employing a range of non-lethal weapons to disperse protesters. These weapons, often described as non-lethal, include tear gas, pepper spray, and rubber bullets. However, these tools have at times resulted in serious injuries.

Tear gas, also known as CS or CN gas, is a chemical compound powder that is sprayed from canisters. It produces a burning sensation in the eyes and mouth, causing temporary incapacitation.

Police have deployed tear gas, pepper spray, and flash-bang devices in cities such as Minneapolis, Seattle, and Washington D.C. Images from these protests show protesters fleeing as they are met with these non-lethal weapons.

Pepper spray, chemically distinct from tear gas, also causes a burning and watering of the eyes and skin. It is discharged from handheld devices and projectiles by police officers.

In addition to tear gas and pepper spray, police have used pepper balls, small projectiles containing chemical irritants. These projectiles can contain PAVA spray, an irritant similar to pepper spray, as well as CS gas. They can be shot from launchers or modified paintball guns.

Flashbang grenades, which explode with bright light and sound to stun and disorient demonstrators, have also been used by police.

Rubber, plastic, and "sponger" bullets have been reported to have struck protesters. In some cases, these bullets have caused injury, with a 2017 survey published by the British Medical Journal finding that 2.7% of deaths were caused by such "kinetic impact projectiles."

Protesters have also reported being shot with wooden bullets by police forces. Images online show wooden dowel-shaped rods sliced into small, bullet-sized projectiles. The Columbus Police Department did not respond to requests for comment.

In Los Angeles, police have used rubber projectiles, and Mayor Eric Garcetti has stated that the police department will minimize their use going forward.

As the protests continue, it is crucial to understand the potential consequences of the non-lethal weapons being used by law enforcement. While these weapons are intended to control and disperse crowds, their use can result in serious injury and even death in some cases.

Title: Germanwings Co-Pilot Concealed Illness, Tore Up Medical Leave Note Before Fatal Crash, Prosecutors Say

A statement from German prosecutors on Friday revealed that Andreas Lubitz, the co-pilot who is believed to have deliberately crashed a German airliner into the Alps, had concealed an illness from his employers and tore up a doctor's note calling for him to go on medical leave on the day of the tragic incident.

Police, during a search on Thursday at Lubitz's Dusseldorf apartment, found a torn medical certificate and other documents. Germanwings, the low-cost airline where Lubitz worked, stated in a Friday release that it had received no such sick leave note for the day of the ill-fated flight. Lufthansa, the parent-company of Germanwings, had previously declared that Lubitz was "100% fit to fly."

The Dusseldorf prosecutors' office statement indicated that no suicide note or claim of responsibility from Lubitz was found, and no evidence of a political or religious background linked to the tragedy was discovered. The officials also stated that the search found no evidence suggesting a political or religious motive for the crash.

The statement revealed that police found medical documents "indicating an existing illness and corresponding medical treatment." The prosecutor added that a torn-up current sick note, also valid for the day of the incident, was among the documents. This, according to the prosecutor, "would -- according to preliminary evaluation -- support the assumption that the deceased had concealed his illness towards his employer and his occupational environment."

The nature of Lubitz's illness remains undisclosed, although German media outlets reported he may have suffered from depression. Dusseldorf University clinic stated that Lubitz visited the facility in February and March, most recently on March 10, for diagnosis but denied he was treated there for depression, according to Sky News reports.

Germany's Federal Aviation Office has requested that Lufthansa provide access to Lubitz's medical records, which would then be sent to French investigators, according to DPA reports.

The cockpit voice recorder revealed that Lubitz deliberately locked the pilot out of the cockpit and then initiated a descent that led to the deaths of all 150 people on board the plane bound for Dusseldorf from Barcelona, French prosecutor Brice Robin said Thursday. No motive was provided.

Investigators searched Lubitz's apartment in Dusseldorf and the home of his parents in Montabaur, about 40 miles from Bonn. They were seen removing boxes and large blue bags from both residences.

Unconfirmed reports circulating in the German media suggested that Lubitz, by all official accounts a skilled pilot with a distinguished training record who was not being monitored by security services, may have been suffering from depression.

Bild reported that on several occasions, Lubitz's training at Lufthansa's flight school in Phoenix, Ariz., was interrupted for mental health reasons after he had a "serious depressive episode." The German tabloid reported that Lubitz may have undergone treatment after being what it called "demoted" several times during his training in the United States.

The newspaper referred to him as a mass murderer. It said the "episode" was noted on his medical records held by the aviation authorities. Der Spiegel also separately reported the findings that have not been confirmed.

Germany's Federal Aviation Office would not confirm the report. Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr said Thursday that Lubitz's training was "interrupted" six years ago, but declined to elaborate.

Thomas Winkelmann, the low-cost carrier's chief executive, released a statement Friday saying that the airline has begun setting up a family assistance center in Marseille, France, and that briefings with family members will start there on Saturday.

"The suffering and pain this catastrophe has caused is immeasurable," he said in the statement. "No words can express it and no amount of consolation is sufficient but we want to be there for visiting family members and friends if our support is desired."

Title: NBC News Poll: Christie Trails Clinton in Hypothetical 2016 Match-Up, Faces Divided GOP - Early Stage Polling and the 2016 Presidential Race

Article:

An early stage poll released by NBC News on Tuesday morning indicates that New Jersey Governor Chris Christie trails former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in a hypothetical 2016 match-up, with a 47% to 42% lead for Clinton. The poll also suggests a divided Republican party, with Christie trailing other potential GOP candidates such as Jeb Bush, Rand Paul, and Ted Cruz.

The poll, which was conducted between February 13 and 16, surveyed 1,000 registered voters and has a margin of error of +/- 3.1 percentage points. It is important to note that neither Clinton nor Christie have officially declared their candidacy for the 2016 presidential race.

The first contest of the 2016 election cycle, if nothing changes, will be the Iowa caucuses, likely in January 2016. The general election is more than 1,000 days away.

The accuracy of polls taken at such an early stage in the election cycle is a matter of debate. For example, President Rudy Giuliani had high poll numbers in 2007 due to his time as the take-charge mayor of New York on 9/11, but he faded quickly once the GOP primaries got underway. Similarly, other potential candidates such as Colin Powell, Mario Cuomo, Gary Hart, Edmund Muskie, and others have decided not to run or have seen their poll numbers decline over time.

While the polling numbers are interesting, it is still early in the election cycle, and the race is likely to change significantly as the candidates begin to campaign and the field narrows. It is important to take these polls with a grain of salt and to remember that the election is still more than a year away.

In the meantime, there are many other issues to discuss and analyze, and the political landscape is constantly evolving. As a journalist, I am excited to cover the 2016 election and to see how the race unfolds over the next year and a half. But for now, I will take a breather and enjoy the ride.

Title: U.S. President Donald Trump to Meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin: A Look at the Anticipated Meeting and Expected Outcomes

Article:

In an anticipated meeting this Friday, U.S. President Donald Trump will hold talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Hamburg, Germany. This meeting, which has sparked concerns worldwide, is expected to be a significant event in the ongoing U.S.-Russia relations.

The meeting will reportedly include only six individuals: the presidents, their respective foreign ministers, Rex Tillerson and Sergey Lavrov, and two translators. This limited attendance has raised concerns, as Lavrov is a seasoned diplomat who has been instrumental in executing Putin's foreign policy since 2004. Tillerson, the U.S. Secretary of State, is expected to be the only other American official in the room.

In an ideal scenario, a U.S. president with a comprehensive understanding of Russian history and statecraft, and a respect for diplomacy, would use this meeting to address the issue of Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. election. The president would unequivocally support investigations into election meddling, including any potential collusion between the Russian government and the Trump campaign. The U.S. would also threaten to expose the hidden bank accounts and investments of senior Kremlin officials as a means to undermine Russia's status as a great power.

However, it is widely expected that this meeting will not follow such a course. Trump's unpredictable and often fractious approach to diplomacy, combined with his apparent distrust of the U.S. diplomatic corps, has led to concerns that the meeting may not yield positive results. Instead, the meeting may focus on issues such as joint U.S.-Russian efforts to combat terrorism, as Trump has shown a greater interest in military matters.

It remains to be seen what the outcome of the meeting will be, but one thing is certain: the world will be watching closely as the two leaders engage in what promises to be a significant and potentially pivotal encounter.

Title: Indiana Primary Polling: A Matter of Uncertainty as Trump and Cruz Battle for Victory

Article:

As Indiana prepares for its primary election on Tuesday, the race between Donald Trump and Ted Cruz remains uncertain, with both candidates holding significant leads in various polls. The state has seen less attention than other major primary contests, with only seven public telephone surveys in the past month, compared to nine in Wisconsin and 17 in New York.

The scarcity of public polling and the varying results, including one survey showing Cruz leading by 16 points and several recent surveys giving Trump similarly large leads, is due to a combination of factors. These include a longer primary process than some organizations budgeted for, a short one-week run-up to the primary, and unique state laws that make it more difficult to conduct some kinds of phone surveys.

Ted Cruz's campaign has been eager to dismiss the new Indiana surveys showing the Texas senator trailing Trump. Cruz stated on Mike Gallagher's syndicated conservative-talk-radio show that "Indiana is neck and neck." Of the seven public polls conducted over the past three weeks, Trump leads six, with Cruz's only advantage coming from an Indiana University-Purdue University Fort Wayne survey that showed Cruz with a massive 16-point lead.

Andy Downs, the pollster for the IPFW survey, said his team was surprised by the results, questioning whether the results for Cruz and Trump were incorrectly reversed. The IPFW poll differs from the other surveys in two ways: a longer, 15-day field period and the lack of demographic weighting.

Demographic weighting allows pollsters to adjust their surveys to ensure a representative sample. Without weighting, the poll may under-represent younger voters and over-represent older voters. Downs declined to weight the results due to the long time since Indiana held a competitive GOP primary.

The other public polls show Trump ahead, but by varying margins. Trump's slimmest lead came in a one-day survey conducted last Wednesday by Clout Research, with a 2-point advantage over Cruz. Trump's largest lead, 17 points, was in a poll conducted last Thursday and Friday by Gravis Marketing, a prolific but less-respected firm.

The most recent reliable poll, an NBC News/Wall Street Journal/Marist survey conducted last Wednesday-Friday and released on Sunday, showed Trump with a commanding 15-point lead over Cruz, 49 percent to 34 percent. Lee Miringoff, the director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion, said the poll came in the wake of two newsmaking maneuvers the Cruz campaign has attempted: the deal with Ohio Gov. John Kasich to allow Cruz a one-on-one shot at Trump in Indiana, and naming Carly Fiorina as Cruz's running mate.

Carly Fiorina, in response, criticized the Marist poll, stating that it has been "way off" in the past. Miringoff responded, citing a line from the Mel Brooks western spoof "Blazing Saddles": "Can't you see that's the last act of a desperate man?"

Marist's biggest miss of the primary campaign was in the Michigan Democratic primary, where Bernie Sanders won by less than 1.5 points after Marist's final poll showed him 17 points behind Hillary Clinton. "It's not accurate" to say they have been "way off," Miringoff said. "In fact, we've had a very good track record in the primaries – which are not easy."

IPFW's Downs acknowledged that the poll is out on a limb showing Cruz ahead, but he stressed that he doesn't yet know why his numbers differ from other pollsters. "We really have no idea what the electorate will be," he said. The outcome of Tuesday's primary will provide valuable insights into the remaining GOP race and the overall presidential election.
