Title: Rep. Ilhan Omar Calls for Impeachment of Supreme Court Justice Kavanaugh Amid Allegations; New York Times Alters Report Following Backlash

Article:

In a series of tweets on Sunday, Representative Ilhan Omar (D-MN) called for the impeachment of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh following a report in The New York Times that alleged an eyewitness saw friends of Kavanaugh engage in an inappropriate act at a college party. However, the Times later amended its report on Sunday evening, stating that the female student involved did not recall the incident, according to friends, and declined to comment.

The initial report, which was adapted from a forthcoming book by two Times journalists, Robin Pogrebin and Kate Kelly titled "The Education of Brett Kavanaugh: An Investigation," did not include the detail that the alleged victim did not recall the incident. This information was added to the article on Sunday evening.

Before the Times amended the report, Democrats, including Omar, began calling for Kavanaugh's impeachment. On Sunday, Omar tweeted, "Nothing terrifies this corrupt president more than the idea of Congress upholding the rule of law. We must open impeachment inquiries against Trump * and * Kavanaugh immediately. It's our constitutional duty."

Omar has not commented or taken back her tweet as of Monday.

The Times' report was met with criticism from both the right and the left for omitting the detail that the alleged victim did not recall the incident. MSNBC's Morning Joe host Joe Scarborough questioned why the Times left out this information, stating, "We were on the phone yesterday asking each other, wait a second, there's a woman who [Max] Stier claims was abused by Kavanaugh. Has she denied this? Has she claimed this happened? Why is there this glaring omission in the New York Times story?"

The Times piece also failed to mention that the person making the new allegation, Max Stier, had served on former President Bill Clinton's defense team during impeachment proceedings. Kavanaugh had served on independent counsel Kenneth Starr's team.

Title: The Rise of Political Polarization in the United States: A Closer Look at the Factors Influencing America's Divide

Article:

The United States, a nation renowned for its democratic system, has been grappling with a significant increase in political polarization over the past decade and a half. Some experts even suggest that the nation is as divided as it was during the Civil War era. This polarization has led to name-calling, gridlock, and a lack of productive discourse.

A recent BBC video investigates the division of Americans into two warring tribes, shedding light on the factors contributing to this polarized attitude. One such factor is the geographical location of individuals, with the place of residence playing a role in shaping political views and thought. The proliferation of hyper-partisan news and social media further exacerbates this issue, allowing Americans to live in ideological isolation, remaining within an echo chamber if they so choose.

In the past, American politics functioned differently. For instance, in 1994, the ideological divide was not as pronounced. According to the Pew Research Center, moderates constituted a majority of voters, and Democrats and Republicans were not as ideologically distant from one another. However, over the past two decades, the field of moderates has significantly shrunk, and Democrats and Republicans have moved further apart in terms of finding common ground.

The question remains: Can America find common ground and bridge the ideological gap? While it is hoped that this may occur in the future, the current state of affairs does not seem promising. Each American strives for what they believe is best for the country, but understanding complex issues and determining effective solutions is a challenging task.

In the future, it is hoped that Americans and American media can strive for integrity in their sharing of information, moving away from the democratization of unfounded opinion on social media. By fostering an environment that encourages open, informed dialogue, Americans may come to realize that they are in this together, regardless of their political leanings.

Title: Presidential Candidate Amy Klobuchar Vows to Counter Restrictive Abortion Laws, Defends Late-Term Abortion in Certain Cases

Article:

In a recent interview on Fox News Sunday, Democratic presidential hopeful Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) criticized new abortion laws in Republican-led states and pledged to take action to counter such measures if she wins in 2020.

The senator pointed to states such as Georgia, which passed the so-called "heartbeat bills," prohibiting abortion once a fetal heartbeat is detected, typically after six weeks - a time when many women may not yet be aware they are pregnant. Last week, Alabama enacted a near-total ban on abortions at any point in time, even in cases of rape or incest.

Klobuchar described these laws as "dangerous" and "a place that we have never seen." She stated that these new laws would effectively make it impossible for women to access abortion, while also noting that some states are attempting to cut funding for Planned Parenthood, which would limit access to contraception.

Lawmakers, such as the sponsor of the Alabama law, have made it clear that the purpose of passing such sweeping restrictions on abortion is to provoke a legal challenge. Their aim is to bring a case before the Supreme Court, where a conservative majority might overturn Roe v. Wade, a landmark 1973 decision that established a woman's right to an abortion under the Constitution. If Roe v. Wade is overturned, individual states would be able to decide whether or not to keep abortion legal.

To combat this, Klobuchar promised that if Roe v. Wade is overturned, "I would make sure that we are codifying Roe v. Wade into law."

In contrast, Republicans have expressed concern over bills that were proposed in states including Virginia and New York, which make broad allowances for abortion, permitting it at any time during a pregnancy under certain circumstances. The Virginia bill, which sparked outrage when Delegate Kathy Tran said it would allow abortion up until birth, failed in the state legislature. In January, New York passed the Reproductive Health Act, which removed certain restrictions on third-trimester abortions and allowed the procedure at any point in a woman's pregnancy in certain situations.

When asked about laws like this, and whether she supports legislation that permits late-term abortions, Klobuchar said she does, in cases where the mother's life or health are in jeopardy.

"That is exactly what the Supreme Court ruling says and I am OK with that," she said.

Title: "Bernie Sanders' Lead in New Hampshire Challenges Hillary Clinton's 'Inevitability' Amidst Ongoing Scandals"

Article:

In the ongoing race for the Democratic presidential nomination, Bernie Sanders is currently leading in the New Hampshire primary, according to recent polls. This development has sparked a shift in the political landscape, with many observers suggesting that Sanders' rise could potentially challenge the perceived 'inevitability' of Hillary Clinton's nomination.

While Clinton continues to lead in national polls by a significant margin, the increasing presence of viable candidates like Sanders is being seen as a positive development by some, as it offers a stronger backup plan should Clinton's campaign be derailed by ongoing scandals.

The email imbroglio, which has been a constant source of controversy since it emerged in March, is currently the most pressing issue for Clinton's campaign. The handling of the scandal, the swirl of half-truths, denials, reversals, and revelations, has left many questioning the transparency of Clinton's campaign.

The past five months have seen a recurring sense of déjà vu and dread, reminiscent of the 1990s, as new allegations and counter-attacks from the Clinton camp have emerged. The ongoing email controversy, the potential slush fund run by her husband, and the association with billionaire investor Jeffrey Epstein and his alleged involvement in underage prostitution are all issues that have the potential to cause significant damage to Clinton's campaign.

The Epstein controversy, in particular, has raised concerns due to the numerous flights taken by Bill Clinton on Epstein's private jet, nicknamed the "Lolita Express." While the nature and extent of Clinton's association with Epstein are still unclear, the potential for further revelations remains a concern for many.

As the primary season approaches, the question on many minds is when the next scandal will break, and whether it will occur before or after the primaries, the convention, or the debates. The ongoing scandals and the potential for more to emerge have led some to question Clinton's ability to maintain her 'inevitability' in the race for the Democratic nomination.

In this context, Sanders' rise in the polls is being seen as a positive development by some, as it offers a viable alternative should Clinton's campaign be derailed by ongoing scandals. The focus now shifts to the upcoming primaries and debates, where the candidates will have the opportunity to present their visions for the future of the Democratic Party and the country.

Title: A Reflection on the Obsessive Focus on Political Scandals: Trump-Cohen Case and Beyond

Article:

The recent court appearance of Michael Cohen, President Donald Trump's former lawyer, has brought renewed attention to allegations of personal misconduct and potential illegal activities. Cohen pleaded guilty to a range of crimes, including making hush money payments to two women at the president's behest, as revealed on Tuesday.

The revelations have sparked a flurry of reactions, with Trump's critics expressing satisfaction, while his supporters remain unwavering. However, the question remains: Has Cohen's court appearance changed anyone's perception of the president? It is doubtful.

This development has led me to reflect on the impact of our obsession with political scandals, particularly in the context of the current political climate. It is a reflection that I anticipate sharing more about in the coming days.

The United States faces significant challenges that require the government's full attention. On Tuesday, for instance, it was reported that Microsoft had detected the Russian military attempting to hack the websites of conservative think tanks. The U.S. continues to engage in low-intensity wars in Afghanistan, Syria, and Yemen, without a clear strategic goal or measure of victory. Furthermore, an assertive and self-confident China is building islands in the South China Sea for military bases, potentially controlling crucial trade routes.

Our preoccupation with the intricate details of illicit but consensual relationships between adults, or the gossipy West Wing intrigue, diverts attention from these pressing issues. I, for one, am exhausted and bored by the psychodramas that consume an unnatural portion of our collective attention.

It is not my intention to shame Trump's critics into silence with this reflection. I share this view regardless of political affiliation. During the Obama years, we were subjected to speculation about his birthplace, notably from Trump himself when he was still a private citizen. If you disagree with the president's policies, such as his plans to renegotiate trade deals or his efforts to secure NATO member contributions, by all means, express your dissent.

However, this fixation on petty personal corruption serves as a harmful distraction. Trump's personal indiscretions are a sideshow. So were Bill Clinton's "bimbo eruptions." Let us refocus our attention on the critical issues that demand our collective effort and understanding.

Title: Trump Accuses China and EU of Currency Manipulation, Threatens Tariffs on All Chinese Imports

President Donald Trump has criticized China and the European Union for manipulating their currencies and interest rates, stating that a stronger U.S. dollar and rising interest rates are undermining America's "competitive edge." In a series of tweets on Friday, Trump also indicated his readiness to impose U.S. tariffs on all Chinese imports, amounting to approximately $500 billion, the value of all U.S. imports from China last year.

Trump's comments come during a week when he is facing growing pressure over his relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin. The president's lukewarm support for U.S. intelligence agencies' findings that Russia interfered in the 2016 election has sparked criticism.

In an apparent reference to the Federal Reserve's interest rate increases, Trump added, "Tightening now hurts all that we have done. Debt coming due & we are raising rates -- Really?"

In a CNBC interview that aired earlier on Friday, Trump stated, "We are being taken advantage of and I don't like it." This marks a shift in an escalating trade war with countries the president accuses of trading unfairly, raising the prospect that the conflict could also morph into a currency spat.

Trump's comments break with decades of tradition that presidents avoid commenting directly on the dollar or the path of U.S. monetary policy. The latter is usually seen as the domain of the Fed, while the U.S. Treasury secretary is typically the chief spokesman on the dollar.

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin is expected to face questions about the U.S.'s dollar policy and the Fed's independence during two days of talks with G-20 counterparts in Buenos Aires this week. Mnuchin has faced criticism from international counterparts about the U.S. talking about currencies before.

Viraj Patel, a foreign-exchange strategist at ING Bank NV, stated that Trump's comments likely put a ceiling on the recent U.S. dollar rally so far this year. There is a risk the dollar "de-couples from interest-rate differentials as investors come to terms with the White House's mercantilist U.S.-dollar policy," Patel said.

Trump's accusations that China and the EU are manipulating currencies contradict a Treasury Department semi-annual report released in April that refrained from naming any country a currency manipulator based on specific criteria.

Trump's criticism of the Fed's series of rate increases and his comments on currency manipulation mark a departure from more than two decades of White House tradition of avoiding comments on monetary policy out of respect for the independence of the U.S. central bank. The Fed has raised interest rates five times since Trump took office in January 2017, with two of those coming this year under Chairman Jerome Powell, the president's pick to replace Janet Yellen. In the CNBC interview, Trump called Powell a "very good man."

The U.S. economy has so far proven resilient to Trump's threat of taking a trade conflict to the next level. The president has already angered allies by slapping tariffs on steel and aluminum, and he is considering a widely-criticized move to levy duties on auto-imports. Trump earlier this month imposed 25 percent tariffs on $34 billion of Chinese goods, with another $16 billion to follow soon. The administration has also released a list of 10 percent tariffs on an additional $200 billion of Chinese goods, which could take effect as early as next month. China retaliated on the first wave of tariffs by slapping duties on the same dollar amount of U.S. imports, and Beijing has said it will fight against any further U.S. actions.

Title: California Senator Diane Feinstein to Propose Legislation for Semi-Automatic Firearm and Large-Capacity Magazine Ban

Article:

In a move aimed at reducing gun violence, California Senator Diane Feinstein has announced plans to introduce legislation in January that would ban the import, export, manufacturing, sale, and transfer of certain semi-automatic firearms, as well as ammunition clips holding more than 10 bullets. The bill, a revised version of the assault weapons ban that expired in 2004, is intended to remove "weapons of war" from urban areas.

During an interview with NBC's David Gregory on "Meet the Press," Feinstein explained that the proposed legislation would prohibit the sale, transfer, transportation, and possession of these weapons and large-capacity magazines, not retroactively but prospectively. She added that ammunition clips, drums, or strips containing more than 10 bullets would also be banned if the bill becomes law.

Feinstein's proposal is part of an ongoing effort to address gun violence in the United States. New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who is known for his armed security detail, has been vocal in his support of the bill and has called for gun control to become President Obama's top priority.

However, a recent Gallup poll indicates that support for the reinstatement of an assault weapons ban is at an all-time low. The poll found greater opposition to a ban on semi-automatic guns or assault rifles (53% to 43%) compared to the initial asking of this question in 1996, when the numbers were nearly reversed (57% for and 42% against).

Despite Mayor Bloomberg's advocacy, the poll also shows that support for the broader concept of making gun laws "more strict" is at its lowest by one percentage point (43%), with 44% preferring that gun laws remain as they are now, and 11% favoring less strict laws.

It is worth noting that mass shootings are not exclusive to the United States. Incidents of mass shootings have occurred in various countries, such as Norway, Finland, and Germany, demonstrating that the issue is not solely a result of insufficient gun control in the U.S.

President Obama has indicated that he will use his executive power to push through new gun control measures before the new Congress starts. The specifics of these measures have yet to be announced.

Title: New York Introduces Alcohol-Filled Traps to Combat Surge in Rat Population

Article:

In an effort to combat the city's rat infestation, New York officials have introduced a new method of rodent control. The system, which involves a machine, a trap door, and a pool filled with alcohol-based liquid, is designed to lure rats and subsequently send them to their demise.

The city, one of the most rat-infested in the United States, has seen rodents moving through rubbish and train tracks, causing disruption for many residents. The device, in essence, functions as a bucket that attracts rats and subsequently sends them to their death.

According to Anthony Giaquinto, president of Rat Trap, the rodents are rendered unconscious by the liquid and eventually "drown." The rodent carcasses are collected in a tank, capable of holding up to 80 dead rats.

During a trial in Brooklyn, a total of 107 rats were lured and killed over a month-long period. In July 2017, the city announced a $32 million (£26 million) program to cull thousands of rodents by installing rat-resistant bins and trialing a liquid bait designed to make rats infertile.

Rat sightings have reportedly increased by almost 38% to 17,353 last year, according to OpenTheBooks, a non-profit watchdog group.

Brooklyn Borough President Eric Adams described the new solution as "humane and environmentally friendly." He suggested that the device would be rolled out in some of Brooklyn's most rat-infested districts.

However, not everyone is in support of the new method. Animal rights group PETA has criticized the approach, describing it as "cruel and frightening." Elisa Allen, PETA's director, argues that the method will be ineffective in the long run, as it does not address the overall rodent population, which can rebound when animals remain fertile.

Listeners can tune in to Newsbeat at 12:45 and 17:45 weekdays, or catch up on the news later.

Title: Republican Senators Criticize Trump for Requesting China to Investigate Biden

Article:

WASHINGTON – In a rare move, three Republican senators have criticized President Donald Trump for asking China to investigate Joe and Hunter Biden. Sen. Susan Collins (R-Maine) stated on Saturday that the president made a mistake by involving China in the political investigation of a rival, calling it "completely inappropriate."

Collins joins Sens. Mitt Romney (R-Utah) and Ben Sasse (R-Neb.) in speaking out against the president's actions. The criticism comes as House Democrats have launched an impeachment inquiry against Trump over his pressure on the Ukrainian president to probe the former vice president and his son over business dealings in Ukraine.

Trump's request for China to investigate the Bidens comes as Hunter Biden had business dealings in China as well. Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) found himself in a contentious exchange with NBC's Chuck Todd over comments he made to the Wall Street Journal. Johnson had said he "winced" at the suggestion that Trump was holding back military aid from Ukraine if the country didn't probe 2016 election meddling.

Johnson explained during the Sunday interview that he didn't want aid tied to an investigation. "When I asked the president about that, he completely denied it. He adamantly denied it. He vehemently, angrily denied it. He said, 'I'd never do that,'" Johnson said, defending Trump.

Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) suggested that Trump was joking when he said Thursday morning that "China should start an investigation into the Bidens." Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio), a top Trump ally in the House of Representatives, made similar comments Sunday.

Meanwhile, Trump defended his requests to Ukraine and China to investigate Hunter Biden's business dealings on Twitter. "There is NO WAY these can be legitimate transactions? As lawyers & others have stated, as President, I have an OBLIGATION to look into possible, or probable, CORRUPTION!" Trump wrote.

The developments come as the impeachment inquiry against Trump continues, with the House Intelligence Committee set to hold its first public hearings this week. The inquiry centers around Trump's pressure on Ukraine to investigate the Bidens in exchange for military aid.

Title: Ethan Couch's Extradition Raises Questions on Equal Justice and Systemic Bias

Article:

Ethan Couch, the Texas teenager who was sentenced to probation and rehabilitation for manslaughter in a 2013 drunk-driving crash that resulted in the deaths of four people, is likely to face a harsher sentence as he is extradited from Mexico following his arrest for parole violation. The case, which has been a subject of controversy and debate, has once again brought to light questions about equal justice under the law and systemic bias in the American justice system.

At a press conference on Tuesday, Tarrant County Sheriff Dee Anderson acknowledged that the justice system "struggled to fulfill its promise" in the Couch case the first time around. The manhunt for Couch concluded on the same day that a grand jury in Cleveland declined to bring charges against two police officers who killed 12-year-old Tamir Rice in 2014.

The Couch case, along with the acquittal of George Zimmerman, the man who killed Trayvon Martin in 2012, has been a subject of intense scrutiny and debate. The verdict in the Couch case, many argue, offered a stark contrast to the treatment of African-American defendants in similar circumstances.

"What we see is how apparently neutral rules are always applied case by case, whether it's parole officers or judges or police officers, based on cultural factors," says Daniel Filler, a law professor at Drexel University in Philadelphia.

The timing of Couch's capture has raised questions about equal justice under the law, with observers noting the juxtaposition of the Couch case and the Tamir Rice grand jury decision. The case has been a subject of discomfort for many Americans, with the verdict offering a stark example of separate justice systems in the United States, one for the rich and another for the poor.

The terms of Couch's parole suggest he could now face up to 10 years in prison, which would represent half the amount requested by prosecutors after the crash. The sentence came after Ethan pleaded guilty to four counts of manslaughter.

The Couch case has brought to light a growing list of disparities in the American justice system, with only 32 percent of Americans thinking the country has made enough changes to its justice system, according to a recent Pew Research Center report. The percentage of Americans who say that more change is needed has risen from 46 to 59 percent in the same span.

Professor Filler notes that events like the capture of Couch in Mexico raise public awareness about glitches in the promise of equal protection, which in turn can act as a check on the law. "Every time you add a layer of risk that someone will detect misconduct, I think you increase the chances that misconduct [in the justice system] will be reduced," Filler says.

Title: Tea Party Groups Raise Concerns Over Immigration Bill, Threatening President Obama's Speedy Approval

Article:

As the Senate has passed its version of the immigration bill, the focus has shifted to the House, where the bill now lies. Republicans in the House have announced they will take up their own version of the legislation. President Obama, during his Africa trip, called on the House to "get this done" before the August recess. However, the House lawmakers are already facing conservative calls to slow down the process.

If the debate extends into August, when Congress takes a nearly month-long recess, the prospects for a speedy approval could become more uncertain. During the 2009 August recess, the Tea Party famously helped stall ObamaCare by storming town hall meetings and other events. Tea Party groups may be preparing to mount demonstrations during the summer break.

Earlier this week, dozens of conservative groups, including the Cincinnati Tea Party, sent a letter to House Speaker John Boehner urging him to declare the Senate package "dead on arrival." They expressed concerns that the Senate bill, by providing up to 11 million illegal immigrants a path to legal status, would make life harder for U.S. workers struggling to reach the bottom rung of the economic ladder.

The Tea Party's influence on the Republican Party's stance on immigration remains to be seen. On health care, the movement was largely united against ObamaCare. On immigration, the party is split. Fourteen Republican senators voted for the bill that passed the Senate last week. Several influential conservative economists have argued that immigration legislation would be beneficial for the economy, with newly legalized workers and an enhanced legal immigration system providing the economy with the boost it needs.

Tea Party supporters argue that these conservatives are falling for the "amnesty" ruse, claiming that the mass legalization will override any security improvements. Political strategists view immigration as an important issue that the Republican Party should not ignore. However, Tea Partiers have a powerful tool at their disposal - the ability to threaten wavering lawmakers with a primary challenge.

In South Carolina, Tea Party activists staged protests at Sen. Lindsey Graham's office, a key Republican who helped draft the bill. Ron Hughes, with the South Carolina Tea Party Coalition, stated that activists would "love" to see Graham face a primary challenge. "We wanted a full-time conservative senator, and he has not done that for us," he said.

House Republicans have stated they will proceed at their own pace, on their own bills, when it comes to immigration. Last Sunday, they dismissed a prediction by Sen. Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., that the House would simply pass the Senate bill. "The House will not simply take up and pass the Senate bill," a Boehner spokesman said. "Our legislation will reflect our principles, particularly on border security."

Title: Fox News Cuts Back on Airing President Trump's Rallies, Concerns Rise Among White House and Campaign Officials

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Fox News, a network that has been a stalwart supporter of President Donald Trump, has been cutting back on airing his campaign rallies. This shift in coverage has raised concerns among White House and campaign officials, as they see a potential loss of a prime-time megaphone to the President's base.

During the past week, Fox News aired clips and highlights from Trump's rallies but largely stuck with its regular weekday prime-time programming. On some occasions, the network opted to air other programming instead, such as the Utah Senate debate or coverage of Hurricane Michael. This shift in coverage was particularly noticeable during the midterms, with less than a month remaining before the elections.

One senior White House official expressed concern about the network's decision, stating that they would be looking into the matter and wouldn't be surprised if White House communications director Bill Shine, a former Fox News executive, was in touch with former colleagues about the trend.

Campaign officials are equally concerned about the loss of national coverage. A Senate Republican campaign staffer noted that the coverage of Trump rallies exposes their campaigns to a national audience that they don't typically reach. They reported seeing an increase in new sign-ups and small-dollar donations as a result of the coverage.

A source close to Trump described the declining coverage as a "huge loss on the state and local level for Republicans because they're certainly not going to get any of that on other cable networks." The source added that if the network stops taking them completely, it might create a problem.

Neither Fox News nor the White House responded to requests for comment.

According to Nielsen ratings, Trump's campaign speeches tend to follow a similar pattern, and this year's numbers have ranged from 2.5 to 3.5 million viewers, depending on various factors. In 2017, Trump's events at times drew more than 4 million viewers on Fox News, a number he hasn't come close to in 2018.

The sheer number of rallies is a significant factor in Fox News' decision to cut back on airing them. A person familiar with Fox News' decision-making stated that the network doesn't want to give up so much prime-time real estate. They also noted that too much repetition could lead to lower ratings, particularly during a busy news period like the first week of October, when Brett Kavanaugh's Supreme Court nomination was still up in the air.

Compounding the issue, Fox News can't take commercial breaks while Trump is speaking, costing the network some of its best advertising slots. With so many rallies and little promise of a ratings boost, there's not much incentive for the network to clear airtime.

Former Fox News host Eric Bolling, who left the network in September 2017, noted that nightly rallies aired live and in full would probably subject Fox News to even greater scrutiny. The channel has often been described as a "propaganda machine" by Trump's political opponents, many of whom claim its coverage of his administration has at times been sycophantic.

Despite the recent changes, Trump has not faulted the network for its programming decisions. At his Tuesday-night rally in Iowa, which wasn't aired, he heaped praise on his "great friends" at Fox News.

Title: American Service Members Halt Train Attack in Europe, Saving Lives

Article:

In a dramatic turn of events on August 21, two American service members thwarted a potential tragedy on a train traveling from Amsterdam to Paris. Two individuals were injured in the attack, one of whom was a U.S. Airman, identified as Spencer Stone, and a person with dual French/American citizenship.

According to fellow service member Alek Skarlatos, who was interviewed, the incident unfolded as they returned from Afghanistan. Mr. Skarlatos, a specialist in the Oregon Army National Guard, stated that he and Airman First Class Spencer Stone, along with another friend, noticed a man carrying an AK-47 and a handgun.

"I looked over at Spencer and said, 'Let's go,'" said Mr. Skarlatos. "And he jumped. I followed behind him by about three seconds. Spencer got the guy first, grabbed the guy by the neck, I grabbed the handgun."

The suspect, a 26-year-old Moroccan man, was identified by Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve of France on Saturday as a known member of the radical Islamist movement. However, the French police have not yet fully confirmed his identity. The man was arrested in Arras on Friday night and was being interrogated early Saturday at the headquarters of the antiterrorism police outside Paris.

French news reports suggest that the suspect denied having terrorist aims, claiming he intended to rob the passengers. However, the arsenal described by the minister, including a Kalashnikov assault rifle, a Luger automatic pistol, nine cartridges, and a sharp blade, paints a different picture. The blade, referred to as a "cutter" by the interior minister, was used to wound Mr. Spencer.

The violent encounter lasted barely two minutes. If not for the quick action by the two American servicemen and the suspect's malfunctioning automatic rifle, many lives could have been lost. "It could have been a real carnage," said Chris Norman, a British businessman who helped restrain the suspect after he had been subdued.

Mr. Norman, interviewed on television, recounted the harrowing incident: "The guy actually came up, he pulled out a cutter, started cutting Spencer. He cut Spencer behind the neck, he nearly cut his thumb off. We eventually got him under control."

This incident serves as a stark reminder of the ongoing global threat of terrorism and the bravery of those who put their lives on the line to protect others.

Title: Trump Proposes Compromise on Immigration Policy, Offering Permanent Status for DACA, TPS, and Central American Minors in Exchange for Border Wall Funding

Article:

In a significant shift in policy, President Donald Trump has proposed a compromise on three contentious immigration issues, marking a retreat from his previous stances on the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA), Temporary Protected Status (TPS), and the Central American Minors (CAM) program. The White House described the move as a "good faith" effort to break the long-standing gridlock on immigration reform.

The proposal, announced on Saturday, involves restoring and legalizing the DACA, TPS, and CAM programs, offering a permanent solution for those currently benefiting from these initiatives. In return, Trump is seeking $5.7 billion for his border wall project and changes to expedite the deportation of illegal immigrant families and address abuses in the asylum system.

The White House also proposed items that both sides generally agree on, such as more technology to scan for drugs in vehicles at legal border crossings and an increase in the number of immigration judges to reduce the backlog of cases.

Vice President Mike Pence stated that the DACA proposal is a significant change, as Trump had previously expressed reluctance to act on DACA until the Supreme Court had ruled on his 2017 attempt to phase out the program. The proposal would provide a three-year guarantee of protections for those currently using DACA.

Regarding TPS, the Homeland Security Department has signaled an end to protection for as many as 300,000 individuals, some of whom have been protected for two decades. The White House, in immigration negotiations last year, resisted adding TPS holders to any deal, but this resistance has now dissipated.

The Trump administration canceled the Obama administration's CAM program in 2017, which aimed to provide asylum applicants in Central American countries a chance to apply from their home countries. The program saw limited participation and was terminated, drawing criticism from Democrats who argued that the president was forcing people to undertake the dangerous journey north. Trump is now proposing to restart the CAM program, this time with full legal protections.

Democrats have expressed a preference for a full pathway to citizenship for the 1.5 million people who could qualify for DACA and the hundreds of thousands under TPS. They also criticized Trump's offer as disingenuous, stating that he had created problems by rescinding protections for DACA recipients and TPS holders only to offer temporary solutions to address them.

The Senate, led by Republicans, is scheduled to vote on Trump's plans next week. However, House Democrats are unlikely to support the proposal. Speaker Nancy Pelosi, California Democrat, rejected the president's proposal and stated that her chamber will vote instead on areas of overall agreement, such as immigration judges and scanning technology.

Title: Donald Trump Jr.'s Speech: A Case of Repurposed Content, Not Plagiarism

Article:

In the recent political discourse, allegations of plagiarism have been a recurring theme. The Melania Trump plagiarism saga made headlines last week, and Donald Trump Jr.'s speech was soon under scrutiny as well, with claims of plagiarism emerging. However, a closer look at the situation reveals a different story.

The similarities between the speech written by Frank Buckley, who also penned Donald Jr.'s speech, and an earlier essay by Buckley, are undeniable. Yet, the speechwriter's repurposing of his own work for the Trump campaign, with permission, negates any claims of plagiarism.

Critics persisted, arguing that self-plagiarism is still technically unethical in an academic setting. However, context is crucial in this case. The defense mounted by the Obama camp during the 2008 cycle, when similar allegations surfaced, provides a useful comparison. Obama's use of unoriginal passages without attribution was defended, as the passages were from a friend and Obama had received permission to use them.

In this political context, if the granting of permission serves as the standard for acceptability, then Donald Trump Jr. is in the clear. This viewpoint was echoed by one of Obama's former speechwriters, Jon Favreau, on Twitter last night.

It is essential to note that the sitting Vice President has also been accused of plagiarism in the past. As the political season unfolds, it is crucial to maintain a clear understanding of the nuances and context surrounding these allegations.

In the early hours of the morning, I offer some analysis: the political landscape is complex, and it is our responsibility as journalists to present facts accurately and fairly, without bias or prejudice.

Title: White Ex-Congresswoman Halvorson Emerges as Front-Runner in Race to Fill Jackson's Seat

Article:

In the upcoming special election on February 26, a former Democratic congresswoman, Debbie Halvorson, is the frontrunner to replace Rep. Jesse Jackson Jr. in a majority-black district that encompasses Chicago and its surrounding areas. Despite being a white Democrat and an NRA-backed candidate, Halvorson's extensive political experience and narrow but critical base of support in suburban and rural areas of the district could potentially secure her the Democratic nomination, and consequently, the seat.

Halvorson, who was defeated by Jackson in a primary last year, has been endorsed by the National Rifle Association in two of her previous congressional campaigns. This, coupled with the district's significant African-American population (54%), raises questions about her potential victory. However, the crowded Democratic field, with 16 candidates vying for the nomination, could lead to a splintering of the black vote, creating a path for Halvorson.

To clinch the Democratic nomination, Halvorson may only need to secure as little as 20% of the vote, given the district's liberal leanings. Black leaders, concerned about Halvorson's lead in the polls, are now focusing on gun control as a central issue in the contest, aiming to portray her as an NRA ally who is insensitive to Chicago's escalating gun violence.

Reverend Michael Pfleger, a Roman Catholic priest and gun control activist in Chicago, has expressed his opposition to Halvorson, stating, "The NRA gives Debbie Halvorson an 'A' rating. That tells me she should not be the representative from the 2nd District. If she gets an 'A' rating from the NRA, she gets an 'F' from me."

Though Halvorson has described herself as a conservative Democrat, she voted with her party more than 90% of the time in Congress. She supported cap-and-trade bills, President Barack Obama's health care and economic stimulus measures, and positions herself as an experienced politician ready to hit the ground running in Washington after Jackson's resignation in November.

However, it is her stance on guns that is drawing the most attention. Though her primary rivals have not directly attacked Halvorson, the campaign's focus on guns is seen as a strategy to differentiate herself from the front-runner. The outcome of the election remains uncertain, but the race is shaping up to be a significant test of the district's political dynamics and the role of gun control in the electoral process.

Title: Young Conservatives Push for Shift in GOP's Stance on Same-Sex Marriage

Article:

A group of young conservative activists is advocating for a change in the Republican Party's approach to social issues, particularly same-sex marriage, as they believe the current stance is driving away younger voters who would otherwise support the party. The young conservatives argue that the GOP's exclusionary positions force young voters to choose between two parties, and a shift within the GOP could attract them.

Ryan Rauner, a leader of NextGen GOP, organized an event last week in Arlington, Virginia, stating, "We need more compassion, empathy, and tolerance, and, unfortunately, sometimes tolerance means tolerating intolerance. What we can never tolerate is the power of government being used by one group against another because they disagree with their beliefs or their lifestyle. That's not freedom; that's not equality."

According to Gallup polling released Wednesday, a record 60 percent of Americans now support same-sex marriage, a significant increase from 2009. Among younger Americans, the issue is even more settled, with conservative activists suggesting that some lesbian, gay, bisexual, or transgender voters could leave the Democratic Party if they feel the GOP is hostile to them.

Jerri Ann Henry, the campaign manager for Young Conservatives for the Freedom to Marry, stated, "There are a lot of LGBT people out there who are brilliant small business owners, who hold to the principles of limited government, strong families, fiscal conservatism, and strong national security—things that we as Republicans love—but they don't have a place in the Republican Party right now."

While the issue of same-sex marriage is important to voters, only 26 percent said it is a make-or-break issue, and a candidate must share their opinion on the issue to win their vote. Among those, support for traditional marriage helps Republicans more than it hurts, with 37 percent of those who oppose gay marriage saying a candidate must agree with them, compared to only 27 percent who support recognition of same-sex marriage.

Republican analysts, however, doubt that the 2016 elections will see any major policy shifts for Republicans on the issue, with Mary Anna Mancuso, a former campaign director for former Florida Republican Rep. Connie Mack's Senate race and founder of Political Hype, stating, "I think that it's an issue that polls well, but I'm not sure it's an issue that's going to vote well."

In reaching young voters, harnessing a digital campaign will likely be critical, and Sen. Rand Paul and Sen. Marco Rubio, two already-announced candidates, have done well on that score. Alex Patton, owner of Ozean Consulting, suggested that on a national level, it would be in a candidate's best interest to stress issues that rank higher on the scale of importance for millennials, such as job security and growing the economy, rather than same-sex marriage.

The young conservatives at the rally do not expect same-sex marriage to be the deciding factor in the 2016 election, but they want to see more Republicans embrace it. Sara Coleman, a realtor who attended the rally, stated, "Overwhelmingly, Republicans across the country are still going to be viewed as anti-that, anti-equality, and [anti-] marriage, and it's a shame. But all you can do is develop these little core groups, let them rise up, and eventually they will become the norm."

Title: Trump Submits Written Responses to Mueller's Inquiry on Russian Election Interference

Article:

In a significant development in the ongoing investigation led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller into Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential election, President Donald Trump has submitted written answers to the questions posed by Mueller's team, according to Trump's lawyer, Rudy Giuliani.

Giuliani stated on Tuesday that the responses addressed only the questions related to the pre-election period and focused on Russia, and did not include any post-election questions or questions about potential obstruction of the investigation. Trump's answers were submitted before the president departed for his Thanksgiving holiday in Florida.

Giuliani emphasized that Trump did not plan to answer questions about whether he attempted to obstruct the investigation following his election, such as the firing of former FBI Director James Comey. The lawyer stated, "It is time to bring this inquiry to a conclusion."

Trump's responses reportedly addressed topics such as the June 2016 meeting between Donald Trump Jr., other members of Trump's campaign team, and a group of Russians, as well as potential connections to WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange and Roger Stone, a longtime Trump ally with ties to WikiLeaks who is also under investigation.

Giuliani described the questions as detailed, complex, and multipart, but declined to disclose the exact number of questions. Mueller has already brought charges against some former Trump aides, including his former campaign chairman and his former national security adviser, as well as a number of Russian individuals and entities.

U.S. prosecutors are also reportedly preparing to pursue a criminal case against Assange, having obtained a sealed indictment that was revealed in an unrelated criminal case filing last week. WikiLeaks is known for publishing documents that were previously not public, and during the campaign, the group published Democratic emails that U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded were hacked by Russia.

Trump's lawyers have been negotiating with Mueller's prosecutors since last year over whether the president would sit for an interview. Trump himself has offered mixed responses regarding his willingness to be interviewed. In a recent interview, he stated that he was unlikely to do so, explaining, "We've wasted enough time on this witch hunt, and the answer is, probably, we're finished."

It is unclear whether Mueller would subpoena Trump to testify, potentially leading to a legal and political battle. Earlier this month, Trump fired Attorney General Jeff Sessions and appointed Matthew Whitaker as his replacement on an acting basis, renewing calls for legislation to protect Mueller's work. As a private citizen, Whitaker criticized the Mueller probe.

Lisa Kern Griffin, a former federal prosecutor and a law professor at Duke University, expressed skepticism about much of what had been asked falling outside the scope of legitimate authority, as Giuliani maintained. "The special counsel has a broad mandate to determine what took place during the campaign and to determine whether there has been an effort to obstruct that investigation," Griffin said. "As other presidents have found out, they are not above the law."

Title: Presidential Debate: Strategies for Clinton and Trump in the Race for the White House

Article:

As the highly anticipated presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump approaches, the stakes are high. The first one-on-one showdown is expected to attract an audience rivaling the 80 million who watched Ronald Reagan and Jimmy Carter in 1980. One-third of voters consider the debates crucial in deciding their presidential preference, making it a significant opportunity for both candidates to make their case.

The debates will likely be characterized by political and personal attacks, with a tendency for departures from the truth, particularly from Donald Trump, who has a history of disregarding factual constraints.

Hillary Clinton, the second least popular major-party presidential nominee in modern polling history, needs to strike a balance between providing a compelling vision and avoiding being redefined by Trump. She must address the concerns of today's Democratic coalition, a diverse group with varying interests. Expect Clinton to emphasize her commitment to social justice issues and an overhaul of the U.S. immigration system, while reminding black and Hispanic voters of Trump's past comments about President Barack Obama's birthplace.

Trump, on the other hand, will need to present a more presidential image and demonstrate a command of policy to run the federal government. His unpredictability, a trait that has been both his strength and weakness, will be a challenge to manage. Already, we've seen this in his controversial Twitter invitation to Gennifer Flowers, a woman with whom Bill Clinton reportedly had an affair, to attend the debate as his guest.

Both candidates will need to navigate the debates carefully, avoiding distractions and focusing on the issues that matter to voters. Clinton will need to engage with Trump's statements in real-time, challenging him when he strays from the truth, while Trump will need to prosecute the case against Clinton without resorting to exaggerations and falsehoods.

In the end, the debates will be a critical test of the candidates' preparedness, discipline, and ability to present a compelling vision for the future of the United States. The stakes are high, and the debates could very well determine the next President of the United States.

Title: GOP Divided Over Proposal to Allow Undocumented Immigrants to Serve in U.S. Military

Article:

A contentious debate is unfolding within the Republican Party over a bill that would allow undocumented immigrants, often referred to as Dreamers, to serve in the U.S. military. The proposal, spearheaded by Rep. Ruben Gallego (D-Ariz.), has sparked a divide among lawmakers, with some advocating for the cause and others opposing it.

Cesar Vargas, a Dreamer and co-director of the Dream Action Coalition, is one of the individuals who stands to benefit from this legislation. Vargas, a high-achieving graduate of a prestigious Brooklyn high school and a law school honors student, has been unable to fulfill his dream of joining the armed forces due to his immigration status.

"I believe that because this country has given me so much, I want to be able to give back," Vargas said in an interview. "This is the reality for us. This is the country we call home... What it really comes down to is the commitment to serve the country you call home, the country you want to wear a uniform for."

Rep. Jeff Denham (R-Calif.) has been a vocal advocate for this cause, pushing a bill that would grant legal status to young undocumented immigrants who serve in the military. An amendment to a must-pass defense-policy bill, sponsored by Gallego, would encourage the Pentagon to consider allowing immigrants brought to the country as children to serve.

However, this amendment has faced opposition from conservative lawmakers, who argue that it could jeopardize the passage of the $612 billion defense-policy bill, which typically receives broad bipartisan support. Led by Alabama Rep. Mo Brooks, more than two dozen House Republicans wrote a letter to the chairman of the House Rules Committee, threatening to oppose the defense bill if the immigration provision was not removed.

"The language contained in Rep. Gallego's amendment contradicts the House's previous position and is a severe threat to the passage of the NDAA — legislation which funds the essential programs that America's military requires," the lawmakers wrote.

Brooks, who has been critical of the amendment, claimed that it could lead to Pentagon force reductions and that "Americans are being handed pink slips as they serve in Afghanistan." He also expressed concern about the amendment potentially exempting Dreamers from citizenship and lawful immigrant requirements to serve in the military.

In response, Gallego said he was surprised by the amendment's controversy and accused Republicans of using it for political gain. "This is something that is really important, not because these young men and women have a right to be in the military," Gallego said. "No one has a right to be in the military. It's the opportunity and the privilege to serve in the military that we should extend to anybody that's in this country... they should have the opportunity to serve and repay their country."

The amendment passed with the support of House Armed Services Committee Democrats and six Republicans: Reps. Mike Coffman (R-Colo.), Chris Gibson (R-N.Y.), Frank LoBiondo (R-N.J.), Tom MacArthur (R-N.J.), Martha McSally (R-Ariz.), and Ryan Zinke (R-Mont.).

Coffman, who served in both Iraq wars, expressed his support for the amendment despite opposition from many of his Republican colleagues. "I'm disappointed in my colleagues for fighting this," Coffman said. "I'm not sure why they're so opposed to this. I've been in the Congress side by side with people who are opposed to this, but yet they themselves did not want to serve. These young people ought to have the opportunity to serve."

The bill is expected to be taken up by the full House this week and then must go to the Senate, where Arizona Sen. John McCain leads the Armed Services Committee. McCain has stated that there will not be a similar provision included in his committee's version of the bill.

Title: Trump Administration Proposes Freeze on Vehicle Fuel Economy Standards, Challenging California's Emissions Authority

The Trump administration has taken a significant step towards dismantling one of former President Barack Obama's key environmental initiatives, proposing to freeze vehicle fuel economy requirements at the 2020 level and revoke California's authority to set stricter tailpipe emissions standards.

In a joint proposal by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) on Thursday, the agencies aim to cap fleet-wide fuel economy at 37 miles per gallon starting in 2020. Under the Obama administration's plan, the fleetwide fuel economy would have gradually increased to approximately 47 miles per gallon by 2025.

The proposal also seeks to revoke California's authority under the Clean Air Act, which has allowed the state to set more stringent emissions limits and an electric-vehicle sales mandate. This move is expected to face strong opposition from California's leaders, environmentalists, and automakers who have expressed concerns about the potential for a patchwork of federal and state standards.

Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao stated, "There are compelling reasons for a new rulemaking on fuel economy standards for 2021-2026. More realistic standards will promote a healthy economy by bringing newer, safer, cleaner, and more fuel-efficient vehicles to U.S. roads."

The proposal initiates a 60-day public comment period, during which automakers, California, and environmentalists are expected to voice their concerns. A final rule could be finalized by the end of 2018 or early 2019.

The Trump administration argues that the proposed freeze will have a "negligible" impact on air quality and increase the earth's temperature by 3/1000th of one degree Celsius by 2100. The administration also claims that its preferred plan for fuel economy will result in $502 billion in savings for vehicles built between 1975 and 2029.

However, the efficacy of these cost estimates is a subject of debate. Nic Lutsey, an engineer at the International Council on Clean Transportation, stated, "This would be utterly unprecedented. Nobody in any regulatory agency has ever done a cost-benefit analysis anything like this. There's no evidence that efficiency regulations have depressed sales and added fatalities as a result—in any market in the world."

The outcome of this proposal and its cost estimates will significantly impact the plan's public acceptance and its ability to withstand court challenges, as California, 16 states, and the District of Columbia have already filed a lawsuit challenging the plan's scientific underpinnings.

Title: Trump Warns Iran Over Protests, Urges Government to End Violence and Restore Internet Access

Article:

In the midst of escalating protests and public outrage in Iran, President Donald Trump issued a stern warning to the Iranian government on Sunday, urging them to refrain from harming their own citizens.

"To the leaders of Iran - DO NOT KILL YOUR PROTESTERS," Mr. Trump tweeted Sunday morning. "Thousands have already been killed or imprisoned by you, and the World is watching. More importantly, the USA is watching. Turn your internet back on and let reporters roam free! Stop the killing of your great Iranian people!"

The protests, which grew on Sunday, followed the Iranian government's admission that it accidentally shot down a Ukrainian airliner last week, resulting in the deaths of all 176 passengers and crew members. The incident occurred shortly after Iran launched ballistic missiles at U.S. military bases in Iraq, bringing Washington and Tehran to the brink of all-out war.

The demonstrations in Iran reveal a growing discontent within the country, as anger is now being directed towards the Iranian government itself. Initially, Iranian leaders denied responsibility for the downing of the plane, only to later reverse their stance as the truth became clear.

"They are lying that our enemy is America, our enemy is right here," a group of Iranian protesters shouted during a demonstration in Tehran, according to Reuters. Protesters also reportedly chanted "Death to the dictator," referring to Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

Iranian leaders have expressed remorse for the incident and pledged to prosecute those responsible.

Trump administration officials on Sunday reaffirmed their willingness to engage in negotiations with the Iranian government to permanently end Iran's nuclear weapons program. Simultaneously, U.S. officials sought to exploit the growing protests and create a rift between the government in Tehran and Iranian citizens.

"They want the same things that most people around the world want. They want prosperity," Defense Secretary Mark Esper told CBS' "Face the Nation" program on Sunday. "They want the ability to live their lives, to raise their children. And we do support those same aspirations for people wherever they are. I just think you see a very corrupt regime that the Iranian people are finally standing up and trying to hold them accountable."

Title: Trump Administration Unveils New Healthcare Transparency Rules, Facing Industry Resistance

Article:

In a move aimed at promoting competition and reducing costs, the Trump administration has unveiled new rules that require insurers and hospitals to disclose upfront the actual prices for common tests and procedures. The sweeping changes, however, face stiff resistance from the healthcare industry and could potentially be challenged in court.

The final rule will apply to hospitals, while a proposed regulation will apply to insurance plans. The disclosure requirements for hospitals will not take effect until 2021, and the timing for insurers is yet to be determined. The rules do not directly affect doctors.

The new rules are designed to illuminate the complex maze of healthcare prices, enabling informed patients to find quality services at the lowest cost. For instance, the cost of an MRI scan can vary by hundreds of dollars depending on where it is performed.

Under the new regulations, insurers will be required to create individualized estimates of what patients would owe out-of-pocket due to deductibles and copayments. Hospitals will be required to publish the prices for the 300 most common services that can be scheduled in advance, such as a knee replacement, a Cesarean-section delivery, or an MRI scan. They will also have to disclose what they would accept if the patient pays cash.

The information will be updated annually, and hospitals will also be required to publish all their charges in a format that can be read on the internet by other computer systems. This will allow web developers and consumer groups to create tools that patients and their families can use.

In addition, insurers will be required to create an online tool that policyholders can use to get a real-time personalized estimate of their out-of-pocket costs for all covered healthcare services and items, from hospitalization to doctor visits, lab tests, and medicines. They will also be required to disclose negotiated rates for their in-network providers, as well as the maximum amounts they would pay to an out-of-network doctor or hospital.

The disclosure requirements are part of an executive order President Donald Trump signed this summer. The healthcare industry, however, has expressed concern, arguing that the push for disclosure goes too far and could potentially violate their private contracts. They contend that the government would force them to publicly disclose rates they negotiate as part of private contracts, which are normally beyond the purview of authorities.

If the industry does go to court, it could be a long time before consumers see any major changes. The ultimate goal of the new rules is to empower patients by providing them with the information they need to make informed decisions about their healthcare and to drive down costs through increased competition.

Title: Grand Jury Decision in Eric Garner Case Sparks National Debate on Police-Community Relations

Article:

Following the announcement of a grand jury decision on Wednesday not to indict a New York police officer in the death of Eric Garner, politicians and community leaders have weighed in on the issue, highlighting the broader concerns of minority communities regarding fair treatment by law enforcement.

U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder stated that the cases of Eric Garner and Michael Brown will be investigated by the Department of Justice. The incident, which occurred in July, has sparked nationwide discussions on police-community relations and civil rights.

Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand expressed her condolences to the Garner family and stated, "The death of Eric Garner is a tragedy that demands accountability. Nobody unarmed should die on a New York City street corner for suspected low-level offenses."

New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo called the circumstances surrounding Garner's death "tragic" and emphasized the importance of respecting the legal process and rule of law. He also acknowledged the need for further investigations and potential improvements to the system.

Rep. Hakeem Jeffries, D-Brooklyn/Queens, questioned the grand jury's decision, stating, "I don't see how you put the video together, you put the coroner's report together, and you don't get one of those two charges, (second-degree manslaughter or criminally negligent homicide) at least as a charge to go to a trial and have a jury ultimately decide guilty or innocence."

The Rev. Al Sharpton has called for a national march in Washington, D.C. on December 13 to halt police brutality and demand the prosecution of NYPD officer Daniel Pantaleo, the officer involved in the Garner case. Sharpton's National Action Network will meet with the National Urban League, the National Coalition on Black Civic Participation, and the Black Women's Roundtable on Thursday in New York City to discuss further action.

Garner's mother, Gwen Carr, expressed her doubts in the justice system, stating, "How could we put our trust in the justice system when they fail us like this? They didn't only fail me, they failed many of us. And if we don't take care of this, they may fail you in the future."

Staten Island Borough President James Oddo called for calm and emphasized the importance of peaceful protest and advocacy for change. Police commissioner Bill Bratton assigned extra police for Staten Island in anticipation of potential protests following the grand jury decision.

Patrick Lynch, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, issued a statement expressing remorse for Garner's death but not accepting responsibility for the actions that led to it.

The family of Eric Garner continues to mourn his loss, with his mother, Gwen Carr, expressing her heartache and calling for change in the justice system. The Garner case serves as a reminder of the critical issues of police-community relations and civil rights that our nation continues to face.

Title: Las Vegas Shooting: Witness Accounts and Latest Updates as Death Toll Rises to 50

Article:

In the aftermath of the tragic shooting incident at the Route 91 Harvest Festival in Las Vegas, survivors and witnesses continue to share their harrowing experiences as the death toll rises to 50. The attack, which also left 406 injured, took place on Sunday night, with the gunman opening fire from the 32nd floor of the Mandalay Bay hotel.

As flashing red and blue lights from countless ambulances and police cars illuminated the Strip, survivors stood teary-eyed and shocked at the Rebel gas station behind the MGM Grand. Many made calls to their families, wondering where they would go, with many hotels under lockdown due to the ongoing police operation.

"The news said it all," said Jackie Hoffing, her eyes glassy, still in a clear state of trauma. "We were there enjoying our time, and it was very obvious it was gunfire coming down into the crowd."

The two gold towers of the Mandalay Bay overlook the site where the concert was being staged. Jason Aldean was beginning his set when the shooter opened fire.

"It sounded like something was wrong with the speakers," said William Walker of Ontario, California. "Jason Aldean kept playing through three rounds of it. Then once he stopped everyone took it more seriously..."

People piled up behind police cars, and ex-military guys were saying, "Give me a gun, I'm going to get these fuckers." William Walker

"I started kicking down fences to take shelter behind the buildings," said Desiree Price, from San Diego. "It sounded like machine-gun fire. Bullets hit concertgoers and sparked off the pavement. Hundreds ran. Others ducked or fell on top of one another."

Two girls hid behind a car with us, right outside the concert, said Desiree Price, from San Diego. "We huddled together. That's why I have their blood on me. One girl was shot in her leg, the other had it in her shoulder. It didn't stop so we all ran – we kept going."

Emily Anderson, also from San Diego, said, "I saw a lady get hit in the leg and her boyfriend dragging her out and everyone was running. It was chaos."

Many said the gunshots sounded as though they were coming from different directions – and getting closer each time the shooter reloaded.

"We were under a big spotlight and someone said, 'Turn off the light,'" William Walker recalled. "They shut it off and you could see and hear bullets hitting the ground. People piled up behind cop cars, and ex-military guys were saying, 'Give me a gun, I'm going to get these fuckers.'"

Taking cover under a table, Kevin Kropf, from Orange County, California, waited until tactical police units came in.

"I didn't want to get up because I didn't want to get mistaken for a bad guy and get shot," he said. "I saw a couple people on the street covered up with sheets, and them loading one girl into the back of a truck. She was definitely dead...she looked to be in her mid-20s and whoever she was with, her husband, was in the back of the truck too. He was a mess."

The streets between the concert grounds and the nearest medical center were a non-stop convoy of ambulances and police.

"I want to find my friends," said Desiree Price. "I want to go to my hotel room. I want to go home."

She reunited at the Rebel gas station with a friend who had taken shelter with dozens of others in a stranger's condo.

"I'm still shaking," Krista Metz said. "Every time I start thinking about it I start shaking again."

Reports of gunmen and shootings at other hotels circulated on Reddit and Twitter, adding to the chaos and panic. Survivors kept emerging from apartment buildings, motels, parking garages, and other emergency shelters. They had nowhere to go, since the Strip remained on lockdown.

"We've been in the Motel 6," said Jackie Hoffing, "We had stopped in the lobby and thought we were safe, but then they came in and said, 'The suspect is here. Everybody has to run.' It was another stampede. We knocked on a random door and went in there – about 15 of us – and hid in the bathroom for two and a half hours."

"I was texting my children," she added. "I thought we were going to die. I told them, 'I love you.'"

Title: Andrew Yang Proposes Licensing Reform to Boost Mobility and Economic Dynamism

Article:

In a bid to revitalize America's economic dynamism, Democratic presidential candidate Andrew Yang has unveiled a plan to streamline occupational licensing requirements, aiming to encourage mobility and job mobility across the nation. The proposal, titled "Get America Moving Again," seeks to address the issue of onerous regulations that have been hindering mobility in many parts of the country.

According to data from the Tax Foundation, mobility in the United States has been declining since 1948, with only 11.2% of Americans moving in 2015-2016, a significant drop from the 22.2% in 1948. Yang's plan aims to reverse this trend by facilitating the movement of lower-income individuals to areas with better job prospects.

A key aspect of Yang's proposal is the increased recognition of occupational licenses across states. Currently, only three states—Arizona, Montana, and Pennsylvania—have adopted this practice. By recognizing out-of-state licenses, workers would no longer be trapped in the state where they began their careers due to the costly and burdensome licensing process when they relocate to a new state to pursue the same profession.

The proposal also addresses the financial aspect of relocation by offering a tax credit, capped at $1,000, for moving expenses. This tax credit aims to offset the costs associated with moving, a benefit that was previously available through a deduction in the tax code but was eliminated by the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017.

Garrett Watson, Special Projects Manager at the Tax Foundation, suggests that Yang's proposed tax credit for moving expenses could stimulate economic growth. However, Watson emphasizes that the tax credit would need to be part of a broader reform package, including reducing licensing burdens and easing zoning laws to drive down the cost of housing, to make a significant impact.

A 2017 paper by labor economists Janna Johnson and Morris Kleiner found that workers in licensed professions are 36% less likely to move across state lines than workers in non-licensed professions. The study also revealed that nationwide, workers in licensed professions lose out on between $178 million and $711 million they could have earned by moving to a different state.

In essence, Yang's proposal aims to make it easier for Americans to move and find better job opportunities, thereby boosting economic dynamism and mobility across the country. The plan is one of several initiatives Yang has proposed as part of his presidential campaign, which centers on a Universal Basic Income.

Title: Trump's Town Hall Performance in Wisconsin: A Sales Pitch, Not a Policy Discussion

Article:

In a town hall setting moderated by Greta Van Susteren on Sunday evening, Donald Trump presented an hour-long performance in Madison, Wisconsin, that left the audience with a sense of a sales pitch rather than a substantive policy discussion. The event, coming after a challenging week for Trump, did not see any significant clarification or restatement of his controversial statements.

Trump reiterated his plans to repeal Obamacare, replace it with a system offering multiple options, and ensure coverage for all while keeping costs low. He also emphasized his intention to lower taxes for the majority of Americans, with the exception of wealthy hedge fund managers who, in his view, are not paying their fair share.

The candidate reaffirmed his stance on renegotiating trade deals, starting with the Iran nuclear agreement, and bringing jobs back from countries like China and Mexico. However, he provided few details on how these ambitious plans would be executed.

Trump also addressed the opioid crisis in New Hampshire, offering specific solutions, such as cutting off the drug supply and making a call to Mexico's president to discuss the issue.

Despite the lack of specifics, Trump's performance was reminiscent of his characteristic salesmanship, drawing comparisons to the boxing strategy of Muhammad Ali, known for his "Rope a Dope" technique. Trump's approach, like Ali's, involves talking extensively while avoiding specifics, a strategy that has proven effective in capturing public attention.

However, while Trump was "Rope a Doping" in Madison, Ted Cruz's campaign was gaining momentum in North Dakota, securing at least 18 of the 25 delegates, either supporting Cruz or opposing Trump. The long-running Republican nomination battle is far from over, and Trump continues to press on.

Cruz's grassroots campaign and Trump's marketing-focused approach highlight the stark differences between the two candidates, with Trump positioning himself as the product and the number one salesman. The race for the Republican nomination remains a heated contest, with both candidates demonstrating their unique strategies to win over voters.

Title: Trump's Unorthodox Foreign Policy Approach: Achievements and Challenges

Article:

In the 16 months of his presidency, Donald Trump has made a significant impact on foreign affairs, surprising critics and detractors with his unorthodox approach. While his domestic achievements have been limited to the passage of a large tax cut and the confirmation of Neil Gorsuch as a Supreme Court justice, his foreign policy actions are far more extensive.

Trump has taken steps to denuclearize the Korean Peninsula, planned a summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, withdrawn from the Paris climate agreement and the Trans-Pacific Partnership, made gains against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS), and increased troop levels in Afghanistan.

Republican strategist Alex Conant, who worked for Trump rival Sen. Marco Rubio during the 2016 primaries, acknowledged that Trump's foreign policy has exceeded the expectations of his critics. However, the president's approach is seen as unpredictable, with few experts certain of Trump's exact position on foreign policy issues.

Joel Rubin, a former deputy assistant secretary of State during the Obama administration, stated that Trump "really lacks a clear, coherent approach around which adversaries, allies, and the agencies can orient themselves." The recent visit of French President Emmanuel Macron to Washington, hoping to save the Iran nuclear deal, is an example of this lack of a clear approach.

Trump's unorthodox approach is evident in his handling of North Korea. When Trump threatened to "totally destroy" North Korea during a speech at the United Nations, many experts predicted a downward spiral in relations and feared war. Instead, Trump agreed to a meeting with Kim in response to an offer conveyed through South Korea, a move that is being seen as a considerable boost for Trump's approach.

James Jay Carafano of the Heritage Foundation argued that the idea of Trump as a chaotic figure is exaggerated. "This is not a scattershot president. This is not a presidency lurching from fire to fire," he said. "This is a president going out very deliberately and pursuing policy."

Trump's foreign policy achievements may not translate into electoral benefits, as voters primarily care about issues that impact them directly. However, incorporating foreign policy achievements into a broader narrative could potentially yield political gains. As the U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem opened, Jared Kushner stated, "When President Trump makes a promise, he keeps it."

The world looks to the United States for predictability and stability, and many people have concerns about the instability that Trump's unorthodox approach may bring. The Memo is a reported column by Niall Stanage, primarily focused on Donald Trump's presidency.

Title: "Al Franken's Impact on the Polarization of American Politics: A Hypothetical Scenario"

Article:

In the realm of political speculation, a hypothetical scenario emerges that places Sen. Al Franken at the center of the polarization, gridlock, and negative sentiments that have characterized Washington for the past decade. This is not a personal indictment of Franken, but rather an exploration of the potential consequences of a different political landscape had Franken lost the Minnesota Senate race in 2008 by several hundred votes instead of winning by a razor-thin margin that prompted months of recounts.

In this alternate reality, Senate Democrats would have only 59 votes in December 2009, and would have needed to corral at least one Republican vote to pass ObamaCare. President Obama, however, faced little real resistance in Congress to start his presidency, and this lack of need to work with the opposition set the stage for the polarization to come.

Without a Democratic supermajority, Obama would have been forced to negotiate with Republicans (or, at least, former Sen. Olympia Snowe of Maine) and settle for incremental health care reforms that his then-Chief of Staff Rahm Emanuel recommended. The GOP would still have been opposed to any Democratic health care reforms, but the antipathy would have been muted because a few Republicans would have supported the legislation. Instead of provoking a pitched partisan showdown that culminated with then-House Minority Leader John Boehner exclaiming that the Congress had "shattered the bonds of trust" with the American people, Obama could have tempered the wrath of the Republican opposition.

"In a democracy, you can only ignore the will of the people for so long and get away with it," Boehner presciently argued before the House's fateful ObamaCare vote. "If we defy the will of our fellow citizens and pass this bill, we are going to be held to account by those who have placed us in their trust."

Imagine, for a moment, the state of the 2010 midterms without ObamaCare in the equation. Republicans would have run against the stagnant economy with some success. But without the galvanizing opposition to Obama's health care law—Republicans netted a whopping 63 House seats that year—Democrats would likely have narrowly kept control of Congress, and continued to press forward with Obama's agenda. Tea-party-aligned Republicans would have been elected, but absent the wave, not enough to form the concerted opposition that emerged. Veteran Blue Dog Democrats like Reps.
