Ike Skelton, Gene Taylor, and Chet Edwards (among others) would likely have been reelected, and become bridge-builders between parties.

The notion of moderate pragmatism prevailing might sound like fantasy to readers who have watched the political cage-fighting over the last seven years. But even in our polarized times, politics is still primarily about self-interest.

Obama acted against his political self-interest in pushing ObamaCare through Congress, but given the divided government that ensued, it then made some sense for him to play to his base in his reelection campaign and stick to his liberal principles after winning. At the same time, Republicans would have been committing political malpractice if they ignored the tea-party tsunami that enveloped the country in 2010. With intensifying energy on the Right, the biggest political threat to members emerged from within their own party, and they adapted accordingly.

The question then becomes: Who started the fire? Obama certainly deserves some of the blame, and he even admitted recently that one of his biggest regrets as president was the polarization that he's leaving behind. The problem is that he hasn't connected his early actions with what transpired.

The notion that Obama was fated to face an intransigent Republican opposition has always been off-base. He won a historically-high 53 percent of the vote in 2008, bringing Democratic congressional seats that they hadn't won in decades, including ones in rural Alabama and Louisiana. He even won 40 percent of non-college-educated whites—a remarkable tally given how despised he is among this constituency today. Democrats had all the political tools they needed to press Obama's widespread personal popularity into an agenda that could pick off enough moderate Republicans to succeed. (Just consider an alternate reality in which legislation addressing income inequality, job-skills training, and the costs and quality of college education were the centerpieces of an Obama agenda after the recession.)

But it's also understandable that Obama, eager to be seen as a historically-consequential president, would want to spend all of his political capital early on the Democratic dream of expanding public access to health care—political backlash be damned.

That's where Al Franken comes in. If it weren't for 312 voters in Minnesota, Obama's ambitions would at least have been curtailed by legislative realities, and the trajectory of his presidency would have looked much different. Franken, the first insult comic to get elected to the Senate, circuitously paved the way for the rise of a much different type of entertainer—Donald J. Trump.

Title: First Amendment Rights and the Sterling Scandal: A Discussion on Privacy and the Marketplace of Ideas

Article:

In the wake of the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling's controversial remarks about black people, questions have arisen regarding the violation of his First Amendment rights. However, it is crucial to understand that while Sterling's rights were indeed infringed upon, his First Amendment rights remain intact.

The First Amendment protects individuals from governmental punishment due to their speech. The National Basketball Association (NBA), as a private club, has the authority to discipline Sterling as it sees fit. The criticism leveled against Sterling is not a violation of his First Amendment rights, but rather a demonstration of the First Amendment in action.

The marketplace of ideas is a fundamental concept of the First Amendment. Individuals express their ideas, and the public decides which ideas are valid and worthy of acceptance. In the case of Sterling, his ideas have failed in the marketplace of ideas, and it is generally agreed that his views are unpopular and unacceptable.

However, the question of legality arises in the context of the recording of Sterling's conversation with V. Stiviano. In California, it is illegal to record a conversation without the knowledge or consent of both parties. The recording featuring Sterling and Stiviano may have been obtained illegally, and the leaking of the recording was morally wrong.

The issue of privacy is a significant concern in this case. In today's digital age, our private conversations and actions can be recorded and disseminated without our knowledge or consent. This raises questions about the boundaries of our personal privacy and the potential for our private conversations to be used against us in the public sphere.

The Sterling scandal serves as a reminder that we live in a world where privacy is increasingly scarce. Our intimate conversations, photos, and personal information can be shared without our consent, and the consequences can be devastating. The Sterling story is not just about the exposure of a bigot, but also about the erosion of privacy and trust in our society.

In conclusion, while Sterling's views are widely condemned, the means by which they were exposed raises questions about the legality and morality of recording and disseminating private conversations without consent. The Sterling scandal serves as a cautionary tale about the importance of privacy in our increasingly interconnected world. As we move forward, it is essential to consider the implications of our actions and the potential consequences of our actions in the digital age.

Title: New Congress Takes Office, Republicans Prioritize Healthcare Reform, Cabinet Confirmations, and Regulatory Rollbacks

Article:

The 115th Congress officially took office on Tuesday, with Speaker of the House Paul Ryan presiding over the swearing-in ceremony. The Republican Party, now in full control of both chambers and the White House for the first time in almost a decade, expressed eagerness to tackle a long list of legislative priorities.

One of the top items on the agenda is the repeal and replacement of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. Cory Gardner, a Republican lawmaker from Colorado, vowed to "repair the damage" of Obamacare, citing its broken promises, soaring premiums, failing insurance markets, and dwindling choices.

In addition to healthcare reform, House lawmakers are planning bills to roll back thousands of federal regulations imposed by the Obama administration, covering areas such as the environment, drilling, and businesses.

The confirmation of President-elect Donald Trump's cabinet nominees is another pressing matter. Democrats have vowed to make the confirmation process challenging, with reports suggesting they plan to target at least eight of Trump's 15 cabinet picks.

Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich expressed concern that the incoming administration might "lose their nerve" in taking on the Democrats, particularly during the confirmation process and potential Supreme Court nominations.

Congressional Republicans have already backed down from a controversial plan to revise congressional oversight, following criticism from both sides over the decision to rein in the independent Congressional Ethics Office and place it under the oversight of the House Ethics Committee.

President-elect Trump has also faced a series of foreign policy challenges, including dealing with Russia in light of the election hacking controversy, defeating ISIS, and managing the ongoing chaos in Syria. Most recently, North Korea announced on New Year's Day that it was close to test launching an intercontinental ballistic missile capable of reaching the U.S. Trump responded on Monday, tweeting, "It won't happen" on his watch.

The new Congress and Trump administration will face a multitude of domestic and foreign policy challenges in the coming years, with the healthcare reform, cabinet confirmations, regulatory rollbacks, and foreign policy issues being just a few of the key issues they will need to address.

Title: Justice Department Declares Case Against Andrew McCabe Closed, Allegations of Lying to Investigators Dropped

Article:

In a significant turn of events, the Justice Department announced on Friday that former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe will not face charges following an investigation into allegations that he lied to investigators about a leak to the media. The decision, which is likely to stir controversy, comes after the department's inspector general found that McCabe "lacked candor" regarding an aide's conversation with the Wall Street Journal about the FBI's investigation into the Clinton Foundation.

In a letter to McCabe's attorneys, the department stated, "based on the totality of the circumstances and all of the information known to the government at this time, we consider the matter closed."

The decision is expected to be met with disapproval from President Trump, who has been vocal in his criticism of McCabe. Trump has repeatedly attacked McCabe online and in public remarks, with McCabe being a frequent target of Republican leaders who allege political bias within the FBI.

McCabe's wife ran for the state legislature in Virginia as a Democrat, sparking early accusations that he might be favoring Hillary Clinton. Later, McCabe was dismissed after investigators concluded he was not truthful about an incident involving the disclosure of information to a reporter. He was relieved of duty in March, just hours before he was due to retire.

McCabe has consistently maintained his innocence and has described himself as a victim of political retribution. In response to the Justice Department's decision, McCabe's lawyers stated, "At long last, justice has been done in this matter." They added, "We said at the outset of the criminal investigation, almost two years ago, that if the facts and the law determined the result, no charges would be brought. We are pleased that Andrew McCabe and his family can go on with their lives without this cloud hanging over them."

The allegations against McCabe stemmed from a report by the Justice Department's Office of Inspector General, which found that McCabe "lacked candor" when he claimed he did not know who authorized an aide to discuss the FBI's investigation into the Clinton Foundation with the media.

The Justice Department's decision not to prosecute McCabe comes a day after Attorney General William Barr publicly criticized Trump's tweets, stating that they "make it impossible for me to do my job."

McCabe has filed a lawsuit against the Justice Department, alleging that his March 2018 dismissal by then-Attorney General Jeff Sessions was a politically motivated act of retribution by Trump and "unlawful."

Title: Virginia Democrats Face Political Quandary as Scandals Engulf State Leadership, Focus Shifts to Black Women

Article:

In the midst of a tumultuous political landscape, Virginia's Democratic party is grappling with a series of scandals that have tarnished the state's executive branch. The allegations against three high-profile Democrats, including Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax, have created a challenging situation, particularly as the party's 2020 presidential primary heats up and boasts a record number of black and female candidates.

State Senator J. Chapman Petersen, a white Democrat, acknowledged the political dilemma, stating, "To show a firm grasp of the obvious, the optics would be difficult and the substance would be difficult." The situation becomes more complex given the political influence of women and African-Americans, who played a significant role in the Democrats' victories in the 2017 top Virginia races and the 40-seat win in the House midterm elections in November.

With the Republicans barely holding onto their legislative majority in the Virginia Capitol, Democrats were counting on these two voter blocs to secure victories in the upcoming election of all 140 delegates and state senators. Amidst this, some Democrats in Virginia are advocating for a shift in focus towards their most loyal constituency: black women.

Following the emergence of sexual assault allegations against Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax by Vanessa Tyson, a California political scientist, on Friday, several senior Virginia Democrats have suggested that if Governor Ralph Northam refuses to resign, he should appoint State Senator Jennifer McClellan to replace Fairfax if he quits or is impeached. However, it is uncertain whether Northam could appoint any successor to Fairfax due to conflicting provisions and interpretations of the Virginia Constitution and state law.

Senator McClellan, a longtime Richmond legislator with statewide ambitions and a close relationship with Senator Tim Kaine, is a black woman who is being considered as a potential replacement. When asked about McClellan, C. Richard Cranwell, a former state Democratic chairman and legislator, stated, "Jennifer would make an exceptionally good lieutenant governor."

As the political landscape in Virginia continues to evolve, the focus on black women as a key constituency and potential political leader underscores the growing political power of these demographics within the Democratic party. The developments in Virginia serve as a reminder of the importance of representation and the role it plays in shaping the political discourse and decision-making processes.

Title: House of Representatives Passes Bill to Protect State Medical Marijuana Laws

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, the Republican-led House of Representatives voted early Friday to prevent the federal government from interfering with medical marijuana laws passed by 32 states and the District of Columbia. The bill, which received 218 yes votes, including 49 from actual Republicans, aims to protect state-level medical marijuana programs from federal intervention.

California Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, a former aide to President Ronald Reagan, was among the leading advocates for the bill. Rohrabacher, who acknowledged that times have changed, argued that strict federal policies regarding medical marijuana were causing more harm than good.

"Some people are suffering, and if a doctor feels that he needs to prescribe something to alleviate that suffering, it is immoral for this government to get in the way," Rohrabacher said. "The state governments have recognized that a doctor has a right to treat his patient any way he sees fit, and so did our Founding Fathers."

However, not all Republicans supported the bill. Virginia's Frank Wolf, who chairs the House committee that wrote the $50 billion appropriations bill on which the marijuana language was tacked, questioned the legitimacy of medical marijuana. Wolf pointed out that several medical organizations, including the American Medical Association, American Cancer Society, and the American Glaucoma Society, among others, opposed medicinal marijuana.

Two doctors who are also members of Congress, Louisiana Republican Rep. John Fleming and Maryland GOP Rep. Andy Harris, expressed concerns about the potential negative effects of marijuana on brain development and the imprecise nature of marijuana prescriptions.

In response, Georgia Republican Rep. Paul Broun presented a counterargument, stating that the components in marijuana are useful for some conditions and are less dangerous than some narcotics prescribed by doctors.

The vote result surprised even those who had been lobbying for the bill for over a decade. Mason Tvert, a spokesman for the Marijuana Policy Project, noted that the proposal had received the most votes previously in the House (165 in 2007).

"We expected that we'd get close to passing it, and then pass it next year," Tvert said. "But clearly things are moving forward very quickly at the federal level just as they are at the state level. People are fed up with the current state of marijuana laws."

Although the bill has only cleared the House, Rohrabacher and his Democratic co-sponsors admitted that they did not have Senate supporters lined up yet to move the language in that chamber. Democratic Rep. Jared Polis, whose state of Colorado allows non-medicinal marijuana, emphasized that the will of the House is important on this issue.

"Congress is far from leading the country in this regard. Rather, we're catching up with where the country already is," Polis said.

Title: Analysis: Democratic Presidential Candidates, Trump's Approval Ratings, and the 2020 Election Landscape

Article:

The 2020 presidential election landscape is taking shape, with the Democratic candidates receiving encouragement from recent polling, while maintaining criticism towards President Joe Biden and offering thoughts on the speeches of contender Pete Buttigieg.

The polling data shows a challenging picture for President Donald Trump, with his approval rating significantly lower than in the key states he won in 2016, such as Wisconsin, Michigan, and Iowa. However, it is important to note that a lot can change between now and the November 2021 election, and it is true that state-level polls underestimated Trump's support in 2016.

The head-to-head polling does not provide a clear picture of events 18 months in the future, but it does suggest that there is no counterintuitive process whereby Trump secures the votes of people who say he is doing a bad job as president. The public is expressing a desire to vote for any Democrat, and the strongest pattern so far indicates that better-known Democrats perform better than more obscure ones.

Rather than being complacent or paralyzed by fear, Democrats should take a modest amount of reassurance from Trump's bad polls and focus on other issues. The real question is whether voters will continue to support Biden as it becomes clearer that his promise of bipartisanship may mean that the rich will continue to come first.

The issue of bipartisanship has been a topic of discussion, with some arguing that Biden is wrong to imply that Republicans in Congress will negotiate in good faith if Trump is no longer in office. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) has stated that he will continue to be the 'grim reaper' and block any legislation from a Democratic president, while promising to further pack the Supreme Court if a vacancy arises during an election year.

Biden and other Democratic candidates should run against McConnell and the Trump Republicans in Washington, according to some. The Democratic Party's donor class is also a factor in the election, with many putting their faith in Biden due to his promise of bipartisanship.

Regarding Buttigieg's speech, some argue that he is an heir to Obama's cautious and intellectual worldview, but with a focus on values rather than realism. Buttigieg is a liberal internationalist who is looking beyond interventions to challenges posed by great powers, bridging the gap between the Obama and Clinton wings of his party. However, others contend that Buttigieg still has work to do to articulate his vision and policies effectively.

In summary, the 2020 election landscape is taking shape, with the Democratic candidates receiving encouragement from recent polling, while maintaining criticism towards President Trump and offering thoughts on Buttigieg's speech. The issue of bipartisanship and the role of the Democratic donor class is a topic of discussion, with some arguing that Biden's promise of bipartisanship may mean that the rich will continue to come first. Buttigieg's focus on values and liberal internationalism is also a point of contention, with some arguing that he still has work to do to articulate his vision and policies effectively.

Title: "Caution Advised: Polling Challenges from 2016 Election Persist in 2020, Experts Warn"

Article:

In the political landscape, polls serve as a beacon for reporters, providing insights into the shifting tides of public sentiment. However, this year, these numbers have garnered less attention from me, given the unpredictable nature of the 2020 election due to the coronavirus, economic downturn, and racial unrest. Yet, several recent headlines have piqued my interest.

One such headline, published in Politico, declared, "We're thinking landslide." This article, based on interviews with over 50 Republican officials from across the country, looks beyond the current political climate and sees an improving economy, a waning pandemic, and a diminishing impact of unreliable polls on President Donald Trump's re-election prospects.

A North Carolina Republican official was quoted as saying, "We're calling him 'Teflon Trump.' Nothing's going to stick, because if anything, it's getting more exciting than it was in 2016."

The Washington Examiner corroborated this sentiment with comments from veteran GOP pollster Neil Newhouse. He stated, "I'm still convinced there is a shy Trump supporter, a hidden Trump vote. I'm convinced that number is at least 2 to 3 points."

The "shy Trump supporter" phenomenon may have contributed to the inaccurate polling of the 2016 election. National polls had shown Hillary Clinton winning the popular vote by 3 percentage points; she won by 2 points. However, election-eve polls in Wisconsin, Pennsylvania, and Michigan failed to predict Trump's victories in those states, ultimately deciding the election in his favor in the Electoral College.

The Trump campaign has seized upon the "shy voter" theme, leading to another headline in Politico: "Trump has a point about the polls." The point is that pollsters, particularly in battleground states, are still grappling with the same issues they faced in 2016 - not just shy voters, but also potentially inadequate consideration of non-college-educated white voters.

Courtney Kennedy, director of research at the Pew Research Center and the lead author of a report on 2016 polling flaws, told Politico, "Some of the fundamental, structural challenges that came to a head in 2016 are still in place in 2020."

This warning is significant for both campaigns and voters. If pollsters do not rectify these issues, both parties must proceed as if the polling might be off. In other words, when it comes to polls, caveat emptor - buyer beware.

Title: Romney Shifts Strategy, Emphasizing Policy Prescriptions and Broader Issues in Campaign

Article:

In a significant move, Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, is altering his campaign strategy, with a new focus on "status quo versus change" as the central theme. This shift, as announced by chief strategist Stuart Stevens, will see Romney's campaign move away from the narrow economic focus that has been the cornerstone of his strategy since his 2008 primary campaign.

The change comes as polls show President Barack Obama gaining ground in crucial swing states, particularly Ohio. Romney's advisers concluded that a course correction was necessary to counter this trend. Stevens emphasized that the economy will remain the dominant focus, but the campaign will now address a broader range of issues, including foreign policy, the threat from China, debt, and the tone in Washington.

On Monday, Romney unveiled a new ad, "The Romney Plan," which counters Obama's emphasis on economic growth for the middle class and outlines Romney's policy proposals. In the ad, Romney states, "My plan is to help the middle class. Trade has to work for America. That means cracking down on cheaters like China. It means opening up new markets."

A second ad, "Failing American Families," released on the same day, is more critical, with a male narrator stating, "Barack Obama: More spending. More debt. Failing American families."

The new ads mark a departure from Romney's previous series of ads, "A Better Future," which focused on state-specific statistics and Romney's plans to improve each state's economy. Some Romney officials had advocated for a more negative approach to move the numbers as needed.

Romney is also expected to emphasize policy solutions when he speaks to the U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce in Los Angeles on Monday. He plans to address the Hispanic vote, a demographic that has been largely supportive of Obama, by proposing improvements to "legal immigration."

Romney's prepared remarks for the speech include, "I will work with Republicans and Democrats to permanently fix our immigration system. I believe we can all agree that what we need are fair and enforceable immigration laws that will stem the flow of illegal immigration, while strengthening legal immigration."

Stevens suggested that Romney's campaign is performing better than many pundits recognize, and that the Middle East unrest and economic uncertainty will help Romney regain momentum and alleviate concerns among GOP insiders.

Title: Charles Kupperman Declines to Testify in Trump Impeachment Inquiry, Seeks Court Ruling on Compliance with House Subpoena

Article:

In the ongoing impeachment inquiry of President Donald Trump, Charles Kupperman, former White House official and top aide to John Bolton, failed to appear for a scheduled meeting with House investigators on Monday. Kupperman, who was the deputy national security adviser, filed a lawsuit on Friday seeking a court ruling on whether he should comply with the House subpoena to testify or comply with a White House order to stay away.

The House Intelligence Committee, led by Rep. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.), had been expected to press Kupperman to corroborate key elements of a top U.S. diplomat's account that Trump built a shadow foreign policy team around his personal attorney, Rudy Giuliani, to pressure the Ukrainian president to investigate a political rival, and that Trump held up U.S. military aid for Ukraine as leverage.

In a statement, Schiff rejected Kupperman's move as a ploy to delay his appearance and stated that the House Democrats do not intend to wait for the court ruling and are prepared to move ahead with their impeachment inquiry. "The lawsuit that Dr. Kupperman filed in district court has no basis in law... we expect the court will make short shrift of that argument," Schiff told reporters.

Other members of Congress, including Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) and Rep. Mark Meadows (R-N.C.), left open the possibility that Kupperman could appear at some point, but offered no timeline for when the court process might be resolved.

Kupperman's lawyer, Charles Cooper, stated in a statement on Friday that his client "takes no position on whether the command of the Legislative Branch or the command of the Executive Branch should prevail; he seeks only to carry out whichever constitutional obligation the Judicial Branch determines to be lawful and binding on him."

House investigators called the lawsuit a stall tactic and accused Kupperman of working with the White House to stonewall Congress. They sent him a letter on Saturday stating that their subpoena "remains in full force" and that Kupperman is legally obligated to appear on Monday.

Kupperman's lawyer said the White House had no advance notice of the lawsuit and stated that it was not discussed or coordinated with anyone from the White House. "We believe the arguments of both Branches are substantial and offered in good faith," Cooper wrote, stating that it would not be appropriate for Kupperman to resolve what he called a "momentous Constitutional dispute."

Nicholas Rostow, who served as legal adviser to the National Security Council in George W. Bush's White House, stated that he expected the congressional subpoena to take precedence over the White House claim, but cautioned that the court may take a different view. "The court may say this is an odd duck because the House has not voted on whether this is an official impeachment inquiry, so executive privilege might still apply," Rostow said.

People who know Kupperman describe him as a conservative, honest, and straightforward individual. Dennis Ross, a former ambassador and top adviser to Republicans and Democrats on Middle East policy, compared Kupperman to Sgt. Joe Friday from the television series Dragnet, a character known for sticking to the facts. "Charlie has always been very conservative but also honest and a straight shooter," Ross said. "He has strong views like Bolton about Russia and Putin. Neither he nor Bolton would have turned a blind eye to what they saw as fundamentally inappropriate and wrong behavior."

Kupperman has expressed some controversial hard-line views in his past work, including with Frank Gaffney, the founder of the Center for Security Policy, who has advocated curtailing immigration and has repeatedly denounced Muslims. However, a former Bush administration official stated that Kupperman was also known to be "quietly instrumental" in helping to strengthen and build National Security Council staff during his time in Trump's White House.

Kupperman started at the National Security Council two months after Bolton's first deputy, Mira Ricardel, was pushed out of her post following an argument with first lady Melania Trump's office. Despite their political differences, Ross said he never knew Kupperman to be anything but straightforward. "It'll be the real facts," Ross said. "It won't be something else. It won't be alternative facts."

Title: Senate Majority Leader and President Obama Face Off Against Republican Senator Ted Cruz Over Obamacare Funding

Article:

In a heated exchange on NBC's "Meet the Press" on Sunday, Republican Senator Ted Cruz of Texas accused Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid of adopting a non-negotiable stance on the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. Cruz, who has been leading the charge to defund Obamacare, claimed that a potential government shutdown over the issue would be the fault of Reid and President Barack Obama, who have stated they will not negotiate on the matter.

Cruz argued that Reid's position is one of unyielding resistance, stating, "His position is 100 percent of Obamacare must be funded in all instances, and other than that he's going to shut the government down."

Early Sunday morning, the House passed a compromise bill, which Cruz described as a delay in the implementation of Obamacare for a year, rather than a complete defunding. Cruz emphasized that while he believes Obamacare should be repealed, his current focus is on defunding it. The House's most recent vote, he said, represents a compromise, as it only delays the implementation rather than outright defunding.

When host David Gregory questioned Cruz's ability to sway the Senate toward his position, given the lack of public protest against the Affordable Care Act, Cruz countered by stating, "The only people who are not listening to the argument are the career politicians in Washington."

Some of Cruz's fellow Republicans have expressed concern that a government shutdown could harm the party. However, Cruz compared his actions to those of former Senator Phil Gramm (R-Texas), who in 1993 opposed the Clinton healthcare initiative and successfully persuaded other Republicans to resist the passage of what Cruz called "Hillarycare Lite."

As the countdown to the implementation of Obamacare continues, Cruz's efforts to defund or delay the law remain a contentious issue in Washington.

Title: Democrats Show Flexibility on Revenue Targets in Fiscal Cliff Negotiations

Article:

In the ongoing negotiations to avoid the fiscal cliff, incoming House Democratic Caucus chair Xavier Becerra has indicated a willingness to negotiate on the revenue target, signaling a shift in the Democrats' stance on the issue. The Democrats, who have been advocating for raising tax rates on high-income earners and opposing entitlement changes, are showing signs of flexibility regarding the government's revenue collection.

However, several Democratic lawmakers have stated that they are not necessarily committed to the multitrillion-dollar revenue target President Barack Obama is proposing, as long as they secure tax rate increases for the wealthy and prevent significant revisions to Medicare, Medicaid, or Social Security.

California Rep. Xavier Becerra, the incoming Democratic Caucus chairman, told media outlet ███ that a balanced approach could result in almost any revenue number. "So long as you come out with a balanced approach, you could come up with almost any number," Becerra said.

The year-end tax debate has primarily focused on the extent to which Republicans are willing to accept tax increases. House Democrats, who have been sidelined in the talks between House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) and Obama, could play a crucial role if a year-end budget package is negotiated. With the Republicans likely to face defections, Democrats in the House will likely be called upon to move the package through to completion.

Most Democrats are unlikely to oppose the White House, but the administration is already softening its stance on the revenue it seeks to generate through a fiscal cliff deal. After initially requesting $1.6 trillion in revenue, the administration presented Republicans with a proposal this week that reduced the request to $1.4 trillion.

Most Democrats are aiming for a deal that closely mirrors Obama's opening bid and reject the $800 billion in revenue offered by Republicans as insufficient. If lawmakers were to pursue a middle ground between the Republican and Democratic offers, they would find themselves in the vicinity of $1.2 trillion. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee (D-Texas) stated that this revenue goal is acceptable to her.

Rep. Bill Pascrell (D-NJ), a member of the tax-writing Ways and Means panel, also suggested a deal could be reached at $1.2 trillion, but not at a lower amount. "The president could come down to $1.2 trillion," Pascrell said. "I don't think he'll go any lower if he did."

Other Democrats have expressed a willingness to negotiate further. In the Senate, Finance Committee Chairman Max Baucus (D-MT) has discussed a deal that raises $1 trillion in revenue. Rep. Linda Sanchez (D-CA), who will join the Ways and Means Committee next year, stated, "There is a lot of middle ground between $1.6 trillion and $800 billion."

Another incoming Ways and Means Democrat, Pennsylvania's Allyson Schwartz, said, "Nothing is set in stone." This flexibility in revenue targets indicates a potential path forward for the fiscal cliff negotiations, as both parties seek a compromise to avoid the impending tax increases and spending cuts.

Title: Democratic Presidential Hopefuls Distance Themselves from Obama's Policies Amidst 2020 Campaign

Article:

In the heart of Detroit, the Democratic presidential candidates are distancing themselves from former President Barack Obama's policies, despite the ongoing admiration among voters for the former president. The candidates argue that Obama's administration was a failure on immigration, healthcare, and trade.

Former Vice President Joe Biden, who once referred to Obama as his "brother from another mother," criticized Obamacare, the trade deal negotiated during the Obama administration, and the high number of deportations during Obama's tenure. When asked if he would continue the Obama administration's deportation policies, Biden said, "Absolutely not."

Senators Kamala Harris of California and Cory Booker of New Jersey also took aim at Obama's legacy, criticizing the Affordable Care Act and the former president's immigration policies, respectively. New York Mayor Bill de Blasio criticized the Obama Justice Department's handling of the 2014 killing of Eric Garner.

In response, Biden defended Obama's immigration record, citing the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) deportation amnesty granted to illegal immigrant "Dreamers." He argued that the number of deportations was not a fair measure of the administration's accomplishments.

Democratic strategist Zach Friend, who worked on Obama's 2008 campaign, stated that it was a mistake to criticize Obama's legacy, as his popularity among Democrats has been as high as 97% in recent polls. Friend argued that the focus should be on President Trump's current policies rather than on criticizing Obama's legacy.

The Rev. Wendell Anthony, president of the Detroit NAACP, agreed, stating that the focus should be on Trump "because his record is destroying the nation and who we are."

Despite the criticism, the continuing appeal of Obama was evident during the Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez's opening remarks at the debate, where he asked, "Am I the only one who misses Barack Obama in this room?" The crowd responded with a roar of applause.

Criticizing Obama's time in the White House is a risky move for any of the 2020 hopefuls, as they risk alienating the party's voters who romanticize the not-so-long-ago days of the Obama administration. The move is particularly treacherous for Biden, who is running as Obama's political heir with the promise of restoring the normalcy of the Obama era.

Obama voters were irked by the attacks on the former president's policies at the debates. Francois Demonique, a professional chauffeur in Detroit, said he "felt bad" seeing Obama's legacy dragged through the mud. Demonique, who moved to the U.S. from Liberia more than 30 years ago and got his U.S. citizenship to vote for Obama, was especially distraught that Senators Bernie Sanders of Vermont and Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts want to replace Obamacare with "Medicare for All" government-run health care.

Iowa-based Democratic strategist Jeff Link stated that it is smart for Biden to keep Obama close because the good in the eyes of primary voters far outweighs the bad. Link argued that Biden's words against the former president may have been "in the heat of the moment" of the debate and noted that he tried to repair any damage afterward.

The Democratic Party has moved dramatically to the left since Obama was in office. Some of the strongest challengers to Biden, who remains the front-runner, are far-left champions Senators Sanders and Warren. Another powerful contender, Senator Harris, is more moderate but also is embracing parts of the far-left agenda, including a variation of Medicare for All.

Darrell West, vice president and director of governance studies at the Brookings Institution, stated that it was an effective strategy for Biden to tap into Obama's popularity with the party's voters. However, West noted that it will be challenging for Biden to defend Obama's record on deportation and trade, as the party has moved well to the left on those issues, and no one is going to accept those policies as the right ones at the current time.

Title: The Controversial Protest: An Examination of Colin Kaepernick's Actions and Their Impact

Article:

In the world of professional sports, controversy often follows those who dare to challenge the status quo. Colin Kaepernick, the former San Francisco 49er quarterback, has found himself at the center of such a storm, with his decision to not stand during the national anthem causing a significant stir in the sports community and beyond.

Kaepernick's actions, he claims, are a form of protest against the treatment of black people and people of color in America. He stated, "I am not going to stand up to show pride in a flag for a country that oppresses black people and people of color. To me, this is bigger than football, and it would be selfish on my part to look the other way."

This decision has been met with a mix of support and criticism. While some applaud Kaepernick for using his platform to bring attention to social issues, others view his actions as disrespectful to the flag and the anthem. The anthem, originally an English drinking song called "To Anacreon in Heaven," has been the national anthem of the United States since 1931, beating out other contenders such as "America, the Beautiful" and "Dixie."

The controversy has led to a surge in sales of Kaepernick's jersey, with fans burning the jersey as a form of protest. This, in turn, has generated revenue for Kaepernick, as he receives a cut of the proceeds from jersey sales.

The internet has been ablaze with reactions to Kaepernick's actions, with a range of opinions expressed. Some fans have taken pride in the unique American right of freedom of speech and expression that Kaepernick is exercising, while others have criticized his methods and the message he is conveying.

Kaepernick's actions have sparked a larger conversation about social issues in America, with some viewing him as a hero for using his platform to bring attention to these issues, while others view him as a distraction from the game of football. Regardless of one's perspective, it is clear that Kaepernick's actions have made a significant impact, both on and off the field.

As Kaepernick continues to sit during the national anthem, it remains to be seen how long this controversy will continue and what impact it will have on his career and the broader conversation about social issues in America. One thing is certain, however: Kaepernick's actions have undeniably made a mark on the sports world and beyond.

Title: First Lady Michelle Obama Urges Maximum Contributions for Democratic Midterm Elections

Article:

In a bid to bolster Democratic chances in the upcoming midterm elections, First Lady Michelle Obama made a fundraising appeal in Chicago on Thursday. The event, held in her hometown, was part of a series of fundraising events the Obama administration has been organizing in recent weeks.

Addressing a crowd of donors, Michelle Obama urged them to contribute the maximum allowable amount. "Write the biggest, fattest check that you can possibly write," she said. "Writing those checks is the single-most impactful thing that you can do right now."

The President, who concluded a three-day fundraising swing on the West Coast earlier, has been actively participating in these events to raise funds for the committees responsible for electing Democrats to office. The Democrats' prospects of capturing the House seem slim, and the Republicans are aiming to secure the six Senate seats they need to take control of the Senate.

Despite President Obama's approval ratings reaching record lows, he remains a draw at high-dollar fundraisers. In the past month alone, he has attended events in New York, Texas, Colorado, Washington state, and California. His recent journey west included stops in Seattle, San Francisco, and Los Angeles.

In addition to the official Democratic committees, Obama has also appeared at several events for two Democratic super PACs, despite his past opposition to outside groups with unlimited fundraising potential. These events, while not officially labeled as fundraisers, are understood to attract high-dollar donors who contribute generously before leaving.

Michelle Obama, in her fundraising pitch, acknowledged the issue of money in politics but emphasized the need for Democrats to match the Republicans' fundraising efforts. "We can't just stake out the moral high ground and feel good about ourselves - we need to act," she said.

During her remarks, Michelle Obama expressed her continued belief in her husband's ability to bring about positive change, a sentiment that seemed to counter Vice President Joe Biden's recent remarks suggesting that some of the campaign promises made in 2008, such as hope and change, have not yet materialized.

"When folks ask me whether I still believe everything we said about hope and change back in 2008, I tell them that I believe it more strongly than ever before," she said. "While we still have plenty of work to do, we have truly made so much of that change we've been talking about."

Title: Bipartisan Push to End NSA Phone Data Collection Program Faces Resistance from National Security Establishment

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, a bipartisan push to end the National Security Agency's (NSA) phone data collection program has faced resistance from the nation's defense and intelligence establishment. The initiative, spearheaded by Representative Justin Amash (R-Michigan), has found an unexpected ally in Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr. (R-Wisconsin), one of the principal authors of the Patriot Act.

Sensenbrenner, who stated that his legislation was never intended to create a program that allows the government to demand the phone records of every American, joined Amash in urging Congress to halt the program. "The time has come to stop it," Sensenbrenner declared.

Opposing this move, however, were not only President Barack Obama and House Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio, but also top figures from the defense and intelligence community. On Tuesday, the NSA's director, General Keith Alexander, provided classified briefings to lawmakers regarding the program, and the White House issued a statement urging lawmakers to reject the measure.

On Wednesday, James L. Jones, the retired Marine Corps general who served as Mr. Obama's national security adviser from 2009-10, added his name to an open letter in support of preserving the NSA's programs. The letter, signed by more than half a dozen top national-security officials from the Bush administration, stated that denying the NSA such access to data would leave the nation at risk.

Representative Mike Rogers (R-Michigan), a vocal supporter of the program, took a personal swipe at Amash, a popular figure on social media, stating that the House was not in the business of garnering "likes" on Facebook. Rogers argued that the calling log program was an essential tool for preventing terrorist attacks.

"This is not a game," Rogers asserted, "This is real. It will have real consequences."

Despite such appeals, many rank-and-file Republicans and Democrats appeared unfazed. Representative Jared Polis (D-Colorado), a supporter of the amendment, argued that if the Obama administration felt strongly about defending the program, President Obama would have spoken out personally. Instead, the White House released a statement under the name of the press secretary, Jay Carney.

"The press secretary says hundreds of things every day," Polis said.

The divisions within Congress seemed to mirror the ambivalence in the nation. In a CBS News poll released Wednesday, 67 percent of Americans considered the government's collection of phone records a violation of privacy. At the same time, 52 percent viewed it as a necessary tool to help find terrorists.

Title: Clinton's Personal Fundraising for Super PAC Sparks Controversy Among Progressive Critics

Article:

Hillary Clinton's decision to personally raise funds for a super PAC supporting her presidential campaign has stirred controversy among her progressive critics, who view the move as a contradiction to her populist rhetoric and a demonstration of her alleged disconnect with middle-class voters.

The former Secretary of State's involvement with Priorities USA, a super PAC that supports her campaign, has highlighted the contrast between her and her only declared rival, Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders. While Clinton has pledged to get big money out of politics, her personal fundraising for a super PAC is seen as a departure from her campaign's initial stance.

Clinton's campaign has explained the decision as a matter of political necessity, citing the need for resources to counter the significant financial backing of Republican candidates and the Koch Brothers' $1 billion pledge for the 2016 campaign. However, the move has invited criticism from progressive activists who view it as a symptom of a larger disconnect between Clinton and middle-class voters.

Senator Sanders, an independent who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination, has been a vocal opponent of super PAC donations. He has no national fundraising operation and has little to lose by going after millionaire and billionaire donors. Last week, Sanders told CNN that Clinton's decision to personally court super PAC donors was "unfortunate."

Phil Noble, a South Carolina Democratic activist and supporter of former Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley, a potential Democratic candidate for president, said the development underscores what progressives view as a "fundamental disconnect" between Clinton and middle-class voters.

"It's not that she raises a bunch of money for a PAC that causes her problems with middle-class voters. That is a symptom as opposed to the ailment," Noble said. "The larger illness is she is out of touch with middle-class voters -- she does have a lifestyle and a history that is about as alien to middle-class voters as corporate jets are to a Subaru."

Activists pushing Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren to challenge Clinton see campaign finance reform as a major issue. "Being a true champion for working families like Elizabeth Warren is about clearly and unequivocally supporting such critical priorities as a constitutional amendment overturning Citizens United," said Erica Sagrans, campaign manager for Ready for Warren, a movement dedicated to drafting Sen. Elizabeth Warren into the 2016 race.

The Democratic Party's evolving relationship with super PACs has been a topic of debate for years. While Democrats initially opposed Citizens United, they have increasingly embraced super PACs over the years, despite their rhetoric against such political entities. In 2012, President Barack Obama reversed course, declaring after years of keeping his distance from super PACs that his campaign would participate in raising money for Priorities USA.

Clinton's personal involvement with Priorities USA marks the latest chapter in the Democratic Party's evolving relationship with super PACs. Clinton's allies also see that her fundraising prowess and the depth of her connections with the kinds of donors who can cut multi-million dollar checks will likely make her a formidable competitor against any Republican candidate she may face in the general election. Officials are careful to emphasize, however, that Clinton and everyone else involved with her campaign will strictly follow the law as they solicit funds for Priorities USA.

The 2016 money race is well underway on the other side of the political aisle. Declared GOP candidates including Senators Ted Cruz of Texas and Marco Rubio of Florida, as well as expected candidates like former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, are on a fundraising tear. They've shown no signs of distancing themselves from super PAC money. The stiff competition against Republican money is a reality that some progressive leaders say they can't ignore.

Former Vermont Governor and Democratic National Committee Chairman Howard Dean said it would be unwise for Clinton to reject super PAC money. "Unfortunately, if you don't play by the same rules everybody else does, you end up losing elections," said Dean, founder of Democracy for America, one of the groups behind the draft Warren movement. "The key is to change the rules, and I think we have a much better chance of doing that with her as president than we do with one of the Republicans."

Title: Mueller's Office Disputes BuzzFeed Report on Trump-Cohen Allegations, but Stop Short of Denying Overall Claim

Article:

WASHINGTON – In a rare public statement, special counsel Robert Mueller's office on Friday disputed a blockbuster report from BuzzFeed News that alleged President Donald Trump directed his former attorney, Michael Cohen, to lie in his testimony before Congress.

Despite worldwide coverage and intense interest, Mueller's office has stayed mostly quiet on reports regarding the investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election. But on Friday, Mueller's office took the rare step of calling BuzzFeed's story "not accurate."

"BuzzFeed’s description of specific statements to the Special Counsel’s Office, and characterization of documents and testimony obtained by this office, regarding Michael Cohen’s Congressional testimony are not accurate," said Peter Carr, a spokesman for Mueller's office.

The BuzzFeed report alleged that Trump instructed Cohen to lie to Congress about the Trump Organization’s pursuit of a deal to build a luxury residential high-rise in the center of Moscow, hoping to conceal these actions during his presidential bid.

The story also asserted that Mueller's office knew of the president's alleged actions after obtaining information through internal emails, text messages, and multiple interviews.

The report revived discussions about the possibility of impeaching Trump and emboldened House Democrats who vowed to investigate the allegations.

While Mueller's office disputed how BuzzFeed characterized statements, documents, and testimony in its story, the statement did not include specifics or a sweeping denial of the story's overall theme: that the president directed Cohen to lie to Congress.

BuzzFeed responded Friday, saying the news organization remained "confident in the accuracy of our report."

"We are continuing to report and determine what the special counsel is disputing," BuzzFeed said in a statement.

The news organization's Editor-In-Chief, Ben Smith, asked that Mueller's office be more clear as to what was inaccurate in the story.

"In response to the statement tonight from the Special Counsel's spokesman: We stand by our reporting and the sources who informed it, and we urge the Special Counsel to make clear what he's disputing," Smith said on Twitter.

Nevertheless, the response from Mueller's office is sure to embolden the president and his supporters. Trump called news of the Mueller team statement a "sad day for journalism" but a "great day" for the country.

Within minutes of the statement being aired on cable news shows, the president started retweeting supporters who called BuzzFeed fake news and the story "nonsense." Some of those he retweeted, including his campaign manager Brad Parscale, used this as a chance to attack other stories over the years about Trump and his Russian contacts as "fake news."

Trump's attorney, Rudy Giuliani, also responded on Twitter by praising Mueller's office for disputing the report, attacking the press, and calling for an investigation into who leaked information to BuzzFeed for its story.

"I commend Bob Mueller’s office for correcting the BuzzFeed false story that Pres. Trump encouraged Cohen to lie," Giuliani said. "I ask the press to take heed that their hysterical desire to destroy this President has gone too far."

Even before Mueller's team got involved, Trump, who frequently calls the media "fake news," lashed out about the report and Cohen's credibility.

"Lying to reduce his jail time!" the president wrote on Twitter.

Cohen, 52, is expected to begin a three-year prison sentence in March after pleading guilty to federal financial crimes, campaign finance violations, and lying to Congress, which was at the heart of the BuzzFeed story.

Cohen admitted he was not truthful when he told the Senate and House Intelligence Committees that all discussions about a Moscow development had ceased in January 2016, knowing that such efforts had continued through at least June – in the heat of the campaign and as Trump repeatedly denied any links to Russia.

Prosecutors have asserted in court documents filed late last year that the tower project "likely required the assistance of the Russian government." And if completed, the company stood to gain hundreds of millions of dollars from Russian sources in licensing fees and other revenues.

The court documents did not address whether Cohen's false statements about the Moscow tower discussions were prompted by any other consideration than an attempt to personally shield the campaign from public association with Russia.

Title: US Opposition Calls for Trump's Interpreter to Testify over Putin Summit Discussions

Article:

In a move that could potentially escalate the ongoing controversy surrounding President Donald Trump's summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin, opposition politicians are urging the subpoenaing of Marina Gross, Trump's interpreter during the Helsinki meeting, to testify before the U.S. Congress.

Senator Robert Menendez, the lead Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has called for Gross to appear before the committee, citing the need for transparency and clarity regarding the private discussions between the two leaders.

The summit, which took place on Monday in Helsinki, has been a subject of controversy, with President Trump having to correct his own words from the press conference. It is highly unusual for an interpreter to be questioned, especially given that the two leaders met privately for two hours with only their interpreters present.

Democrats argue that, as the only other American official present in the room, Gross can and should provide details of what the two presidents said to each other. Senator Menendez told MSNBC, "We want the interpreter to come before the committee. We want to see the notes. We're going to have a massive effort to try to get to what happened."

Representative Bill Pascrell stated that the "concessions" Mr. Trump had made in public to Mr. Putin meant "Congress and the American public deserve to know the details of their private conversation." If Gross declined to appear before the committee, she should be subpoenaed, he wrote.

Interpreters are typically meant to be all but invisible at summits, and Gross is a U.S. State Department employee with years of experience translating at the highest level, according to CNN.

Republican Senator Bob Corker, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said he would consider the calls to summon Gross but questioned the idea. "They're not policy people," he told reporters. "They are in some cases contract folks. In the future, would any notes even be allowed to be taken if you started doing this kind of thing?"

Corker also pointed out that Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who was in Helsinki with Mr. Trump, would be questioned by the committee next week.

In Russia, Konstantin Kosachev, head of the foreign affairs committee in the upper house of parliament, said the idea of questioning an interpreter set a dangerous precedent that threatened the "whole idea of diplomacy." The Associated Press reports this statement.

Gamal Helal, an Arabic interpreter and senior adviser to four U.S. presidents and seven secretaries of state, told CNN he could not remember such a situation. "It would be a horrible precedent if a president was not free to talk one-on-one with a head of state... If he [Mr. Trump] spoke in English, there would be no other way for Congress to know what he said, except to ask the president himself. Or Putin."

While the summit was held behind closed doors, the two leaders gave a news conference afterwards at which Mr. Trump shocked many by defending Russia over the allegations of election interference. Contradicting his own intelligence agencies, he said there had been no reason for Russia to meddle in the vote.

A day later, Mr. Trump came out to say he had "misspoken" and did actually accept U.S. intelligence agencies' findings that Russia had interfered. However, a new row developed when the U.S. leader appeared to disagree with U.S. intelligence over whether Russia was still targeting American elections.

Investigations into the alleged interference, denied by Russia, continue, and last week, the U.S. justice department charged 12 Russian intelligence officers with hacking Democratic officials in 2016.

Title: Democratic Representatives Boycott State of the Union Address Over President Trump's Remarks

Article:

In a move that marks a growing dissent among Democratic lawmakers, Florida Rep. Frederica Wilson announced on Sunday that she will boycott President Trump's State of the Union address, citing the President's recent controversial remarks about Haiti and African nations.

Wilson, who was elected in 2010 and made headlines last year for her public disagreement with Trump over his telephone call to the widow of a fallen soldier, stated in a late Sunday release that she will not attend the Jan. 30 speech.

"For the first time since I began serving in the U.S. House of Representatives, I will not be attending the president's State of the Union address," Wilson said. "I have no doubts that instead of delivering a message of inclusivity and an agenda that benefits all Americans, President Trump's address will be full of innuendo, empty promises, and lies."

Wilson joins Reps. Maxine Waters (D-Calif.), John Lewis (D-Ga.), and Earl Blumenauer (D-Ore.) in boycotting the event.

Rep. Maxine Waters, in an interview with MSNBC over the weekend, expressed her reasons for boycotting the event, stating, "Why would I take my time to go and sit and listen to a liar? Someone who lies in the face of facts, someone who can change their tune day in and day out. What does he have to say that I would be interested in? I don't appreciate him, and I wouldn't waste my time sitting in that house listening to what he has to say. He does not deserve my attention."

Rep. John Lewis made his announcement on Friday, citing reports that Trump had referred to some African countries as "s--tholes" in a conversation with lawmakers about immigration.

"I can not in all good conscience be in a room with what he has said about so many Americans," Lewis said on MSNBC Friday. "I just can not do it. I wouldn't be honest with myself."

Rep. Earl Blumenauer said he would be skipping the event before Trump's remarks became public, but said it would be a waste of time, and he was staying home.

"Rather than listening to another destructive, divisive speech by Trump, I will not attend this year's annual address to Congress," Blumenauer said in a statement. "Instead, like I did during his inauguration, I'll be working at home listening to Oregonians about what they think about the State of the Union."

In response to the accusations of racism, President Trump addressed the issue on Sunday, stating, "I'm not a racist. I am the least racist person you have ever interviewed. That I can tell you."

The State of the Union boycott isn't the only protest planned by Democrats. Rep. Jackie Speier (D-Calif.) plans to wear black in order to stand in solidarity with victims of sexual harassment, while other House lawmakers say they are planning on inviting victims of sexual assault to attend the president's first State of the Union address.

"Some members will be bringing survivors of sexual assault and advocates as their guests," an aide to Florida Rep. Lois Frankel told NBC News.

Other ideas that have since been nixed include holding mock trials with the women who have accused Trump of sexual misconduct.

In 2016, Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) skipped former President Barack Obama's last State of the Union address. That same year, three conservative Supreme Court judges -- Justices Clarence Thomas, Samuel Alito, and Antonin Scalia -- were also a no-show.

Scalia, who died in 2016, had missed the State of the Union address more than a dozen times, and called the event "a childish spectacle."

Title: Florida Senate Rejects Assault Weapons Ban, Advances Bill to Arm Some Teachers Following Parkland Shooting

In a closely contested vote, the Florida Senate has rejected a proposal to ban assault weapons and advanced a bill that would allow some teachers to carry firearms in schools, following the deadly shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida.

The vote on Saturday saw the amendment that aimed to ban assault weapons attached to a wider bill fail in a largely party-line vote, with the final tally being 20-17 against the ban. Two Republicans joined all of the Senate's 15 Democrats in support of the proposal, according to the Miami Herald.

The full bill, known as the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School Public Safety Act, is expected to pass the state Senate on Monday and then move to the Florida House. The bill includes measures such as raising the minimum age to buy a rifle or a shotgun to 21 from 18, banning the use, sale, or possession of bump stocks, and providing $400 million in funding for schools to address mental health issues.

Following the Senate's rejection of the assault weapon ban, Stoneman Douglas student Jaclyn Corin tweeted, "This breaks my heart, but we will NOT let this ruin our movement. This is for the kids." Fellow classmate David Hogg, who has become one of the school's leading activists on gun safety, tweeted, "Elections are going to be fun!"

An amendment to remove a provision to train and arm some teachers also failed. The bill's passage through the Senate comes amidst criticism of the Broward County school system and sheriff's department for not acting on red flags regarding the mental health problems and potentially violent behavior of the accused 19-year-old shooter, Nikolas Cruz.

The bill's progression through the legislative process reflects the ongoing national debate on gun control and school safety in the aftermath of the deadliest high school shooting in U.S. history. The bill's eventual passage and the outcome of the ensuing negotiations between the Senate and House will have significant implications for gun laws in Florida and potentially beyond.

Title: Reflecting on the Political Landscape: The Role of Government and the Pursuit of a Content Life

Article:

In the aftermath of the recent election, it is evident that the political landscape has once again proven to be a significant force in shaping societal norms and expectations. The campaign trail, as always, has left many questioning the role of government in our lives and the impact of political promises on our daily lives.

The political process, with its constant promises of a utopian society, often overshadows the importance of family, community, and personal responsibility. The pursuit of happiness, as envisioned by our founding fathers, seems to have taken a backseat to the political enterprise that has come to dominate our affairs.

The Affordable Care Act, for instance, made grand promises about singlehandedly improving the insurance system, yet failed to deliver on those promises. Similarly, the removal of Confederate battle flags was expected to bring about racial understanding, but the reality has been far more complex. The movement to enforce mutual consent for sexual relations at college parties is another example of political intervention that has raised more questions than answers.

Both major political parties seem to have a propensity for imposing their ideals upon society, with Democrats often resembling stern schoolmarms and Republicans encouraging centrally conceived, centrally managed projects. The current obsession with Title IX rules governing sex on college campuses is a testament to this trend, with political figures drawing up rules and regulations in an attempt to define personal conduct.

The question arises: Who are we, as a society, supposed to be? And how do we become the individuals we aspire to be? The answer, it seems, lies not in the hands of political regulators, but in the power of individual character and the discourse of civilized societies.

The role of a democratic society is not to dictate who we are, but to protect the inborn right to a life of freedom, virtue, and, ultimately, contentment. This right, once familiar to Americans, has become less so in recent years. It is time for us, as a society, to reclaim this right and to remember that the pursuit of a content life is not a political endeavor, but a personal one.

Title: Kentucky's Affordable Care Act Enrollment: A Double-Edged Sword for Sen. Mitch McConnell in Senate Race

Article:

In the closely watched Senate race in Kentucky, Republican Sen. Mitch McConnell, who is statistically tied with his Democratic opponent, has been vocal in his criticism of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), or "Obamacare." However, the ACA may not be the campaign issue that Sen. McConnell hopes it will be.

According to a survey by The New York Times/Kaiser Family Foundation, people in Kentucky disapprove of the ACA, but they also sense that it is broken yet helpful, particularly through the state-run exchange, "kynect." More than 1 in 10 residents is now covered by kynect, and this year, more than 413,400 people were enrolled in kynect by mid-April.

Stephen Voss, an associate professor of political science at the University of Kentucky in Lexington, suggests that Obamacare as a political issue will likely be "a wash" for Sen. McConnell. Voters in Kentucky are open to the help that the ACA represents, specifically through kynect.

In the state, about 80 percent of kynect customers are covered by the Medicaid expansion, and the other 20 percent have chosen the exchange's private plans. In areas devastated by the recent collapse of the coal industry, such as Hazard, coverage for the poor is especially welcome.

Stephen Kelly, a young man who recently moved to Hazard, has a wife and two sons and a master's degree in Christian ministry. After signing up for Medicaid under kynect, he underwent a physical and lab tests, which he had not had "in quite some time." This is the first time he has had health insurance.

While the ACA is helping him and his family, Mr. Kelly has mixed feelings about the law. While it is helping those who need it, he notes that his father, who lives in Harlan, Ky., is seeing his insurance costs skyrocket.

The ambivalence of Kentuckians toward the ACA is reflected in the April poll by The New York Times/Kaiser Family Foundation. People don't like it, but they don't want to scrap it either. A majority – 55 percent – disapprove of the health-care law. But a majority also say their representative in Congress should work to improve the law, not repeal it and replace it with something else.

Meanwhile, Sen. McConnell's Democratic opponent, Kentucky Secretary of State Alison Lundergan Grimes, who favors the keep-and-fix approach, has avoided talking about the health-care law. Her supporters call kynect "Beshearcare," after the governor.

State Sen. Robert Stivers (R) predicts that people will experience "sticker shock" when health insurance enrollment notices go out for the new year, just before the election. If that comes to pass, McConnell may well benefit from his anti-ACA message. However, until then, the new law "loses its power as an issue" because of the ambivalence about it, according to Professor Voss.

Title: Biden's Marijuana Policy and Criminal Justice Record Under Scrutiny in 2020 Presidential Race

In a recent public appearance, a potential 2020 Democratic candidate expressed concerns about the growing market for marijuana sales in middle schools, highlighting the lack of ID checks and the potential dangers this poses to minors. This statement, made by a yet-to-be-named candidate, underscores the evolving landscape of marijuana policy within the Democratic party.

The candidate who may face the most scrutiny on this issue is former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who, during his tenure in the 1980s and 90s, was a key figure in the "war on drugs." His policies, which included tough mandatory minimum sentences for drug offenses, contributed to an era of mass incarceration, with significant economic and social repercussions for minorities.

John Hudak, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution who specializes in state and federal marijuana policy, stated, "In 1994 Biden had a fairly mainstream position, but in 2020 that position is so far from the mainstream of Democratic politics that it is almost offensive." Hudak further characterized Mr. Biden's history on criminal justice issues as his "biggest liability in the 2020 primary."

Mr. Biden has acknowledged some aspects of his record, particularly a 1980s law that mandated harsher penalties for crack cocaine compared to powder cocaine, a disparity that disproportionately affected African-Americans. He has since referred to this law as "a big mistake."

Spokespersons for Mr. Biden, who has reportedly told aides he is 95 percent committed to entering the presidential race, did not respond to requests for comment.

Two Democratic senators, Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota and Sherrod Brown of Ohio, who are opposed to federal marijuana legalization, represent battleground states in the Midwest, where politics tend to be less progressive than in coastal states that have led the way in legalizing cannabis for adult use. This dynamic could potentially influence the party's stance on marijuana policy in the upcoming election.

Title: ASEAN Foreign Ministers Express Concern Over South China Sea Tensions, Seek Dialogue with China

Article:

In a joint statement issued at the conclusion of their annual retreat in Vientiane, Laos, the foreign ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) expressed their "serious concern" over recent developments in the disputed South China Sea region. The ministers reaffirmed the importance of maintaining peace, security, and stability in the area, which is at the center of a territorial dispute involving China and several ASEAN countries, including Vietnam, the Philippines, and Malaysia.

Tensions have escalated since China began a massive land reclamation program in 2013. Recent satellite imagery suggests that China has installed surface-to-air missiles in a disputed area in the Paracels chain, prompting accusations that Beijing is militarizing the area.

The joint statement noted the ministers' concerns over the land reclamations and escalation of activities in the South China Sea, stating that these activities have "eroded trust and confidence, increased tensions, and may undermine peace, security, and stability in the region."

Vietnam's foreign minister, Pham Binh Minh, told reporters as he left the meeting that he was "seriously concerned about the situation" and called for the "non-militarization" of the South China Sea. Cambodia's foreign minister, Hor Namhong, said ASEAN would seek a meeting with China over the matter, though no date or venue had been set.

Other matters were on the agenda as well. The ministers reiterated their perennial call for the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. They also addressed Islamic extremism, in the wake of an attack in the Indonesian capital of Jakarta in January that left eight people dead.

"The threat is real. It's no longer fictitious or mere imagination," said Malaysia's foreign minister, Anifah Aman.

Other topics included ways to bring about ever closer economic cooperation since the advent of the ASEAN Economic Community at the end of last year.

Title: Rowan County Clerk's Absence Leads to Issuance of First Same-Sex Marriage License

In a historic and emotionally charged event at the Rowan County Courthouse in Kentucky, a same-sex couple, James Yates and William Smith, were granted a marriage license after five previous unsuccessful attempts. The couple, who braved protesters outside the courthouse, entered the clerk's office as the sun rose over the mountains.

The county clerk, Kim Davis, who had previously denied them a marriage license, was in jail due to contempt of court charges for defying the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling on same-sex marriage. In her absence, Deputy Clerk Brian Mason issued the license to Yates and Smith.

The couple, now the first same-sex pair to receive a marriage license from Rowan County, were greeted with chants of "Love has won" as they exited the courthouse. "I don't want her in jail," Yates said, referring to Kim Davis. "No one wanted her in jail. We just wanted the licenses given out."

Kim Davis' husband, Joe Davis, was also present outside the courthouse, leading a group of protesters who viewed this as a moral fight. "We don't hate these people," he said. "We don't hate nobody. We just want to have the same rights that they have."

The legality of the marriage licenses issued today is still uncertain, as they do not bear Kim Davis' signature. This event marks a significant step forward for civil rights in Rowan County, as the couple's victory underscores the fact that civil rights are not subject to personal beliefs.

Title: Attorney General Jeff Sessions Responds to President Trump's Criticism in Unusual Rebuttal

Article:

In an unprecedented move, Attorney General Jeff Sessions responded to repeated criticisms from President Donald Trump by defending his tenure at the Department of Justice in a statement on Thursday. The statement comes days after Trump criticized Sessions in a Fox News interview, accusing him of failing to control the Justice Department.

Sessions' statement read:

"I took control of the Department of Justice the day I was sworn in, which is why we have had unprecedented success at effectuating the President's agenda -- one that protects the safety and security and rights of the American people, reduces violent crime, enforces our immigration laws, promotes economic growth, and advances religious liberty."

He continued, "While I am Attorney General, the actions of the Department of Justice will not be improperly influenced by political considerations. I demand the highest standards, and where they are not met, I take action. However, no nation has a more talented, more dedicated group of law enforcement investigators and prosecutors than the United States. I am proud to serve with them and proud of the work we have done in successfully advancing the rule of law."

The statement appears to be a direct response to Trump's criticism of Sessions in a Fox News interview on Wednesday, where he said, "I put in an attorney general that never took control of the Justice Department. Jeff Sessions never took control of the Justice Department and it's a sort of an incredible thing."

Trump's criticism of Sessions was not limited to this statement. He also told Fox News host Ainsley Earhardt that "even my enemies say that Jeff Sessions should have told you that he was going to recuse himself and then you would not have put him in." Trump added that the only reason he gave Sessions a job in his administration was because he was loyal. And, in perhaps the most cutting and personal attack, Trump said this of Sessions: "He took the job and then he said, 'I'm going to recuse myself.' I said, 'What kind of a man is this?'"

Sessions' statement marks a rare instance of him directly responding to a Trump attack. The only other time, according to reports, was back in February when Trump tweeted about the Inspector General's investigation into the FBI's handling of the Russia investigation. Sessions responded by saying he had "initiated the appropriate process that will ensure complaints against this department will be fully and fairly acted upon if necessary."

Sessions' statement on Thursday seems to be a response to Trump's anger over the conviction of former campaign chairman Paul Manafort and the plea deal of former lawyer and fixer Michael Cohen on Tuesday, which came as a result of special counsel Robert Mueller's probe. Trump has publicly expressed his belief that the investigation is illegal and that Sessions' decision to recuse himself from the Russia investigation is the root of his political problems. However, legal experts have consistently maintained that Sessions' decision to recuse himself was the right thing to do, given his role as a prominent surrogate for Trump during the 2016 campaign and his failure to disclose several interactions he had with Russians during the campaign.

Despite Trump's repeated criticisms of Sessions, the President has not fired him, with his lawyer Rudy Giuliani stating in May that Trump has "some grievances" with Sessions but is not going to fire him before the Mueller investigation is over. However, with Sessions' latest statement, it seems that he is goading Trump to get rid of him.

Title: President Obama Promotes Infrastructure Investment Plan to Boost U.S. Job Creation

Article:
