In a bid to stimulate private sector investment in infrastructure and create jobs, President Barack Obama visited the port of Miami on Friday. Addressing a crowd, he emphasized the importance of rebuilding the nation's infrastructure to strengthen the economy.

"There are few more important things we can do to create jobs right now and strengthen our economy over the long haul than rebuilding the infrastructure that powers our businesses and our economy - our roads, our bridges, our schools, and our ports like this one," President Obama said.

The president's plan, named the "Rebuild America Partnership," consists of three components: the creation of a $10 billion national infrastructure bank, the establishment of new "America Fast Forward Bonds" for infrastructure investment, and the expansion of funding for the TIGER and TIFFIA infrastructure programs.

"Let's rebuild this country we love. Let's make sure we're staying on the cutting edge. Let's make sure we've always got the best ports. Let's make sure we've got the best airports. Let's make sure we've got the best rail lines. Let's make sure we've got the best roads. Let's make sure we've got the best schools," he said. "We're going to push on this issue each and every day and make sure we get the middle class going again."

Before delivering his speech, the president toured a tunnel project at the port of Miami, which is undergoing a $2 billion renovation funded by government and private money. "Breaking ground on more projects like this tunnel that I just saw means more good construction jobs that can't be outsourced," Obama said. "They have to be done right here in America, and they end up getting people good pay and good opportunities to raise their family."

Alan Krueger, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisors, stated that the program will total $21 billion but assured that it would not increase the deficit. Details of the costs of the program will be outlined in the president's budget, which will be presented on April 10.

"They will not increase the deficit by a dime because they are paid for in our budget," Krueger told reporters aboard Air Force One Friday. The president's speech was delivered in front of a crane manufactured by a Chinese company called ZPMC.

Title: Charlotte Police Claim 70% of Arrested Protesters Were Out-of-State Residents, Sparking Debate on Influence of George Soros

Article:

In the aftermath of the recent unrest in Charlotte, North Carolina, Todd Walther, spokesman for the Charlotte-Mecklenburg Fraternal Order of Police, has claimed that 70% of the protesters arrested during the demonstrations had out-of-state identification cards. Walther stated that the unrest was not caused by local protestors, but rather by "outside entities" instigating the violence.

According to a tweet by CNN's OutFront, Walther made these comments during an interview with Erin Burnett on CNN. The tweet, which can be found at <https://twitter.com/OutFrontCNN/status/777400580007309312>, states, "Charlotte police: 70% of arrested protesters had out of state ID's, outside entities are causing these problems."

This statement has sparked debate and raised questions about the influence of outside groups on the protests. In 2014, during the Ferguson riots, liberal billionaire George Soros was accused of funding social justice organizations and turning local protests into national flashpoints.

In an article published by The Washington Times in 2014, it was reported that Soros donated $33 million to social justice organizations during the Ferguson protests. The article states, "Still not buying it? As The New American recently reported, Ken Zimmerman, the director of U.S. programs at Soros’s Open Society Foundations (OSF), denied last year that Soros had funded BLM, saying it was just a rumor."

However, it was later revealed that the OSF had given at least $650,000 directly to BLM, according to documents published by DCLeaks.com. The documents also revealed that the OSF's funding of BLM was intended to "dismantle" America and recast it according to the vision of Soros and his leftist cohorts.

The communist-on-its-face nature of the demands of organizations under the BLM umbrella, as well as the deep-pocketed funding by Soros, the Center for American Progress, the Ford Foundation, and Borealis Philanthropy, have led some to believe that BLM is a tool of social revolutionaries aiming to destroy America and build a dystopia in its place.

With Hillary Clinton's poll numbers declining and a debate looming, some are questioning whether the sudden appearance of "out of state" protesters in Charlotte was an attempt to shift the focus away from Clinton's email scandal and other controversies. George Soros, a major donor to the Democratic Party, has been mercurial in his political donations, contributing to both Clinton and Barack Obama in 2008, but not since.

Soros, who founded the Quantum Fund in 1969 with $12 million, is now worth $24.7 billion and continues to invest through Soros Fund Management, a family firm. As a political donor, Soros has contributed $54 million to federal candidates and committees since 2003. The Open Society Policy Center, the advocacy arm of his philanthropic network, spent $8.2 million on lobbying Washington in 2015 and focuses on international human rights, immigration, foreign aid, public health, and criminal justice reform, among other issues.

Title: U.S. Presidential Campaign Shifts Focus to Foreign Policy Amid Middle East Unrest

Article:

In a sudden change of pace, the U.S. presidential campaign has delved into a second day of intense foreign policy debate, with Republican nominee Mitt Romney continuing his criticism of President Barack Obama's approach to the recent attacks on U.S. diplomatic posts in Cairo and Benghazi, Libya.

At a rally in a northern Virginia suburb of Washington, Romney expressed his condolences to the families of the American diplomatic workers who perished in the Benghazi attack, including Chris Stevens, the American ambassador to Libya. However, he swiftly transitioned to a critical assessment of the United States' global position under Obama's administration.

"As we watch the world today, sometimes it seems that we're at the mercy of events instead of shaping events, and a strong America is essential to shape events," Romney said.

Meanwhile, Obama, also campaigning on Thursday, did not address Romney's criticisms but issued a warning to the perpetrators of Tuesday's killings.

"I want all of you to know that we are going to bring those who killed our fellow Americans to justice," Obama said to applause at a campaign stop in Colorado. "I want people around the world to hear me, to all those who would do us harm, no act of terror will go unpunished. It will not dim the light of the values that we proudly present to the rest of the world."

The aggressive stance from Obama contrasted with the image Romney began painting of the president late Tuesday, when his campaign issued a statement calling the Obama administration's response to the assault on the U.S. embassy in Cairo "disgraceful." This statement was issued before news broke that America's ambassador to Libya had died in an attack on a consulate in Benghazi.

On Wednesday, Romney continued his approach, stating that Obama had "demonstrated a lack of clarity as to a foreign policy."

"I think it is a terrible course for America to stand in apology for our values," Romney also said. "That instead when our grounds are being attacked and being breached that the first response of the United States must be outrage at the breach of the sovereignty of our nation. And apology for America's values is never the right course."

In his remarks, Romney again accused the Obama administration of sympathizing with the instigators of the violence in Cairo, citing a statement released by the American embassy there stating it "condemns the continuing efforts by misguided individuals to hurt the religious feelings of Muslims."

However, a timeline of events Tuesday suggests Romney was mistaken in this allegation, as the violence came after the first statement was published. A later tweet from the embassy, which was subsequently deleted, indicated the embassy was standing by their original statement and also condemning the protests.

Reaction to Romney's sharply negative tack has been mixed. Obama, along with other Democrats, pushed back, saying Romney was injecting politics during a time of still-developing international crisis. Like Romney, Obama did not mince words about his political opponent.

"Gov. Romney seems to have a tendency to shoot first and aim later," Obama said during an interview with CBS. "As president, one of the things I've learned is you can't do that. It's important for you to make sure that the statements that you make are backed up by the facts and that you've thought through the ramifications before you make them."

Former Ambassador Nick Burns, who served in the administrations of former Presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush, said he was "dismayed" by Romney's choice to inject politics into what he said was a "very difficult situation" for the United States.

"I think it's time for Americans to stand together and I hope Gov. Romney would stand with the administration," Burns said, also on CNN.

Republicans have largely refrained from criticizing their party's nominee, at least publicly. Sen. John McCain of Arizona, the 2008 GOP presidential nominee and the ranking Republican member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, would not support or chastise Romney's stance on CNN Thursday morning, saying only that he agreed Obama's policy toward the Middle East was weak.

"Now the tick tock back and forth is something, frankly, I didn't pay attention to," McCain said on "Starting Point."

"I do know this. Americans are outraged when our embassy is attacked and the Egyptian government does not take the proper measures to protect it," McCain continued. "How much that affects our relationship with Egypt, I think, is something we have to carefully calibrate, recognizing how important a role Egypt is in the entire Middle East."

Other conservative voices, including the editorial page of the Wall Street Journal, also attempted to shield Romney from critics.

"As Tuesday's events showed, pandering to Islamists who would use the video to inflame anti-American sentiment is not going to stop the protests," read the editorial, which was published under the headline "Romney Offends the Pundits."

"His political faux pas (sic) was to offend a pundit class that wants to cede the foreign policy debate to Mr. Obama without thinking seriously about the trouble for America that is building in the world," it continued.

This week's deviation to foreign policy comes after more than a year of a near-singular campaign focus on jobs and the economy. The topic re-entered the political discussion following the Republican National Convention at the end of August, when Democrats piled on Romney for not mentioning Afghanistan in his speech accepting the GOP presidential nomination.

Later, during their own convention, Democrats highlighted support for American troops currently in war zones and the president's successful foreign policy actions, including the mission that killed Osama bin Laden. This particular thread was viewed by many as successfully positioning Obama ahead of Romney on an issue that Democrats have traditionally not seen as a strength.

Voters consistently say in polls Obama would better handle America's relationships with other countries if re-elected. In the latest CNN/ORC International survey released earlier this week, Obama had a 54% - 42% advantage over Romney on foreign policy.

Title: A Retrospective on Hillary Clinton's Controversial History of Honesty and Trustworthiness

Article:

In the aftermath of Hillary Clinton's health scare during a 9/11 commemoration ceremony, the Democratic presidential nominee's long-standing reputation for dishonesty and lack of trustworthiness has once again come under scrutiny.

From her involvement in the White House Travel Office scandal during her husband's presidency to her claims about braving sniper fire in Bosnia and her secret email setup as secretary of state, Clinton has left a trail of questionable truths and false statements that date back over a quarter-century.

The Democratic nominee has often dismissed these accusations as right-wing hit jobs. However, her campaign's attempt to downplay her health issues and the subsequent fallout has brought these past controversies to the forefront.

Republican strategist Ed Rollins traces Clinton's problem with veracity back to her 1992 interview on "60 Minutes," where she defended her husband, then-presidential candidate Bill Clinton, from accusations of a 12-year extramarital affair with Gennifer Flowers.

Clinton's statement, "I'm not sitting here some little woman standing by my man like Tammy Wynette," has been a point of contention, with the truth of her words remaining uncertain. The interview, however, is credited with saving Clinton's campaign and launching a political legacy marked by scandal.

Another of Clinton's early brushes with truthfulness came during the White House Travel Office scandal in 1993, when she was accused of orchestrating the firings, which were believed to be intended to make room for hiring friends of the Clintons. The independent counsel investigating the scandal, known as Travelgate, found that Clinton's statements denying her involvement were "factually inaccurate."

Similarly, FBI Director James B. Comey outlined numerous lies Clinton told the public about her secret email server as secretary of state, including misrepresentations about the number of devices she used, the classification of emails, and the extent of her email turnover to the State Department.

Clinton's mischaracterization of Comey's statements and her subsequent reversal of positions on various political issues have also raised questions about her honesty.

Some of Clinton's breaks with the truth have seemed trivial, such as her claims about her grandparents being immigrants or her connection to Sir Edmund Hillary. However, more significant discrepancies, like her statements regarding the Benghazi attack and the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal, have raised concerns among voters.

As the 2016 presidential race continues, Clinton's history of questionable truthfulness and her campaign's handling of her health issues will likely remain a point of contention for both supporters and critics alike.

Title: Rising Car Loan Delinquencies Pose Challenge for America's Working Poor

Article:

In the heartland of America, a once-essential ingredient for employment - owning a car - has become increasingly costly for millions of low-wage earners, despite a prolonged economic growth and low unemployment. According to the New York Federal Reserve, more than 7 million Americans are already 90 or more days behind on their car loans, with serious delinquency rates among borrowers with the lowest credit scores seeing the fastest acceleration.

The roots of this problem can be traced back to the 2008 financial crisis, when automakers drastically reduced production in the midst of the worst economic downturn since the Great Depression. A decade later, this has made used 10-year-old vehicles, typically more affordable for low-wage earners, a relative rarity.

According to data provided to ███ by industry consultant and car shopping website Edmunds, the average price of that vintage of vehicle is $8,657, still nearly 75% higher than in 2010 despite some softening in prices over the last year. In contrast, the average new car has seen a price rise of 25% in that same time period.

"This is pinching people at the worst point possible," said Ivan Drury, Edmunds' senior manager of industry analysis. "If you need basic A to B transportation, you have to get an older car that needs more repairs and has more wear-and-tear issues."

Monthly auto payments for Americans making under $40,000 have remained flat since 2017, while those in higher wage brackets have seen their payments rise, according to a Cox Automotive Inc analysis for ███. This might seem like good news, but to Cox chief economist Jonathan Smoke, it indicates poorer Americans are stretched so thin they can not afford to pay more.

Weak lending standards in recent years are partly to blame for the rising delinquency rates, which Warren Kornfeld, a senior vice president on Moody's financial institutions team, said are approaching record highs despite a solid economy. Auto lenders are belatedly tightening lending standards, but it may already be too late, he said.

"The economy is masking the true performance of auto loans," Kornfeld said. "If we hit a downturn today, the performance of auto loans would not look very good."

Research from the New York Fed earlier this year showed that while delinquency rates among borrowers with high credit scores have remained steady and low, for subprime borrowers they have been rising, pushing up the overall delinquency rate. Around 8% of loans originated by lower-score buyers with a credit score below 620 were categorized as seriously late, "a development that is surprising during a strong economy and labor market," Fed researchers wrote.

For many Americans, a lack of a car means a lack of a job. Hollis Heyward, a 30-year-old father of two, makes $10 an hour working at a warehouse in Freeport, a rural town of 25,000 about 115 miles (185.07 km) northwest of Chicago. In the midst of a divorce, all he could afford was a gray 2005 Pontiac Grand Prix with close to 200,000 miles on it, which he bought for $1,300 cash - a fraction of the average new car price.

Suddenly also stuck paying off the loan on his future ex-wife's car, Heyward had to rework the loan with local used-car dealer Gordy Tormohlen of Good People Automotive. Under his "workout" deal, Heyward is paying the loan's principal only, and Tormohlen has waived the interest payments. Heyward's monthly payment is now around $120 per month, down from around $350 before the workout.

"Right now, it's hard to make ends meet," said Heyward. "But I am not the kind of guy to walk away from my commitments."

Tormohlen, 59, a second-generation dealer, said his business is up 10% this year as auto finance companies tighten lending standards. He said the market feels like it did before the financial crisis hit in 2008, when consumers were over-extended with debt.

"Americans have grown too comfortable with debt, and the time has come to pay the piper," he said.

Tormohlen is a "Buy Here, Pay Here" dealer, offering subprime loans that he finances himself at 19%, which is higher than a bank but lower than many finance companies. He said he can work directly with struggling customers like Heyward, whom he has known for a decade, but worries that large finance companies with tens or hundreds of thousands of borrowers will be in deep trouble when a downturn hits.

Indeed, according to the New York Fed, more than 1 million more Americans are behind on their car loans now than at the peak of delinquencies in 2010 after the financial crisis.

"The big lenders who do not know their customers are going to have a problem when the economy turns," Tormohlen says.

Expensive older used cars are exacerbating the problem, and it may take years for them to return to more affordable levels. George Augustaitis, director of automotive industry analytics at CarGurus Inc (CARG.O), an online marketplace for new and used cars, said late this spring his team started to notice an "accelerating decline" in the number of available vehicles under $10,000, which typically would include vehicles between eight and 12 years old.

In an analysis for ███, CarGuru's data shows a falling share of inventory of Great Recession-era cars, while the number of online "leads" from consumers seeking those vehicles has remained steady. In fact, the average American car is the oldest on record, and CarGurus' Augustaitis said the available inventory of vehicles costing under $10,000 will not return to more normal levels until 2022, reflecting rising car production after the Great Recession.

Ken Shilson, president of the National Alliance of Buy Here, Pay Here Dealers (NABD), said American consumers have become too comfortable with debt, and subprime customers have been "poisoned" by easy access to capital for much of the long economic expansion. But he added that those customers will be forced by tighter underwriting to seek even older vehicles.

"The American way is to always live beyond your means, and Americans aren't good at making life adjustments," Shilson said. "But there's a reality check coming, and many subprime buyers will be forced to find more affordable transportation."

Title: Unemployment Rate Drops to 7.8 Percent; 114,000 Jobs Added to Payrolls: A Closer Look at the September Labor Report

The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) reported a decline in the nation's unemployment rate to 7.8 percent in September, despite a relatively weak job growth of 114,000 jobs added to private and public payrolls. The decrease in the jobless rate, which is the first time it has been below 8 percent since President Obama took office in January 2009, is partly attributed to an increase in the number of Americans who found part-time jobs.

The BLS report, which is based on a household survey, showed an estimated 873,000 more people reported being "employed" in September compared to August, the biggest one-month jump since June 1983. Conversely, the figure on payroll employment, based on a survey of public and private employers, showed a gain of 114,000 jobs. The discrepancy between the two figures can be explained by a 582,000 increase in the number of people who took part-time work "for economic reasons" last month.

The unemployment rate, which is based on a survey of households, is an estimate of the labor force's unemployment status. The figure on payroll employment, on the other hand, is based on a survey of employers and provides a count of the number of jobs in the economy. The sampling error on the business establishment survey is plus or minus 100,000 jobs, while the sampling error on the household survey is plus or minus 280,000 jobs.

The BLS report also showed that there were 456,000 fewer people counted as being among the unemployed last month. Additionally, the economy created 86,000 more jobs in July and August than initially estimated, with employers adding 146,000 jobs per month from July through September, up from 67,000 in the previous three months.

The report is sure to be a hot topic on the campaign trail, with President Obama and Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney offering their respective takes on the economy. President Obama said the report is a "reminder that this country has come too far to turn back now," while Romney described the report as "not what a real recovery looks like."

The broader unemployment rate, which includes "marginally attached workers" and people who are employed part-time for economic reasons, remained unchanged last month at 14.7 percent. The choice in this election, according to Romney, is clear: "Under President Obama, we'll get another four years like the last four years. If I'm elected, we will have a real recovery with pro-growth policies that will create 12 million new jobs and rising incomes for everyone."

Title: Jeb Bush's Presidential Campaign: Awaiting Primary Vote, Facing Challenges, and Gaining Support

Article:

In the political landscape of the United States, Jeb Bush's presidential campaign is gearing up, with the first primary votes still approximately 10 months away. Bush's team is taking a measured approach, allowing time for adjustments and candidate development, as the Republican party shows no signs of coalescing behind another candidate.

Scott Reed, the top political adviser to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, commented, "Raising money is an important part of the game. But it's not the whole game."

Kristy Campbell, a spokeswoman for Mr. Bush, stated in an email, "As Governor Bush considers the possibility of a run, he's working hard to earn the support of people throughout the party and deliver a positive message about how conservative reforms can restore opportunity and prosperity for more Americans."

In January, Bush's allies began using the phrase "shock and awe" to describe his strategy of securing as many of the party's major donors and policy experts as possible. The aim was to establish Bush as the sole credible contender for the Republican establishment's blessing. Bush successfully deterred Mitt Romney, the 2012 nominee, from mounting another campaign. However, his organization will not disclose its finances until July.

Despite positioning himself as the Republicans' best hope in the general election, recent polls show Bush performing no better against Hillary Rodham Clinton than Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin or Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky. He also lags behind Mr. Walker in Iowa, a state known for rejecting candidates perceived as the party's inevitable nominees.

Colleen Platt, a City Council member in University Park, Iowa, questioned, "If he's going to run for the presidency because his father and his brother were president, is that why we should support him?"

There is also lingering suspicion of Mr. Bush among the Tea Party grassroots, a sentiment that emerged during his focus on business and philanthropic interests. As the race unfolds, Bush's campaign will need to address these concerns and solidify his position within the Republican party.

Title: Biden Denies Inappropriate Conduct Allegations, Promises to Listen and Learn

Article:

In the wake of Nevada Lieutenant Governor candidate Lucy Flores' accusation that former Vice President Joe Biden inappropriately kissed her during a 2014 campaign event, Biden has issued a statement denying any wrongdoing but expressing a commitment to listen and learn from any allegations of misconduct.

Flores, a former Nevada state representative, alleged in an article published on Friday that Biden "planted a big slow kiss on the back of my head." In response, a Biden spokesperson denied that the vice president or his staff were aware of Flores' discomfort.

Biden, in his statement on Sunday, said, "In my many years on the campaign trail and in public life, I have offered countless handshakes, hugs, expressions of affection, support, and comfort. And not once -- never -- did I believe I acted inappropriately."

He continued, "If it is suggested I did so, I will listen respectfully. But it was never my intention."

Flores, in an interview with CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday, expressed her satisfaction with Biden's statement, stating, "I'm glad that he's willing to listen... If he is saying he never believed that was inappropriate, then frankly I believe that's a little bit of a disconnection... I want him to change his behavior and I want him to acknowledge that it was wrong."

The allegations have led to a flood of pictures showing Biden with various women at campaign events and other administration functions surfacing on social media. Vox.com published a piece on Friday titled, "Lucy Flores isn’t alone. Joe Biden’s got a long history of touching women inappropriately," which catalogued several alleged episodes of misconduct by the former vice president.

White House adviser Kellyanne Conway, speaking to "Fox News Sunday," defended Biden, stating, "This woman Lucy is very bold to come forward, and I would remind the audience that she shares Joe Biden's political party... If anybody just types in 'Creepy Uncle Joe Videos,' you come up with a treasure trove of far more evidentiary information and videos than we saw when Brett Kavanaugh's nomination was trying to be derailed..."

Meanwhile, several other Democratic 2020 presidential hopefuls, including Bernie Sanders, Kamala Harris, and Kirsten Gillibrand, are also facing accusations of mismanaging sexual-misconduct claims against their subordinates. As the three prominent senators each have sought to draw a sharp contrast with President Trump, who has faced his own misconduct allegations, the claims have highlighted vulnerabilities that could become major liabilities not only in a heated Democrat Party primary, but also in the general election.

Title: The Importance of Understanding the U.S. Constitution: A Call to Familiarize Ourselves with the Foundational Document

Article:

As Americans, we celebrate our Declaration of Independence on July 4th with grandeur and pomp. However, the significance of September 17, Constitution Day, often goes unnoticed. This day marks the adoption of the U.S. Constitution, a document that has played a pivotal role in shaping our republic and preserving our independence.

The Constitution, unlike the Declaration of Independence, lacks the flair and pageantry of our national birthday. Yet, without this landmark document, it is unlikely we would still be celebrating the declaration in the 21st century. Understanding the Constitution is crucial to making sense of our history, government decisions, and the rulings of the U.S. Supreme Court.

The Constitution outlines the structure of our government, the powers of its branches, and the rights of its citizens. Without this understanding, it is impossible to form an informed opinion about the decisions reached by the courts or the actions of government agencies that affect our lives daily.

According to Thomas Ginsburg, Zachary Elkins, and James Melton, authors of “The Lifespan of Written Constitutions,” the average life span of a constitution since 1789 is only 17 years. The U.S. Constitution, however, has endured for over two centuries, a remarkable achievement given the numerous wars and periods of transformation and upheaval it has weathered.

To help understand the Constitution, resources like "The Heritage Guide to the Constitution" are available. This guide, first published in 2005 and now in a revised edition, provides expert analysis of every clause, relevant court cases, interpretations, and an overview of the Constitution's creation. It is used by law schools nationwide and is a valuable tool for any citizen who wants to understand the law of the land.

As former U.S. Attorney General Edwin Meese III writes in the guide, "The continued success and viability of our democratic Republic depends on our fidelity to, and the faithful exposition and interpretation of, this Constitution, our great charter of liberty."

So, the next time September 17 rolls around, consider taking a moment to familiarize yourself with the U.S. Constitution. It is not a daunting task, and understanding it can provide a deeper appreciation for the foundation of our democratic republic.

Title: White House Press Secretary Jay Carney Hints at Possible Delay of Obamacare Individual Mandate Due to Website Issues

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, White House press secretary Jay Carney has hinted at the possibility of a delay in the implementation of the individual mandate under the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, due to ongoing issues with the healthcare law's enrollment website.

During a press briefing on Monday, Carney did not directly confirm a delay but stated that if individuals were unable to enroll in Obamacare due to the glitchy website, they would not be penalized. This is the first official indication that the president may be considering a delay in the implementation of the individual mandate.

The individual mandate, a key provision of the Affordable Care Act, requires uninsured Americans to sign up for health insurance. If they do not, they could face a fine. Carney was asked if people would have to pay a fine if they were unable to enroll in Obamacare due to the website's issues.

The administration has been under pressure to delay the implementation of Obamacare, with Republicans pushing for a delay for months. The White House has consistently rejected these calls, insisting that the program would be ready to roll out on October 1. Those who sought a delay in return for fully reopening the government were criticized by the White House.

The White House's handling of the Obamacare rollout has been criticized, with the website experiencing numerous technical issues since its launch on October 1. The administration has struggled to fix these issues, with some experts suggesting that the code may need to be rewritten, a process that could take weeks or even months.

The White House has yet to provide details on how a delay would be implemented or who would be responsible for overseeing the process. It is unclear whether the administration will ask Congress for the delay or if they will impose it unilaterally.

The White House's handling of the Obamacare rollout has been widely criticized, with some calling it a "clusterfark." The administration has been unable to provide a clear timeline for when the website issues will be resolved, and there have been reports of individuals being unable to enroll in the program.

The White House has also been criticized for using "photo-ops" to showcase individuals who have successfully enrolled in Obamacare. However, it has been reported that some of these individuals are not actually enrolled in the program, or have not been able to find coverage through the exchanges.

It remains to be seen whether the administration will formally announce a delay in the implementation of the individual mandate, and if so, how it will be implemented. The White House has yet to provide a clear timeline for when the website issues will be resolved, and it is unclear who will be held accountable for the ongoing technical issues.

Title: Montana GOP House Candidate Greg Gianforte Charged with Misdemeanor Assault Ahead of Special Election

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Montana law enforcement officials have charged GOP House candidate Greg Gianforte with misdemeanor assault following an alleged physical altercation with a reporter Wednesday evening, just hours before voters head to the polls. The incident occurred at the candidate's campaign headquarters in Bozeman.

The Guardian reporter, Ben Jacobs, claims that Gianforte allegedly slammed him to the floor as he posed questions about the Republicans' ObamaCare repeal plan. However, Gianforte denies the allegations.

Gallatin County Sheriff Brian Gootkin issued a statement Wednesday night, stating that Gianforte had been cited for misdemeanor assault. The statement reads, "Following multiple interviews and an investigation by the Gallatin County Sheriff's Office, it was determined there was probable cause to issue a citation to Greg Gianforte for misdemeanor assault. The nature of the injuries did not meet the statutory elements of felony assault."

An audio recording of the incident, released by The Guardian, captures the initial exchange between Gianforte and Jacobs. In the recording, Gianforte initially brushes aside Jacobs' question about the new Congressional Budget Office score of the House GOP's American Health Care Act, which passed the House earlier in the month.

The altercation ensues after Jacobs persists with his questions. "We'll talk to you about that later," Gianforte says in the recording. "Yeah, but there's not going to be time," Jacobs responds.

Gianforte then asks Jacobs to contact the candidate's spokesman. Before Jacobs can respond, sounds of an altercation erupt. "I'm sick and tired of you guys," Gianforte screams. "The last guy who came in here you did the same thing. Get the hell out of here!" Jacobs later posted pictures of the broken glasses from the back of an ambulance.

Gianforte's office offered a different account, stating that Jacobs encroached on "a separate interview in a private office" and "aggressively shoved a recorder in Greg's face."

However, eyewitness accounts from several Fox News reporters contradict Gianforte's story. Fox reporter Alicia Acuna stated, "Gianforte grabbed Jacobs by the neck with both hands and slammed him into the ground behind him." Acuna and others "watched in disbelief as Gianforte then began punching the man, as he moved on top the reporter and began yelling something to the effect of 'I'm sick and tired of this!'"

Democrats have seized on the news, calling on Gianforte to quit the race and for Republicans to condemn his conduct. "Greg Gianforte must immediately withdraw his candidacy after his alleged violent assault of an innocent journalist," said Tyler Law, spokesman for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. The group also launched an 11th-hour Facebook ad campaign highlighting the episode in hopes of swaying voters heading to the polls Thursday.

Thursday's special election pits Gianforte against Democrat Rob Quist in a contest to replace former GOP Rep. Ryan Zinke, who is now heading President Trump's Interior Department. Gianforte is seen as a slight favorite in the race.

Gianforte is expected to appear in court before June 7. He faces a maximum sentence of six months in jail, a $500 fine, or both. Sheriff Gootkin, a Gianforte supporter, acknowledged his donation to the Republican candidate in his statement. However, he added, "this contribution has nothing to do with our investigation which is now complete."

Title: Trump Disputes Wall Street Journal's Account of Interview on Kim Jong Un Relationship

Article:

In a series of tweets on Sunday, U.S. President Donald Trump contested the Wall Street Journal's account of an interview with him last week, in which he was quoted as saying he probably had a "very good relationship" with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. The President argued that he used a conditional tense, stating "I'd probably" have a good relationship, which he considered a "big difference."

The White House released a portion of the audio from the interview, which it claimed showed Trump saying "I'd." The Wall Street Journal, in turn, released its own audio that it said supported its version of the events.

The President's comment about a potential relationship with Kim Jong Un is significant, as any suggestion of direct contact between the two leaders, who have exchanged threats and insults, would indicate a significant shift in the U.S.-led pressure campaign against Pyongyang over its nuclear and missile programs.

Trump has previously referred to Kim as a "maniac" and "little rocket man," while Kim has called Trump a "mentally deranged U.S. dotard." Fears of war have somewhat abated after the first round of intra-Korean talks in over two years last week, ahead of February's Winter Olympics hosted by South Korea. North Korea has announced its participation in the Games.

On Sunday, when asked about resolving the North Korea standoff, Trump said, "We'll see what happens." He mentioned upcoming meetings, possibly referring to further talks planned between North and South Korea. "Hopefully it's all going to work out," Trump added. "We have great talks going on, the Olympics you know about, a lot of things can happen."

In the Wall Street Journal interview, Trump was asked whether he had spoken with the North Korean leader. "I don't want to comment on it. I'm not saying I have or haven't. I just don't want to comment," he had said.

Trump, currently at his oceanfront Mar-a-Lago club in Palm Beach, Florida, tweeted on Sunday, "Obviously I didn't say that. I said 'I'd have a good relationship with Kim Jong Un,' a big difference. Fortunately, we now record conversations with reporters... and they knew exactly what I said and meant. They just wanted a story. FAKE NEWS!"

A White House official stated that the delay in publicly disputing the Journal's account was due to a failed attempt to get the paper to correct the record. "The reason there was a delay is because we had several calls and emails with WSJ, starting Friday morning, asking them to issue a correction. They refused, and so we pushed out our own clarification," the official said.

Title: GOP Candidates Embrace Hardline Immigration Stance in TV Ads, While Democrats Focus on Healthcare in 2018 Midterms

Article:

WASHINGTON – House Republican candidates are airing a significant number of TV ads emphasizing a hardline stance on immigration, according to a Kantar Media analysis of data from the Campaign Media Analysis Group (CMAG). This shift in messaging is a stark contrast to the midterm elections in 2014.

Republicans have aired over 14,000 campaign ads this year promoting a Trump-style immigration platform. This barrage of ads highlights the concerns of House GOP leaders about the potential risks for GOP candidates in the fall election if a legislative fix for DREAMers, undocumented immigrants brought to the country as children, is passed.

Democrats, on the other hand, are focusing on ads that promise to protect Obamacare, shore up Social Security, and expand Medicare. One such ad by California Democrat Paul Kerr recounts his family's financial devastation due to medical bills after his mother was diagnosed with Lou Gehrig's disease.

The competing messages illustrate the significant ideological divide between the two parties. They are not just discussing issues differently; they are promoting different issues to mobilize activists and win hotly contested primaries.

Kyle Kondik, a political analyst with the University of Virginia's Center for Politics, noted, "It sometimes feels like the two parties are talking to two different countries."

In many ways, they are, especially in primaries, Kondik said. Republicans appeal to a whiter, older, more rural electorate, while Democrats court a more diverse, younger, urban constituency.

The GOP's focus on immigration is particularly notable, given that it was not among the top 10 issues Republicans spent their ad dollars on at this point in the 2014 midterms. In that cycle, GOP contenders attacked President Obama, bashing the Affordable Care Act and promising to rein in government spending.

Now, immigration ranks second only to pro-Trump spots in GOP campaigns across the country. Brian Murray, a GOP consultant based in Arizona, attributes this shift to Trump's impact during his 2016 presidential campaign.

In Washington, House GOP leaders are grappling with the immigration issue, which is causing division within the party and potentially jeopardizing House Speaker Paul Ryan's grip on power. Moderate Republicans are pushing for legislation that would grant legal status to DREAMers, while conservatives are demanding legislation to slash legal immigration and authorize construction of Trump's proposed border wall.

Some strategists warn that the GOP's full-throated embrace of Trump's anti-immigration positions in primaries could harm them in the fall. A Pew Research Center poll in January showed that 74% of Americans support granting permanent legal status to DREAMers, and 60% oppose expanding the wall along the U.S.-Mexico border.

Meanwhile, Democratic candidates have focused overwhelmingly on health in their advertising, running more than 26,000 ads on the subject. Of those, over 8,500 Democratic spots promise to protect or expand Medicare.

The ideological divide between the parties is also evident in the primary races. In Montana's only House seat, for instance, Democrat Grant Kier promises in a TV spot to fight Trump on climate change, oppose his health care plan, and protect women's health care choices. However, this could potentially harm Democrats in the general election, according to the Congressional Leadership Fund, a super PAC affiliated with House Republicans.

In conclusion, the 2018 midterms are shaping up to be a battle of contrasting ideologies, with Republicans focusing on immigration and Democrats emphasizing healthcare. The grass-roots wings of both parties are demonstrating a significant divergence in the issues that are motivating them.

Title: Trump Legal Team Files Lawsuit to Block Congressional Subpoena of Financial Records from Mazars USA

Article:

In a move to challenge a congressional subpoena, attorneys for President Donald Trump and the Trump Organization have filed a lawsuit against House Oversight Committee Chairman Elijah Cummings on Monday. The lawsuit, filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, aims to block Mazars USA, a longtime accounting firm for the company, from complying with the subpoena issued by Cummings.

The lawsuit, which also names Peter Kenny, chief investigative counsel for the oversight committee, as a defendant, alleges that Cummings has overstepped constitutional limits on Congress' power to investigate and that the subpoena lacks a "legitimate legislative purpose." The lawsuit further argues that the subpoena threatens to expose "confidential information" and seeks to declare the subpoena "invalid and unenforceable."

Jay Sekulow, one of the president's attorneys, stated, "We will not allow congressional presidential harassment to go unanswered." The lawsuit claims that House Democrats are using their newfound majority to investigate "every aspect" of President Trump's personal finances, businesses, and his family, and are "singularly obsessed" with finding politically damaging information on the president.

The White House has been accused of "unprecedented stonewalling on all fronts" by Mr. Cummings, who has not produced a single document or witness to the oversight committee this year. In response, Mr. Cummings stated, "The president has a long history of trying to use baseless lawsuits to attack his adversaries, but there is simply no valid legal basis to interfere with this duly authorized subpoena from Congress."

The subpoena demands financial statements and supporting documents from Mazars for President Trump, the Trump Organization, and other entities, covering documents from 2011 to 2018. The subpoena was issued to corroborate testimony from Michael Cohen, President Trump's longtime former lawyer and fixer, about the president's financial information.

Cohen, who testified to the committee in February, has pleaded guilty to lying to Congress, among other crimes. In a memo to committee members announcing his intention to issue the subpoena, Mr. Cummings said financial statements Cohen provided to the committee in 2011, 2012, and 2013 raise "serious questions" about President Trump's representations of his financial condition.

In a separate battle between Mr. Trump and congressional Democrats, Ways and Means Committee Chairman Richard Neal has given the IRS a new April 23 deadline to turn over six years' worth of President Trump's personal tax returns, as well as returns for some associated organizations, like one of his golf courses. The lawsuit filed by the Trump legal team is the latest signal from Mr. Trump's legal team that they plan to push back strongly against what one of his attorneys called "presidential harassment" from a newly empowered Democratic majority in the House.

Title: Impact and Implications of U.S. Tariffs on Chinese Imports: A Focus on Technology and Intellectual Property

The ongoing trade tensions between the United States and China are set to escalate, with the potential impact of the proposed tariffs on Chinese goods being significantly larger and more concentrated than the steel and aluminum measures. According to Joseph Parilla of the Brookings Institution, the steel and aluminum tariffs would affect approximately $33 billion in imports, excluding Canada and Mexico, which are expected to be exempt from the measures. In contrast, the China tariffs could affect at least $50 billion in annual imports.

Chinese companies have been actively investing in American businesses, with annual Chinese acquisition deals totaling tens of billions of dollars, according to Rhodium Group. These investments have spanned various sectors, including non-strategic assets like movie theaters and the Waldorf Astoria hotel in New York, as well as cutting-edge areas such as semiconductors and start-ups related to autonomous driving. China's strategic acquisitions are aimed at upgrading its technological capabilities and countering the perceived American stranglehold on fundamental technologies, which it views as a long-term economic and security threat.

Unlike the metal tariffs, which have caused divisions within the Trump administration and opposition from many Republican lawmakers and businesspeople, the technology-focused moves against China are likely to find political support on Capitol Hill and in certain industries. Daniel DiMicco, a steel executive and trade adviser to the Trump campaign, stated, "Their theft costs us over $350 billion per year, so the bigger the better." This refers to the forced transfer of intellectual property and other unfair practices alleged by the administration.

The business community, which once defended trade with China despite accusations of intellectual property theft, has grown increasingly dissatisfied with the adverse treatment in the Chinese economy. With the Chinese government and state-owned enterprises playing an ever-larger role in the market, the environment for American companies has deteriorated.

However, American business groups have expressed concern over the possibility that U.S. tariffs could prompt other countries to raise their own trade barriers. As the trade tensions between the U.S. and China continue to escalate, it remains to be seen how these developments will shape the global economic landscape.

Title: Obama's Austin Visit: A Political Move Amidst Economic Agenda Amidst Stalled Congressional Action

Article:

In a move aimed at reiterating his economic agenda, President Barack Obama visited Austin, Texas, this week, a trip that Republican officials have criticized as a campaign-style stunt with little potential to boost the economy or create jobs. The Republican National Committee released a statement titled "Obama's Jobs Strategy: Pivot Back to the Economy Every So Often."

In his State of the Union address this year, President Obama outlined an economic plan that included a renewed focus on manufacturing, increased funding for early childhood education, a rise in the minimum wage, and greater investment in infrastructure. While some Republicans have shown support for parts of this agenda, there is little evidence that the majority of it will be passed in the current Congress, which has become increasingly gridlocked on fiscal matters.

However, aides to the president argue that events such as the ones in Austin, though possibly futile in their immediate impact, are essential to maintain pressure on Republicans and demonstrate to Americans that President Obama remains committed to his economic agenda. The risk for President Obama is that such events may appear as costly excursions with minimal economic improvement. Aides, however, counter that the president would likely face criticism if he announced an agenda in the State of the Union address and did not actively pursue it.

The president's political advisers recall the lessons learned during his first two years in office, when he largely remained in Washington, focusing on shepherding his health care legislation through Congress. His approval ratings and mood plummeted, leading aides to believe that frequent travel is important.

In Austin, President Obama was scheduled to meet with local residents and technology entrepreneurs, officials said. He was also set to tour a facility of Applied Materials, a Silicon Valley-based company that manufactures the complex equipment needed to produce silicon chips for computers, phones, and other high-tech devices.

Title: Deadly Riot in Altamira Prison Leaves 57 Inmates Dead, 16 Decapitated

RIO DE JANEIRO (AP) — At least 57 prisoners were killed by other inmates during clashes between organized crime groups in the Altamira prison in northern Brazil Monday, with 16 of the victims being decapitated, according to prison officials.

The riot, which erupted around 7 a.m., took place between the Rio de Janeiro-based Comando Vermelho and a local criminal group known as Comando Classe A. A fight initiated by the Comando Classe A, who set fire to a cell belonging to one of the prison's pavilions, housing members of the Comando Vermelho.

The fire, which spread rapidly due to the prison's old container units, prevented police forces from entering the building for several hours. Two prison staff members were held hostage but were eventually released.

State prisons chief Jarbas Vasconcelos described the incident as a targeted attack, stating, "It was a settling of accounts between the two groups, not a protest or rebellion against the prison system."

Authorities have not found any firearms following the riot, only makeshift knives. Prison authorities said 46 inmates will be transferred to other prisons, with 10 of them going to stricter federal facilities.

President Jair Bolsonaro, who was elected on the promise of curbing widespread violence in Brazil, including in the country's often overcrowded, out-of-control prisons, has yet to comment on the incident.

The Altamira prison, located in the city of the same name, had 343 detainees for a maximum capacity of 163, according to a July 2019 report from the National Justice Council. State prisons chief Jarbas Vasconcelos stated that the situation did not meet the official requirements to be considered overcrowded.

The judge who filed the report described the overall state of the prison as "terrible." In many of Brazil's prisons, badly outnumbered guards struggle to retain power over an ever-growing population of inmates who are able to run criminal activities from behind bars.

The killings echoed those of 55 inmates who died in a series of riots in May in several prisons in the neighboring state of Amazonas. In early 2017, more than 120 inmates died in prisons across several northern states when rival gangs clashed over control of drug-trafficking routes in the region.

Para state authorities spent the afternoon in Altamira, drafting a security plan to avoid possible retaliations in the region. Police forces from the nearby municipality of Santerem were sent as reinforcement in the coming weeks. Prison authorities said they had not received any prior intelligence reports of an upcoming attack.

The prison is run directly by the state, not a third-party private operator as in the Manaus prisons where the riots took place in May. Last year, inmates had already set fire to another wing inside the same prison unit, according to the state prosecutors' office.

Title: Former Vice President Al Gore Expresses Optimism on Climate Change Debate, Citing Shift in Republican Stance

In an interview with The Washington Post, former Vice President Al Gore expressed optimism about the future of the climate change debate, suggesting that Republicans are growing weary of global warming deniers. Gore, who is a prominent climate change activist, compared the current climate change debate to historical movements such as the civil rights movement, the anti-apartheid movement, the nuclear arms race, and the abolition movement.

Gore argued that activists are in the process of "winning the conversation" on climate change, just as activists won these historical movements. He pointed to the debate over smoking, stating that people once thought Senator Frank Lautenburg of New Jersey was "crazy" for pushing legislation that would ban smoking in airplanes, but the political landscape eventually shifted in favor of such legislation.

Gore also highlighted the efforts of Organizing for Action, the political group formed from President Barack Obama's re-election campaign, which earlier this month delivered unicorn statues to Republican deniers in Congress as part of a larger push to "hold members of Congress accountable for their positions on climate change."

Gore credited President Obama for his aggressive new climate change strategy, which includes limiting pollution from existing coal-fired power plants and issuing directives requiring the EPA to establish carbon pollution standards for plants that are already active. Gore expressed being "very encouraged" by these policy moves.

However, Gore acknowledged that the process of "winning the conversation" on climate change has been stalled in the past due to the resistance of a small group of denialists who fly into a rage when the topic is mentioned. He likened this resistance to a family with an alcoholic father who becomes enraged when certain subjects are discussed, leading others to avoid the topic to maintain peace. Gore argued, however, that the ability of these denialists to halt progress is waning every day.

Title: US Urges Iran to Reroute Aid Ship to Djibouti, Citing UN Humanitarian Hub

Article:

Washington has called on an Iranian ship, reportedly carrying humanitarian aid to Yemen, to alter its course and head to Djibouti, where the United Nations is overseeing humanitarian deliveries, according to US officials on Tuesday. The US military is tracking the ship, the Iran Shahed, after Tehran announced plans to send warships to escort the vessel to Yemen.

Pentagon spokesman Colonel Steven Warren told reporters that the ship, currently in the Gulf of Oman, was not under naval escort at the moment. "We are monitoring the Iranian ship," he said. "We are aware of the Iranians' statement that they plan to escort this ship with warships."

The Iranian state news agency IRNA earlier quoted a naval commander, Rear Admiral Hossein Azad, saying naval forces would be "safeguarding" the vessel. Iran's Red Crescent had announced last week that it would send a ship carrying 2,500 tons of humanitarian aid to Yemen, where Iran-backed Huthi rebels are fighting pro-government forces supported by a Saudi-led coalition.

When asked if the US military would attempt to search the ship or prevent it from docking in Yemen, Warren declined to comment. "If the Iranians are planning some sort of stunt in the region, they know as well as we do that it would be unhelpful and in fact could potentially threaten the ceasefire (in Yemen) that has been so painstakingly brought about," Warren said.

The US Navy has bolstered its presence in the Gulf following Iran's seizure of a Marshall Islands-flagged vessel in the Strait of Hormuz. Iranian authorities later released the ship, citing a commercial dispute with Denmark's Maersk group, which chartered the vessel.

The US officials urged Iran to deliver the humanitarian aid to the United Nations humanitarian aid distribution hub in Djibouti, stating that this would allow the aid to be rapidly and efficiently distributed to those in Yemen who require it.

Title: Elizabeth Warren Advocates for Criminal Indictment of Sitting Presidents, Citing Obstruction of Justice

In a statement released on Friday, Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren called for Congress to pass a law that clarifies the Justice Department's ability to indict a sitting president for criminal activity, including obstruction of justice.

Warren's call comes in response to Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report on his investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election and Mueller's statement this week that Justice Department policy prevented him from bringing charges against a sitting president.

Mueller's report concluded that Russia repeatedly interfered in the 2016 election and that Trump's election campaign had multiple contacts with Russian officials, but did not establish a criminal conspiracy with Moscow to win the White House. The report declined to make a judgment on whether Trump obstructed justice, although it outlined 10 instances in which Trump tried to have Mueller fired or otherwise impede the investigation.

"When the federal government tried to investigate, Donald Trump did everything he could to delay, distract, and otherwise obstruct that investigation," Warren's statement said. "That's a crime. If Donald Trump were anyone other than the president of the United States, he would be in handcuffs and indicted."

Warren urged Congress to pass a law making it clear that presidents can be indicted for criminal activity, including obstruction of justice. She also suggested amending statutes relating to such obstruction to allow for indictment when a president abuses the powers of office.

Warren criticized Trump's Attorney General, William Barr, saying he had "acted like Trump's personal defense attorney." She promised that if she is elected, she would ensure her appointees reverse a Justice Department opinion that argues a sitting president cannot be indicted.

"Donald Trump is not a king. No president is. And our democracy only works if everyone can be held accountable," Warren said.

Title: Court Ruling Reveals NSA Metadata Querying Violations, Sparking Debate on Oversight Effectiveness

Article:

In a significant turn of events, a recent court ruling has revealed that the National Security Agency (NSA) had been routinely violating the standards for querying metadata, according to Judge Bates' recounting. The ruling, which was obtained by the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF), a free speech and privacy rights group, following a lawsuit, concluded that the requirement for oversight of the NSA's metadata collection had not functioned effectively due to these violations.

Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat who sits on the Senate Intelligence Committee, had fought last summer to declassify the basic fact that the surveillance court had ruled against the NSA. In a statement, Mr. Wyden, an outspoken critic of NSA surveillance, described the declassification of the ruling as "long overdue." He argued that while the NSA had increased privacy protections for purely domestic and unrelated communications that were swept up in the surveillance, the collection itself "was a serious violation of the Fourth Amendment."

Mark Rumold of the Electronic Frontier Foundation praised the administration for releasing the document with relatively few redactions, although he criticized the time and the difficulty in obtaining it. However, he also said the ruling showed the surveillance court was not equipped to perform adequate oversight of the NSA. "This opinion illustrates that the way the court is structured now it can not serve as an effective check on the NSA because it’s wholly dependent on the representations that the NSA makes to it," Mr. Rumold said. "It has no ability to investigate. And it’s clear that the NSA’s representations have not been entirely candid to the court."

A senior intelligence official, speaking to reporters in a conference call, portrayed the ruling as showing that NSA oversight was robust and serious. He said that some 300 NSA employees were assigned to seek out even inadvertent violations of the rules and that the court conducted "vigorous" oversight.

The ruling focused on a program under which the NSA has been searching domestic Internet links for communications—where at least one side is overseas—in which there are "strong selectors" indicating insider knowledge of someone who has been targeted for foreign-intelligence collection. One example would be mentioning a person's private email address in the body of an email. The revelation of these violations has sparked a debate on the effectiveness of the NSA's oversight mechanisms, with critics arguing for more robust and independent oversight.

Title: GOP Leaders and Conservatives Skeptical of Immigration Bill Progress in 2014

Article:

In a recent development, conservative Republicans have expressed doubts about the possibility of an immigration bill being passed this year, citing a lack of trust in President Obama's administration to enforce strict security measures.

At a Heritage Foundation event, Republican House members voiced their reservations, stating that while they acknowledge the House GOP leaders' principles as a starting point for discussion, it is premature to attempt to pass a bill at this time.

Rep. Raul Labrador, an Idaho Republican who was part of a group working on a comprehensive immigration bill last year but dropped out, stated that President Obama should spend this year demonstrating his commitment to security measures before Republicans consider action in 2015, should they regain control of the Senate.

"We need to have the trust with this administration, and that trust is not there," Mr. Labrador said. "Until we have that trust, there will be no immigration reform, and it would be a mistake for leadership to push that."

House Speaker John A. Boehner released principles last week that called for increased security but also for illegal immigrants to be granted legal status, with a specific pathway to citizenship for young adult illegal immigrants. However, Mr. Boehner himself stated on Tuesday that Republicans have yet to decide whether to move forward with a bill this year.

Rep. Joe Barton, a Texas Republican, noted that while it is not the right time to advance a broad bill, the principles themselves are beneficial for "beginning a dialogue with the Hispanic community on conservative principles."

The Senate passed a comprehensive bill in June, which includes citizenship rights for most illegal immigrants, with a bipartisan 68-32 vote. However, even this legislation has faced challenges.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican who voted against the Senate bill, stated on Tuesday that he does not see a way to align the Senate bill with the House's current discussions.

"I don't see how you get to an outcome this year with the two bodies in such a different place," he said.

Democrats had hoped the release of the principles would facilitate an agreement this year, but the two sides remain far apart on significant issues. House Republicans have insisted on addressing immigration in a series of bills, while the Senate passed a single, comprehensive measure.

Another contentious issue is citizenship. The Senate bill offers a new specific pathway for most illegal immigrants to become citizens in about 13 years, while the House Republicans' principles call for illegal immigrants to receive some form of legal status, but only specify a path to citizenship for young illegal immigrants, often referred to as the "Dreamers," who are considered the most sympathetic cases.

Title: Trump's Debut: A Shift from Political Outsider to Mainstream Candidate

Article:

In the first Republican presidential debate of the 2016 election cycle, Donald Trump, the self-proclaimed political outsider, found himself not only a part of the official GOP field but the central focus of the debate. However, as the two-hour event unfolded, Trump's dominance began to wane, and he was no longer the sole star of the show.

Entering the debate as the frontrunner, Trump was expected to dominate the stage. Yet, as the debate progressed, he was drawn into the fray, engaging in debates with other candidates and responding to questions from the moderators. This marked a shift from his usual controlled appearances, friendly rallies, and one-candidate news conferences, where he excels at dominating.

One of the most notable moments of the debate came when Megyn Kelly asked Trump about his myriad insults to various women. In response, Trump made a rather petulant reference to Kelly herself not being "very nice" to him. The evening began with a challenge to Trump from Fox newsman Bret Baier, who wanted to know if anyone onstage was unwilling to commit to supporting the eventual Republican nominee in 2016. Trump immediately raised his right hand, causing both boos and a few cheers from the live crowd.

Trump's response that he could not pledge to support the nominee "if it's not me," adding that it would have to be someone he respected, may resonate with many Republicans in the days to come. This statement, while in line with his many statements of independence in the past, had a different ring to it on this stage on this night.

The sharpest exchange of the night did not even involve Trump. It stemmed from Sen. Rand Paul's making a brief speech about his opposition to phone records being gathered by the National Security Agency. When he said he wanted to collect records of terrorists, not citizens, New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie interrupted to ask how Paul would tell one number from another.

Other candidates found ways to hold the camera when they could. Ohio Gov. John Kasich, the 16th candidate to enter the race, benefited from a friendly local crowd and a compact message about balancing budgets and creating jobs. Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, who has been running third in national polls, talked about winning three times in a blue state and about hardening his stance on immigration after talking to "the American people."

Sen. Ted Cruz talked about religious liberty and his father's conversion to Christianity, prompting Walker to talk about his Baptist faith as well. The only actual ordained minister onstage, former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee, also stressed his moral convictions in talking about the Planned Parenthood controversy.

Neurosurgeon Ben Carson had a neat formulation for his closing statement, suggesting his status as a physician would be appropriate for national leadership. It was a charming summation with a neat barb in it, but it was perhaps the only time he broke through all evening.

Sen. Marco Rubio, the youngest candidate in the field, made his usual points about understanding and representing the future. If it's about experience, he said, Hillary Clinton will be the next president. Contrast would be the key, he said, his expression the embodiment of "fresh face."

Earlier Thursday, seven additional candidates who did not make the cut for the evening debate met in a slightly less confrontational format, also in Cleveland, also on Fox. Here the apparent standout was businesswoman Carly Fiorina, who would have been the visual highlight in any event as the only participant in fuchsia.

Fiorina was controlled, crisp, and gimlet-eyed. And while she did not have a chance onstage with Trump, her question for him was perhaps the best of either session. "Since he has changed his mind on amnesty, on health care, and on abortion," Fiorina said, "I would just ask, what are the principles by which he will govern?"

As the 2016 election cycle progresses, it remains to be seen if Trump can continue to make up the rules as he goes along. The sharp exchange between Rand Paul and Chris Christie, the controlled performance of Carly Fiorina, and the clear message of John Kasich indicate that the other candidates are not afraid to challenge Trump and make their own mark in the race.

Title: Senator Rand Paul Secures Assurance from Attorney General Holder: No Use of Drones to Kill Noncombatant Americans on U.S. Soil

Article:

In a significant development, Senator Rand Paul declared victory on Thursday after Attorney General Eric Holder assured him that the president does not have the authority to use a drone to kill a noncombatant American on U.S. soil, an assurance Paul had sought during his 13-hour filibuster the day before.

During the filibuster, which delayed a vote on CIA director nominee John Brennan, Paul had demanded the administration clarify the government's authority to kill on U.S. soil. The filibuster ended past midnight early Thursday morning, and the Senate voted, 63-34, to confirm Brennan later Thursday afternoon.

Shortly before the vote, Holder sent a terse letter to Paul that read: "It has come to my attention that you have now asked an additional question: 'Does the President have the authority to use a weaponized drone to kill an American not engaged in combat on American soil?' The answer to that question is no."

In response, Paul said Thursday that "we're proud to announce that the president is not going to kill unarmed Americans on American soil." He later took to the floor to promote the attorney general's response, as the Senate moved to confirm Brennan.

Though Paul's 13-hour stand drew praise from all sides of the political spectrum, the senator also took heat Thursday from some in his own party who claimed he stirred unnecessary fear about the use of drones.

Senator John McCain, R-Ariz., said, "The senator should know better," arguing that some of the concerns raised about drone missile attacks on Americans, like Paul's suggestion that the U.S. could have killed Jane Fonda when she went to North Vietnam, were "ridiculous."

Senator Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., displayed a sign that showed the number of Americans killed in the U.S. by Al Qaeda—2,958—versus the number killed in the U.S. by drones, which is zero.

Paul, however, argued that he was raising concern about how future presidents might use their drone authority.

Paul told Fox News the critical senators "think the whole world is a battlefield, including America."

"I do not think the laws of war apply to America. I think the Bill of Rights do," Paul said.

While the Obama administration increasingly employs armed drones as a pivotal counterterrorism tool overseas, domestic law enforcement agencies are also moving to broaden the use of surveillance mini-drones over the next several years. The Federal Aviation Administration projects as many as 10,000 licensed systems by 2017.

The lethal drones used in Pakistan are a far cry from the unarmed eyes in the sky used in America. But Paul and a host of other lawmakers see constitutional pitfalls across the board—namely focusing on how armed, and unarmed, drones might someday be used against American citizens.

Paul and the senators from both sides of the aisle who joined him on the floor Wednesday described a bleak future in which an unscrupulous government might use drones against its own population if left unchecked.

"Your notification is the buzz of propellers on the drone as it flies overhead in the seconds before you're killed. Is that what we really want from our government?" Paul asked.

Lawmakers have already started pushing legislation to rein in the drone program—legislation that might get a second look after Paul's dramatic performance Wednesday.

Rep. Zoe Lofgren, D-Calif., and Ted Poe, R-Texas, last month introduced a bill to regulate domestic drones much like the government regulates wiretaps. It would require officials to obtain a warrant in order to perform many kinds of surveillance with those drones. Further, it would prohibit law enforcement drones from being equipped with firearms or explosives in U.S. airspace.

"As we enter this uncharted world of drone technology, Congress must be proactive and establish boundaries for drone use that safeguard the constitutional rights of Americans," Poe said in a statement last month.

The use of armed drones in U.S. airspace fueled Paul's lengthy filibuster Wednesday. Before he took the floor, Paul announced that he had received a letter from Holder, which opened the door, in extremely rare circumstances, to using a drone to kill someone within U.S. territory. Holder said "catastrophic" attacks such as the Sept. 11 attacks or the attack on Pearl Harbor are examples of circumstances where the president could conceivably feel such an action is necessary.

Testifying on Capitol Hill on Wednesday, Holder agreed that it would be unconstitutional to use a drone on American soil against a U.S. citizen or a suspected terrorist who did not pose an imminent threat.

Paul, during his filibuster, said he wanted a formal assurance from the administration that it would not use drones to kill noncombatant Americans, which prompted the Holder letter on Thursday.

Title: Pollsters Face Challenges in Balancing Sampling and Bias as Presidential Election Nears

Article:

As the 2012 presidential election approaches, pollsters are grappling with the challenge of accurately representing the electorate while minimizing bias in their surveys. With President Obama and congressional Democrats surging in polls, Republicans are increasingly questioning the validity of the surveys, with some accusing pollsters of intentionally trying to demoralize GOP voters.

Pollsters argue that their sampling methods are designed to yield an accurate representation of voter demographics by party, gender, ethnicity, and other categories. However, this is easier said than done, especially when surveys usually sample fewer than 1,500 people. The question for pollsters then becomes whether to tweak the data to give added weight to responses from groups that often go underrepresented in polls, such as Republicans, young voters, and minorities, to come up with a sampling that better represents the electorate.

Charles Franklin, who runs the Marquette University Law School poll, which is tracking the presidential and U.S. Senate races in Wisconsin, adjusts weights for gender, age, and ethnic balance but not for political party. He argues that an increase in participation by a certain party can be an indicator that it is more energized than the other side.

Democrats historically hold a turnout edge in presidential elections, but their advantage often fluctuates. In 2008, 39 percent of presidential voters were Democrats compared with 32 percent who were Republicans, according to exit polling. The parties each represented 37 percent of the electorate in 2004, which was the Republicans' largest share in decades.

"Forcing there to be a certain percentage of your electorate denies that change," Mr. Franklin said. "There's a legitimate debate as to which way to go, and I don't think it is by any means a settled statistical question."

Scott Rasmussen, founder of Rasmussen Reports, which has President Obama with a 1-point lead over Mitt Romney, said, "We absolutely know that party affiliation is the best single indicator of how someone is going to vote."

Pollsters are also dealing with issues brought on by technology and changing demographics. Many polls continue to collect their data from calls to landlines rather than cellphones, which could increase responses from older voters who rely on their home phones and minimize participation among younger voters. Mr. Rasmussen predicts that polling might move entirely online in five to 10 years.

The different methods and varieties of approaches among the various pollsters mean poll watchers need to take individual surveys with a grain of salt. "Look across all of the polling," Mr. Franklin said. "Don't just try to believe that one poll is always right or that one is always the best. If you see all of the polls pointing in the same direction, that's certainly more reliable."

Title: Global Climate Strike: Youth Lead the Way in Demonstrations Across 139 Countries

Article:

Young people and adults from around the world participated in the global climate strike on Friday, marking what is expected to be the largest such demonstration to date, with 4,638 events scheduled in 139 countries. The demonstrations were organized by the Fridays for Future movement, inspired by 16-year-old Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg.

Thunberg, who testified at a Capitol Hill hearing on Wednesday, urged U.S. lawmakers to take "real action" in addressing climate change. The Fridays for Future website states, "With the worsening climate destruction, this goal of going to school begins to be pointless. Why study for a future, which may not be there?"

The youth participating in the climate strike demonstrations showed a flair for language, with pithy and pointed protest signs such as "We are skipping our lessons to teach you one" and "When leaders act like kids, kids act like leaders."
