Many also mixed humor with urgency, such as riffing off of Nelly's 2002 hit "Hot in Herre" with "It's getting hot in here, so take off all your coal."

Social media platforms like Twitter and Facebook were flooded with shots of climate strike crowds across the globe. Primary school pupils in Abuja, Nigeria, called for climate action, while activists in other countries demanded climate justice.

The demonstrations come as the Amazon rainforest continues to burn, with some activists using the hashtag #WrongAmazon to highlight the connection between deforestation and climate change.

The global climate strike is a testament to the growing movement of young people demanding action on climate change, and a call for world leaders to take the issue seriously and take real action to address it.

Title: Virginia Governor Ralph Northam Declares Juneteenth an Official State Holiday

In a significant move, Virginia Governor Ralph Northam announced on Tuesday that Juneteenth, a day commemorating the end of slavery in the United States, will be an official holiday in the state, which was once the capital of the Confederacy.

The holiday, also known as Emancipation Day and Freedom Day, is celebrated annually on June 19. Texas first made it a state holiday in 1980. The holiday will be a paid day off for all state employees, and Governor Northam believes Virginia will be only the second state to do so.

"It's time we elevate this," Northam said of the June 19 commemoration. "Not just a celebration by and for some Virginians but one acknowledged and celebrated by all of us."

Governor Northam is granting every executive branch employee this Friday as a paid holiday, and he will work with the legislature later this year to pass a law codifying Juneteenth as a permanent state holiday. The legislation is expected to pass the Democratic-controlled legislature with little trouble.

Juneteenth marks June 19, 1865, when news reached African Americans in Texas that President Abraham Lincoln had issued the Emancipation Proclamation, freeing slaves living in Confederate states two years earlier. When Union soldiers arrived in Galveston to bring the news that slavery had been abolished, former slaves celebrated.

The announcement comes less than two weeks after Northam announced he was ordering the removal of a statue of General Robert E. Lee along Richmond's prominent Monument Avenue. It is one of the country's most iconic monuments to the Confederacy. Earlier this year, Northam signed legislation scrapping Lee-Jackson Day, a state holiday named after two Confederate generals.

Nearly forced from office last year after a racist yearbook photo surfaced, Northam has won widespread praise among black lawmakers for his actions in Virginia following the death of George Floyd, a black man who died after a Minneapolis officer pressed his knee into Floyd's neck as he pleaded for air.

President Donald Trump announced last week that he has rescheduled a campaign rally that was planned in Tulsa, Oklahoma, on Juneteenth. The announcement of the rally had sparked an outcry because Tulsa was the site of one of the worst instances of racial violence in U.S. history in 1921, when hundreds of African Americans were massacred by a white mob that burned black-owned businesses and homes.

Governor Northam was joined Tuesday at his news conference by musician Pharrell Williams, who is from Virginia. Williams said Juneteenth deserves the same level of recognition and celebration as Independence Day.

"Here's our day, and if you love us, it'll be your day too," Williams said.

In a statement, state House Republican Leader Todd Gilbert echoed the same sentiments.

"July 4th is the birthday of our nation, but Juneteenth is the day where it truly began to fulfill its promise of freedom for all," Gilbert said. "For the first time since enslaved Africans landed at Jamestown in 1619, the chains of bondage were finally cast off."

Joseph Rogers, a 29-year-old activist who has been a regular protester in Richmond during more than two weeks of demonstrations over Floyd's killing, hailed Northam's announcement.

Title: Boehner Unveils Plan B as Fiscal Cliff Negotiations Stall

Article:

In a move that signals a potential impasse in ongoing fiscal cliff negotiations, House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) unveiled a new legislative strategy on Tuesday, aiming to pass a bill that would increase tax rates for income exceeding $1 million while extending rates for the rest of Americans.

During a closed-door meeting with fellow Republicans, Boehner presented the so-called "Plan B," a proposal that has already been dismissed by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) and the White House, who argue it still favors the wealthy. The House Democrats are unlikely to support Boehner in gathering the 218 votes necessary to pass the bill, as indicated by the No. 2 House Democrat, Maryland Rep. Steny Hoyer.

The vote, expected to take place this week, is intended to provide a safety net for House Republicans, should the nation plunge into the fiscal cliff and see income tax rates rise for all. If President Barack Obama continues to accuse Republicans of prioritizing the wealthy, the backup plan allows them to counter that it is not the case.

Despite recent progress in talks between Obama and Boehner, there is still a significant distance to cover. The success of the GOP fallback plan remains uncertain, with the potential to rekindle negotiations or further complicate the situation.

Boehner shared his Plan B with Obama during a phone call on Monday night, prompting Obama to inform Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) that negotiations with the White House had stalled. White House advisors Rob Nabors and Gene Sperling addressed both the Senate and House Democratic caucuses on Tuesday.

With taxes set to rise for everyone in 13 days, followed by tens of billions of dollars in Pentagon and federal agency spending cuts, Boehner's decision to put his bill on the floor underscores the current state of negotiations. As of Monday evening, the two sides appeared to be inching toward an agreement, with Boehner conceding on his earlier insistence that tax rates should not rise for the wealthy and offering the president $1 trillion in new revenue—a significant concession that was unimaginable a year ago.

Title: Debt and Deficit Issues Take a Back Seat in Democratic Presidential Debates

Article:

In the four-hour-long Democratic presidential debates, the words "deficit" and "debt" were scarcely mentioned, with the former only appearing once. This reluctance to address the ballooning annual budget deficits and overall debt, a long-standing issue in the United States, is a reflection of the campaign's focus on popular policies that could pose significant budget challenges.

Policies such as expanding Medicare health coverage, offering government assistance to reduce college costs, and alleviating student debt are among the Democrats' most popular proposals going into the 2020 election. While Democrats argue they have viable plans to cover the costs of these proposals, Republicans counter that their tax-the-rich solutions are unrealistic.

On the other side of the political divide, Republicans are equally hesitant to discuss the issue, having supported President Donald Trump's massive tax cuts and increased military spending, two key drivers of the deficit increase. By backing Trump, many Republican lawmakers have effectively abandoned their commitment to balanced budgets and reducing the national debt, a concern that Senator Rob Portman, a Republican and former White House budget director, lamented.

Economists worry that the rising debt will lead to higher interest costs, increasing the pressure on future governments to make deep spending cuts or even causing the United States to default on its debt payments, which could have catastrophic global consequences. Bill Hoagland, a senior vice president at the Bipartisan Policy Center, a Washington think tank focused on fiscal policy, likened the situation to termites undermining a porch: "You step on the porch and everything's fine... Then one day, you fall through."

When running for president, Trump claimed he would pay off the national debt in about eight years. However, since taking office in January 2017, the national debt has increased by $2.45 trillion. The total debt outstanding, accumulated over many years of deficits, is now $22.4 trillion, its highest level ever, equating to approximately $68,000 of debt for every American.

The deficit has risen from $666 billion in fiscal 2017, the final year of President Barack Obama's administration's impact on budgets, to an expected $900 billion this year, and is projected to exceed $1 trillion a year by 2022. The prospect of such high and rising debt poses substantial risks for the nation, according to the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office.

With the U.S. economy expanding, inflation and unemployment low, and the stock market near record levels, the government could be expected to take advantage of the strong fundamentals to reduce deficits. However, the opposite is happening. When asked about rising deficits last month, White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow downplayed concerns, stating, "It doesn't bother me right now."

During a campaign stop in Marshalltown, Iowa, former Vice President Joe Biden accused Republicans of running up the nation's debt as a pretext for seeking cuts to federal retirement and healthcare benefits later. "Folks, this is a sham," said Biden, who has led most polls in the early days of the Democratic primary race.

Marlene Rush, a Marshalltown community organizer, said Biden was "the first Democrat I've heard actually mention the deficits." Rush added, "I appreciate that. Deficits matter. For Republicans, it seems, they only care about the deficit when Democrats are in the White House."

The first set of Democratic primary debates on June 26-27 in Miami passed without any of the 20 candidates offering up ideas to control debt or deficits. When asked about paying for the expansion of public benefits if they win the White House, Senator Kamala Harris responded, "I hear that question, but where was that question when the Republicans and Donald Trump passed a tax bill that benefits the top 1 percent and the biggest corporations in this country?" Harris' response was met with silence from the other candidates on the stage.

Although Republicans portray Democrats as the party of big spending, the last time the budget was balanced was under Democratic President Bill Clinton in 1998 and for the next three years. This run ended under Republican George W. Bush, who slashed taxes and fought wars abroad while presiding over large domestic spending increases. Obama, another Democrat, ran deficits high at the start of his presidency to address a deep recession, then trimmed them in his final years in office as the economy picked up.

Now, neither party shows any interest in offering detailed policies to tackle the debt in the 2020 campaign, preferring to focus on healthcare, immigration, and climate change. Maya MacGuineas, head of the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, a nonpartisan group focused on budget reform, described this era as "an era of hyper-partisanship with both parties engaging in free lunchism to try to appeal to voters."

Last year, the House of Representatives and Senate formed a special bipartisan panel to examine ways to improve how budgets are written. However, it failed to make any recommendations, and its operating expenses added about $500,000 to the national debt.

Title: Oregon Governor John Kitzhaber's Resignation: A Tale of Hubris and a Greek Tragedy

Article:

In a dramatic turn of events, Oregon Governor John Kitzhaber, who has been in office for an unprecedented four terms, finds himself in the midst of a political scandal that has echoes of a Greek tragedy. The governor's decision to resign and subsequent change of mind, followed by a state investigation, has left Oregon political observers questioning the hubris that may have clouded his judgment.

Jake Weigler, an Oregon Democratic strategist, draws a parallel between Kitzhaber's current predicament and the failure of the state's healthcare exchange website under the Affordable Care Act. "It was audacious and big and bold—and it fell on its face," he noted, referring to the healthcare exchange.

Weigler further compares Kitzhaber's administration's approach to policy-making, suggesting that the governor's assertive and aggressive style, while effective in setting the conversation across the state, may have lacked the necessary caution.

The root of the scandal appears to be the governor's relationship with his fiancée, Cylvia Hayes, who has been linked to Kitzhaber since his 2002 campaign. Their relationship, which began in August, has been a source of scrutiny and headaches for the governor due to Hayes' private consulting work during his 2010 campaign and her subsequent advisory role in energy policy.

Recent developments have seen Hayes advising Kitzhaber and state employees on energy policy while being paid by a group advocating for specific policies. Additionally, she has not disclosed some of her income from the state, and the governor reportedly tried to erase his personal emails from public records, raising further questions about the situation.

These developments have led to a criminal investigation by the state Attorney General and an FBI investigation as well. Despite the scandal breaking last October, Kitzhaber managed to secure reelection. However, the situation reached a tipping point when it threatened to undermine the Oregon legislature's agenda.

Few lawmakers were willing to work with Kitzhaber going forward, and Democrats do not want to "tarnish an agenda" that had wide support in the legislature by keeping it pinned to a scandal-marred governor. State Sen. Elizabeth Steiner Hayward, who called the saga a "Greek tragedy," expressed concern that it would sink the governor's legacy.

Democrats, largely united in calling for Kitzhaber's resignation, believe that the state will be in good hands if he steps down. His successor, Secretary of State Kate Brown, is seen as more of a Democratic loyalist than Kitzhaber. She will also make history as the nation's first openly bisexual governor.

Chad Griffin, the president of the Human Rights Campaign, praises Brown, saying, "While she'll make history as the nation's first sitting LGBT governor, the more important truth is that she's supremely capable of leading the state to better days ahead."

Title: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie and Carly Fiorina Exit 2016 Presidential Race After New Hampshire Primary

Article:

In a joint announcement on Wednesday, New Jersey Governor Chris Christie and former HP executive Carly Fiorina suspended their respective Republican presidential bids following a disappointing performance in the New Hampshire primary. The two candidates, who were once considered promising contenders, have now exited the race, leaving a still-crowded GOP field to vie for their support.

According to sources, Christie gathered his campaign team in Morristown, New Jersey, and held a conference call to announce his decision. The announcement was expected after Christie returned home following his sixth-place finish in the primary contest. Fiorina, who finished seventh, also announced her withdrawal from the race.

In a statement on Facebook, Christie expressed his commitment to the principles he campaigned on, stating, "I ran for president to say that the government needs to once again work for the people, not the people work for the government." He added, "I leave the race without an ounce of regret."

Fiorina, the only female GOP candidate in the 2016 race, announced her decision in a written statement, stating, "While I suspend my candidacy today, I will continue to travel this country and fight for those Americans who refuse to settle for the way things are and a status quo that no longer works for them."

Christie's campaign was marked by the George Washington Bridge scandal, which tarnished his political image. Despite his efforts to focus on drug addiction, a major issue in New Hampshire, voters gravitated more toward Ohio Governor John Kasich, who finished second in the primary. Trump and Texas Senator Ted Cruz finished first and third, respectively, followed by Christie, former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, and Florida Senator Marco Rubio.

Fiorina's political career began in 2010 when she ran for Senate in California and lost to incumbent Sen. Barbara Boxer by 10 points. Throughout her presidential bid, Fiorina emphasized her business experience, having started her career as a secretary, earned an MBA, and worked her way up at AT&T to become a senior executive at the telecom giant. However, she was also dogged by questions about her record at Hewlett-Packard, where she was hired as CEO in 1999 and was eventually fired six years later after leading a major merger with Compaq and laying off 30,000 workers.

With the exit of Christie and Fiorina, the Republican primary race continues to heat up as the remaining candidates vie for the party's nomination.

Title: Sen. Lindsey Graham Criticizes Current Background Check System, Questions Democratic Push for Expansion

Article:

In a recent interview on CNN's State of the Union, Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) voiced his opposition to Democratic efforts to pass new gun-control bills, particularly those that expand background checks. Graham argued that the current system is broken and needs improvement before any expansion should be considered.

Graham pointed out that in 2020, approximately 76,000 individuals who failed a background check were not prosecuted, and in 2010, around 9,000 felons who failed a background check were also not prosecuted. He emphasized the need to address the existing system before moving forward with new legislation.

The senator also stated that the current proposals would not have prevented the Sandy Hook massacre, as the shooter did not fail a background check. Furthermore, Graham declared that he would not join the five Senate Republicans who have pledged to filibuster any legislation that infringes on the Second Amendment, provided that alternative amendments are allowed.

Senate Democrats have shifted their focus to background checks since bans on semi-automatic weapons are no longer a priority. New York Democratic Sen. Chuck Schumer told NBC's "Meet the Press" that background checks are the "sweet spot" because they would do a significant amount of good and have a good chance of passing. Schumer is working with both Democrats and Republicans to create a background check bill that would be acceptable to 60 senators and effectively address gun violence.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid is expected to bring legislation to the floor next month. The debate on gun control and the future of gun legislation in the United States continues as both parties grapple with finding a solution that addresses gun violence while respecting the Second Amendment.

Title: U.S. International Trade Commission Reports Positive, Yet Modest, Economic Impact of Trans-Pacific Partnership

The U.S. International Trade Commission (ITC) has released a report stating that the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) would have a positive, yet modest, impact on the U.S. economy. The report predicts that TPP would increase real GDP by nearly $43 billion annually by 2032 and support an additional 128,000 full-time jobs.

According to the ITC, the agriculture and food sector would see the most significant gains, with a $10 billion boost, or 0.5 percent, by the 15th year of the deal. On the other hand, the manufacturing, natural resources, and energy sectors would collectively lose $10 billion, or 0.1 percent, after 15 years.

The ITC was asked by Congress to assess the economic impact of the proposed trade deal involving the United States and 11 other countries. President Obama strongly supports the pact and signed it in February, but the deal is currently on hold without congressional approval.

The TPP is intended to open markets for U.S. exporters and farmers, protect intellectual property, and strengthen the U.S. political position in Asia. President Obama has stated that TPP allows the U.S. to write the rules of the road in the 21st century, which is especially important in a region as dynamic as the Asia-Pacific.

However, not everyone agrees with the ITC's findings. Lori Wallach of Public Citizen argues that the pact could have disastrous effects for most Americans' jobs and wages. Wallach states that the report's findings are based on the same widely criticized methodology and unrealistic assumptions that have resulted in past ITC reports systematically overstating the benefits from trade deals that ended up causing serious damage.

In the past, trade deals have been a contentious issue, with critics fearing massive job losses and supporters predicting large economic gains. The Congressional Research Service found that the net overall effect of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) on the U.S. economy was relatively modest, with neither the predicted job losses nor the large economic gains materializing.

The ITC report's forecast for TPP's impact won't be known for a long time, as the proposed trade deal could take anywhere from five to 30 years to come into effect. The TPP is expected to bring about small changes gradually over a long period.

Trade has become a central issue in this year's election cycle, with candidates such as Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders expressing strong opposition to the TPP. The outcome of the TPP's impact remains to be seen, and the debate over its benefits and drawbacks will likely continue.

Title: Hillary Clinton Hints at 2016 Presidential Run in Iowa, Leaves Decision Unclear

Article:

Hillary Clinton, a frontrunner in many early presidential polls, made a return to Iowa on Sunday, a state she last visited in 2008 during her unsuccessful bid for the Democratic nomination. The former Secretary of State, who has not yet announced her intentions for the 2016 presidential race, appeared alongside her husband, former President Bill Clinton, at the annual steak fry event hosted by U.S. Sen. Tom Harkin.

The event, a must-attend for state Democratic activists, provided little insight into Clinton's presidential plans, but did not dampen the widespread belief that she will indeed run. The gathering, held in Indianola on a beautiful September day, was Harkin's last, as he is retiring after five terms.

Cindy Pollard, a 57-year-old who served as a precinct captain for Clinton in 2008, was among the enthusiastic crowd. "I was a precinct captain for Hillary. I've been decided," Pollard said.

Clinton's speech, following speeches by Iowa Democrats running for U.S. Senate, House seats, and governor, was filled with subtle hints about her potential candidacy. She mentioned her new memoir, "Hard Choices," and said, "There are many more chapters to be written in the amazing life of Hillary Clinton."

As the crowd chanted her name, Clinton playfully acknowledged the elephant in the room. "It is true I am thinking about it," she said, referring to a potential presidential run, but added, "for today that is not why I'm here."

The crowd, which included potential voters like Linda Dedecker, an accountant from Ames, and Karen Hill of Marshalltown, seemed to take Clinton's ambiguity in stride. Dedecker, who was wearing a Clinton button, said, "I'm considering her," but added, "I don't know who else is going to run."

Clinton's return to Iowa, a state where she finished third in the 2008 caucuses, was a reminder of the importance of understanding the state's unique caucus system. Some, like Hill, offered advice for Clinton's 2016 campaign: "Don't take anything for granted—come and hang out with us for a while."

The event also saw a push for Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren to enter the race as a progressive alternative to Clinton. One Warren supporter emphasized the importance of not anointing Clinton so early, before any official declarations of candidacy. Clinton's appearance in Iowa, while not revealing her decision, has certainly kept the speculation about her presidential plans alive.

Title: President Trump Calls for Border Legislation, Cites Immigration Crisis and DACA

Article:

In a series of tweets on Monday, President Donald Trump reiterated his stance on the country's immigration policies, criticizing Democrats for failing to reach a deal on the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program and the ongoing immigration crisis at the U.S.-Mexico border.

The President stated, "Mexico has the absolute power not to let these large 'Caravans' of people enter their country. They must stop them at their Northern Border, which they can do because their border laws work, not allow them to pass through into our country, which has no effective border laws."

He continued, "Congress must immediately pass Border Legislation, use Nuclear Option if necessary, to stop the massive inflow of Drugs and People. Border Patrol Agents (and ICE) are GREAT, but the weak Dem laws don't allow them to do their job. Act now Congress, our country is being stolen!"

Trump also expressed his view on DACA, stating, "DACA is dead because the Democrats didn't care or act, and now everyone wants to get onto the DACA bandwagon... No longer works. Must build Wall and secure our borders with proper Border legislation. Democrats want No Borders, hence drugs and crime!"

These comments follow threats Trump made Sunday on Twitter that there would be "NO MORE DACA DEAL." The messages come after a report revealed photos of more than 1,000 migrants from Central America heading through the streets of Mexico on their way to the United States, with Mexican immigration officials doing nothing to stop the flow.

Title: GOP Candidates intensify efforts to outmaneuver each other ahead of Super Tuesday

Article:

As the Republican primary race heats up, Donald Trump's rivals are making a last-ditch effort to undermine each other in a bid to boost their own chances before Super Tuesday. The goal is to secure a viable challenge against the billionaire front-runner, who has won three consecutive contests so far.

Ahead of Thursday's crucial debate in Houston, Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz, and John Kasich have all claimed to be the only candidate capable of derailing Trump. Ben Carson, who has lagged behind in previous contests, has chosen a different approach, characterizing his distant finishes as evidence that "things are starting to happen."

Ohio Governor John Kasich's campaign, despite poor performances in South Carolina and Nevada, issued a defiant call on Thursday for Rubio to withdraw from the race. Kasich's spokesman, Chris Schrimpf, tweeted, "@ JohnKasich is the ONLY candidate who can beat @ realDonaldTrump on 3/15. @ marcorubio needs to do the right thing & suspend campaign."

Rubio, who has yet to win a primary contest but has been steadily gaining endorsements, has been positioning himself as the best candidate to win a general election in November and take on Trump. During a forum with host Megyn Kelly on Wednesday, Rubio acknowledged that Trump is the frontrunner but emphasized, "I've been an underdog my entire life."

The candidates will face off in Thursday's debate, a potential final opportunity to define themselves as the anti-Trump candidate before the more than a dozen states holding contests on Super Tuesday. A near-sweep by Trump on Tuesday would be detrimental for the remaining candidates.

Texas Senator Ted Cruz argued on Wednesday that he, not anyone else, is the best alternative candidate, as he is the only other candidate who has won a primary contest, the Iowa caucuses. Cruz stated, "My campaign is the only campaign that can beat Donald [Trump] and has beaten Donald."

Trump, however, has consistently argued that if other candidates drop out, their support would not necessarily gravitate to the other non-Trump candidates. Trump contends that he would also pick up some of that support.

Larry Sabato, director of the University of Virginia Center for Politics, supports Trump's view, stating, "Trump will get a share. He might not get a majority, but he'll get a share."

The pressure is most intense on candidates Kasich and Ben Carson, whose campaigns have struggled in the polls and performed poorly in the first four contests. Carson, despite a fourth-place finish in Nevada, declared to supporters that "things are starting to happen."

Carson seemed to acknowledge the pressure in a fundraising email on Wednesday, stating, "Without a strong showing on Super Tuesday, it's going to be very tough for my campaign. That's the honest truth."

Kasich, however, told reporters that "the people calling for me to get out are the people who are inside the Beltway... I'm certainly not listening to a bunch of lobbyist insiders."

Title: Rep. Denny Heck Announces Retirement, Leaving Vacancy in Democratic-Leaning Washington District

Article:

In a heartfelt statement, U.S. Representative Denny Heck (D-WA) announced his retirement from Congress, citing his disillusionment with the political process following the impeachment inquiry and the investigation into Russian election interference.

Heck, who has served in Congress since 2013, expressed his disappointment in the actions of some of his colleagues, stating, "I will never understand how some of my colleagues, in many ways good people, could ignore or deny the president’s unrelenting attack on a free press, his vicious character assassination of anyone who disagreed with him, and his demonstrably very distant relationship with the truth."

Heck, a Washington state native, served a decade in the state House, beginning with his election in 1976. He also served as chief of staff to then-Washington Governor Booth Gardner during Gardner's second term in Olympia. He first ran for Congress in 2010, losing to now-Rep. Jaime Herrera Beutler (R-WA). Two years later, he won a different seat created by the post-2010 redistricting.

In Congress, Heck led recruitment efforts for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) for the past two cycles, personally drafting many of the newly elected Democratic freshman members, including Reps. Stephanie Murphy (D-FL) and Susie Lee (D-NV).

He ran unsuccessfully last year to serve as chairman of the committee, losing a four-way race to Rep. Cheri Bustos (D-IL).

Washington's 10th District, which Heck represented, is a Democratic-leaning territory. Heck won reelection last year with 62 percent of the vote, and Hillary Clinton carried the district by an 11-point margin in 2016.

Heck's retirement will likely result in a crowded field of candidates vying to succeed him. Under Washington's top-two primary system, all candidates will run together on the same ballot, regardless of party, in the Aug. 4 primary, with the top two finishers advancing to a head-to-head general election.

Possible Democratic candidates for the seat include Olympia Mayor Cheryl Selby, Phil Gardner, Heck's district director, state Reps. Beth Doglio, Christine Kilduff, and Mari Leavitt. Heck already had a Democratic challenger next year: truck driver Joshua Collins.

Title: Pope Francis' U.S. Visit: A Week of Controversy, Political Maneuvers, and Religious Freedom Debates

Article:

As Pope Francis embarks on his highly anticipated visit to the United States, the week ahead promises a whirlwind of events, political maneuvers, and contentious debates on religious freedom and social issues.

From the streets of Washington D.C., Philadelphia, and New York City, to the halls of Congress and the United Nations, the pontiff's visit is set to be a memorable one, not just for the religious ceremonies, but also for the political and social undercurrents that will surface.

In Cuba, the pope was given a warm send-off by Fidel and Raul Castro, with the brothers expressing their solidarity and shared political ideologies. The pope's denunciation of capitalism and America's economic system has been welcomed by the Castro brothers, who view it as a softening of President Obama's stance on the Cuban embargo.

In Washington D.C., the pope is expected to address a joint session of Congress, where he may face a boycott from some Catholic members due to disagreements on religious liberty and abortion issues. The White House, in turn, has been criticized for snubbing representatives of the anti-abortion movement, a cause of high priority for American bishops.

In New York City, the pope will visit the United Nations, where he may hear a reprise of Marxist bloviation. The pope's visit to Philadelphia will culminate in a speech at the Independence National Historical Park, where he can deliver his final thoughts on the issues at hand.

Throughout his visit, the pope is expected to navigate a complex web of political and social issues, from capitalism and social justice to religious freedom and abortion. His actions and words will be closely watched by Catholics, Protestants, and political leaders alike, making this a week that will undoubtedly leave a lasting impact on the religious and political landscape of the United States.

Wesley Pruden, editor in chief emeritus of The Washington Times, aptly sums up the week ahead as a "busy week" for the pope, filled with "crosstown traffic in the chaos" that will be his most memorable gift to the tale of three cities.

Title: The Debate Over the Iran Nuclear Deal: A Look at the Prospects of a "Better Deal"

Article:

As the Iran nuclear deal is being debated in Congress, with a September vote looming, the option of rejecting the current deal in favor of a "better deal" is gaining traction. On Wednesday, Rep. Grace Meng (D-NY) announced her opposition to the deal, stating that "the world could and should have a better deal." However, the likelihood of renegotiating and toughening the deal if Congress rejects it and overcomes a presidential veto is a contentious issue.

The debate centers on the perception of Iran and whether the United States should be entangled in such a complex deal, and whether Iran should be allowed to possess any uranium enrichment program at all. Critics of the Iran deal argue that there is historical precedent for renegotiating and amending international agreements, and that Iran is so intent on getting a deal with the US that Tehran could be brought back to the negotiating table after a congressional rejection.

Mark Dubowitz, an international sanctions expert and executive director of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies (FDD) in Washington, says, "Congress should require the administration to renegotiate certain terms of the proposed [deal] and resubmit the amended agreement to Congress." He cites nearly 80 multilateral agreements that Congress has either rejected or for which it has required amendments.

However, senior administration officials involved in the Iran negotiations say there is no chance the deal could be renegotiated, and they warn that rejection of the deal would likely result in a ramped-up uranium enrichment program, shrinking "breakout" time for Iran to rush to produce a nuclear weapon if it chose to. Secretary of State John Kerry called the prospect of a "better deal" a "fantasy."

Nonproliferation experts echo this position, saying the Iranian nuclear program was already too advanced years ago to reduce it any more than what the deal reached on July 14 does. Jeffrey Lewis, director of nonproliferation studies at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey, Calif., says, "The most important thing now is to prevent Iran from getting a nuclear weapon in the next 10 to 15 years, and this deal does that."

Others are less certain the deal blocks Iran's paths to a nuclear weapon, but they believe a renegotiated deal could. FDD's Mr. Dubowitz sees three different directions the Iran nuclear issue could take if Congress rejects the current deal and holds out for an agreement "renegotiated on better terms." However, many regional experts say that prospects for wooing European allies to join the US in pressing for a tougher deal, if Congress rejects the one now before it, are dim.

Looming large over the calls for a return to negotiations are strong suspicions on the part of deal supporters that the "better deal" advocates really have no interest in a stronger deal at all, but instead want to thwart any US agreement with the Iranian government. "We had a 'better deal' in Iraq after 1991 [following the Gulf War], there were no restrictions, inspectors could go where they wanted when they wanted, and that deal wasn't good enough," says Dr. Lewis, adding that "we still went to war. So really I don't believe them when they say they just want a 'better deal' this time."

Doubters of the sincerity of the seekers of a "better deal" say it's telling to note that the sponsor of the TV ad campaign demanding a better deal is a group called Citizens for a Nuclear Free Iran, which is backed by the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, a pro-Israel organization lobbying Congress hard for the deal's defeat. "There really is no 'better deal' for [such critics] in the sense of an agreement that leaves any nuclear program in the hands of the current Iranian government," Lewis says. "Any deal is bad because it means living with the Islamic Republic."

Title: Study Reveals Higher Lead Levels in American Children with Private Well Water Sources

Article:

A new study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences has found that American children whose homes rely on private wells for drinking water are 25 percent more likely to have high lead levels in their blood than those with access to regulated community water services. The research, which is the first to specifically analyze lead exposure in children who rely on private wells, highlights the need for an overhaul of the Safe Drinking Water Act to provide support for households relying on private wells.

The study, conducted by researchers from the Indian University school of public health, examined the water sources and health records from almost 60,000 children in North Carolina. The researchers found that children relying on private wells had blood lead concentrations that were 20 percent higher, on average, than children with community water service.

The study also found that children living in older, lower-value houses suffered higher lead levels and had higher risks of elevated blood lead, as did those in majority-Black neighborhoods. "Risks are especially high for children in low-income households and in African American neighborhoods that remain excluded from access to nearby municipal water service—a legacy of discriminatory zoning practices," said Jackie MacDonald Gibson, author of the study and chair of the department of environmental and occupational health at the Indian University school of public health.

Lead, a heavy metal which has no smell and is invisible to the naked eye, is a suspected carcinogen and highly toxic to the brain and nervous system, as well as most other organs. The water scandal in Flint, Michigan, in 2014 exposed concerns about lead in regulated city drinking water supplies, but little attention has been paid to dangerous contaminants in unregulated private wells which provide drinking water to 42.5 million Americans, the equivalent of 13 percent of the population.

The increased exposure is probably due to corrosion of indoor plumbing and well components. Private wells are excluded from the Safe Drinking Water Act, which since 1991 has required all community water utilities to monitor lead levels as part of the Lead and Copper Rule provision. This means households with private wells must monitor their own water quality, and, when necessary, replace parts and install and manage their own corrosion-control systems. But it is seldom done, according to Gibson, because lead control requires awareness of the risks, knowledge about testing, and money.

"This study highlights the need for an overhaul of the Safe Drinking Water Act to provide support for households relying on private wells," Gibson said. "That includes financial support, and education and support on proper testing. No level of lead exposure is safe. This is an issue that must continue to be addressed." The increased exposure is linked to reduced IQ, ADHD, school failure, and criminality, according to the CDC.

Title: George Papadopoulos Disputes Jeff Sessions' Testimony on Trump-Putin Summit Prospect

In a recent interview on ABC's "This Week," George Papadopoulos, the former Trump campaign adviser who was recently sentenced to two weeks in prison for lying to investigators, claimed that Attorney General Jeff Sessions was "quite enthusiastic" about the prospect of a summit between President Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin during the 2016 campaign.

According to Papadopoulos, during a roundtable of campaign officials in 2016, he shared his connection that could establish a summit between Mr. Trump and Mr. Putin. President Trump, then a candidate, reportedly nodded but did not seem committed, while Mr. Sessions seemed "quite enthusiastic" about the prospect, according to Papadopoulos.

However, Sessions has testified that he pushed back on the idea. Papadopoulos said, "All I can say is this was a meeting from about two years ago — my recollection differs from Jeff Sessions'."

On Friday, Papadopoulos was sentenced to two weeks in prison for lying to federal investigators about his contacts with Joseph Mifsud, a London-based professor who supposedly told him in 2016 that Russia had damaging information on Hillary Clinton, Mr. Trump's Democratic opponent.

Papadopoulos also said he had no recollection of sending an email about the possible dirt to John Mashburn, a Trump campaign and White House official who has reportedly testified to congressional investigators he thought he got such an alert about possible Clinton dirt from Papadopoulos.

"If I did send an email, and especially if others were copied on it, I'm sure that evidence would have [been] introduced by now," Papadopoulos said. "If that email was sent, even if I deleted it, if that's what people believe I did, there would be a copy somewhere else."

Papadopoulos also expressed uncertainty about whether special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation will reveal actual collusion between Russian officials and the Trump campaign. "All I can say is that my testimony might have helped move something towards that, but I have no idea," he said.

President Trump himself has repeatedly said there was "no collusion."

Title: U.S. Presidential Campaigns Adapt to Coronavirus Outbreak: Biden, Sanders, and Trump Shift to Virtual Events and Remote Work

Article:

In a significant shift due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, the campaigns of Democratic candidate Joe Biden and independent candidate Bernie Sanders, as well as the incumbent Republican candidate Donald Trump, have made adjustments to their operations.

Biden, in a sober speech delivered from his home, announced that his campaign would be holding its fundraisers online indefinitely and that staff at its Philadelphia headquarters would work from home starting this weekend. The Sanders campaign, similarly, has instructed all staff to work from home.

The Trump campaign, while not mandating work-from-home for its employees, is giving them the option to work remotely from March 13-16, as the Arlington, Va. headquarters undergoes sanitization.

Field organizing, a crucial aspect of campaigning, has become vastly more complicated due to the outbreak. The Republican National Committee (RNC) has moved its National Week of Training, a nationwide effort to recruit and activate supporters, to online and phone-based formats. The committee is also planning an upcoming online training day for volunteers.

The Trump campaign, known for its digital infrastructure and database of contact information, is betting on its ability to reach key voters online. The reelection effort recently set up a new website, ArmyforTrump.com, designed to serve as an online hub for volunteers.

Tim Murtaugh, a Trump campaign spokesman, stated, "The Trump campaign is built on data and uses technology to its highest advantages, so is better positioned to virtually engage voters than any other campaign."

The Biden campaign, in its Thursday memo, announced the closure of all field offices to the public and plans to organize voters through phone banking, text messaging, virtual events, and other distributed organizing models. The Sanders campaign, in response to the outbreak, has halted all door-to-door canvasses and is moving to digital formats and outreach wherever possible.

While Trump advisers express concerns about the president's response to the coronavirus and its impact on his reelection hopes, they remain relatively optimistic. However, they acknowledge the political danger posed by the spreading virus and the accompanying school and office closures, as well as the loss of life.

Biden is using the crisis as an opportunity to present himself as a steady leader who will return the country to normalcy after a turbulent Trump presidency. During a Thursday speech on the outbreak, Biden charged that "public fears are being compounded by a pervasive lack of trust in this president, fueled by his adversarial relationship with the truth."

Ron Klain, a top Biden campaign adviser who coordinated the Obama administration's response to an Ebola outbreak in late 2014, stated, "The No. 1 question right now is what's your response to this coronavirus?"

Title: Trump's Foreign Policy Shift: A New Approach to Iran and Beyond

Article:

In a significant departure from his predecessor's policies, President Donald Trump is pursuing a more confrontational approach to foreign policy, particularly in relation to Iran. This shift, according to sources familiar with the President's thinking, is a reflection of Trump's belief that his personal efforts to negotiate and pressure global rivals can yield results that eluded his predecessors.

On Tuesday, Trump announced the U.S.'s withdrawal from the 2015 Iran nuclear deal, a move that has sparked criticism and concern from European allies and increased tensions in the Middle East. The decision, according to Trump's allies, is part of a broader strategy to dismantle elements of former President Barack Obama's foreign policy agenda and reshape international relations.

Mark Dubowitz, chief executive of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies, who advocated for changes to the Iran deal, described Trump's approach as "The Art of the Deal": refusing to be bound by existing agreements that are not in America's interest, exiting or threatening to exit such agreements, and applying maximum pressure to negotiate better terms.

The potential risks of this approach were evident in the hours following Trump's announcement, as Syrian officials reported Israeli airstrikes on Iranian targets near Damascus, and Israel warned residents in the Golan Heights of potential Iranian attacks, raising fears of escalating conflict in the region.

Critics argue that Trump's approach lacks a clear strategy and could lead to chaos. Former CIA Director and Defense Secretary Leon Panetta stated, "The result is that he takes steps which create a great deal of chaos without any kind of strategy as to what you do next."

Trump's supporters, however, point to the ongoing negotiations with North Korea as evidence of the approach's success. For months, Trump's belligerent rhetoric and threats of military action against North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Un, have been met with a response: talks between the U.S. and North Korea.

The administration faces challenges in persuading European allies to cooperate, particularly in light of the U.S.'s withdrawal from the Iran deal. European leaders, led by French President Emmanuel Macron, have distanced themselves from the U.S. decision and vowed to work with Iran to salvage the agreement.

Trump is relying more on Israel and Saudi Arabia, Iran's two main regional adversaries, to counter Iran's influence. This shift increases the risk of broader regional conflicts, according to some analysts.

With a revamped national security team, Trump is challenging the status quo, advocating for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Syria and Afghanistan, and moving forward with plans to open the U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem. The embassy's opening next week marks a significant departure from previous estimates that it might not occur for years.

Trump's approach to foreign policy, some argue, bears similarities to President Ronald Reagan's strategy for confronting the Soviet Union in the 1980s. Reagan's style, while controversial, ultimately led to a historic reduction in nuclear weapons through negotiation.

However, there are differences. While Reagan relied on the recommendations of his seasoned national security team, Trump has reportedly chafed at the guidance of his own advisers, leading to a high turnover rate among top officials.

As Trump continues to implement his foreign policy agenda, the world watches with anticipation and apprehension, awaiting the outcomes of this new approach to international relations.

Title: Republican Tax Policy Makers Unveil Corporate Tax Cut Plan, Avoiding Individual Tax Rate Reduction

Article:

WASHINGTON - The Republican "Big Six" tax policy makers, led by top Trump administration officials and congressional Republican leaders, are set to release a plan on Wednesday that aims to reduce corporate tax rates, while avoiding a reduction in the top individual tax rate of 39.6 percent.

The "Big Six," which includes Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, Trump economic adviser Gary Cohn, Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan, and two tax committee chairmen, have been working on the plan for months. However, they are still undecided on key issues, such as whether to allow businesses to write off new investments immediately, how to lower tax rates for small businesses, and whether to cut middle-class taxes by doubling the standard deduction for individuals and families.

Under pressure from corporate America, the team is expected to call for a corporate income tax target rate within a range of 18-23 percent, down from the current rate of 35 percent. The Big Six is expected to refrain from cutting the top individual tax rate, a move that many Republicans in the House of Representatives could find difficult to accept.

"They're not going to cut the highest income tax rate. They're not," predicted Stephen Moore, a fellow at the conservative Heritage Foundation think tank who helped write Trump's campaign tax plan.

Overhauling the tax code was a key pledge for Trump in his 2016 presidential campaign. However, after eight months in office, he has made only limited progress. Washington has achieved no major tax overhaul since 1986.

Trump portrays lower corporate taxes as a boon to workers, saying they would lead to more jobs and higher salaries. A rate cut on corporate profits could also be used to benefit shareholders and offer up more executive bonuses, however.

Senator Ron Wyden, top Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee, said this week that the leaked details of the Big Six meetings paint a picture of an unprecedented tax giveaway for the most fortunate and biggest corporations.

Lobbyists said they do not expect the Big Six to offer many details about the tax loopholes and deductions that could be eliminated to help pay for tax cuts. Instead, the plan is expected to focus on lowering corporate tax rates and simplifying the tax code.

The Big Six is also expected to address the estimated $2.6 trillion in U.S. corporate profits held overseas by requiring companies to bring the money home at rates of 3.5 percent for reinvested profits and 8.75 percent for on cash and equivalents. To offset lost revenue, the Trump administration plans to forecast a flood of new tax revenue in coming years, based on aggressive assumptions of tax-fueled economic expansion.

However, Senate Republicans have shown signs of moving away from such "dynamic" scoring of any tax legislation impact. Two senators, including a prominent fiscal hawk, agreed this week to a "static" score that could allow tax reform to lose up to $1.5 trillion over the next decade. Senate Republicans are also likely to avoid budget baseline changes to generate savings for tax reform on paper, which could well mean the Big Six plan would balloon the federal budget deficit.

"Without those, the price goes up. There's no other way to look at it," said John Gimigliano, a former House Ways and Means Committee tax counsel who leads federal legislative and regulatory services at KPMG LLP.

Title: The Historical Precedent of Military Appointments in U.S. Administration and the Trump Administration's Nominees

Article:

The recent appointments of retired military generals to cabinet-level positions in the Trump Administration has sparked controversy, with critics labeling it as a "militarization" of the government. However, a closer look at history reveals that choosing military men for top positions is not unprecedented, nor is it necessarily a cause for concern.

President-elect Donald Trump's nominees for national security adviser, defense secretary, and secretary of homeland security are all retired generals: Michael Flynn, James Mattis, and John Kelly, respectively. High-ranking officers such as General David Petraeus and Admiral Michael Rogers have also been rumored for other positions in the Trump administration.

These nominees are not only retired but also seasoned veterans with extensive experience in managing thousands of soldiers and interacting with key leaders worldwide. The criticism of the Flynn, Mattis, and Kelly nominations is largely politically motivated, similar to past partisan frenzies over issues such as the "war on women" or the "climate of hate."

Comparing the scrutiny of these nominees to those with backgrounds in banking, politics, or law is unwarranted. In the past, presidents have appointed retired military personnel to cabinet positions or high-ranking positions in their administrations. For instance, Barack Obama appointed five retired generals and one retired admiral to either Cabinet posts or high-ranking positions in his administration.

Under Obama, General David Petraeus became CIA director, while Michael Flynn served as Obama's director of the Defense Intelligence Agency. Retired general Eric Shinseki was head of the Department of Veterans Affairs, and retired general James Jones was national security adviser. Retired admiral Dennis Blair and retired general James Clapper served as successive directors of national intelligence.

Historically, retired generals and admirals have served in the executive branch, with President Harry Truman appointing General George Marshall (of Marshall Plan fame) as secretary of state and later secretary of defense. General Omar Bradley was head of the Veterans Administration while still on active duty. Dwight Eisenhower, without prior elected office, proved a most-effective Republican president.

The chief complaint about Trump's appointments is that too many generals will mean too great a likelihood of war. However, historical evidence points to the opposite conclusion. Generals were not the proverbial "best and brightest" who argued for military intervention in Vietnam, the invasion of Iraq in 2003, or the bombing of Libya in 2011.

In fact, retired generals and flag officers have traditionally been against sending their own troops into what they see as optional wars abroad. Their occasional harangues about building up military power are predicated on notions of peace-through-strength deterrence: The more powerful the military is perceived abroad, the less likely it will be needed to be used.

Conversely, the reliance on ex-senators and politicians with law degrees to fill important executive positions, despite their lack of outside-the-Beltway administrative experience, is a more significant concern. In 2008, Obama's résumé consisted mainly of having been a Harvard Law School grad and, briefly, a U.S. senator. As a result, he looked to people with similar backgrounds for some key appointments, such as former senator and lawyer Joe Biden as vice president, former senator and lawyer Hillary Clinton as secretary of state, and later, former senator and lawyer John Kerry as secretary of state.

The current state of affairs, from the collapse of several Middle Eastern nations to the failed reset with Russia to the outrageous Iran deal, is not evidence of success at the State Department. An Obama appointee with a similar background, former senator and lawyer Ken Salazar, was not an especially successful secretary of the interior.

Lawyers, Ivy League graduates, and former politicians usually dominate presidential appointments. How have these stereotypical profiles worked out? We are currently nearing $20 trillion in national debt, stagnating under nonexistent economic growth and near-zero interest rates, and suffering from record labor nonparticipation rates. We are seeing a failed health-care system, a discredited IRS and VA, and the worst racial relations in half a century. Generals did not compile that record. Lawyers and lifetime Washington politicians did.

Title: Democratic Political Group Launches Ad Campaign Questioning Bernie Sanders' Electability and Health in Nevada

Article:

A political action committee (PAC) affiliated with the Democratic Party has initiated a new ad campaign in Nevada, targeting presidential candidate Bernie Sanders' electability and health ahead of the state's presidential nominating caucuses on February 22.

The Democratic Majority for Israel PAC (DMFI) has reportedly purchased over $175,000 worth of cable and network ad time this week, according to Federal Communications Commission (FCC) filings. The ads are set to air for a week, starting this Saturday.

The exact extent of DMFI's Nevada ad buy was not immediately available, as the group had not yet filed an independent expenditure report with the Federal Election Commission (FEC) as of Friday morning. However, FCC filings suggest the total size of the buy exceeds $175,000.

In the run-up to the Iowa caucuses earlier this month, DMFI aired an ad that questioned Sanders' ability to win a general election and raised concerns about the Vermont senator's health. A woman featured in the ad stated, "I do have some concerns about Bernie Sanders' health, considering he did have a heart attack."

Mark Mellman, a Democratic consultant who runs DMFI PAC, declined to provide specifics about the Nevada ad, stating only that it would differ from the Iowa ad.

DMFI's funding primarily comes from a few high-dollar donors. Stacy Schusterman, a Tulsa oil and gas heiress, donated nearly $1 million to DMFI PAC in December, according to FEC records. The group also received $495,000 from venture capitalist Mark Gary Lauder.

The new ad campaign against Sanders comes as he attempts to gain ground in the race for Democratic delegates in the third presidential nominating contest. Sanders trails former South Bend mayor Pete Buttigieg by two delegates despite strong performances in both Iowa and New Hampshire.

DMFI's plans for a Nevada offensive against Sanders were first reported by Mediaite. FCC filings posted on the agency's website on Wednesday and Thursday show DMFI has purchased ad time on broadcast stations in Las Vegas and Reno, as well as various statewide cable programs.

Title: U.S. Court of Appeals Orders Judge to Respond to Michael Flynn's Request to Dismiss Charges

Article:

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has instructed the judge presiding over the criminal case against former President Donald Trump's national security adviser Michael Flynn to respond to a petition in which Flynn's lawyers are seeking to force the judge to grant a Justice Department request to dismiss the case.

The U.S. Court of Appeals, in a move that could potentially expedite the legal process, has given District Judge Emmet Sullivan 10 days to respond to an emergency petition filed by Flynn's lawyers seeking to compel Sullivan to dismiss the charges.

The Department of Justice, in a significant reversal on May 7, asked Sullivan to drop the charges, drawing criticism from Democrats and retired career prosecutors who accuse Attorney General William Barr of politicizing the U.S. criminal justice system to go easy on Trump's friends and associates.

A retired Army lieutenant general who also advised Trump's 2016 presidential campaign, Flynn pleaded guilty in 2017 to lying to the FBI about his conversations with Russia's U.S. ambassador Sergey Kislyak in the weeks before Trump took office. Flynn, charged as part of former Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation that documented Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election to boost Trump's candidacy, later sought to withdraw his plea and accused the FBI of deceiving him. The Department of Justice's decision to ask Sullivan to drop the charges followed public pressure from Trump and the Republican president's political allies.

Sullivan, in a previous ruling, signaled reluctance to drop the charges, appointing a retired judge to advise whether Flynn should face an additional criminal contempt charge for perjury. Sullivan has scheduled an in-person court hearing in the case for July 16.

Flynn served as national security adviser in the first weeks of Trump's presidency before being fired for misleading Vice President Mike Pence about his dealings with Kislyak.

Title: A Reassessment of U.S. Policy Towards Syria: Letting Assad Win Could Have Prevented the Current Chaos

Article:

In the aftermath of recent terrorist attacks in various cities worldwide, the focus has been on Syria as the root cause of the ongoing instability in the region. A common narrative suggests that if the United States had taken a more active role in Syria's civil war, the Islamic State (ISIL) might not have gained traction, and the scale of the war might have been significantly smaller. However, a closer examination of the situation reveals that this conventional wisdom is flawed.

This article argues that providing lethal aid early in the conflict would have exacerbated the situation, accelerating the war rather than slowing it. A more effective policy could have prevented the chaos now engulfing the region. The U.S. and its partners should have allowed Assad to win.

Several key points are worth considering when examining the origins of the Syrian civil war. First, the moderate opposition was weak, with limited resources and combat experience. While there were Syrians who peacefully protested and hoped for a secular alternative to Assad, they were no match for a well-trained Syrian army supported by Russia, Iran, and Hezbollah.

Second, the opposition was disorganized and lacked coherent leadership. While names like Assad, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, and Abu Mohammad al-Julani are familiar, few can name leaders within the moderate Syrian opposition, such as the Free Syrian Army or the Syrian National Coalition.

Third, Assad and his allies had a clear objective: maintain power. Syria's allies were unburdened by the regime's atrocities, as they had a vested interest in the outcome. In contrast, the U.S. found itself in a catch-22, as attacking Assad would help extremist rebels, while attacking extremist rebels would help Assad. Unwilling to back either party and without a viable alternative, the U.S. had no clear goal or strategy.

In this context, Washington chose a third way. When President Obama called on Assad to step down in August 2011, the U.S. invested in the dictator's defeat without implementing policies to facilitate that outcome. The possibility of Assad winning the war outright was no longer an option, and U.S. acquiescence to a political solution in which Assad remained became increasingly difficult.

To address the situation, the U.S. imposed additional sanctions on the Syrian government, froze Syrian assets under U.S. control, prohibited commercial ties with Damascus, and blocked the import of Syrian oil. The U.S. also established supply routes, funneled money, intelligence, and non-lethal aid to handpicked rebels, many of whom later switched sides. Physical supplies included communications equipment, night vision goggles, bulletproof vests, pickup trucks, food, medicine, and more.

However, these actions did little to prevent Assad's victory or end the war. Instead, they inadvertently fueled the conflict, allowing extremist elements to gain strength and attract recruits from around the world. By doing enough to avoid accusations of inaction, the U.S. poured fuel on a fire that might have extinguished itself, and watched as others poured on more.

In conclusion, the main problem with U.S. policy towards Syria is not that the administration did too little early in the conflict. It is that the administration did too much. If the U.S. and its partners had not intervened, Assad would have likely stamped out the civil war before it began. A brutal dictator would have retained control of his country, but the death toll would be lower, Syria would be more stable, the refugee crisis might not have happened, and ISIL might never have taken its current form. When we look at Iraq and Libya, we see obvious examples of the unintended consequences of intervention. We should see that when we look at Syria, too.

Seth Cantey is an assistant professor of politics at Washington & Lee University with a focus on international security, American foreign policy, and Middle East politics.

To read diverse opinions from our Board of Contributors and other writers, go to the Opinion front page, follow us on Twitter @USATOpinion, and sign up for our daily Opinion newsletter.

Title: North Dakota Senators Heitkamp and Cramer Emphasize Civility in Final Debate Ahead of Midterms

Article:

In a display of political unity amidst a divisive political climate, North Dakota Senators Heidi Heitkamp and Kevin Cramer, who are running against each other in the upcoming midterm elections, agreed on the need for more civility in American politics during their final debate on Thursday. The debate took place just hours after the arrest of Cesar Sayoc, a pro-Trump supporter, for sending dangerous packages to CNN and Democratic leaders who have criticized President Trump.

Both candidates acknowledged that no one is to blame for Sayoc's actions other than himself. This harmony comes after critics have accused President Trump of using divisive rhetoric, which some believe sparked one of his supporters to terrorize the nation this week.

Sen. Heitkamp recalled Rep. Steve Scalise, a Louisiana Republican who was shot and wounded by a left-wing partisan last year, speaking in the aftermath of the attack. "He never once mentioned Democratic politics," Ms. Heitkamp said. "Looking at that as an example, the message couldn't be clearer—we all need to quit blaming. There is only one person responsible here," she said.

Both candidates agreed that everyone should be accountable for their words, with Rep. Cramer, a Trump-ally, stating that debates, like the one they held Thursday, are an opportunity to celebrate political civility. "Let's look to North Dakota as an example," he said.

The two have been in a fierce race, with Sen. Heitkamp trying to hold onto her seat in the U.S. Senate this November in a state where President Trump won by 36 points. However, she has seen her poll numbers sink after voting against Supreme Court Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh. In a poll released this week, she is behind Rep. Cramer by 16 points, a significant increase from the four-point deficit she had prior to her vote against the president's high court pick.

Despite the setback, Sen. Heitkamp's campaign has received more than $12 million in donations during the first two weeks of October, the majority of which came from individual donors, according to a recent filing with the Federal Elections Commission. Former Vice President Joe Biden, one of the bomber's targets earlier this week, is heading to campaign for Sen. Heitkamp, kicking off her statewide tour in Fargo next week.

Both lawmakers agreed on the need for a border wall and increased security to deter illegal immigrants from entering the country, as thousands of migrants from Central America are heading to the border through a caravan. "We can not leave our borders unprotected. The rule of law has to be imposed—if there is 4,000 today, there will be a million tomorrow," Ms. Heitkamp said, separating herself from many of her Democratic colleagues who have balked at a wall along the southern border.

Both lawmakers also saw eye to eye on the Paris Climate Accord, disagreeing with President Trump's decision to pull out of the agreement. However, they sparred over the Affordable Care Act and whether to fix the law as it exists, or to repeal and replace it entirely. Rep. Cramer said money should go to the states, where they can provide better health care options for constituents, while Sen. Heitkamp said not to throw the baby out with the bath water—and instead, fix areas of the healthcare law which aren't working.

Title: AFL-CIO President Warns Hillary Clinton of Political Consequences Over Pacific Trade Pact Support

Article:

In a stark warning to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, the head of the nation's most powerful labor union, Richard Trumka, has vowed to defeat President Obama's key trade legislation in the House next month. Trumka, president of the AFL-CIO, predicted that no more than 20 House Democrats would vote for the Trade Promotion Authority, a bill that passed the Senate on Friday.

The labor leader's comments, made in an interview with Capital Download, indicate a growing rift between the Democratic president and the country's biggest labor federation over the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a trade deal among the United States and 12 other Pacific Rim nations. The TPP requires Congress to approve or reject the agreement without amendments.

Many labor unions have frozen campaign donations as they lobby against the legislation. The battle between the Democratic president and the AFL-CIO underscores the complex politics of Obama's attempts to pass legislation through a Republican-controlled Congress during the final two years of his tenure. It also exposes challenges ahead for Clinton, who has avoided declaring her view of the TPP since becoming a presidential candidate.

Trumka criticized the TPP, stating, "It's not gold. It's going to cost us jobs and it's going to lower wages in this country." He expressed uncertainty about Clinton's stance on the issue, saying, "She's going to have to answer that."

If Clinton supports the TPP and the fast-track authority, there will be political costs, Trumka cautioned. "It will be tougher to mobilize working people," he said, adding that it would make it more difficult to secure the AFL-CIO's endorsement.

When asked whether Obama's presidency had been good for working Americans, Trumka paused before responding, "The president's been seriously handicapped in his ability to deliver things for the American public, because you've got a determined opposition in the Republican Party that will actually hurt the country to deny him a victory."

In the Senate vote, Trumka was surprised to have lost the support of Democratic senators Benjamin Cardin of Maryland, Chris Coons of Delaware, and Patty Murray of Washington state. When the interviewer commented that it's hard to defeat a president, he replied, "We'll see."

Title: Trump's Executive Order on Immigration: A Political Move Amid Economic Crisis

Article:

In a move that has sparked debate and controversy, President Donald Trump announced on Monday that he would be signing an executive order to temporarily suspend immigration to the United States in response to the coronavirus pandemic. The order, which is more limited than initially suggested, will halt the issuance of permanent residency visas, or green cards, for 60 days.

Under the order, the U.S. will not issue green cards to new immigrants, but will not affect temporary workers. There are reported exceptions for workers in "essential" professions and family members of U.S. citizens. The full details of the order have yet to be released.

Trump stated that the decision was made to "protect the jobs" of Americans amid an unprecedented spike in unemployment caused by lockdown measures aimed at limiting the spread of the virus. Immigration has already been significantly curtailed during the outbreak due to travel restrictions and a pause in most visa processing procedures.

The economic impact of the order is a subject of debate among economists. Limiting restrictions to green card applicants, who represent a fraction of the immigrant workforce, may have little to no impact on jobs, many economists say.

Trump's conservative allies argue that the order is a sincere, if limited, attempt to ensure that jobs are reserved for the more than 20 million Americans who have become unemployed since the start of the crisis.

Others see the order as a political tactic. Cutting immigration was a key element of Trump's platform in the 2016 election. Doubling down on that strategy could serve to invigorate his base supporters and distract from the administration's response to the virus, which has received significant criticism.

Some of the president's liberal critics argue that he is using the crisis as an opportunity to impose an anti-immigrant agenda that has been high on the Republican to-do list since long before the pandemic began.

The initial 60-day freeze on new green cards could be extended indefinitely depending on economic conditions, Trump said. He also said the administration was considering a "secondary order" that could further limit immigration down the road.

The pandemic has provided an opportunity for Trump to enact his wish list of immigration policies, according to some analysts. White House adviser Stephen Miller has long advocated for shutting down most immigration, legal and illegal. In the coronavirus, he may have found his opening.

Others argue that Trump is looking for anyone else to blame for the crisis. He has been accused of cycling through scapegoats, including immigrants, public health officials, governors, and the news media, in an attempt to deflect accountability for his administration's response to the pandemic.

The order's impact on the economy and job market remains to be seen, but it is clear that the pandemic has provided an opportunity for Trump to advance his immigration agenda. Whether this move will ultimately benefit the American people or serve as a political distraction remains to be determined.

Title: Israel's Historic Election Yields No Clear Winner as Netanyahu and Gantz Tie in Seats

Article:

TEL AVIV, Israel — Preliminary vote tallies indicate no clear winner in Israel's historic election, with the incumbent Likud party of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the Blue and White party of rival Benny Gantz reportedly tied at 32 seats each. Three surveys also suggest that Netanyahu did not secure enough seats in the Knesset to form a right-wing majority government coalition without Blue and White or Avigdor Liberman's Yisrael Beytenu party.

Exit polls on Channel 12 show a dead heat between Likud and the Blue and White party. Official results are not expected to be announced until Wednesday afternoon local time.

"We're still waiting for the results," Netanyahu told supporters early Wednesday morning at the Likud election headquarters in Tel Aviv. "But one thing is clear, the State of Israel is at a historic turning point. We are facing immense opportunities and immense challenges... including the existential threat from Iran."

Netanyahu also stated that Israel will never have a government "that leans on Arab, anti-Zionist parties."

"We were busy with the campaign for too long," Gantz said. "And with your permission, we will be waiting for another day or two, and we wish the people of Israel a good and desirable unity government."

Tuesday's election is considered a referendum on Netanyahu, who has served as Israel's longest-running prime minister. This election is unprecedented as it marks the first time Israel has held elections twice in the same year. Netanyahu's Likud party won the election in April, but the prime minister's inability to form a government coalition weeks after the election led millions of Israelis back to the polls on Tuesday.

After casting his ballot in Jerusalem, Netanyahu said the vote would be "very close."

"It's not in the bag," he told Israelis in Jerusalem. "But if you go (vote), we will win."

Gantz voted in his hometown of Rosh Haayin and urged fellow Israelis to end Netanyahu's long reign as prime minister.

"We will bring hope, we will bring change, without corruption, without extremism," he said.

There was plenty of drama as Israelis made their way to the polls. Police reported at least 29 arrests and 69 investigations were launched against individuals suspected of voting fraud and other violations. Voting slips were vandalized, several people illegally filmed inside the voting booths, and one man cut the power at a polling site and stole several voting slips. One suspect even threw a firework outside a polling station outside Jerusalem.

Israeli media also reported that the Blue and White website was shut down due to a cyberattack hours before polls closed. The party said the "significant cyberattack" was carried out in a wide-scale operation.

"Over 500 attempted breaches were detected from various servers abroad," the party said.

Despite the drama, both Likud and Blue and White are cautious not to celebrate any perceived victory too early. Party leaders are waiting for the final vote to be counted.

Official results will only come out in the next week, and forming a government can take another month or more after that. If no government is formed, Israelis will go to a third round of elections. For now, Israelis are waiting to see if a government is formed and what it will look like.

Title: Beijing Wins Bid for 2022 Winter Olympics in Low-Key Manner

Article:

China's capital city, Beijing, has been selected to host the 2022 Winter Olympics in a joint bid with Zhangjiakou, a nearby city known for its ski resorts. The International Olympic Committee (IOC) announced the decision on Friday, with Beijing beating out the Central Asian city of Almaty, Kazakhstan. This marks the first time a city has hosted both the winter and summer games.

The announcement was met with a subdued response in Beijing, contrasting the jubilant celebration that followed the city's successful bid for the 2008 Summer Olympics. The low-key reaction is attributed to a variety of factors, including less popularity of winter sports in China, a more restrained publicity campaign, and a diminished sense of significance due to Beijing's previous Olympic hosting experience.

According to the Beijing 2022 Bid Book and state media, the total budget for the games is $3.9 billion, with $1.98 billion allocated for operations and $1.92 billion for infrastructure. Notably, the budget does not include a new 108-mile high-speed train line linking Beijing with the mountain venues.
