The games will utilize 12 venues, half of which are recycled from the 2008 Summer Games. The average snow depth at the alpine skiing venue in February is 5.3 inches. Six venues are new, all but one of which are located in the far suburbs of Yanqing or at Zhangjiakou, where the skiing and sledding events will be held.

The 2022 Winter Olympics is expected to bring 350 billion yuan (approximately $56.4 billion) in investment, primarily to Zhangjiakou and the surrounding rural areas. A high-speed rail line connecting Beijing to Zhangjiakou is already underway, financed and built by state-run railway engineering companies.

China's state-run Xinhua News Agency reported in July that the games would generate significant economic benefits, with the investment primarily focused on developing Zhangjiakou and its surrounding areas. The games are seen as an opportunity to cater to China's growing middle class, with the ski resorts outside Zhangjiakou now attracting large numbers of Beijing residents seeking leisure activities.

While the 2008 Olympics were marked by tight security measures and a focus on national ambitions, the 2022 games seem to be more focused on addressing the leisure needs of China's prosperous population. As one Zhangjiakou official noted, "We hope we can meet the needs of this emerging middle class."

The disposable income of greater Beijing's 21 million residents has nearly doubled since 2008, reaching 43,910 yuan per capita last year. Not everyone is a fan of the winter sports, however. Among the thousands of performers organized to watch the IOC ceremony was 21-year-old subway worker Xiao Shuai, who expressed indifference towards winter sports and noted the challenges of traveling to Zhangjiakou for skiing.

Olivia Geng in Beijing and Will Davies in Hong Kong contributed to this article.

Title: Unprecedented Political Shift: Donald Trump's Presidential Victory and the Rural White America Rebellion

Article:

In a political landscape that has left many in shock, rural white America has staged an unprecedented rebellion in the 2016 presidential election, propelling billionaire developer Donald Trump to the White House. This unexpected turn of events has overthrown a Washington establishment and challenged a pundit class that, as recently as Tuesday afternoon, believed Hillary Clinton was on the brink of a tight but clear victory.

The Republican surge, largely unnoticed by polling, has ensured the party's continued control of the House and Senate. "The polls underestimated two forces – one was voter discontent and the other was Republicans' loyalty to their party's nominee despite the ambivalence about Trump expressed by GOP leaders," says Columbia University political science professor Donald P. Green in an email.

This election result will lead to at least four years of a Washington dominated by one party, potentially leading to a significant shift in the nation's direction on key issues such as foreign policy, trade, immigration, healthcare, and the environment.

Trump's victory marks a reversal of the narrative of the past few years. Many conservative white voters have felt economically, militarily, and culturally disenfranchised, perceiving the country as slipping away. Now, they have emphatically turned the tables on Democratic voters.

After Clinton called Trump to concede the election, he offered her his congratulations for "a very, very hard-fought campaign." He also called for reconciliation, stating it was time to heal the nation's wounds and come together "as one united people."

"I pledge to every citizen in our land, that I will be president for all Americans," he said. "For those who have chosen not to support me… I am reaching out to you for your guidance and your help so we can unify our great nation."

It remains to be seen if any party can hold the presidency for three consecutive terms, and this may have played a role in Trump's victory. However, his win seems a foretold story, as his core supporters – whites without college degrees – turned out in record numbers and supported him to an unprecedented degree.

This mixed up the nation's long-standing order of electoral swing states. Trump took Florida and Ohio before midnight, and won the election in Wisconsin and Pennsylvania. Exurban and rural areas were the Trump heartland, with significant support in places like Newton County, Georgia, about an hour outside of Atlanta.

Al Fortune, a trucking company manager, had a long list of policy issues he expected Trump to address if elected: job creation, conservative healthcare reform, and energy independence from the Middle East. Exit polls on Tuesday night showed Trump winning 80 percent or more of voters who rated "change" as their top priority.

As for Democrat Hillary Clinton, her loss is likely to spark a battle of bitter recriminations among Democrats, with the liberal faction, personified by Senators Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, pushing for radical change in the party agenda.

Trump, of course, represents a major change in GOP identity, focusing unabashedly on white Americans – contrary to the desires of party leadership – and rejecting mainstream Republican principles such as free trade. While that strategy won him the White House in 2016, the changing demographic landscape of the US, with a fast-growing Hispanic population and a declining percentage of whites, may challenge the approach in coming years.

"It's not a good strategy in the long-term," noted Matthew Wilson, an associate professor of political science at Southern Methodist University, as Trump's victory hung in the balance.

Title: Chicago's Homicide Rate and the Debate on Gun Control: A Comparative Analysis of Chicago, Georgia, and Virginia

Article:

In a shocking turn of events, forty individuals were shot over the Easter weekend in Chicago, with nine fatalities. This violent spree, occurring in a city known for its stringent gun control laws, has sparked a renewed debate on the effectiveness of such measures.

Chicago Police Superintendent Garry McCarthy reported that the city's declining homicide tally is "still ahead of where we were last year." In 2013, Chicago recorded 415 homicides, a decrease of 18% from the previous year's 503. However, critics argue that the city's efforts to curb gun violence through stricter gun laws may not be yielding the desired results.

While Chicago's homicide rate improvement could be attributed to the gradual relaxation of its gun laws, other states, such as Georgia, are taking a different approach. Georgia legislators are currently reviewing and repealing archaic gun-control restrictions. From July 1, law-abiding residents will be allowed to carry guns into taverns without restriction and enter churches, schools, and government buildings under certain circumstances.

Georgia Governor Nathan Deal, a Republican, defends this move, stating, "This bill respects the rights of private-property owners, who still set the rules for their land and their buildings." Critics of the expansion of gun rights predict that this law will lead to increased violence, but evidence from states like Virginia suggests otherwise.

Virginia, which abolished its ban on guns in bars four years ago, has seen a decrease in violent crime at drinking establishments. When the Richmond Times-Dispatch investigated crimes committed by concealed-carry permit holders, it could only find one instance of a permit holder propositioning a waitress. Violent crime at drinking establishments dropped 5%.

Respecting Virginians' right to keep and bear arms has made the commonwealth a safer place. Last year, there were just eight homicides in all of Fairfax County, five in Alexandria, and none in Arlington County. In contrast, the District of Columbia, with its strict gun control measures, recorded 103 homicides.

Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel, who has been known to capitalize on crises, may want to consider learning from Georgia and Virginia's approaches to gun control. The debate on gun control continues to be a contentious issue, but the evidence suggests that respecting citizens' right to bear arms may lead to a safer environment.

Title: Government Shutdown Looms as Bipartisan Agreement Remains Elusive

Article:

As the clock ticks down to midnight, the federal government is on the brink of a shutdown, with no clear solution in sight. The House-passed bill, which failed to garner enough support, has left lawmakers scrambling for a last-minute deal to avoid a government shutdown, the first since 2013.

The Senate, and consequently the House, are now starting from scratch, with any new package facing a real time crunch to pass through both chambers before the deadline. The most likely outcome at this point is a government shutdown, as both parties dig in their heels over the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which shields undocumented children of immigrants from deportation.

Democrats, who have been largely united in their demands to address DACA in any legislation, are not in a compromising mood. They view this as their one piece of leverage in Washington and are determined to use it to protect DACA recipients. They also believe they will win the politics of the blame game, as the average American will likely question why the GOP, which controls the House, Senate, and White House, cannot keep their own house in order.

Republicans, led by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Speaker Paul Ryan, are in a more compromising mood, aware that the history of shutdowns does not look favorable for their side if Friday's deadline comes and goes without a deal. The strategy for Republican congressional leaders is also complicated by President Donald Trump, who seems to be veering back and forth on whether a deal should be made and what should be in the deal.

As the focus shifts from finding a solution to avert a shutdown to preparing for the political fallout from a shutdown, momentum appears to be on the side of a shutdown. With no obvious solution or much interest in finding one on either side of the aisle, the government shutdown looms large. The White House's decision to hold a press briefing, featuring Office of Management and Budget Director Mick Mulvaney, suggests it has pivoted toward positioning for a likely shutdown.

Title: Lawmakers Face Potential Exodus Over Obamacare Premium Hikes

Article:

Quiet conversations about the potential impact of the Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare, are taking place among lawmakers and their aides on Capitol Hill. The issue at hand is the impending increase in health insurance premiums for these individuals due to a provision in the health care law that will transition them from the current government-subsidized health care plans to the government health care exchanges.

The fear is that the government-subsidized premiums will disappear at the end of the year under a provision in the health care law, which could make their benefits exorbitantly expensive. Democratic and Republican leaders are taking the issue seriously, but they need more specifics from the Office of Personnel Management on how the new rule should take effect.

If the issue isn't resolved, and massive numbers of lawmakers and aides bolt, many on Capitol Hill fear it could lead to a brain drain just as Congress tackles a slew of weighty issues, such as fights over the Tax Code and immigration reform. The problem is far more acute in the House, where lawmakers and aides are generally younger and less wealthy.

Several aides have already given lawmakers notice that they'll be leaving over concerns about Obamacare. Republican and Democratic lawmakers said the chatter about retiring now, to remain on the current health care plan, is constant.

Rep. John Larson (D-Conn.), a Connecticut Democrat in leadership when the law passed, said he thinks the problem will be resolved. "If not, I think we should begin an immediate amicus brief to say, 'Listen, this is simply not fair to these employees,'" Larson told a news outlet. "They are federal employees."

Republicans, never a fan of Democratic health care reform, are more vocal about the potential adverse effects of the provision. Rep. Pete Sessions (R-Texas) said, "This is the law.... It's going to hinder our ability with retention of members, it's going to hinder our ability for members to take care of their families."

Alabama Rep. Jo Bonner said the threat is already real, especially for veteran lawmakers and staff. If they leave this year, they think they can continue to be covered under the current health care plan. "I've lost one staffer who told me in confidence that he had been here for a number of years and the thought of losing the opportunity to keep his health insurance on Dec. 31 [forced him to leave]," said Bonner, who had already planned his resignation from Congress. "And then I've got another staff member that I think it will be a factor as she's contemplating her future."

The Affordable Care Act, signed into law in 2010, contained a provision known as the Grassley Amendment, which says the government can only offer members of Congress and their staff plans that are "created" in the bill or "offered through an exchange" — unless the bill is amended. Currently, aides and lawmakers receive their health care under the generous Federal Employee Health Benefits Program, with the government subsidizing upward of 75 percent of the premiums for the health insurance plans. In 2014, most Capitol Hill aides and lawmakers are expected to be put onto the exchanges, and there has been no guidance whether the government will subsidize those premiums. This is expected to cause a steep spike in health insurance costs.

Title: Conservative Group Criticizes McConnell for Fiscal Cliff Deal Negotiations

Article:

A conservative advocacy group, ForAmerica, has launched a series of online ads targeting Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) for his role in negotiating the fiscal cliff deal. The ads, which read "Mitch McConnell: Whose side are you on?", are part of a campaign to express disapproval of McConnell's actions during the fiscal cliff negotiations.

Brent Bozell, president of ForAmerica, stated, "This is a statement we're making, and I suspect there will be more statements that are going to be coming out. It is a statement to make it emphatically clear that what the minority leader did was 100 percent unacceptable. Conservatives are going to hold him responsible for this."

The ad buy is reportedly a "five-figure" amount and will be distributed through Google display ads and Facebook in Kentucky, as well as running on The Daily Caller and Drudge Report in Washington. McConnell is up for reelection in 2014 and is hoping to fend off a conservative primary challenge.

After negotiations between House Speaker John Boehner and President Barack Obama broke down, McConnell and Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-NV) took over negotiations. McConnell called in Vice President Joe Biden at the final minute when negotiations reached an impasse. The McConnell-Biden framework ended up becoming the basis for a deal.

Bozell, who vocally opposed the fiscal cliff deal that involved tax increases, made clear that his ire is aimed at McConnell for signing off on a deal. "When Republicans agree to do what they did agree to do, then they are just as much tax-and-spend Democrats as Democrats are," Bozell said.

"Do I have any confidence that Republicans will stand by [McConnell's] statements a couple of days ago that the talk about tax increases are over? None," Bozell said. "It is a fluid situation. There are some serious battles coming up. I'm not writing off anything. If Republicans find their mojo and rediscovered their soul and try to do the right thing, we'll support them, but they just can't count on us anymore."

The ads come as McConnell faces criticism from the right for his role in the fiscal cliff deal, which included tax increases. The conservative group's campaign is an attempt to hold McConnell accountable for his actions and express dissatisfaction with the deal's outcome.

Title: Pennsylvania Focus Group Declares Hillary Clinton the Winner in First Presidential Debate, but Remains Pessimistic About Choices

Article:

In a focus group of undecided voters in the battleground state of Pennsylvania, Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton was declared the clear winner in the first presidential debate, but the participants remained deeply pessimistic about their choices in November. The group, selected and paid to participate in a focus group conducted by Republican pollster Frank Luntz in Philadelphia on Monday, shared entrenched views that voters across the country have expressed over the past 18 months.

The visceral electoral anger that helped fuel Donald Trump's rise during the primaries was felt in the room at the National Constitution Center, where the mood was perhaps best encapsulated by Luntz's opening question: "How the hell did we get here?"

The Pennsylvania voters described Clinton as a "liar," "corrupt," "secretive," and "self-centered." They labeled Trump as "scary," "fake," an "egomaniac," and a "shape-shifter."

The battleground state voters watched the debate from a room inside the National Constitution Center while Luntz's team tracked their snap reactions throughout the 90-minute debate. On display behind the voters were large, expressionistic paintings of an American flag, John F. Kennedy, Ronald Reagan, Trump, and Clinton by artist and GOP darling Steve Penley.

At the end of the debate, 16 of the 27 participants agreed that Clinton had won, while just six believed Trump had won the debate. In near uniformity, the voters said the outcome of the debate was the result of Trump's failure rather than Clinton's success.

Asked to react to their performances, the voters offered that Trump's was "strong start, weak finish," "bombastic," "sloppy," and "verbose." When asked to respond to Clinton's performance, the answers were markedly positive: "firm," "powerful," "strong," and "informed."

Trump struggled to defend himself against attacks by Clinton over his denigration of women, insensitivity on race relations, and an assertion that he avoided paying federal taxes for years. The freewheeling Republican nominee repeatedly interrupted Clinton and drew sardonic laughs from both the audience in New York and the voters in Pennsylvania, when he claimed to have a "winning temperament."

"He dug his own grave by just talking and talking," said one woman named Marti G, who described herself as truly undecided.

On the monitor tracking the voters' reactions to the candidates, which was visible to the handful of reporters observing the group, even those leaning toward the Republican nominee disapproved of his windy response when Clinton ticked off possible reasons Trump may not want to disclose his tax returns.

As the lines on the screen plummeted, Luntz, sporting a pair of American Flag Nike sneakers, bounded over to the small group of reporters. "Donald Trump just got nuked," he said. "And I don't know if he can recover from this debate."

Until that point, Trump appeared to be doing a better job appealing to the firmly undecided voters in the room. He was at his best when he was railing against the political system. But support for him cratered when he began to defend his years of questioning Barack Obama's citizenship.

Clinton wove the so-called birtherism issue – which she referred to as a "racist lie" – into a larger narrative, accusing Trump of having "a long record of engaging in racist behavior." As she spoke, many of the voters in the room agreed with her, especially among those already leaning towards her.

After the debate, the voters lamented that too much time was spent discussing birtherism. Overall, the voters rated Clinton's response on issues of race higher than Trump's, and after the debate, several people flatly labeled the Republican nominee a racist.

"He's come to the black community because he wants our vote, not because he truly cares about [me] as a black person," said Ragni Lee, of Collegeville, Pennsylvania.

The group included women and men who were reluctant to support either candidate, including a lifelong conservative voter who would rather sit out than vote for Trump, a millennial who supported Bernie Sanders in the primary but has been persuaded by Clinton, and a middle school teacher who says Trump "lost" her when he began denigrating Muslims.

"When I looked at my Muslim students and I knew he was talking about them, he lost me," said Judy McDermott, who remains "really undecided."

Hillary Clinton shows strength over Trump in one of history's weirdest, wildest debates. Yet some left the first debate impossibly conflicted and even more pessimistic than when they arrived.

"Hillary Clinton is not a good candidate and Donald Trump is just a despicable person," Nicole Gerson, an attorney in Philadelphia, reflected after the debate. She said Trump's criticism of Clinton steered her away from the Democrat but not in his direction.

"I'm actually thinking of voting for Gary Johnson," she said, naming the Libertarian candidate. "Maybe the third party will finally become more viable so we're not left with such extreme candidates. It's a vote for the future."

Title: Study Finds Facebook's Fact-Checking Efforts May Have Unintended Consequences

Article:

In a recent study conducted by MIT, it has been revealed that Facebook's efforts to combat fake news may have unintended consequences. The study found that the platform's fact-checking warnings may inadvertently lead users to assume that unmarked content is accurate.

David Rand, one of the authors of the report and a professor at the MIT Sloan School of Management, explained, "Putting a warning on some content is going to make you think, to some extent, that all of the other content without the warning might have been checked and verified."

The researchers have coined this phenomenon the "implied truth effect." Given the vast scale of Facebook's platform, which has 1.25 billion daily users, and the sheer amount of content posted, fact-checkers are unable to keep up.

The study involved over 6,000 participants who were shown a variety of real and fake news headlines as they would appear on Facebook. Half of the group was shown stories without any fact-checking tags, while the other half was shown a typical Facebook feed consisting of a mix of tagged and untagged posts.

The results showed that the use of "false" tags, which are used to flag inaccurate content, significantly reduced participants' willingness to share fake stories from 29.2% to 16.1%. However, the study also found that unmarked false stories were believed to be true and shared 36.2% of the time.

One-fifth of the study's participants believed that unmarked posts had already been fact-checked.

Rand, who is an unpaid advisor to Facebook's efforts to combat fake news, suggests that one solution is to employ more fact-checkers so that all news content posted to Facebook is checked. He also suggests that ordinary Facebook users could be recruited to do this work.

While many people assume that allowing Facebook users to do this work would make the situation worse, given the partisan nature of content already on the site, Rand's research has found the opposite. In fact, this is something Facebook is already considering. In December, it announced it would be hiring some part-time "community reviewers" who will help corroborate or debunk content flagged by the company's automated systems.

Rand concludes, "If, in addition to putting warnings on things fact-checkers find to be false, you also put verification panels on things fact-checkers find to be true, then that solves the problem because there's no longer any ambiguity. If you see a story without a label, you know it simply hasn't been checked."

Facebook did not respond to questions about the study's findings.

Title: Trump Announces Potential Vice Presidential Picks as Convention Nears

Article:

In a series of developments on Monday, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump named three potential running mates for the upcoming party convention in Cleveland later this month. The three individuals named were Iowa Senator Joni Ernst, Arkansas Senator Tom Cotton, and Indiana Governor Mike Pence.

Trump spent time with Pence and his family on Sunday, and was due to meet Ernst in New Jersey on Monday. Ernst, a first-term senator and Tea Party endorsee, made headlines in 2014 with her campaign ad featuring her background of growing up on an Iowa farm and her promise to "know how to cut pork" in Washington. In 2015, she delivered the Republican response to Barack Obama's State of the Union address.

Cotton, a 39-year-old senator who has been mentioned as a potential 2020 presidential candidate, has not been as often named among potential Trump vice presidential picks as Pence and Ernst. In his NBC interview, Trump praised Cotton for his performance on "Meet the Press" and said he was "great" despite a "one-sided" interview by Chuck Todd.

Trump's choice of vice president has been a topic of much speculation, with some names such as Newt Gingrich, Chris Christie, and Jeff Sessions also being mentioned. However, Gingrich, who has expressed interest in the position, may be too forthright, as he recently criticized Trump for "screwing up" the election.

The convention, which starts on July 18, is expected to be a major event for the Republican party, with many big names set to speak. Possible speakers include former Indiana basketball coach Bobby Knight, New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady, and boxing promoter Don King. However, some celebrities, such as Super Bowl-winning Chicago Bears coach Mike Ditka, have passed on the convention.

Trump's daughter Ivanka predicted that the convention would be "a great combination of our great politicians, but also great American businessmen and women and leaders across industry and leaders across really all sectors." She added that the convention would be "a convention unlike any we've ever seen."

The Trump campaign has also been in touch with aides to Texas Senator Ted Cruz, who has reportedly been trying to win a speaking slot. Other potential speakers include former United Nations ambassador John Bolton, West Virginia Senator Shelley Moore Capito, and Washington representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers.

Trump's choice of vice president will be a crucial decision for his campaign, and it is expected that he will use his business acumen to put together a program that appeals directly to the American people. Ohio Republican party chairman Matt Borges said, "He's going to have to bring all his skills to bear to make this work, not just in Cleveland, but for the next four months."

Title: White House Tensions Mount as 'Saturday Night Live' Skit Sparks Controversy Over Sean Spicer's Portrayal

Article:

The portrayal of White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer in a recent 'Saturday Night Live' sketch has caused a stir within the White House, with sources close to President Trump expressing discomfort and concern over the gum-chomping, super soaker-wielding caricature of Spicer, played by actress Melissa McCarthy in drag.

According to sources, it was not just the lampooning of Spicer as a press secretary who makes up facts, but his portrayal by a woman that was most problematic for the president. The unflattering send-up by a female comedian was not considered helpful for Spicer's longevity in the high-profile job, where he has struggled to strike the right balance between representing an administration that views the media as the "opposition party," and developing a functional relationship with the press.

The White House's discomfort was evident in Trump's uncharacteristic Twitter silence over the weekend, and sources said the caricature of Spicer by McCarthy struck a nerve and was upsetting to the press secretary and his allies.

On Monday, Spicer was traveling aboard Air Force One from Florida to Washington, D.C., and joked about the sketch in an interview with Extra, saying, "Melissa McCarthy needs to slow down on the gum chewing; way too many pieces in there."

Spicer's allies were trying to put a positive spin on the incident, with one person close to Spicer saying, "He takes the job seriously but does not take himself that seriously." This person added that the instant-viral skit helped Spicer reach a new level of fame and that he should "embrace it."

However, on Tuesday, Spicer faces the uncomfortable task of facing reporters once again in the briefing room, where the elephant in the room will be the unflattering McCarthy caricature. White House sources said they expect him to cut the tension with humor, and that he has already been on a charm offensive, reaching out to reporters and wishing them happy birthdays, and making self-effacing jokes about his first stumble out of the gate.

Spicer has been fighting to repair his troubling first impression behind the lectern, where he took no questions and made false statements about the crowd size at Trump's inauguration, losing some of his credibility with the room of reporters he faces off with every day. Internally, people close to Trump are eager to point out that Spicer was not Trump's first choice for the high-profile position of press secretary, but that Chief of Staff Reince Priebus pushed for the former Republican National Committee spokesman to get the job.

The "SNL" clip was seen by some in Trump's orbit as devastating because it was accurate. One Trump ally said, "I thought they had Sean down pretty good." In a phone interview on Monday afternoon, Spicer tried to tack away from the skit, saying, "I would much rather have the focus be on the president's agenda and the success he's having." When pressed about his own reaction to the skit, he demurred, saying, "It doesn't really matter what I think."

Title: The Influence of Hard-Line Faction on Speaker Boehner and the Government Shutdown

Article:

The ongoing government shutdown has shed light on the significant influence of a small group of hard-line House Republican members, who have reportedly forced Speaker John Boehner to abandon his initial plan for a temporary government funding bill.

In mid-September, Boehner, in a statement, acknowledged the diversity within his caucus, stating, "We've got 233 members—all of whom have their own plan. It's tough to get them on the same track. We got there."

Boehner's plan, which would have likely avoided the shutdown by allowing a symbolic vote on defunding the Affordable Care Act, was abandoned due to the hard-liners' insistence on a harder stance.

The following day, Boehner held a rally in the Capitol, celebrating a government funding bill vote that also defunded the health care law. Several members present at the rally, including those who had attempted a coup on the House floor in January, were part of this hard-line faction.

Representative Steve King of Iowa, one of the hard-liners, commented, "I think the speaker is stronger today than he was yesterday. And he was stronger yesterday than he was the day before. If we continue in that direction, we're going to be in pretty good shape."

Despite the 30 hard-liners predominantly occupying safe seats in deep-red districts, they face minimal pressure from their constituents. Representative Ted Yoho, a freshman Republican from Florida, stated, "I come from a very conservative area, and my constituents are saying, 'Don't blink, don't cave in, don't back up.'"

The question on everyone's mind in Washington is whether Boehner will ultimately yield and bring up what's called a "clean CR" – the short-term spending bill the Senate passed with Obamacare funding intact. This bill is believed to pass easily on the House floor with a combination of Democratic and Republican votes.

Representative Marlin Stutzman, another hard-liner, argues that passing a clean CR at this time would be detrimental to the Republican conference and weaken Boehner's negotiating ability in the future.

David Hopkins, a political scientist at Boston College, suggests that the hard-liners' actions could potentially threaten Boehner's speakership, as they are not viewed as allies by this faction and may attempt to depose him as speaker.

Because Republicans have a relatively slim majority in the House, the hard-liners wield more power than their numbers would suggest. Hopkins estimates that at least 50 other Republicans are hesitant to distance themselves from the hard-liners, fearing reprisal from outside activist groups or primary challenges.

The remaining Republicans have not taken steps to discourage the hard-liners, according to Hopkins. He states, "The way this has gotten portrayed has been the villains in this story are these 30 guys on the end, and the innocent victims are the rest of the Republican caucus. And I think the rest of the Republican caucus is implicated in this strategy. They've gone along."

As long as the majority of Republicans continue to align with the hard-liners, there is no reason to expect Boehner to deviate from their stance.

Title: Freedom Caucus Threatens to Release Own Tax Reform Plan as Deadline Looms

The House Freedom Caucus, a conservative group of Republican lawmakers, has warned White House officials that they may release their own tax reform plan if the administration and GOP leaders do not act swiftly on a unified plan.

On Thursday, Freedom Caucus Chairman Mark Meadows (R-N.C.) and Vice Chairman Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) delivered this message to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn, and White House legislative liaison Marc Short during a meeting at the White House. The White House officials expressed concern about the Freedom Caucus releasing their own legislation, fearing it could prevent Republicans from uniting behind one plan.

Meadows downplayed the possibility of the group releasing their own legislation, stating that the White House has assured him that action is imminent. However, conservatives are eager to deliver on a major campaign promise after the failure of the Obamacare repeal bill in the Senate. If necessary, they are prepared to forge ahead on their own.

"I'm not threatening my own tax bill if we don't get our way," Meadows said. "At the same time, if we don't make decisions in the near term on what we're going to do, [we might] put forth something."

The White House officials would prefer to avoid dealing with dissent from the Freedom Caucus. However, they are also concerned about keeping conservatives in the fold after President Trump cut a budget deal this week with Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.), surprising his own party.

When Mnuchin met with Republicans on Friday morning and asked them to vote for the deal, he was jeered and hissed by the room. Trump has encouraged legislators to "hurry" on a tax plan in September, but debates are still ongoing between the House and the Senate on specifics, including whether to allow immediate business expensing and deciding how much the corporate tax rate can be lowered. Trump has repeatedly pushed for a 15 percent rate, even as some of his top advisers say it is not mathematically possible.

The possibility of the Freedom Caucus going rogue on tax reform has alarmed administration and Capitol Hill Republicans working on the issue. GOP leaders believe that a single, unified tax bill backed by Trump, the House, and the Senate is critical to success.

Meadows stated that his conversations with the White House and House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) are about making decisions and starting debates on the merits of rates and expensing models, rather than allowing the so-called Big Six or Secret Six to negotiate something and present it to the rest of the GOP conference.

Conservatives are desperate for a win to show to constituents back home. An antsy Meadows listed six major tax reform questions that have yet to be answered, from the exact corporate tax rate to how business expensing will be handled. "Those are six items that you and I can't answer, and if we can't answer them, then we don't have any idea what we're doing on tax reform," he said.

Meadows also mentioned that several Freedom Caucus members are crafting tax legislation. Axios reported earlier this week that one such plan would lower the corporate tax rate to 16 percent, a more aggressive cut than the Big Six believes Congress can achieve.

However, the meeting appears to have persuaded conservatives to hold off—at least for now. "The only way that a plan from the Freedom Caucus would be introduced is if there is inaction on behalf of the Big Six, and we're still talking about principles weeks from now," said Meadows, who argued that there was "no need" for his group to drop a plan at the moment.

"I'm not saying that I'll never put out a bill," he continued. "But as long as they put out a bill and negotiate in good faith over the next few weeks, there will be no Freedom Caucus bill or a need for a Freedom Caucus bill."

Title: California and New Jersey Primaries Yield Mixed Results for Democrats, Republicans in Midterm Elections

Article:

In a series of primary elections held across eight U.S. states on Tuesday, California and New Jersey emerged as key battlegrounds for the upcoming midterm elections, with Democrats and Republicans vying for control of the U.S. House of Representatives and the Governor's seat in California.

California's unique electoral system, which advances the top two vote-getters to the election regardless of party, raised concerns for Democrats in conservative suburbs south of Los Angeles. However, Democratic candidates managed to overcome these challenges and advance to the final vote, as did Republican John Cox in the race for Governor.

In the 48th Congressional District, where voters chose Democrat Hillary Clinton over President Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election but re-elected longtime Republican Representative Dana Rohrabacher, the battle for a place on the November ballot was particularly dramatic. With 414 of 415 precincts reporting early Wednesday, Rohrabacher easily won a spot on the November ballot. Two Democrats, Harley Rouda and Hans Keirstead, were next, separated by fewer than 100 votes, leaving the race too close to call. About 1,000 votes behind the two Democrats was Republican Scott Baugh. If the final tally puts him ahead of them, it could set up a general election fight between Rohrabacher and his fellow Republican, ending Democrats' chances to take that seat.

In the race for Governor, Democrat Gavin Newsom's first-place finish over a field of 27 candidates was expected. However, Republican John Cox's presence as the second candidate to advance to the November ballot could potentially boost Republican voter turnout, improving the party's chances in Congressional races.

In New Jersey, establishment-backed Democrats muscled past liberal challengers in key congressional races, setting up contests in November that will test the question of whether more moderate candidates will fare better against Republicans in swing districts. In southern New Jersey, state Sen. Jeff Van Drew, a conservative Democrat, appeared set to prevail over left-leaning candidates. He will face Republican Seth Grossman, a former city and county official, who emerged from a four-way contest.

In a suburban New Jersey district, former Obama official Tom Malinowski was well ahead of two Democrats backed by independent liberal groups and will take on the moderate Republican Leonard Lance in what is expected to be a competitive race. Democrats also hope to capture two other Republican-held seats in the state.

Republicans control both chambers of Congress. While Democrats need only a net total of two seats to take command of the Senate, Democratic senators must defend a bevy of seats in rural states such as Indiana, Montana, North Dakota, and West Virginia that supported Trump two years ago.

Voters on Tuesday also went to the polls to choose candidates in primaries in Iowa, Mississippi, Alabama, Montana, South Dakota, and New Mexico. A number of women won Democratic contests, continuing a trend that began earlier this year. Women will represent the party in key House races in Iowa, New Jersey, and New Mexico, based on Tuesday's results.

Title: Hagel Acknowledges Potential Ground Force Deployment in Iraq, Emphasizes No Combat Troops

Article:

In a significant development, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has acknowledged that he may consider recommendations to place ground forces in Iraq to assist local forces in locating targets, but clarified that these forces would not engage in combat. Hagel made these statements during an interview with CNN at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in California.

President Obama, during the G20 summit in Australia, reiterated his stance on U.S. ground forces in Iraq, stating that he has not changed his mind about deploying them. He also emphasized that General Dempsey, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has not advised him to send U.S. troops to fight.

However, President Obama did not rule out the possibility of deploying ground troops in the most dire of circumstances, such as if ISIL were to obtain a nuclear weapon. In such a scenario, he suggested, General Dempsey would recommend sending U.S. ground troops to retrieve the weapon, and he would order the operation.

During the same seminar, Hagel declined to comment on whether any top members of the Khorasan Group had been killed by U.S. airstrikes in Syria. He did, however, affirm that the group still poses a significant threat, planning and plotting attacks against U.S. interests, particularly in Europe.

The seminar, which also featured Republican Sen. John McCain, former defense secretaries Leon Panetta and Robert Gates, and Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson, saw a heated discussion on the White House and Pentagon's strategy to combat ISIS.

Sen. McCain, in a blistering critique, stated that "no one outside the Joint Chiefs of Staff believes we have a strategy" to defeat and degrade ISIS, as set forth by the administration. Former defense secretaries Panetta and Gates, who have recently published critical books about Obama, also participated in the discussion.

In a related note, Jeh Johnson emphasized that the potential for a lone wolf attack inspired by ISIS poses a significant threat to the United States.

Title: Rep. Rashida Tlaib Breaks Ranks, Announces Impeachment Resolution for President Trump

Article:

In a move that breaks ranks with House leadership, Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-MI) has announced her plans to file a resolution to impeach President Trump. The freshman progressive made the announcement on Wednesday, surrounded by a group of supporters who wore shirts and held signs with statements such as "He's a Racist" and "#TimeToImpeach."

Tlaib, in a statement, expressed her concerns about the ongoing constitutional crisis and its impact on the ability of Congress to address pressing issues. "We want to be able to work on these economic justice issues, racial justice issues and everything," she said. "But guess what? There is a wall there, and a constitutional crisis that is not going to be able to have us be able to do our jobs as American Congress members to push a lot of these agendas forward."

Tlaib argued that the last election was a mandate for impeachment proceedings against Trump. "This last election was a calling," she continued. "I mean we saw record turnout in an election year where people wanted to elect the jury that would begin the impeachment proceedings to Donald Trump."

In an attempt to maintain party unity, Tlaib argued that her party agrees the president needs to be impeached. "This is not to say that we disagree," she continued. "I think that every single colleague of mine agrees there are impeachable offenses. That's one thing we all agree on."

Tlaib's decision to file the motion is contrary to the desire of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other senior Democrat leaders. The Washington Examiner reports that Democrat Caucus Chair, Rep. Hakeem Jeffries (D-NY), called the announcement "premature."

Speaker Pelosi has continually pushed back on the notion that the Democrats' priority is impeachment. Party leaders maintain they're waiting to hear from Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation of Russian meddling in the 2016 election before making their final decision.

"When the facts are known, then we can make a judgment," Pelosi said last week according to Fox News. In a February interview with Rolling Stone Magazine, Pelosi shared her concerns about impeachment, finding the process to be "disruptive" to the nation.

Tlaib's move comes at a divisive time in the Democrat Party, as House Democrats attempt to establish a measure addressing recent anti-Semitic remarks from freshman Democrats Rep. Ilhan Omar and Rep. Tlaib. Senior leaders want to maintain Jewish support; however, the newer House members want the measure to include protections from Islamophobia.

Rep. Tlaib also faces her own turmoil as she stands accused of breaking campaign rules. Fox News reports Tlaib is under questioning for campaign records that reveal she paid herself $17,500 after midterm elections. The FEC rules no one can receive salary payments "beyond the date he or she is no longer a candidate."

After making the public impeachment announcement from Capitol Hill, Rep. Tlaib took to Twitter to announce the resolution would be introduced later this month. "Today, I announced that later this month, I will be introducing a resolution to have the Judiciary Committee move on investigating grounds for impeachment," Rep. Tlaib wrote. "Our democracy must be protected."

Title: Immigration Reform Back on the Agenda: A Shift in GOP Strategy Amidst Record Hispanic Voter Turnout

Article:

In a significant development, top Republicans have signaled a renewed interest in immigration reform, a topic that has been largely absent from the legislative agenda for the past five years. This sudden focus on immigration reform underscores the growing concern among Republicans about the increasing disengagement of Latinos from their party.

The resurgence of immigration as a priority issue in Washington, D.C., signals a potential shift in the Republican Party's approach, which has been marked by conservative hardliners setting the agenda on immigration after several failed attempts to pass a bill during the Bush administration.

Despite the challenges of enacting a comprehensive overhaul, given the deep-rooted opposition within GOP ranks to creating a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants, the renewed interest in tackling the issue suggests a significant change in the political landscape.

This development is another indication of the Republicans' acknowledgment of the need to adapt to changing demographics. The 2012 elections saw a record Hispanic voter turnout, which significantly contributed to President Barack Obama's victory.

Kansas Sen. Jerry Moran, who is running for the National Republican Senatorial Committee chairmanship, emphasized the importance of addressing the immigration issue and engaging with Latino voters. "It's clear to me," Moran said, "if Republicans are going to have the opportunity to be in the majority, we clearly have to determine how we deal with minority and Latino voters. In some fashion, the way we have dealt with immigration gives us a black eye. And we need to figure out how to talk about issues and pursue policies that matter to Latino, Hispanic voters."

Republicans are not the only ones under pressure. Latino leaders have expressed expectations for Obama to deliver on his promise of immigration reform, a promise he failed to fulfill during his first term.

"The Latino giant is wide awake, cranky, and taking names," said Eliseo Medina, secretary-treasurer of the Service Employees International Union and a leader of Latino mobilization in battleground states.

Obama has indicated that he plans to pursue a broad immigration reform proposal early next year. In the past, the president had promised to introduce a comprehensive immigration reform bill during his first year in office but did not follow through due to a lack of Republican support. Facing pressure from the Latino community to show progress on the issue, Obama took executive action last summer to allow certain young immigrants to remain in the country.

Vice President Joe Biden expressed optimism about the prospects of immigration reform, stating, "I feel very optimistic about, in my view, immigration reform." Biden added, "It's a different day."

Title: White House Acknowledges Involvement in Shaping Benghazi Talking Points, Emphasizing Stability Image

Article:

The White House admitted on Wednesday that it withheld an email from Congress and the media regarding Susan Rice's controversial "talking points" about the 2012 Benghazi terrorist attack due to the memo not being directly related to the attack itself.

White House press secretary Jay Carney stated, "This document was explicitly not about Benghazi, but about the general dynamic in the Muslim world at the time."

A government watchdog group obtained an email this week that revealed the White House's involvement in shaping the administration's message about the September 11, 2012, attacks in Benghazi, Libya, to portray them as spontaneous anti-U.S. protests that did not occur in that city. Four Americans, including U.S. Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens, were killed in the attack.

The internal email, dated September 14, 2012, was sent from Ben Rhodes, President Obama's assistant and deputy national security adviser, to White House press officials. In the email, Mr. Rhodes listed as a "goal" the White House's desire "To underscore that these protests are rooted in an Internet video, and not a broader failure or policy."

The email, titled "RE: PREP CALL with Susan, Saturday at 4:00 pm ET," detailed White House involvement in preparing Rice, then-U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, for her upcoming appearances on Sunday television talk shows.

The email and others provide the clearest evidence to date that top presidential aides sought to use the anti-American protests sweeping across the Middle East in 2012, as well as the aftermath of the Benghazi terrorist attack, to project an image of President Obama's foreign policy as "steady and statesmanlike," just weeks before his re-election.

Mr. Carney explained the White House's decision to withhold the Rhodes memo from congressional and media inquiries, stating, "It was explicitly not about Benghazi."

"The overall issue of unrest in the Muslim world and the danger posed by these protests... was very much a topic in the news at the time," Mr. Carney added, referring to protests in Egypt and elsewhere directed at the U.S. over an anti-Muslim video produced in America.

Under the heading "Goals" for Rice's Sunday talk show appearances, Mr. Rhodes wrote to other White House communications officials that a main objective of Rice's interviews should be to "reinforce the president and the administration's strength and steadiness in dealing with difficult challenges." A second goal was to link the Benghazi attack—and those on other diplomatic sites across the Middle East—to the obscure anti-Muslim video and to insist that the protests were not "rooted" in a "broader failure of [administration] policy."

Title: Unemployment Claims Reach 17 Million in Three Weeks; Senate Stalemate Over Small Business Aid

In the past three weeks, nearly 17 million Americans have filed for unemployment benefits, with long lines of people waiting for food assistance in various states. Many states are struggling to process the influx of unemployment claims.

"How long it takes will vary by states," said Secretary of Labor Eugene Scalia. In Washington, Thursday, Senate Republicans pushed for an additional $250 billion to help small businesses in dire need, but the aid was blocked by Democrats who are demanding a $500 billion bill to offer more support to health care providers and state and local governments.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) stated during a speech on the floor, "We need more funding, and we need it fast." However, Democrats argue that the bill was designed to fail and was a political stunt.

Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-MD) argued from the Senate floor, "This was in fact, designed to fail."

The unemployment rate is feared to reach 15% soon, and White House officials are eager to stave off a severe recession. Companies in areas free from outbreaks could potentially reopen in May, but the decision to restart the economy is largely out of the federal government's hands, as many governors have issued stay-at-home orders through the end of May or later.

President Trump stated during his daily coronavirus briefing, "We're at the top of the hill. Pretty sure we're at the top of the hill, and now we're going downward. In some cases, we've already started that process."

Health officials say social isolation methods are working, and Dr. Anthony Fauci now predicts the American death toll will be 60,000, down from earlier, more dire, predictions of 100,000 to 240,000.

"We have to be prepared that when the infections start to rear their heads again that we have in place a very aggressive and effective way to identify, isolate, contact, trace," Dr. Fauci told CBS News.

Meanwhile, a bipartisan group of senators is calling on China to immediately close all wet markets where fresh meat and produce is sold in unsanitary conditions. This comes after the director of the Chinese CDC admitted, "The origin of the new coronavirus is the wildlife sold illegally in a Wuhan seafood market."

Title: Obama Vows to Pursue Executive Action on Immigration Despite Congressional Opposition

 Article:

President Barack Obama, during a diplomatic trip to Asia, has reaffirmed his commitment to taking executive action on immigration reform, despite facing opposition from Congress and Republican leaders.

At a joint news conference with Myanmar dissident leader Aung San Suu Kyi, Obama expressed his frustration with the ongoing stalemate on the issue, stating, "They have the ability to fix the system. What they do not have is the ability to do is expect me to stand by with a broken system in perpetuity."

The president emphasized that unless Congress issues legislation first, he is determined to act before the end of the year on proposals that are expected to include extending amnesty and work permits to possibly millions of illegal immigrants. Obama stated, "I gave the House over a year to at least give a vote on the Senate bill. They failed to do so."

Republican leaders, such as Speaker John Boehner, have threatened that Obama's decision to act will lead to an adversarial relationship with Congress. Boehner reportedly told reporters, "We're going to fight the president tooth and nail if he continues down this path."

In response, Obama warned Republicans against a governance approach where "having a disagreement on a single issue suddenly [becomes] a deal-breaker on every issue." He added, "Democracy cannot work that way."

The president's comments come as Republicans grapple with a strategy to derail his plans. A rift is developing within the party about the best way forward, threatening to undermine the party's post-election pledges to proceed with unity.

One potential strategy being considered is to leverage the upcoming spending bill to force Obama to stand down. At least 50 conservative lawmakers are pushing for this approach, which could lead to a government shutdown if the president refuses to comply.

Another option under consideration is to allow the executive action to take effect but work to undermine its provisions incrementally over the coming months. A lawsuit over the president's misuse of his authority is also an idea that has been floated.

The timing for Obama's announcement has not been decided, but reports suggest it may be made as soon as next week. The details of the plan are still being finalized, but it is believed that the proposal may grant amnesty to as many as 5 million illegal immigrants and authorize amnesty for parents of children who are U.S. citizens or legal residents, giving them the right to obtain work documents.

Immigration rights supporters and Democrats are urging Obama to extend amnesty to as many migrants as possible. In recent days, they have been rallying behind the president's decision to take action, arguing that it is not out of step with other presidents who have acted unilaterally on major issues.

Title: U.S. Faces Economic Uncertainty as Fiscal Cliff Negotiations Loom

Article:

As the deadline for the Fiscal Cliff negotiations approaches, the political drama unfolding in Washington is far from solving the nation's budget woes. The Budget Act of 2011 mandates a nine-year $1.2 trillion deficit reduction program, or automatic cuts in annual defense and non-entitlement outlays each equal to $54.7 billion, set to take effect on January 1. Simultaneously, the Bush Tax cuts, the 2 percentage point payroll tax holiday, and other programs expire.

The combined impact of these spending reductions and tax increases could lead to catastrophic consequences for the economy. Unemployment could surge past 15 percent, state government finances could collapse, homeowners could default on mortgages, and hundreds of banks could fail.

To avoid this calamity, President Obama and House Republicans are expected to agree on a compromise that involves raising taxes on high-income Americans by $100 to $150 billion and curbing spending by an equal amount. However, these efforts may still not be enough to prevent the economy from slipping into recession, depriving the federal government of tax revenues and further exacerbating the budget gap.

The federal deficit currently exceeds $1 trillion, up from $161 billion in 2007, the last year before the financial collapse. Spending has increased by approximately $1 trillion, as outlays for Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, and other entitlements have increased by an amount equivalent to the entire 2013 defense budget.

By the end of the decade, runaway entitlement spending will require drastic cuts to the military or crippling many other domestic spending programs to prevent ballooning deficits. The only reasonable solution, according to the article, is to raise the Social Security retirement age to 70 and pattern U.S. health care reforms after other national systems that better contain costs.

The Germans and Dutch spend one-third less on health care than the United States, as their governments more aggressively regulate prices, better ration care, and spend less on lawsuits. Democrats, hamstrung by unions, are reluctant to require Americans to work longer, and are too beholden to tort lawyers and the medical establishment for campaign support. Republicans, on the other hand, refuse to admit more competition to adequately slow rocketing health care costs.

Over the next decade, without a significantly higher retirement age, effective price controls in health care, and tort reform, federal spending and the national debt will skyrocket. Mounting interest payments, investor reluctance to buy U.S. Treasurys, and consequent draconian cuts in spending will thrust the United States into the crisis now gripping Greece and Spain.

More immediately, even modest tax increases and spending cuts threaten a second recession, as President Obama and Congress have failed to address the dysfunctions that created the bubble and bust of the 2000s and made the economy overly dependent on deficit spending. From 2001 to 2005, the trade deficit doubled to over $700 billion, due to subsidized imports from China, restrictions on U.S. sales into the Middle Kingdom, and rising oil prices. This loss of demand for U.S.-made goods and services should have instigated a recession; however, Chinese and Middle East oil exporters stepped up purchases of U.S. securities, helping to finance questionable mortgages, car loans, and credit card debt. Americans spent more than they earned, and the boom continued into 2007. When homeowners and other borrowers could no longer service their debts, defaults and bankruptcies resulted, and the economy crashed.

A huge trade deficit with China and on oil continues, but now the federal government is doing the extra spending and borrowing for us. If budget negotiations reduce the deficit by $200 to $300 billion, as is likely, GDP will contract $350 to 500 billion, and unemployment will rise above 10 percent.

President Obama and House Republicans indicate no interest in confronting Beijing to force a more equitable trading relationship with the Middle Kingdom. Slashing oil imports requires the President to permit more drilling in the Gulf, off the Atlantic and Pacific coasts, and in Alaska, and for Republicans to embrace alternative energy sources and more aggressive conservation measures.

In conclusion, absent major changes in trade and energy policies to boost domestic demand and growth, budget deficit reduction is not possible without another long, hard recession. And absent genuine deficit reduction, the country is headed for economic chaos by the end of the decade.

Title: Supreme Court's June Medical Services Decision: A Narrow Victory for Abortion Rights and a Potential Future Challenge

In a 5-4 ruling on Monday, the U.S. Supreme Court struck down a Louisiana law that required abortion providers to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital, preserving access to abortion services for Louisiana's residents. However, the decision, in the case of June Medical Services v. Russo, may not be as favorable to abortion rights as it initially appears, according to legal writer Mark Joseph Stern in Slate.

The outcome of the case is a victory for Louisiana's three remaining clinics, which can now remain open. But, as Stern explains, the Supreme Court's ruling is not an unqualified endorsement of a constitutional right to choose. In fact, the chief justice, John Roberts, cut back protections for women seeking abortions and laid the groundwork for a future erosion, if not outright reversal, of Roe v. Wade.

The Supreme Court's ruling in June Medical Services is similar to its 2016 ruling in the case Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt, which struck down a similar law in Texas. In Whole Woman's Health, the Court ruled that Texas' admitting privileges law imposed an 'undue burden' on the constitutional right to abortion. Since Louisiana's law is indistinguishable from Texas', it should have been plainly unconstitutional under Whole Woman's Health. However, the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals effectively defied precedent by upholding the Louisiana regulation.

The big question in June Medical was whether Roberts, who dissented in Whole Woman's Health, would nonetheless invalidate Louisiana's law on the grounds of stare decisis, or respect for precedent. And that's exactly what Roberts did, with a catch. The Court actually splintered 4-1-4: Justice Stephen Breyer wrote for the four liberals, the chief justice wrote an opinion concurring in the judgment, and the four other conservatives dissented. Although Roberts supported Breyer's bottom line holding, he declined to join Breyer's opinion.

Because the chief justice's opinion is narrower than Breyer's, it is 'controlling' - that is, it's the law of the land. Advocates on both sides of the abortion debate will thus be scrutinizing Roberts' concurrence for years to come. And it gives both sides reason for encouragement.

According to Stern, Roberts' decision in June Medical does not necessarily mean that Roe v. Wade will not be overturned at some point. In short, Roberts - alone among the conservatives - agreed with the liberals that Louisiana cannot pretend its law creates no real burden for abortion patients in the face of ample evidence that it would shutter clinics. But the chief justice then whittled down the holding of Whole Woman's Health, replacing its balancing test with a stingier rule that may give states broader leeway to restrict abortion. Roberts expressly disavowed Breyer's test, which weighed a law's benefits to patients against its burdens.

Title: New Pass-Through Tax Loophole in GOP Tax Bill Favors Wealthy at Expense of Most Americans, Analysis Reveals

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy, the new pass-through tax loophole in the recently passed Republican tax bill is drawing criticism for its potential to disproportionately benefit the wealthy at the expense of the average American.

According to reports, Republican leaders, including Senator Bob Corker, who has a real estate partnership in Tennessee, have denied that the loophole was included to win over his vote. With the GOP able to afford to lose only two votes, Senator John McCain's absence due to his cancer treatment has made Corker more influential.

Despite Republican claims that the provision was not "airdropped" into the tax bill during conference committee negotiations, and that its main purpose was to ensure pass-through businesses were not unfairly treated due to the corporate tax cut, the loophole has been criticized as another example of Congress' efforts to maximize benefits for the wealthy.

President Trump has claimed that the tax bill would "cost me a fortune" and that his accountants are "going crazy now." However, this claim has been labeled as "fake news." With the new loophole, the president's statement has become even more questionable.

The Joint Committee on Taxation estimates that the 20% deduction for pass-through income would cost the government $414.5 billion in lost revenue over 10 years. This is approximately 29 times the annual federal funding for the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP), which covers nearly nine million children from low-income families.

The tax bill's generosity towards real estate titans stands in stark contrast to its stinginess towards the average wage earner. Average wage earners who would initially receive modest tax cuts would see these benefits disappear by 2025. Homeowners and others in high-cost states, such as California, New Jersey, and New York, would see their once-sizeable deductions for state and local taxes shrink to a maximum of $10,000 a year, which could potentially reduce home values.

Further, the tax bill would permanently change how tax brackets are adjusted for inflation, pushing more people into higher tax brackets over time even if they received only modest raises in salary.

The new pass-through tax loophole has raised concerns about the fairness and impact of the tax bill on different income groups and regions, with critics arguing that it disproportionately benefits the wealthy at the expense of the average American.

Title: A New Era: Unprecedented Shift in Media Coverage of President-elect Trump

Article:

In an unexpected turn of events, the media's coverage of President-elect Donald Trump has shown a marked shift in tone, mirroring the inclusiveness demonstrated by Trump himself in his post-election interactions with former critics. This change in approach has been met with a mix of praise and criticism, as some view it as a positive evolution, while others see it as a blatant flip-flop.

President-elect Trump, who was not expected to win the election by many, has reached out to critics such as Mitt Romney, Nikki Haley, and Rick Perry, who had previously criticized him harshly during the campaign. Trump's temporary truce with the media, even visiting the New York Times, has been noted, as well as his rethinking of some campaign promises, such as his abandonment of support for waterboarding, his open-mindedness on climate change, and his decision to keep two key parts of Obamacare.

However, this positive assessment is balanced with more critical perspectives. Some argue that Trump's post-election evolution is merely a series of flip-flops, while others view it as a necessary adaptation to the role of President-elect. The media's focus on Trump's evolving views has been met with a range of reactions, from left-handed compliments to criticism of his campaign promises.

CNN's Fareed Zakaria, who had previously called Trump a "cancer on American democracy," has since expressed hope that Trump will continue to flip-flop on his positions. From the right, Trump critic Kathleen Parker has criticized Trump's campaign promises, while acknowledging her happiness with his new positions.

Trump's efforts to bring establishment Republicans into his administration have also been met with scrutiny, with the media focusing on the potential nomination of Mitt Romney as secretary of State and the appointment of Nikki Haley as U.N. ambassador. The question of whether Trump should divest himself of his real estate empire to avoid conflicts of interest has also been a topic of discussion, as has the role of Jared Kushner in the administration.

The media's coverage of Trump's presidency is expected to remain adversarial, as is the relationship between the media and an incoming leader of the free world. However, those who believe Trump is being covered the way President-elect Obama was may have a short memory, as the media's coverage of Obama was markedly different during the same period.

Title: Supreme Court Ruling on Same-sex Marriage: A New Era of Religious and LGBT Rights Conflict

Article:

In a historic decision, the Supreme Court of the United States has ruled that states cannot ban same-sex marriage, establishing a new civil right and marking a significant victory for gay and lesbian advocates. The ruling, however, has sparked a new wave of debate and potential conflict between religious and LGBT rights.

President Barack Obama, in his response to the ruling, urged celebrants to remember that many Americans oppose same-sex marriage based on deeply held religious beliefs. He emphasized the importance of protecting these beliefs as part of the country's commitment to religious freedom.

The decision, while acknowledging the right of faith groups to object to same-sex marriage, has been met with criticism from more conservative justices and religious groups. They argue that the ruling fails to fully address the First Amendment's "free exercise" clause, which they believe encompasses not just preaching and teaching, but also the "free exercise" of faith in various activities, including religious ceremonies, charitable works, and business operations.

Justice Clarence Thomas, in his dissent, argued that the majority's nod towards religious liberty was a "weak gesture," and that the ruling could have "ruinous consequences." He suggested that the ruling could lead to conflicts between competing definitions of marriage, potentially forcing pastors and churches to participate in and endorse same-sex marriages.

Chief Justice John Roberts and Justice Antonin Scalia also expressed concerns about the potential clash between religious liberty and the new right to same-sex marriage. They raised questions about the implications of religious institutions, such as religious colleges and faith-based adoption agencies, when their practices conflict with the new right to same-sex marriage.

The Catholic Church and Evangelicals, who make up about 25% of the country's population, have pledged to fight the legal implications of the ruling. They fear that their sacred beliefs about marriage and sexuality could be compromised in the face of cultural and legal demands.

The Catholic Church and Evangelicals are not alone in their concerns. Archbishop William Lori of Baltimore, the U.S. Catholic bishops' point-man on religious rights, predicted a surge of legal controversies affecting the organization and running of their ministries. The Catholic Church, in particular, is concerned about the ruling's lack of acknowledgment of their right to follow their teachings when intersecting with the broader society.

The skirmish between religious and LGBT rights is expected to endure for years, potentially leading to casualties on both sides. Russell Moore, president of the Southern Baptist Convention's Ethics & Religious Liberty Commission, called "religious liberty" the "next front in the skirmish in American life."

In his signature scathing style, Justice Scalia accused his colleagues of playing God, stating that the ruling on same-sex marriage "is not of special importance to me." However, he added, "who it is that rules me, is a majority of the nine lawyers on the Supreme Court."

The Supreme Court's ruling on same-sex marriage has undoubtedly opened a new chapter in the ongoing battle between religious and LGBT rights. As the nation moves forward, it remains to be seen how this conflict will unfold and how the two sides will navigate their differences in the years to come.

Title: Ferguson Grand Jury Decision Delayed, Protests Continue as Community Awaits Verdict in Michael Brown Shooting

Article:

Residents in Ferguson, Missouri, remain on edge as the city awaits a decision from a grand jury on whether to indict police officer Darren Wilson for the shooting death of Michael Brown, an 18-year-old unarmed black man. The grand jury decision, initially expected as early as this weekend, is now delayed until Monday at the earliest, according to a federal law enforcement official who spoke to media outlets on condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to comment publicly on the matter.

Protesters took to the streets again Saturday evening, chanting slogans such as "No justice, no peace" and "Mike Brown means, we've got to fight back." They later gathered at the Ferguson police station before moving back into the street when police in riot gear appeared. Two people were arrested for unlawful assembly, according to St. Louis County Police spokesman Brian Schellman.

Authorities have set up barricades around the building where the grand jury has been meeting, as well as in a shopping center parking lot where police set up a makeshift command center in the aftermath of Brown's death. Police and protesters are planning ahead, with police leaders meeting five times with some protest group leaders, resulting in them agreeing to 11 rules of engagement, such as avoiding the use of excessive force and communicating to de-escalate tense situations.

President Obama and Attorney General Eric Holder have called for people to temper their reactions. The president spoke during an ABC News interview, saying people who were upset should not use the grand jury's decision as "an excuse for violence." Holder urged law enforcement officials to minimize the potential for confrontations during demonstrations.

Joining in the call for calm is Michael Brown's father. In a video statement released Thursday, he said he, his family, and the entire region "are hurting... But hurting others and destroying property is not the answer."

If violence or unrest does erupt, Missouri Gov. Jay Nixon will call in the National Guard. He declared a state of emergency earlier this week. Some schools in the area are preparing for what comes next. The Jennings school district decided to close its schools on Monday and Tuesday, lengthening the Thanksgiving break for its students and avoiding having them in school during potential demonstrations.

Regardless of what happens, Wilson reportedly is resigning from Ferguson's police force. Yamiche Alcindor, a reporter for ███, is on the ground in Missouri. Follow her on Twitter for live updates.

Title: Exploring the Alternative: A New Perspective on Allocating Capital and Labor in a Socialist Economy

Article:

In a departure from the traditional capitalist model, a new approach to allocating capital and labor is being proposed, one that prioritizes social equality and addresses regional disparities. This new system aims to move beyond the traditional financial market, focusing on the distribution of capital not just for its highest return, but to support underperforming firms and promote overall social and economic development.

The concept of sectoral councils is central to this new model. In each sector, such as healthcare, education, or manufacturing, workers from the respective firms would elect representatives to a sectoral council. These councils would be responsible for creating plans that benefit the entire sector, with the allocated capital distributed in a manner that improves the productivity and quality of every firm within that sector.

This system also emphasizes equality across sectors, with centralized research and development to ensure equal access to innovative technologies and resources. This multi-layered planning approach includes central planning, sectoral planning, regional planning, and individual firm planning, allowing for a more comprehensive and adaptable economic system.

Economist F.A. Hayek's argument that capitalism is the only system capable of revealing latent information and capacities through markets is acknowledged. However, the counterargument is that capitalism, under its current structure, systematically hides information, while socialism encourages information sharing. Hayek's focus on the capacities of entrepreneurs is recognized, but the proponents of socialism argue that the system should also focus on the potential capacities of ordinary people, particularly their ability to learn and adapt.

Productivity growth in capitalism is typically around 1-2%, with the argument being that this is due to the incentives provided by capitalism. However, it is suggested that workers, given the opportunity, could come up with ideas for increased productivity that could match or even surpass this rate. The benefits of such an approach would extend far beyond productivity, proponents argue.

This new approach to economic planning and resource allocation is a significant departure from the traditional capitalist model. It represents a shift towards a more equitable and adaptable economic system, one that recognizes the potential of all members of society and prioritizes their well-being over the pursuit of profit.

Title: FAA Clears Helicopter in Kobe Bryant Crash for Special Flight Through Foggy Conditions

Article:

In the aftermath of the tragic helicopter crash that took the lives of basketball legend Kobe Bryant, his daughter, and seven others, new details have emerged regarding the flight's clearance. According to The New York Times, the helicopter was given a special flight clearance to navigate through dense fog from Orange County toward the Los Angeles area, allowing it to enter Burbank airspace.

The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has confirmed that the special clearance would have permitted the pilot to fly around Burbank and Van Nuys but not from there onto Calabasas. A FAA official told The Times that a pilot is responsible for determining whether it is safe to fly in current and expected conditions, and for determining flight visibility.

Los Angeles Police Sgt. Yvette Tuning, the LAPD's Air Support Division Watch commander when the crash occurred, stated that police helicopters do not typically fly under such conditions. She explained that while the weather has been favorable most of the winter, she knew that police helicopters were not going to operate in the fog that enveloped the Los Angeles basin.
