Officials in Los Angeles have suggested that the dense fog may have played a role in the crash. Several experts have pointed to the poor flying conditions in the area, and fog is likely to be a key factor in the ongoing investigation, according to the Los Angeles Times.

The Los Angeles County Medical Examiner's Office announced that three bodies were recovered from the scene, but the remains have not been identified. The Sikorsky S-76 helicopter went down in Calabasas, about 30 miles northwest of downtown Los Angeles.

As the investigation continues, federal transportation safety investigators are examining the pilot's history, the chopper's maintenance records, and the records of its owner and operator, according to NTSB board member Jennifer Homendy. The Los Angeles County Sheriff's Office has confirmed that there were nine people listed on the helicopter's manifest, and all are believed to be deceased.

Title: Maryland Congressman Elijah Cummings Passes Away at 68, Known for His Advocacy and Oversight of President Trump

Article:

Maryland Representative Elijah E. Cummings, a prominent figure in U.S. politics, passed away early Thursday at Johns Hopkins Hospital due to complications from longstanding health challenges, according to his congressional office. He was 68.

Born on January 18, 1951, Cummings, a sharecropper's son, rose through the ranks of Maryland politics to become the powerful chairman of the U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Reform. In this role, he led multiple investigations of President Donald Trump's governmental dealings, including probes in 2019 relating to the president's family members serving in the White House.

Cummings' political career spanned decades, beginning with his tenure in the Maryland House of Delegates before winning his congressional seat in a special election in 1996 to replace former Rep. Kweisi Mfume. As chairman of the House Oversight and Reform Committee, Cummings was instrumental in multiple investigations, using his fiery voice to highlight the struggles and needs of inner-city residents.

Notably, Cummings' tenure as chairman coincided with President Trump's administration, during which he faced criticism from the president. In July 2019, Trump referred to Cummings' district as a "rodent-infested mess" where "no human being would want to live." The comments came weeks after Trump drew bipartisan condemnation following his calls for Democratic congresswomen of color to get out of the U.S. "right now," and go back to their "broken and crime-infested countries."

In response, Cummings called for government officials to stop making "hateful, incendiary comments" that only serve to divide and distract the nation from its real problems, including mass shootings and white supremacy.

Throughout his career, Cummings used his oratorical skills to advocate for the poor in his black-majority district, which encompasses a large portion of Baltimore as well as more well-to-do suburbs. He was a firm believer in some much-debated approaches to help the poor and addicted, such as needle exchange programs as a way to reduce the spread of AIDS.

Cummings was an early supporter of Barack Obama's presidential bid in 2008. He chaired the Congressional Black Caucus from 2003 to 2004, employing a hard-charging, explore-every-option style to put the group in the national spotlight.

Cummings was born on a farm in South Carolina and moved to Baltimore as a young boy. Despite being told in grade school that he was too slow to learn and spoke poorly, Cummings proved the counselor wrong, becoming not only a lawyer but one of the most powerful orators in the Maryland House of Delegates. He rose to become House speaker pro tem, the first black delegate to hold the position.

Cummings is survived by his wife, Maya Rockeymoore Cummings, and their two children, as well as five children from a previous marriage. His passing leaves a significant void in the political landscape, as he was a strong voice for the voiceless and a tireless advocate for justice and equality.

Title: "Employee Ownership and Broad-Based Asset Ownership: A New Strategy for Addressing Income Inequality in the United States"

Article:

In the face of escalating income inequality in the United States, a movement is gaining momentum at the community level to address the issue by promoting broad-based ownership of assets. This shift, away from wealth concentration and extraction, is aimed at creating a more equitable distribution of wealth and fostering economic growth.

The Economic Confidence Index, as reported by Gallup, has plummeted by nearly 20 percent over the past 18 months, reflecting the American public's growing disillusionment with the economy. The American Dream, once a symbol of upward mobility, is increasingly out of reach for most Americans.

One solution to this problem lies in employee ownership, a model that has proven effective over several decades. Employee-owned businesses, such as Recology in San Francisco, pay higher wages, offer better retirement benefits, and exhibit increased productivity and profitability compared to traditionally owned companies. Recology, a waste collection and recycling firm with $800 million in revenues, is 100% owned by its 3,000 employees.

Employee ownership is just one of several models being embraced by local coalitions of civic, advocacy, city, and state leaders. Other models include social enterprises, municipally owned enterprises, and B Corporations, which are profit-making firms with a professed aim of social benefit.

The coming wave of company sales from aging baby boomer entrepreneurs presents a unique opportunity to promote employee ownership. Over the next decade, at least 7 million owners of privately held businesses will reach retirement age. If these businesses are sold to employees, they can represent new wealth-building opportunities for millions of Americans.

Cities like New York are already taking steps to advance broad-based ownership. New York has allocated $3.3 million over two years to develop worker cooperatives, and the city is home to the nation's largest worker cooperative, Cooperative Home Health Care Associates, which employs over 2,300 people and generates $60 million in revenues.

Beyond municipal policy, another tool for advancing broad-based ownership is the nation's nearly 1,000 Community Development Finance Institutions (CDFIs), chartered to aid disadvantaged communities. These CDFIs can facilitate and finance business conversions to ESOPs or cooperatives, as demonstrated by the 2014 worker buyout of three rural Maine businesses by the Cooperative Fund of New England and Coastal Enterprises, Inc.

H.R. 2096, the Promotion and Expansion of Employee Ownership Act, could further aid in the development of ESOPs by providing additional tax incentives and technical assistance for conversion. Sixty-eight percent of Americans support employee ownership, and it's no surprise why, given the model's benefits, such as greater job security, local retention, and wealth distribution.

Proven to be stable and sustainable models for economic growth, broad-based ownership models provide an important new strategy for reversing income inequality. As more and more cities and states develop cooperative economic models, financing of broad-based ownership is no longer on the fringe of economic debate; it's just good business.

Marjorie Kelly, a Senior Fellow and Executive Vice-President of the Democracy Collaborative, is among those working towards this shift in broad-based ownership. The 50 by 50 initiative, with a goal of 50 million employee owners by 2050, is one example of the collaborative efforts underway to address income inequality and restore the American Dream.

Title: US Faces Challenges in Responding to Egypt's Political Crisis Following President Morsi's Ouster

Article:

The removal of Egypt's President Mohammed Morsi by the country's military has placed the United States in a delicate position, as it grapples with how to respond to a military coup in a key Middle East partner and a major recipient of US military aid. The days ahead are likely to remain agitated and tense in Egypt, and the US will face criticism from Morsi's supporters, who will argue that the US acquiesced to the illegal removal of an elected leader who had just marked the first year of a four-year term.

The Egyptian military, in an attempt to deflect accusations of a coup, suspended the Morsi-era constitution and announced that the chief justice of Egypt's constitutional court, not a military leader, would fill the presidency until new presidential elections can be held. The new interim president is to be sworn in Thursday.

The military acted to end the country's chaotic political crisis and implement a "roadmap to democracy" that would have the support of Egypt's political factions and foster reconciliation, General Sissi said. The US, in an attempt to appear neutral among the dueling parties, had emphasized that "we don't take sides" and called on all factions to engage with each other and find a nonviolent political solution to their differences.

However, as events in Cairo moved fast and Morsi's ouster looked likely, US officials began shifting their stance. US officials criticized Morsi over his failure to address Egyptians' concerns, particularly his defiant refusal to meet protesters' demands and vow to step down in a televised speech Tuesday.

Thousands of Egyptians celebrated publicly Wednesday night, but it was unclear what path Morsi's many supporters planned to take. Meanwhile, the US military was preparing for the worst in Egypt, dispatching part of a Marine crisis response team stationed in Spain to Sigonella, Italy, to shorten the team's distance from Egypt in case its intervention was needed. The United States also ordered the evacuation of its embassy in Cairo, news reports said.

In May, the US approved the annual $1.3 billion in US military aid to Egypt, despite qualms over progress in the country's democratization process, and it seems unlikely to suspend that aid even after a coup. The Egyptian military has close ties to the Pentagon, and the emphasis on civilian leaders and a "roadmap" to democracy appears likely to blunt any criticism in Washington.

Now that Morsi is out, the US is likely to insist that it continues to take no sides and only supports "the Egyptian people." However, the US was already suffering from a perception among Egyptians opposed to Morsi and the increasingly repressive actions of his Muslim Brotherhood party that it had "tilted" in Morsi's favor. It will take more forceful pronouncements from Washington in favor of a democratic transition to sway a public dubious of US support.

Title: Obama Administration Announces Deportation Reprieve for Young Illegal Immigrants, Sparks Mixed Reactions

Article:

In a move aimed at addressing the contentious issue of immigration reform, the Obama administration has announced a new policy that will halt the deportation of young illegal immigrants who meet certain criteria and will begin granting work permits to them. The policy change, which could potentially affect up to 800,000 individuals, has been met with a mix of praise and skepticism, with some hailing it as a significant step forward, while others view it as a political maneuver to win over Latino voters.

The new policy, which is similar to the stalled DREAM Act, applies to individuals who were brought to the United States before they turned 16, are 30 or younger, have lived in the country for at least five years, have no criminal record, and have either attended or graduated from a U.S. high school or served in the military.

The policy change has been met with confusion and criticism, with some questioning the administration's motives and consistency. Some argue that the administration is attempting to preempt a nearly identical proposal by Republican Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, which would also halt deportations and issue work permits but would not offer a pathway to citizenship. The left has been vocal in its disapproval of the omission of a pathway to citizenship in the Rubio plan, yet many are now supportive of the Obama administration's plan, despite the lack of a pathway to citizenship.

The administration's immigration record has been a subject of debate, with some praising the administration's efforts and others criticizing it for broken promises. In the past, the administration had pledged to use prosecutorial discretion to free from deportation proceedings individuals who had been in the country for a number of years, had U.S.-born children, or were otherwise rooted in the United States. However, these promises have not been fully realized.

Ruben Navarrette, a syndicated columnist, has expressed skepticism about the policy change, stating that while some DREAM'ers may benefit from the new policy, many probably will not. Navarrette argues that the idea behind the DREAM Act, which trades legal status for college attendance or military service, is still unpopular with most voters in the country, and the administration has no interest in antagonizing a wide portion of the electorate in an election year.

Navarrette also points out that the administration's record on immigration has been most impressive to those who follow it least closely. In other words, the closer one follows the record, the less impressive it seems. Navarrette concludes by quoting former President Ronald Reagan, who once said, "Trust, but verify." In light of the administration's record, he suggests that Latino voters, immigrant advocates, and the DREAM'ers themselves should approach this latest promise with a healthy dose of skepticism.

Title: Trump Administration Weighs Treaty Option for Paris Climate Agreement

Article:

As President Trump's top advisers prepare to finalize their policy on the Paris climate agreement, a new option has emerged: declaring the deal a treaty and sending it to the Senate for potential rejection. This treaty option could serve as a middle ground in the escalating debate between those who advocate for adhering to Mr. Obama's global warming agreement and the Paris agreement's detractors, who argue that Mr. Trump would be breaking a key campaign promise by not withdrawing from the pact.

On Thursday, Trump's principal advisers are set to meet to discuss a final set of recommendations for the president, with several deadlines approaching next month. At a preliminary meeting of top staffers on Tuesday, several memos and letters were circulated, outlining options, including the treaty proposal put forth by Christopher C. Horner and Marlo Lewis Jr., senior fellows at the Competitive Enterprise Institute.

Under their proposal, Mr. Trump could rescind Mr. Obama's decision that the Paris accord was an executive agreement, declare it a treaty, and send it to the Senate for ratification. Given the Republican control of the Senate, the agreement's opponents argue that senators would either shelve the deal or outright defeat it, thereby derailing the agreement.

A briefing paper circulated among Republican senators this week stated that the deal should have been sent to Capitol Hill by Mr. Obama, but he "knew that Congress would never approve such a flawed deal, so he refused to seek the Senate's advice and consent."

Supporters of the Paris accord have their own memo drafted by lawyers in the State Department. That memo argues that by sending the agreement to the Senate, the president would be giving up important powers and leaving Mr. Trump and his successors open to congressional meddling.

The Paris agreement is the primary international vehicle for addressing climate change. Mr. Obama committed the U.S. to the deal in 2015 but never submitted it for ratification, stating that it was an extension of the U.N. Framework Convention on Climate Change, which the Senate ratified in 1992.

The State Department memo asserts that there are few risks to remaining part of the Paris deal, stating that the "legal obligations are relatively few and are generally process-oriented [and] discretionary in their application or repeat existing obligations already contained in the Framework Convention."

As a decision nears, the positions among Mr. Trump's top advisers have become clear. Energy Secretary Rick Perry, on Tuesday, appeared to join the "remainers," though he stated that the deal should be renegotiated. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson is a remainer, as are perhaps Mr. Trump's closest advisers, son-in-law Jared Kushner and daughter Ivanka Trump. The White House general counsel's office also appears to be leaning toward remain, sources familiar with the negotiations said.

Environmental Protection Agency chief Scott Pruitt is pushing for withdrawal, and he is joined by U.N. Ambassador Nikki R. Haley, analysts said. Top presidential strategist Stephen K. Bannon is also a withdrawal advocate. Exxon Mobil Corp. has written a letter urging the administration to stick with the Paris agreement, and the National Mining Association said this week, after its leaders met with Mr. Pruitt, that it will push for withdrawal.

The next test for the Paris accord will be in the middle of May, when finance ministers of the Group of Seven major economies meet in Italy. The heads of state meet at the end of the month. The leaders are hoping for a communique reaffirming the Paris agreement, while opponents within the U.S. are hoping to prevent that, stating it would tie Mr. Trump's hands going forward.

Title: Trump's Support Base Remains Steadfast Despite Controversies, Conditional for Others

Article:

In a recent interview, Gregory Kline, a 46-year-old Republican lawyer from Severna Park, Maryland, expressed his support for President Donald Trump, despite not voting for him in the 2016 election. Kline, who acknowledges that part of Trump's appeal comes from the anger towards the left, particularly the media, criticized the media's response to attacks by Muslim terrorists versus white supremacists.

Kline, who is not alone in his sentiments, believes that Trump's sometimes erratic behavior is overlooked due to a general apathy towards accountability. He cited the support Trump receives from his base, with 61% of current approvers in a recent Monmouth University poll stating they cannot imagine anything Trump could do to make them disapprove of him.

However, for many others, support for Trump is conditional. Michael Dye, a 52-year-old engineer and the treasurer for the Republican Party in Annapolis, Maryland, expressed his disappointment in Trump's response to the neo-Nazi march at the University of Virginia, his alma mater. Dye, who voted for Trump reluctantly, felt that Trump's lack of explicit condemnation of the "Jews will not replace us" chant was problematic, even if it was only a portion of the crowd.

The article underscores the complexities of Trump's approval ratings, with a significant portion of his base remaining steadfast, while others' support is contingent on his actions and decisions. The poll numbers indicate a drop in support since Trump took office in January, suggesting a potential shift in public opinion.

Title: Presidential Candidates Mobilize for Final Push in Battleground States as Election Day Nears

Article:

In the final days leading up to the 2012 presidential election, both the Republican and Democratic parties are gearing up for a fierce battle in the battleground states, with each side accusing the other of voter fraud and suppression.

Robert Bauer, the chief counsel for President Barack Obama's campaign, emphasized the importance of a smooth Election Day. "The larger issue, in my view, is the scale of the effort that is required to have Election Day run smoothly," Bauer said. "Any number of things can go wrong, not by anybody's fault or intention, but we are fully prepared, and so, we believe, are election officials around the country."

On the campaign trail, both candidates presented themselves as agents of change while painting the other as an obstacle in a tight race that may hinge on the success of the campaigns' elaborate turnout operations.

At a rally in Des Moines, Iowa, President Obama scoffed at Mitt Romney's bid to claim the mantle of change, deriding him as a political quick-change artist who is repackaging the failed policies of previous Republican administrations. "When you make this choice, part of what you're choosing is who do you trust," Mr. Obama said. "After four years as president, you know me by now. You know I mean what I say and I say what I mean."

Racing against the sun and the clock, both campaigns brimmed with confidence about their chances on Tuesday, though polls showed Mr. Obama holding a slender lead in several of the battleground states he needs to win the Electoral College. That advantage was evident in the itineraries of the two men on Sunday.

While each covered familiar ground from New Hampshire to Ohio, Mr. Romney sought to open a new front with a rally in Pennsylvania. Tightening polls have given him hope that he can take the state from Mr. Obama, who won there by a double-digit margin in 2008. But the president's advisers dismissed the foray as a desperate move by a challenger running out of other paths to victory.

At the rally in Morrisville, Pennsylvania, Mr. Romney made a point of mentioning a high-profile supporter, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, whose lavish praise of Mr. Obama's leadership after Hurricane Sandy has raised Republican eyebrows.

In Hollywood, Florida, Mr. Obama was endorsed by Pitbull, a Cuban-American hip-hop artist, one of many celebrities lined up by the campaigns to help draw crowds. In Pennsylvania, the Marshall Tucker Band warmed up the audience for Mr. Romney, while Stevie Wonder played "Signed, Sealed, Delivered" for Mr. Obama at a rally in Cincinnati.

Hours earlier in New Hampshire, Mr. Obama spoke to 14,000 people beneath the gold dome of the State House in Concord on a bright, chilly day that recalled any number of days that he and other hopefuls had walked the streets in their quest for a victory in the nation's first presidential primaries.

Nearby was a reminder of how the state almost dashed Mr. Obama's dreams in 2008. On a line of paving stones in front of the New Hampshire State Library are chiseled the names of winners in the state's primary, including Hillary Rodham Clinton, whose victory there halted, for a time, Mr. Obama's surge after he won the Iowa caucus.

On this Sunday, however, Mr. Obama had the fortifying presence of former President Bill Clinton, who noted approvingly in his introductory speech that Mr. Obama wanted to accomplish many of the same things that Mr. Clinton had during his two terms in office.

"The test should be: What did the president do? What are the results? And compared to what?" Mr. Clinton said. "Compared to what could have happened, Barack Obama has done a good job."

Savoring the moment, his voice not yet raw from too many speeches, Mr. Clinton gleefully accused Mr. Romney of shifting his position on the bailout of the automakers so many times that he could find work as "chief contortionist in Cirque du Soleil."

Moments earlier, in Des Moines, Mr. Romney told his supporters that the clock had nearly run out on the president's time in office, and he promised to usher in a new era of economic hope for families who are struggling across the country.

"Instead of building bridges, he's made the divide wider," Mr. Romney said. "Let me tell you why it is he's fallen so short of what he promised: it's because he cared more about a liberal agenda than he did about repairing the economy."

Mr. Romney led the crowd in a call and response: "I mean, do you think Obamacare created jobs? Did his war on coal, oil, and gas create jobs? Did Dodd-Frank regulations help banks make more loans? Does raising taxes put people to work?"

"No," the crowd cried out in response to each question.

Iowa was also the scene of skirmishing over voting, as Republicans on Sunday night accused Democratic operatives of encouraging older voters to illegally fill out absentee ballots for their family members. A letter to the state's top election official from the chief counsel of the Republican National Committee said that a news report of "the alleged conduct of Democratic and Obama operatives, if true, is highly disconcerting."

With the election being waged most intensely in fewer than a dozen states, the candidates seemed to be shadowboxing each other, with one arriving in a state just hours after the other left. After Iowa, Mr. Romney held rallies in Ohio and Virginia. He planned events in Florida, Virginia, Ohio, and New Hampshire on Monday.

Title: Ceasefire in Gaza: One Killed, Tensions Remain High as Israel and Palestinians Clash at Border

Article:

Israeli troops clashed with Palestinians near the Gaza-Israel border on Friday, resulting in one fatality and 19 injuries, despite a two-day-old ceasefire between Hamas and Israel. The truce, which aims to halt cross-border attacks and airstrikes, was established after eight days of intense fighting, the bloodiest between Israel and Hamas in four years.

In a letter to the United Nations Security Council, Palestinian U.N. observer Riyad Mansour described the situation in Gaza as "extremely fragile" and accused Israel of violating the ceasefire and engaging in illegal actions that could jeopardize the fragile peace.

Hundreds of Palestinians approached the border fence in several locations in southern Gaza, testing Israel's commitment to the no-go zone established to prevent infiltrations into Israel. In one incident captured by Associated Press video, dozens of Palestinians, mostly young men, approached the fence, coming close to a group of Israeli soldiers.

Israeli soldiers reportedly warned the Palestinians to move back, and after they refused, troops fired warning shots in the air and later fired at the legs of the Palestinians. A Palestinian infiltrated into Israel during the unrest but was returned to Gaza, according to Israel's military.

Gaza health official Ashraf al-Kidra confirmed the death of a 20-year-old man and the injuries of 19 others near the border. Palestinian U.N. observer Mansour stated that Israeli forces fatally shot Anwar Abdulhadi Qudaih in the head and injured at least 19 other Palestinian civilians in a border area east of Khan Younis.

During the incidents, Hamas security attempted to defuse the situation and keep the crowds away from the fence. Moussa Abu Marzouk, a top Hamas official at the ongoing negotiations in Cairo, said the violence would have no effect on the ceasefire.

The crowds were primarily made up of young men but also included farmers hoping to farm lands in the buffer zone. Speaking by phone from the buffer zone, 19-year-old Ali Abu Taimah said he and his father were checking three acres of family land that have been fallow for several years.

``When we go to our land, we are telling the occupation (Israel) that we are not afraid at all,'' he said.

Israel's military stated that roughly 300 Palestinians approached the security fence at different points, attempted to damage it, and crossed into Israel. The Israeli military also reported that a Palestinian was arrested during the unrest.

The ceasefire allowed both Hamas and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to step back from the brink of a full-fledged war. Over eight days, Israel's aircraft carried out some 1,500 strikes on Hamas-linked targets, while Gaza fighters fired roughly the same number of rockets at Israel.

The fighting resulted in 166 Palestinian deaths, including scores of civilians, and six Israeli deaths. Mansour, the Palestinian U.N. envoy, stated that more than 1,230 Palestinians were injured, predominantly women and children.

In Cairo, Egypt is hosting separate talks with Israeli and Hamas envoys on the next phase of the ceasefire, focusing on a new border deal for blockaded Gaza. Hamas demands an end to border restrictions, while Israel insists Hamas halt weapons smuggling to Gaza.

Mansour also accused Israel of intensifying its use of "excessive and lethal force" against Palestinian civilians in the West Bank and East Jerusalem in recent days and of arresting at least 230 Palestinian civilians since the Gaza fighting began, including several members of the Palestinian Legislative Council who were detained at dawn on Friday.

The Palestinian U.N. observer called on the Security Council and the international community "to remain vigilant in their demands for a complete cessation of hostilities and for compliance by Israel."

A poll on Friday showed that about half of Israelis think their government should have continued its Gaza offensive. The independent Maagar Mohot poll showed 49 percent of respondents felt Israel should have kept pursuing squads that fire rockets into Israel, 31 percent supported the decision to stop, and 20 percent had no opinion. Twenty-nine percent thought Israel should have sent ground troops into Gaza. The poll of 503 respondents had an error margin of 4.5 percentage points.

The same survey showed Netanyahu's Likud Party and electoral partner Israel Beiteinu losing some support, but his hard-line bloc was still favored to form the next government after January 22 elections.

Title: Debt Ceiling Standoff Looms as Budget Agreement Passes Congress

The recent bipartisan budget agreement, passed by the House last week and expected to be approved by the Senate this week, has alleviated the threat of a government shutdown. However, the looming debt ceiling fight is now a pressing concern, with the potential for a U.S. government default on the horizon.

In a statement on Fox News Sunday, House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan (R-WI) hinted at another debt ceiling standoff, stating, "We don't want nothing out of this debt limit. We're going to decide what it is we can accomplish out of this debt limit fight."

Ryan's stance is consistent with his previous statements, as he has long advocated for using the debt ceiling as a bargaining chip for spending cuts. During the government shutdown, Ryan argued that the debt ceiling was the appropriate battleground for fiscal debates, citing historical precedents of presidents engaging in debt ceiling negotiations.

With Ryan's reputation as a fiscal conservative and his ambitions for higher office, it is unlikely he will back down from this position. This places him at odds with the White House, where Press Secretary Jay Carney reiterated on Monday that the president will not negotiate over the debt ceiling.

The standoff between Ryan and the White House could lead to another default scare early in the midterm election year, potentially in March, coinciding with the start of the 2014 primary season. This timing could put many Republicans under maximum grassroots pressure to vote against a clean debt ceiling bill.

If the two-year budget agreement marks a brief respite from the partisan tensions that have long plagued Washington, it may only serve as a temporary reprieve from the ongoing fiscal debates.

Title: Protests on Immigration and Policing Disrupt Second Night of Democratic Debate in Detroit

Article:

The second night of the Democratic presidential primary debate in Detroit was disrupted twice by protesters, who aimed to highlight immigration and policing issues. The first interruption occurred during New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker's opening statement, with audience members chanting "Fire Pantaleo."

The chant was a reference to Staten Island, N.Y. police officer Daniel Pantaleo, who was involved in the 2014 death of Eric Garner. Garner, who was African American, died after being placed in a chokehold by Pantaleo, who is white. Police had approached Garner, suspecting he was illegally selling cigarettes.

The video of the incident, which captured Garner saying "I can't breathe," became another rallying point in the ongoing tensions between the African American community and law enforcement. It appears the protest burst was aimed at New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, who has been criticized for not pushing for Pantaleo's dismissal, particularly after the Justice Department declined to bring criminal charges against Pantaleo on July 16.

De Blasio does not legally have the power to fire Pantaleo, The New York Times reports. However, his handling of the issue has contributed to his low approval ratings from his constituents. Other city leaders say de Blasio—who often talks about race issues through the lens of having a biracial son and who touted halting "stop and frisk" during his own opening statement—needs to speak up.

New York City public advocate Jumaane Williams told The Times that the mayor needs to "do something or do not mention Eric Garner's name ever again." Williams stated, "You cannot be president, you cannot be the Democratic nominee if Daniel Pantaleo is still on the force."

The chants grew loudest not when de Blasio spoke but during Booker's time. The former Newark, N.J. mayor has pressed de Blasio on the issue, and his staff tweeted during the debate that they welcomed the interruption to draw attention to the controversy, writing, "Good for you. That's how change is made."

De Blasio did later acknowledge the issue on Twitter, writing, "While I believe that respecting the process is the best way to get justice for Eric Garner's family, I recognize and identify with the pain people across this country are feeling."

Former Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julián Castro weighed in from the debate stage, saying Pantaleo should be immediately removed from the NYPD. "Officer Pantaleo used a chokehold that was prohibited by NYPD," Castro said. "He knew what he was doing, that he was killing Eric Garner, and yet he has not been brought to justice. That police officer should be off the street."

A separate group of protesters later briefly disrupted the debate to protest former Vice President Joe Biden and the Obama administration's record on immigration. A group who identified themselves as the Cosecha Movement began chanting "3 million deportations" and unfurled a banner that read "Stop all deportations on day one."

The group says it wants a halt to all immigrant detention and deportations on the first day of a new Democratic president's term in office. It's also pushing for reunification of families separated by deportation under the Trump administration and the immediate legalization of all estimated 11 million people who live in the country illegally.

Earlier in the day, the Cosecha Movement had held a protest outside the Detroit theater and blocked traffic at the Detroit-Windsor Tunnel, which is an international border crossing between the U.S. and Canada.

Title: Millennial Political Newcomer Stuns Democratic Establishment in New York Primary

Article:

A political newcomer, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, has caused a seismic shift in the US Democratic Party by defeating the incumbent congressman, Joe Crowley, in the Democratic primary for New York's 14th congressional district. The 28-year-old Ocasio-Cortez, a former Bernie Sanders volunteer from a Puerto Rican family, secured 57.5% of the vote, while Crowley, a 10-term Democrat and former party leader contender, had not faced a primary challenge in 14 years.

Ocasio-Cortez will now face Republican candidate Anthony Pappas in the November mid-terms. If she wins, she will become the youngest woman ever elected to Congress. The progressive candidate ran on a platform supporting universal healthcare, tuition-free college, and criminal justice reform.

Following Ocasio-Cortez's win, Merriam-Webster tweeted that socialism was their top search item. The political novice, who identifies as a democratic socialist, had a significant grassroots following and raised more small-dollar donations than any other New York City congressional candidate.

Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, a top Democrat who has a political action committee designed to support women candidates, endorsed Crowley. Ocasio-Cortez responded to Gillibrand's endorsement on Twitter, stating that the New York senator "did not even bother to talk to nor consider me before endorsing."

The upset victory by Ocasio-Cortez serves as a warning shot to the Democratic Party establishment. Crowley, who was seen as a potential future Speaker of the House, is now taking a forced exit from politics. In his concession speech, he paid tribute to Ocasio-Cortez with a rendition of Bruce Springsteen's Born to Run.

The liberal base's anger and energy during the Trump presidency have led to new bursts of activism, confrontation, and an anti-establishment fervor that could endanger seemingly safe Democratic politicians. The party is moving to the left, with growing support for universal healthcare and free college education.

During her campaign, Ocasio-Cortez criticized Crowley for his ties to Wall Street and accused him of being out of touch with his increasingly diverse constituents. They thanked each other after the result, with Crowley saying he would support Ocasio-Cortez in the mid-terms.

Ocasio-Cortez is one of 130 women who have won primary elections for US House seats, 80% of whom are Democrats. There are still 341 women in the running in the House of Representatives, a record high, according to the latest data from the Center for Women and American Politics.

Ocasio-Cortez is a Bronx-born Latina, a community organizer, and educator from a working-class background. She made a viral campaign video in which she said, "Women like me are not supposed to run for office." She has a degree in economics and international relations from Boston University, but after graduation, she worked as a waitress and bartender to supplement her mother's income as a house cleaner and bus driver.

Ocasio-Cortez decided to run for office after watching the election of Donald Trump as president. She described her congressional district in an interview with US news outlet Mic during her campaign, stating, "Our median income is around $47,000 a year, we're about 70% people of color." She added, "We've had the same representation for a generation."

Ocasio-Cortez campaigned on universal healthcare, free university tuition, and an end to immigration raids. As the mid-term elections approach, her victory serves as a reminder of the power of grassroots activism and the changing political landscape of the Democratic Party.

Title: House of Representatives Passes Continuing Resolution to Fund Government, Excluding Obamacare

Article:

In the final days leading up to the expiration date for America's "temporary budget," the House of Representatives has passed a continuing resolution that will fund all parts of the government at sequestration levels through Dec. 15. However, the resolution does not include funding for the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare.

The move by the House is in line with the Republican position that if the health care law is not ready to be implemented in full, the American people should not be paying for it. The Republicans are not calling for a government shutdown, but rather an "Obamacare shutdown."

The House has found a way to fund the government without funding Obamacare, following thousands of calls from constituents nationwide and a tumultuous August town hall recess. The question remains, however, as to why the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, and the Senate Democrats are so vehemently defending a law that has been a revolving door of procedural failures and harmful unintended consequences.

To date, there have been more than 20 delays, exemptions, and revisions to Obamacare, including a delay of the employer mandate for businesses. Sen. Max Baucus, Montana Democrat, one of the law's primary architects, predicted that implementation of the 2,000-plus page law would prove a "train wreck."

Obamacare disproportionately burdens the most vulnerable among us. Young Americans will pay higher costs to subsidize the older and wealthier. According to Investor's Business Daily, four different industries have cut their workweeks below 30 hours since Obamacare was signed into law, harming low-income hourly-wage earners the most.

Public discontent for the law continues to grow. A recent FreedomWorks national poll found that an overwhelming 82 percent of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents favor a continuing resolution that "does not include funding for Obamacare." Only 17 percent of all voters think Obamacare will have a positive personal impact, a new low point since the law was passed in March 2010.

Sixty-two percent of all voters prefer a "patient-centered" health care system that allows for competition and choice. The people have spoken, and members of Congress are beholden to their constituents—not the other way around.

Then why would Mr. Reid refuse to compromise, and instead strip the defunding language from the continuing resolution and hold the government hostage? The answer remains to be seen as the Senate considers the House-passed resolution.

Title: "GOP Health Care Bill: A Race Against Time as Republicans Seek to Replace ObamaCare"

Article:

In a bid to replace the Affordable Care Act (ObamaCare), Congressional Republicans are facing a critical juncture, with some drawing inspiration from the King of Rock and Roll, Elvis Presley, as they croon the tune of "It's Now or Never." House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Kevin Brady (R-Texas) has urged his fellow Republicans to act swiftly, stating, "We can act now or we can keep fiddling around and squander this opportunity to repeal ObamaCare."

The Republican health care bill is currently under scrutiny, with some conservative lawmakers and interest groups criticizing the GOP legislation as "ObamaCare-lite." Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky) has expressed his concerns, stating, "We have to admit we are divided on replacement." House Freedom Caucus co-chairman Rep. Mark Meadows (R-N.C.) has also voiced his reservations.

The passage of the Republican health care bill hinges on the numbers. The GOP can only lose 21 votes before the measure fails on a party-line vote. The Freedom Caucus, with its bylaw that compels its members to vote as a bloc if 80% of its members feel the same on a given issue, holds significant sway. If enough members of the Freedom Caucus balk at the bill, it could be incinerated on the floor.

To address these concerns, the Trump administration has deployed Budget Director and Freedom Caucus founder Mick Mulvaney and Vice President Mike Pence to liaise with congressional Republicans. Pence has reportedly told Freedom Caucus members that the bill is still open for negotiation, but after a lunch meeting with Senate Republicans, he suggested the bill might not be that agile.

The Freedom Caucus, like the Democratic Blue Dog coalition that was key to approving ObamaCare, could play a pivotal role in the GOP health care bill's passage. The question now is how lawmakers will contour the GOP health care plan to their liking and what amendments might the GOP brass permit. Is there flexibility? What happens if just enough Republicans balk at the bill?

The American Health Care Act (AHCA) is the first test of President Trump's legislative power, according to House Republican Chief Deputy Whip Patrick McHenry (R-N.C.) after a White House confab. The margin to pass this bill could be tight, and Ryan and other AHCA supporters must earn the support of skeptics in their own party, not antagonize them.

House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) has expressed confidence in securing the necessary votes, predicting, "We will have 218 votes, I can guarantee you." Ryan only needs 216 to approve the AHCA. The bill must be passed by the end of the month, according to Ryan, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) aiming for early April. The bill could calcify if it sits out too long. In 2009 and 2010, congressional Democrats burned nearly 10 months approving ObamaCare.

As the King sings, "It's now or never" – if Republicans are to repeal and replace ObamaCare. "Tomorrow will be too late."

Title: U.S. Presidential Candidates' Divergent Views on Iran Nuclear Agreement and Iraq War Lessons

Article:

In the ongoing U.S. presidential race, the candidates' views on foreign policy, particularly the Iran nuclear agreement and the lessons learned from the Iraq and Afghan wars, are coming under scrutiny.

Recently, Donald J. Trump, a candidate with minimal foreign policy experience, proposed seizing oil fields that fund extremist groups, a proposal that drew a sharp rebuke from the retiring Army chief of staff, Gen. Ray Odierno, who led American troops during the worst days of the Iraq war. Gen. Odierno cautioned Mr. Trump and other candidates about the need to ensure "sustainable outcomes" after American troops leave, a central lesson from the Iraq and Afghan wars.

The debate about short-term versus long-term results, and American strength or weakness, is also playing out in the debate over the nuclear agreement with Iran, signed a month ago in Vienna. All Republican candidates oppose the agreement, with Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin advocating for tearing up the accord on his first day in office. This stance, however, risks leaving the Iranians free to resume their nuclear program, which, by the Obama administration's own estimates, has brought them within two or three months of "breakout," the production of one weapon's worth of highly enriched uranium.

Some candidates, such as Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, are more cautious, stating they would not immediately abrogate the agreement. Candidates are, however, largely silent on what they would replace the agreement with or how they would prevent Iran from resuming its nuclear program if the deal is abandoned.

Marco Rubio, the Florida senator, has proposed reimposing the sanctions waived by President Obama and working with Congress to impose new crushing sanctions. Yet, even he has not addressed what good reimposing those sanctions would do if America's negotiating partners—China, Russia, and three European powers—refuse to go along.

The ongoing debate underscores the importance of foreign policy experience and the need for candidates to articulate clear, feasible, and sustainable solutions to complex global issues.

Title: Study Reveals Impact of Local Newspaper Closures on Political Polarization

Article:

In the era of constant political news, the national media landscape has seen significant growth, with major outlets such as The New York Times, Wall Street Journal, and CNN experiencing increased digital subscriptions and viewership. However, local newspapers have not fared as well, with a drastic decline in ad revenues, workforce, and circulation over the past decade.

A new study by political scientists and communications scholars has found a direct correlation between the decline of local news and political polarization. The research, published in the journal Political Behavior, suggests that the loss of local newspapers contributes to increased political polarization, making governing more challenging at both the local and national levels.

The study, which focused on split-ticket voting as a measure of polarization, found that in areas where local newspapers have closed or merged, voters are more likely to vote for the same party for both presidential and senatorial elections. This shift in voting patterns is significant, with the difference in voting choices often being enough to decide close elections, as seen in the 2018 U.S. House races in Minnesota's 1st district, Utah's 4th district, and Illinois's 13th district.

The researchers examined 110 newspaper closures between 2009 and 2012, comparing split-ticket voting in the 2012 election in those counties to statistically similar counties that did not lose a newspaper. The majority of closed newspapers were weeklies, such as the Clarke Courier of Virginia or the Boston Phoenix, though the data also included some major metropolitan dailies like Denver's Rocky Mountain News.

The study's findings suggest that the decline of local newspapers and the "nationalization" of political news are polarizing vote choice. Voters are more likely to vote for the same party for president and senator after a newspaper closes in their community, compared to voters in statistically similar areas where a newspaper did not close.

The researchers considered two explanations for their finding: either people switched to national news once their local newspaper closed or they lost the information they needed to vote in more local races. The study found no evidence of increased "ballot roll-off," indicating that people did not feel less informed about local politics after the closure of their local newspaper. Instead, the partisan voting is likely due to switching to national news rather than feeling less informed about local politics.

The study also addressed the possibility that the correlation between local newspaper closures and political polarization might be due to the economic conditions in the areas where newspapers closed. However, the researchers found no correlation between split-ticket voting in 2012 in places that lost a newspaper shortly thereafter and areas with similar economic conditions but no newspaper closure.

The study's findings underscore the importance of local newspapers in maintaining a focus on community issues and promoting informed voting. The researchers suggest that if Americans can support local news with their dollars and attention, it could help to push back against the partisan polarization that has taken over American politics today.

Title: Senate Intelligence Committee Report Confirms Al Qaeda Involvement in Benghazi Attack

A bipartisan report by the Senate Intelligence Committee has concluded that individuals linked to Al Qaeda groups were involved in the 2012 Benghazi attack, challenging previous assertions that the terror network played no role in the incident. The report, released on Monday, comes nearly a year after then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's controversial statement, "What difference, at this point, does it make?"

The administration initially attributed the attack to a protest, but subsequent assessments have provided a more complex narrative. However, administration officials have consistently downplayed Al Qaeda's involvement, citing a New York Times report that supported their claims.

The report, while not implicating Al Qaeda's "core" leadership, does blame significant Al Qaeda branches, including Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) and Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM). The report states, "Individuals affiliated with terrorist groups, including AQIM, Ansar al-Sharia, AQAP, and the Mohammad Jamal Network, participated in the September 11, 2012, attacks."

The militant group Ansar al-Sharia, separately labeled as a terror group by the State Department last week, is alleged to have played a role in the Benghazi strike.

The Senate committee report emphasizes that the intelligence suggests the attack was not "highly coordinated," but rather "opportunistic" - possibly set up in "short order" following protests in other regions over an anti-Islam film. The report, however, reiterates that there was no protest in Benghazi before the attack.

The report also delves into the security lapses at the U.S. mission in Benghazi before the attack. The committee determined the attack was "preventable" and the administration failed to respond to "ample" warnings that security was deteriorating before Sept. 11, 2012.

The report faults the State and Defense departments for their roles in the security failures. It also criticizes the Obama administration for its failure to "bring the attackers to justice."

The report provides a detailed account of a possible failed ambush, where attackers attempted to lure the CIA into the hospital where Ambassador Chris Stevens' body was being held.

Senate Intelligence Committee Chairwoman Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) stated, "The committee worked on a bipartisan basis to investigate the various allegations that have come out since the terrorist attacks in Benghazi in September 2012 and to get to the truth about what happened leading up to, during, and after the attacks."

Sen. Saxby Chambliss (R-Ga.), the top Republican on the panel, also said the report provides "needed and deserved answers."

"In spite of the deteriorating security situation in Benghazi and ample strategic warnings, the United States Government simply did not do enough to prevent these attacks and ensure the safety of those serving in Benghazi," Chambliss said.

Title: Iowa Democratic Caucuses: Buttigieg and Sanders in Virtual Tie, Warren in Third Place

Article:

In the latest results released overnight, former South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont are in a virtual tie in the Iowa Democratic caucuses, with Buttigieg holding a slight lead of 3 out of 1,097 votes. With 97 percent of precincts reporting, Buttigieg has 26.2 percent of state delegate equivalents, while Sanders has 26.1 percent.

Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts trails in third place with 18.2 percent, followed by former Vice President Joe Biden with 15.8 percent and Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota with 12.2 percent. No other Democratic presidential candidates broke the double-digit level in state delegate equivalents in the caucuses, which were marred by technical problems.

Sanders leads the popular vote, getting 26.5 percent compared to Buttigieg's 25 percent. That translates into a difference of about 2,500 votes. Warren is also in third place in the popular vote in Iowa, getting more than 18,000 votes.

Buttigieg had held a narrow lead over Sanders in earlier tallies of state delegate equivalents. The chairman of the Iowa Democratic Party, Troy Price, said in a call with state party officials Wednesday night that full results should be released by Thursday morning, according to CNN. A person on the call also told the network that Price promised an independent review.

The results of the Iowa caucuses are closely watched as the first contest in the Democratic primary race. The next primary contest will be in New Hampshire on February 11.

Title: New Poll Shows Tightening Race Between Trump and Biden, Trump Gaining Ground in Potential 2020 Matchup

Article:

A new CNN/SSRS poll indicates a narrowing gap between President Donald Trump and former Vice President Joe Biden in a potential general election matchup, with Biden leading Trump 49% to 44%. The poll also shows closer matchups between Trump and other leading Democratic contenders, including South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren.

Compared to polling taken in October, the Democratic margin in all head-to-heads has been reduced by at least 5 points. The polling data suggests that Trump is gaining ground, with his lead over the other leading Democrats increasing since October.

In the 15 closest states of the 2016 election, where the presidential contest was decided by 8 or fewer points, Trump is in a stronger position. None of the Democrats led in CNN's December poll, which follows other swing state polling suggesting that Trump could win the electoral college while losing the popular vote, as he did in 2016.

The shift in Trump's favor nationally coincides with an upward movement in his personal popularity. His net favorable rating (favorable - unfavorable) stood at -6 points among voters in CNN's latest poll. This is a significant improvement from the -12 points he had in the two prior CNN polls that asked the question.

The average poll also shows Trump at the high end in his popularity. According to the FiveThirtyEight aggregate, this week Trump hit his highest approval rating among voters (45%) since March 2017. The upward trajectory in Trump's popularity is likely, at least in part, due to the economy. While most people generally think the economy is good, a booming 76% said it was good in the CNN poll out this week, the highest percentage since 2001.

The impeachment of Trump does not seem to be making much of an impact on the polls. This could be because fewer voters say it's an extremely or very important issue to their vote than any other issue tested by CNN in November. Additionally, it could be because opposition to impeaching and removing Trump is higher than Trump's popularity ratings. This means more talk of impeachment may actually move Trump's approval rating up.

Another factor helping Trump is that presidential elections are not referendums. He will have a named Democratic opponent. None of the leading Democrats had a positive net favorability rating among voters in CNN's December poll. The drop in the Democrats' popularity could be because they are involved in a competitive primary, which is hurting their intra-party favorability ratings. None of the Democrats are anywhere near as popular among their own party's voters as Trump is with his. This could change once the primary ends, though.

Indeed, it's not like Trump is in a great position. The two most likely Democratic nominees, Biden and Sanders, are ahead of him by 7 points and 4 points, respectively, in the average poll. Most incumbent presidents have been leading their potential opposition at this point before the election.

Title: Trump's Approval Rating Remains Steady Amidst Controversy: A Look at the Current Political Landscape

Article:

In the aftermath of President Donald Trump's controversial joint press conference with Russian President Vladimir Putin, a recent poll has shown that Trump's approval rating has risen to 45 percent, marking his highest level in the NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll since taking office. This resilience in Trump's approval rating has left Democrats puzzled, as they grapple with the implications for the 2018 midterm elections and the 2020 presidential race.

The polls, which included responses both before and after the Helsinki summit, suggest a more pronounced negative impact may not be immediately apparent. However, the share of Americans who strongly approve of Trump, at 29 percent, is significantly outweighed by the 44 percent who strongly disapprove. This disparity could potentially translate into greater intensity among Democratic voters, a factor that could be crucial given that Democratic-leaning voting blocs tend to turn out less reliably in midterm elections.

Despite the Democrats' lead in the so-called generic ballot shrinking to 6 percentage points, there is continued faith among Democrats that they will make gains in November. Tad Devine, a senior adviser to Sen. Bernie Sanders' 2016 presidential campaign, believes a takeover of both the House and Senate is a real possibility for the Democrats.

"The intensity is there. Democratic voters are paying a lot more attention, they are a lot more interested in participating," Devine said. He added that the party does not need to adopt a one-size-fits-all approach to framing the election, emphasizing the need for unique, district-specific strategies.

The polarizing nature of Trump's approach has led some to question whether he has alienated a significant swath of the voting public, potentially to the detriment of his party. Joe Trippi, a Democratic strategist, believes that Trump's conduct during the news conference with Putin and the subsequent days has "really locked in" the 55 or 56 percent who disapprove of him, making it more difficult for a Republican candidate for Congress to win them over.

The reasons behind Trump's strong loyalty from his base remain a topic of debate. Robert Shrum, a Democratic strategist who has worked on several presidential campaigns, argues that economic factors are less relevant than emotional responses, stating, "I just think there is a deep emotional investment in him by a shrinking Republican Party."

Devine, on the other hand, attributes Trump's strong economy and his anti-media stance as contributing factors to his support. He also suggests that support for Trump is more complex than the headline figures from a poll might indicate, with voters holding mixed feelings about the president.

For the moment, the idea of a Trump collapse looks increasingly unrealistic, at least in the short term. This leaves both his supporters and opponents with much to consider as the political landscape continues to evolve.

Title: Ex-IRS Commissioner's Wife Tied to Liberal Campaign Finance Reform Group Amid IRS Scandal

Article:

In the midst of the ongoing scrutiny surrounding the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) scandal, a new development has emerged involving the former IRS commissioner, Douglas Shulman. Shulman, who led the agency during the period when it targeted conservative groups between 2010 and 2012, has been under fire following a report of his frequent visits to the White House during the Obama administration.

It has been revealed that Shulman's wife, Susan L. Anderson, is a senior program adviser for the Washington-based group Public Campaign. The group, which claims to be nonpartisan, is working with a broad range of organizations to reform campaign-finance rules.

However, Public Campaign receives significant funding from liberal groups such as the Ford Foundation, Barbra Streisand's The Streisand Foundation, and Health Care for America NOW, a coalition of labor unions supporting ObamaCare that includes the AFL-CIO and the Service Employees International Union, according to the Public Campaign website.

The group's stance on campaign finance has also come under scrutiny. In 2011, Public Campaign produced a "holiday card" video that suggested the wealthiest Americans, specifically the top 1 percent, were trying to buy or influence elections by secretly donating to political groups.

The video, which depicted a person saying "Sure, my kids might get asthma because Congress keeps doing dirty energy's bidding, but the Koch brothers need their third home," is a clear reference to David and Charles Koch, successful businessmen aligned with conservative and libertarian causes. The Koch brothers have nonprofit groups like the David H. Koch Charitable Foundation and support Tea Party-tied heavyweights like FreedomWorks and Americans for Prosperity.

When the IRS scandal over the targeting of conservative groups broke, Public Campaign appeared to defend the tax agency. Nick Nyhart, the group's chief executive, suggested to ABC News that the misdeeds of a "few bad apples" within the agency will "make it harder for those questions to be asked without claims of bias."

Anderson, who has also been a supporter and apparent participant in the Occupy Wall Street movement, has tweeted messages such as "DC, good morning! Come down to the (National) Mall and tell your 99 percent story."

Shulman and Anderson met as students at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government. Shulman was appointed commissioner by former President George W. Bush. He reportedly logged more than 100 visits to the White House under Obama, a claim he did not deny during congressional testimony last month on the IRS scandal. That number refers to the number of times Shulman was cleared to visit.

Title: U.S. to Issue Guidance on Reducing Unnecessary COVID-19 Testing, Aims to Improve Turnaround Times

The United States is set to release new guidance aimed at reducing unnecessary COVID-19 testing and expediting test results, according to Brett Giroir, assistant secretary for health at the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. The guidance is intended to discourage individuals who have completed home quarantine from getting retested before returning to work or school, as such tests are currently "clogging up the system."

Giroir, speaking on a call with reporters, emphasized that retesting is generally unnecessary for individuals who have recovered from COVID-19, except for critically ill patients in hospitals or those with immune system deficiencies who may continue to test positive for longer periods.

Turnaround times for COVID-19 tests remain an issue, with only 26 states currently taking three days or less to produce test results, while one state is taking more than five days. The new guidance is not a response to testing shortages, Giroir clarified, but rather a measure to ensure that tests are only conducted when necessary.

The U.S. government is working towards facilitating a transition from lab-based tests, which can have longer turnaround times, to point-of-care tests, which can provide results in minutes and can be conducted in a wider variety of locations. The U.S. government expects that 20 million point-of-care tests will be available per month by September.

On Wednesday, Becton Dickinson announced that the U.S. government had agreed to purchase 750,000 of its point-of-care tests. The new guidance on testing is expected to be released soon, providing further details on the specific measures aimed at reducing unnecessary testing and improving turnaround times for COVID-19 tests.

Title: Biden Expresses Regret to Anita Hill Over 1991 Supreme Court Hearings, but Hill Calls for More Action

Article:

In a move to address a defining moment from his past, former Vice President Joe Biden, who is running for president, contacted Anita Hill to express his regret for the way he handled her testimony during the 1991 Supreme Court hearings. However, Hill, who is now a law professor, was not "satisfied" with the conversation and did not consider it an apology.

Biden, who chaired the Senate Judiciary Committee during the hearings, contacted Hill earlier this month to express his "regret for what she endured" during the hearing. This conversation took place just before Biden launched his 2020 presidential campaign.

In an interview with the New York Times, Hill stated, "I cannot be satisfied by simply saying I'm sorry for what happened to you. I will be satisfied when I know there is real change and real accountability and real purpose."

Biden has previously apologized for allowing an all-male and all-white panel of lawmakers to aggressively question Hill during the hearing, where she accused Clarence Thomas of sexual harassment.

Hill told the newspaper that she could not support Biden until he takes responsibility for his behavior. She emphasized, "The focus on apology to me is one thing, but he needs to give an apology to the other women and to the American public because we know now how deeply disappointed Americans around the country were about what they saw."

Biden publicly addressed his treatment of Hill last month at an event in New York City honoring students who helped fight sexual violence on college campuses. He acknowledged, "She faced a committee that didn't fully understand what the hell this was all about. To this day, I regret I couldn't give her the kind of hearing she deserved."

Hill's comments come as Biden faces allegations from several women who have accused him of unwanted, inappropriate behavior. In response, Biden stated, "Social norms are changing. I understand that, and I've heard what these women are saying. Politics to me has always been about making connections, but I will be more mindful of personal space in the future."

A spokesperson for Biden's 2020 campaign confirmed his outreach to Hill, stating, "They had a private discussion where he shared with her directly his regret for what she endured and his admiration for everything she has done to change the culture around sexual harassment in this country."

Title: Facebook's Study Suggests Limited Impact of News Feed Algorithm on Political Bias, Sparking Mixed Reactions Among Academics

Article:

In a recent study published in the journal Science, Facebook has revealed that its News Feed algorithm, which determines what content appears on users' feeds, may have a limited impact on reinforcing political biases among its users. The study, which analyzed the sharing and engagement of news articles among Facebook's 1.3 billion users, has been met with mixed reactions from academics.

According to the Pew Research Center, about 30 percent of American adults get their news from Facebook. However, the editorial decisions behind the News Feed algorithm have been criticized for their lack of transparency. The study's results could potentially be used by Facebook to demonstrate that the algorithm is not negatively influencing national discourse.

Facebook's researchers were given wide latitude to pursue their research interests and present their findings without interference. The study was reviewed before publication, with an anonymous panel of scholars unaffiliated with Facebook overseeing the process. Science, the journal where the study was published, does not disclose the identity of its reviewers and advises them to declare any potential conflicts of interest.

The study differed from a controversial one from last year, in which Facebook's scientists manipulated the number of positive and negative posts that some users saw to examine the effects on mood. This study did not involve any experimentation that altered users' experience of Facebook; instead, researchers analyzed how people use Facebook as it currently exists.

For the study, researchers first identified the political leanings of news articles by determining whether liberals or conservatives had shared them most. They found predictable partisan attitudes towards certain news sources, with Fox News stories being shared primarily by conservatives and Huffington Post articles being shared by liberals.

Researchers then measured how often feeds of users, whose identifying details had been removed, displayed stories that contradicted their professed ideologies, and how often they clicked on those stories.

Some academics have expressed concerns that Facebook could easily manipulate the News Feed to create a more insular echo chamber. David Lazer, a political scientist at Northeastern University who studies social networks, wrote in a commentary on the Facebook study also published in Science, "A small effect today might become a large effect tomorrow. The deliberative sky is not yet falling, but the skies are not completely clear either."

The study's findings suggest that the News Feed algorithm may have a limited impact on reinforcing political biases among its users. However, the study's conclusions have sparked debate among academics, with some expressing concerns about the potential for Facebook to manipulate the News Feed in the future.

Title: Gaetz, Gohmert, and Biggs Call for Mueller's Recusal Amid Uranium One Controversy

Article:

In the aftermath of the first indictments in the ongoing investigation into potential collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia, Representative Matt Gaetz (R-FL) has introduced a resolution calling for the resignation of Special Counsel Robert Mueller. Gaetz, along with Reps. Louie Gohmert of Texas and Andy Biggs of Arizona, cite Mueller's involvement in the "Uranium One" controversy, during which he served as FBI Director.

The Uranium One scandal refers to a deal approved by the Obama administration that allowed a Russian company to purchase a controlling interest in Uranium One, a Canadian mining company. Gaetz, in a statement, argued that evidence has emerged that the FBI withheld information from Congress and the American people about Russian corruption of American uranium companies. He further stated that a confidential U.S. witness revealed that Russia had compromised an American uranium tracking firm through bribery and financial kickbacks.

However, it is important to note that Clinton did not have the ability to approve or veto the sale. Her involvement was as one of nine cabinet members of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS). Only the president can decide to block a sale for national security reasons, and none of the other eight members or President Obama voted against or blocked the sale.

The resolution comes as a faction on the right continues to question Mueller's impartiality, with some arguing that his involvement in the Uranium One deal compromises his ability to lead the Russia investigation impartially. While a recent report found that roughly 20 Republican Senators have expressed support for Mueller and his investigation, there is still a faction on the right that believes Mueller should resign.

The White House has stated that President Trump has "no intention" of firing Mueller, but Trump himself has certainly left the possibility open. During a New York Times interview in July, Trump responded to a question about Mueller's focus on the Trump family finances by saying, "I would say yeah. I would say yes." This suggests that if Trump were to fire Mueller, he would have the support of some members in Congress.

The resolution introduced by Gaetz, Gohmert, and Biggs is a clear indication of the ongoing political divide surrounding the Russia investigation and the Uranium One controversy. It remains to be seen whether this resolution will gain traction in Congress and whether it will further complicate the ongoing investigation into potential collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia.

Title: The Decline of Community Organizations in America: A Threat to Democracy and Freedom

Article:

In the spirit of the French historian Alexis de Tocqueville, who observed the unique role of community organizations in the United States during his visit in the 1830s, it is crucial to examine the current state of these associations and their impact on American society.

De Tocqueville noted the prevalence of non-political community organizations in the U.S., which ranged from religious and educational to recreational and charitable. These groups played a significant role in fostering a sense of community and self-reliance, as Americans relied on each other rather than relying on the government.

Fast forward to the present day, and a concerning trend has emerged. According to political scientist Robert Putnam, Americans are increasingly isolating themselves, with a significant decline in membership in community organizations since the 1960s. This decline has been observed in various groups, including the Elks, the PTA, and Kiwanis, among others.

Putnam's research reveals a startling decrease in social interactions, with a nearly 60% drop in the number of Americans attending club meetings, more than 40% drop in the number of family dinners, and more than 30% drop in the number of people having friends over. This fracturing of community organizations has led to a weakening of the social fabric, with a growing political polarization and a lack of meaningful relationships across ideological divides.

The decline of community organizations has far-reaching implications for American democracy and freedom. As de Tocqueville warned, an ever-growing government may not be able to effectively replace the "innumerable multitude of small undertakings" that American citizens execute every day. Moreover, the lack of cross-ideological relationships makes it difficult to share the ideals of freedom and to change hearts and minds.

In the face of this trend, it is essential for Americans to recommit to their communities. By joining social clubs, civic organizations, or other groups, and making an effort to build relationships with people who live near us, we can help to strengthen our communities and save the country. After all, as de Tocqueville observed, "Americans of all ages, all conditions, all minds constantly unite." Let us remember the power of community and work together to build a stronger, more connected America.

Title: Republican Leadership Vows to Avoid Gridlock and Infighting in New Congressional Term

Article:

In the aftermath of their recent midterm election victories, the Republican leadership in Congress has signaled a shift towards unity and a more pragmatic approach to governance. According to Politico, incoming Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has indicated that he will not support conservative calls to use the debt ceiling as a bargaining chip for spending cuts, a move that triggered the government shutdown last year.

In a statement, McConnell emphasized the need to avoid the fiscal fights that have eroded public confidence in Washington and characterized the GOP-controlled House in past years. "Emboldened by sweeping midterm election victories," McConnell said, "Republican leaders are vowing not to repeat the errors of past years."

McConnell has also made it clear that he will not allow a government shutdown to occur during his tenure. In his victory speech on Tuesday night, he extended an olive branch to President Barack Obama, stating that the GOP has a "duty" to work with the White House on issues they agree on.

House Speaker John Boehner is also reportedly planning to be a "responsible leader," and to maintain unity within the party to capitalize on its political dominance, according to Politico. The leadership may feel more justified in demanding loyalty from the conservative wing of the party, given that the victories from this election cycle were largely the result of the party's early backing of establishment candidates, some of whom represent moderate districts.

Ohio GOP Rep. Steve Stivers, a close ally of Boehner, told Politico that the election results have given the Republicans a "working majority" and that they will be pursuing a "responsible Republican agenda." Stivers added that the party will not veer hard right, but will instead focus on issues that are "straight down the fairway."

McConnell and Boehner have already outlined their legislative agenda, with their top priority being to help the struggling middle class. They plan to pass many of the bills that the House has already approved, a move that they believe will signal that the logjam in Washington has been broken and will establish a foundation of certainty and stability.

The leadership will also be aware that unity could be crucial to maintaining the Senate majority in 2016, when a number of senators from blue and purple states are up for re-election, according to Politico. The Republican leadership's focus on unity and pragmatism could mark a significant shift in the political landscape and may lead to a more productive and less contentious Congress in the coming years.

Title: Republican Party Shifts Stance on Marijuana Laws: A Look at the 2016 Presidential Hopefuls' Views

Article:

As the 2016 presidential race heats up, a significant shift in the Republican Party's stance on marijuana laws is becoming increasingly evident. Traditionally, the GOP has been critical of marijuana and its medicinal value, but several key figures are advocating for a softening of federal marijuana laws, marking a dramatic departure from the party's recent contenders.

Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has been the most vocal on the issue, advocating for the federal government to leave marijuana regulation to the states. Texas Governor Rick Perry also supports state-level control of marijuana laws, citing drug courts in his state that he believes have contributed to Texas' movement towards decriminalization.

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, on the other hand, has pledged to end the "failed war on drugs," a policy initiated by President Nixon, a Republican, in 1971.

Erik Altieri, a spokesman for the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, noted this shift, stating, "This is something that probably would have been unimaginable in 2008: that GOP front-runners for president would be talking in terms of being smart on crime rather than hard on crime."
