In 2012, Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney vowed to fight marijuana legalization, even for medical use, and the 2008 nominee, Senator John McCain, labeled marijuana as a "gateway drug." However, Mr. McCain signaled a change in attitude in September, stating, "Maybe we should legalize" marijuana.

The change in stance is not limited to the Republican Party. In a New Yorker interview this month, President Obama, who has acknowledged using marijuana in his youth, said marijuana may be less dangerous than alcohol.

Despite federal laws classifying marijuana as a Schedule I substance, making it illegal to manufacture or distribute the drug, the Obama administration has stated it will allow states leeway as long as they do not see evidence of criminal gangs trafficking the drug or children gaining access.

This shift in marijuana policy is gaining traction in states that will be crucial in the 2016 elections, such as New Hampshire, which hosts the first-in-the-nation presidential primaries. In states that permit medical marijuana, it is commonly prescribed for chronic pain, nausea from cancer chemotherapy, glaucoma, and some other conditions.

An NBC/Wall Street Journal Poll released this week found that 55 percent of those surveyed would support efforts in their states similar to those in Colorado and Washington, where marijuana is legal for recreational use by adults over 21.

As the 2016 presidential race unfolds, the evolving views on marijuana laws among Republican candidates promise to be a significant factor in the political landscape.

Title: South and North Korean Leaders Meet to Discuss US-North Korea Summit

Article:

The leaders of North and South Korea have convened in the demilitarized zone (DMZ) between the two countries for a second meeting, as both sides continue their efforts to revive the planned US-North Korea summit. The meeting, which took place on the northern side of the Panmunjom truce village, was held between 15:00 and 17:00 local time (06:00 and 08:00 GMT), according to South Korean President Moon Jae-in's office.

Both leaders exchanged opinions on the successful holding of the North Korea-US summit, with South Korea's office stating that President Moon would announce the outcome of the talks on Sunday morning. In response, US President Donald Trump's administration confirmed that an advance team of White House and Department of State officials would leave for Singapore this weekend to prepare for a possible summit there.

The potential meeting between Trump and Kim Jong-un would focus on ways to denuclearize the Korean peninsula and reduce tensions. The US has expressed a desire for the complete and irreversible dismantling of North Korea's nuclear program and weapons, allowing international inspectors to monitor every step of the process before any sanctions are lifted. In contrast, North Korea views denuclearization as a more reciprocal agreement, with the expectation of comparable gestures from Washington, such as a reduction in the US military presence in South Korea and Japan.

The scheduled summit faced uncertainty when North Korea expressed displeasure over comments from senior US officials, who made comparisons with the case of Libya, where former leader Colonel Gaddafi gave up his nuclear program only to be killed by Western-backed rebels a few years later.

The leaders of both Koreas held a historic meeting at the border in April, marking the first time the Korean leaders had met to hold talks since 2007. At the meeting, Kim Jong-un expressed a desire to "write a new chapter" for the region's troubled history and to "start a new history from now, at the historic starting point of an era of peace."

Future economic cooperation between the Koreas was also discussed, with Kim Jong-un admitting that the North's critical infrastructure was in need of improvement. Such projects are likely to have suffered under international and US sanctions, imposed on the North in response to its nuclear program and missile tests.

Title: New Jersey Senator Cory Booker's Testimony Against Sessions: A Call for Civility and Respect in Political Debate

Article:

In a recent turn of events, New Jersey Senator Cory Booker testified against Sen. Jeff Sessions' nomination to be attorney general in Washington, on January 11, 2017. The exchange, captured by Joshua Roberts of Reuters, has sparked a debate on civility and respect in political discourse.

The incident has brought to light the term "manterrupting," a phenomenon where male senators interrupt female senators during hearings. In two separate hearings, California Democrat Kamala Harris was interrupted. The exchange between Booker and Harris, in particular, has been a subject of discussion, with Booker's behavior being criticized for its intensity and tone.

The exchange, if it had involved a conservative male senator and a progressive female cabinet secretary, would likely have been met with strong criticism from the liberal side. However, Booker's outburst was met with applause from some, with him proudly tweeting out his rant, quoting himself as if he had just had "a moment."

The incident has led to a broader discussion on identity politics, with many arguing that the Left's "respect for women" often stops when a female politician, pundit, or activist leans slightly to the right of moderate. The human capacity for rationalization and self-justification, it seems, is nearly infinite, and it was on display during the exchange.

The incident has also highlighted the hypocrisy that pervades political discourse, with many of the same Democrats who are critical of President Trump's words and actions once cheering similar comments from other politicians. The double standards and selective outrage have led many to question the sincerity of lamentations about "norms," "values," and "civility."

In the end, the only way to restore a measure of civility and dignity to public debate is to treat people with respect, even when one is angry. As a retired federal judge once said, "When you're troubled, even when you're angry, endeavor to speak with regret, not outrage." This thoughtful approach, it seems, is what is needed to cut through the noise and rebuild our body politic.

David French, a senior writer for ███ and a senior fellow at the ███ Institute, and an attorney, has called for a more thoughtful and respectful approach to political discourse. In the aftermath of the exchange between Booker and Harris, it is clear that such an approach is needed more than ever.

Title: U.S. and China Agree to Continue Trade Talks Amid Escalating Tariff War

Article:

WASHINGTON - U.S. President Donald Trump has ordered the imposition of tariffs on all remaining imports from China, marking an intensification in the ongoing trade war between the two economic powerhouses. The new tariffs, which could potentially affect about $300 billion worth of Chinese imports, are set to come on top of an increase in tariff rates to 25% from 10% on $200 billion worth of Chinese imports.

In a statement, U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer confirmed that a final decision on the new duties has not been made. The escalation in tariffs follows a lack of progress in trade negotiations between the U.S. and China, as both sides continue to grapple with significant differences over key issues.

Despite the escalation, Trump and Chinese Vice Premier Liu He have agreed to press on with further talks, avoiding a complete breakdown in negotiations. In a series of tweets, Trump expressed optimism, stating that the U.S. and China had held "candid and constructive conversations" and that the talks were "constructive."

The crux of the disagreement lies in China's proposal to delete prior commitments regarding changes to Chinese laws and policies on issues such as intellectual property protection and forced technology transfers. These changes were a significant part of the draft trade agreement, and their deletion has been a major stumbling block in the negotiations.

The new tariffs, if implemented, would impact more than 5,700 categories of products, including internet modems, routers, circuit boards, furniture, and lighting products. Seaborne cargoes shipped from China before midnight on Friday will not be subject to the new tax as long as they arrive in the United States prior to June 1.

The higher tariffs could potentially reduce U.S. gross domestic product by 0.3% and China's by 0.8% in 2020, according to consultancy Oxford Economics. The trade war's impact on U.S. businesses and consumers is a matter of concern, with American farmers and manufacturers expressing apprehension about the prolonged dispute.

In response to the U.S. tariff hike, China's Commerce Ministry has stated that it will take countermeasures but has not elaborated on the details. China responded to Trump's tariffs last year with levies on a range of U.S. goods, including soybeans and pork.

In light of the ongoing trade tensions, U.S. Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue has been tasked with creating a plan to support American farmers, who have already received up to $12 billion in government aid to help offset their China-related losses.

The trade war between the U.S. and China continues to unfold, with both sides expressing a willingness to engage in further talks. The outcome of these negotiations will have far-reaching implications for the global economy.

Title: Potential Vice Presidential Pick: Michael Bloomberg Emerges as a Contender for Mitt Romney's Running Mate

Article:

In the ongoing speculation surrounding Mitt Romney's choice for a vice presidential running mate, a surprising name has emerged: Michael Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City.

Rumors suggest that Romney is looking for a candidate who can attract voters on the fence, someone with a successful track record and a moderate social stance that would not immediately alienate independents. Bloomberg, known for his union-fighting and gay-couple-supportive policies, could be that candidate.

Four years ago, Sen. John McCain selected Sarah Palin, a game-changer who turned out to be more divisive than unifying. Bloomberg, on the other hand, would be a curveball, someone who could get people talking and thinking, not just talking.

Bloomberg is viewed as a real Republican, an old-school Republican, who would focus on reducing deficits by increasing revenue and making tough decisions on spending cuts. He is also known for his compassionate leadership and traditional Republican views, a stark contrast to the current GOP incarnation of the anti-tax, Bible-thumping conservative.

One of the key points in Bloomberg's favor is his stance on taxes. He has been open about the need to raise taxes as part of the deficit reduction equation, a position that could appeal to voters who are looking for honest, non-partisan assessments.

In a Wall Street Journal op-ed in March, Bloomberg wrote, "Republicans who emphasize economic freedom would have a lot more credibility if they'd stop promising a free lunch." This kind of honest assessment is what voters on the fence are looking for, according to LZ Granderson, a CNN commentator.

Despite Bloomberg's support for Romney, he has not endorsed the former Massachusetts governor due to their differences in social politics. However, if Romney is looking for a vice president who can help him appeal to independents and attract voters on the fence, Bloomberg could be the answer.

The opinions expressed in this article are solely those of the author and do not necessarily reflect the views of CNN.

Title: Migrant Mother Selected for Asylum Processing at U.S.-Mexico Border

Article:

Tijuana, Mexico - Gabriela Hernandez, a 27-year-old pregnant mother of two, was chosen by her fellow migrants on Monday to begin the process of seeking asylum in the United States. Hernandez, who had fled a threat of violence in Honduras with her sons, ages 6 and 2, was among eight people selected to present themselves to U.S. border officials.

Hernandez, her sons Jonathan, 2, and Omar, 6, braved a month-long journey to reach the port of entry at San Ysidro, only to be told by officials that they had reached capacity and were "temporarily unable to bring additional persons traveling without appropriate entry documentation into the port of entry for processing."

Dozens of migrants vowed to camp outside the center, waiting for "every last one" to be admitted into the United States. When customs officials began processing cases of "undocumented arrivals" on Monday, the migrants looked among themselves for who should step forward.

Hernandez, who had traveled 3,000 miles to reach this place, was chosen. The group agreed that Hernandez and another mother, along with their children, and a teenager traveling alone would go through the asylum process.

Hernandez's plan had always been to claim asylum, given the danger to her life and her children in Honduras. However, she knew it held no guarantees. "I don't know what I'm going to do," she had said earlier. "I can't go back to my country."

The journey to the U.S.-Mexico border was not easy for Hernandez and her family. They had scrounged for food, braved the rain, and faced the chill to make it to Tijuana. Hernandez's fellow migrant, Tesla Rich, had left her 9-month-old daughter Valentina with someone at the crossing.

On Monday, Hernandez and Rich, with their children, waited in line for hours, huddled together to keep warm. They ordered pizzas for the kids from a Domino's franchise, and Rich nursed Valentina while Hernandez made coffee for her sons.

The group faced challenges, including long wait times, cold weather, and the loss of a coffee cup that soaked their blankets. However, they remained hopeful, determined to seek a better life in the United States.

As of now, Hernandez and her family have entered the processing center, taking a step closer to their asylum claim. The outcome of their case remains uncertain, but they are hopeful for a brighter future.

Title: State Attorneys General Join Forces in Antitrust Probes of Google and Facebook, Adding Pressure on Federal Regulators

Article:

A bipartisan group of attorneys general from 48 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico have announced a joint investigation into Google's advertising business, marking a significant escalation in antitrust scrutiny of Big Tech. This move follows a smaller, overlapping group of attorneys general, led by New York's Letitia James, who are investigating Facebook's business practices.

The group investigating Google, which includes all states except California and Alabama, emphasized their independence from federal regulators, who are already questioning the company. Google previously disclosed that federal regulators are also investigating the company.

DC Attorney General Karl Racine, a Democrat, said Monday, "The state attorneys general, they are an independent bunch. And they can be quite tenacious. So I'm very confident that this bipartisan group is going to be led by the facts and not be swayed by any conclusion that may fall short, if you will, if it's inconsistent with our facts, on the federal side."

Racine's comments, and the mobilization of such a large group of attorneys general, could indicate a level of dissatisfaction among top state legal officials regarding federal action against Big Tech.

Recent federal regulatory action against Facebook and Google has had minimal impact on their core businesses or stock prices. For instance, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) fined Google $170 million for allegedly violating a law protecting children online, an amount that represented less than half of a single day's revenue for its parent company based on its second-quarter 2019 earnings.

The FTC's $5 billion settlement with Facebook over its use of user data also resolved all claims against Facebook and its executives involving its previous agreement with the agency.

For those waiting to see if the U.S. government will deal a more significant blow to Big Tech, the state AG investigations may be a welcome development. States have played a noteworthy role in past cases, gaining significant concessions from tobacco companies and pressuring Microsoft in a landmark antitrust case. In that case, attorneys general from 20 states and the District of Columbia joined the Justice Department in alleging Microsoft suppressed competition in the software market.

However, half a dozen antitrust experts interviewed for this article said state investigations can add heat to the federal probes, but ultimately, their resources pale in comparison to those of the FTC and DOJ. "The big picture here is that states can serve as a backstop if the federal government decides not to go after these companies," Rutgers Law professor Michael Carrier said. "You're putting 30 generally small offices together and then they have to coordinate," said Harry First, a professor at the New York University School of Law. "It's good, but it's not quite the same as the extent of the staffs on the federal level."

Considering both Google and Facebook are large global companies, "it's a heavy lift," First said. The state attorneys general's investigations will likely intensify the heat on Google and Facebook, but the outcome remains to be seen.

Title: Mark Zuckerberg Outlines Future Remote Work Plans for Facebook, With Salary Adjustments Based on Location

Article:

In a videoconference with employees on Thursday, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg outlined the company's plans for remote work in the future, stating that he expects about half of Facebook's employees to work from home permanently within the next five to ten years. However, there is a caveat for those hoping to maintain their high Silicon Valley salaries while living in a less expensive area.

Zuckerberg revealed that Facebook will aggressively ramp up the hiring of remote workers, though not all employees will be allowed to work from home permanently at the start. For those who choose to work in areas with lower costs of living, they should expect to be paid less.

"That means if you live in a location where the cost of living is dramatically lower, or the cost of labor is lower, then salaries do tend to be somewhat lower in those places," Zuckerberg said.

Currently, Facebook pays its employees based on location, but Zuckerberg stated that employees working remotely must notify Facebook if they move to a new area before January 1, 2021. At that point, the company will adjust the salary to the new location, taking taxes into account. Zuckerberg warned that there will be "severe ramifications" for those who are not honest about their location.

This may impact the plans of some workers who were hoping to stretch their salaries further in cheaper areas. A recent survey of San Francisco Bay Area tech workers found that two-thirds would consider moving away from the pricey area if they could work remotely. "It makes no sense paying Bay Area rent if we can earn our salary living elsewhere," one startup employee told Bloomberg News.

As of 2018, the median employee compensation at Facebook was over $240,000 a year. The median home price in Menlo Park, California, where Facebook's headquarters is located, is $2.4 million, according to Zillow, while the median home price in the wider Bay Area was $928,000 last year.

Zuckerberg also shared that, in a company survey, of the people who said they would want to work remotely full-time, about 45% were "pretty confident" that they would move to another place if they had that opportunity, with an additional 30% saying they "might" move. About 60% of that total said they'd prefer to move to a smaller city or town.

Ultimately, Zuckerberg said the changes will help Facebook become more diverse in its workforce. "When you limit hiring to people who either live in a small number of big cities or are willing to move there, that cuts out a lot of people who live in different communities, different backgrounds, or may have different perspectives," he said. "Certainly being able to recruit more broadly, especially across the U.S. and Canada to start, is going to open up a lot of new talent that previously wouldn't have considered moving to a big city."

Currently, about 95% of Facebook's employees are working from home due to coronavirus stay-at-home orders. The company has previously said workers will be able to work from home at least through the end of the year.

Title: A Closer Look at the U.S. Election Interference Allegations: A Matter of Voter Education or Cybersecurity?

Article:

Last week, President Obama announced sanctions against Russia in response to alleged data theft and disclosure activities that were intended to interfere with the U.S. election process. Hillary Clinton described these activities, which revealed purloined emails that were detrimental to her during her unsuccessful presidential campaign, as an "attack against our country" and "our electoral system" that undermined "the integrity of our democracy."

However, these overheated descriptions may misleadingly equate information that guides voters' choices with nullification of those choices. A calmer, less partisan perspective suggests that what Clinton and Obama view as interference with the election process might more accurately be described as voter education, which strengthens democracy by helping its participants make better-informed choices.

News reports frequently describe the leaking of emails stolen from the Democratic National Committee (DNC) and John Podesta, Clinton's campaign chairman, as "election hacking." John McCain, the GOP's 2008 presidential nominee, seems to agree with that characterization. In a CNN interview last month, the Arizona senator, a harsh critic of Donald Trump who denounced him, endorsed him, and then withdrew his endorsement, complained that by leaking information helpful to the Republican nominee, "the Russians…have been able to interfere with our electoral process." He warned that "if they are able to harm the electoral process, then they destroy democracy, which is based on free and fair elections."

This take seems pretty hysterical in light of what actually happened. True election hacking, aimed at perpetrating voting fraud, obviously would be a threat to the democratic process. But there is no evidence of such interference, and it's not even clear that the DNC and Podesta emails had an impact on the election results—or why it would be so terrible if they did.

The New York Times reports that hackers gained access to the emails through standard phishing techniques, tricking Podesta and at least one DNC employee into revealing their passwords by pretending to be from Google. The Times notes that "every major publication, including The Times, published multiple stories citing the D.N.C. and Podesta emails posted by WikiLeaks, becoming a de facto instrument of Russian intelligence."

Those news organizations did that because much of the information in the emails—including DNC officials' disdain for Clinton rival Bernie Sanders, excerpts from her secret Wall Street speeches, and observations about her weaknesses as a candidate—concerned matters of legitimate public interest. It was information that voters might rationally want to consider before deciding which candidate to support.

Valuable journalism is often based on information that was obtained or divulged illegally by people with axes to grind. It is hard to see how this case is different in principle. Is it the nationality of the informants that matters? If the emails that embarrassed Clinton had been swiped by Americans, would she still be talking about a democracy-threatening attack on our electoral process?

Last fall, the Times "obtained" parts of Donald Trump's 1995 tax return and shared them with the public. If that information had come from a foreign source, would publishing it have undermined democracy?

Suppose German hackers had managed to obtain complete copies of Trump's recent tax returns—a subject of intense journalistic interest—and shared them with news outlets, either directly or through an intermediary like Wikileaks. Would Clinton have perceived the resulting exposés as undermining the electoral process or assisting it?

Cybersecurity is a serious concern, especially when it comes to systems that control important functions such as vote counting, banking, and the distribution of electricity. Helping politicians conceal facts that might alienate voters probably does not belong in the same category. Judging from the account in the Times, both the FBI and the DNC were remarkably lax in their initial responses to the intrusions that produced a bounty of newsworthy emails. Politicians with things to hide might want to be more careful about the security of the systems they use to discuss sensitive matters. But we should not confuse their challenge with a threat to democracy.

Title: China and U.S. Express Confidence in Reaching Trade Deal, but Skepticism Prevails Amidst Tight Negotiating Window

Article:

China and the United States have expressed confidence in reaching a trade deal, despite President Donald Trump's warning of potential tariffs if negotiations fail. The Chinese Commerce Ministry, in a statement on Wednesday, expressed optimism about the implementation of issues already agreed upon, following a temporary truce in the trade war between the two nations.

The ministry stated that both sides would actively promote negotiations within 90 days, following the agreement reached by Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping at a meeting in Argentina on Saturday. The ministry described the latest bilateral talks as "very successful."

Trump, via Twitter, hinted at the possibility of an extension of the ceasefire but warned of potential tariffs if the talks did not yield fruitful results. He stated that negotiations with China would end 90 days from the date of their dinner with President Xi, unless extended.

The White House has stated that China has committed to start buying more American products and lifting tariff and non-tariff barriers immediately, while beginning talks on structural changes with respect to forced technology transfers and intellectual property protection.

However, the threat of further escalation in the trade war between the world's two largest economies has cast a shadow over financial markets and the global economy for much of the year. Investors initially welcomed the ceasefire, but skepticism about the ability to reach a substantive deal within the short negotiating period agreed has led to a downturn in global financial markets.

China's Foreign Ministry has referred specific questions to the Commerce Ministry, which is due to hold its weekly news briefing on Thursday in Beijing.

Officials from the U.S. and a number of other major economies have often criticized China for its slow approach to negotiations and not following through on commitments. China has been relatively quiet about the Trump-Xi agreement, with some differences between U.S. and Chinese accounts of what the deal entails.

Analysts suggest that officials now face the difficult task of fleshing out a deal that is acceptable to China but also involves significant enough concessions not to be torpedoed by the China hawks in the Trump administration. There is a possibility that no agreement can be reached within 90 days, with the higher tariff rate coming into force only a few months later than originally planned.

A Chinese official told Reuters that officials were "waiting for the leaders to return" before publicizing details. President Xi and his most senior officials are due back in China on Thursday, having visited Panama and Portugal since leaving Argentina.

The Global Times tabloid, which is run by the Chinese Communist Party's main newspaper, suggested that myriad statements from the Trump administration about the deal were designed to highlight or even exaggerate facets of the deal that benefited the United States. The tabloid stated that reaching an agreement within three months is a spur to not only China, but also the U.S. If the two sides fail to reach a deal, all the White House promises will be invalid.

In conclusion, while both China and the U.S. have expressed confidence in reaching a trade deal, skepticism remains about the ability to reach a substantive agreement within the tight negotiating window agreed upon by the two nations. The potential for further escalation in the trade war between the world's two largest economies continues to cast a shadow over financial markets and the global economy.

Title: Harvard Honors Colin Kaepernick, Dave Chappelle, and Other African American Luminaries with W.E.B. Du Bois Medal

Article:

In a significant recognition of African American culture and contributions, Harvard University's Hutchins Center for African & African American Studies has announced the recipients of this year's W.E.B. Du Bois Medal. The prestigious award, named after the renowned scholar, civil rights activist, and first African American to earn a doctorate from Harvard, honors individuals who have made significant contributions to African American culture and the life of the mind.

This year's recipients include Colin Kaepernick, Dave Chappelle, Kevin Hart, Bryan Stevenson, Kenneth Chenault, Shirley Ann Jackson, Pamela Joyner, Florence Ladd, and Kehinde Wiley. The ceremony honoring these individuals will take place at Harvard's Memorial Hall on October 11.

Colin Kaepernick, the former NFL quarterback, is being recognized for his protests against racial injustice and inequality. Dave Chappelle, the celebrated comedian, is being honored for his ability to combine racial insight, reason, and comedy. Kevin Hart was considered but was not able to attend due to seating limitations.

Bryan Stevenson, the founder, and executive director of the Equal Justice Initiative, is being recognized for his work in the field of criminal justice reform. Kenneth Chenault, the former CEO of American Express and a member of Facebook's Board of Directors, is being honored for his efforts in promoting diversity in corporate boardrooms.

Shirley Ann Jackson, the first black woman to earn a doctorate from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is being recognized for her groundbreaking achievements in physics and her National Medal of Science. Pamela Joyner, a San Francisco philanthropist, is being honored for her significant contributions to the promotion and collection of black art.

Florence Ladd, the legendary novelist and poet, is being recognized for her extensive body of work and her contributions to education, both in the United States and abroad. Kehinde Wiley, the artist who painted the portrait of Barack Obama that hangs in the Smithsonian's National Portrait Gallery, is being honored for his contributions to the visual arts.

The ceremony will be free and open to the public. It is expected to be a celebration of the achievements and contributions of these eight individuals, and a testament to the enduring legacy of W.E.B. Du Bois.

Title: The Misinterpretation of Social Mobility in America: A Closer Look at Achievement and Aspiration

Article:

In recent discussions surrounding social mobility in America, a crucial distinction has been overlooked: the difference between opportunity and realization. While it is true that the United States has seen a decline in upward mobility for those born into lower socioeconomic levels, it is essential to recognize that this does not necessarily equate to a lack of opportunity, but rather, a disparity between opportunity and actual achievement.

The focus on "barriers" created by society often overshadows the internal values and aspirations that drive individuals to pursue certain paths. For instance, the fact that sons of high school dropouts are less likely to become doctors or scientists than the sons of Ph.D.s does not automatically imply that American society is inherently unfair. Instead, it may simply reflect the differing interests and aspirations of various demographic groups.

Moreover, the notion that equal representation of every demographic group in every field is a sign of fairness is flawed. Life has never been fair, and it is unrealistic to expect it to be so in the United States or anywhere else. The idea that an absence of evidence for discrimination is merely proof of its covert nature is a dangerous and misguided assumption.

A case in point is the under-representation of women in computer engineering. Instead of attributing this disparity to "barriers" created by society, it is essential to consider the unique agendas and interests of women, who may not be as drawn to computer engineering as other demographic groups. Forcing women into engineering schools or launching propaganda campaigns to change their interests would be counterproductive and disregard their individual aspirations.

Furthermore, it is worth noting that some celebrated statistical studies of social mobility exclude Asian Americans, a group that has achieved remarkable success in various fields, including technology and academia. This success challenges the notion that upward mobility is a rare occurrence in America.

In conclusion, it is crucial to approach discussions of social mobility with a nuanced understanding of opportunity, achievement, and individual aspirations. By recognizing the complexities of human behavior and the role of personal choices, we can better understand the factors that contribute to social mobility and work towards creating a more equitable society that respects and nurtures the unique talents and aspirations of all its citizens.

Title: Conservative Commentator Ann Coulter Criticizes Sen. Marco Rubio's Immigration Reform Proposals, Labels Plan as "Amnesty"

Article:

In a recent column for Human Events, conservative commentator Ann Coulter has joined a growing chorus of Republican critics of Sen. Marco Rubio's immigration reform proposals. Coulter argues that Rubio's efforts are aimed at creating "more Democratic voters."

Coulter's criticism follows similar sentiments expressed by Louisiana Sen. David Vitter, who called Rubio's attempts to forge a bipartisan overhaul bill that grants citizenship to illegal immigrants "naive." Former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush also weighed in this week, writing that some in Congress are seeking "quick fixes" to the problem.

In her column, Coulter notes that Rubio's supporters claim that his proposals are not amnesty, but rather a pathway to citizenship. "They seem to think they can bully Republicans the way the Democrats do, by controlling the language," she wrote. "Rubio’s bill is nothing but amnesty. It isn’t even ‘amnesty thinly disguised as border enforcement.’ This is a wolf in wolf’s clothing."

Coulter continued, "Despite all the blather about how Rubio demands ‘Enforcement First,’ the very first thing his proposal does is make illegal aliens legal."

On Wednesday, Rubio defended his efforts in a conversation with Rush Limbaugh, stating that his bipartisan effort is designed to avoid the problems that plagued the 1986 immigration bill that granted amnesty to three million illegal immigrants but failed to provide more border security and tougher enforcement mechanisms.

"Well-intentioned, but counterproductive because, A, they granted a blanket amnesty to 3 million people at the time, and B, they didn’t do any of the enforcement mechanisms," he said of the 1986 law. "And so our point is, if we’re going to deal with this, let’s deal with it once and for all and in a way that this never, ever happens again."

That includes beefed up border security, workplace enforcement, and a visa tracking system, he said.

However, Coulter wrote, "Step One of Marco Rubio’s plan is: Grant illegal aliens the right to live and work in America legally. (Rubio’s first move in poker: Fold)."

The debate over immigration reform continues to be a contentious issue within the Republican Party, with some members advocating for a more hardline approach and others, like Rubio, seeking a more comprehensive solution. The future of the proposed legislation remains uncertain, as both sides continue to negotiate and debate the best course of action.

Title: Analysis: Ten Contradictions in Donald Trump's Foreign Policy Speech Suggest a Strategy of Having "Cake and Eating It"

Article:

In his first major foreign policy address, former President Donald Trump presented a speech that, while echoing familiar tones, has sparked a heated political debate due to its content's scrutiny. Madeleine Albright, a former Secretary of State representing the Hillary Clinton campaign, criticized the speech for containing "simplistic slogans, contradictions, and misstatements." Trump's supporters, however, argue that he effectively highlighted the inconsistencies of the Democratic establishment's approach under Obama and Clinton.

Here are ten passages that suggest Trump may be engaging in a common political tactic: having his cake and eating it.

1. Trump stated that some groups "will never be anything but our enemies," following his criticism of Obama for negotiating with Iran. However, he later claimed, "The world must know we do not go abroad in search of enemies, that we are always happy when old enemies become friends, and when old friends become allies."

2. Trump lambasted Obama for neglecting overseas partners, promising, "America is going to be a reliable friend and ally again." Yet, he issues warnings about paying for NATO membership that might sound like blackmail to some. "The countries we are defending must pay for the cost of this defense – and, if not, the US must be prepared to let these countries defend themselves."

3. Trump was ambiguous about America's role in promoting democracy, claiming, "We are getting out of the nation-building business," but then adding, "I will work with our allies to reinvigorate western values and institutions."

4. Trump argued for promoting "western civilization and its accomplishments" to inspire positive reforms worldwide, but he has also offended much of the Muslim world by threatening to ban their citizens from entering the US.

5. Criticisms of Obama's "humiliations" at the hands of foreign governments do not stand up to much scrutiny. Trump claimed that Obama was snubbed during state visits to Cuba and Saudi Arabia because he was not greeted at the airport by a senior leader. However, the Queen's decision to send a less prestigious official to meet Obama at London's Stansted airport was not mentioned.

6. Trump's criticism of Obama's failed attempt to secure the 2016 Summer Games for Chicago does not hold up to scrutiny. He argued that the president should not have flown all the way to the IOC meeting in Copenhagen if he did not already know they were going to award the games to the US, but what would have been the point of flying all that way to lobby for something that had already been secured?

7. Trump's call for unpredictability in foreign policy is contradicted by his call for a more transparent and principled approach. "We have to be unpredictable and we have to be unpredictable starting now," he argued, but by the end of the speech, he argued for the virtues of a more transparent and principled approach.

8. Trump claimed, "There are scores of recent migrants inside our borders charged with terrorism," an assertion already open to dispute, but went on to add, "For every case known to the public, there are dozens and dozens more." If "scores" means at least 40, then by this logic, Trump is claiming the existence of around 1,000 more people than anyone else has.

9. The speech's abiding slogan, "America First," could have done with more fact-checking. Putting America first sounds like an extension of Trump's hallmark promise to make America great again, but it also harks back to the America First Committee of the 1940s, a group set up to prevent the US from joining the second world war, only to be disbanded three days after the attack on Pearl Harbor.

10. The speech's biggest contradiction may be the tension between its isolationism and interventionism. At once, Trump urges a pragmatic and realist approach to the exercise of US power, unconstrained by the niceties of political correctness, and yet blasts Obama for having "no vision, no purpose, no direction, no strategy."

It is perhaps unfair to dwell too closely on textual analysis of a speech clearly written by a number of people. However, the speech's inconsistencies and contradictions are worth noting as they provide insight into Trump's foreign policy stance and the challenges that may arise in implementing it.

Title: Hillary Clinton Advocates for Comprehensive Immigration Reform, Distancing Herself from Republican Contenders

In a significant move, former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has outlined her immigration policy during a speech in Las Vegas on Tuesday, positioning herself as a strong advocate for immigration reform. This stance places her to the left of President Barack Obama and sets her apart from potential Republican presidential candidates.

Clinton's proposals include a path to citizenship for the estimated 11 million undocumented immigrants residing in the United States. As President, she pledged to take broader executive action on deferring deportations for those with strong community ties, such as through family and work. Additionally, she promised to improve conditions for immigrant detainees, aiming to make them more humane.

In contrast to Clinton's comprehensive approach, several potential Republican candidates appear to be advocating for more limited reforms. For instance, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, who was once an advocate for sensible reform, now seems to be pushing for a provisional status for the undocumented, a lengthy and challenging path to a temporary work permit. Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, who has been moderate on the issue in the past, is reportedly wobbly on citizenship, with his stance on the matter unclear.

Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky and Governor Scott Walker of Wisconsin, meanwhile, have expressed more conservative views. Paul's agenda appears to be focused on border security and ending the 14th Amendment guarantee of citizenship by birth. Walker, on the other hand, has called for all unauthorized immigrants to leave the country and has also expressed a desire to limit legal immigration.

Clinton's full-throated public commitment to expansive immigration action is a recent development, and it remains to be seen whether she will maintain this stance throughout her campaign. However, her clear and unequivocal support for immigration reform is a departure from her previous, more cautious approach, as demonstrated by her response to questions from young immigrant advocates last fall, where she suggested electing more Democrats as a solution.

Title: Trump Files Lawsuit Against Deutsche Bank and Capital One to Prevent Congressional Financial Records Release

Article:

In a significant legal move, U.S. President Donald Trump has filed a lawsuit against Deutsche Bank and Capital One in an attempt to prevent the banks from complying with subpoenas issued by Democrat-led congressional committees for information on his financial records. The lawsuit, which was filed in New York on Monday, aims to block the banks from complying with the subpoenas, which are part of an investigation into the Trump family's financial dealings.

The lawsuit, which includes Trump's three eldest children and the Trump Organization, argues that there are no legitimate grounds for investigating the president's business affairs. The filing alleges that the subpoenas "have no legitimate or lawful purpose" and were issued "to harass President Donald J. Trump, to rummage through every aspect of his personal finances, his businesses, and the private information of the president and his family."

Deutsche Bank, one of the Trump Organization's major lenders, and a number of other financial institutions were issued subpoenas earlier this month by the House Intelligence and Financial Services Committees. The committees are reportedly seeking documents and materials relating to the bank's longstanding relationship with Trump and his family.

Representative Adam Schiff, the Democratic chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, described the subpoenas as part of an investigation "into allegations of potential foreign influence on the US political process." In a joint statement, Schiff and fellow Democrat Maxine Waters, the chairwoman of the Financial Services Committee, described the lawsuit as "meritless."

"[It shows] the depths to which President Trump will go to obstruct Congress's constitutional oversight authority," they said. "He will find that Congress will not be deterred from carrying out its constitutional responsibilities."

In 2017, Deutsche Bank rejected requests by Democrats in the House of Representatives to provide details of the president's finances, citing privacy laws. That year it was also reported that special counsel Robert Mueller, who led the investigation into alleged collusion between the Trump presidential campaign and Russia, had ordered Deutsche Bank to provide records of Trump's accounts.

Title: Controversy Surrounds Free Summer Meal Program for Children Across the U.S.

Article:

Every summer, more than 3 million children across the United States receive free meals at over 30,000 sites, including schools, recreation centers, and migrant worker camps. This program, funded by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, provides a valuable resource for families who are struggling, but it has also become a subject of debate among critics.

At the "Summer Fun Cafe" in northern California, and similar locations, meals are offered to children, with at least half of the children in the area qualifying for free lunches during the school year. However, during the summer, anyone aged 18 and under can partake in these free meals.

"There's no income requirement, no enrollment, no paperwork," said Monique Stovall, nutrition director for the San Juan Unified School District outside Sacramento. "All children in the community in that age range can come eat with us for free."

Signs around the district headquarters advertise the fact that there is no eligibility requirement, and invite all children to take advantage. This has led to concerns among critics about the potential for taxpayers to unintentionally fund meals for children who may not be in need.

Jon Coupal, with the Howard Jarvis Taxpayers Association, questions, "If someone is coming from a family that makes a quarter-of-a-million dollars a year, and they're not checking eligibility when they're coming in the door, I think most people would wonder, 'Am I paying for this?'"

For low-income families, a free lunch means more money can be allocated towards other meals or necessities. For those who can afford to feed their children, it offers a convenient option.

"Normally, we wouldn't qualify for a free lunch, but we're close and it's convenient, and my kids like it—that's important," said mom Julie Marks, who brought her two young boys.

In many cases, charity and nonprofit groups help sponsor free meal sites in their community. According to program supporters, the summer lunch program is easier to administer when the location qualifies, as opposed to the user.

"We don't have to ask your income, because the overall purpose of the program is to provide a healthy meal to children," Stovall said.

Organizers argue that after a summer of nourishing meals, these children will do better when school resumes in the fall. Monitors are present to ensure that the lunch is consumed on-site, and that adults do not exploit the program.

Title: Republican Senators Propose Replacing Columbus Day with Juneteenth as Federal Holiday

Article:

In a bid to acknowledge and celebrate the nation's historical milestones, Republican senators Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) and James Lankford (R-Okla.) have introduced an amendment that proposes replacing Columbus Day with Juneteenth as a federal holiday. The proposal, which follows a bipartisan Senate bill introduced last week by Senator John Cornyn (R-Texas), aims to establish Juneteenth as a federal holiday while offsetting the associated costs.

The amendment, if passed, would mark a significant shift in the federal recognition of historical events. Juneteenth, commemorating the day in 1865 when slavery definitively ended in the U.S., is currently celebrated as a holiday in 47 states. The holiday has gained increased attention amid the nationwide protests that followed George Floyd's death in police custody.

The proposal comes amid the ongoing debate surrounding the removal and vandalization of statues of Christopher Columbus, an Italian Renaissance-era explorer often credited with being the first European to discover the Americas. Critics have called for Columbus Day to be eliminated or renamed as Indigenous Peoples' Day, citing Columbus's subjugation and mistreatment of the New World's native population.

Senator Lankford stated, "Throughout our history, we have strived to become a more perfect union, and Juneteenth was a huge step in attaining that goal." He further added, "We should celebrate these strides on the federal level while remaining cognizant of the impact the existing 10 federal holidays have on federal services and local businesses."

Senator Johnson echoed Lankford's sentiments, stating, "We support celebrating emancipation with a federal holiday, but believe we should eliminate a current holiday in exchange." He specified that Columbus Day was chosen as the holiday to be replaced due to its light celebration and minimal disruption to Americans' schedules.

The proposal is not without controversy, as Senator Cornyn told The Hill that eliminating Columbus Day in favor of Juneteenth is "problematic" and "dilutes the message we're trying to send, which is one of being respectful and honoring and remembering our history."

The amendment's passage and the eventual establishment of Juneteenth as a federal holiday would mark a significant step in recognizing and celebrating the end of slavery in the United States. The debate surrounding the replacement of Columbus Day with Juneteenth, however, continues to spark discussions about historical recognition, racial equality, and the impact of federal holidays on American society.

Title: Bipartisan Efforts Yield Approval of Coronavirus Relief Bill as Trump Tweets Support

Article:

In a series of events marked by uncertainty and last-minute negotiations, the House of Representatives passed the Families First Coronavirus Response Act on Saturday, following a tweet of approval from President Donald Trump. The bill, which aims to provide relief to individuals and businesses affected by the ongoing coronavirus outbreak, was the result of intense, round-the-clock negotiations between Democrats and Republicans.

The day began with a sense of confusion, as key officials from both parties contradicted each other on the status of the deal. Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi, in a letter to her fellow Democrats after 10 p.m. on Friday, acknowledged the intense negotiations required to meet the deadline for the bill's passage. She thanked her colleagues for their patience amid the frenetic back-and-forth with the administration.

Pelosi had initially announced a deal around 6 p.m., but House Republicans, including the No. 2 House Democrat, Steny Hoyer, disputed this, stating that talks were still ongoing. Key Republicans expressed concerns about a tax credit for paid family sick leave, with House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy confirming that Republicans sought more flexibility for small business owners.

Adding to the confusion, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, in an unexpected move, announced on Fox Business that he had reached an agreement with Pelosi. This announcement came after a meeting with Trump that delayed Mnuchin's appearance on the network.

Trump eventually tweeted his support for the bill hours later, providing long-awaited clarity to hundreds of members and aides who had been in limbo for 48 hours. In his tweet, Trump expressed his support for H.R. 6201 and directed the Secretary of the Treasury and the Secretary of Labor to issue regulations that would provide flexibility to small businesses. He encouraged all Republicans and Democrats to vote yes.

One of the other major obstacles during the negotiations was Trump's personal demand for a payroll tax cut in this package. This idea has little support on Capitol Hill, and Democrats have already stated that it would be debated as part of future coronavirus crisis-related legislation.

McCarthy, who met with Trump and Mnuchin multiple times in the last 24 hours, confirmed that Trump had sought the last-minute addition. He also indicated that Republicans would push for it in the next tranche of economic relief, which could be presented later this month or in April.

"I believe this will not be the only one," McCarthy said, alluding to future aid packages related to the outbreak. "This is something that the president wants, we would have liked to have that as well. I think that would have taken a little more time."

Title: GOP Faces Internal Disagreement on Healthcare Reform as ObamaCare Repeal-Only Bill Faces Uncertain Future

Article:

In a turn of events, Republican lawmakers are grappling with competing ideas for the future of healthcare reform following the collapse of the current ObamaCare replacement effort. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) acknowledged Monday night that the Senate's current approach would fail after two more senators announced opposition to the current healthcare draft.

Without the necessary votes, McConnell stated that the Senate will take up a repeal-only bill that Congress passed in 2015. "Regretfully, it is now apparent that the effort to repeal and immediately replace the failure of Obamacare will not be successful," McConnell said in a statement.

The repeal-only approach is backed by conservatives, who argue that Congress should just pass again what it already approved in 2015. President Trump joined the conservatives, tweeting Monday night, "Republicans should just REPEAL failing ObamaCare now & work on a new Healthcare Plan that will start from a clean slate. Dems will join in!"

However, the 2015 repeal-only bill does not appear to have the votes to pass, and other GOP lawmakers called Monday for working with Democrats or passing an alternative GOP bill. "The Congress must now return to regular order, hold hearings, receive input from members of both parties, and heed the recommendations of our nation's governors so that we can produce a bill that finally provides Americans with access to quality and affordable health care," Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) said in a statement.

Some Republicans have raised the idea of a bipartisan bill to stabilize ObamaCare markets, which could include funding for key payments to insurers known as cost-sharing reductions and possibly funding to bring down premiums for high-cost enrollees, known as "reinsurance." However, conservative members, including Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn (R-Texas), have objected to the idea of a stabilization bill as simply throwing more money at the healthcare law.

Meanwhile, Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) put forward a third approach on Monday night, touting a bill he recently proposed with Sen. Bill Cassidy (R-La.) to give states a chunk of money and let them decide whether to keep much of ObamaCare or try something new. That approach has been attacked from both the left and right.

The internal disagreement among Republicans on the future of healthcare reform is a setback for the party, which has long criticized ObamaCare and promised to repeal and replace it. The ongoing debate highlights the challenges of crafting a healthcare policy that can garner the support of a diverse Republican caucus, as well as the potential for bipartisan cooperation on healthcare issues.

Title: President Trump Makes Surprise Visit to Afghanistan on Thanksgiving, Holds Secret Peace Talks with Taliban

Article:

In an unexpected turn of events, President Donald Trump made a surprise visit to Afghanistan on Thanksgiving morning to express his gratitude to the troops for their service and to serve a traditional turkey dinner. The visit, however, required stringent security measures to maintain secrecy and prevent the news from leaking out.

"There's nowhere I'd rather spend Thanksgiving than with the toughest, fiercest warriors," Trump told the troops on the ground. "I'm here to say Happy Thanksgiving and thank you very much. As president of the United States, I have no higher honor than serving as commander in chief."

The journey began on Wednesday, with Trump departing from Mar-a-Lago undercover. The specifics of his departure are largely unknown, but it is known that he flew out of an undisclosed airport in Florida on a small, undisclosed plane in the evening.

On the flight bound for Joint Base Andrews, in Maryland, only one Fox News journalist served as the pool reporter. The plane was sparsely equipped, with only four blue leather chairs and a portable toilet brought for the occasion. Phones were confiscated from all onboard, including senior White House officials, and Trump remained in the cockpit for takeoff.

Upon landing at Joint Base Andrews later Wednesday evening, Trump switched to Air Force One, which was hidden in a hangar. The plane took off from JBA with all interior lights off and the windows drawn. The plane landed in Afghanistan on a pitch-black runway, with the pool only allowed to take pictures of Trump's arrival from a nearby van.

Accompanying Trump were White House Press Secretary Stephanie Grisham, Acting Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney, National Security Adviser Robert O'Brien, Deputy Press Secretary Judd Deere, and Sen. John Barrasso (R-Wyo.). Grisham stated that only a tight circle of White House officials knew about the trip, and the White House even scheduled tweets to be sent out from the president's account during the Internet blackout that he faced.

"It's a dangerous area, and he (the President) wants to support the troops," Grisham said. "He and Mrs. Trump recognize that there are a lot of people who are away from their families during the holidays, and we thought it would be a nice surprise."

The visit came as a surprise to the troops, the public, and the media, catching some outlets off guard. Newsweek had to overhaul an article that it had earlier posted, reporting that the president would spend the day tweeting and playing golf.

After serving and eventually sitting down for a Thanksgiving dinner, which included turkey, mashed potatoes, cornbread, baked ham, mac and cheese, cornish hen, and candied yams, Trump took as many pictures as time allowed with the troops. He then met with Afghan President Ashraf Ghani. Due to security concerns, the White House notified Ghani only "a few hours ago," according to the White House.

Trump then finished his trip by addressing a few hundred cheering troops in the hangar on the airfield, bringing Ghani on the stage to also express his appreciation to the American troops. Trump told them that everyone was working hard to bring them back home.

"We will continue to work tirelessly for the day when all of you can go home to your families... and that day is coming very soon," he said. The president also stated that peace talks with the Taliban have resumed, but later tweeted that the talks are "dead" after cancelling a secret Camp David summit.

Title: Terrorist Incident in London: Car Ramming Attack on Westminster Bridge and Parliament

Article:

In a shocking turn of events, a car plowed through pedestrians on Westminster Bridge and crashed into a fence surrounding the Houses of Parliament in London on Tuesday afternoon. The incident, confirmed as a terrorist attack, has left several casualties and sent shockwaves through the city.

Kirsten Hurrell, a 70-year-old newsstand owner opposite Big Ben, was the first to witness the aftermath. She described seeing a car swerve across a bicycle lane and into the Parliament fence, with a body lying on the ground. "At first I thought it was an accident," she said, "but then I was told the car had already mowed down quite a number of people on Westminster Bridge."

Robert Vaudry, a 52-year-old fund manager from Stratford-upon-Avon, was in the vicinity when the incident occurred. He had emerged from the Westminster subway station around 2:40 p.m. for a meeting with a lawmaker when he was confronted by armed policemen. "I came out of the Tube and there were two armed policemen," he said in an interview. "One grabbed my arm, pushed me to the left and said, 'Get out of here.'"

Radoslaw Sikorski, a former foreign minister of Poland, was in a taxi on Westminster Bridge when the pedestrians were hit by the car. He did not see the impact but heard it, describing the sound as a car hitting a sheet of metal. He saw five people lying on the ground, one of whom was unconscious and bleeding heavily from his head.

Andrew Bone, the executive director of the Responsible Jewellery Council, was on a bus heading toward Victoria Station when it was stopped at the edge of Parliament Square. Initially thinking an action movie was being filmed, he soon realized the gravity of the situation as the bus was evacuated and he saw the vehicle that had crashed into a railing.

The incident marks the first large-scale terrorist attack in Britain since July 7, 2005, when bomb attacks on subway trains and a bus killed more than 50 people. Political violence is relatively rare in Britain, where gun ownership is stringently restricted.

This attack is consistent with the recent pattern of attacks in which a vehicle was used to kill people, citing assaults in France, Germany, and Israel. Jeremy Shapiro, a former State Department official now at the European Council on Foreign Relations, commented on this trend, stating, "We've seen a gradual movement away from terrorist attacks on the West to attacks on softer and softer targets with more improvised weapons."

The incident has left the city in a state of shock, with many recalling past incidents such as the assassination of Airey Neave, a Conservative Party member, in 1979, when his car was blown up near the Parliament building. The city remains on high alert as investigations continue.

Title: Trump Withdraws John Ratcliffe as U.S. Spy Chief Nominee, Considering Alternatives Amidst Resume Concerns and Lack of Experience

Article:

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - President Donald Trump on Friday withdrew his choice of John Ratcliffe to be U.S. spy chief after questions arose about the congressman's lack of experience and possible exaggerations in his resume, marking the latest upheaval over a top national security post.

Trump announced the move five days after he surprised many in Washington by making the conservative Republican lawmaker from Texas his selection to replace Daniel Coats as director of national intelligence, a post that oversees the 17 U.S. civilian and military intelligence agencies including the CIA.

According to a source familiar with the situation, Trump is considering Republican Representatives Michael McCaul and Devin Nunes for the job. McCaul is a former chairman of the House of Representatives Homeland Security Committee and Nunes is a former chairman of the House Intelligence Committee.

Trump told reporters at the White House he has "a list of three people" he will consider for the job this weekend. The Republican president blamed unflattering news coverage for Ratcliffe's decision to bow out and instead remain in the House. Ratcliffe, 53, faced a potentially difficult Senate confirmation process.

The vacancy comes as the U.S. intelligence community grapples with an array of challenges, including the threat of foreign interference in next year's U.S. elections, the impact of a rising China, escalating tensions with Iran, North Korea's nuclear program, and the desire to end years of conflict in Afghanistan, Iraq, and Syria.

Trump announced last Sunday that Coats, who had clashed with him over assessments involving Russia, Iran, and North Korea, will step down on Aug. 15.

Ratcliffe, a Trump loyalist and the most junior member of the House Intelligence Committee, had been tapped, but not formally nominated, to replace Coats.

"Rather than going through months of slander and libel, I explained to John how miserable it would be for him and his family to deal with these people," Trump said on Twitter.

The change in leadership at the top of the U.S. intelligence community comes after a half-year of turmoil atop the Pentagon. The Senate on July 23 confirmed Army Secretary Mark Esper as defense secretary, ending the longest period that the Pentagon had been without a permanent top official, a stint that began after James Mattis resigned in December over policy differences with Trump.

Trump's previous pick for defense secretary, Patrick Shanahan, withdrew in June after reports of domestic violence in his family.

The post of director of national intelligence was created after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks on the United States.

Ratcliffe, confirming he had withdrawn from consideration, said he thought the confirmation process would become a partisan battle between Republicans and Democrats.

"I do not wish for a national security and intelligence debate surrounding my confirmation, however untrue, to become a purely political and partisan issue," Ratcliffe said.

Ratcliffe gained attention by defending Trump and criticizing former Special Counsel Robert Mueller during a July hearing on Mueller's investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election.

Although Ratcliffe had touted his counter-terrorism experience as a federal prosecutor in Texas, media outlets including Reuters reported on concerns that he may have exaggerated his achievements in the post.

Democratic lawmakers and some former senior U.S. intelligence officers had said Ratcliffe lacked the expertise and experience to replace Coats. Some voiced concern that he would warp U.S. intelligence to support Trump's views. Ratcliffe served for six months on the intelligence panel.

Trump said he might name the No. 2 intelligence official, Sue Gordon, as acting director of national intelligence. That is required when there is a vacancy in the top job. Such a move would likely be reassuring to many U.S. intelligence experts because of her deep experience.

However, some Trump allies, according to the source familiar with the matter, were floating the possibility of instead naming CIA Director Gina Haspel as acting director until a permanent director is confirmed by the Senate.

Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman Richard Burr said while he was "heartened" that the office of the director of national intelligence has an experienced team in place during the transition, "there is no substitute for having a Senate-confirmed director in place" leading it.

Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer, a critic of Ratcliffe for the job, said in a statement, "The next Director of National Intelligence must be someone who is nonpartisan, sees the world objectively, and speaks truth to power."

U.S. President Donald Trump talks to reporters as he departs for travel to Bedminster, New Jersey from the South Lawn of the White House in Washington, U.S., August 2, 2019. REUTERS/Leah Millis

Ratcliffe joined a growing list of Trump's choices for senior jobs who have had to withdraw, leading to questions about the rigorousness of White House background checks.

Asked whether Ratcliffe's history was inadequately reviewed before he was picked, Trump defended the White House process. While Trump regularly attacks the media, he told reporters, "You're part of the vetting process.... We save a lot of money that way."

Title: Major US Retailers Implement New Gun Sales Restrictions Following Florida School Shooting

Article:

In the aftermath of the tragic shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida, where 17 lives were lost, two major U.S. retailers, Dick's Sporting Goods and Walmart, have announced new restrictions on gun sales.

Dick's Sporting Goods, with over 600 stores nationwide, has decided to discontinue the sale of assault-style rifles and high-capacity magazines, and will no longer sell firearms to anyone under the age of 21. The company had previously stopped selling such weapons at its main shops after the 2012 Sandy Hook shooting but 35 shops run by a subsidiary called Field & Stream had continued to do so.

Walmart, the largest seller of guns in the U.S., has also made changes, raising the minimum age for anyone buying guns or ammunition to 21 years and removing items from its website that resemble assault-style rifles. The retailer stopped selling high-powered rifles in its shops in 2015, citing low demand.

In a statement, Walmart said, "We take seriously our obligation to be a responsible seller of firearms."

President Donald Trump has urged a bipartisan group of lawmakers to come up with a comprehensive solution to the gun control issue, following a meeting on the matter. Republican leaders in Congress have rejected raising the minimum legal age to buy rifles from 18 to 21, but Trump said he "would give pretty serious thought to it."

Meanwhile, a teacher in the state of Georgia was arrested after barricading himself in a classroom and firing a handgun. No one was injured.

In announcing its policy change, Dick's Sporting Goods said, "We have heard you. The nation has heard you." The company expressed its support for the Second Amendment, but also acknowledged that "gun violence is an epidemic that's taking the lives of too many people."

Dick's CEO Edward Stack told CNN he expected a backlash from some customers, saying "the hunt business is an important part of the business, no doubt about it." The Parkland shooting suspect, 19-year-old Nikolas Cruz, bought a gun at Dick's, but not the weapon he is alleged to have used in the attack, according to Mr. Stack.

At Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, students returned to classes on Wednesday, greeted by a line of police officers, school staff, and community members bearing flowers. Many reporters were also present, shouting questions to the teenagers about their feelings.

Lyliah Skinner, a 16-year-old student, told the BBC before leaving home, "We're not going to really be learning much today - it's all about healing." She also expressed her nervousness, "because I'm scared it's going to happen again." Lyliah listed people she knew who would not be returning, including Joaquin Oliver, who sat just in front of her in a class they shared.

David Hogg, a senior student and now leading activist, also felt trepidation. "It was really hard to think about" what occurred two weeks ago, he said. "Imagine getting in a plane crash and having to get back on the same plane again and again and being expected to learn and act like nothing's wrong," he told NBC News.

The handling of the shooting by authorities has sparked criticism after it emerged that the FBI and local police had failed to follow up on multiple tips about the shooter, and that an armed deputy at the school had stayed outside the school building while the attack took place.

The school's Building 12, the site of the shootings, will remain closed and cordoned off indefinitely. Members of Florida's State House and Senate will soon begin reviewing proposed bills related to firearms, which need their approval and also that of Governor Rick Scott. Among other restrictions, they would raise the legal age to buy rifles from 18 to 21 and give police more control to seize weapons from mentally ill people. A controversial $67m voluntary program to arm school staff, including teachers, would ensure they were trained by law enforcement and allowed to carry concealed weapons on campus, according to the New York Times.

Title: Power Cuts Plague Middle Eastern Countries, Affecting Daily Life and Infrastructure

Article:

Cairo, Egypt - A power cut during a hysterectomy operation last month in an Egyptian hospital left doctors scrambling for alternatives, using cellphones to continue the procedure. The incident is a stark reminder of the regular power cuts that plague hospitals, shops, and homes across the Middle East, where conflict and severe economic strife have left millions in the dark.

Dr. Nader Mohsen Al-labede, the surgeon who performed the operation, described the patient as thinking her life was ending when the operating room went dark. The patient was awake but numbed under spinal anesthesia. The doctors managed to calm her down, and the operation continued for the next hour and a half with the help of a handful of cellphones.

Egypt has been grappling with power cuts for years, with blackouts sending pangs of frustration surging through the country. The outages worsened this summer, stemming from a range of factors, including a shortage of gas, poor maintenance of power plants, and the state's failure to pay debts to foreign oil companies. Egypt's leadership has blamed militants for attacking electricity pylons, contributing to the difficulties.

On Thursday, a massive power outage stopped parts of Cairo's subway, took TV stations off the air, and ground much of the country to a halt for several hours. Egyptian President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi addressed the nation on Saturday, acknowledging the challenges and asking for patience. He said the outage was largely due to crumbling infrastructure that needs billions of dollars and time to fix.

In neighboring Libya, power outages have been a constant issue, with challenges resounding in the capital Tripoli. Rival militias have fought for control of the city's international airport since mid-July, affecting many aspects of life, including power supply. In the eastern Libyan city of Benghazi, power cuts have been common during the summers since the 2011 revolution against dictator Moammar Gadhafi.

The Gaza Strip has also struggled with power cuts, with power sources meeting no more than 70% of the population's needs. The Gaza Strip's only power plant was hit by Israeli shelling, which also damaged transformers and electrical wires, hindering flows of power coming from Israel.

In Iraq, power cuts have been a long-standing issue, with many people relying on generators, but the poor cannot afford them. In Lebanon, power cuts are so routine that apps for Apple and Android devices were created to let users track them. An ongoing strike by electrical company workers threatens to make matters worse as limited state funds and increased demand from an influx of more than 1 million Syrian refugees have led to a rise in power rationing across the country.

In war-torn Syria, power cuts have hit Damascus, while some parts of Aleppo had no power at all at the end of June. Other districts had less than one hour a day, according to the United Nations. The problem contributes to worsening health conditions.

Power cuts have become a part of daily life in the Middle East, affecting everything from healthcare to communication. Governments and international organizations are working to address the issue, but it will take time and significant investment to fix the crumbling infrastructure and reduce power outages.

Title: New Zealand Implements Immediate Ban on Assault Rifles Following Deadly Mosque Shootings

Article:

In the aftermath of the Christchurch mosque shootings, New Zealand's Prime Minister, Jacinda Ardern, announced a ban on all assault rifles, high-capacity magazines, and military-style semi-automatic rifles. The ban, which went into effect immediately, will be followed by legislation next month.

In a live television announcement, Ardern urged citizens to make arrangements to turn in weapons banned under the new laws. She emphasized that the ban is a response to the nation's deadliest massacre in history, stating, "The guns used in this attack had the power to shoot continuously. The times for the easy availability of these weapons must end."

Ardern added, "We just want the guns back... It's about all of us. It's in the national interest, and it's about safety." She noted that gun ownership is "a privilege and not a right" in New Zealand.

The Prime Minister stated that an amnesty will be put in place for weapons to be handed in by citizens. The New Zealand cabinet will also implement a buyback plan for banned weapons, with "tightly regulated" exemptions for some owners such as hunters and farmers.

In the days following the attacks, the New Zealand government immediately began asking all owners of assault weapons or now-banned attachments to report them to the government in the next two days before turning them in.

Since the attacks, Ardern has led a nation trying to grieve and work through the news of the killings, which, in total, rival the annual number of murders in New Zealand. On Tuesday, Ardern had told New Zealand's Parliament that tough gun laws were coming. She also said she would deny the man responsible for the nation's worst terror attack in modern history the one thing he likely craved: fame.

"He is a terrorist, he is a criminal, he is an extremist, but he will, when I speak, be nameless, and to others I implore you: Speak the names of those who were lost rather than the name of the man who took them," Ardern said.

New Zealand has fewer restrictions on rifles or shotguns than many countries. Handguns are more tightly controlled. About 1.5 million firearms are owned – legally and illegally – by civilians in New Zealand, according to police data tracked by GunPolicy.org, a website run in conjunction with the University of Sydney. This equates to about 30 firearms per 100 people. In the United States, the rate is approximately 120 firearms per 100 people, according to the site.

All gun owners in New Zealand must have a license, which they can get from age 16 (age 18 for semi-automatic weapons), but the weapon itself does not need to be registered with authorities, according to the Council of Licensed Firearms Owners, a New Zealand lobby group. Ardern said the suspect in Friday's attacks had a license and owned five guns. The majority of firearm owners in New Zealand are farmers or hunters.

According to GunPolicy.org, New Zealand is among a handful of countries where police officers are routinely unarmed when they are on patrol. Officers in Britain, Ireland, Norway, and Iceland also carry firearms only in special circumstances.

The death toll in the attack at the Al Noor and Linwood mosques rose to 50 people Saturday; victims range in age from 2 to over 60. Services for the victims were held at churches across the country Sunday, and people laid flowers at memorial sites. A group of bikers performed the haka – a traditional ceremonial dance of New Zealand's Maori people – at the memorial in Christchurch.

Thirty-nine people remain in the hospital, and 11 were in intensive care in critical condition.

Title: Call for Proscription of Order of Nine Angles as Terrorist Organisation

Article:

A prominent anti-racism campaign group, Hope Not Hate, has called for the British government to outlaw the neo-Nazi Satanist group, the Order of Nine Angles (ONA), as a terrorist organisation. The call comes in the wake of the group's annual State of Hate report.
