The Home Office stated that the list of proscribed terrorist groups is kept "under review." Last week, two British extreme right-wing organisations were added to the list. One of these, Sonnenkrieg Division, was influenced by the ONA's Nazi-Satanist ideology.

In the past year, four teenagers linked to the ideology have been jailed in the UK for terror offences. One of them was convicted of preparing for a terror attack, which included attempts to alter himself in line with instructions set out in ONA texts.

In court, prosecutors described the organisation as "self-consciously, explicitly malevolent" and the "most prominent and recognisable link between Satanism and the extreme right."

Hope Not Hate's report suggests that the occult organisation, thought to have been founded in the 1970s, has become increasingly prominent online. The report notes that the ONA's terminology and trappings have been adopted into the lexicon of the wider terroristic far-right.

The anti-racist campaign group argues that the group's "sick ideas have drawn in young extremists in the UK and elsewhere, and have helped nourish a dangerous culture of unprecedented depravity amongst the extreme right, which has none of the moral constraints that previous generations of far-right activists had."

Yvette Cooper MP, chair of the home affairs select committee, urged the home secretary to immediately refer the ONA to the government's proscription review group. "The combination of Nazi-Satanism, extreme violence, and sexual abuse makes it particularly troubling," she said. "Action needs to be taken to prevent them grooming and radicalising other people."

A Home Office spokesperson stated that action is being taken to "root out and dismantle the groups that promote extreme right-wing views and we are giving police the tools and resources they need to tackle this threat." The spokesperson added, "We keep the list of proscribed organisations under review."

Counter-terrorism police have previously spoken about the increasing amount of work relating to "niche ideologies" such as violent Satanism.

Title: Biden's Shift in Political Landscape: A Look at the Democratic Party's Shift and Biden's Career

Article:

In a significant political shift, former Vice President Joe Biden addressed union workers at the Teamsters Local 249 hall in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, on April 29, 2019. This event underscores the evolution of the Democratic Party, with Biden, at that time the most recent candidate to file for the Democratic presidential nomination, being labeled as a moderate.

This labeling of Biden as a moderate highlights two key aspects: the rapid leftward shift of the Democratic Party and the progressive slant of the national media. A Democratic politician, in today's context, is considered a moderate if they advocate for the preservation of private health insurance, restrict third-trimester abortions, and maintain a key role for deportation in immigration policy. These positions were once compatible with liberal Democrats' creed, as held by Biden during his tenure as vice president, less than three years ago.

In the progressive media, Biden is facing criticism not just for his policies, but also for his relative silence on President Donald Trump. Critics argue that his indictment of Trump has not been expanded into a broader indictment of America for electing him.

As the primary elections approach, there is a possibility that Biden may shift his positions further left to appeal to the progressive base. He has already denounced the legal system as a "white man's law," a statement that has raised questions about his views on the presumption of innocence. Clarity on this matter is sought from Biden.

It is crucial to note that Biden, throughout his career, has been a strong, albeit not wholly consistent, supporter of left-wing causes, including higher taxes, hate-crimes laws, and liberal judicial activism. Conservatives should not be deceived into perceiving him as a moderate, and neither should actual moderates. This shift in the political landscape underscores the importance of understanding the evolving dynamics within the Democratic Party and the role of social media in shaping public perception.

Title: Parents of ISIS Victims Call for Trump Administration's Assistance in Repatriating U.S. Hostages and Detainees

Article:

In the aftermath of the death of ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the parents of victims of the terrorist organization have called on President Trump to collaborate with them in bringing more U.S. hostages and detainees home from around the world.

During a recent interview on Fox & Friends, the parents of some of Baghdadi's victims expressed their gratitude for the president's actions but emphasized the need for further assistance. Dianne Foley, mother of American journalist James Foley, who was beheaded by ISIS in 2014, commended the administration for prioritizing the return of American hostages.

"It's the beginning of a bit of justice," she said. "For too many years, innocent Americans who are kidnapped or taken hostage around the world have been a very low priority. And so, I commend this administration for doing that."

However, Dianne Foley also highlighted the ongoing issue of hundreds of innocent Americans still detained or taken hostage worldwide. "So, I would ask that our intelligence and our amazing people help us to find Americans before tragic things happen -- that happened to our kids," she told host Steve Doocy.

Carl and Marsha Mueller, the parents of Kayla Mueller, who was kidnapped in 2013 while serving as an aid worker, have conducted their own private investigation outside of the government. Mueller was reportedly forced to have sex with Baghdadi before she was crushed by debris in an airstrike. Despite their efforts, the Muellers have yet to find their daughter's body.

"We have been doing this now since we learned about this [Kayla's kidnapping] on August 5, 2013, and we had been fighting to bring her home all along," Marsha said. "We need the U.S. government. So, we are asking President Trump to please work with the people that we are working with now to try to bring these people home."

The parents' plea comes as the Trump administration has prioritized the return of American hostages during his presidency. While announcing the death of ISIS leader al-Baghdadi last weekend, Trump named some of the innocent Americans who were killed at the hands of ISIS, including James Foley and Kayla Mueller.

Title: Pennsylvania Congressman's Personal Actions Contradict Anti-Abortion Stance

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, a Pennsylvania congressman, Rep. Tim Murphy, has found himself in the center of a controversy that contradicts his long-standing anti-abortion stance. According to a report published by the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette on Tuesday, Murphy, a vocal pro-life advocate, asked his girlfriend to terminate a pregnancy this year.

The report states that Shannon Edwards, a Pittsburgh woman half Murphy's age with whom he recently admitted to having an extramarital affair, texted Murphy in January about a possible pregnancy that turned out to be a false alarm. Edwards, in a text message, accused Murphy of hypocrisy, referring to a post from Murphy's professional Facebook account that criticized America for allowing abortions past 20 weeks of gestation.

"You have zero issue posting your pro-life stance all over the place when you had no issue asking me to abort our unborn child just last week when we thought that was one of the options," she said, referring to Murphy's pro-life messages.

In response, Murphy admitted to not writing the messages himself, stating, "I've never written them. Staff does them. I read them and winced. I told staff don't write any more. I will."

This revelation raises questions about Murphy's sincerity in his pro-life stance. As a congressman, Murphy has advocated for the U.S. government to define life as beginning at conception, a position that would outlaw some forms of birth control and force every woman to birth any conceived fetus against her will. The man who implied that his girlfriend abort a fetus he (hypothetically) helped conceive is trying to keep every other woman from accessing the same right.

Moreover, Murphy is a current sponsor of the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, a bill that would ban abortion care provided after 20 weeks' gestation, defying the protections enshrined by Roe v. Wade. The House is set to vote on the bill on Tuesday.

Murphy is not the first anti-abortion legislator to exhibit a different set of ethics in his personal life compared to the lives of the millions of U.S. women whose lives his votes affect. Anti-abortion Rep. Scott DesJarlais of Tennessee, who is still in office, supported his wife's two abortions and was recorded telling a 24-year-old woman with whom he was having an affair that she had to have an abortion "to get this solved and get it over with so we can get on with our lives." DesJarlais, unsurprisingly, is also a sponsor of the 20-week abortion ban.

This revelation serves as a stark reminder of the importance of personal integrity and the need for politicians to uphold the values they advocate for in their public lives.

Title: Ted Cruz Apologizes to New Yorkers in South Carolina Campaign Speech

Article:

TIGERVILLE, S.C. – In a surprising turn of events during his stump speech in South Carolina, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas took aim at New York values, a remark that had previously sparked controversy among New York residents and officials.

During a nearly full auditorium at North Greenville University, Cruz, seemingly eager to address the issue, asked, "Now I’m curious, do the people of South Carolina know what New York values are?"

In an attempt to quell the backlash from his earlier comments, Cruz issued apologies in various forums, including remarks to reporters, on Sean Hannity’s radio show, in a news release, and on Twitter.

By the end of the day, Cruz had introduced the topic to voters, stating, "So today, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton and Gov. Andrew Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York City all demanded I apologize."

He continued, "I apologize to the millions of New Yorkers who’ve been abandoned for years by liberal politicians."

Cruz also addressed specific political issues in New York, such as the ban on fracking, pro-life and pro-marriage advocates, and the exodus of small businesses due to high taxes and regulations.

In conclusion, Cruz said, "I hope that was the apology they were looking for."

Jim Clinton, a 55-year-old resident of Greer, S.C., commented, "He basically apologized to the rest of New York."

Title: Trump Announces $12 Billion Aid Package for Farmers Amidst Ongoing Trade Tensions

Article:

In a series of tweets on Tuesday, President Donald Trump reiterated his support for tariffs, stating that they are "the greatest" and that the United States will either negotiate fair trade deals or impose tariffs. The President's tweets come as the agricultural industry, which has been significantly impacted by the administration's trade policies, is set to receive $12 billion in emergency aid to cope with the fallout.

According to reports by Politico and The Washington Post, the aid package is expected to be announced this week and will provide direct financial assistance to farmers, a purchase and distribution program for surplus agricultural products, and a trade promotion program. The aid package is reportedly being funded through a Depression-era program that allows the government to borrow up to $30 billion from the Treasury without congressional approval.

The agricultural industry has been one of the hardest hit sectors under President Trump's protectionist trade agenda. Foreign countries, including China, Mexico, and Canada, have retaliated with tens of billions of dollars in retaliatory tariffs on American soybeans, dairy, pork, apples, potatoes, and other US products. The impact of these tariffs has led to a drop in prices for agricultural products like soybeans to a 10-year low.

Rep. Mike Conaway (R-TX), who chairs the House Agricultural Committee, expressed confidence last week that the administration would act to help farmers "persevere" through this period. Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue has also been working on tools to mitigate the impact of the tariffs.

However, President Trump has shown no signs of backing down from his tariff agenda. He has already threatened to tax foreign car imports ahead of trade talks with the European Union this week and has been tweeting a positive outlook on the tariffs' impact on the American economy.

While many farmers are Republicans and Trump supporters, some are growing increasingly nervous about the long-term impact of the trade war. Roger Mehre, a Wisconsin dairy farmer, told a news outlet earlier in July that farmers in his circles are getting increasingly nervous about the trade war. "We need them, and they need us. Both sides are going to lose," Mehre said.

The aid package is a step towards mitigating the financial disaster faced by farmers, but it remains to be seen whether it will be enough to alleviate the industry's concerns. Republican lawmakers from agriculture-heavy states, such as Sens. Ben Sasse (R-NE) and Chuck Grassley (R-IA), have warned the administration about the potential political fallout of the trade war.

"This is dumb," Sasse said in a statement in May. "Europe, Canada, and Mexico are not China, and you don't treat allies the same way you treat opponents. We've been down this road before—blanket protectionism is a big part of why America had a Great Depression."

The aid package is expected to be formally announced this week.

Title: Russian Pilot Rescued After Downing of Warplane by Turkey; Tensions Remain High

Article:

In a developing story, one of the two crew members of the Russian warplane shot down by Turkey on Tuesday has been rescued, according to Russian officials. The rescue operation, which took place over a 12-hour period ending in the early hours of Wednesday, was carried out by a Syrian commando unit.

The incident has escalated international tensions, with the shooting down of the Russian Su-24 fighter jet by Turkish F-16s occurring after Turkey claimed the Russian plane was in Turkish airspace. Turkey maintains that it issued 10 warnings to the Russian warplane before taking action, while Russia asserts that the jet was flying over Syria at the time.

Initial reports indicated that both crew members had ejected from the jet and parachuted to the ground, but one was found dead Tuesday by a Syrian rebel group. The surviving crew member was rescued in the operation, although one of the helicopters involved in the search was reportedly shot down by rebel fighters and destroyed on the ground.

Russia's defense minister stated that one of the helicopter crewmen was killed, but the rest were evacuated safely. The incident has resulted in a series of angry exchanges between the two countries, with both sides calling for military restraint while continuing to trade harsh rhetoric.

Turkish Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu stated Wednesday that Russia could not justify its attacks on ethnic Turks in Syria under the pretext of fighting the Islamic State, and reiterated President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's stance that Turkey will continue to defend its airspace. However, Davutoglu also stated that targeting Russia is "out of the question."

Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov described the shooting of the plane as a "planned provocation" that is prompting Moscow to "reconsider relations with Ankara." On Tuesday, Russian President Vladimir Putin called the shooting a "stab in the back."

Russia has deployed an advanced anti-aircraft system to its base in Syria, with the missiles appearing to be aimed at Turkish planes or planes from other coalition members, such as the U.S. or France. Moscow may also be considering nonmilitary forms of retaliation against Turkey, with Russian Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev stating Wednesday that "important joint projects could be canceled and Turkish firms could lose Russian market share."

The two countries' economies are closely linked by energy purchases, tourism, and other business activity. The incident has raised concerns about the potential for further escalation and the impact on regional stability.

Title: Bipartisan Senate Group Nears Deal to End Government Shutdown and Raise Debt Ceiling

Article:

In a significant development, a bipartisan group of senators, led by Joe Manchin (D-West Virginia) and Susan Collins (R-Maine), is reportedly 70% to 80% close to a deal that could end the ongoing government shutdown and raise the debt ceiling. The deal, which is still under negotiation, would also address the looming deadline for the debt limit and provide a framework for a long-term budget agreement.

The senators have been working on a plan that includes a longer extension of the debt limit and government funding, a two-year delay on the 2.3% tax on medical devices, and greater flexibility for federal agencies to deal with sequestration. The plan also includes verification measures to prevent fraud in the health care insurance system.

Sen. Manchin, in an interview with CNN's Chris Cuomo on Monday, expressed optimism about the progress being made. "We're making progress. We're going to continue to meet throughout the day. And the conversations have been very constructive," he said. Sen. Collins, who has been actively involved in the negotiations, told reporters on Monday that "we're not going to release any details until we have an agreement. I hope we will have an agreement. We're making progress toward an agreement, but we're not there yet."

However, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nevada) rejected the plan on Saturday, stating that it "is not going to go anyplace at this stage." Reid, who has been a key player in the negotiations, expressed support for the plan's objectives but criticized the lack of agreement with the Democrats on other issues.

The Senate voted on a separate procedural measure to extend the debt limit with no strings attached on Saturday, but the measure fell short of the 60 votes needed to proceed. The partial shutdown of government services has been in effect since October 1.

A key sticking point in the negotiations is the issue of sequestration, with Democrats and the White House resisting any agreement that would allow for another round of spending cuts as scheduled in mid-January. Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Kentucky) is pushing back against this demand, citing the need to address the spending limits.

Republican Sen. Bob Corker (Tennessee), who has been working closely with Manchin and Collins, expressed optimism about the prospects of a deal being reached on Monday. "I know Mitch and Harry are talking, and I think we're about to get to a place to move something hopefully off the Senate floor that's widely bipartisan," he told CNN.

The Senate reconvenes at 2 p.m. ET on Monday, with the House meeting at noon. The Treasury Department has warned that the government will be unable to pay its bills unless the debt limit is increased by Thursday. The negotiations are a critical step in resolving the ongoing political impasse and restoring normal government operations.

Title: FBI Interview of Hillary Clinton Concludes, Trump Calls for Criminal Charges

Article:

In a significant development, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) concluded its interview with presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton on Saturday, following an investigation into her use of a private email server for official correspondence. The interview, which took place at FBI headquarters in Washington, D.C., marked the final steps in the case.

Clinton's campaign stated that the meeting lasted approximately three-and-a-half hours. In a statement, campaign spokesman Nick Merrill said, "Hillary Clinton is pleased to have had the opportunity to assist the Department of Justice in bringing this review to a conclusion." Clinton, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, would have no further comment about the interview, the campaign added.

Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus commented on the interview, stating, "Hillary Clinton has just taken the unprecedented step of becoming the first major party presidential candidate to be interviewed by the FBI as part of a criminal investigation surrounding her reckless conduct." He further questioned whether this was the kind of leadership the American people want in the White House.

The email issue has been a significant point of contention in the campaign, with Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee, repeatedly stating that the probe undermines Clinton's fitness for office. Trump has called his opponent "Crooked Hillary" and questioned her trustworthiness in the White House.

Clinton has argued that she is more trustworthy than Trump on handling the issues that matter to most Americans: foreign policy, national security, and running the economy. However, the email investigation has lingered throughout her campaign, and Trump has asserted that Clinton will receive leniency from a Democratic administration.

The email scandal intensified earlier this week when Clinton's husband, former President Bill Clinton, initiated an impromptu meeting with Attorney General Loretta Lynch on her airplane in Phoenix. The meeting raised concerns about special treatment, as Lynch, a President Obama appointee, decides whether to bring charges in the case.

Lynch has stated that she will accept whatever recommendations she receives from the agency's career prosecutors and lawyers. Clinton has said using a private server was a mistake but that other secretaries of state had also used a personal email address. The matter was referred for investigation last July by the inspectors general for the State Department and intelligence community following the discovery of emails that they said contained classified information.

Agents have already interviewed top Clinton aides, including her former State Department chief of staff Cheryl Mills and Huma Abedin, a longtime aide who is currently the vice chairwoman of Clinton's campaign. The staffer who set up the server, Bryan Pagliano, was granted limited immunity from prosecution by the Justice Department last fall in exchange for his cooperation. The FBI, as a matter of course, seeks to interview individuals central to an investigation before concluding its work.

The emails were routed through a server located in the basement of Clinton's New York home during her tenure as the nation's top diplomat from 2009 to 2013. Dozens of the emails sent or received by Clinton through her private server were later determined to contain classified material. Clinton has repeatedly said that none of the emails were marked classified at the time they were sent or received. As part of the probe, she has turned over the hard drive from her email server to the FBI.

Title: Satellite Evidence Confirms Destruction of Ancient St. Elijah Monastery in Iraq by Islamic State

Article:

In a grim confirmation, satellite images have revealed that the oldest Christian monastery in Iraq, St. Elijah's, has been destroyed by the extremist group Islamic State (IS). The monastery, which stood for 1,400 years on a hill near Mosul, is believed to have been demolished in late 2014, shortly after IS seized the city.

The images, obtained by the Associated Press, suggest that the ancient site was reduced to rubble, a stark reminder of the group's brutal campaign against religious and cultural heritage in Iraq and neighboring Syria. Father Paul Thabit Habib, a Catholic priest from Mosul, described the destruction as an attempt to "expel us from Iraq, eliminating and finishing our existence in this land."

IS has been notorious for its persecution of Christians, seizing their property, forcing conversions, and imposing a special tax. The group has also demolished numerous monasteries, churches, and pre-Islamic sites, including Nimrud, Hatra, and Nineveh in Iraq, and Palmyra in Syria.

St. Elijah's Monastery, or Deir Mar Elia, is believed to have been constructed by Assyrian monks in the late 6th Century. It was later claimed by a Chaldean Catholic order. In 1743, its monks were given an ultimatum by Persian forces to convert to Islam. Many were massacred, with as many as 150 monks reportedly killed.

The destruction of the monastery would have gone unnoticed had it not been for the satellite images. Due to the security risks in IS-controlled areas, journalists and archaeologists are unable to access these regions. Moreover, IS did not release any footage showing the demolition of this particular ancient site on its propaganda outlets.

Since taking control of the area in 2014, IS has destroyed more than 100 churches and monasteries in Mosul and surrounding Christian villages, such as Bashiqa and Qaraqosh. The militants, who believe that Islam is the only valid religion, have targeted minorities and destroyed their places of worship, forcing those who remain to choose between conversion and execution.

Fr. Thabit described St. Elijah's as a "spiritual place for Christians to visit and to have religious ceremonies." He added that the monastery was a significant part of Iraq's Christian history, attracting visitors from Mosul, both Christians and Muslims.

In the 1970s, the monastery served as a base for the Iraqi Republican Guard. In 2003, one of its walls was damaged by the impact of a T-72 tank turret during the US-led invasion of Iraq. The US Army later used the monastery as a base, but a chaplain recognized its historical significance, leading to the monastery being cleared.

Stephen Wood of Allsource Analysis told AP that the satellite images published on Wednesday suggest the monastery was destroyed between August and September 2014, two to three months after IS captured Mosul and ordered Christians who had not already fled to leave. The images show that the stone walls have been "pulverized," according to Mr. Wood.

A security source in Nineveh province separately confirmed to the BBC on Wednesday that IS militants had blown up the monastery, completely destroying it. The loss of St. Elijah's Monastery is a significant blow to Iraq's rich Christian heritage, underscoring the devastating impact of IS's campaign of destruction and intolerance.

Title: Trump-Media Relationship: A Love-Hate Saga Continues into Fourth Year

Article:

WASHINGTON -- The relationship between President Donald Trump and the mainstream media has been a rollercoaster ride of criticism and counter-criticism since the inception of his presidency. The two entities have been engaged in a verbal sparring match, with the President often labeling the media as the "enemy of the American people," while the media retaliates with their own rebuttals.

At the heart of this ongoing feud is the President's disdain for what he perceives as biased and negative coverage. A Media Research Center study indicates that 89 percent of the Trump coverage by major media networks is negative. Corey Lewandowski, former Trump campaign manager, believes this treatment is intentional, stating, "They want to highlight what they perceive to be failures... This is exactly what they did during the campaign."

However, the media maintains their stance, with White House Correspondents' Association President Jeff Mason asserting, "We are not fake news, we are not failing news organizations, and we are not the enemy of the American people."

The President's first press conference, a testy affair, set the tone for this relationship. He sparred with several journalists, declaring, "The public does not believe you people anymore!"

Despite the ongoing tension, there are those who believe the President has a soft spot for the media, albeit a complex one. Paul Farhi, media reporter for The Washington Post, suggests, "I think Trump makes a very big show of disliking us, disrespecting us, and disparaging us, but I think in fact, secretly, or maybe not so secretly, really likes us."

Trump's approach to the media is multifaceted, using handwritten notes to either praise or criticize them. Regardless of the message, Farhi notes, "Trump is a very sophisticated media animal... He knows how to utilize the media to get his message out."

As the President's fourth year in office approaches, the question remains whether this daily soap opera drama will continue. Jake Sherman with Politico believes the answer is yes, stating, "Donald Trump is 70 years old... He's not going to change... He is who he is, and you're not going to change that at this point in the game."

One potential development in this escalating fight is the President's proposed changes to libel and slander laws to make it easier to sue reporters and media outlets over their stories. This could mark the next level in a battle with no foreseeable end.

Title: Congressional Democrats Criticize Obama Administration Over NSA Surveillance Programs

Article:

In a significant turn of events, the Obama administration faced a backlash from congressional Democrats on Friday following revelations that the National Security Agency (NSA) broke privacy rules and overstepped its authority thousands of times since 2008. The details were reported late Thursday in The Washington Post, based on an audit and other secret documents provided by NSA leaker Edward Snowden.

The report has challenged claims by President Obama just last week that the NSA was not abusing its authority, and complicated his effort to reassure Americans and Congress that with a little more oversight and transparency, the surveillance programs are nothing to be worried about.

House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi called the latest reports "extremely disturbing." Rep. Mike Thompson, D-Calif., a member of the House Intelligence Committee, said, "Reports that the NSA repeatedly overstepped its legal boundaries, broke privacy regulations and attempted to shield required disclosure of violations are outrageous, inappropriate and must be addressed."

Senior lawmakers said they had been unaware of the audit until they read the news on Friday. Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said he planned to hold another hearing in the wake of the report.

"The American people rely on the intelligence community to provide forthright and complete information so that Congress and the courts can properly conduct oversight," Leahy said in a statement. "I remain concerned that we are still not getting straightforward answers from the NSA."

Obama has repeatedly said that Congress was thoroughly briefed on the programs revealed by Snowden in June. The two programs that were described vacuum up vast amounts of metadata -- such as telephone numbers called and called from, the time and duration of calls -- from most Americans' phone records, and scoop up global Internet usage data.

Proposed legislation to dismantle the programs was narrowly defeated last month in the House, and at least 19 other pending bills are aimed at restraining NSA's powers or changing how the agency is regulated, according to a count kept by the ACLU.

A week ago, Obama sought to soothe concerns by promising to consider reforms to NSA surveillance. "It's not enough for me to have confidence in these programs," he said at a White House news conference. "The American people have to have confidence in them as well."

He announced changes such as convening an outside advisory panel to review U.S. surveillance powers, although it is unclear how that would differ from the existing U.S. Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board, mandated by Congress to monitor surveillance and constitutional concerns.

Obama also said the NSA would hire a privacy officer -- though the NSA already has a compliance office. None of those measures would seem likely to stop the kind of inadvertent collection of information that was described in the NSA audit.

Most of the infractions revealed late Thursday involve unauthorized surveillance of Americans or foreign intelligence targets in the United States, both of which are restricted by law and executive order, according to the May 3, 2012 audit, and other top-secret documents.

The May audit counted 2,776 incidents in the preceding 12 months of unauthorized collection, storage, access to or distribution of legally protected communications. Most were reported to be unintended, and many involved failures to take sufficient care or violations of standard operating procedure. They ranged from significant violations of law to typographical errors that resulted in unintended interceptions of U.S. emails and telephone calls.

The most serious incidents included a violation of a court order and unauthorized use of data about more than 3,000 Americans and green-card holders.

Sen. Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, backed up the administration on its claims, releasing a lengthy statement on Friday afternoon claiming that most the compliance problems at the NSA happen when the agency inadvertently collects records on a non-American who enters the U.S., a point when the NSA is supposed to follow different procedures.

"The majority of these 'compliance incidents' are, therefore, unintentional and do not involve any inappropriate surveillance of Americans," she said. "As I have said previously, the committee has never identified an instance in which the NSA has intentionally abused its authority to conduct surveillance for inappropriate purposes."

Late Friday, the White House issued a statement saying, "the majority of the compliance incidents are unintentional. The documents demonstrate that the NSA is monitoring, detecting, addressing and reporting compliance incidents."

It directed questions to the National Security Council, and NSC spokeswoman Caitlin Hayden directed questions to the NSA. NSA spokeswoman Vanee Vines said the number of incidents in the first quarter of 2012 was higher than normal, and that the number has ranged from 372 to 1,162 in the past three years, due to factors such as "implementation of new procedures or guidance with respect to our authorities that prompt a spike that requires 'fine tuning,' changes to the technology or software in the targeted environment for which we had no prior knowledge, unforeseen shortcomings in our systems, new or expanded access, and 'roaming' by foreign targets into the U.S., some of which NSA can not anticipate in advance but each instance of which is reported as an incident."

"When NSA makes a mistake in carrying out its foreign intelligence mission, the agency reports the issue internally and to federal overseers -- and aggressively gets to the bottom of it," Vines said.

Title: Obama Urges Congress to Revive Economic Stimulus Measures Amid Growing Concerns

Article:

NEW YORK ( CNNMoney ) -- In response to economic headwinds from Europe and a series of concerning labor market reports, President Obama has called on Congress to reconsider a set of legislative proposals aimed at stimulating the economy. The initiatives, initially proposed in September, include investments in infrastructure, tax breaks for small businesses, and funding for teachers, firefighters, and other public sector workers.

Congressional Republicans declined to pass the measures last year, and the Obama administration had previously moved on to other debates. However, the current economic climate has sparked concern that the economy may be slowing, and further fiscal stimulus may be necessary to maintain growth rates.

Europe's debt crisis and the resulting economic malaise are adding to worries, as American exports may potentially slow due to the situation. President Obama emphasized the need for action, stating, "Right now, people in this town should be focused on doing everything we can to keep our recovery going and keeping our country strong -- and that requires some action on the part of Congress."

However, the partisan Congress, known more for its gridlock than its legislative abilities, is unlikely to heed Obama's call. Lawmakers will recess in July and already face deadlines on student loan and highway funding bills. Upon their return from recess, they will face the so-called fiscal cliff.

The fiscal cliff includes the expiration of the Bush tax cuts, middle-class protection from the Alternative Minimum Tax, and more than 50 "temporary" tax breaks for individuals and businesses that are set to run out. It also includes nearly $1 trillion in across-the-board spending cuts across many areas of the federal budget. These spending cuts would significantly impact defense and non-defense spending.

A number of stimulus measures, such as the payroll tax cut and extended unemployment benefits, will also be ending. Congress must act before the end of the year to address these issues.

Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke, speaking to members of Congress on Thursday, urged swift action to resolve the issue, stating that going over the cliff would "pose a significant threat to the recovery." He added that uncertainty over the issue's resolution, largely in Congress's hands, could "undermine business and household confidence."

Despite the pleas from Bernanke and Obama, lawmakers are unlikely to move quickly on legislation that would provide further stimulus or certainty to markets. Republicans are generally opposed to additional spending, and election year politics is unlikely to allow for compromise. Every House seat, one-third of the Senate, and the presidency are up for grabs in November.

Obama, acknowledging that his plea for action may fall on deaf ears, suggested that Congress will be held accountable. "If Congress decides despite all that that they are not going to do anything about this simply because it's an election year, then they should explain to the American people why," he said.

Title: "A Year After Parkland: Shift in Gun Policy and the Evolution of the Second Amendment Debate"

Article:

One year after the tragic shooting in Parkland, Florida, the landscape of gun policy in the United States has undergone significant changes. The once-unyielding stance on gun rights, famously encapsulated by Charlton Heston's declaration, "From my cold, dead hands," has softened in the face of a series of mass shootings.

Since the Parkland tragedy, nine states have implemented "red flag" laws, allowing temporary seizure of weapons for a variety of reasons, including domestic battery and social media threats. Last year, authorities carried out at least 1,700 such seizures. This shift has been observed in states with Republican governors as well.

According to Adam Winkler, author of "Gunfight: The Battle Over the Right to Bear Arms in America," the number of Americans living in states leaning towards more gun control has risen to 140 million from about 112 million.

Robert Spitzer, author of "The Politics of Gun Control," notes a change in public perception, stating, "We don't have tens of thousands of people being rousted in the middle of the night by the police [to take their guns]." He adds, "That rhetoric gets dulling and not very effective after a while."

President Trump, who has appointed two gun-rights-friendly Supreme Court justices, will soon test their views in a gun rights case originating from New York City this spring. However, the powerful appeals from Florida shooting survivors have led to what former Representative Gabrielle Giffords, a mass shooting survivor herself, calls a "tectonic shift" in U.S. gun policy.

This shift comes amidst the NRA's struggles with financing and its involvement in the investigation of Russian meddling in U.S. political affairs. The youth movement launched in the wake of the Parkland shooting has played a significant role in this change, challenging the status quo and prompting a reevaluation of the Second Amendment in light of public safety concerns.

Title: Republican Party Shifts Stance on Immigration: A Step Toward Reality or a Political Gamble?

Article:

In a significant shift from its 2012 stance, the Republican Party has issued a new statement of principles on immigration that advocates for a path to legal residence and work permits for undocumented immigrants who were brought to the U.S. as children. This change in policy, while a step forward in addressing the concerns of the Hispanic community, also presents a risky move within the party due to potential backlash from conservative factions.

The new policy, which contrasts with Mitt Romney's 2012 vow to veto the Dream Act, acknowledges the plight of these individuals, stating, "It is time to provide an opportunity for legal residence and citizenship for those who were brought to this country as children through no fault of their own, those who know no other place as home."

The 2012 party platform had been critical of any form of amnesty and had promised steps to enforce self-deportation. However, the new policy, while not offering a special path to citizenship, does allow for these individuals to live legally and without fear if they meet certain requirements, such as paying back taxes, passing background checks, and learning English.

The policy also addresses the issue of eventual citizenship, stating that while a special path to citizenship is rejected, there is no outright denial of eventual citizenship. This stance contrasts with President Barack Obama's desire to create a new avenue for the undocumented to be naturalized.

However, the policy has drawn criticism for its stance on E-Verify, a system that requires the federal government to confirm the employment eligibility of every new hire in America. This system, endorsed in the new statement, has been criticized for its potential to infringe on the rights of native-born Americans and for its susceptibility to errors, leading to delays in hiring and applicant frustration.

The Republican Party's shift in policy represents a significant change, but it also poses a challenge for the party leadership in managing the expectations of conservative factions and maintaining the support of the Hispanic community. The need to appease tea party members is evident in the policy's tough demands, such as securing the borders and implementing E-Verify.

The question remains whether this policy shift will be enough to attract the Hispanic vote and whether it will appease conservative factions within the party. Only time will tell if this halfway measure toward reality will prove to be a successful compromise or a political gamble.

Title: European Union and United States Impose Tough Economic Sanctions on Russia, Escalating Pressure on Putin Amid Ukraine Conflict

Article:

The European Union (EU) has adopted a series of tough new economic sanctions against Russia in response to the ongoing conflict in eastern Ukraine. The measures, coordinated with the United States, include an arms embargo and a ban on the sale of dual-use and sensitive technologies, such as advanced energy technology equipment relevant for deep sea and Arctic drilling.

Under the financial sanctions, Russian state-owned banks will be prohibited from selling bonds or equities with a maturity of over 90 days in European capital markets. Additionally, eight individuals close to Russian President Vladimir Putin and three entities have been added to the list of people and companies subject to EU-wide asset freezes and travel bans.

The new sanctions come as Ukrainian forces reportedly made significant gains near the site where Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crashed on July 17. According to reports, Ukrainian forces are attempting to split the territory held by pro-Russian rebels into two parts between the major cities of Donetsk and Luhansk, and to cut off supply lines from Russia to the rebels.

Igor Girkin, a Russian citizen who is the top defense official in the separatist Donetsk People's Republic, stated on Monday that more than 100 wounded separatist fighters had been evacuated to Russia. Meanwhile, the self-proclaimed Prime Minister of the separatist republic, Alexander Borodai, left the rebel-held territory for Moscow on Monday, sparking speculation that the rebels may be fleeing the city.

The EU measures were decided at a meeting of ambassadors from the bloc's 28 member countries. The new sanctions will take immediate effect and will be codified in legal language and published on Thursday. The names of the individuals and entities to be added to the travel ban and assets freeze list will be known on Wednesday.

The Western nations are demanding that Russia halt the alleged supply of arms to Ukrainian separatists and other actions that destabilize the situation in eastern Ukraine. The EU measures are intended to be under constant review and can be adjusted in light of new developments.

French President Francois Hollande stated that the Western leaders "regretted" that Russia has not effectively pressured the separatists to negotiate nor taken expected concrete measures to assure control of the Russian-Ukrainian border. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov stated that any sanctions imposed by the U.S. and European countries on Russia would not be effective.

The new sanctions are not expected to fully cut off Russian economic sectors from the West, with U.S. officials holding in reserve the option of imposing more severe sanctions if Russia launches a full-on military incursion in Ukraine or takes a similarly provocative step.

Title: Trump Embarks on Seven-State Whirlwind Tour Ahead of Election Day

Article:

In a final push before the 2016 presidential election, Republican nominee Donald Trump is set to visit seven states on Sunday, holding five rallies in a day-long sprint. The tour will commence in Denver, Colorado, where Trump addressed a packed rally on Saturday, following a brief interruption at a rally in Reno, Nevada, earlier in the day.

The itinerary includes a stop in Sioux City, Iowa, at the Sioux City Convention Center at 12:00 p.m. Central Standard Time (CST). Following this, Trump will travel to Minnesota, a state where the race is closer than anticipated, with Trump and Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton tied in a late September poll. Trump will address supporters at the Sun Country Airlines Hangar at 2:00 p.m. CST.

The tour will then take Trump to Michigan, where he will hold a rally at the Freedom Hill Amphitheater in Sterling Heights, north of Detroit, at 6:00 p.m. Eastern Standard Time (EST). Next, Trump will travel to Moon Township, Pennsylvania, near Pittsburgh, where he will hold a rally at the Atlantic Aviation hangar at 8:00 p.m. EST.

The final stop of the day will be in Virginia, where Trump will hold his last rally at the Loudoun Fairgrounds at 9:30 p.m. EST. Trump will then fly to Sarasota late Sunday night, completing his seven-state Sunday and preparing for another busy day on Monday.

Meanwhile, Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton will be addressing two events on Sunday. She will participate in a get-out-the-vote event with LeBron James in Cleveland, Ohio, and another rally in Manchester, New Hampshire, at the Whittemore Center Arena with President Barack Obama at 3:00 p.m.

Joel B. Pollak, Senior Editor-at-Large at ███, has released a new book titled "See No Evil: 19 Hard Truths the Left Can’t Handle." The book is available from Regnery through Amazon. Follow him on Twitter at @joelpollak.

Title: The Future of Obamacare: A Look at the Implications of the Failed "Repeal and Replace" Effort

Article:

WASHINGTON – The Senate's attempt to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, has failed, leaving the future of the healthcare law uncertain. Here's what the collapse of the "repeal and replace" effort could mean for you.

While Republicans have argued that Obamacare is collapsing under its own weight, independent analyses paint a different picture. The focus of the debate primarily revolves around the health insurance marketplaces created by the Affordable Care Act for individuals who do not receive coverage through an employer or government programs like Medicare or Medicaid. Approximately 7% of the country buys coverage on the individual market.

If the law remains unchanged, the marketplaces will remain stable in most parts of the country, according to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office. Moreover, participating insurers are on track to have their best year in the marketplaces since they began in 2014, according to the nonpartisan Kaiser Family Foundation.

However, some major players, such as Anthem, have announced they will no longer offer coverage in many places next year due to uncertainty about federal policy. Yet, Centene, another insurer, is expanding its coverage areas. Centene CEO Michael Neidorff stated Tuesday that the company's marketplace business "continues to be particularly strong."

Despite this, those buying coverage on the exchanges are likely to have fewer options next year. There are more than 24,000 people currently buying insurance on the exchanges who live in counties that might not have a participating insurance provider, according to preliminary insurance filings. Final decisions won't be made until fall.

"The individual insurance market has been stabilizing, but it needs continued support and can be undermined," tweeted Larry Levitt, senior vice president of the Kaiser Family Foundation, on Friday. "Congress could play a big role in shoring them up and improving affordability."

Premiums remain out of reach for some people, particularly those who do not qualify for federal subsidies. Additionally, the cheapest plans come with high deductibles that can make it difficult to access coverage.

The pool of people using the exchanges has been sicker and older than anticipated, leading to higher premiums and fewer insurance companies willing to participate. One reason there aren't more younger, healthier people buying insurance on the exchange is due to one of the ACA's most popular provisions: the requirement that insurers let young adults stay on their parents' plans until age 26. The Obama administration also allowed people to keep their pre-ACA plans longer than originally anticipated, keeping some healthier people from moving to the marketplace. Insurers also complain that the ACA's penalties for not having coverage are too lenient, and that it's too easy for people to enroll only when they anticipate needing care.

Do Republicans share some of the blame for existing problems? In 2014, Congressional Republicans limited the funding in one part of the ACA that helped offset extreme losses by insurers as the marketplaces were being started. Republicans also took the Obama administration to court to block payments to insurance companies for subsidies that reduce deductibles and co-payments for lower-income customers.

The administration has kept insurance companies guessing about whether it will continue to reimburse them for the cost-sharing subsidies. The administration has also eased enforcement of the requirement that most people have insurance. These acts are the main drivers of the premium increases sought by insurers for next year, according to the consulting firm Oliver Wyman. The uncertain future of the cost-sharing subsidies is the main factor Anthem CEO Joseph Swedish cited Wednesday when telling investors the company may pull out of more state exchanges unless Washington takes steps to stabilize the market.

If Democrats and Republicans want to improve the marketplaces, what could they do? Besides ending the dispute over the cost-sharing subsidies, lawmakers could also continue one of the other industry supports, which was only supposed to be temporary. That program essentially subsidizes the cost of the sickest customers, reducing premiums. Experts have proposed many other changes, including expanding premium subsidies, giving insurers incentives to sell plans in counties that would otherwise lack coverage, and making families eligible for premium subsidies if plans offered by an employer aren't affordable. Some of those changes would be easier to pass than others, and Majority Leader Mitch McConnell warned Friday morning that Republicans will not pass a "bailout" for insurance companies.

Most of the gains in insurance coverage since the ACA was passed have come through the law's expansion of Medicaid eligibility, even though 19 states have chosen not to expand the program. However, more states are expected to do so. If the law isn't changed, 80% of the population could live in states that expanded Medicaid by 2026, according to the CBO.

States that haven't expanded may be more likely to if they can get permission from the Trump administration to not follow some Medicaid rules. Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price has told governors he's eager to approve alternative Medicaid models. However, advocates for the poor could challenge any actions they think go beyond what's allowed without changing the law.

Title: Republican Losses in Virginia and New Jersey Elections Signal Potential Trouble for GOP in 2018 Midterms

Article:

WASHINGTON - The Democratic victories in Virginia and New Jersey have indicated a significant loss of ground for the Republican Party in suburban areas, where President Donald Trump's unpopularity could lead to heavy losses in next year's congressional races.

The results from Tuesday, particularly in Virginia, suggest that Trump's strategy of catering to a loyal but limited base has not enabled him to broaden support for his presidency or his party.

Democrats were elated, believing that control of the U.S. House of Representatives, currently controlled by the Republicans, and perhaps even the Senate, might be up for grabs in next year's elections.

Some Republicans shared this view after their party's candidates did poorly among independent, college-educated, women, and minority voters in suburban areas.

"Unless we get our act together, we are going to lose heavily," said Republican Senator John McCain on Wednesday.

Democrats would need to pick up 24 seats next year to retake control of the House. Should that happen, Trump's policy agenda would be effectively dead, and the administration would come under greater scrutiny.

The win by Democrat Phil Murphy in New Jersey's governor's race came as no surprise due to the unpopularity of outgoing Republican Governor Chris Christie. However, Ralph Northam's 9-point victory over Republican Ed Gillespie for governor in swing-state Virginia was larger than expected.

Trump quickly tried to distance himself from Gillespie's poor showing, saying on Twitter that the Republican candidate "worked hard but did not embrace me or what I stand for."

Still, Trump's leadership record appeared to motivate Democrats to vote in record numbers in Virginia, with exit polls showing that many came out simply to express their displeasure with the president.

"Trump is turning off more voters than he's bringing in," said Rodell Mollineau, a Democratic strategist in Washington. "His base is strong, but it isn't growing."

During his first year in office, Trump has consistently played to a base of passionate supporters, many of them older white men who live in rural areas declining in population, and has shown little inclination to reach out to the majority of voters who disapprove of him.

Whit Ayres, a Republican pollster based in Virginia, said the party was on a risky track. "Republicans have traded fast-growing upscale suburban counties for slow-growing or declining rural areas. That is not a formula for long-term success."

There may also be signs of slippage in Trump's political base.

In Virginia, Gillespie campaigned hard on immigration and crime - two hot issues with the president's supporters - but did worse than expected in some rural and suburban areas that Trump easily won last year.

In rural Dickenson County, considered to be the heart of Trump country in Virginia, Gillespie's margin over Northam was almost 7 percentage points less than Trump's margin of victory over Democrat Hillary Clinton last year.

Trump won the city of Virginia Beach in 2016 by 3 points, but Gillespie lost to Northam there by 5, a swing of eight points.

More critically, Gillespie was blown out by Northam in northern Virginia's populous suburbs, where Trump also struggled in the presidential race.

"The suburbs came out in full force," said Matt Mackowiak, a Republican strategist. "They appear to be very motivated to try and deliver a message to Trump."

In growing Loudoun County, outside of Washington, Democrat Barack Obama barely edged out Republican Mitt Romney in the 2012 presidential race. On Tuesday, Northam buried Gillespie there by almost 20 points.

"I'm worried," said Ari Fleischer, a former White House spokesman for Republican President George W. Bush, to Fox News on Wednesday. "Democrats came out in huge numbers yesterday in the races, and if they have that kind of enthusiasm going into 2018, it's going to be very tough sailing for Republicans."

Gillespie, a longtime Washington insider and lobbyist, tried to keep his distance from Trump personally even as he adopted some of his more combative campaign rhetoric.

It was a strategy that failed, and Mackowiak said the result reflected Trump's historically low approval rating. "I don't think the White House was worried about that before, but now I think they have to be."

The five-day Reuters/Ipsos tracking poll has Trump hovering around 35 percent approval nationally, with close to 60 percent of respondents disapproving of his performance in office.

A person familiar with Trump's political operation dismissed the election results on Tuesday as having anything to do with the president, noting that both New Jersey and Virginia were won by Clinton in 2016.

Andrew Surabian, an adviser to the pro-Trump political group Great America Alliance, said Gillespie lost because he was exactly the kind of establishment Republican that Trump voters have rejected.

"Ed Gillespie's campaign went down in flames because he failed to fully embrace the president or his agenda," Surabian said, "and without a coherent message and an authentic messenger, Republican candidates will not be successful moving forward."

Title: Trump's Legal Challenge Against Michigan's Vote-by-Mail Plan: A Closer Look

Article:

The ongoing debate over vote-by-mail in the United States has taken a new turn with President Donald Trump's criticism of Michigan's plan to send absentee ballot applications to all of its 7.7 million registered voters. The legality of this move, however, remains unclear.

On Wednesday, Trump tweeted that Michigan's plan was illegal and without authorization, stating that he would withhold funding to the state if it chose to proceed with this path. The tweet read, "I will ask to hold up funding to Michigan if they want to go down this Voter Fraud path!"

However, it is probably unlikely that the president can withhold federal funding to assist with Michigan's elections this year, as the New York Times noted in its own fact check, which suggests that the funding has likely already been distributed to the states.

The Trump campaign, however, has a solid legal case against the state sending unsolicited vote-by-mail applications to voters. The key issue is the term "unsolicited." The Times notes that a Trump campaign official cited a 2008 Michigan case in which a judge stated that local clerks could not send absentee ballot applications to a limited universe of voters.

The 2018 amendment to Michigan's constitution, known as Proposition 3, allows absentee voting for any reason but does not address the issue raised by the 2008 case. The amendment does not authorize state authorities to send unsolicited applications, nor does it state that state authorities should be able to make voting by mail more available than required.

In the 2008 case, Fleming v. Macomb, the Michigan Court of Appeals held unanimously that while private entities—including political parties—may send unsolicited absentee ballot applications to their members, the state itself cannot. The Times' "fact check" claims that the 2008 case is no longer applicable because it involved sending applications to "a limited universe of voters." However, this was not the basis for the court's decision.

Therefore, President Trump's claim that Michigan's effort "was done illegally and without authorization" appears to be well-rooted in precedent and the text of the Michigan election statute. As for funding, that is another issue. Trump could potentially withhold other, future funding to the state, though this could prove more politically damaging than the risk of voter fraud itself.

Joel B. Pollak, Senior Editor-at-Large at ███ and the host of ███ Sunday on Sirius XM Patriot, has weighed in on the issue. His new book, RED NOVEMBER, is available for pre-order. Follow him on Twitter at @joelpollak.

Title: Critics Slam Obama Administration's Deportation Policy as Ineffective in Reducing Deportations

Article:

Immigrant advocacy groups have criticized the Obama administration's efforts to reduce the deportations of law-abiding undocumented immigrants, claiming that the policy has had minimal impact. The administration's review found that fewer than 2% of the over 400,000 pending deportation cases have been halted, with thousands more cases expected to be closed.

On Monday, a coalition of immigrant advocates condemned the administration's policy, stating that the paltry results so far expose a reluctance among immigration agents to enforce the new policy. Frank Sharry, executive director of America's Voice Education Fund, expressed disappointment, stating, "We were quite hopeful that the new policies would usher in a new era of humane enforcement. A year later, we are sad to declare that the implementation of this policy is failing."

In 2011, the Obama administration announced a shift in focus to the deportation of convicted criminals, national security threats, and visa fraudsters. The administration issued memorandums granting its agents "prosecutorial discretion" to extend leniency to DREAM Act-eligible individuals and those with clean records. Options included deferred deportation, which could last for up to 12 months, and the authorization of people to work in the U.S. legally.

However, critics argue that the administration's immigration policies have drawn criticism from all sides. Republicans claim the administration is trying to circumvent immigration laws to grant amnesty and blocked the Senate's passage of the DREAM Act bill in 2010. On the other hand, immigrant advocates and Latino leaders have criticized Obama for increasing the pace of deportations beyond that of the Bush administration. The Obama administration's tougher enforcement has led to the deportation of a record 1.1 million people in the last three years.

Last week, ICE Director John Morton told NPR's Weekend Edition Saturday that the targeting of serious criminal offenders is driving the deportation numbers. He stated that roughly 216,000 criminals were removed last year. However, immigrant advocates argue that the stepped-up enforcement continues to target people who are supposed to be protected under the new policy.

Critics claim that ICE is not effectively applying its newfound discretion, in part by declining to offer the full range of options called for in the new policy even though people in a majority of cases meet the standards. Crystal Williams, executive director of the American Immigration Lawyers Association, stated on the call that most people are being offered administrative closure without the option to obtain work: "It's putting your file on a shelf. That's it. No other possibilities are being offered, like the settlement of cases, adjustment of status."

As a result, critics predict that the new policy will clear no more than 5% of the cases. The administration has yet to respond to these criticisms.

Title: House Democrats Vow to Investigate Allegations of Trump-Cohen Collusion in Moscow Project

Article:

WASHINGTON – Two House Democratic committee chairmen have vowed to investigate allegations that President Donald Trump personally directed his former attorney Michael Cohen to lie to Congress about a potential real-estate development in Moscow.

Rep. Jerrold Nadler (D-N.Y.), chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, tweeted, "We know that the President has engaged in a long pattern of obstruction. Directing a subordinate to lie to Congress is a federal crime. The @ HouseJudiciary Committee’s job is to get to the bottom of it, and we will do that work."

Rep. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.), who chairs the House Intelligence Committee, also vowed to "do what’s necessary to find out if it’s true." He tweeted, "The allegation that the President of the United States may have suborned perjury before our committee in an effort to curtail the investigation and cover up his business dealings with Russia is among the most serious to date."

The report, published by BuzzFeed News, claims Trump directed Cohen to mislead Congress about when negotiations to launch a condo project in Russia's capital ended, as well as the extent of Trump's involvement in the deal. The project ultimately fell apart.

Trump did not comment directly on the claim, but retweeted a Fox News story that mentioned Cohen has been convicted of perjury and fraud, and is reportedly under investigation over other matters.

"Lying to reduce his jail time!" Trump tweeted. "Watch father-in-law!"

Trump attorney Rudy Giuliani called Cohen "a convicted criminal and a liar," according to a statement. "Any suggestion – from any source – that the President counseled Michael Cohen to lie is categorically false."

BuzzFeed, which cited two unnamed law enforcement officials for its report, further claimed that the office of special counsel Robert Mueller investigating Trump's Russia ties has additional evidence about the alleged deception backed up by "interviews with multiple witnesses from the Trump Organization and internal company emails, text messages, and a cache of other documents."

Cohen previously testified he falsely told Congress that Trump’s attempt to get the Moscow project off the ground concluded in January 2016 when he actually continued to pursue the project through June 2016. Cohen pleaded guilty in November to lying to Congress on this matter.

He is now cooperating with Mueller's probe and agreed to appear before the House Oversight Committee on Feb. 7 before he begins a three-year prison term in March for crimes that include arranging for payments during the 2016 U.S. presidential campaign to silence women who claimed they had extramarital affairs with Trump.

BuzzFeed's story, if true, is significant because Trump consistently denied on the campaign trail having had any financial links to Russia. In fact, since 2016, Trump has publicly repeated more than two dozen times that he has "nothing to do with Russia."

"There was no talking to Russia. There was no phone calls. I didn’t make phone calls to Russia. I didn’t receive phone calls. I didn’t have meetings. I didn’t have texts. I didn’t have anything," he said aboard Air Force One in September.

The White House and the special counsel's office at the Department of Justice did not respond to requests for comment.

Democratic leaders reacted with anger and concern but also caution, pledging to investigate and establish the accuracy of the BuzzFeed report.

At least one lawmaker called for Trump's impeachment if the report's accuracy is proved.

"If the @Buzzfeed story is true, President Trump must resign or be impeached," said Rep. Joaquin Castro (D-Texas), a member of the House Intelligence Committee.

Lanny Davis, Cohen’s legal and communications adviser, issued the following statement after the BuzzFeed report.

"Out of respect for Mr. Mueller’s and the Office of Special Counsel’s investigation, Mr. Cohen declined to respond to the questions asked by the reporters and so do I," Davis told the media outlet.

Giuliani shot down the report Thursday night, saying in a statement, according to a tweet from Washington Post reporter Philip Rucker: "If you believe Cohen, I can get you a great deal on the Brooklyn Bridge."

Title: Global Spread of Novel Coronavirus Continues: Latest Updates from China and Japan

A thermal camera monitor captures the body temperature of a visitor arriving at the ISU Four Continents Figure Skating Championships in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, February 6, 2020. Ten more individuals have been diagnosed with a new virus on one of two quarantined cruise ships, according to health officials in Japan. Simultaneously, China reported 73 additional deaths and announced that the first group of patients will begin taking a new antiviral drug. (AP Photo/Lee Jin-man)

The ongoing viral outbreak, which originated in China, has now affected over 31,400 people worldwide.

As of Friday in Beijing, the following figures have been reported by health authorities:

- China: 636 deaths and 31,161 confirmed cases on the mainland. In addition, Hong Kong has reported 22 cases, including one death. Macao has reported 10 cases. The majority of the deaths have occurred in central Hubei province, where the new type of coronavirus was first detected in December.

The global community continues to monitor the situation closely as the virus spreads, with efforts underway to contain and mitigate its impact.

Title: Speaker Paul Ryan Officially Announces Support for Donald Trump as Republican Presidential Nominee

Article:

In a significant development, Speaker of the House Paul Ryan (R-WI) has announced his intention to vote for the Republican Party's presumptive nominee, Donald Trump, in November's election. The announcement, made in an op-ed published in his Wisconsin hometown's Walworth County Gazette Xtra, marks a shift in Ryan's stance, who had resisted endorsing Trump for months.

Ryan's statement, delivered without the theatrics typically associated with Trump's campaign, emphasized the importance of choosing a vision for America, rather than just two individuals. He wrote, "House Republicans are helping shape that Republican vision by offering a bold policy agenda, by offering a better way ahead."

Ryan's endorsement comes after months of evading questions about Trump from journalists, with the speaker often attempting to steer the conversation towards other topics, such as the opioid crisis. In an interview with the Associated Press, Ryan expressed hope that the constant clarification is now over.

Ryan's criticisms of Trump's policy ideas and tone have been well-documented. He told the AP, "I've felt very motivated to speak out about some of the things he had said, like the Muslim ban." However, he added, "My hope is that I won't have to speak out in the future on a case-by-case basis."

Trump, in response, told The New York Times he was "pleased" with Ryan's endorsement and described their relationship as good. He also acknowledged that Ryan's endorsement was delayed due to the expectation that Trump's situation would go to the convention.

Ryan's op-ed, while acknowledging his concerns and the need for time, primarily focused on a hypothetical Republican president's policy agenda, rather than Trump specifically. This suggests that Trump may not entirely fit the description of the Republican vision that Ryan has been advocating.

In a statement to the AP, Ryan said, "My hope is that I won't have to speak out in the future on a case-by-case basis." This declaration signifies a move towards party unity and a desire for the Republican Party to move forward with a unified front.

Title: Pentagon Policy Chief John Rood Resigns Amid Impeachment Inquiry Fallout

Article:

John Rood, the undersecretary of defense for policy, will step down from his position at the end of this month, the Pentagon announced on Wednesday, confirming earlier reporting. Rood, who joined the administration in 2018, was involved in approving $250 million in security assistance for Ukraine, aid that was temporarily withheld by the White House last summer.

Administration officials told Bloomberg that senior national-security officials had lost confidence in Rood's ability to execute President Donald Trump's agenda. Sources told Foreign Policy that he was asked to resign after Trump lost confidence in him following a string of departures of senior Pentagon policymakers.

In a tweet on Wednesday morning following reports of Rood's resignation, the president wished Rood well and thanked him for his service. Rood's resignation letter, a copy of which was obtained by NBC, reveals that Trump requested his resignation.

Secretary of Defense Mark Esper thanked Rood in a separate statement. Speaking to reporters at the Pentagon on Wednesday, Jonathan Hoffman, a Defense Department spokesman, declined to say whether Rood's resignation came at the direction of the White House but did say that the "president can make a decision to go in a different direction."

While the specific reason for Rood's resignation is still unclear, multiple reports have noted his connection to the security aid to Ukraine that became the focus of impeachment proceedings. In his role at the Pentagon, which involved building partnerships and encouraging defense cooperation with US allies and partners, Rood certified to Congress that Ukraine was eligible to receive $250 million in security assistance. That aid was temporarily withheld at the White House's direction last summer.

In May, before the president decided to withhold the aid, Rood said in a letter to lawmakers that he "certified that the Government of Ukraine has taken substantial actions to make defense institutional reforms for the purposes of decreasing corruption, increasing accountability, and sustaining improvements of combat capability enabled by U.S. assistance." The letter, which was leaked in September, undermined the administration's argument.

Rood expressed concern about withholding aid to Ukraine in an email to Esper following Trump's July 25 call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky that set in motion Trump's impeachment. In the email, recently reviewed by CNN, Rood wrote that "placing a hold on security assistance at this time would jeopardize this unique window of opportunity and undermine our defense priorities with a key partner in the strategic competition with Russia." Ukrainian forces are fighting Russian-backed separatists in the country's eastern region.

Trump was impeached by the House of Representatives on charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress and acquitted by the Senate earlier this month. Since his impeachment, Trump has taken steps to remove some officials from their posts. The specific reason for Rood's resignation remains unclear, and the White House has not yet commented on the matter.

Title: Marco Rubio's Surprising Third-Place Finish in Iowa and His Strong Showing in New Hampshire

Article:

In the aftermath of the Iowa caucuses, the momentum for Florida Senator Marco Rubio was palpable in New Hampshire. On the night following the caucuses, Rubio stood before more than 700 enthusiastic supporters at Exeter's town hall, a crowd that nearly filled the venue to capacity.

Rubio delivered his familiar stump speech, a speech he has been consistently presenting for months. However, on this night, the audience responded with raucous applause to every word. They cheered as he recounted his family's immigrant, working-class roots, emphasizing that his parents, who were a bartender and a maid, would drive him through the affluent Las Vegas suburbs and tell him, "If you want to be financially successful and live in a house like that, you live in the one country in the world where it does not matter that your dad is a bartender and your mother's a maid. You can do that, too."

Rubio is positioning himself as a candidate uniquely qualified to unite Republican voters and reach out to lower-income and minority communities that have historically delivered Democratic votes. "If I'm our nominee, we will win, and the Democrats know this," Rubio told another packed venue in Laconia on Wednesday. "They do not want to run against me. There is a reason why the Democrats, and in particular Hillary Clinton, attack me five times for every time they want to attack someone else. They know that if I'm our nominee, they lose."

Republicans are not particularly fond of comparisons to Barack Obama these days, but there is a resemblance between Obama's and Rubio's candidacies. Both centered their pitch around a powerful personal narrative that taps into the American dream and the appeal of a telegenic first-term lawmaker and his young family.

However, this similarity has also become a point of criticism for other Republicans, who argue that Rubio is too inexperienced. These critiques have been particularly pointed from the three governors Rubio is trying to outmaneuver in the "establishment lane" – John Kasich, Jeb Bush, and Chris Christie.

Bush, in the final push of his New Hampshire campaign, drew a not-so-subtle parallel between Obama and Rubio, his one-time ally. Bush referred to Rubio and Texas Senator Ted Cruz as "two people that are back-benchers, that have never done anything of consequence in their lives. They're gifted beyond belief. They can give a great speech. But I think it's time for us to recognize that maybe what we need is someone who can lead."

Christie has begun referring to Rubio as "the boy in the bubble," mocking both Rubio's youth and his propensity to deliver the same speech at event after event.

Perhaps mindful of Christie's critique, Rubio's campaign made a point to hold several brief press availabilities during Wednesday's town hall swing.

The four-way tussle among Rubio, Kasich, Christie, and Bush is intense because the stakes are high. Republican power-brokers, often referred to as the "establishment," have made it clear they are worried about either a Donald Trump or a Ted Cruz nomination.

All four campaigns are banking on elected officials and high-powered donors to rally around whichever campaign emerges on top in New Hampshire. A repeat strong showing from Rubio would all but anoint him as that establishment bet.

Rubio, aware of the anti-Washington and anti-establishment sentiment this year, is quick to point out the irony. "I can tell you that when it comes to the establishment, which is, people who have been involved in politics for a long time, they did not want me to run for president," he told reporters. "And they did not want me to run for Senate five years ago."

However, in a Trump- and Cruz-dominated primary, party power-brokers are desperate for someone to rally around. If Rubio does well for a second week in a row, he'll likely be that candidate.

Title: A New Approach to Student Loans: Income-Sharing Agreements Offer a Fresh Perspective

Article:

In a shift from traditional student loan models, some colleges and universities are adopting Income-Sharing Agreements (ISAs) as a means to fund education. Unlike conventional loans, ISAs involve investors providing funds to the college, which then offers a partially or fully free education to students. Upon graduation, students pay the college a percentage of their future income for a specified period.

Beth Akers, co-author of the book "Game of Loans," explains, "It's a way for the school to say to students, 'You're only going to pay us if we help you succeed.'"
