Andrew Hoyler, a professional pilot and ISA recipient from Purdue University, is one such student. He will pay Purdue 8% of his income for 104 months. Hoyler shared in a recent interview, "After that 104-month term ends, if I still owe money, it's forgiven, forgotten, I don't owe another penny." He added, "Now, if I find myself in a six-figure job tomorrow, there's a chance that I'll pay back far more than I took out."

The terms for ISAs vary based on the student's major. For a $10,000 ISA, English majors must pay 4.58% of their income for 116 months, while math majors, who are more likely to secure higher-paying jobs, pay just 3.96% for 96 months.

Akers notes, "It conveys information to the student about how lucrative a different major's going to be." She continues, "Some think that's unfair, but really that's just a way (investors) can recapture the money that they've put up."

Hoyler agrees, stating, "ISA recipients learn not only what a career may pay, but how stable it may be, what the future is like."

Akers proposes, "We should invest in students the same way that we invest in startups. Share equity." The key difference is that the college acts as the middleman, selecting the students, while investors do not have a direct relationship with the students.

Purdue ISA recipient Paul Larora shared, "We don't know who the investor is, but I'd love to give him a hug or buy him a beer!"

Akers explains, "The institutions are saying, 'If I'm operating as the middleman, I can make sure that no one's taking advantage of my students.'"

Despite the potential benefits of ISAs, some politicians advocate for government intervention in student loans. In 2010, President Barack Obama signed a student debt relief bill, claiming it would "cut out private middlemen," meaning banks. However, costs to taxpayers increased rather than decreased.

Some politicians continue to blame banks for student loan debt, as evidenced by Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Calif., who, during a hearing, asked JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon, "What are you guys doing to help us with this student loan debt?" Dimon responded, "We stopped doing all student lending," pointing out that "the government took over student lending in 2010."

Rather than forcing banks out of the loan business, Akers argues, we should remove the government from it. Banks are in the business of assessing loan risk, and if private lenders made loans, they'd care about being paid back. They'd tell students which majors might lead to higher-paying careers and warn them that studying certain subjects may make it tough to get out of debt.

The market would make better judgments and prevent students from starting their adult lives under a burden they may never escape. The Brookings Institution found that 28% of students do not even know they have a loan.

Critics of ISAs label them as "predatory" because investors hope for profit. They argue that ISAs make students "indentured servants." However, as Larora points out, "If you don't have a job, you're not paying anything! Where's the servitude in that?"

Akers is the author of "No They Can't! Why Government Fails -- But Individuals Succeed."

Title: Dual Responses: Rand Paul and Marco Rubio Deliver Tea Party and Official GOP Responses to State of the Union Address

Article:

In a unique turn of events, the Republican Party is facing a split response to President Obama's State of the Union address, with two high-profile senators delivering separate speeches: Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul and Florida Sen. Marco Rubio. While Rubio is delivering the GOP's official response, Paul is delivering a response sponsored by the Tea Party Express.

Jenny Beth Martin, co-founder of the national Tea Party Patriots, stated that both Paul and Rubio are elected officials who are fighting for tea party values of fiscal responsibility and constitutionally limited government. However, the Republican Party leadership's choice of Rubio, a son of Cuban immigrants, to deliver the official response has marked him as the establishment's chosen spokesman, potentially acceptable as the 2016 presidential nominee if he decides to run.

Rubio's spokesman, Alex Conant, said having high-profile responses is a good thing for the GOP. "We're glad Sen. Paul is doing his speech tonight. As far as we're concerned, the more Republicans that are responding to the president, the better," Conant said.

Paul, who unofficially launched his 2016 nomination bid with a visit to Israel last month, elected to give what he calls his own "tea party" response to the president. He doesn't explicitly deny that his move is an intentional clash with Rubio. Paul views his speech as an "extra response" rather than a competitive one.

However, Paul doesn't explicitly say his speech isn't intended to draw contrasts with Rubio on a variety of hot issues, from immigration to foreign aid. Paul, in a bid to further bond himself to the anti-spending movement, emphasized that none of the things he ran on as part of the tea party have been fixed, and the debt crisis is still a looming concern.

Rubio's popularity within the Republican Party, his boyish good looks, and his ability to captivate audiences, along with his Republican Hispanic identity, have earned him the title of the new face of the GOP by some in the press and in official GOP circles. However, Paul has rejected this title, stating that no one gets to choose who is the face of the party.

Tea Party Patriots' co-founder Marc Meckler, now president of Citizens for Self-governance, argued that it's hard to legitimately call Rubio 'establishment' when he beat down the establishment to take out Charlie Christ. Rubio's voting record in the Senate and his stands generally comport with tea party values, Meckler added.

However, Meckler also recounted his observations of a growing rift between Rubio and the tea party, with some tea party groups in Florida expressing skepticism and a sense of distance from Rubio due to his perceived inaccessibility. This rift, if true, could potentially impact Rubio's standing within the tea party movement and, by extension, his political aspirations.

Title: Ukraine-Russia Tensions Escalate as Ceasefire Violations Continue and Humanitarian Aid Delivered

Article:

Ukraine and Russia faced a fresh round of conflict on Saturday, as Ukrainian forces repelled pro-Russian rebels at Donetsk airport and Moscow sent a second convoy of aid into the country, highlighting the fragility of the ceasefire agreement between the two nations.

The latest fighting in eastern Ukraine erupted about a week after the ceasefire agreement was reached, with a volley of rockets striking residential buildings near the airport, although no casualties were reported. Ukrainian military leaders successfully fended off the separatist attack at the airport.

Tensions escalated further as Russia sent a second convoy of trucks into Ukraine without its consent, delivering humanitarian aid to the eastern Ukrainian city of Lugansk. The convoy, consisting of about 245 trucks, was reported to be carrying nearly 2,000 tons of supplies, including cereals, sugar, medicines, and warm clothes.

Russian President Vladimir Putin, who annexed most of the Crimean Peninsula from Ukraine in March, has consistently denied that Russian troops have entered eastern Ukraine. However, he defends the Russian-speaking minority's right to defend themselves.

Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk, in a speech at a conference of Ukrainian and European officials in Kiev, asserted that despite the truce, his country remains in a state of war, with Russia being the key aggressor.

The delivery of the second convoy of humanitarian aid from Russia, following the first one in August, marks a shift in the mood in the Kiev government. Ukrainian officials' silence on the second convoy indicates a willingness to accept aid, despite their previous objections. However, Ukrainian officials have expressed concerns about the lack of International Red Cross oversight during the aid deliveries.

In his speech, Yatsenyuk also highlighted the impact of the ongoing conflict on government-proposed reforms, stating that if the war is stopped and Russia is contained, Ukraine will have the opportunity to attract international investors.

The ongoing conflict and ceasefire violations have hindered the implementation of reforms aimed at benefiting the entire country, according to Yatsenyuk. The situation underscores the complex and volatile nature of the relationship between Ukraine and Russia, and the challenges both countries face in finding a lasting solution to the ongoing conflict.

Title: CBS News Reporter Faces Internal Criticism for Aggressive Pursuit of Benghazi Story

Article:

In an unexpected turn of events, CBS News correspondent Sharyl Attkisson, known for her relentless pursuit of the Fast & Furious scandal, is now facing criticism from her own network. The reason? Her aggressive coverage of the Benghazi story.

According to a report by Politico, Attkisson's investigative work on Benghazi has been met with frustration from CBS News executives, who view her as wading dangerously close to advocacy on the issue. Attkisson has reportedly faced difficulties getting her stories aired, leading to feelings of marginalization and underutilization.

This internal conflict is a significant context for the current situation, as Attkisson is reportedly in talks to leave CBS ahead of her contract, as POLITICO reported in April. The report also mentions "internal conflicts," though it seems to dismiss them. However, these conflicts are indeed real, with Attkisson still considering an exit, according to sources.

The situation raises questions about the media's role in investigative journalism and the pursuit of truth, particularly in high-profile, politically charged stories like Benghazi. Some, like Ed Morrissey and Allahpundit, argue that Attkisson's work is being marginalized because it challenges the mainstream narrative and risks lending credence to Republican accusations.

In the midst of today's House Oversight Committee hearing, Attkisson's Twitter feed went silent, leading to speculation about her absence. Some believe this silence is a result of the network's disapproval of her coverage.

The media's handling of the Benghazi story has been a topic of discussion, with some suggesting that the story is being dismissed as a right-wing obsession or a political food fight. The Washington Post and Kasie Hunt, a NBC News correspondent, have tweeted about the hearing, with the former implying that only out-of-touch old white guys and conservative-leaning individuals care about the story, and the latter questioning the relevance of the story in light of Hillary Clinton's potential 2016 presidential bid.

The media's role in shaping public perception and the challenges faced by journalists like Attkisson in pursuing the truth are issues that warrant further discussion. The silence from Attkisson today, and the network's apparent disapproval of her work, are reminders of the challenges faced by journalists in the pursuit of truth and the importance of a free and independent press.

Title: Controversial Gun Registration Renewal Law in Washington D.C. Sparks Legal Challenge and Criticism

Article:

In the nation's capital, a contentious gun control measure is stirring debate and legal action. The District of Columbia Police Department has proposed a new law that requires all legal firearm owners to personally renew their registration certificates at police headquarters. This renewal process, which starts on January 1, 2022, will involve fingerprinting, photographing, providing proof of address, paying a fee, and confirming the individual's eligibility to possess the firearm.

The Metropolitan Police Department filed proposed rules last week, and citizens have until December 15 to comment on the regulations. George Lyon, a plaintiff in the original Heller case, expressed his concerns, stating, "I don't see that they need a re-registration system at all. But if they do, this whole thing ought really to be done online, automated, and without adding more fees."

The renewal process was initially intended to be done online and by mail, starting in 2012, but the police did not retain any of the fingerprints or photos taken until March 2013. City Council Chairman Phil Mendelson defended the renewals, stating, "The reason for renewals is to make sure people don't become disqualified to own a firearm."

However, critics argue that the police could easily run gun owners' names and social security numbers through the FBI's background-check system at any point. Stephen P. Halbrook, the lead attorney for Heller II, described the registration-renewal requirement as "onerous and completely unnecessary and is a trap for the unwary." He added, "Fail to re-register for whatever reason, and you're committing a crime — possession of an unregistered firearm. This is plain harassment for the exercise of a constitutional right."

The registration-renewal requirement is already being challenged in court through Heller v. District of Columbia, commonly known as "Heller II." The case takes on the entire registration law that was enacted in 2009 after the Supreme Court overturned the District's 30-year-old handgun ban in the original Heller decision.

Critics argue that the law is a violation of the Founding Fathers' intent that the Second Amendment would prevent government tyranny. They contend that once the government knows about every single gun owned by each citizen, an armed populace is no longer a deterrent.

Emily Miller, senior editor of opinion for The ███ and author of "Emily Gets Her Gun" (Regnery, 2013), has also expressed her opposition to the law. The estimated 30,000 firearms registered to private citizens in D.C. is remarkably low for a city of 600,000, as most law-abiding people choose not to go through the 11 steps necessary to register. Furthermore, criminals are not showing up at police headquarters to offer up their fingerprints or take a written test before buying guns.

The renewal process is expected to be a complex and time-consuming endeavor, potentially causing delays and inconvenience for law-abiding gun owners. The police propose scheduling everyone in three-month windows based on the individual's birthday, with eight windows starting on January 1 and going through 2015. They plan to set up an online system to make an appointment, but the acceptance of credit cards for the $13-per-gun fee has not been finalized.

The renewal process is a significant change from the original Heller decision, which overturned the District's 30-year-old handgun ban. The renewal requirement has sparked controversy and legal challenges, with both sides filing motions for summary judgment this month and next. The outcome of the case will likely have significant implications for gun rights in Washington D.C. and potentially beyond.

Title: Roy Moore Threatens Legal Action Against Washington Post Over Sexual Misconduct Allegations

The Alabama Republican Senate candidate Roy Moore has announced his intention to sue The Washington Post over a report alleging sexual misconduct with teenagers, including a 14-year-old, when he was in his 30s.

During a campaign speech in Huntsville, Alabama, on Sunday night, Moore stated, "The Washington Post published another attack on my character and reputation because they are desperate to stop my political campaign. These attacks said I was with a minor child and are false and untrue — for which they will be sued."

Historically, public figures have threatened legal action against news organizations but have not followed through. In 2017, President Donald Trump threatened to sue The New York Times after it published accounts of two women who claimed Trump touched them inappropriately. Trump's lawyers never filed a lawsuit. Similarly, disgraced Hollywood mogul Harvey Weinstein initially threatened to sue the Times after it first reported allegations of sexual misconduct against him, but that suit never materialized.

The Washington Post report, published on Thursday, was based on interviews with more than 30 people. In addition to the allegations that Moore had sexual contact with the then 14-year-old when he was aged 32, three other women also told The Post that Moore pursued them when they were between the ages of 16 and 18.

The woman who was 14 years old at the time claimed Moore took her to his house, undressed down to his underwear, and undressed her down to her bra and underwear and touched her and moved her hand to touch his underwear, which could have been sexual offenses due to her age, but the statutes of limitations in effect during that time have passed.

None of the other three women told The Post that Moore sexually harassed, or assaulted them, or forced them into a relationship. Alabama's legal age of consent is 16.

Moore has denied the allegations since they were published. He called the claims "completely false" on Friday when appearing on Sean Hannity's syndicated radio show. Speaking at a Veterans Day event at the Mid-Alabama Republican Club in Birmingham on Saturday, Moore called the allegations "fake news" and "yet another attack on my character and reputation in a desperate attempt to stop my political campaign for the United States Senate."

He added that the alleged incidents happened nearly 40 years ago and called them "very hurtful to me personally — I have the highest regard for the protection of young children." Moore also stated that he has never provided alcohol to a minor and has "not been guilty of sexual misconduct with anyone."

Moore added that there were ongoing "investigations" looking into the motivations behind the Post article, and promised "revelations" about the story to come in the next few days, though he did not provide further specifics.

A number of Republicans have withdrawn their endorsements of Moore following the Washington Post article, including the National Republican Senatorial Committee, which severed a joint fundraising agreement that benefits Moore's campaign. This story has been updated to reflect The Post's decision to not comment.

Title: NBC News Alters Approach to Climate Change Discussion on "Meet the Press"

Article:

In a significant shift, NBC News has announced that it will no longer treat climate change as a two-sided issue, with host Chuck Todd of "Meet the Press" stating during Sunday's episode that the show will no longer provide a platform for climate change deniers. Todd's decision was met with both praise and criticism, as the debate over climate change continues to be a contentious topic.

During the hour-long panel discussion, Todd stated, "We're not going to debate climate change, the existence of it. The earth is getting hotter, and human activity is a major cause. Period." He further added, "We're not going to give time to climate deniers. The science is settled even if political opinion is not."

Skeptics of the most alarmist climate change scenarios argue that the term "denier" is misleading, as it implies parallels to those who deny historical events such as the Holocaust or the September 11, 2001, terror attacks. They contend that while it is accepted that burning fossil fuels releases carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, there is a wide range of scientific opinion on matters such as the extent to which human activities affect gas levels, the likelihood of various consequences, the impact of other factors on the climate, and the quality and extent of past historical data on climate.

Todd's panel on Sunday included non-scientists offering their opinions, such as California Governor Jerry Brown, Representative Carlos Curbelo, and potential Democratic presidential candidate Michael Bloomberg. Curbelo commented, "We need to stop covering the debate and start covering the story so that people see that this is real, and so that politicians take a more pragmatic approach and find solutions that are actually achievable."

Politicians such as Senator Bernie Sanders praised the one-sided discussion, with Sanders taking to Twitter to congratulate Chuck Todd and "Meet the Press" for holding a serious discussion about climate change. Sanders asked, "Will this be a breakthrough moment for mainstream TV?"

The distinction between "weather" and "climate" was emphasized by climatologists, with Todd himself making this distinction in a previous conversation with a conservative skeptic. Scientists are typically reluctant to attribute specific weather events to man-made climate change. The debate over climate change continues to be a topic of discussion and research among scientists and policymakers worldwide.

Title: NRA Executive Vice President Warns of Potential Gun Control Measures as Obama Prepares to Sign Executive Orders

Article:

In an email sent to supporters late Tuesday evening, National Rifle Association (NRA) Executive Vice President Wayne LaPierre expressed concern as President Obama prepares to sign up to 19 executive orders on new gun control measures. LaPierre's message emphasized that these measures are not about protecting children or reducing crime, but rather about restricting gun rights.

LaPierre alleged that last week's White House meeting, billed as an "open discussion" about school safety, was a misrepresentation. He claimed that the administration did not listen to gun owners' concerns or consider practical solutions for school safety. Instead, LaPierre accused the Obama administration, Vice President Joe Biden, and their gun control allies in Congress of attempting to blame, vilify, bully, and restrict gun owners' Second Amendment rights.

The NRA executive vice president warned that the administration is pushing forward with legislation that could ban certain guns, register ammunition purchases, and require gun owners to register their firearms with the government. LaPierre urged NRA members to renew or upgrade their membership as soon as possible, emphasizing the importance of their support in the upcoming fight for gun rights.

LaPierre also addressed the media's portrayal of gun owners, stating that he and other NRA members have been slandered and threatened. He vowed to challenge these attacks and defend the right to self-defense and the Right to Keep and Bear Arms. LaPierre emphasized the strength of the NRA organization comes from its members and their commitment to the membership. He called for support from gun owners today.

Title: Clinton and Trump Address Gun Control and Criminal Justice Reform in Campaign Rally

In a recent campaign event, Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton addressed gun control and criminal justice reform, two key issues that have been central to her primary campaign. Clinton's rival, Republican nominee Donald Trump, also touched upon the former Secretary of State's policies and their potential impact on women's safety.

During a rally on Friday, Mr. Trump criticized Mrs. Clinton's policies, stating that they could put women in particular danger. He suggested that in rough or dangerous communities, women might not be able to defend themselves if stricter gun control measures were implemented.

Mrs. Clinton, on the other hand, reaffirmed her commitment to both gun control and the overhaul of the criminal justice system during a rally on Saturday. She has been vocal about these issues, often campaigning alongside the mothers of individuals who have lost their lives due to police encounters or gun violence.

The Clinton campaign has utilized these stories in evocative television ads, featuring the mothers of Eric Garner, Jordan Davis, Sandra Bland, and others, as well as Erica Smegielski, the daughter of the school principal killed in the Sandy Hook massacre in Connecticut.

However, as the focus shifts from the primary to the general election, gun control seems to have become less of a driving force in Clinton's campaign. A New York Times/CBS News poll in January found that 57 percent of respondents wanted stricter laws governing gun sales, and 88 percent favored background checks for all purchases.

In her Saturday speech, Clinton vowed to end the "school to prison pipeline" that disproportionately affects black men. She emphasized, "Something is wrong when so many Americans have reason to believe that our country doesn't consider their children as precious and worthy of protection as other children because of the color of their skins."

Clinton also restated her promise to "end the era of mass incarceration" and to "rebuild the bonds of trust between law enforcement and communities." These issues could resonate with voters in California, particularly in cities like Los Angeles and Oakland, ahead of the state's June 7 primary.

Both candidates are now vying for the support of white voters in the Rust Belt, and their stances on gun control and criminal justice reform could play a significant role in the upcoming election.

Title: The Rise of a Religious Left: A New Era in American Politics

Article:

In the political landscape of the United States, the emergence of a religious left, spearheaded by candidates like Pete Buttigieg, is gaining traction among progressive voters. This shift, as some see it, is a response to the conservative Christian right's influence in American politics.

For many voters who gathered to celebrate a record 'rainbow wave' of LGBT political candidates, the sight of a same-sex couple running for president as a team was a powerful and unprecedented moment. This is particularly significant for individuals like Buttigieg, who have experienced discrimination based on their sexual orientation.

Buttigieg's candidacy is not just about his policy proposals; it is also about his identity and the experiences that come with it. As a gay man, he represents a segment of the population that has historically been marginalized and understands the struggles of the powerless and the alienated.

The candidate's approach to faith and politics is resonating with a growing number of Americans who believe in a more inclusive Christianity. This Christian left, as some are calling it, is challenging the traditionalist Christian right's stranglehold on religious values in politics.

Progressive religious leaders are coalescing in support of issues such as immigrant rights, universal health care, LGBTQ rights, and racial justice. Buttigieg, along with candidates like Elizabeth Warren and Cory Booker, is a symbol of this rising movement.

Critics argue that the focus on sexuality has resulted in a disproportionate fixation on homosexuality in religious and political discourse. However, proponents of the religious left argue that a fair reading of the Gospels reveals a far greater emphasis on issues such as generosity towards the poor, welcoming to the stranger, and treating people with dignity.

The debate surrounding Buttigieg's faith and its role in his political platform is a complex one. While some see it as a valuable perspective, others view it as a potential distraction from the core issues at hand. As the primary season unfolds, the role of faith in American politics and its impact on the electorate will continue to be a topic of discussion.

In the midst of this debate, the investigation into President Trump's dealings with Ukraine remains a significant issue. While the evidence of a quid pro quo may be circumstantial, the context and circumstances are what will become the focus of the investigation. Whether this evidence is enough to lead to impeachment and removal remains to be seen.

Title: Guam Residents Carry On Amid North Korea Tensions: Business as Usual on the Pacific Island

Article:

GUAM — Despite the escalating tensions between the United States and North Korea, life on the Pacific island appears to be carrying on as usual. On Saturday, the customer rush was on at Guam's Home Depot, with residents stocking up on essentials such as batteries, flashlights, and bottled water. However, the purchases were not as a result of the recent geopolitical developments, but rather for everyday use.

In a statement that contrasts with the international spotlight on Guam, Guam Governor Eddie Calvo received assurances from President Trump and White House Chief of Staff Gen. John Kelly on Saturday morning. Calvo, in a subsequent video message, expressed comfort in knowing that the U.S. administration is watching out for the island.

Amid the concerns on social media, Guam residents remained calm, with some engaging in activities such as fishing, football practice, and visiting beaches and malls. The island's leaders may have been alarmed, but the residents themselves seemed unfazed.

Andrew Guilliot, the loss prevention manager at Home Depot, noted that while there was a slight increase in the purchase of bottled water, batteries, and portable fans, the demand was not extraordinary. He added that the typical items one would see during typhoon preparation, such as water, generators, batteries, tarps, and plastic, were not seeing any significant spikes in sales.

In interviews, some residents expressed concerns about the situation, but most seemed to view it as just another speed bump in their lives. David Lessard, a resident of Ordot, was considering stocking up on canned goods and bottled water, but he viewed the threats as North Korea trying to save face.

Roger Hostetler, a retired Navy civil service worker, was concerned about the unstable leaders of North Korea and the United States, but he had faith in the THAAD anti-missile system and the combined Japan-U.S. military forces. He, however, expressed hope that China and Russia would not get involved on the other side.

For many Guam residents, the explosive threats are just more of the same. Vicente Bautista, a resident of Dededo, recalled similar threats in 1977 when he was an Army infantryman stationed near the Demilitarized Zone. He believes that North Korea wants to show off, but does not have the technology to back up the threats.

Mike Soderquist, a resident of Dededo who lived in South Korea for about four years, viewed the rhetoric as typical North Korea bluster. He was out shopping on Saturday, going about his regular activities.

In a simple statement issued on Friday, the Guam Chamber of Commerce declared, "It is business as usual on Guam." For now, it seems, life on the Pacific island is carrying on as usual, despite the looming threats from North Korea.

Title: Rand Paul's Healthcare Stance: Principle or Political Expediency?

Article:

In the political arena, it is often challenging to discern whether a politician's actions are driven by principles or political expediency. This conundrum is particularly relevant when discussing Senator Rand Paul, a prominent figure in the Republican Party who has been vocal about his opposition to the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare.

Paul, who has been dubbed the GOP's would-be Man for All Seasons, has consistently voted against any compromise that does not call for full repeal of Obamacare. In response to the recent health-care reform debacle, Paul expressed his disappointment, stating, "Look, this is what we ran on for four elections. Republicans ran four times and won every time on repeal Obamacare, and now they're going to vote to keep it. Disappointing."

While many of Paul's arguments and complaints are persuasive on their merits, there have been instances that raise questions about the motivations behind his stance. For example, it is worth noting that more than one in five Kentuckians, Paul's home state, are on Medicaid. This coincidence, coupled with Paul's history of adhering to strict libertarian principles, has led some to question whether his opposition to the bill is driven by principles or political expediency.

Paul's political career was shaped by his father, Ron Paul, a longtime Texas congressman and presidential candidate. Known as "Dr. No" in the House, Ron Paul was notorious for voting against most bills on the grounds that they were not constitutional or libertarian enough. Similarly, Rand Paul has opposed various trade deals and health-care reforms, not on protectionist grounds but in service to his higher libertarian conscience.

However, Paul's actions during the health-care reform process have been inconsistent. Every time the proceedings moved in his direction, he seemed to move one step back. For instance, when Senator Ted Cruz offered an amendment to open up the market for more flexible and affordable plans, Paul expressed opposition, citing concerns about the Obamacare mandates. Yet, a provision for exempting associations from Obamacare mandates was already in the bill.

Paul has also been criticized for his approach to earmarks during his father's political career. Ron Paul was known for cramming pork for his district into must-pass spending bills like an overstuffed burrito, only to vote against them in the name of purity.

In conclusion, while it is difficult to definitively determine whether Rand Paul's actions are driven by principles or political expediency, his inconsistencies during the health-care reform process have raised questions about his motivations. As the health-care debate continues, it will be interesting to see how Paul's stance evolves and whether he will remain a consistent "no" vote on any compromise that does not call for full repeal of Obamacare.

Title: U.S. Defense Secretary Defends Border Wall Funding Diversion Amidst Bipartisan Criticism

Article:

MUNICH, Germany (AP) — U.S. Defense Secretary Mark Esper defended his decision to divert billions of dollars in funding for Navy and Air Force aircraft and other military programs to help pay for President Donald Trump's promised wall on the U.S.-Mexico border during a press conference on the sidelines of an international security conference in Munich on Friday.

Esper faced questions about the diversion of funds, which has drawn criticism from both Democrats and Republicans in Congress, including Rep. Mac Thornberry, a Republican from Texas, who called the move contrary to the constitutional authority of Congress.

"Border security is national security," Esper said. "And national security is our mission."

He added, "The action we took is legal under the law, and so it should be no surprise, and I'll just leave it at that for now."

The Pentagon announced on Thursday that Esper approved shifting $3.8 billion in funds that Congress had previously authorized for F-35 fighter aircraft and other military programs. The money is being diverted to help the Department of Homeland Security build portions of the border wall. The Pentagon indicated that more such actions could be coming to provide additional funding for Trump's signature campaign promise.

The action drew sharp rebukes from Democrats as well as Republicans. Rep. Adam Smith of Washington, the Democratic chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said in a statement, "Today's reprogramming request confirms once again that the President is obsessed with fulfilling a campaign promise at the expense of our national security."

Last year, despite congressional opposition, Trump faced no consequences when making similar transfers by cancelling or postponing dozens of military construction projects to free up $3.6 billion.

In reaction to Thursday's Pentagon announcement, Thornberry, the top Republican on the committee and a supporter of wall construction, said that while the administration's constitutional role is to recommend how tax dollars are spent, final choices are made by Congress.

"Once those choices have been made, the Department of Defense can not change them in pursuit of their own priorities without the approval of Congress," he said. "Attempts to do so undermine the principle of civilian control of the military and are in violation of the separation of powers within the Constitution. The re-programming announced today is contrary to Congress' constitutional authority, and I believe that it requires Congress to take action."

Trump, while campaigning for the Republican presidential nomination in 2016, repeatedly promised that Mexico would pay for the wall, but Mexico refused.

Title: The Enduring Influence of the New Deal on Modern Political Agendas: A Comparative Analysis of the Trump Presidency and the Democratic Party's "Better Deal"

Article:

In the political landscape of the United States, the New Deal, a series of programs, jobs projects, and reforms introduced during the Great Depression, continues to cast a long shadow over the nation's political discourse. This is particularly evident in the current political climate, with the Trump presidency and the Democratic Party's recent unveiling of their "Better Deal" agenda.

The Trump presidency, with its unconventional approach and departure from traditional Republican policies, has been hailed by some as a disruption that shattered the calcified agenda of the GOP. The Democratic Party, on the other hand, has been grappling with a need for disruption of its own, as the New Deal paradigm has largely defined the party for the better part of a century.

The Democrats' search for a policy vision often leads them back to the New Deal. Harry Truman's Fair Deal and LBJ's Great Society were both continuations of the New Deal. After the 9/11 attacks, New York senator Charles Schumer wrote in the Washington Post that the attacks proved that "the era of a shrinking federal government has come to a close." This new challenge necessitated a "new New Deal."

Even the New Deal's biggest competitor, John F. Kennedy nostalgia, has always been about aesthetics and atmospherics. Kennedy's own policy agenda never broke with the New Deal paradigm. Barack Obama, who had a Kennedy-esque cult of personality, was nonetheless expected by liberals to be a new FDR. When Obama rolled out his sweeping policy vision, a "New Foundation," it was a New Deal rehash.

House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi, 78, is a child of the New Deal. Her father, Thomas D'Alesandro Jr., a passionate New Dealer in Congress, named one of his sons Franklin D. Roosevelt D'Alesandro. The New Deal remains Pelosi's North Star, which may be why she accidentally referred to their new program as "the New Deal."

Now, the Democrats have their "Better Deal" agenda, yet another New Deal retread. The Democrats even admit it. Pelosi insisted that the Better Deal is not "a course correction." It is "a presentation correction." Schumer says it was chosen in part for "its relation to both the New Deal and a better deal than Trump."

It's remarkable how Democrats call GOP ideas tired and outdated yet keep returning to a well that was dug four years after the invention of sliced bread. At the rollout of a Better Deal, Pelosi said it is "founded on strong values that we share. Strong values fueled by fresh ideas."

On Fox News Sunday, anchor Chris Wallace asked House Democratic Caucus chairman Joe Crowley to "give me one fresh idea that Democrats are offering voters for November." The FDR coalition is a relic. The coalition the Democrats want is shot through with divisions. The Better Deal gives Democratic pols something to talk about that won't rile one faction or another.

Crowley's confident response: A new infrastructure plan! But one that, unlike Trump's plan, the feds would pick up more of the tab for. Can't you smell the freshness?

Ironically, the New Deal was never a coherent program. It was a mixed and entirely ad hoc, dirigiste response to an economic crisis. "To look upon these programs as the result of a unified plan," wrote Raymond Moley, FDR's right-hand man during much of the New Deal, "was to believe that the accumulation of stuffed snakes, baseball pictures, school flags, old tennis shoes, carpenter's tools, geometry books, and chemistry sets in a boy's bedroom could have been put there by an interior decorator."

There are many reasons the Democrats remain a cargo cult to the New Deal, but the most important one for this moment is that the approach unifies not Democratic voters but Democratic politicians. The FDR coalition is a relic. The coalition the Democrats want is shot through with divisions. The Better Deal gives Democratic pols something to talk about that won't rile one faction or another.

That may be good enough to win the 2018 midterm elections, as all they really need is some boilerplate to rely on as they ride an anti-Trump wave. But the time will come when it won't be enough. The disruption is coming. They can help shape it, or they await a destroyer not of their own choosing.

Title: Congress and President Trump Negotiate Budget Deal, Potential Changes to Legal Immigration Policies

Article:

In a significant development, Congress now appears to be on the verge of reaching a budget deal to maintain government operations without using the status of hundreds of thousands of young undocumented immigrants, often referred to as "Dreamers," as bargaining chips. However, it is also expected that President Trump may reconsider his threat of deportation for these individuals only if Congress considers the first significant cuts to legal immigration since the 1920s.

The proposed changes by the President stem from a nativist, zero-sum perspective that what is beneficial for immigrants is detrimental to America. This view contradicts not only the best of American tradition and principles but also evidence suggesting its negative impact on the country.

The programs under scrutiny by Mr. Trump are designed to make legal immigration more diverse and humane. One such program is the lottery system, which offers visa opportunities to individuals from countries underrepresented as sources of American immigrants. The other is family-based immigration, which grants visas to the close relatives of citizens and legal residents.

President Trump, who has frequently portrayed immigrants as terrorists and criminals, has recently focused his fear-mongering on the diversity visa program. Last month, his Department of Homeland Security released a report alleging that those entering the country via the lottery were more likely to be involved in terrorist attacks. However, a study by the Cato Institute found that lottery visa holders were responsible for only eight of the 3,037 Americans murdered by foreign-born terrorists since 1975.

Immigrants selected through the lottery are not chosen "without any regard for skill, merit or the safety of our people," as Mr. Trump stated in his State of the Union address. In reality, they must possess at least a high school education or two years of experience in skilled work. They also undergo criminal, national security, and medical checks. The 50,000 recipients of the visas are not guaranteed permanent residence, but rather a chance to proceed through the rest of the immigration process.

The ongoing negotiations between Congress and the President will likely shape the future of these and other immigration policies, with implications for the diversity and composition of the American immigrant population.

Title: House Democrats Ponder Participation in Benghazi Select Committee, Leaning Toward Non-Participation

Article:

In a closed-door meeting on Wednesday, House Democrats debated the structure of a proposed special investigative committee on the Benghazi attacks, with some members considering boycotting the investigation altogether. Following the meeting, Democratic leaders declined to disclose their future plans.

House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., stated, "One day at a time."

Some rank-and-file Democrats argue that participating in the select committee would improperly legitimize what they view as a political effort. Others, however, argue that by not participating, they will not be able to influence the direction and narrative of the investigation. Sources told Fox News that, based on Wednesday's meeting, it appears Democrats are leaning toward not participating.

GOP leaders outlined the particulars of the select committee on Tuesday evening, setting the stage for a comprehensive probe into various aspects, including U.S. response efforts and internal communications following the attack.

"It's not going to be a sideshow, it is not going to be a circus," said House Speaker John Boehner.

In a move that has caused contention among Democrats, GOP leaders proposed a committee consisting of seven Republicans and five Democrats. House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., and her deputy, Rep. Steny Hoyer, D-Md., objected in a letter to Boehner, calling for the panel to be evenly split between Democrats and Republicans. They also called for Democrats to have a "real and equal voice" in issuing subpoenas, questioning witnesses, and other areas.

Pelosi and Hoyer did not threaten to boycott the committee, as some rank-and-file Democrats have. GOP leaders argue that the select committee is crucial, particularly in light of revelations that the Obama administration withheld relevant emails for months before their release as part of a lawsuit last week.

The select committee's priorities include determining the response to the Sep. 11, 2012 attack, including rescue efforts for U.S. personnel. Four Americans, including Ambassador Chris Stevens, died in the assault on the U.S. compound. The committee will have subpoena power and may order depositions to be given under oath. A final report is required, though some of it may be classified. The next step will be for the House to vote on the committee, and for members to be chosen. Rep. Trey Gowdy, R-S.C., has already been selected to chair the committee.

Title: Trump Administration to Reshape Title X Family Planning Program, Potentially Impacting Abortion Services

The Trump administration is poised to redefine the terms of Title X, a federally funded family planning program that has long been a target of conservative critics. The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) is set to issue new guidelines for Title X grants, potentially reshaping the program to align with the administration's anti-abortion stance.

Teresa Manning, the deputy assistant secretary of the office of population affairs at HHS, who is a prominent anti-abortion advocate and a former lobbyist for the National Right to Life Committee, is expected to play a significant role in these changes.

"This is the administration's first attempt to really kind of redefine what they want the family planning program to look like," said Audrey Sandusky, communications director for the National Family Planning and Reproductive Health Association (NFPRHA), which represents Title X grant recipients. "We anticipate some attempt to undercut the program."

Supporters of Title X are concerned that the administration may exclude clinics that also provide abortions, restrict services, limit access to certain types of birth control, or reduce funding for the program. On the other hand, anti-abortion advocates are hopeful that the administration will reinstate Reagan-era regulations that prohibited Title X providers from offering abortion referrals and counseling, and from encouraging, promoting, or advocating for abortion as a method of family planning.

Steve Aden, chief legal officer and general counsel at Americans United for Life, an anti-abortion advocacy group, expressed support for this move, stating, "The best thing for health care and for women is that they receive [family planning services] in a setting that’s devoid of the possibility of Planned Parenthood pushing quote unquote options, when what they’re doing is referring them to the abortion facility."

The Trump administration's intentions will become clear when HHS issues a funding opportunity announcement for Title X grants. The conditions are expected to differ significantly from those set by the Obama administration.

In 2017, Congress appropriated $286 million for Title X grants, with Planned Parenthood and its affiliates receiving approximately $60 million annually through the program. The potential changes to Title X could have a significant impact on women, particularly those living in underserved communities, according to Kinsey Hasstedt, a senior policy manager at the Guttmacher Institute.

"Any attempt to undermine this program or the providers or women’s access to affordable care would be a huge setback and would definitely impact these women in these communities and represents a really unacceptable disruption of the program," Hasstedt said.

Title: FBI Director James Comey and CIA Head Mike Pompeo Criticize WikiLeaks, Sparking Debate on Transparency and Journalism

Article:

In a hearing with the Senate Judiciary Committee, FBI Director James Comey discussed the bureau's ongoing investigation into potential ties between the Trump campaign and Russia. During the hearing, Comey made critical remarks about WikiLeaks, distinguishing it from legitimate news sources.

Comey stated, "It crosses a line when it moves from being about educating a public to pushing out information...just to damage the United States." He further added, "There's nothing that even smells journalist about some of this content." Comey also mentioned that the focus of investigations would usually fall on leakers during legitimate investigations.

These comments echo those made by CIA head Mike Pompeo just a couple of weeks prior, in a speech at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. Pompeo declared, "We can no longer allow [Julian] Assange and his colleagues the latitude to use free speech values against us." He continued, "To give them the space to crush us with misappropriated secrets is a perversion of what our great Constitution stands for. It ends now."

It is important to note that no official should be in the position of defining journalism, implicitly sanctioning government action against whistleblowers and other leakers. However, the irony is palpable when the head of the FBI, an agency with a history of illegal and ineffective subterfuge, criticizes what constitutes legitimate media and what does not.

For instance, during a four-year period, the FBI authorized criminal activity by confidential informants over 22,000 times. The situation becomes even more disconcerting when the FBI director serves a president who has been vocal in his criticism of the press, calling for the "loosening" of libel laws regarding public figures and elected officials, and generally declaring war on the press.

The ongoing tension between Comey and President Donald Trump over the latter's refusal to recommend charges against Hillary Clinton adds an additional layer of complexity to the situation.

While it may be unrealistic to expect U.S. officials to embrace WikiLeaks and other sources that reveal government secrets, there is no denying that WikiLeaks has forced transparency in ways that have greatly benefited the public.

Title: Ross Perot, Billionaire Businessman and Independent Presidential Candidate, Dies at 89

 American businessman and former independent presidential candidate Ross Perot has passed away at the age of 89, following a five-month battle with leukemia, according to family spokesman James Fuller.

 Perot, who made his fortune by selling a controlling interest in the data processing business he founded to General Motors for $2.5 billion, was one of the most colorful political figures of the 1990s. His Texas twang, populist platform, and frequent television appearances brought him wide recognition.

 In the 1992 presidential election, Perot garnered nearly 19% of the vote, finishing third behind Bill Clinton and incumbent President George H.W. Bush. His 1992 campaign remains one of the most successful third-party bids in American history.

 Perot's impact on the election has been a subject of debate, with some, including former President Bush, believing he played a significant role in his defeat. However, election experts and scholarly research have challenged that theory, with The New York Times finding Perot's effect on the outcome of the election "appears to have been minimal."

 In 1995, Perot created the Reform Party, and the following year, he received 8% of the vote in the presidential election as the party's candidate.

 After his second and final bid for the presidency, Perot served as president and CEO of Perot Systems Corporation, which he founded in 1988. He was the head of the company until 2000, when he passed the title on to his son, Ross Perot Jr. Nine years later, Dell Incorporated bought Perot Systems for $3.9 billion, resulting in a net gain of about $400 million for the Perot family.

 Aside from his business and political careers, Perot also received national attention for his efforts during the Vietnam War to create better conditions for US prisoners of war. He traveled to Laos, where he met with ambassadors from Russia and North Vietnam, and was awarded the Medal for Distinguished Public Service by the Department of Defense in 1974 for his efforts. In 1979, when two EDS employees were taken hostage during a revolution in Iran, he organized and paid for a successful private mission called Operation Hotfoot to rescue the men and bring them home.

 "In business and in life, Ross was a man of integrity and action. A true American patriot and a man of rare vision, principle, and deep compassion, he touched the lives of countless people through his unwavering support of the military and veterans and through his charitable endeavors," Fuller said in a statement. "Ross Perot will be deeply missed by all who loved him. He lived a long and honorable life."

 Henry Ray Perot, who later legally changed his name to Henry Ross, was born on June 27, 1930, in Texarkana, Texas, where his father ran a cotton mill. By the time he was 7 years old, Perot was an accomplished horseman and a budding businessman. His father was training him to make a profit by buying and selling bridles.

 Perot graduated from the Naval Academy in 1953 and spent four years at sea. After the Navy, Perot worked as a salesman at IBM before starting his own corporation, Electronic Data Systems (EDS), in 1962 with a $1,000 loan from his wife, Margot. The company grew quickly, and when the company went public in 1968, Fortune magazine put Perot on its cover, calling him the "fastest, richest Texan."

 He later sold a controlling interest in EDS to General Motors, becoming a billionaire and GM's single largest stockholder and a director. He netted approximately $750 million in 1986 when he resigned from the General Motors board of directors as part of a buyout agreement and sold his GM shares.

 Although he had never held public office, by the early 1990s, Perot, sensing an opportunity for an outsider campaign with an anti-Washington message, was openly talking about a presidential run. Speaking to CNN's Larry King in 1992, he said that if he were to launch a campaign, he would run as an independent and "get both parties' heads straight."

 "I was down in Texas taking care of business, tending to my family, (but) this situation got so bad that I decided I better get into it," he later said during a presidential debate. At one point during the summer of 1992, Perot dropped out, stating he could not win and that staying in the race would only create problems for the electoral process. His withdrawal came shortly after he stumbled during a speech at the NAACP, where his comments on unemployment were interpreted as patronizing and insensitive.

 "Few people in this country have been able to live the American Dream to the extent that I have," Perot said when he re-entered, adding, "Neither political party has effectively addressed the issues that concern the American people."

Title: The Nuclear Option and the State of Partisanship in American Politics

Article:

In a highly contentious week in the Senate, Republican Sen. John McCain and Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin expressed their dismay over the potential use of the "nuclear option" to confirm Judge Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court. The GOP is expected to change the rules of the Senate to eliminate the filibuster for Supreme Court nominations, allowing Gorsuch to be confirmed with a simple majority of votes.

Senate Republicans will move to a vote on Gorsuch's nomination on Thursday, with Senate Democrats expected to filibuster to block that vote. The Republicans' response to the filibuster is likely to be the elimination of the filibuster for Supreme Court nominations, a move that has sparked criticism from both parties.

Brian Balogh, co-host of the BackStory With the American History Guys podcast and a professor of history at the University of Virginia, described the Republican use of the nuclear option as exceptional but not unprecedented in American history. Balogh's research focuses on the evolution of American political parties and movements.

Sarah Binder, a professor of political science at George Washington University, author of Stalemate: Causes and Consequences of Legislative Gridlock, and an expert on the Senate, agreed that the move is part of a long-term parliamentary arms race between the two parties. Binder explained that the gradual ratcheting up of partisanship has been underway since the 1980s in the Senate, and this is surely part of the natural outgrowth of that rising partisan tension.

The use of the nuclear option will make bipartisan cooperation in the future even harder, according to both Balogh and Binder. The removal of the institutional incentives to compromise or to move towards a more consensual position across party lines will likely lead to a more scorched-earth policy, with both parties digging in their heels and refusing to compromise.

Balogh and Binder both agreed that the American public will have to decide that they care more about effective governance than their party allegiances. The public will have to reward moderation and compromise over extreme partisanship if they want to see a return to more consensual politics.

Despite the current state of partisanship, lawmakers can still find mutually beneficial compromises, as demonstrated by the Senate immigration deal in 2013. Real legislative gains are made by enlarging the pie, giving each party its preferred outcome. The key to overcoming partisan gridlock is for lawmakers to close the doors and find an issue on which both parties can win.

Title: Analysis: Democratic Presidential Debate Highlights Harris, Buttigieg as Standouts, Challenges for Biden and Sanders

Aritcle:

The second night of the 2020 Democratic presidential debates took place on Thursday, with ten candidates taking the stage. The consensus among pundits and viewers was that Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.) and South Bend, Ind. Mayor Pete Buttigieg were the winners, while Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and former Vice President Joe Biden were considered the losers.

Sen. Bernie Sanders, who had a strong performance in the previous debate, struggled to offer unique proposals and came across as stern, yelling, and short on details. His Medicare-for-all plan and free college plan were criticized, with Mayor Buttigieg arguing that college should not be subsidized for billionaires' children. Sanders' performance wore thin as the debate went on, and he was unable to explain how his Medicare-for-all plan would work on a national level.

Joe Biden, on the other hand, started the debate capably, defending Obamacare and rattling off his plans on education. However, as the debate went on, he ran into trouble, particularly on the issue of race, where Sen. Kamala Harris went after him for his positions on civil rights and criminal justice. Harris was the clear standout on the stage, demonstrating her toughness and prosecutorial experience.

Sen. Kamala Harris' first big moment of the debate was when she said, "America does not want to witness a food fight." Her second was when she heaped an entire tray of spaghetti in former Vice President Joe Biden's face. Harris was well-prepared, clear, and measured in her answers, and her willingness to take on Biden signaled that she was the alpha on the stage.

Mayor Pete Buttigieg also impressed with his self-criticism and thoughtful approach to issues. When asked about the ongoing lack of minority representation on South Bend's police force, Buttigieg confessed, "I couldn't get it done." He went on to talk about the pain of his community, his own anguish over the situation, what he has managed to accomplish, and what he plans next.

The debate should teach the Democratic presidential candidates a valuable lesson: be yourself and show Americans what you stand for. The debate was a chance for the candidates to show their leadership skills, policy acumen, and authenticity, regardless of gender, color, or sexual orientation. The debate was a reminder that voters are attracted to candidates who are genuine and have a clear plan.

One night won't sink the Joe Biden campaign, but his performance was lackluster, and he seemed unfocused, distracted, and out of touch. When asked what his first priority as president would be, Biden answered that it would be defeating Donald Trump. This response was criticized as a lackluster answer, and it was pointed out that "build upon what we've done" is a more reassuring and appealing message than completely scrapping the entire existing system of private health insurance.

In conclusion, the second night of the Democratic presidential debates was a chance for the candidates to show their leadership skills, policy acumen, and authenticity. Sen. Kamala Harris and Mayor Pete Buttigieg were the standouts of the night, while Sen. Bernie Sanders and former Vice President Joe Biden struggled to impress. The debate was a reminder that voters are attracted to candidates who are genuine, have a clear plan, and are willing to take responsibility for their actions.

Title: Boeing Ends 2019 with First-Ever Negative Commercial Airplane Orders, Amidst 737 Max Crisis

Article:

In a significant setback, Boeing, the aerospace giant, reported a negative commercial airplane order count for the first time in decades at the end of 2019, according to CNBC. The company lost orders for 87 airplanes, with more cancellations than new orders.

The high rate of cancellations is a clear indication that the ongoing crisis surrounding the 737 Max, the airplane involved in two fatal crashes that claimed 346 lives, is continuing to impact Boeing's financial performance. The order book for the troubled jet shrank by 183 planes, though much of this was due to the bankruptcy of low-cost overseas airlines like India's Jet Airways and Vietnam's VietJet. However, the ongoing problems in getting the 737 Max certified led to insufficient demand to offset the losses.

There was a 90 percent drop in orders for 737 models during the year, according to CNN. Boeing barely had any firm orders for the Max after the grounding in mid-March, but other models also suffered a 29 percent drop in new orders.

Meanwhile, American Airlines has extended its cancellations for the 737 Max until June 4th, after previously targeting April 7th. The carrier has repeatedly pushed back the date as Boeing continues to grapple with regulatory approval for the 737 Max.

The Federal Aviation Administration ordered the grounding of all Boeing 737 Max jets after two deadly crashes in October 2018 and March 2019. Both crashes have been linked to a piece of software known as the Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS) that Boeing had installed on the 737 Max.

Recently, Boeing has been embroiled in a fresh controversy involving internal messages in which employees discussed the problems with the 737 Max in ways the company characterized as "completely unacceptable." In the chats and emails released by congressional investigators, employees mocked regulators, expressed concerns about flying the 737 Max themselves, and described interactions with FAA officials as cover-ups.

The messages reveal Boeing's attempts to reduce the amount of simulator training required by the FAA to certify pilots for the 737 Max. Last week, the company announced it would recommend simulator training for pilots of its 737 Max jets after previously stating that such training was unnecessary.

Boeing had initially sold the 737 Max to carriers on the promise they wouldn't have to pay for pilot training on simulators, a costly expense for airlines. Instead, pilots who were certified to fly on the 737 Next Generation planes took a short course on an iPad to fly the Max, according to The New York Times.

Title: Economic Recovery Slows Down Amidst Rising COVID-19 Cases and Job Losses

Article:

A recent analysis of employment data from platforms like ZipRecruiter and Homebase reveals a slowdown in job postings and small business openings, signaling a potential setback in the economic recovery. In June, job postings on ZipRecruiter decreased after a significant rise in May, while small business employment and openings, as per Homebase data, worsened over the past week.

The decline in small business activity, which had shown a nearly 40 percent improvement in May, fell to 6 percent across all of June. This trend is particularly evident in states experiencing infection surges, such as Texas, where layoffs and business closings have been observed even before the reimposition of some economic activity restrictions.

Foot traffic to retailers and other businesses has also decreased in large cities across southern states, including Houston, Orlando, and Jacksonville, where infections have spiked. This observation is based on an analysis of Safegraph.com data by researchers at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington.

Furthermore, data from 40 million households compiled by the financial firm Commerce Signals shows that after weeks of improvement, credit and debit card spending declined at the end of May across most states.

Economists have expressed concern about this development, as it marks a departure from the optimistic "rocket ship" recovery that President Trump had predicted in June. Federal Reserve officials have publicly warned that the recovery's success is highly dependent on public health, with Fed Chair Jerome H. Powell stating that a full recovery is unlikely until people feel safe to resume a broad range of activities.

The next few months of recovery could be rocky even if the current infection surge abates. Job losses remain at levels higher than in any previous recession, and an increasing number of workers report permanent layoffs rather than temporary furloughs. Moreover, a significant share of small businesses have yet to reopen, even as states lift restrictions on their operations, suggesting some of them may be closed permanently. By many measures, business activity and employment remain down by a quarter or more from pre-crisis levels.

Title: Trump Declares Hillary Clinton as "Real Enemy" in Exclusive Interview Ahead of Indiana Primary Victory

Article:

In an exclusive interview with ███ on Tuesday evening, presumptive Republican nominee for President, Donald Trump, declared that the "real enemy" lies ahead in the likely Democratic nominee, Hillary Clinton. The interview took place before the polls closed in Indiana, as Trump was wrapping up his victory in the GOP nomination for the presidency.

Trump's interview aimed to unify the Republican Party and to set his sights squarely on Clinton, stating that she is the "real enemy." He asserted that four more years of the Obama administration, under a potential Clinton presidency, would be detrimental to the country.

"The real enemy is Hillary Clinton and four more years of essentially Obama," Trump said. "The country can not take it. Our country is not going to be able to survive four more years of incompetence and bad decision-making."

Trump criticized Clinton's positions in favor of trade deals like NAFTA and the Trans Pacific Partnership, her opposition to securing the U.S. border with Mexico, and her stance on a strong American military. He claimed that Clinton's economic policies, particularly her role in the signing of NAFTA, have weakened the U.S. economy and cost the country jobs.

Regarding his vice presidential pick, Trump stated that he would be selecting a political figure, rather than a businessperson, to help navigate the political landscape and get things done in Congress. He expressed that he would like to finalize the nomination process before making a decision on a running mate.

Trump also attributed the high Republican primary turnout and low Democrat turnout as a sign of his strength in the general election. He stated that the high turnout was a result of his campaign and that he would be beating Clinton in popular votes if he had only faced one, non-serious competitor during the primaries.

The interview comes as Trump is expected to win big in Indiana but before his last remaining serious rival, Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX), officially drops out, thereby handing the nomination to Trump.

Title: GOP Senator Bob Corker Criticizes President Trump's Border Wall Funding Demand as a "Made-Up Fight"

In a recent interview on CNN's "State of the Union," Senator Bob Corker (R-TN) criticized President Trump's insistence on securing funding for a border wall, calling it a "made-up fight."

"This is a made-up fight so the president can look like he's fighting, but even if he wins, our borders are going to be insecure," Mr. Corker said.

The senator, who has been a frequent critic of the president, argued that the White House is proposing the wrong solution, suggesting that the focus should be on more sophisticated technology.

"It's not unlike going to the Pentagon and saying, 'Look, we need to buy fighters, and we have stealth fighters, and they're supersonic technology and they have precision guided missiles, but no, let's use the Wright brothers,'" said Mr. Corker.

He added, "And so it's not just about the money, it's what we're spending it on."

The current standoff between Mr. Trump and Democratic leaders over the border wall funding has led to a partial shutdown of the federal government.

"We could secure our borders. We could solve this problem. This is a made-up fight," Mr. Corker said.

President Trump tweeted Sunday that technology is fine but that the wall is essential, stating that "it is only a good old fashioned Wall that works!"

The ongoing debate between the two parties has left the government partially shut down, with no clear resolution in sight. The only way to stop drugs, gangs, human trafficking, and other criminal elements from entering the country, according to the president, is with a wall or barrier.

Title: House Oversight Committee Schedules Vote to Consider Contempt Charges Against Attorney General Eric Holder

Article:

The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee has announced a vote for next week to consider holding Attorney General Eric Holder in contempt of Congress over the controversial Fast and Furious gun-tracking operation. The vote is scheduled for June 20.

The committee's decision follows a 64-page memo released by Chairman Darrell Issa (R-Calif.) in early May, outlining the case for holding the attorney general in contempt. Issa's argument is based on Holder's failure to respond to an October 2011 subpoena for internal Justice Department documents on the operation.

In a statement Monday, Issa accused Holder of having "failed to meet his legal obligations" and of "obstructing the investigation." He added that the Justice Department can still stop the process of contempt by delivering key documents.

House Speaker John Boehner also issued a statement, saying the department is "out of excuses."

The Justice Department maintains that it has cooperated with the investigation and provided thousands of documents. Holder has testified before the committee at least eight times about Fast and Furious, most recently on Thursday before the House Judiciary Committee.

In a statement, Justice Department spokeswoman Tracy Schmaler called the scheduled vote "unfortunate and unwarranted." She said there had been "ongoing discussions" with committee staff about a "mutually acceptable resolution" to their information requests.

The White House Press Secretary Jay Carney on Monday also noted that Justice has provided 7,600 pages of documents to date and provided testimony during "hours and hours" of congressional hearings. He suggested the vote next week is political.

At Thursday's hearing, Issa grilled Holder in a particularly heated exchange where he accused the attorney general of failing to answer questions about the investigation.

The Fast and Furious program oversaw sales of nearly 2,000 firearms to suspected Mexican drug cartels in an attempt to trace gun trafficking. However, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) recovered only 567 of the guns. Most controversially, many of the guns were found at violent crime scenes, including at the shooting of Border Patrol Agent Brian Terry.

The Republican leadership initially hedged on fully supporting Issa's case due to concerns that charging the attorney general in contempt in an election year could backfire. At the same time, they tried to allay concerns from conservatives -- particularly freshmen -- who called for Holder's resignation.

Six House Republican freshmen wrote to the leadership on May 18 to push for a contempt of Congress resolution against Holder. Hours later, House Speaker John Boehner, Majority Leader Eric Cantor, and Majority Whip Kevin McCarthy issued a letter to Holder demanding that he fully cooperate with the Oversight Committee investigation.

They also warned that "if necessary, the House will act to fulfill our constitutional obligations in the coming weeks."

Sen. Charles Grassley (R-Iowa), ranking Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said Monday that the latest announcement is "straightforward and necessary."

"Contempt is the only tool Congress has to enforce a subpoena," he said.

However, Issa's Democratic counterpart on the House oversight committee, Rep. Elijah Cummings (D-Md.), called the committee's action "unfortunate."

"I am guardedly optimistic that a path forward exists that will serve the legitimate interests of the Committee in conducting rigorous oversight, protect the legitimate interests of the Department in its ongoing investigations and prosecutions, and avoid the needless politicization of this very serious issue," he said in a statement.

Holder would join only one other attorney general, Janet Reno in 1998, to be held in contempt by the Oversight Committee. The last time the House voted to find an executive branch official in contempt was in 2008 over the U.S. attorney firings controversy. It passed a resolution against White House Chief of Staff Joshua Bolten and former White House counsel Harriet Miers for failing to provide internal documents. Miers also refused to comply with a subpoena to appear at a hearing. The House Judiciary Committee also found White House adviser Karl Rove in contempt later that year over the same issue.

Title: Age Differences in Attention to COVID-19 News Remain Consistent Over Time

Article:

A new study by Pew Research Center's Election News Pathways project reveals that while a vast majority of U.S. adults (92%) are closely following news about the COVID-19 pandemic, significant differences in attention to the news emerge by age, particularly between the youngest and oldest Americans.

The study, which is part of the Election News Pathways project, found that more than two-thirds of adults ages 65 or older (69%) are following news of the pandemic very closely. Conversely, about four-in-ten Americans between the ages of 18 and 29 (42%) are paying as much attention to COVID-19 news. Those adults ages 30 to 49 and ages 50 to 64 fall in between.

The differences persist over time. Even as the public's attention to news about the coronavirus outbreak grew from the first half to the second half of March, that growth did not occur equally across all age groups. Attention among the youngest cohort remained behind others.

The study was conducted in two parts, with the first survey administered from March 10-16, 2020, among 8,914 U.S. adults, and the second survey from March 19-24 among 11,537 adults. In that short period of time, when reported U.S. COVID-19 cases and fatalities quickly mounted and efforts by government and public health experts to respond to the outbreak intensified, overall attention to news about the outbreak remained extremely high, with the share following it very closely rising from 51% to 57% over this period.

Some age groups intensified their attention, while others did not. The portion of those ages 30 to 49 and ages 50 to 64 following the news very closely grew about 10 percentage points. On the other hand, the portion of those ages 18-29 and 65 and older following coronavirus news very closely remained largely unchanged.

From mid to late March, the percentage following COVID-19 news very closely grew among middle-aged groups, while youngest adults remained least engaged. The share of those ages 30 to 49 who said they were following coronavirus coverage very closely rose 10 percentage points, from 44% to 54%. Among people ages 50 to 64, the percentage following news about the pandemic very closely rose by nine points – up from 54% to 63%.

Attention among those ages 65 and older did not change much between the two time periods, but this may largely be due to their very high level of interest from the outset. Even during the first survey, fully two-thirds said they were following news very closely, something that could reflect both the news consumption habits of senior citizens as well as warnings that they were among those most vulnerable to the new virus. In the March 16-24 survey, that number remained largely unchanged at 69%.

However, the increasingly sobering news of the pandemic had little impact on the group paying the least attention, those 18 to 29 years of age. Four-in-ten said they were following news about the virus very closely in the first survey, a figure that remained almost the same later in March (42%).

In conclusion, the youngest adults, those ages 18 to 29, are the least likely to say they are following news about the coronavirus very closely, while the oldest adults ages 65 and older are the most likely to do so. This level of engagement remained consistent from mid to late March. These measures and more can be explored further in the Election News Pathways data tool, where all of the data associated with this project is available for public use.

Title: House Budget Committee Advances GOP's ObamaCare Repeal and Replacement Plan, Facing Opposition from Conservative Members

Article:

The House Budget Committee has approved the Republican's ObamaCare repeal and replacement plan in a 19-17 vote on Thursday, with three Republican representatives voting against the bill. The three dissenting members, Reps. Dave Brat (Va.), Mark Sanford (S.C.), and Gary Palmer (Ala.), are all members of the conservative House Freedom Caucus, which has criticized the bill for retaining some ObamaCare provisions and insurance mandates.

Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) stated that the Budget panel's action brings Republicans "another step closer toward keeping our promise to repeal and replace ObamaCare." He emphasized that the repeal and replace process will be a step-by-step approach, and the bill is on track and on schedule as intended.

The bill will now move to the House Rules Committee, where leadership may make amendments to address concerns from both conservative and moderate members. The Rules Committee will serve as the final stop before the bill reaches the floor.
