House Freedom Caucus Chairman Rep. Mark Meadows (R-N.C.) has announced he will offer an amendment to leadership on Friday, but has not disclosed its content.

In her opening remarks, Budget Chairwoman Diane Black (R-Tenn.) encouraged conservative members to stay engaged in the discussions and work towards improving the proposal. She stated, "To my Republican colleagues who have doubts today, I encourage you: Don't cut off discussion. Stay in this effort and help us enhance this proposal by advancing it out of committee and pushing for further conservative reforms."

The committee also approved four non-binding recommendations from Republicans, including a work requirement for able-bodied adults enrolled in Medicaid and a plan to gear the refundable tax credits towards low-income individuals. The current GOP plan provides tax credits based on age, not income, for individuals making up to $75,000.

Some Republicans have expressed concerns that the tax credits are too generous for higher-income individuals and do not provide enough assistance for older, low-income individuals. Two Democrats also supported the recommendation to adjust the tax credits to better assist lower-income individuals.

The work requirement, as well as the option to accept Medicaid funding through block grants, is generally supported by both conservatives and moderates. The White House has stated it is working with leadership on a manager's amendment to the bill, but has not provided details.

House Republican leaders face a narrow margin for error once the healthcare bill reaches the floor, as at least 15 Republicans have stated they will vote against the bill or are leaning against it, according to CNBC's Whip List. Twenty-two defections would be enough to defeat the bill on the floor.

In the Senate, some Republicans are privately expressing hope that the House bill may fail, given the challenges they could face in passing the measure. A Republican senator, who requested anonymity to speak freely about the bill, stated, "Right now this is disintegrating in the Senate, with everyone off on their own about what they don't like about the bill."

Title: Sanders' Rising Funds and Controversial Foreign Policy Stance in Democratic Primary Race

Article:

In the ongoing Democratic primary race, Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders has reportedly raised a significant amount in fundraising, putting him in a strong financial position. According to recent reports, Sanders pulled in about $34.5 million in the fourth quarter of 2019, bringing his total to nearly $100 million. This places him far ahead of his competitors in terms of fundraising.

Historically, candidates who lead in fundraising at this stage in a primary, especially when an incumbent is not running, have a strong chance of winning the nomination. In 14 out of 14 primaries where a leader in fundraising was not an incumbent, they went on to win the nomination. Even when a candidate is trailing in the national polls, the leader has won 3 out of 5 times, including candidates like Democrat Bill Clinton in 1992 and Republican Mitt Romney in 2012.

However, former Vice President Joe Biden has a significant lead in endorsements from members of Congress and governors. Endorsement leaders at this stage in a primary have a strong track record of winning, having gone on to win the nomination 10 out of 14 times. When a candidate leads in both fundraising and endorsements, they have won 7 out of 9 nominations.

Sanders is reportedly using this financial advantage to draw clear contrasts with his fellow Democratic candidates, particularly on foreign policy issues. Sanders has studied Biden's long voting record and is beginning to highlight their differences, such as Biden's support for the Iraq War and Sanders' opposition. The question remains whether Sanders will use these contrasts in television ads in states like Iowa and New Hampshire as the voting nears.

Some caution that Sanders may face challenges in taking down Biden on the Iraq War issue, as he was unable to do so in the 2016 primary against Hillary Clinton. The issue may be less potent than it once was, and former Navy intelligence officer and former South Bend, Ind. mayor Pete Buttigieg, who was too young to vote on the Iraq War, may present a stronger challenge on national security issues.

Others argue that Sanders is in a strong position to use the escalating hostilities in the Middle East as an opportunity to highlight his alternative foreign policy. Sanders has a long record as an anti-war activist, and in 2016, he gained traction by contrasting his vote against the Iraq War with Clinton's vote in favor. In the current race, Sanders has staked out a radical foreign policy that includes ending the forever wars, using aid money as leverage to push Israel to negotiate with the Palestinians, and making climate change a cornerstone of American foreign policy.

The difficulty for Sanders is that if he raises the salience of foreign policy, he will have to argue against not only Trump but also former President Barack Obama. The safer course for Sanders would be to stick to domestic policy, where his popular policies distinguish him enough to carry him to victory. However, Trump's recklessness may make that safer path impossible, as the United States is already in a de facto war with Iran. If that war becomes a large-scale conflict, Sanders may have no choice but to run as the only true anti-war candidate.

In the end, the Democratic primary race remains a complex and dynamic contest, with Sanders' strong fundraising and controversial foreign policy stance adding another layer of intrigue. As voting nears, it will be interesting to see how Sanders' campaign strategy evolves and how his competitors respond.

Title: U.S. Senate Leaders Disagree on Witness Testimony in Impeachment Trial of President Trump

Article:

WASHINGTON ( ███ ) - U.S. senators are at odds over the format of the impeachment trial of President Donald Trump, with Republican leader Mitch McConnell and Democratic leader Chuck Schumer expressing differing views on witness testimony.

McConnell, in an interview with "Fox & Friends," stated that the Senate has not ruled out hearing from witnesses, but has not agreed to a Democratic request for a commitment to call witnesses before the trial begins. He cited the 1999 impeachment trial of President Bill Clinton as a model, where senators decided on witnesses after the trial had commenced.

"We haven't ruled out witnesses," McConnell said. "We've said, 'Let's handle this case just like we did with President Clinton.' Fair is fair."

In the 1999 trial, senators went through opening arguments, had a written question period, and decided on witnesses later. Limited testimony by video was allowed. Allowing witness testimony, particularly from current and former administration officials, could prolong the trial and potentially introduce new damaging evidence for Trump, who was impeached by the Democratic-controlled House of Representatives last week.

Schumer, on the other hand, insisted that the trial must include witnesses and the release of relevant Trump administration documents. He warned that a trial without documents and witnesses could be perceived as a "sham trial" or a "show trial" by the American people.

"It's hard to imagine a trial not having documents and witnesses," Schumer said at a press conference in New York. "If it doesn't have documents and witnesses, it's going to seem - to most of the American people - that it is a sham trial, a show trial."

The House voted along party lines to impeach Trump on two charges over his pressuring Ukraine to announce an investigation of former vice president Joe Biden and Biden's son. Trump was charged with abuse of power and obstructing Congress' investigation. He has maintained his innocence.

Trump, on Monday, accused Democrats of delaying tactics and urged for a quick conclusion to the impeachment process. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has not yet transmitted the articles of impeachment to the Senate, a move to pressure Senate Republicans to reach an accord with Schumer on trial rules. McConnell said the Senate could not take any action until it receives the articles.

Schumer has requested to have four witnesses subpoenaed for the trial. The White House blocked all four, including acting Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney and former national security adviser John Bolton, from testifying during impeachment proceedings in the House of Representatives in December.

Title: Rep. Ayanna Pressley Calls for Impeachment Inquiry into Supreme Court Justice Kavanaugh Amidst New Allegations

Article:

In a move that could potentially escalate the ongoing debate, Representative Ayanna Pressley, D-Mass., one of the four freshman congresswomen known collectively as the "Squad," has announced plans to introduce a resolution on Tuesday calling for an impeachment inquiry into Supreme Court Associate Justice Brett Kavanaugh. This decision comes in the wake of a New York Times report that included a new allegation of sexual misconduct from Kavanaugh's college days, although the alleged victim later stated that the incident did not occur.

In a statement, Pressley expressed her belief in Christine Blasey Ford and Deborah Ramirez, two women who came forward during Kavanaugh's confirmation process. "I believe Christine Blasey Ford. I believe Deborah Ramirez. It is our responsibility to collectively affirm the dignity and humanity of survivors," Pressley stated.

The proposed resolution, as suggested by Pressley's tweets, would initiate an inquiry into whether the House of Representatives should impeach Brett Kavanaugh, and would task the House Judiciary Committee with conducting depositions and taking affidavits, if necessary.

However, the top Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, Rep. Jerrold Nadler, D-N.Y., has not explicitly voiced support for impeaching Kavanaugh. In a radio interview on Monday, Nadler stated, "We have our hands full with impeaching the president right now."

As the news unfolded, Republican leaders criticized the renewed attacks on Kavanaugh, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell stating, "This is not normal political behavior."

The original New York Times piece, adapted from a forthcoming book, asserted that a Kavanaugh classmate, Max Stier, witnessed Kavanaugh with his pants down at a different drunken dorm party, where friends allegedly pushed Kavanaugh's penis into the hand of a female student. By late Sunday, the paper had revised its story to include the fact that several friends of the alleged victim said she did not recall the reported sexual assault in question.

Several Democratic presidential candidates, including Sens. Kamala Harris, D-Calif.; Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass.; Cory Booker, D-N.J.; South Bend, Ind. Mayor Pete Buttigieg; former Rep. Beto O'Rourke, D-Texas; and former Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julian Castro, have called for Kavanaugh's impeachment after the initial Times report. Despite the editors' note and revision to the story, these candidates have not retracted their calls for impeachment.

Sen. Kamala Harris continued to push for an investigation on Monday, even circulating an impeachment petition on her Twitter account. The ongoing developments in this story are expected to generate further discussion and potential action in the coming days.

Title: NSA Taps into Google and Yahoo Data Links, Allegedly bypassing Domestic Oversight

Article:

In a report published by The Washington Post on Wednesday, it was revealed that the National Security Agency (NSA) has allegedly tapped directly into the communications links used by Google and Yahoo to move large amounts of email and other user information among overseas data centers. The report, based on secret NSA documents leaked by former contractor Edward Snowden, suggests that the agency has exploited major U.S. companies' data to a greater extent than previously known.

The operation, code-named MUSCULAR, reportedly intercepts data outside the United States, thereby avoiding oversight by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court. The interception is said to occur at a cable or switch that relays the traffic through an unnamed telecommunications provider.

Google's chief legal officer, David Drummond, expressed outrage over the alleged actions, stating, "We are outraged at the lengths to which the government seems to have gone to intercept data from our private fiber networks, and it underscores the need for urgent reform." Google has recently stepped up its efforts to encrypt internal traffic, but was reportedly unaware of the program.

Similarly, Yahoo has strict controls in place to protect the security of its data centers, and it has not given access to its data centers to the NSA or any other government agency, according to a Yahoo spokeswoman. Yahoo plans to begin encrypting users' email as it moves to the company, but has not yet announced plans to keep email encrypted as it moves within Yahoo.

The NSA, in a statement, denied the allegations, stating that the suggestion that the agency relies on a presidential order to skirt domestic restrictions imposed by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act and other laws is not true. The agency also denied collecting vast quantities of U.S. persons' data from this type of collection.

The report is likely to add to the growing tensions between the U.S. intelligence establishment and tech companies, which have been struggling to assure customers overseas that they need not fear U.S. spying. Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy has announced his intention to ask for an administration briefing on the program, citing potential privacy concerns for millions of U.S. residents.

Title: Tea Party Conservatives and Healthcare Reform: A Long-Term Effort to Defund and Repeal Obamacare

Article:

On Capitol Hill, Tea Party conservatives have found allies in their efforts to defund and potentially repeal the Affordable Care Act, colloquially known as Obamacare. These conservatives have threatened to shut down the government if their demands are not met regarding spending issues related to the healthcare law.

Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota, founder of the House Tea Party Caucus, expressed support for the defunding campaign, stating, "This is exactly what the public wants" on the eve of the potential government shutdown. However, not all advocacy groups are fully on board with the defunding campaign. For instance, the Koch-financed Americans for Prosperity, which spent $5.5 million on health care television advertisements over the past three months, is more focused on sowing public doubts about the law.

Despite this, all groups share a common goal: to undermine a measure that Senator Ted Cruz, a Texas Republican and leader of the defunding effort, has likened to a horror movie. Tim Phillips, the president of Americans for Prosperity, stated, "We view this as a long-term effort." He also mentioned that his group expected to spend "tens of millions" of dollars on a "multifront effort" that includes working to prevent states from expanding Medicaid under the law. The group's objective is not to defund the law but to see it repealed.

"We want to see this law repealed," Mr. Phillips declared.

The crowd at the Hilton Anatole, just north of downtown Dallas, was enthusiastic during a town hall meeting in August, the second stop on a nine-city "Defund Obamacare Town Hall Tour." The event featured two prominent figures of the Tea Party movement: Senator Cruz and Jim DeMint, a former South Carolina senator who now runs the Heritage Foundation.

"You're here because now is the single best time we have to defund Obamacare," declared Senator Cruz, who later delivered a 21-hour monologue against the law on the Senate floor in September. "This is a fight we can win."

Although Senator Cruz is new to the Senate, the tactic of defunding legislation is not. For years, Congress has used the Hyde Amendment to ban the use of certain federal funds for abortions, except in cases of incest and rape, by attaching the amendment to spending bills. After the Affordable Care Act was passed in 2010, former Republican congressman Todd Tiahrt proposed defunding parts of the law. He discussed the idea with Speaker John Boehner's staff while the Supreme Court, which upheld the central provision, was considering the law's constitutionality.

Title: Judge Dismisses Defamation Lawsuit Against Former British Spy Christopher Steele in US

Article:

In a significant ruling, a judge in Washington D.C. has dismissed a defamation lawsuit against former British spy Christopher Steele, who compiled a dossier alleging links between Donald Trump and the Kremlin. The lawsuit was filed by three Russian oligarchs who claimed they were defamed by Steele's writings that they attempted to influence the 2016 US election.

Judge Anthony Epstein ruled in favor of Steele, stating that he has a right to his opinion. The Russian billionaires, Mikhail Fridman, Petr Aven, and German Khan, had argued that Steele was not entitled to free speech protections under the First Amendment, as he is not a U.S. citizen. However, Judge Epstein disagreed, stating that advocacy on issues of public interest furthers the purposes of the First Amendment, regardless of the speaker's citizenship or residency.

The judge also cited Washington D.C.'s anti-SLAPP law, which prevents parties from filing lawsuits to tamp down on opposing political views. Christy Hull Eikhoff, Steele's American lawyer, said the court had shown support for the First Amendment and the "profound national principle" that debate should be "uninhibited, robust, and wide open."

This victory for Steele comes after he argued through his lawyers that the owners of Alfa Bank, referred to as "Alpha" in the dossier, were trying to intimidate him into silence. The court in Washington D.C. ruled that Steele should have the same guarantees of free speech as American citizens, specifically the protection given by legislation designed to stop lawsuits being used by rich individuals to stop public debate.

The Alfa Bank owners accused Steele of acting maliciously or recklessly when he wrote a headline about "cooperation" between "Alpha" and the Kremlin in the US presidential election. However, the judgment states that this headline represents Steele's opinion based on what his sources were telling him about the Alfa oligarchs' long relationship with Vladimir Putin, including the claim that they sent him "large amounts of illicit cash" when he was deputy mayor of St. Petersburg.

The court's judgment notes that the dossier "does not present any direct evidence that Alfa interfered in the election." The FBI has been investigating whether a computer server in Trump Tower was communicating with one belonging to Alfa Bank during the campaign. It is not known what, if anything, the FBI found.

Lawyers for the Russian billionaires told the BBC in a statement they would probably appeal the decision. The three billionaires have previously brought a defamation case against Fusion GPS, the Washington D.C.-based research company that hired Steele. The dossier, containing salacious allegations against President Donald Trump, was first published by BuzzFeed in January 2017.

President Trump has repeatedly dismissed the Steele dossier on Twitter as "fake" and "fraudulent." He has also called Steele a "lowlife" and claimed that the document was financed by his 2016 presidential rival, Hillary Clinton.

Title: CNN's Debate Moderation Sparks Controversy Over Sanders-Warren Allegation

Article:

The recent Democratic debate hosted by CNN has sparked controversy among supporters of Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) over perceived bias in the moderation of the event. The debate, which took place on Tuesday, provided another instance where Sanders' supporters believe the mainstream media may have subtly undermined their candidate.

The controversy stems from an unproven allegation that Sanders, during a 2018 meeting with Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.), privately stated that a woman could not win the presidency. The allegation surfaced over the weekend, with media outlets citing unnamed sources, likely members of the Warren campaign, as the source. Sanders has vehemently denied making such a statement, and was asked about it again on the debate stage.

During the exchange, when Sanders reiterated that the story was not true, CNN's Abby Phillip asked, "You're saying that you never told Senator Warren that a woman could not win the election?" Phillip then turned to Warren and asked, "Senator Warren, what did you think when Sen. Sanders said a woman could not win the election?"

It is noteworthy that Phillip did not actually ask Warren whether Sanders had made the comment—she merely presumed that he had, even though he had just denied it. Moments later, CNN.com ran with the headline, "Sanders denies saying a woman can't be president." This framing of the subject makes it sound as if Sanders is denying an objective reality, even though there is no evidence he said it, and Warren's recollection of the statement was not specifically probed by the moderator.

The debate provided an opportunity for CNN to shed light on the rare dispute between Sanders and Warren, but instead, they chose to avoid the issue, a move that implicitly took Warren's side. Many of Sanders' most fervent online supporters found this approach telling.

Title: Intelligence Community's Refusal to Brief Congress on Russian Election Interference Sparks Controversy

Article:

Washington D.C. - A heated exchange took place on Capitol Hill Wednesday night as the House Intelligence Committee's planned briefing on Russian interference in the U.S. election was abruptly canceled due to the intelligence community's alleged "intransigence."

Rep. Peter King (R-N.Y.), a member of the committee, expressed his frustration to Fox News' "The Kelly File," stating, "Somebody has the time to leak it to The Washington Post and The New York Times, but they don't have the time to come to Congress." He further added, "It's their job to come. They don't have any choice. They have to come in, especially when they have created this."

Initially, Chairman Devin Nunes (R-Calif.) had requested a closed, classified briefing from the FBI, CIA, Office of the Director of National Intelligence, and National Security Agency. However, according to Fox News, CIA Director John Brennan declined to provide a briefer, citing the full review requested by President Obama. The other agencies did not respond to the committee's request, which is unusual given the panel is the most-senior committee with jurisdiction.

Nunes issued a statement expressing his concern, stating, "It is unacceptable that the Intelligence Community directors would not fulfill the House Intelligence Committee's request to be briefed tomorrow on the cyber-attacks that occurred during the presidential campaign." He added, "The Committee is deeply concerned that intransigence in sharing intelligence with Congress can enable the manipulation of intelligence for political purposes."

King highlighted the irony in the lack of cooperation, stating, "The consensus was that there was an attempt by the Russians to put a cloud over the election, to create disunity. Well, that's what's happening right now, but it's the intelligence community that's doing it."

King also noted that lawmakers have not received any assessment from the CIA that Russia interfered to help Trump win the presidency over Hillary Clinton, allegations first reported by The Washington Post Friday.

In a late Wednesday statement, the intelligence community defended its position, noting that senior administration officials regularly provide "extensive, detailed classified and unclassified briefings to members and staff from both parties on Capitol Hill." The statement added that they are focusing on the review ordered by President Obama on foreign efforts to influence U.S. elections.

However, the statement also noted that once the review is complete in the coming weeks, the Intelligence Community stands ready to brief Congress and make the findings available to the public, consistent with protecting intelligence sources and methods.

King, referring to recent press reports, said, "It's almost as if people in the intelligence community are carrying out a disinformation campaign against the president-elect of the United States." He added, "It's absolutely disgraceful, and if they're not doing it, then it must be someone in the House or the Senate who's leaking false information, and there should be a full investigation of this."

Further details about the "full review" ordered by President Obama are still emerging. Fox News has learned that the review is being led by the Office of the Director of National Intelligence and is a multi-agency effort. Investigators plan to take existing intelligence and reconstruct what happened, with a focus on whether there is new intelligence that substantiates analysis that the interference was designed to ensure a Trump victory, or whether a review of the existing intelligence with "fresh eyes" leads to new conclusions.

Title: White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus Responds to Allegations of Intelligence Leaks by Evelyn Farkas

Article:

In a Thursday morning interview with radio host Hugh Hewitt, White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus addressed the recent comments made by Evelyn Farkas, former Assistant Deputy Secretary of Defense, regarding the alleged leaking of sensitive information about the Trump transition team's interactions with Russia.

During a March 2nd interview on MSNBC's 'Morning Joe,' Farkas stated, "I became very worried because not enough was coming out into the open, and I knew that there was more. We have very good intelligence on Russia. So then I had talked to some of my former colleagues, and I knew that they were trying to also help get information to the Hill."

Priebus, in response to these comments, expressed his surprise and skepticism, stating, "It's almost so cavalier and unbelievable that I just wonder whether this person knows what the heck she's talking about." He further added, "It's just an incredible statement, you know, and how, what it means and what she meant by that, and whether that has anything to do with the issues in regard to surveillance of Trump transition team members is something that we need to figure out this morning and throughout the day."

When asked about a personal reaction to the statement, Priebus questioned Farkas' understanding of the situation, stating, "It's so much in your face that it makes you wonder what she means."

Regarding the potential interest of Director Comey in Farkas' statement, Priebus responded, "I hope that the intelligence committees and agencies are interested in all of these things." He also emphasized the White House's desire for a thorough investigation, stating, "We want this thing done thoroughly, and I will tell you that because we have got nothing to hide."

Radio hosts Sean Hannity and Mark Levin both mentioned the story Wednesday afternoon, and the original clip from MSNBC's 'Morning Joe' is available online. The transcript of the Priebus interview, courtesy of the Hugh Hewitt Show, provides further insight into the White House's response to Farkas' allegations.

Title: Reflecting on Martin Luther King Jr.'s Dream: A Call for the End of Race in America

Article:

Fifty years after Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s iconic "I Have a Dream" speech, the nation is still grappling with race relations. Despite the progress made, the issue remains a significant part of American discourse.

Racism, a persistent and pervasive issue, has been a part of human history for millennia. In the United States, a country that boasts of being the most advanced, successful, and powerful nation in history, the struggle to move past skin color continues.

The author argues that focusing on skin color is a shallow, hollow, and soulless way to view human beings. It is a senseless preoccupation, and any logical, decent person should not give it a second thought.

In the context of race relations, the author shares personal experiences, including his parents' immigration to the United States and his own political career in Louisiana. He notes that voters are more interested in a candidate's beliefs, values, and plans than their skin color.

The author acknowledges that while racism still exists, significant progress has been made in the half-century since Dr. King's speech. However, he also points out that the country has taken a step backward by emphasizing separateness rather than unity. The author suggests a return to the concept of the melting pot, where individuals from diverse backgrounds blend into a unified whole.

The author concludes by emphasizing the importance of treating people as individuals, regardless of their skin color, ethnicity, or heritage. He calls for an end to the focus on race in America, advocating for a society that values unity and individuality over separateness and hyphenated identities. The author's ultimate goal is a society where people are judged based on their character, not their skin color.

Title: Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren Endorses Hillary Clinton and Expresses Interest in Vice-Presidential Role

Article:

In a move that could potentially position her as a vice-presidential candidate, Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren has endorsed Hillary Clinton as the Democratic Party's presidential nominee. Warren, a prominent figure among the progressive wing of the Democratic party, made the endorsement in an interview on MSNBC and in an endorsement article published by the Boston Globe on Thursday.

During the MSNBC interview, Warren was asked by Rachel Maddow if she would accept a running mate position if offered by Clinton. Warren responded affirmatively, expressing her readiness to support Clinton's campaign and ensure her victory over Donald Trump.

In the Boston Globe article, Warren praised Clinton as a "fighter" who would keep Trump from reaching the White House. She also commended Clinton's primary opponent, Bernie Sanders, for running a powerful and impactful campaign that brought millions of people into the democratic process. Warren acknowledged the importance of Sanders' campaign, stating that it had "thrust issues... near and dear to [her] heart... into the spotlight."

Warren's endorsement follows President Barack Obama's formal endorsement of Clinton's candidacy and Vice-President Joe Biden's apparent endorsement, as indicated in a speech on Thursday. Warren's progressive stance and her popularity among the left could potentially help entice disaffected left-leaning voters who have been excited by Sanders but have been ambivalent about Clinton.

In a speech earlier on Thursday, Warren criticized Trump as a "businessman who inherited a fortune and kept it rolling along by cheating people." She described Trump as a "loud, nasty, thin-skinned fraud who... serves no one but himself," and labeled his attacks on Gonzalo Curiel, the federal judge presiding over the Trump University suit, as "exactly what you would expect from somebody who is a thin-skinned racist bully."

Warren's recent speeches have been characterized by a searing criticism of Trump, positioning her for a prominent and pugilistic role in the presidential election, whether she is on the ticket or not. As a constitutional law professor at Harvard, Warren's potential vice-presidential candidacy could offer a strong progressive voice and a sharp contrast to Trump's campaign.

Title: Supreme Court Ruling on Arizona Immigration Law: A Potential Boon for Mitt Romney's Presidential Campaign?

Article:

In the aftermath of the Supreme Court's ruling on the Arizona immigration law, political strategists suggest that the decision could potentially benefit Mitt Romney's presidential campaign. The ruling, they argue, provides Romney an opportunity to highlight the Obama administration's perceived mishandling of illegal immigration.

Analysts suggest that Arizona's ongoing struggle to enforce its own immigration law could help reinforce the narrative that the federal government needs to step in with a more effective approach, an approach that Romney, who recently outlined his immigration plan, claims to offer.

Brad Blakeman, former deputy assistant to President George W. Bush and a public policy professor at Georgetown University, stated, "Romney should come out and say the president created a constitutional crisis on immigration." He further added, "The Supreme Court basically said that federal law trumps state law, but the fact of the matter is federal law is not being enforced."

Blakeman suggested that Romney should use the ruling to emphasize the need for a "fair, just, and equitable comprehensive policy." He believes the ruling will help Romney's campaign, stating, "I think it’s going to help him. But Romney has got to tell the American people that this president created a constitutional crisis when he should’ve been leading to avoid one with both houses of Congress."

President Obama, on the other hand, argues that Republicans have persistently blocked reforms to the immigration system. In a recent address to Latino officials in Florida, the president stated, "politics" got in the way of passing the DREAM Act. Obama has since instituted a similar policy administratively.

Other political strategists suggest that the ruling will give Romney an opportunity to appeal to his supporters but that it is unlikely to be a key issue in the general election. Don Fowler, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, stated, "I don’t think it’s going to get him any net advantage. The electoral impact of this is going to be relatively minor."

Ben Golnik, a Republican strategist based in Minnesota, stated, "It gives him an opportunity to clearly spell out his views on immigration and what kind of reforms he sees necessary." He further added, "It’ll be an issue for those who have immigration at the top of their list, but the reality is it’s mostly about the economy."

In a statement issued after Monday's ruling, Romney appeared to follow the strategists' advice. He stated, "President Obama has failed to provide any leadership on immigration. This represents yet another broken promise by this President." He further added, "I believe that each state has the duty — and the right — to secure our borders and preserve the rule of law, particularly when the federal government has failed to meet its responsibilities."

Obama, in response, stated that the decision "makes unmistakably" clear that Congress must act on comprehensive immigration reform. He also expressed concern about the practical impact of the remaining provision of the Arizona law that requires local law enforcement officials to check the immigration status of anyone they suspect may be in the country illegally.

Monday's decision upheld one provision of Arizona's law—requiring law enforcement to check immigration status during routine stops for those they suspect may be in the country illegally. However, the ruling struck down three other provisions, one of which allowed Arizona's law enforcement to arrest those they think might be guilty of a deportable offense.

Other analysts contacted by FoxNews.com, including former South Carolina GOP chairman Van Hipp, Jr., suggested that Romney should now focus on the national security aspects of securing the border. Hipp stated, "Romney needs to remind American people why he supports securing our southern border." He further added, "His campaign has to keep his message focused on national security. He has early on, but now more than ever, it brings immigration to the forefront so it’s incumbent upon Romney to get out in front of thing and not allow it to be buried in the weeds."

Title: Shifting Landscape of Gay Marriage Support in the United States: A Look at the Republican Party

Article:

As the US Supreme Court prepares to hear arguments in two landmark gay marriage cases this week, the political landscape on this contentious social issue is rapidly evolving. Recent headlines reflect this shift: "Support for Gay Marriage is Soaring" (Washington Post), "Why Republicans Are Saying 'I Do' to Gay Marriage" (Time), "The Normalization of Gay Marriage" (The Atlantic), "Millennial Support For Gay Marriage Hits All-Time High" (Huffington Post).

The changing tide of public opinion, as depicted in these stories, poses particular challenges for the Republican Party.

In response to the issue, Republican Senator Rob Portman of Ohio, who recently declared his support for same-sex marriage due to his son's homosexuality, has faced a mixed response from fellow Republicans. While they have expressed personal support for him, they have also disagreed with his stance.

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, who is up for re-election this year and is considered a strong contender for the 2016 presidential race, has grappled with the issue of so-called "conversion therapy," a controversial practice aimed at changing homosexual individuals into heterosexuals.

"I'm of two minds just on this stuff in general," Gov. Christie said at a news conference last week. "No. 1, I think there should be lots of deference given to parents on raising their children." He further expressed skepticism towards bills that restrict parents' ability to make decisions regarding their children's care, but acknowledged that exceptions could be made.

Ohio Governor John Kasich initially expressed support for civil unions, but later retracted his statement through a spokesperson.

Sen. Saxby Chambliss of Georgia attempted to sidestep the issue with a humorous remark that drew laughter: "I'm not gay, so I'm not going to marry one."

Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky, a potential 2016 presidential candidate, has leaned on his libertarian/states' rights ideology. "I don't want the government promoting something I don't believe in, but I also don't mind if the government tries to be neutral on the issue," he told Fox News Sunday, which would imply that the Defense of Marriage Act (one of the Supreme Court cases) would no longer apply.

Ken Mehlman, a former chairman of the Republican National Committee and head of the 2004 Bush re-election campaign who came out as gay in 2010, has gathered signatures from 131 prominent Republicans to file a friend-of-the-court brief in the other case before the Supreme Court, challenging California's Proposition 8, a 2008 ballot measure that defines marriage as a legal union of one man and one woman.

When asked on Fox News Sunday if he could imagine the next Republican nominee for the White House supporting gay marriage, political strategist Karl Rove responded affirmatively. Margaret Hoover, a former George W. Bush White House aide and leading Republican Party operative, agrees.

"At the rate this issue is changing within the party, I think it's not out of the question," Hoover told Time.

According to polls, the issue is changing more rapidly with the public than with the GOP. The latest Washington Post/ABC poll shows that 58% of Americans support allowing gay and lesbian couples to marry, compared to 32% in 2003 and 47% in 2010. Meanwhile, support among "millennials" (those born after 1980) has soared to 70% from 51% when President Obama took office in 2009. The Post/ABC poll also finds that 81% of adults under 30 support same-sex marriage.

The Republican Party is well aware of this shift, having lost this segment of the electorate in the 2012 presidential election, when the party platform advocated a marriage amendment to the Constitution and defended the Boy Scouts of America's ban on gay scouts and troop leaders.

Today, the party's efforts to rebrand itself assume a softer tone regarding gay rights as part of an overall effort to appear (if not become) more inclusive. At the Conservative Political Action Conference last weekend, former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, another potential 2016 presidential candidate, criticized his party for appearing "anti-everything," including "anti-gay."

Republican National Committee chairman Reince Priebus took a similar stance in comments to reporters this past week.

"I think Senator Portman made some pretty big inroads last week," Mr. Priebus said. "I think it's about being decent. I think it's about dignity and respect, that nobody deserves to have their dignity diminished, or people don't deserve to be disrespected. I think that there isn't anyone in this room – Republican, Democrat, in the middle – that doesn't think that Rob Portman, for example, is a good, conservative Republican. He is. And we know that."

Title: Fact-Checking President Trump's Claim on Fauci's Views on China Travel Ban

Article:

In a recent interview with Maria Bartiromo on Fox News Business, President Trump asserted that Dr. Anthony Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, disagreed with his decision to restrict travel from China and later agreed that the move saved hundreds of thousands of lives. However, this claim contradicts the statements made by both Trump and Fauci in the past.

During the April 13 coronavirus task force press briefing, Trump stated that he and Fauci were "on the same page" from the beginning. At the same press briefing, Fauci discussed the responsiveness of the Trump administration to the recommendations made by the task force, including the travel restrictions with China.

In the early stages of the pandemic, Fauci reportedly did not consider a China travel ban, according to interviews with White House aides and Fauci himself in the New York Times. However, by January 30, leading public health officials in the federal government were recommending travel restrictions with China to President Trump. Aides also told the Wall Street Journal that Fauci, CDC Director Dr. Robert Redfield, and Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar convinced the initially-skeptical Trump to make the decision.

Fauci supported the travel restrictions publicly as well. At the task force press briefing on the day the restrictions were announced, Fauci said that the restrictions were implemented to "mitigate, as best as we possibly can, this risk." On February 3, the day after the restrictions took effect, Fauci stated on CNBC that the travel restrictions would "dampen down" coronavirus cases in the United States.

Fauci also repeated the value of the travel restrictions during the February 29 coronavirus task force press briefing, stating that without the travel restrictions, the United States would have had "many, many more cases" to deal with. It is important to note that the travel restrictions did not prevent all travel from China; they merely restricted it.

Furthermore, Fauci consistently agreed with the travel decision. On March 15, he stated that the president's decision to restrict travel from China had an effect on the spread of the virus in the United States, comparing it to Italy's situation. On March 22, Fauci said the United States was "not necessarily on the same trajectory" for coronavirus cases as Italy, citing Italy's decision not to "shut out as well the input of infections that originated in China" early on as a possible reason for the country's high number of cases.

Based on all available information, Trump's claim that Fauci criticized the president's decision to restrict travel with China is not accurate. In fact, Fauci was an early advocate for such restrictions in internal government coronavirus discussions.

Title: Grand Jury Impaneled in Mueller Investigation: A Routine Procedure or Sign of Intensifying Inquiry?

Article:

In a move that has sent shockwaves through the political landscape, The Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday that special counsel Robert Mueller has impaneled a grand jury in Washington, D.C. This development, according to the Journal, signals a growing intensity in Mueller's investigation into potential collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia during the 2016 election.

However, as a seasoned Justice Department reporter, I can attest that the convening of a grand jury is a common practice for prosecutors. Grand juries are routinely used to question witnesses and gather evidence. The surprise would have been if Mueller had not utilized this tool in his investigation.

In fact, as the Journal article notes, a grand jury was already in place, across the river in Alexandria, that the FBI was using in this case before Mueller was appointed. The association of "grand jury" with "indictment" in the public mind may lead to the assumption that the former FBI director could be preparing to indict the president and his inner circle. However, it's important to note that neither Mueller nor we, the public, have any way of knowing whether the evidence gathered will ultimately lead to indictments.

The Washington Post reports that the grand jury's existence is a sign that investigators continue to aggressively gather evidence in the case. USA Today adds that the move gives Mueller, a former FBI director, enormous power to subpoena documents and compel witnesses to testify under oath.

Ty Cobb, the president's lawyer, told the Post that he was unaware of the development but welcomed it if it could accelerate the resolution of Mueller's work. This is significant, as grand jury proceedings are meant to be secret.

However, the leak of this information, like many other aspects of this White House, has sparked an orgy of media speculation. It's worth noting that this is not the first time the Washington Post has published sensitive information, having previously published the transcripts of President Trump's January calls to the leaders of Mexico and Australia, following earlier leaks of those conversations.

While the grand jury could potentially pose a serious threat to the White House, its existence at this stage primarily fuels media speculation. The grand jury's role and the evidence it gathers will likely become more significant as the investigation progresses. For now, we can only wait and see.

Title: Journalist Ian Millhiser Challenges The Weekly Standard's Fact-Checking Decision on Brett Kavanaugh and Roe v. Wade

Article:

In a recent turn of events, Ian Millhiser, justice editor at ThinkProgress, has expressed his discontent with The Weekly Standard, a right-leaning magazine, for labeling one of his articles as "false." The article in question, titled "Brett Kavanaugh said he would kill Roe v. Wade last week and almost no one noticed," is under scrutiny for its headline's alleged misleading nature.

ThinkProgress, a left-leaning news site, has previously voiced concerns about Facebook granting fact-checking powers to an explicitly conservative media outlet, a privilege shared by only four other organizations: the Associated Press, Factcheck.org, Politifact, and Snopes.com. Articles tagged as false could potentially lose "80 percent of future traffic," according to Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, making the stakes high for media organizations. Millhiser notes that at its peak, Facebook provided as much as 40 percent of ThinkProgress's traffic, and while the social media giant has altered its algorithm, it still accounts for between 10 to 15 percent of the site's readers.

The crux of the issue lies in the headline's claim that Kavanaugh stated he would overturn Roe v. Wade. Millhiser's article presents a more nuanced argument, as he summarizes it in a follow-up post:

Kavanaugh, during his confirmation hearing, cited the "Glucksberg test" – a reference to Washington v. Glucksberg, a 1997 Supreme Court decision that established the Constitution does not protect a right to physician-assisted suicide. Under the Glucksberg test, courts should determine which rights are protected by the Constitution by asking which rights are "deeply rooted in this Nation's history and tradition." Kavanaugh also stated in 2017 that "even a first-year law student could tell you that the Glucksberg's approach to unenumerated rights was not consistent with the approach of the abortion cases such as Roe vs. Wade in 1973, as well as the 1992 decision reaffirming Roe, known as Planned Parenthood v. Casey."

Millhiser's article also cites law professors Jim Oleske and Jamal Greene, who reached similar conclusions regarding Kavanaugh's embrace of the Glucksberg test.

The question remains: Does this information imply that Kavanaugh would be inclined to overturn Roe v. Wade? A reasonable person might infer that this is so. The article concludes with this statement: "Judge Kavanaugh appears to be telegraphing his belief that Roe, Obergefell, and the Supreme Court's decision in Lawrence v. Texas, which provides that the government can not prosecute consenting adults for having sex, were not correctly decided."

If the headline had said that Kavanaugh "appeared to be telegraphing," or "hinted at," or even "heavily suggested" he would overturn Roe v. Wade, that would be one thing. But "said" is a strong word. It makes it sound like Kavanaugh directly stated his intention to overturn Roe v. Wade.

In his follow-up, Millhiser concludes that this all hinges on the definition of the verb "said." He turns to the dictionary, which does indeed list "indicate, show, and communicate" as possible definitions for the word. However, "said" is generally used as a synonym for indicate, show, and communicate when the subject of the sentence is a thing that cannot use words. A look in your eyes can "say" a great deal, but not literally – a "look" does not use words. People, on the other hand, do use words, so when writers describe a person as having said something, it's implied that they did so with their mouths.

This may seem like nitpicking, but we're in the midst of an intense news cycle revolving around the question of whether Associate Justice Brett Kavanaugh would vote to overturn Roe v. Wade. A headline that straightforwardly claims he admitted he would do so is manipulating readers' expectations, and thus the claim should have been hedged in the headline – even just a little bit – as it was in the article. If the claim is The Weekly Standard was wrong to say this headline is false, then I rate this claim: Mostly false.

Title: NRA Warns of Intensified Threat to Second Amendment Rights at Annual Meeting

Article:

At the National Rifle Association's (NRA) annual meeting in Houston on Saturday, leaders of the gun rights organization issued a stern warning to its members, stating that President Barack Obama and gun control advocates are determined to restrict their rights.

In a series of impassioned speeches, NRA leaders predicted that liberal forces would exploit future shooting tragedies to push for stricter gun control measures beyond what has been debated since the December shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

Jim Porter, who is set to become the group's president on Monday, asserted, "Revenge is what is motivating the president's unremitting challenge to gun owners today. Obama is meeting and plotting with the who's who of the gun ban movement."

Wayne LaPierre, the NRA's chief executive, described the Senate's recent vote to block background check legislation as "but one skirmish in what can only be defined as one long war against our Constitutional rights." He emphasized that the group is "in the midst of a once in a generation fight for everything we care about."

LaPierre also announced that the NRA has grown to a record 5 million members in the wake of the post-Newtown battle. He declared, "So we don't care if it is round one, round two or round 15, the NRA will go the distance. We will never give up or sacrifice our constitutional freedom. Not one single inch!"

Chris Cox, the group's chief lobbyist, quoted an old Margaret Thatcher line, stating, "We are stronger right now than at any time in our 142-year history, but the fact is we have to be stronger because right now our freedom is under attack like never before."

LaPierre concluded his speech by stating, "We will never surrender our guns. Never. By the time we're finished, the NRA must and will be 10 million strong." The NRA leaders' warnings serve as a call to action for its members, emphasizing the importance of maintaining their Second Amendment rights in the face of perceived threats.

Title: Federal Lawmakers Propose Enhanced Security Standards for U.S. Electric Grid Following California Substation Attack

Article:

In response to a significant incident of domestic terrorism involving the U.S. power grid, lawmakers are pushing for the imposition of federal standards to protect the country's electric grid from potential attacks. The call for action comes after a report detailing a sniper assault on a California electrical substation last year, which has raised concerns about the grid's vulnerability to terrorism.

Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) has announced plans, along with her fellow senators, to request the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) to establish minimum security standards for critical substations. The FERC, which oversees the electric grid's reliability, would be responsible for setting these standards.

The attack on Pacific Gas & Electric’s Metcalf transmission substation in April 2013 involved the severing of AT&T fiber-optic lines to disrupt phone and 911 service, and gunfire into a PG&E substation, causing outages. The incident, which had not been widely publicized until a report by The Wall Street Journal on Wednesday, involved intruders lifting manhole covers, cutting fiber-optic cables, and firing over 100 rounds into substation equipment, disabling 17 of 20 large transformers, causing approximately $16 million in damage. No arrests have been made in the case.

During an oversight hearing in December, Rep. Henry Waxman (D-Calif.) described the incident as an "unprecedented and sophisticated attack on an electric grid substation with military-style weapons." He added that communications were disrupted, and the attack inflicted substantial damage.

Congress is currently discussing a proposal that would grant the FERC the power to write and impose interim rules on grid defenses. The utility industry would still have the ability to influence any permanent requirements, according to The Wall Street Journal.

Rep. Trent Franks (R-Ariz.) stated, "The last thing I want to do is regulate any industry," but added that utilities must take steps to protect the grid for the sake of national security. Under current law, the commission has to accept or reject proposals written by an industry-dominated group, but cannot alter them, according to the report.

Some utility industry executives told The Wall Street Journal that it would be challenging to create rules for improving security that would be effective in both urban and rural areas. Lisa Barton, executive vice president of transmission for American Electric Power, noted, "One size fits all may not get you true resiliency." She added that increasing protections could be costly, but emphasized that it might be worth the investment.

Title: White House Summons Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein for Meeting Amidst Russia Investigation Tensions

Article:

In a move that has added fuel to the ongoing political drama, Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein was summoned to the White House for a meeting with President Donald Trump on Thursday. The meeting comes amidst recent calls from some of Trump's supporters for Rosenstein's ouster over his role in the expanding Russia investigation.

Rosenstein, who is Attorney General Jeff Sessions' deputy and was appointed by Trump, was spotted leaving the West Wing on Thursday afternoon. However, a White House official downplayed the meeting's significance, stating, "Rod Rosenstein met with the president at the White House regarding routine department business."

The meeting, though, seemed to have been arranged quickly. Rosenstein had been scheduled to introduce Sessions during an afternoon event at the Justice Department. But the emcee of that event announced that Rosenstein had been "called away on another matter."

Justice Department officials said Rosenstein was at the White House for about an hour. He was accompanied by FBI officials and discussed document production to Congress, they said. Rosenstein also met with White House Counsel Don McGahn.

The meeting takes place at a sensitive time for Rosenstein. Trump, outraged over the FBI's raid of personal lawyer Michael Cohen's office this week, has been publicly venting his frustration with Rosenstein, Sessions, and Special Counsel Robert Mueller, who is investigating Russian meddling in the 2016 election.

Trump's attack on Rosenstein is in reference to how the deputy attorney general signed a FISA surveillance warrant for former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page. The president has repeatedly decried the DOJ and FBI's efforts to obtain that surveillance warrant.

Trump has long been public about his frustration with how Sessions recused himself from the Russia investigation, setting in motion the series of events that led Rosenstein to appoint Mueller as special counsel.

Some Trump supporters have been urging him to get rid of Rosenstein. Former federal prosecutor Joseph diGenova told Fox News' "Hannity" on Wednesday, "Rod Rosenstein is so incompetent, compromised, and conflicted that he can no longer serve as the deputy attorney general."

However, despite this pressure, Trump on Thursday tweeted that he agrees with his legal team in cooperating with Mueller's probe. "I have agreed with the historically cooperative, disciplined approach that we have engaged in with Robert Mueller (Unlike the Clintons!)," the president tweeted Thursday.

Other supporters, including former adviser Stephen Bannon, have publicly encouraged Trump to stop cooperating with Mueller's requests. "The president wasn't fully briefed by his lawyers on the implications of not invoking executive privilege," Bannon told The Washington Post. "It was a strategic mistake to turn over everything without due process, and executive privilege should be exerted immediately and retroactively."

Earlier Thursday, Trump denied seeking to shut down Mueller's Russia probe, saying he would have fired the special counsel months ago if he'd wanted him gone. "If I wanted to fire Robert Mueller in December, as reported by the Failing New York Times, I would have fired him," the president tweeted. "Just more Fake News from a biased newspaper!"

Title: Experts and Political Divide: Balancing Public Health and Protests Amidst COVID-19 Resurgence

Article:

As the nation grapples with a resurgence of COVID-19 cases in several states, a heated debate has emerged between political factions regarding the reopening of the economy and the potential risks associated with ongoing protests.

According to recent reports, new hotspots have emerged in Arizona, Arkansas, Florida, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas, and Utah. While some of this spike in cases can be attributed to increased testing, the positive test rate is also on the rise, up from less than 8% at the end of May to nearly 14% currently. Concerns are mounting as these areas, which have recently reopened businesses and public spaces, are seeing a surge in COVID-19 cases.

The ongoing nationwide protests sparked by the death of George Floyd and issues of police violence and systemic racism have also raised concerns about potential superspreading events. However, experts caution that it is too early to definitively determine whether the protests are contributing to the spread of the virus. Outdoor exposure, unlike indoor exposure, is less risky, and it may be that arrests and detainment in police vans or jail cells are the primary sources of infection, rather than the protests themselves.

The debate surrounding the protests and their impact on the COVID-19 pandemic has sparked a contentious discussion. Some argue that the protests, if they lead to a significant increase in infections and deaths, would call into question the endorsement of these events by public health experts. On the other hand, proponents of the protests argue that the demonstrators are well aware of the risks and are taking necessary precautions.

In an effort to minimize risk, many experts and public health officials have adopted a harm-reduction approach, offering recommendations for safe protesting and providing protective gear on-site. This approach reflects the longstanding goal of public health experts to maximize the health of the population across all aspects of life.

As Jeff Shaman, an infectious disease modeler at Columbia University, noted, the initial lockdown period was intended to avoid the worst possible scenario, but the U.S. did not use that time to prepare for managing the pandemic effectively. The weeks that have passed since reopening have been squandered, and the nation is now grappling with both a resurgence in COVID-19 cases and the economic fallout of the lockdown.

In conclusion, the ongoing debate between political factions and the balancing act between public health and protests is a complex issue that requires careful consideration and a nuanced approach. The nation must strive to protect public health while also addressing pressing social and political concerns.

Title: House Immigration Reform Gains Momentum as Bipartisan Group Nears Bill Release and Speaker Boehner Meets with Congressional Hispanic Caucus

Article:

The House of Representatives is set to take a significant step forward in the immigration reform debate this week, as a bipartisan group of lawmakers nears the release of a bill and Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) is scheduled to meet with the all-Democratic Congressional Hispanic Caucus.

The bipartisan group, which has been working for four years without producing any legislation, is on the verge of unveiling a bill that focuses on enforcement measures. The House Judiciary Committee will hold its first immigration markup on Tuesday on this enforcement-centered bill, a move that Democrats have expressed disapproval of.

Speaker Boehner and Rep. Luis Gutierrez (D-Ill.), head of the CHC immigration task force, are aiming to collaborate and finalize a comprehensive immigration reform deal this week. "He's the speaker of the House, the leader of the House and of the Republican Conference," Gutierrez said in an interview on Monday. "He wants to get comprehensive immigration reform; we want to get comprehensive immigration reform passed. We should form a pact. Let's cement it this Wednesday."

The dual-track approach, with the Senate considering the bipartisan Gang of Eight bill and the House working on its own legislation, could signal a renewed momentum in the House's immigration reform efforts, which have lagged behind the Senate's progress so far. The Senate may vote on the Gang of Eight bill before the July 4th recess.

The House group, now composed of three Republicans and four Democrats, appears poised to release its bill as early as Wednesday, although a later release in the week or early next week is also possible. Negotiators are still meeting to finalize the language and make any necessary adjustments.

The Democratic members of the group will update all House Democrats at a caucus meeting on Tuesday and will hold smaller briefings with different members throughout the week, including meetings with the Congressional Black Caucus and the Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus on Tuesday, and New Democrats and the Congressional Progressive Caucus on Wednesday.

"Democratic members are seeking input from their caucus on the bipartisan agreement the working group is drafting into legislative language," a Democratic aide said. "It's their hope that once all the i's are dotted and the t's are crossed, they will be able to introduce the measure with support from both sides of the aisle."

The focus this week will be on the meeting between Boehner and the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, marking the first time a Republican House speaker has met with the group. This meeting is expected to provide insight into the direction of the House's immigration reform efforts and the potential for bipartisan cooperation.

Title: White House Warns of Potential $200 Billion Consumer Spending Drop in 2013 Due to Failed Middle-Class Tax Cut Extension

Article:

In a strategic move timed for the peak shopping season, the White House has issued a warning to Republican lawmakers, stating that consumer spending could decrease by approximately $200 billion in 2013 if Congress fails to extend tax cuts for the middle class by the end of next month. The warning was accompanied by a report from the National Economic Council and the Council of Economic Advisers, which analyzed the impact on retailers if taxes increase for families earning less than $250,000 per year as of January 1, 2013.

The report, released on Cyber Monday, the busiest online shopping day of the year, suggests that allowing middle-class tax rates to rise and failing to address the Alternative Minimum Tax could result in a 1.7 percentage point decrease in the growth of consumer spending in 2013. This potential decrease in spending is nearly four times the amount spent during the "Black Friday" weekend in 2011.

The White House emphasized the need for bipartisan cooperation to renew middle-class tax cuts, stating, "The president believes Democrats and Republicans should come together to renew middle-class tax cuts so families and businesses have more certainty at this critical time for our economy."

The administration's move appears to be a calculated effort to build support for President Obama's position in negotiations with Congress to avoid the so-called "fiscal cliff," a combination of tax increases and automatic spending cuts set to take effect in January. The president is urging lawmakers to first approve an extension of tax cuts for the middle class and to address tax rates for wealthier families later, which could result in an automatic tax increase for households earning more than $250,000 on January 1.

In a statement, the office of White House press secretary Jay Carney said, "While the president is committed to working with Congress to reach compromises on areas of disagreement, there is no reason to delay acting where everyone agrees: extending tax cuts for the middle-class." Carney added, "There is no reason to hold the middle-class hostage while we debate tax cuts for the highest income earners."

Lawmakers from both parties have expressed optimism about reaching a deal with the White House before the end of the year. Senator Jon Kyl of Arizona stated on CNN, "I think it's likely that there will be a solution — not a final solution by any means, and not a big solution — but will get us through the end of the year into next year with a plan for trying to deal with these issues long-term over the course of the next Congress." Kyl added, "That will require compromise."

Title: The Debate Over Enemy Combatant Status for Domestic Terror Suspects: A Look at the Case of Mr. Tsarnaev and the Legal Implications

Article:

In the aftermath of the Boston Marathon bombing, the question of whether the U.S. government can hold citizens arrested on domestic soil as enemy combatants has resurfaced. While some, like Senator Lindsey Graham, believe it to be lawful, others disagree. The Constitution's permissibility in such cases remains unclear, as neither Congress nor the Supreme Court has definitively addressed the issue.

The Supreme Court's ruling on the indefinite military detention of Yaser Esam Hamdi, an American citizen captured on the Afghanistan battlefield, during the Bush administration, offers some insight. However, the court never resolved the case of Jose Padilla, another American held as an enemy combatant for several years following his arrest in Chicago. The Bush administration transferred Mr. Padilla back to the civilian court system before the Supreme Court took up the case, with two federal appeals courts disagreeing on the legality of indefinite detention without trial.

In the Hamdi ruling, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote that there is no bar to the U.S. holding one of its own citizens as an enemy combatant. However, she also limited the decision to Mr. Hamdi's "narrow circumstances" and stated that indefinite detention for the purpose of interrogation is not authorized.

Senator Graham advocates for holding Mr. Tsarnaev as a military detainee to question him without a lawyer, citing the potential for lengthy interrogations without the interruption of a lawyer. The Obama administration has stated it would use a public-safety exception to the Miranda rule, but Graham argues this would only provide a few days before a lawyer intervened.

Graham also emphasizes that any interrogation as an enemy combatant would not involve inflicting suffering to make Mr. Tsarnaev talk, and that any information obtained would not be admissible as courtroom evidence. He contends that the Federal Bureau of Investigation might not be as effective as intelligence officials in persuading Mr. Tsarnaev to provide information, even with a defense lawyer present, due to the potential for leverage in a plea bargain.

However, Graham's stance faces opposition, with some arguing that the FBI would be equally or more effective in obtaining information. Ultimately, Mr. Tsarnaev must be transferred back to the civilian criminal justice system for prosecution, as the statute authorizing military commissions does not apply to U.S. citizens. The debate over the legality and effectiveness of holding domestic terror suspects as enemy combatants continues to be a contentious issue in the U.S. legal system.

Title: Biden Rallies in Detroit Ahead of Michigan Primary, Aims to Unite America

Article:

In the final days before Michigan's presidential primary, former Vice President Joe Biden made a stop in Detroit on Monday, rallying supporters, volunteers, and campaign donors. Addressing a crowd of approximately 1,000 people at Renaissance High School, Biden emphasized the importance of Michigan in the upcoming November election, stating, "Michigan, I’m counting on you in a big way."

Biden, who has garnered significant support from the African American community, was joined by U.S. Senators Kamala Harris of California and Cory Booker of New Jersey at the rally. The choice to bring his former rivals to a city where 82% of residents are African American was a clear nod to his strong backing in this demographic, particularly in South Carolina on February 29, where a landslide victory helped rejuvenate his campaign and secure 10 of the 14 states voting on Super Tuesday.

Not all attendees were supporters, however. About a dozen protesters carrying Green New Deal signs disrupted the rally, chanting, "Joe has to go." They were peacefully escorted out of the gymnasium.

Lt. Gov. Garlin Gilchrist, who is supporting Biden, received some boos from the crowd when he took a swipe at Hillary Clinton's 2016 campaign.

Biden emphasized the significance of the election, stating, "This election isn’t about a battle for the soul of the Democratic Party, it’s a battle for the soul of America." He reminded the crowd of the $2.5 billion investment the Obama administration made to help restore the Great Lakes and highlighted his experience and track record as key factors in his campaign.

Before the rally, Biden attended a $1,000-per-person fundraiser at the Detroit Athletic Club, hosted by some of Michigan's most prominent political figures.

Biden's rally at Renaissance High School was the largest event of the day, featuring a lively crowd, a marching band, and signs bearing slogans such as "Joementum" and "Michiganders love Biden!" Despite his late entry into the state and minimal ground organization, polls released on Monday showed Biden with a significant lead over his competitors. However, Sanders was in a similar position in 2016, down by 26 points to Hillary Clinton before the primary and ultimately securing a narrow victory.

In Grand Rapids, Biden spoke at the Cherry Health Heart of the City Community Health Center to a small audience of media and Cherry Health officials. He discussed the expansion of community health centers under the Affordable Care Act, or Obamacare, and expressed his intention to build on this progress in the White House. Biden also noted the challenges of implementing Sen. Bernie Sanders' Medicare for All plan, stating, "His Medicare for All push would be a long and expensive slog, if we can get it done at all."

Biden is scheduled to travel to Columbus, Ohio, on Tuesday, while his wife, Dr. Jill Biden, will wrap up the campaign in Michigan with visits to Lansing and Flint on Tuesday.

Title: The Media's Opportunity to Regain Trust: A Look at the Election of Donald Trump and the State of the News Industry

Article:

The election of Donald Trump as the 45th President of the United States has presented the media with a unique opportunity to regain the trust of the American public, a demographic that has shown a significant lack of faith in the news industry. According to a Gallup poll from last September, only 14% of Americans have "a great deal" of trust in the media to report the news fully, accurately, and fairly. Combining this with the 18% who have "a fair amount" of trust, only a third of the country's trust lies with the media.

Given the often negative and petty coverage of President Trump during the campaign, it is no surprise that much of this distrust comes from his 63 million voters. The media's chance to re-gain these disenchanted readers and viewers lies in treating Donald Trump the same way they treated Barack Obama when he became president in 2008. Remember the special commemorative issues, the broadcast network specials, and the tributes that marked the historic election of the first black president?

Instead of celebrating another historic occasion – the election of the first truly outsider president – news organizations have gone out of their way to continue being mean and petty. For example, a week after Trump's election, the New York Times led a chorus of news outlets that reported the Trump transition team was in chaos, after Vice President Mike Pence took the reins from Governor Chris Christie. However, the transition went smoothly, and Trump appointed a Cabinet of competent men and women.

Meanwhile, there is chaos at the New York Times, where layoffs have begun, and management is moving sections of the staff from the New York Times Building, as the newspaper plans to rent out another eight stories of the building to outsiders, as it seeks to offset the loss of ad revenue.

The misreporting of the transition team's chaos was only the first of many lost opportunities to reach out to disenchanted readers and viewers. Major media outlets are based on the liberal fringes of a conservative nation – Washington, New York, and Los Angeles – and are staffed by people who either never lived in the nation's interior or who fled because they did not like the place where they grew up.

Last summer, the Columbia Journalism Review published a column urging reporters to abandon even the pretense of objectivity to stop Trump. David Mindich, in a July 15 column, wrote, "The declining audience for traditional news is well documented and creates twin pressures... Second, networks can not replicate the influence that Murrow, Cronkite, and others had—on Election Day (November 8), we will be eager for signs to see if today's journalists pushing back against Trump actually stop him."

Of the newspapers that endorsed in the election, 243 went for Hillary Clinton, and 20 went for Trump. If newspapers had any influence, it would have been a 50-state shutout for her. Instead, it was a 30-state sweep for him.

Rather than give wise counsel to the profession on restoring its integrity, Columbia Journalism Review editor Kyle Pope urged the news media to double down on the stupid. Pope published an open letter to the president on January 17 to protest Trump's plan to treat the media as poorly in his presidency as the media treated him in the election.

Pope should have told reporters to knock off the anti-Trump tweets, to stop looking for trouble where there is none, and to start playing the game straight. For until news organizations do, they will be laying off workers and trying to rent out more office space to make ends meet. Don Surber, a retired newsman who lives in Poca, West Virginia, and is the author of "Trump the Press," which covered the 2016 Republican nomination process, offers this advice. In February, he will publish its sequel, "Trump the Establishment," which covers the general election.

Title: White House Hosts Social Media Summit: Trump Accuses Tech Firms of Suppressing Conservative Voices

Article:

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - President Donald Trump welcomed a group of prominent conservative social media personalities to the White House on Thursday, accusing big tech firms of suppressing conservative voices and vowing to look for regulations and legislation to protect free speech.

Trump, who has long claimed that online platforms employ tactics to silence conservative voices, said he would summon major social media firms to the White House for talks in coming weeks. He did not provide details on the measures being discussed.

"We're not going to be silenced," Trump said, complaining about fluctuations in the number of his Twitter followers. "Big tech must not censor the voices."

The event, dubbed the "Social Media Summit," brought together dozens of pro-Trump online personalities, who discussed what they say is censorship on social media platforms. The gathering included several members of Trump's cabinet and his White House team, as well as his son Donald Trump Jr.

In freewheeling remarks, Trump talked about the power of social media and railed against the traditional media standing at the back of the room. "We hardly do press releases anymore," Trump said. "If I put it out on social media, it's like an explosion."

Trump acknowledged criticism about the online behavior of some conservative users of social media. "Some of you guys are out there - but even you should have a voice," Trump said.

Trump more than once has threatened retaliatory action related to free speech. In March, he signed an executive order requiring U.S. colleges and universities to maintain "free speech" on campus if they want to continue receiving federal research funds. Last September, he suggested that the license of television network NBC could be challenged over its news reporting.

Senator Mark Warner, a Democrat, criticized the event, saying, "Instead of focusing on combating Russian social media misinformation, punishing anti-competitive practices, or protecting Americans' data and privacy, the president has invited trolls, conspiracy theorists, anti-Semites, and the whole comments section to the White House."

Facebook Inc (FB.O), Twitter Inc, and Alphabet Inc's (GOOGL.O) Google declined to comment on Trump's announcement that he would bring them to the White House for a meeting. The Internet Association, a trade group representing major tech firms like Facebook, Twitter, and Google, said, "Internet companies are not biased against any political ideology, and conservative voices in particular have used social media to great effect."

Republicans in Congress have held numerous hearings on the issue of alleged conservative bias on social media outlets.
