Republican Senator Josh Hawley, who is working on proposed legislation on the issue, took the stage briefly on Thursday to air his complaints. "They've gotten rich off of their special privileges from government. They want to keep those, they shouldn't discriminate. They shouldn't censor," Hawley said.

A Senate panel chaired by Republican Ted Cruz is set to hold a hearing titled "Google and Censorship through Search Engines" featuring Google's vice president of public policy, Karan Bhatia.

Title: Pope Francis' Visit to North America: A Divisive Figure Amidst a Polarized America

Article:

As Pope Francis embarks on his first visit to the United States this month, the pontiff's approval ratings have seen a significant decline, according to Gallup, from 76% in 2014 to 59% currently. The Pope's message of compassion, care for the planet, and rejection of opulent living has elicited a range of emotions, from love and admiration to scorn and fear.

One extreme example of this polarization can be seen in an article with the headline, "Why so Many People Think Pope Francis is the Antichrist." This headline appeared on Charisma News, and a quick Google search for "pope antichrist" yielded a multitude of hits, including claims that the Pope's visit was foretold by a Jesuit priest and that he is "demonically inspired."

While such claims may seem absurd, they highlight the deep-seated divisions that Pope Francis' message has stirred up in American society. The Pope's call to care for the poor and his criticism of unfettered capitalism have left many conservatives cold, particularly those who view him as a Marxist seeking to "spread the wealth."

R. Albert Mohler Jr., the president of the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, expressed concern over the Pope's words, stating that they are dangerous and could potentially split Roman Catholicism on the issue of poverty. Mohler also expressed displeasure with the fact that the Pope will address a joint session of Congress, viewing the Vatican as a diplomatic fiction and the Pope's visit as an attempt to exert influence over American politics.

On the other hand, the Pope's progressive supporters view him as a champion of their causes, such as climate change, immigration, and social justice. However, they are also frustrated by the Church's stance on issues like same-sex marriage, women priests, divorce, birth control, and abortion.

The Rev. Thomas Bohlin, vicar of Opus Dei, suggested that the Pope is not seeking to change Church doctrine but rather to shift the emphasis and the way people view religion. He believes that Francis wants to move away from left and right categories and instead encourage people to think deeply about their roles and responsibilities.

Mayor Bill de Blasio echoed this sentiment, stating that the Pope is not concerned with popularity but rather with telling the truth. De Blasio also noted that the Pope's message resonates with people of all backgrounds, demonstrating the wide-ranging appeal of the Pope's message.

In conclusion, Pope Francis' visit to North America has sparked a range of reactions, from admiration to fear and everything in between. His refusal to be easily categorized and his emphasis on personal responsibility and care for the poor have made him a divisive figure in a polarized America. However, his message of truth and compassion has also resonated with many, transcending religious and political boundaries.

Title: Pennsylvania Manhunt Concludes as Eric Frein Surrenders to Police

Article:

After a 48-day manhunt in northeast Pennsylvania, the suspected cop killer Eric Frein, 31, was apprehended late Thursday at an abandoned Poconos airplane hangar. Frein, who had eluded capture in the thick, cave-strewn Pocono Mountain woods, was spotted by a team of US marshals assisting in the manhunt.

The self-styled survivalist and fantasy soldier, who was believed to be ready to go down fighting, instead surrendered quietly. He was clean-shaven and "healthier than expected," police noted. A cut on his nose wasn't caused by police, they say. There were conflicting reports about whether Frein was armed at the moment of arrest.

The capture happened at the Birchwood Pocono Air Park in Tannersville, Pa., about 30 miles from Blooming Grove, where the shootings occurred. Frein was transported to the Pike County Correctional Facility from the barracks early this morning. He is scheduled to appear in court at 9 a.m. this morning.

Troopers used the handcuffs of the slain officer, Cpl. Bryon Dickson, to manacle Frein. Police also used Mr. Dickson's cruiser to transport Frein to a cell at the Blooming Grove barracks, the same police safehouse he attacked near midnight on Sept. 12 before slipping away into the deep woods.

The fact that Frein was captured alive to stand trial highlighted the best of American justice, a local newspaper columnist noted. "The news was a stinging rebuke to bar stool and Internet 'experts' who insisted the accused cop killer was long gone as state police, FBI, and ATF agents combed the woods of Monroe and Pike counties for 48 days," writes Scranton, Pa., Times-Tribune columnist Chris Kelly.

Prosecutors say they'll seek the death penalty amid a litany of murder and bomb-making charges. But even after finding parts of his diary, combing his Internet history, and plumbing his past, Frein's motives remain elusive, answerable perhaps only at his upcoming trial.

So far, police have only described Frein's alleged sniper attack as "pure evil," partly for his cold-blooded remembrance of the shootings in a diary found by searchers. "Got a shot around 11 p.m. and took it," Frein wrote, according to police.

Frein had been a standout on his high school rifle team. His father, an Army officer, had said Frein "doesn't miss." He had been jailed for 109 days in the mid-2000s for larceny stemming from a war-reenactment festival in New York. It's not known whether that incarceration forged what police have said is a deep-seated hatred of law enforcement.

He played organized war games using rifles that shoot rubber bullets. He dressed in a Serbian Army uniform and smoked Serbian cigarettes. His work history is patchy, and it was at his bedroom in his parents' house in Canadensis, Pa., where police found two pipe bombs he had constructed.

"I don't think that he is actually that well-versed in survival," Tom Brown, Jr., founder of the Tracker School in New Jersey, told the Monitor recently. "He's going to make a mistake."

Police believe Frein had planned the attack and escape for years. They found hints that he'd searched the Internet for information about how to elude police. And for 48 days, he managed to do just that, partly because of extreme caution on the part of searchers.

"A tracker is torn between looking at tracks on the ground and worrying about someone dropping them at 300 yards or 500 yards," Mr. Brown said.

Indeed, as Frein managed to stay just ahead of the manhunt, some civilian tracking experts noted that police manhunt methods had fallen short, and officials acknowledged that the combination of thick geography and concerns about another sniper attack on searchers had slowed the manhunt down.

Meanwhile, the surrounding hill communities in part worried about Frein's ability to wreak more havoc even as residents griped about area lockdowns and school closings. The manhunt atmosphere created a sort of police state "that raised important questions about law enforcement's authority to curtail the rights of innocent citizens," Mr. Kelly, the Scranton columnist, writes.

The shooting and manhunt also came in a year of anti-police protests in New York City and Ferguson, Mo., over cases where unarmed black men were killed by white police officers. Police fraternal organizations have been warning in recent years of an uptick in ambush assaults on law enforcement and courts.

In some cases, "police are not making friends of [the people]," so you have to expect that this sort of activity is going to occur and more people are going to disappear in the woods who have more [wilderness] training," says Shane Hobel, the founder of the Mountain Scout Survival School in New York's Hudson Valley.

Frein had become a ghostly presence as he hovered at the periphery of daily life in the quiet Pennsylvania township where he grew up. When police had sighted him, he flickered away in the thicket. Mr. Hobel, the tracker, wondered if Frein perhaps really was "on a beach somewhere." Police, however, say they never gave a thought to shutting down the manhunt, which was costing more than $1 million a week.

After Frein's capture, local officials also made sure to tell everyone that Halloween was no longer canceled.

Title: President Trump Refuses to Address Police Violence Against Black Americans, Defends Confederate Flag

Article:

WASHINGTON — In an interview with CBS's Catherine Herridge on Tuesday, President Donald Trump refused to answer a question about police violence against Black people, instead pointing out that white people are also victims of police violence.

When asked why Black Americans are still dying at the hands of law enforcement, Trump responded, "And so are white people, so are white people." He continued, "What a terrible question to ask. So are white people, more white people by the way, more white people."

According to a Washington Post database tracking fatal police shootings in the United States, white people make up roughly half of the people shot and killed annually by police. However, the Census Bureau estimates that roughly 76 percent of the country is white while only 13 percent is Black. The Washington Post database shows that the rate at which Black people are shot and killed by law enforcement is twice as high as that of white people.

During the interview, Trump also defended the Confederate flag, stating, "It's freedom of speech." When asked if he would be comfortable with his supporters displaying the Confederate flag at political events, Trump replied, "I'm comfortable with freedom of speech."

"I know people that like the Confederate flag and they're not thinking about slavery. I look at NASCAR, you go to NASCAR, you had those flags all over the place, they stopped it. I just think it's freedom of speech — whether it's Confederate flags, or Black Lives Matter, or anything else you want to talk about — it's freedom of speech," Trump said.

NASCAR announced in June it would ban Confederate flags from its events after Darrell "Bubba" Wallace Jr., the only black driver in the racing association's top series, called for change in the aftermath of the killing of George Floyd.

Trump has been criticized for his insistence on protecting monuments that honor Confederate leaders who fought to protect slavery and uphold white supremacy. Trump went as far as to threaten to veto Congress's annual defense authorization bill if it contained language to rename U.S. military bases honoring Confederate commanders, such as Fort Bragg in North Carolina, Fort Benning in Georgia, and Fort Hood in Texas.

Trump signed an executive order at the end of June to protect federal monuments after statues memorializing the Confederacy and some of the nation's Founding Fathers were vandalized.

Title: Kentucky Governor Matt Bevin Challenges Election Results, Alleges Voter Fraud in Gubernatorial Race

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Kentucky Governor Matt Bevin has expressed concerns over potential voter fraud in the state's gubernatorial election, as he trails his Democratic challenger, Attorney General Andy Beshear, by approximately 5,000 votes. Bevin's remarks came during a press conference on Wednesday, where he requested a recanvass of the results.

"There's more than a little bit of history of vote fraud in our state," Bevin told reporters, referring to Tuesday's election. He alleged "thousands of absentee ballots that were illegally counted," "voters incorrectly turned away," and malfunctioning voting machines, according to Politico.

The governor's claims come as he faces off against Beshear, who has claimed victory and dismissed Bevin's charges. The election night saw a strong performance by Republican candidates in Kentucky, with GOP candidates winning races for state attorney general, secretary of state, auditor, agriculture commissioner, and treasurer.

The nearly clean sweep by Republican candidates for Kentucky's top jobs followed President Trump's Monday night rally in support of the candidates, seemingly contradicting the mainstream-media narrative that the gubernatorial vote was a gauge of Trump's popularity rather than Bevin's.

Bevin stated, "We're in the process of getting affidavits and other information that will help us to get a better understanding of what did or did not happen," according to the Associated Press. Kentucky's secretary of state, Alison Lundergan Grimes, has scheduled the recanvass for next Thursday.

Kentucky law does not mandate a recount, so if Bevin decides to pursue one, he would need a court's approval. Despite Bevin's refusal to concede, some prominent Kentucky Republicans, such as state Rep. Jason Nemes and Republican strategist Scott Jennings, have begun referring to Beshear as Kentucky's next governor.

President Trump, in a Twitter message Wednesday, focused on his role in the Kentucky elections, stating, "Our big Kentucky Rally on Monday night had a massive impact on all of the races. The increase in Governors race was at least 15 points, and maybe 20!"

Turnout in Kentucky was up by nearly 50 percent over the state's 2015 governor's race, increasing from 974,000 voters to more than 1.4 million. The number of voters Tuesday equaled turnout in Kentucky's 2014 race for U.S. Senate, rare for an election in an odd-numbered year.

Title: North Carolina Joins 11 Other States in Requiring Voter ID, Sparking Controversy Over Voter Access

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy, North Carolina lawmakers have passed a measure requiring residents to present photo identification to vote, joining a handful of other states that have approved the controversial proposal. The Republican-dominated House approved the measure late Thursday night, with the state's Senate passing it a day earlier.

The new law, which aims to prevent voter fraud, will bring North Carolina in line with the majority of other states that already require voter ID. According to Senate President Pro Tempore Phil Berger, the measure "restores confidence in our election process and ensures voters are who they say they are."

However, critics argue that the law disproportionately affects poor, minority, and disabled voters. The American Civil Liberties Union of North Carolina stated that the law "attacks democracy at its core" by making it harder for eligible voters to cast their ballots. The group also pointed out that provisions in the measure, such as eliminating same-day voter registration, shortening early voting, and eliminating state-mandated voter registration drives, will negatively impact young, elderly, and disabled voters.

Proponents of the bill argue that having a valid, government-issued photo identification is a reasonable, modern-day necessity to prevent voter fraud. A poll this year showed that more than 72% of North Carolina residents support requiring voters to show photo ID before casting their ballot, according to Berger.

The passage of the law comes after the Supreme Court's decision last month to halt the enforcement requirements of the Voting Rights Act. The high court's ruling essentially allows states to make adjustments to voting laws without "preclearance" from the federal government. This change could potentially make it easier for states to implement voter ID laws, as requests by Texas and Mississippi for clearance in their voter ID laws were pending with the federal government when the high court struck down Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act.

Attorney General Eric Holder expressed displeasure with the change in the Voting Rights Act, stating that it "served as a potent tool for addressing inequities in our election systems." Holder has directed the Justice Department to ask a Texas federal court to subject the state to a condition similar to preclearance rights, citing evidence of racial discrimination in the state. He also noted that the Justice Department will continue to monitor jurisdictions nationwide for changes that may hamper voting rights.

States that may wish to implement their voter ID laws may still face legal action under Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, another part of the law that works to prevent discrimination. This could potentially lead to further legal battles over the implementation of voter ID laws in various states.

Title: Supreme Court Clears Bridgegate Officials of Federal Charges, Raising Questions on Public Corruption and Political Favors

Article:

In a unanimous decision, the Supreme Court has ruled that the actions of officials involved in the Bridgegate scandal, realigning toll lanes for political purposes, do not constitute a federal crime under current law. The officials did not obtain any money or property, but instead used their governmental authority for corrupt and fraudulent reasons to make life difficult for the political opponents' constituents.

The ruling is a continuation of the Court's history of permitting public officials to engage in allegedly corrupt acts. In a similar case involving the former governor of Virginia, the Court vacated his conviction for giving out access to meetings in exchange for political donations. The Court accepted that such acts are part of the ordinary, if untoward, functioning of government.

The Court's decision in the Bridgegate case concludes that the defendants' conduct is not currently prohibited by federal criminal law. However, it remains unclear whether Congress could pass a law criminalizing such behavior. The Court has expressed significant constitutional concerns with the federal government's attempt to prosecute a government official for taking a bribe, viewing it as ordinary government conduct.

The decision comes at a time of heightened public concern over government corruption, particularly during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Recent events have raised questions about the politicization of government responses, with allegations of federal officials using their positions to influence state responses based on political affiliation. The president's comments about withholding support from uncooperative governors and the Department of Justice's refusal to prosecute the president's former national security adviser for lying to the federal government and working for a foreign government are among the controversies that have arisen.

The ruling in the Bridgegate case underscores the ongoing debate about the role of money in politics and the potential for corruption in government. The Supreme Court's conservative justices have previously invalidated statutes designed to combat public corruption, citing the constitutional enshrinement of money in politics. The Citizens United and McCutcheon cases, which struck down limits on corporate campaign expenditures and aggregate limits on campaign contributions, respectively, are examples of this trend.

The full implications of the Bridgegate decision remain to be seen, but it raises questions about the limits of federal power to prosecute public corruption and the role of money in politics. As the pandemic continues to challenge the nation, the politicization of government responses and the potential for corruption remain significant concerns for many Americans.

Title: Unlikely Alliances: Democrats and Tea Party Unite to Challenge McConnell in 2014 Primary

Article:

In an unexpected turn of events, the 2014 primary race for the Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell in Kentucky could see an unusual alliance between Democrats and Tea Party activists. Big Democratic donors, local liberal activists, and a left-leaning super PAC in Kentucky are reportedly planning to support a right-wing candidate should one challenge McConnell in a primary.

The strategy, according to sources, is to soften McConnell's position in a general election, where Democrats still hold a voter registration advantage in Kentucky. Alternatively, the goal is to see Kentucky GOP primary voters nominate a weak candidate, similar to Todd Akin or Richard Mourdock, who may not be able to win the general election.

Keith Rouda, a field organizer with the liberal group MoveOn and the Democratic super PAC, Progress Kentucky, stated, "We are doing a lot of reaching out to some of the tea party folks across the state. What we’re finding — at least in this stage of the race — we’re finding that our interests align. It’s unusual."

Progress Kentucky has begun circulating petitions urging Republicans to run for the Senate seat, and Democratic donors active in Kentucky and national politics are reportedly willing to bankroll a Tea Party candidate. At this point, the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee and the Kentucky Democratic Party are not involved in these unorthodox efforts, officials said.

Sarah Durand, president of the Louisville Tea Party, confirmed that Democratic donors and activists have expressed their willingness to spend seven figures in a GOP primary to help a candidate challenging McConnell. Durand noted the challenge for Tea Party groups is to recruit a candidate who wouldn't hand the seat to the Democrats, even though Tea Party leaders across the state are not satisfied with McConnell's three-decade tenure in Washington.

"I guess the fear would be ending up in the Dick Lugar situation where you oust the incumbent and end up with a Democrat," Durand said. "But I really think if Sen. McConnell can’t garner some enthusiasm within the Tea Party, which is going to be very difficult at this point, then he’s going to have a really tough road ahead in this election cycle."

Behind the scenes, McConnell and his campaign staff are reportedly taking proactive measures to prevent a primary challenge. McConnell's staff has attended more than 100 Tea Party meetings in the state over the past two years, and the leader himself has stumped at three Tea Party rallies, including one with Sen. Rand Paul in the state capital of Frankfort last August.

McConnell has also held face-to-face meetings with several Tea Party activists, including Durand and her fellow activists for coffee right before the November election; her group is one that is skeptical of recruiting a primary challenger against McConnell. McConnell has also been quick to bring under his wing the two biggest forces in Tea Party politics in the state: Paul and freshman Rep. Thomas Massie (R-Ky.), who was initially seen as a possible primary threat to the GOP leader.

Title: Global Warming Skepticism on the Rise: A Look at the Shifting Tides in Climate Change Perception

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, the narrative surrounding global warming appears to be shifting, with a growing number of individuals and entities expressing skepticism towards the widely accepted climate change theory. This shift is evident in various sectors, including politics, entertainment, and academia.

President Obama's recent address to world leaders, where he emphasized the need to address climate extremes, seems to have met with a lukewarm response. The President's call for carbon sacrifices to combat climate change has been met with skepticism, particularly from leaders who recognize the importance of affordable energy sources in achieving prosperity.

This skepticism is not confined to the political sphere. In the world of entertainment, the mention of global warming in movies and television shows has significantly decreased. According to historian Benjamin Schmidt of Northeastern University, the use of the phrase "climate change" in scripts has diminished, with such mentions now often appearing as jokes or in animated shows.

Moreover, several European nations have been identified as fair-weather global warmists, with attempts to impose a binding worldwide treaty collapsing in Copenhagen five years ago.

The skepticism towards global warming is also reflected in the scientific community. Last week, New Scientist magazine, a reputable scientific publication, claimed that the growth in Antarctic sea ice is a result of global warming. This assertion, however, contradicts the general understanding that global warming leads to melting ice caps.

Despite these developments, it is important to note that the proponents of global warming remain steadfast in their beliefs. They continue to advocate for action to combat climate change, albeit with less fervor than in previous years.

As the world's diplomats gather to discuss climate change, it is crucial to approach the issue with an open mind, considering all perspectives. The resilience of Earth, as demonstrated by its survival of various natural disasters, suggests that it may be more robust than some predictions suggest.

In conclusion, the shifting tides in global warming perception are a testament to the dynamic nature of public opinion and the ongoing debate surrounding this complex issue. As more information becomes available, it is essential for all parties involved to engage in constructive dialogue to ensure a sustainable future for all.

Title: Congress Urged to Limit Executive Authority in Cuba Policy Amidst Controversial Deal

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy and criticism, President Obama's decision to normalize relations with Cuba has been met with resistance from Congress, who are urging to limit the executive's authority in the matter. The deal, which includes the release of American hostage Alan Gross and the exchange of three Cuban spies, has been criticized for its perceived moral and legal equivalency, as well as its potential to incentivize rogue regimes to kidnap Americans worldwide.

The deal, which has been on Obama's agenda for some time, has been met with skepticism and opposition from lawmakers who argue that the president lacks the authority to lift the embargo, allow trade, or grant Cuba access to capital markets. The Helms-Burton Act of 1996 grants Congress the power to override any executive action to lift the embargo.

In order to lift the embargo, the Cuban government would have to grant a number of rights to its citizens, such as freedom of association, speech, and political activity, which President Obama reportedly failed to secure in his recent conversation with Cuban dictator Raul Castro.

Congress is also considering using policy riders in the upcoming DHS appropriations debate in February and the Fiscal Year 2016 appropriations process to deny the president funds for setting up relations. Senators have also threatened to place a hold on any ambassador nominated to serve in Cuba unless the Cuban government is no longer a threat to the United States and has decided to grant freedom to its people.

Senator Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) has already stated his intention to do so. The deal has been criticized for failing to advance freedom in Cuba and for throwing a lifeline to the island's dictators, whose main source of funding, Venezuela, is currently in a precarious position due to plunging oil prices.

Critics argue that the deal fails to address the human rights abuses and state terrorism that have been perpetrated by the Cuban government for decades. The deal has also been criticized for its perceived moral equivalency, as the three Cuban spies released in exchange for Gross were convicted of actions that led to the death of an American in the 1990s.

Congress is urging action to limit the damage of the deal, with some lawmakers arguing that President Obama's approach to Cuba has been feckless and misguided. Senator Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) has described Obama as the worst negotiator since Carter. The deal has been met with criticism for its perceived lack of concessions from the Cuban government and its potential to incentivize rogue regimes to kidnap Americans worldwide.

Title: Trump Calls for Unified Fight Against Extremism in Historic Speech to Muslim Leaders in Riyadh

Article:

In a historic speech on Sunday, President Donald Trump called on Muslim leaders from across the Middle East and North Africa to take the lead in the fight against extremism, emphasizing the need for religious tolerance and the eradication of extremist ideology within their own societies.

Addressing a gathering of 50 leaders from Muslim countries at the Arab Islamic American Summit in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, Trump vowed that the U.S. would be a strong partner in the fight against terrorism but that Muslim nations would have to take the lead in rooting out extremism, even from within mosques and religious schools.

"There can be no coexistence with this violence. There can be no tolerating it. No accepting it. No excusing it and no ignoring it," Trump said. "They don't worship God. They worship death."

Trump's speech marked a dramatic break with the anti-terror and foreign policy of the Obama administration, which many Muslim countries saw as emboldening Iran through the Iran nuclear deal. The speech also provided a political win for Trump at home, as the focus shifted from accusations and investigations of collusion with Russia.

However, Trump did not use the phrase "radical Islamic terrorism," a phrase he harshly criticized President Obama for not using. During the campaign, Trump's rhetoric often risked offending Muslims, but he made clear the source of the extremism, referring to "Islamists" and "Islamic terror."

Trump stressed that the U.S. was not at war with Islam, stating, "I stand before you as a representative of the American people to deliver a message of friendship and hope and love." He also emphasized that the U.S. was not there to lecture or dictate, but to offer partnership based on shared interests and values.

The strategy outlined by Trump included denying territory or safe havens for extremists and cutting off financial streams to groups associated with terrorism. He stressed that more than military action, a message of religious tolerance and anti-violence had to come from political and religious leaders in the Muslim world.

Trump and Saudi King Salman agreed to establish the Terrorist Financing Targeting Center as a hub for efforts to counter terrorist fundraising. The speech, which touched on sensitive topics for Muslims, appeared to be well-received, with early endorsement from Saudi King Salman.

Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich compared Trump's speech to President Reagan's famous Westminster address to the British Parliament that set the stage for the defeat of the Soviet Union. "You have the president of the United States surrounded by the largest alliance we've ever seen in the Muslim world, talking and articulating about a practical and realistic idealism they are going to move forward together to create a better world," Gingrich said on Fox News.

Title: Major Cities Worldwide on High Alert Amidst Terror Threats: New York, Brussels, Paris, and Beyond

Article:

In the wake of chilling terror threats, major cities across the globe, including New York and Brussels, have heightened their security measures. New York City, boasting the world's strongest and most agile first responders, conducted an extensive active-shooter drill, with a focus on the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. Meanwhile, Brussels extended its highest alert level into Monday, citing an "imminent threat" to the capital.

New York Mayor Bill de Blasio commended the city's first responders after a three-hour training exercise that involved a multitude of federal and local agencies. "They're ready to protect us," de Blasio said.

In Brussels, Belgian Prime Minister Charles Michel extended the highest alert level due to a perceived "real threat." The city was in a virtual lockdown, with schools, commuter rails, cultural and sports venues closed. The city experienced a scare on Sunday when a major railway station was evacuated for a suspicious package, but no explosives were found. Later, streets were sealed off in the city's tourist district due to security concerns.

Belgian Interior Minister Jan Jambon acknowledged the heightened tension, stating, "There is a real threat, and we will make every effort day and night to face it." Jambon also revealed that several suspects linked to the Nov. 13 Paris attacks were being sought in Belgium, with the face of the manhunt belonging to suspected terrorist Salah Abdeslam.

In Brussels, Abdeslam's brother made a plea on Belgian TV for Salah to surrender. "I prefer to see my brother in a jail rather than in a graveyard," Mohamed Abdeslam told Belgian public broadcaster RTBF. Abdeslam expressed doubt that Salah participated in the attacks, stating his brother may have changed his mind and declined to participate in the massacre.

Paris remained jittery, with the sound of an explosion at the central Gare du Nord train station causing evacuation but ultimately revealing only a bird electrocuted on the rails. French police also released a photo of a man they believe was one of three terrorists who died outside the national stadium during the Nov. 13 attacks, seeking the public's help in identifying him.

French authorities have decided to continue the detention of a man who had housed some of the attackers, following the death of suspected attack mastermind Abdelhamid Abaaoud in a firefight with police.

Rome and Milan were also on alert after the foreign ministry warned that St. Peter's Basilica in Vatican City and some sites in Milan might be potential terror targets.

In Los Angeles, a Southwest Airlines flight from Indianapolis arrived an hour late after making an unscheduled landing in Kansas City due to "suspicious" behavior. The airline reported that all passengers aboard Flight 5929 exited the plane, and bomb-sniffing dogs searched it but found nothing.

In Washington, D.C., Police Chief Cathy Lanier advised residents to consider taking action, including shooting, if they find themselves in the midst of a terror attack. "Your options are run, hide, or fight," Lanier told CBS News' Sixty Minutes. "If you're in a position to try and take the gunman down, to take the gunman out, it's the best option for saving lives before police can get there."

No imminent, credible threat was reported for Washington or New York, but security was tight across both cities. U.S. House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes, R-Calif., discussing New York City, told CNN that reliable intelligence can be difficult to gather. "We do not know what we do not know," Nunes said. "They've gotten very good at hiding from intelligence services across the world."

Title: Senate Acquits President Trump in Bipartisan Vote, Dashing Democrats' Hopes for Conviction

Article:

In a bipartisan vote, the U.S. Senate acquitted President Donald Trump on both articles of impeachment on Wednesday, dashing hopes of Democrats who had hoped for a conviction before the 2020 election. The decision came after a two-week trial that saw heated debates and emotional appeals from both sides.

Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R-AK) announced her decision to acquit the president on Monday, joining a growing number of Republicans who had already declared their support for Trump. Murkowski criticized the president's behavior but also accused the House of bungling the case against him, stating that he could not receive a fair trial in the Senate. She expressed a preference for censure instead of impeachment.

Sen. Joe Manchin (D-WV), considered the most likely Democrat to side with Trump, has yet to announce his decision. However, he also expressed support for censure, stating that the president's dealings with Ukraine were not "perfect," as Trump has insisted. Manchin believes a bipartisan majority would back censure, but impeachment will fail due to the lack of the necessary 67 votes.

House Democrats made a last-ditch appeal to senators on Monday, urging them to convict Trump on both articles of impeachment as the only way to constrain him. Rep. Adam B. Schiff, the lead impeachment prosecutor, accused Trump of lacking character, breaking every boundary of decency, and betraying the country by subverting national security to his political whims.

Trump's lawyers argued that the only fair outcome was acquittal, as the impeachment process had been tainted from the start. They presented a video montage of Democrats vowing impeachment in January 2017, even before Trump was inaugurated. White House Counsel Pat Cipollone urged senators to leave judgment of Trump to voters, who began casting their ballots in the Iowa caucuses on Monday.

With closing arguments over, senators have two days to ponder their votes before Wednesday's final action. The House impeached Trump on December 18 on two articles: abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. The first article accuses Trump of abuse of power stemming from a July phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, in which Trump requested a corruption probe into political rival Joe Biden and Democrats' activities in 2016, while withholding financial aid to Ukraine. The second article accuses Trump of obstruction of Congress for claiming immunity from the House's probe and blocking witnesses and documents Democrats sought.

No Republicans voted for the articles in the House, marking the first time an impeachment of a president happened on a purely partisan basis. Trump's allies argue that he had the authority to request a probe into possible corruption, citing Hunter Biden's role on the board of a Ukrainian energy company and his receipt of about $50,000 a month from Burisma, despite lacking expertise in the industry. Democrats argue that Trump abused his position and that there is no basis to question the Bidens' behavior.

During the House impeachment inquiry, Democrats picked the witnesses to be called and blocked the president's team from calling its own witnesses or cross-examining the Democrats' choices. No witnesses testified that they heard Trump condition aid on Ukraine investigating the Bidens, but several said they believed it to be the case based on circumstantial evidence. Democrats said those in the know, such as former National Security Adviser John R. Bolton and acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney, rebuffed attempts to get them to appear. Bolton has since said he would testify to the Senate and has written a book that reportedly says he was asked by the president to help facilitate a meeting between Ukrainian officials and Trump's personal attorney Rudy Giuliani, who was allegedly part of the pressure campaign to start corruption investigations in Ukraine focused on the Bidens.

Senators will have all day Tuesday to make remarks on the chamber floor about the impeachment proceedings, and will cast their final vote on whether to acquit Trump the following afternoon. Meanwhile, Trump will deliver the State of the Union address on Tuesday night with the pending acquittal vote less than 24 hours away. Democrats have pivoted away from arguments over documents and witnesses and said the country's national security and fairness of the 2020 presidential election is at stake should Trump be left in office.

Title: Midterm Elections Shift Focus: Foreign Policy and ISIS Dominate as Election Day Nears

Article:

As the 2014 midterm elections approach, the rise of the Islamic State (ISIS) has significantly altered the political landscape, pushing national security and terrorism to the forefront of the campaign trail. The focus on foreign policy issues has overshadowed the partisan sparring over ObamaCare and multiple scandals that have plagued the Obama administration.

With just nine weeks remaining before voters decide the makeup of the next Congress, ISIS, Ukraine, Gaza, and Boko Haram have replaced the IRS, Benghazi, NSA data-gathering, and the VA as the primary concerns for candidates and voters alike.

Four years ago, Fox News polled voters on their top issues at the ballot box, with the economy leading, and Iraq at the bottom. However, recent polling shows that voters now prioritize a tougher approach to foreign policy as ISIS militants wreak havoc in northern Iraq and Syria, posing a threat to western interests.

Candidates are responding to this shift in public sentiment. Sen. Mark Warner (D-VA), who is facing a Republican challenge from former GOP chairman Ed Gillespie in November, urged the Obama administration to present a "clear strategy" for "eliminating" the Islamic State threat.

The sudden focus on foreign policy presents challenges for both parties. Republicans, who have been pulled in an isolationist direction by Sen. Rand Paul (R-KY) and budget-minded Tea Party groups, are adjusting their tone. Even Paul, while advocating for Obama to make his case for military action to Congress, acknowledged that ISIS has "absolutely" declared war on America.

For Democrats, the focus on the Middle East allows candidates to momentarily step away from the defensive on ObamaCare and administration controversies such as Benghazi and IRS targeting. However, the increased emphasis on terror threats means there is less room for Democratic candidates to tout modest domestic gains like job creation or the rebound of the stock market.

Sen. Jeanne Shaheen (D-NH), who is in a race against former GOP Sen. Scott Brown, distanced herself from the president's comments on Wednesday when he said the goal is to make the terror group "manageable." Shaheen tweeted, "Do not believe ISIL is'manageable,' agree these terrorists must be chased to the 'gates of hell.'"

Lara Brown, associate professor of political management with George Washington University, suggested that the economy, and the "languishing recovery," will remain a top issue in the fall. However, she also noted that voter perceptions of Obama's leadership abroad could impact the election, particularly for moderate Democrats who need the president to take a strong stand to maintain voter support.

A new GWU poll underscores the president's vulnerability on foreign affairs, with 58% disapproving of his handling of foreign affairs and 54% viewing him as "not tough enough" on security issues. The same poll showed a dramatic shift in attitudes toward America's role in the world, with the share of Americans who believe the U.S. does "too little" to address world problems nearly doubling since November 2013.

As Democrats attempt to toughen their tone, Republicans are doing the same, criticizing the president for a foreign policy strategy they deem ineffective. Brown, Shaheen's opponent, accused the Obama administration of emboldening America's enemies with an "incoherent foreign policy."

Brown released a scathing web video this week, juxtaposing Biden's 2012 claims about Obama's "strength" with ominous footage of Islamic militants and the president's recent gaffe where he said "we do not have a strategy" yet to address ISIS in Syria. The ad concludes with the text "Obama Biden - a foreign policy failure."

Title: Analysis of Key Senate Races: Democrats Face Uphill Battle in Midterm Elections

Article:

As the midterm elections approach, political analyst John Waage of ███ News has been scrutinizing the poll numbers to examine the crucial Senate races that are up for grabs. The Democrats, who have been predicted to experience a so-called "blue wave" that would give them control of the House and Senate, may be facing an uphill battle.

To seize control of the Senate, Democrats need to win two seats. However, they are defending six states where they are facing tough competition from the Republicans. The Kavanaugh Supreme Court confirmation battle may have left a mark on the polls, as some surveys indicate a voter backlash against the Democrats' handling of the Kavanaugh hearings.

In North Dakota, incumbent Sen. Heidi Heitkamp (D) is trailing her Republican challenger, Kevin Cramer (R), by double digits. In Missouri, Josh Hawley (R) is giving incumbent Sen. Claire McCaskill (D) a tough fight. In Montana, Sen. Jon Tester (D) is nearly neck and neck with Matt Rosendale (R). In West Virginia, incumbent Sen. Joe Manchin (D), who voted for Kavanaugh, is holding onto the lead.

Republicans are defending seats in Arizona and Tennessee, where Sen. Jeff Flake and Sen. Bob Corker are retiring. In Tennessee, Marsha Blackburn (R) now has a 14-point edge against Phil Bredesen (D) in the latest New York Times poll, despite pop singer Taylor Swift's endorsement of Bredesen. In Arizona, Martha McSally (R) is tied with or slightly ahead of Kyrsten Sinema (D). In Texas, Sen. Ted Cruz (R) has increased his margin over Beto O'Rourke (D). However, Democrats have poured millions of dollars into the Texas race, and O'Rourke has a significant campaign war chest.

Democrats are also targeting the Republican-held seat in Nevada, where Jacky Rosen (D) is facing incumbent Sen. Dean Heller (R). Heller currently has a slight lead in recent polls.

According to Waage, based on the current polls, Republicans would gain two Senate seats if the election were held today. The possibility of a House takeover is more likely for the Democrats, but it all comes down to voter turnout. Waage believes that even if Democrats win control of the House, it will be by a narrow margin. "Both bases are mobilized," he says. "Republicans weren't before the Kavanaugh hearings, but they are now."

Title: Senate Clears Path for Immigration Bill, but House Outcome Remains Uncertain

Article:

In a significant step towards potential immigration reform, the U.S. Senate cleared a key hurdle on Tuesday, paving the way for a comprehensive immigration bill to be debated. The bipartisan measure, which offers a 13-year path to citizenship for millions of undocumented immigrants, received strong support from both parties, with a vote of 82-15.

The bill, which addresses a highly charged issue with significant political implications for both parties, aims to fulfill a long-standing promise to Hispanic Americans, a key voting bloc, to address the limbo of the 11 million immigrants living in the country illegally.

President Barack Obama, who has made immigration reform a priority of his second term, urged Congress to pass the bill at a White House event earlier in the day. He emphasized that the bill would increase spending on border security, require undocumented immigrants to undergo background checks, learn English, pay taxes, and a penalty before they could begin the 13-year path to citizenship.

However, one GOP opponent, Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas, predicted that the Republican-controlled House would reject the bill in its current form due to the pathway to citizenship. Cruz, who is a member of the Republican Party, argued that the bill is designed to fail in the House.

The bill, which was hammered out this spring by a bipartisan group of senators known as the "Gang of Eight," has faced opposition from some congressional conservatives who view it as a form of amnesty for those who entered the country illegally. In addition, concerns about the bill's effectiveness in securing the nation's porous borders may make it difficult for conservatives to support it, especially those up for re-election next year.

Sen. John Cornyn of Texas, the chamber's No. 2 Republican, who voted for opening debate, questioned the wisdom of granting permanent legal status to millions of undocumented immigrants without any guarantee of securing the border.

Sen. Marco Rubio, R-Florida, a member of the bipartisan "Gang of Eight" and a possible GOP presidential contender in 2016, has made it clear that border security requirements must be toughened if he and other GOP skeptics will support the bill. He is pushing an amendment that would make Congress, not the executive branch, responsible for deciding if security metrics at the border have been met before other aspects of the reform bill, including the pathway to citizenship, are triggered.

The vote on the Rubio amendment will be closely watched as floor action unfolds over the next three weeks. Other planned amendments will involve stepped-up security checks of people entering the country, temporary visas for high- and low-skilled workers, and other technical provisions.

In a rare display of unity, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, union leaders, and other interest groups have come out in support of the Senate plan. Advocates for comprehensive reform won the first major legislative victory last month when the Senate Judiciary Committee voted 13-5 to approve the "Gang of Eight" plan. Democratic leaders hope to have a Senate vote on final passage by the end of June.

A bipartisan group has been working on a separate immigration plan in the House, but the effort suffered a setback last week when a key member dropped out of the negotiations. Previous efforts to pass immigration reform fell short last decade even though it was said to be a priority of President George W. Bush. Now, Obama has made the issue a major priority of his second term.

Title: Trump Selects Montana Representative Ryan Zinke as Interior Secretary Nominee

WASHINGTON (AP) - President-elect Donald Trump has chosen first-term Republican U.S. Representative Ryan Zinke of Montana, a former Navy SEAL commander, as his nominee for the position of Interior Secretary, a senior transition official announced on Tuesday.

U.S. Representative Ryan Zinke (R-MT) is set to head the Interior Department, which employs more than 70,000 people across the United States and oversees more than 20 percent of federal land, including national parks like Yellowstone and Yosemite.

Zinke's selection was unexpected, as some Republican officials had hoped he would challenge Democratic U.S. Senator Jon Tester of Montana in the 2018 elections. Initially, Trump had considered nominating U.S. Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers of Washington state for the position.

Zinke, 55, is a proponent of keeping public lands under federal ownership, a stance that puts him at odds with some in his Republican Party who favor privatization or state control. It remains unclear where Zinke stands on increasing drilling and mining on federal lands, a promise made by Trump during his presidential campaign.

Trump's official energy platform calls for opening "onshore and offshore leasing on federal lands, eliminating the moratorium on coal leasing, and opening shale energy deposits."

Rumors circulated last week that McMorris Rodgers had been picked for the post, but a source close to the congresswoman stated on Tuesday that she had never been offered the job.

Zinke, an early Trump supporter, has voted for legislation that weakens environmental safeguards on public land. However, unlike other candidates who were on the shortlist for the interior secretary job, Zinke opposes the transfer of public lands to the states, a position that aligns with Trump's.

Trump has stated that he does not believe public land should be turned over to the states and should be protected. In July, Zinke resigned as a delegate to the Republican nominating convention because the party platform called for transferring public lands to the states.

Public land comprises more than 30 percent of Montana, according to the Montana Wilderness Association. The League of Conservation Voters, which ranks lawmakers on their environmental record, gave Zinke an extremely low lifetime score of 3 percent. The Wilderness Society, a leading conservation group, expressed concern over Zinke's support for logging, drilling, and mining on public lands.

The Interior Department also oversees the Bureau of Indian Affairs and handles tribal policy. Under the Obama administration, the department played a significant role in efforts to curb the effects of climate change by limiting fossil fuel development in some areas.

Title: Harvey Weinstein Indicted on Rape Charges in New York

Article:

In a significant development, disgraced Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein has been indicted by a Manhattan grand jury on charges of first- and third-degree rape in one case and a first-degree sex act in a second case. The charges, announced on May 30, mark the first criminal charges against Weinstein in connection with the numerous allegations of sexual harassment and assault that have been levied against him since October of last year.

Weinstein surrendered to authorities in New York on May 25 and was arraigned shortly thereafter. Bond was set at $10 million or $1 million cash, which he paid with a cashier's check. Weinstein was also required to relinquish his passport and wear a GPS monitoring system. He is only permitted to travel between New York and Connecticut.

In a press conference on Friday, Weinstein's lawyer, Ben Brafman, reiterated Weinstein's contention that he did not engage in nonconsensual sexual activities. Weinstein is expected to enter a plea of not guilty.

The indictment comes two days after reports that federal prosecutors had begun a sex crimes investigation into Weinstein, and that a state grand jury had convened to hear evidence in sexual assault allegations against the former Hollywood mogul.

The NYPD does not release the names of sex crime victims. However, Lucia Evans, now a marketing consultant, confirmed to the New Yorker's Ronan Farrow that she is pressing charges against Weinstein. Evans alleges that in 2004, when she was an aspiring actress, Weinstein forced her to perform oral sex on him at the Miramax office in Tribeca—just blocks from the NYPD precinct where Weinstein turned himself in on Friday.

Actress Paz de la Huerta told Vanity Fair that Weinstein raped her in 2010 at a Manhattan hotel, but she told Farrow that her allegations are not part of the charges expected to be filed against Weinstein, though she will testify if asked.

The case has raised questions about Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance's handling of previous allegations against Weinstein. In 2015, Vance declined to prosecute Weinstein in connection with a sexual assault allegation, and later received a campaign donation from Weinstein's lawyer. Vance will be faced with the decision of whether to prosecute, under public pressure from critics of his previous decision, and from the #MeToo movement more generally.

In a statement Wednesday after the indictment, Vance said, "This indictment brings the defendant another step closer to accountability for the crimes of violence with which he is now charged."

The arrest and indictment are only the beginning of a long legal process. Weinstein's connection to Vance could play a role in the future of this case, as the producer has hired another lawyer who was a donor to Vance's campaign, and who represented two high-profile rape defendants whom Vance declined to prosecute. Whether Weinstein will get a fair trial, or a trial at all, remains to be seen. But if he does, it will be momentous, as the first in a wave of powerful men accused last year finally faces his day in court.

This isn't the first time Weinstein has been investigated by the NYPD. In 2015, model Ambra Battilana Gutierrez reported to police that Weinstein had grabbed her breasts and tried to reach up her skirt during a meeting at his Tribeca office. Despite a recording in which Weinstein appeared to admit to the incident—saying, "I won't do it again"—Vance's office decided not to press charges.

The issue of donations matters not just for the previous Weinstein case but for the current one. Weinstein has hired high-powered defense attorney Ben Brafman to represent him this time around. Brafman's firm has donated about $4,600 to Vance in the past, the Times reports. And Vance has declined to prosecute two high-profile Brafman clients accused of rape in the past: lawyer Sanford A. Rubenstein in 2015 and French politician Dominique Strauss-Kahn in 2011.

Now, of course, critics are watching Vance for any sign of favoritism toward Weinstein. And the rise of the #MeToo movement means public opinion around the case may look different than it did for, say, Strauss-Kahn.

We don't yet know how all these conflicting forces will come into play at a trial, if the case goes that route. What we do know is that the man whose name has become inextricably linked with #MeToo has been arrested and will likely soon be charged. Whatever happens next, the whole country will be watching.

Title: Fed Chairman Warns of Economic Recession if Congress Fails to Avert Budget Crisis

Article:

In a grim assessment of the U.S. economy, Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke warned Tuesday that a looming budget crisis could lead to a recession and the loss of 1.25 million jobs in 2013 if Congress fails to reach an agreement to avoid the fiscal cliff.

Testifying before the Senate Banking Committee, Bernanke outlined the potential consequences of the automatic tax increases and spending cuts set to take effect at the end of the year. He noted the Congressional Budget Office's warning that a recession would occur, and job growth would be significantly reduced.

The Fed is prepared to take further action to support the economy if unemployment remains high, but Bernanke did not specify the steps the Fed might take or whether any action was imminent. He emphasized that the Fed's role is limited, and Congress holds the key to resolving the budget impasse.

Bernanke's testimony came as the economy is growing modestly but has weakened. Manufacturing has slowed, consumer spending is down, and job growth has slumped to an average of 75,000 jobs per month in the second quarter of 2012 from 226,000 jobs per month in the first quarter. The unemployment rate remains at 8.2 percent.

The economy, after growing at a 2.5 percent annual rate in the second half of 2011, slowed to roughly 2 percent from January through March and likely weakened further in the April-June period. Bernanke urged Congress to resolve the budget impasse well before the year ends to reduce uncertainty and boost household and business confidence.

The potential job losses from the fiscal cliff could reach as many as 2 million, according to a report by the Aerospace Industries Association. A separate report Tuesday highlighted the budget crises many states are facing due to shrinking federal revenue.

Republicans in Congress are demanding deeper spending cuts, while extending income tax cuts for all. Democrats want to extend the tax cuts for middle- and lower-class Americans but let them expire for those in the highest-income brackets.

Bernanke stopped short of telling Congress what steps to take, challenging them to think broadly. He also warned that the economy's challenges go beyond the budget impasse, and lawmakers must produce a long-term plan to shrink federal budget deficits to avoid a potential financial crisis marked by rising interest rates.

Stocks rose sharply despite Bernanke's grim assessment, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing more than 90 points. The Fed chairman also addressed Europe's debt crisis, stating that the Fed has been working with U.S. banks to ensure they are prepared for a potential crisis.

Sen. Charles Schumer (D-N.Y.) implored Bernanke to take action now, stating, "Given the political realities of this year's election, I believe the Fed is the only game in town. I would urge you, now more than ever, to take whatever actions are warranted."

Even if the Fed announces another round of bond purchases, some economists question how much it might help, as mortgage rates and other key borrowing rates are already at record lows. The economy was already sputtering when the Fed's policymaking committee last met in June, and the Fed decided to extend a program that shifts its bond portfolio to try to lower long-term interest rates. The Fed also reiterated its plan to keep its key short-term interest rate near zero until at least late 2014.

Title: New York Times Allegation Against Kavanaugh: A Closer Look at the Details and Corroboration

Article:

In a recent development, a new allegation of sexual misconduct has surfaced against U.S. Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh, as reported in a New York Times essay by Robin Pogrebin and Kate Kelly. The allegation, which is detailed in their forthcoming book, involves an incident from Kavanaugh's freshman year at Yale University that allegedly echoes the claims made by Christine Blasey Ford, another of Kavanaugh's classmates.

The essay states that a classmate, Max Stier, saw Kavanaugh with his pants down at a different drunken dorm party, where friends allegedly pushed Kavanaugh's penis into the hand of a female student. However, the logistics of the allegation are unclear, as it is not specified whether Kavanaugh was allegedly walking around naked or if his friends physically maneuvered him in such a way.

The authors provide little information about the corroboration of the story, stating only that Stier notified senators and the FBI about the account, but the FBI did not investigate, and Stier has declined to discuss it publicly. The authors claim to have corroborated the story with two officials who have communicated with Stier.

It is worth noting that the female student involved in the alleged incident has reportedly denied any memory of the event, a fact that was omitted from the New York Times story. This omission has been criticized as a case of journalistic malpractice.

The new allegation is intended to lend credence to the on-the-record allegation made by Kavanaugh's Yale classmate Deborah Ramirez in 2018. Ramirez's allegation was that Kavanaugh exposed himself to her at a party while they were both college freshmen. The authors of the essay downplay Ramirez's own doubts about the incident, focusing instead on details that are meant to portray Kavanaugh as a privileged individual who might engage in such behavior.

However, the details provided do not corroborate Ramirez's allegation. The essay does not provide any first-hand witnesses to the alleged incident, and the supposed corroborating source for Ramirez's claim, classmate Kenneth Appold, was not present when the alleged incident occurred. Appold has also reportedly recanted his account.

In conclusion, the new allegation against Kavanaugh, as detailed in the New York Times essay, is unclear in its details and lacks corroboration. The omission of key information, such as the alleged victim's lack of memory of the event, raises questions about the credibility of the story. The book, which is not yet released, may provide more details, but the current essay does not offer a strong case against Kavanaugh.

Title: Government Shutdown Halts Key Economic Reports, Leaves Policymakers in the Dark

Article:

The ongoing government shutdown has resulted in a significant halt in the production of key economic reports by key agencies, leaving policymakers in the dark regarding crucial budget information, spending, and the economy. The shutdown has caused the cancellation of three major reports, including the Labor Department's September jobs report, the Congressional Budget Office's (CBO) monthly budget reviews, and the Treasury Department's final deficit report for fiscal year 2013.

The CBO announced that its Monthly Budget Review will not be published during the shutdown's duration, while the shutdown has also delayed another CBO report that was supposed to outline tax and spending options for reducing the deficit. Marc Goldwein, senior policy director at the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, lamented, "The irony of this whole thing is we just shut down our means to have those budget options to avoid the shutdown."

The shutdown's impact on the economy and politics remains uncertain, with some analysts predicting it could save money due to halted programs and fewer employees to pay, while others argue that it takes money to shut down and start up operations. Douglas Holtz-Eakin, former CBO director and president of the American Action Forum, noted that the cost of a shutdown is "not a lot of money" in relation to the federal budget.

As the shutdown enters its second week, the lack of information has left policymakers with little understanding of the economy's real-time status. The problem for federal agencies is that the number crunchers have been furloughed as part of the 800,000 federal employees whose jobs were deemed non-essential to protecting life or property. At the CBO, only about 10 percent of agency employees are on the job, dealing with bills actively under consideration in Congress.

Sen. John Cornyn (R-TX) argued that the lack of information benefits the White House by hiding bad budget numbers. However, Holtz-Eakin stated that the lack of data isn't catastrophic but does hurt. He noted that the calculations of damage to the economy are probably overblown, and the shutdown's impact on the economy is relatively minor at this stage.

Even amid the shutdown, some numbers are still coming in, such as the Treasury Department's Daily Treasury Statement showing the status of the federal debt. The administration has also released reports arguing that approaching the debt limit could cause a severe recession. Private analysts are filling the gap with their own calculations and data, with organizations like the Alliance for American Manufacturing and the Center for American Progress issuing reports on job creation and economic impact.

As the shutdown continues, the fear is that it could extend into the middle of October, potentially damaging the department's ability to collect data for this month's report. The longer the shutdown continues, the more reports are likely to be delayed, leaving policymakers in the dark about the economy's current state.

Title: Trump Nominates Heather Nauert, Former Fox News Anchor, as United Nations Ambassador

Article:

President Donald Trump has announced his intention to nominate Heather Nauert, the current State Department spokeswoman and a former Fox News host, as the United States' next ambassador to the United Nations. If confirmed by the Senate, Nauert will replace Nikki Haley, who is set to step down from her post at the end of the year.

Nauert, who joined the State Department in April 2017, has been a prominent figure in the Trump administration, having worked at ABC and Fox News prior to her tenure at the State Department. She has not traveled extensively with her first boss, former Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, and was not particularly close to him. However, with Mike Pompeo now leading the State Department, Nauer has been more active on diplomatic trips.

Nauert's nomination comes amidst some controversy, with critics pointing to a tourist-like Instagram post from Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, during a trip focused on the killing of Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi. There have also been other missteps, such as when Nauert cited D-Day – the Allied invasion of Normandy against the Nazis – as an example of America's strong relationship with Germany.

Despite these criticisms, Nauert has been a staunch defender of President Trump at the podium, a fact that Trump himself has acknowledged. "She's excellent, she's been with us a long time, she's been a supporter for a long time," Trump said of Nauert in November.

The State Department previously held daily briefings, but this has been scaled back to two a week, at most. Nauert, who is 48 years old, has been balancing her job in Washington, D.C. with her family in New York. Before joining the Trump administration, she had no government or foreign policy experience, though she did work on some overseas assignments for ABC, including in Baghdad.

If confirmed by the Senate, Nauert will take over from Nikki Haley, who has been a vocal and influential figure in the United Nations during her tenure. The confirmation process for Nauert's nomination is expected to begin in the coming weeks.

Title: " Addressing the Migrant Caravan Crisis: A Call for Action and Reform"

Article:

In recent times, thousands of migrants from countries such as Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, and other Central and South American nations have embarked on a journey towards the United States, collectively known as a "caravan." This mass migration, often referred to as a "caravan" to avoid the more direct term "invading horde," has become a pressing issue that requires immediate attention and long-term solutions.

The article suggests several strategies to address this issue, focusing on economic incentives and foreign policy adjustments.

Firstly, the article proposes leveraging the economic dependence of Mexico on the United States. By imposing taxes on remittances sent by Mexican nationals living and working in the U.S. legally or illegally, or even stopping these remittances altogether, the U.S. could send a strong message and potentially deter future caravans.

Secondly, the article emphasizes the need for stricter enforcement of immigration laws, particularly in relation to employers hiring illegal immigrants. The proposal is for significant fines for companies that hire undocumented workers, which could make employment opportunities scarce and reduce the incentive for illegal immigration.

Thirdly, the article suggests coupling these employment measures with work requirements for welfare recipients, especially during periods of full employment. This would make it more challenging for illegal immigrants to sustain themselves in the U.S.

The article also calls for a reevaluation of U.S. foreign aid policies, suggesting that aid should be tied to reform efforts in recipient countries. This approach could encourage positive change and potentially discourage mass migration.

Lastly, the article highlights the upcoming Brazilian elections and the potential impact of the election of candidate Jair Bolsonaro, who is running on an anti-corruption platform. The article suggests that the U.S. should support leaders like Bolsonaro who are willing to fight corruption and promote reform within their countries.

In conclusion, the article argues that by implementing a combination of economic disincentives, stricter immigration enforcement, and foreign policy adjustments, the U.S. can deter future caravans and ultimately create a win-win situation for all parties involved, except for political mega-donors and the Democratic Party who may have invested in voter registration efforts for potential amnesty grants.

Title: Senate Races Ahead with Amnesty Bill Amidst Transparency Concerns and Unread Legislation

Article:

In a move reminiscent of the Obamacare debate, the Senate is facing criticism for its approach to the Gang of Eight's 1,200-page amnesty legislation. The bill, which has been merged with the Corker-Hoeven amendment, is set for a vote tomorrow at 5:30 pm. However, the vote is not solely on the amendment but on a procedural motion by Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid to cut off debate on the combined bill, which no senator has had the opportunity to fully read.

Senator Marco Rubio, one of the bill's original sponsors, has expressed his opposition to the rushed process, stating, "I hope that he, and all members who believe in open process, will vote against Majority Leader Reid's motion to silence debate on a bill no one has read." Rubio further challenged the bill's sponsors, urging them to commit to extensive, open debate if they are confident in their proposal.

The amnesty bill, according to Rubio and other critics, lacks sufficient provisions for border security, a concern shared by many Americans. The bill's proponents are being accused of "Pelosi-ing" the amnesty bill, a reference to then-Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi's famous statement that the Affordable Care Act had to be passed to understand what was in it.

Former Alaska Governor Sarah Palin, in an article for Breitbart, has also weighed in on the issue, criticizing the Gang of Eight for their approach to the legislation. The bill, she argues, is similar to the unpopular and unaffordable Obamacare, and is not supported by informed Americans.

The debate over the amnesty bill continues, with the Senate facing criticism for its handling of the legislation and calls for transparency and open debate. The vote tomorrow promises to be a significant moment in the ongoing immigration debate.

Title: President Trump Endorses Grassley's Immigration Bill, Urges Support for Four Pillars of Immigration Reform

Article:

In a recent statement, President Donald Trump has expressed his support for Senator Chuck Grassley's immigration legislation, as the debate over immigration reform continues to unfold in the Senate. The President has urged the Senate to back Grassley's bill and oppose any legislation that does not align with the four pillars of the White House's Immigration Reform and Border Security Framework.

The Grassley bill, also known as the "Secure and Succeed Act," is based on the White House's framework and aims to provide a lasting solution for DACA recipients, end chain migration, cancel the visa lottery, and secure the border through wall construction and closing legal loopholes. The bill, initially introduced by Grassley and Arkansas Senator Tom Cotton, provides a path to citizenship for 1.8 million DACA recipients, includes $25 billion in border security and wall funding, and limits family-based migration while eliminating the diversity visa lottery.

President Trump's statement emphasizes that the Grassley bill is the only legislation on the table that has a chance of becoming law and serves as a workable compromise. The bill's backers argue that it protects nearly two million immigrants while also addressing the security funding that immigration hawks desire.

In addition to Grassley's bill, House Judiciary Chairman Bob Goodlatte and House Homeland Security Committee Chairman Michael McCaul have also introduced immigration legislation that the President says "also enshrines our four pillars." Goodlatte's bill, unveiled last month, takes a tougher stance on illegal immigration enforcement and addresses the future of DACA recipients, allowing beneficiaries to be eligible for 3-year renewable permits to stay in the U.S.

While the Goodlatte bill does not include 35 out of the 70 security points outlined in the Trump administration's immigration wish list sent to Congress in October, it does contain funding for the border wall and aims to end the chain migration system and the visa lottery program. Goodlatte's bill also includes a long-term plan for DACA recipients that outlines a potential path to citizenship while not necessarily favoring DACA recipients over other immigrants seeking citizenship.

President Trump has expressed optimism about the developments in the House and has hailed Goodlatte's bill as a "good starting point" for his administration to accomplish its immigration goals. The President has stated that his focus is now on "enacting responsible and commonsense immigration reform that delivers for the American People."

Title: The Royal Exit: Meghan and Harry's Decision to Step Back from Senior Royal Roles and Its Implications

Article:

The decision of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, to step back from their roles as senior royals and carve out a more independent path has sent shockwaves through the British royal family and beyond. The couple's decision, announced earlier this year, comes amidst a backdrop of a tumultuous relationship with the British press and growing public scrutiny.

The couple's decision to distance themselves from the British royal family, the symbolic heart of a nation with a complex and troubled history, has been met with a mix of surprise and understanding by many, particularly within the black British community. The legacy of Britain's colonial past, marked by its role in the slave trade, the ideologies of racism, and discriminatory policies towards people of color, has left a lasting impact on society.

Meghan's decision to join the royal family, a move that was perplexing to many, has been followed closely by the couple's actions, which some interpret as a rejection of the traditional royal lifestyle and a desire to distance themselves from the negative aspects of the institution. The couple's decision to withhold a title for their son, Archie, and the rumors of a potential relocation to southern Africa, were seen as early indicators of their intention to chart a different course.

In recent months, the couple have opted to bypass official royal channels and engage directly with the press, a departure from the usual royal protocol. This shift was further underscored by Meghan's candid admission in a television documentary that adjusting to royal life was challenging, and Harry's revelation that the tragic death of his mother, Princess Diana, had left him determined to protect his wife and family.

The announcement of their decision to step back from their senior royal roles appears to have taken Buckingham Palace by surprise, signaling a significant break from tradition. As the couple embarks on this new chapter, the implications of their decision will continue to unfold, offering a glimpse into the evolving nature of the British monarchy and its relationship with the public.

Title: UN Imposes Toughest Economic Sanctions on North Korea in Response to Missile Tests

Article:

In a unanimous decision by the United Nations Security Council, new economic sanctions have been imposed on North Korea in response to its recent intercontinental ballistic missile tests. The sanctions, which could reduce the regime's annual export revenue by a third, target key revenue earners such as coal, iron, lead, and seafood, but not oil.

The North Korean government, through the official KCNA news agency, has denounced the sanctions as a "violent violation of our sovereignty" and part of a "heinous plot to isolate and stifle" the country. In a statement, Pyongyang threatened to take "righteous action" and described the sanctions as a crime for which the US would pay "thousands of times" over.

The US Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson, stated on Monday that North Korea should halt missile launches if it wanted to negotiate. He added that the best signal North Korea could give to the US for negotiations would be to stop these missile launches. Tillerson also mentioned that unspecified "other means of communication" were open to Pyongyang.

North Korean Foreign Minister Ri Yong-ho, in a speech at a regional conference, stated that the new sanctions would not force Pyongyang into negotiations over its nuclear and ballistic missile programs. Ri also said that North Korea would not put its nuclear deterrent on the negotiating table and would continue to strengthen its nuclear might.

The White House stated that US President Donald Trump and South Korean President Moon Jae-in agreed that Pyongyang's nuclear and missile programs pose a "grave and growing direct threat" to the US, South Korea, Japan, and most countries around the world. The leaders also agreed to continue applying pressure to North Korea.

Many experts believe that Pyongyang is still some way off being able to mount a miniaturized nuclear warhead on a long-range missile, but the regime now has missiles that are theoretically capable of striking the US mainland. The KCNA alluded to this new capability, stating, "There is no bigger mistake than the United States believing that its land is safe across the ocean."

The new sanctions come as part of an effort to persuade countries attending the Association of Southeast Asian Nations meeting to push Pyongyang to end its nuclear plans.
