Pressure on China, North Korea's main ally and by far its biggest trading partner, to sign up to and enforce more robust sanctions has mounted since the regime conducted two intercontinental ballistic missile tests last month.

China has stated that any punitive actions targeting North Korea must "avoid bringing disaster" to the economically fragile state. In a front-page commentary, the overseas edition of the ruling Communist party's official People's Daily stated that sanctions must be employed with precision, avoiding negative impacts on ordinary people and third countries, and avoiding causing disaster to the country in question's normal and legal trade and business exchanges with the outside world, people's normal lives, and the humanitarian situation.

Title: A Retrospective on the Tenure of Attorney General Eric Holder Jr.: A Mixed Legacy of Groundbreaking Achievements and Controversial Decisions

Article:

In a historic tenure spanning nearly six years, Eric Holder Jr., the first African-American to serve as the United States' top law enforcement official, has left an indelible mark on the nation's legal landscape. His announcement of resignation on Thursday, effective until his successor's confirmation, marks the end of a tenure that was both groundbreaking and contentious.

Holder's tenure was marked by bold and commendable stances on numerous hot-button issues, despite a frequently antagonistic Congress. However, his legacy is not without blemish, particularly in relation to the role the Justice Department played in matters of secrecy and national security under his leadership.

Same-sex Marriage: In 2011, Holder announced that the Justice Department would no longer defend the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), a federal law that defined marriage as between a man and a woman. He declared the law unconstitutional. This decision foreshadowed President Obama's own "evolution" on same-sex marriage the following year and the Supreme Court's 2013 ruling that invalidated a significant part of the law. Since the court's decision, nearly two dozen federal courts have struck down state bans on same-sex marriage across the country, and the Supreme Court has been asked again to rule on whether there is a constitutional right to same-sex marriage—a question it avoided in 2013.

Voting Rights: Under Holder's leadership, the Justice Department successfully fought discriminatory voting restrictions before the 2012 elections. In the wake of the Supreme Court's 2013 decision that gutted the core of the Voting Rights Act, Holder swiftly found new ways to challenge discriminatory laws. Shortly after the ruling, the Justice Department joined lawsuits challenging new restrictions, such as strict voter-ID requirements and cutbacks to voting hours, in North Carolina and Texas. In both states, Republican-controlled legislatures imposed rules that disproportionately affected poorer and minority voters, who tend to vote Democratic.

As Holder steps down, his legacy remains a complex tapestry of groundbreaking achievements and controversial decisions. His tenure will be remembered for his unwavering commitment to civil rights, particularly in the areas of same-sex marriage and voting rights, as well as the role the Justice Department played in matters of secrecy and national security. His departure marks a significant shift in the nation's legal landscape, and it remains to be seen who will continue to carry on his legacy.

Title: Trump Expands on Foreign Policy Stances in Anti-Terrorism Speech, Proposes US-Russia Cooperation Against ISIS

Article:

In a measured and scripted address at a rally in Youngstown, Ohio on Monday, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump outlined his stance on radical Islamic terrorism, emphasizing the threat it poses and proposing a shift in US foreign policy, particularly in relation to Russia and ISIS.

The speech, while quieter in tone, could have significant implications for the campaign, which has been marked by the candidate's unpredictability in recent weeks. Trump, in his speech, reiterated the threat of radical Islamic terrorism and expanded upon some of his most contentious foreign policy statements.

One of the most notable aspects of the speech was Trump's proposal for the US to work with Russia in "coalition operations" to fight ISIS. He acknowledged Russia's own battles with Islamic terror and suggested that their interests in Syria's outcome could be leveraged in the fight against ISIS. This departure from current US policy, which has long insisted on the removal of Syria's embattled president Bashar al-Assad, could potentially mark a significant shift in US-Russia relations.

Another key point in the speech was Trump's emphasis on "extreme vetting" for immigrants and refugees from regions plagued by terrorism. This method, Trump suggested, would involve questioning potential entrants about their beliefs regarding a "tolerant" way of life and agreement with US values on women's rights, the rule of law, and the primacy of the US Constitution.

Critics on social media pointed out that such a test could be easily manipulated, and the process of scrutinizing applicants' social media records would require significant time and effort. The proposal, some argue, seems more a rebranding of Trump's previously proposed temporary ban on the entry of non-citizen Muslims into the US, rather than a departure from it.

Trump also appeared to walk back his previous statement about the US withdrawing from NATO unless other members contributed more to the common defense. He acknowledged NATO's new anti-terrorism initiative and suggested that this could justify the US's continued membership.

Reactions to the speech were mixed. Trump's allies, such as former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani, praised the speech as a demonstration of Trump's presidential capabilities. Critics, however, such as President Obama's former speechwriter Jon Favreau, characterized the speech as a continuation of Trump's dishonesty and incompetence.

The speech serves as a reminder of the stark contrast between the two presidential candidates' foreign policy stances, and the potential implications of their respective policies for US relations with other nations. As the election approaches, the focus on foreign policy will likely remain a key point of contention between the two candidates.

Title: House Democrats Stage 25-Hour Sit-In on Gun Control, Claim Progress Despite Failed Vote

Article:

In a dramatic turn of events, House Democrats staged a 25-hour sit-in on the House floor Thursday, demanding a vote on gun control measures. The sit-in, which began around 11:30 a.m. Wednesday and ended early Thursday afternoon, failed to force a vote, but Democrats claimed they had made "some progress" on the issue.

As House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-WI) decried the protest as a "publicity stunt," Democrats argued they had succeeded in dramatizing the arguments for action to stem gun violence. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) declared, "Just because they cut and run in the dark of night, just because they have left does not mean we are taking no for an answer."

The sit-in, which lasted over 25 hours, came to an end hours after Republicans held a final vote on the Zika response and sent lawmakers home until July 5. The spectacle captured the attention of a Washington gridlocked on guns despite the slaughter in Orlando.

Georgia Rep. John Lewis, who had participated in the civil rights sit-ins in the 1960s, declared Thursday that "some progress" was made in the lawmakers' efforts to get the attention of the nation to recognize the need for a vote on gun control legislation.

Republicans, however, said their colleagues had accomplished nothing other than disrupting the business of the House to score political points. Pressure had been building on both sides of the Capitol in the wake of the shooting rampage at a Florida gay nightclub earlier this month that killed 49 people and injured 53 others.

The agitation for action caused a Senate filibuster last week and led to the chaos on the House floor that lasted well into Thursday. A burst of activity in the middle of the night, including recorded votes on some other issues such as the Zika virus, capped more than 15 straight hours of Democratic protests.

The sit-in had the look of a 1960s-style protest, as some lawmakers sat on the floor, others in their seats. The House chamber grew increasingly chaotic as the night wore on, and some lawmakers took breaks on pillows and blankets.

C-SPAN, a cable and satellite network that provides continual coverage of House and Senate floor proceedings, did not control the cameras. They're run on authorization by legislative leaders. Although the cameras were turned off Wednesday, lawmakers relied on social media to transmit video, using Facebook, Twitter, and Periscope. C-SPAN broadcast live video streamed on Periscope and Facebook from lawmakers' accounts. Democrats posted the Capitol's main telephone number, which was overwhelmed, and urged constituents to call and request a vote. They also encouraged tweeting under the hashtag #NoBillNoBreak.

Title: Trump Delivers Polished Address to Congress, Aims for Bipartisan Cooperation

Article:

In his debut speech to Congress, President Donald Trump awarded himself a C or C+ in terms of messaging, stating that he would give himself a lower grade on communication. However, the polished and optimistic address delivered on Tuesday night may prompt a revision of this self-assessment.

Rep. Michael McCaul (R-TX), chairman of the Homeland Security Committee, described the speech as a "new face" on the president that looked very presidential. The speech, delivered after almost six weeks in office, is seen by Trump supporters as a sign that he is hitting his stride and learning from his early stumbles.

The next phase of Trump's political journey now moves to Congress, where he will embark on the delicate task of trying to pass a budget, and legislation on health care, tax reform, and immigration. Whether this marks a long-awaited pivot toward a more presidential Trump, or a rare night of polished oratory remains to be seen.

While even Democratic lawmakers and commentators agreed that the president showed a new face Tuesday, some offered a caveat: A more effective communicator of an unacceptable agenda makes Trump more dangerous. Embedded in Trump's agenda, Democrats warn, is the threat of mass deportations, the gutting of environmental protections, and the loss of health coverage for millions of newly insured low-income Americans.

For now, Trump is apparently allowing himself to linger in this presidential "moment," and reportedly will not sign a revised travel ban on Wednesday, as planned. The original order, drafted hastily and now on hold, temporarily barred travel to the US by citizens of seven largely Muslim countries and suspended Syrian refugee resettlement.

Trump did not discuss the travel ban in his speech Tuesday, or his reported willingness to allow millions of otherwise law-abiding illegal immigrants to stay in the US and work – a revival of campaign talk of a compromise on immigration.

On its face, the content of Trump's speech contained many of the touchstones of a typical State of the Union address. He spoke of healing and hope, and called for bipartisanship in the name of common national purpose.

And he began by condemning the recent vandalism and threats against Jewish targets, and the shooting of two Indian men in Kansas last week, following criticism that he was slow to speak out against such attacks.

"I am here tonight to deliver a message of unity and strength," Trump said.

The speech was centered on policies that serve his controversial campaign theme of "America first," including a major increase in defense spending, a pull-back from multilateral trade agreements, the border wall, and tax cuts for corporations and the middle class. He expressed support for NATO, but also signaled a retrenchment of America's role on the global stage.

"My job is not to represent the world," Trump said. "My job is to represent the United States of America."

In addition, Trump offered policies that play well across the aisle, such as a call for investment in infrastructure, paid family leave, and guaranteed access to health insurance for those with pre-existing conditions.

The speech won early high marks from the American public, with 7 in 10 Americans who tuned in saying it made them feel more optimistic about the country, according to a CNN poll.

These are early days for the mercurial Trump, and it's anybody's guess as to whether he can keep up the more presidential posture he adopted Tuesday night. All through the campaign, as even supporters and family members urged him to tone down the inflammatory rhetoric, he insisted he could be "presidential."

But he never quite got there, until now. His convention address came across as dark and dystopic; ditto his short inaugural speech, remembered for the phrase "American carnage." Now his supporters have a more positive message to point to.

Republican strategist Ford O'Connell points to a particular moment of "optimism and compassion" in Tuesday's speech: "Everything that is broken in our country can be fixed. Every problem can be solved. And every hurting family can find healing and hope."

Some Democrats weren't particularly moved by Trump's message. Sen. Jeff Merkley (D-OR) dismissed his talk of clean air and water as "empty" words. He was also unimpressed by the president's inclusive language.

"It's just a rehash of everything we've heard before," said Senator Merkley, one of the chamber's most liberal members.

Democrats are in the minority on Capitol Hill, and they have pledged to do everything they can to block a Trump agenda that aims to undo key parts of President Obama's legacy. But Republicans are hopeful.

"Trump's overall goal of the address was to instill in Congress the 'will to govern,' to compromise where possible in an effort to get things done on behalf of the American people," writes Mr. O'Connell in an email. "It's not an easy task in a broken, bipartisan town like Washington, D.C. But on this night, he succeeded."

Title: U.S. Job Growth Slows Down, Unemployment Rate Rises to 8.2 Percent in May

Article:

The U.S. unemployment rate increased from 8.1 percent to 8.2 percent last month as businesses across various sectors reduced their hiring activities, according to a report released by the Labor Department on Friday. Job growth fell significantly to 69,000 during the month, marking the weakest growth in a year, and revisions showed that only 77,000 jobs were created in April, far below the 115,000 previously reported.

The slowdown was observed in numerous industries, with construction, which had seen unusual job gains in the winter due to mild weather, reporting a loss of jobs. The business services sector, a key sector that has created 1.4 million jobs since the end of the recession, lost 1,000 jobs in May. On the positive side, health care, transportation, and wholesaling sectors reported healthy job gains.

Economists attributed the slowdown to a combination of factors, including the possibility of payback after stronger-than-usual hiring earlier in the year due to warmer-than-normal weather in the winter months, as well as potential signs of a fundamental slowdown in the economy that could lead to further increases in the unemployment rate.

The average workweek declined 0.1 hour to 34.4 hours in May, and average hourly wages slumped to a 1.7 percent yearly rate, close to a record low. The rise in unemployment was not only due to the slowdown in job growth but also a surge in people looking for work but unable to find jobs. About 642,000 more people went on a job hunt last month, but only 422,000 of those landed jobs, the department said.

Economists are currently scrambling for an explanation as to why the job market has fallen into a spring slump for the second year in a row. One underlying source of friction, according to Aparna Mathur, economist at the American Enterprise Institute, is the millions of long-term unemployed people who lack the technical skills needed to fill many of the jobs that are coming open, creating a situation where both employers and the unemployed cannot find what they need and want.

The report has sparked a heated political debate, with Republicans criticizing President Obama's economic policies, while the White House Council of Economic Advisers chairman Alan B. Krueger attributed the slowdown to external factors such as the European economic crisis and the spike in gasoline prices this spring.

Title: President Trump Denies Campaign-Russia Connection, Accuses U.S. Intelligence of Leaking Information

Article:

In a series of tweets on Wednesday, President Donald Trump denied reports suggesting his associates had contact with Russian officials during the 2016 presidential campaign, labeling the allegations as "non-sense." The President accused the U.S. intelligence community of illegally leaking information to news outlets.

"This Russian connection non-sense is merely an attempt to cover-up the many mistakes made in Hillary Clinton’s losing campaign," Mr. Trump tweeted. He also claimed that the "real scandal" is that the intelligence community is giving out classified information "like candy."

The President's tweets come after multiple news outlets, including CNN and The New York Times, reported Tuesday that Russian officials were in touch with members of Mr. Trump's team during the campaign. According to CNN, advisers close to Mr. Trump were in "constant communication during the campaign with Russians known to US intelligence."

Among those reportedly communicating with Russian nationals was former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort. Manafort, in response, denied ever knowingly talking to any intelligence official or anyone in Russia regarding matters under investigation.

"I have never had any connection to (Russian President Vladimir) Putin or the Russian government before, during or after the campaign," Manafort told CNN.

Mr. Trump and his team have consistently denied any contacts between the campaign and Russian officials ahead of the November election. The reports come on the heels of the resignation of former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn, who reportedly misled Vice President Mike Pence and others about the nature of his conversations with Russia's ambassador to the U.S. after the November election but before Mr. Trump was sworn into office.

Title: California Primary Election: Clinton and Sanders Battle for Delegates as Unity Concerns Loom

Article:

As the California primary election approaches on Tuesday, the race for Democratic delegates remains uncertain, with Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders vying for the 475 delegates at stake in the Golden State. In a recent interview with CNN's "State of the Union," Clinton expressed confidence in her chances, stating, "I believe, on Tuesday, I will have decisively won the popular vote and I will have decisively won the pledged delegate majority."

However, Sanders' campaign counters that the delegate count and financial resources do not tell the whole story. In a press conference in Los Angeles on Saturday, Sanders stated, "It is extremely unlikely that Secretary Clinton will have the requisite number of pledged delegates to claim victory on Tuesday night." He further predicted that the Democratic National Convention will be a contested convention, with no candidate having enough pledged delegates to secure the nomination outright.

The ongoing competition between the two candidates has raised concerns about the potential impact on Democratic unity ahead of the general election, with the possibility of a significant portion of Sanders supporters refusing to vote for Clinton if she were the nominee. According to a Quinnipiac University poll, 25% of Sanders supporters would not vote for Clinton in a general election matchup against Donald Trump. In California, the USC Dornsife/LA Times poll indicates that Clinton trails Sanders 43% to 44% among registered voters.

As of now, Clinton holds 1,809 delegates and 548 superdelegates, totaling 2,357. To secure the nomination, she needs at least 2,382 delegates. The upcoming Democratic primaries on Tuesday, which include California, New Jersey, the Dakotas, Montana, and New Mexico, will award 694 delegates, including 475 in California.

Sanders has also been campaigning vigorously in California, emphasizing the importance of voter turnout and his momentum in the race. During a rally outside the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum, he told supporters, "If we can win, and win big here in California and in the other states, and in Washington D.C., we are going to go into the Democratic convention with enormous momentum."

The outcome of the California primary and the ensuing contests will significantly shape the Democratic race and the party's unity ahead of the general election.

Title: U.S. Faces Tough Decision on Egypt: Navigating the Complexities of a Military Takeover

Article:

As the political landscape in Egypt continues to shift, President Barack Obama finds himself in a precarious position, facing mounting pressure to clarify the U.S.'s response to the ongoing chaos in Cairo. The administration has so far been reluctant to label the current situation as a coup d'etat, instead opting for cautious statements expressing concern.

With the return of Congress and the Independence Day holiday, the debate over U.S. policy towards Egypt is heating up, blurring traditional partisan and ideological lines. The coalition that once united over the Iraq war is now fractured, with Israel supporters welcoming the ousting of President Mohamed Morsi and his Muslim Brotherhood government, while democracy advocates argue that his removal was an illegitimate overthrow of a democratically elected regime.

The Washington Post and The New York Times have offered contrasting perspectives, with the former criticizing Obama's response as "feckless" and the latter praising his "appropriate caution." Under U.S. law, the $1.3 billion in military aid to Egypt must be suspended if Morsi's ouster and the arrest of his allies are formally declared a coup.

Two emerging camps in Washington are taking shape, each offering a different approach to the Egyptian crisis. One camp, which includes both Republicans and Democrats, argues that the Egyptian military, despite its self-serving culture, is a stabilizing force in the region and a key partner of the U.S. They advocate for maintaining aid to exert influence within the Egyptian power structure and, ideally, to coax the generals back to civilian rule.

House Majority Leader Eric Cantor (R-Va.) is among those in this camp, stating, "The Egyptian military has long been a key partner of the United States and a stabilizing force in the region, and is perhaps the only trusted national institution in Egypt today."

On the other hand, some observers argue that the military takeover may merely return Egypt to its previous state of a bloated and dysfunctional government controlled by a self-serving military elite. However, they contend that the removal of the Muslim Brotherhood from power has partially discredited radical Islam, a significant threat to global peace.

As the situation in Egypt remains fluid, President Obama will need to make a clear choice. His decision will not only impact the future of Egypt but also the broader region and U.S.-Egypt relations. The choice will be a difficult one, as both sides in this complex conflict present their own set of challenges and uncertainties.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Express Frustration Over Debate Format, Rapid-Fire Exchanges

Article:

In the aftermath of the second round of Democratic presidential debates, several candidates, including Joe Biden and Kamala Harris, have expressed frustration with the debate format they believe did not allow for in-depth discussion of policy issues.

The debates, which took place in Detroit on July 30 and 31, featured ten candidates each night, a crowded field that has led to rapid-fire exchanges. This format, according to the candidates, did not provide ample time for each candidate to explain their views, leading to sound-bite-oriented discussions.

U.S. Senator Kamala Harris, who faced a series of attacks on her record during Wednesday's debate, stated, "It can be a frustrating process. There are so many of these issues that can not be captured in 60 seconds." Harris, a U.S. senator from California, added, "It is a process that is conducive to sound bites."

Former Vice President Joe Biden, the Democratic front-runner, who was also a target of attacks over healthcare, immigration, and criminal justice reform, echoed Harris' sentiments. "That's not a debate," Biden said. "I understand why it has to be that way, but I'm looking forward to getting to a place where we can actually exchange ideas."

The Democratic National Committee has doubled the fundraising and polling requirements to qualify for participation in an effort to reduce the number of candidates on stage for the next debate, which is not until September.

Both Biden and Harris acknowledged that they were not surprised to be the target of attacks from all directions during the debate. Harris stated, "If you're considered a front-runner, you should be prepared to take a hit." Biden added, "This, going back 10, 20, or 30 years, is just a game to make sure we hand the Republicans an election."

The candidates' clashes, particularly between Biden and Harris over their healthcare plans, have been a topic of discussion. Harris criticized Biden for leaving too many people uninsured under his proposal, while Biden ridiculed the idea that Harris' plan would not require a middle-class tax hike.

Cory Booker, a U.S. senator from New Jersey who clashed with Biden on criminal justice records, expressed optimism about the primary debates, stating, "We may be having a primary debate right now, but we know we are going to close ranks behind the candidate."

Title: Moore Denies Sexual Misconduct Allegations, Accuses Washington Post of Political Agenda

Article:

In a defiant response to the allegations made by The Washington Post, embattled Alabama Republican Senate nominee Roy Moore has accused the newspaper of having a "political agenda." During a campaign appearance in Birmingham on Saturday, Moore stated, "In the next few days, there will be revelations about the motivation and the content of this article."

Moore, a former chief justice of Alabama's Supreme Court and a staunch social conservative, has been accused of pursuing relationships with four teenage women dating back to the 1970s when he was in his early thirties and single. The Washington Post reported on Thursday that one woman claimed she was 14 when the 32-year-old Moore asked her out and made sexual advances.

In response to the allegations, Moore admitted on Sean Hannity's radio show that "after my return from the military, I dated a lot of young ladies." However, during his Saturday appearance, Moore insisted the accusations about his conduct "nearly 40 years ago" are "completely false and untrue."

"I have not been guilty of sexual misconduct with anyone," Moore said.

The allegations have caused significant damage to Moore's campaign ahead of next month's special election for the seat once held by Attorney General Jeff Sessions. Top Republicans, including President Trump, Vice President Mike Pence, and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, have called for Moore to drop out of the race if the allegations are true. However, Moore has shown no sign of doing so.

Moore also accused The Washington Post, which has endorsed his Democratic opponent Doug Jones, of "yet another attack on my character and reputation in a desperate attempt to stop my political campaign for United States Senate."

The story has sparked talk of possible write-in campaigns from other Republicans, though nothing has yet materialized. On Saturday, President Trump, who has been traveling in Asia over the past week, did not seem interested in commenting further on the situation, stating he's been too busy reading documents and has not had time to catch up on television news coverage about Moore.

Title: Washington Post Apologizes for Controversial Cartoon Depicting Sen. Ted Cruz's Children

Article:

In a swift response to public outcry, The Washington Post has removed a controversial cartoon by Ann Telnaes, the paper's editorial cartoonist, that depicted Senator Ted Cruz (R-Texas) and his two daughters. The cartoon, which was published earlier this week, sparked a wave of criticism from both Cruz and his fellow Republican presidential candidate, Senator Marco Rubio (R-Florida), as well as a fundraising appeal from the Cruz campaign.

The cartoon, which has since been taken down, depicted Cruz dressed as Santa Claus accompanied by his two daughters, who were dressed in red outfits and appeared to be attached to strings, as Cruz put it. Cruz, who spent his 45th birthday Tuesday campaigning across several SEC primary states, responded swiftly to the Washington Post cartoon on Twitter, calling it "classy" and stating that the newspaper was attacking his girls, who are "out of your league."

Rubio later tweeted his own disgust for the newspaper and support for Cruz, stating that the cartoon featuring Cruz's children was "disgusting" and that The Post's statement that the kids are "fair game" was even worse.

The Cruz campaign was quick to turn the cartoon into a fundraising appeal to supporters, characterizing it as an attack on Cruz and his family from the "liberal media." The first line of the email from Cruz, which includes a screen grab of the cartoon, reads, "I'm sickened... I knew I'd be facing attacks from day one of my campaign but I never expected anything like this."

In response to the backlash, The Washington Post's editorial page editor, Fred Hiatt, issued an editor's note stating, "It's generally been the policy of our editorial section to leave children out of it. I failed to look at this cartoon before it was published. I understand why Ann thought an exception to the policy was warranted in this case, but I do not agree."

The headline of the original article still stands, reading, "Ted Cruz uses his kids as political props (updated with statement)," but the cartoon has been replaced with the editor's note. The Washington Post has not issued a formal apology to Cruz or his family.

Title: "The Road to Herd Immunity: Cautious Optimism and the Pursuit of a Coronavirus Vaccine"

The global race to develop a coronavirus vaccine is in full swing, with over 100 potential candidates in various stages of development. The U.S., spearheaded by the Trump administration's "Operation Warp Speed," aims to have millions of doses available by the end of the year. However, experts caution that a game-changing vaccine may not be just a few months away, and preparations for a long-term response are equally crucial.

Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation's top infectious disease expert, expressed "cautious optimism" that a vaccine could be ready by early 2021. To achieve herd immunity, experts estimate that about 70 percent of the population must develop immunity, either through vaccination or recovery from the virus. The alternative—waiting for natural infections to build herd immunity—could lead to millions of deaths, epidemiologists warn.

While promising progress is being made on several vaccine candidates, there are valid reasons to remain skeptical of a vaccine being available in a matter of months. Developing a vaccine in such a short timeframe would break the current record of four years for the fastest vaccine ever developed. Even if this milestone is achieved, drug companies will still need to produce hundreds of millions of doses and distribute them efficiently.

Some experts worry about investing too heavily in a best-case scenario, suggesting that a more prudent approach would be to focus on developing effective systems for testing, tracing, and therapeutic medicines that can last as long as they're needed. There is also concern that the idea of a vaccine being imminent may be hindering the implementation of necessary virus mitigation measures in the present.

Rushing development could increase the risk of an unsafe vaccine reaching the market first, which may exacerbate anti-vaccine sentiment among the public and undermine herd immunity. Additionally, any setbacks could further delay the vaccine's availability, and there is a possibility that any new vaccine may not be entirely effective or may provide immunity for a limited period.

As Dr. Fauci stated, "An approved coronavirus vaccine won't do any good if people aren't willing to roll up their sleeves for it." A vaccine won't be a magic solution, but it remains the best path out of the pandemic. In the words of Caroline Chen from ProPublica, "There's much to be hopeful about, and enormous challenges lie ahead."

Title: Former College Interns Reflect on Personal Growth and Political Evolution in Shared Journey

Article:

In an intimate conversation, two former college interns, Lindsey and Annie, reminisce about their shared journey of personal growth and political evolution during their time in Washington D.C. The duo, who hail from the University of Oklahoma, discuss their political leanings, the impact of feminism, and the importance of self-discovery in their formative years.

Lindsey, who was once a self-proclaimed Republican, shares her experiences growing up in a socially liberal, fiscally conservative household. She explains that her political affiliation has shifted over time, but her core values remain unchanged. Annie, on the other hand, maintains a strong connection to the Democratic Party, a bond forged by her family's political beliefs.

The turning point in their relationship came when Lindsey, initially skeptical of feminism, was enlightened by Annie's explanation of the movement's importance. Lindsey admits to having a misguided understanding of feminism, believing it to be a system that catered to women without merit. However, through conversations with Annie and her peers, Lindsey came to understand the uneven playing field and the importance of feminism in advocating for equal treatment and opportunities for women.

Annie, in turn, credits Lindsey for teaching her the value of self-confidence and the importance of embracing her womanhood. Annie recalls feeling insecure and ashamed, while Lindsey exuded a level of self-assuredness that was foreign to her. Lindsey, in her own words, taught Annie that her body and sexuality should be celebrated, not hidden or ashamed.

The duo's shared journey serves as a testament to the power of open dialogue, self-discovery, and the transformative impact of feminism. Their story underscores the importance of understanding and respecting differing viewpoints, while also highlighting the role models that can shape and empower individuals during their formative years.

Title: U.S. Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg Laments Partisanship, Expresses Hope for Bipartisan Cooperation

Article:

In a talk at Stanford University on Monday, U.S. Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg voiced her concerns over the current partisanship in Congress, expressing a hope that it would return to an era where it worked for the good of the country and not just along party lines. Ginsburg refrained from commenting on the nomination of Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court seat vacated by the late Justice Antonin Scalia, as well as President Donald Trump's travel ban, which could potentially be heard by the high court.

During the discussion, Ginsburg did express a desire to change the Electoral College, a comment that was met with applause from the packed church. She did not elaborate on her reasons for this desire.

Ginsburg had previously stated during the presidential campaign that she presumed Democrat Hillary Clinton would win and would have the opportunity to make a few appointments to the court. She had also called Trump a "faker" with an "ego" in one interview.

On Monday, Ginsburg recalled receiving bipartisan support for her nomination to the U.S. Supreme Court, stating that Republican Sen. Orrin Hatch was her most ardent supporter. "I think today he wouldn't touch me with a 10-foot pole," she joked.

Ginsburg's talk was billed as an exploration of what it means to lead a meaningful life. The discussion took place after Trump last week nominated Gorsuch to the Supreme Court, a nomination that would likely restore the court's conservative tilt.

As the leader of the court's liberal wing and the oldest justice on the court, Ginsburg's health and future impact on the court has been a topic of concern among liberals. With Trump's potential opportunity to replace her or any of the other liberal judges on the bench, her supporters have joked about steps she could take to stay healthy, such as eating more kale.

When asked by a Stanford student who else should eat more kale in Washington, D.C., the justice quipped, "Justice Kennedy." Anthony Kennedy, 80, is the second oldest justice on the Supreme Court and is considered a swing vote.

Ginsburg has shown no signs of slowing down and has said she has a personal trainer who leads her through hour-long workouts that include push-ups and weights. She emphasized the importance of family in her life and expressed a resilient attitude, stating, "The attitude is I'm going to surmount this whatever it is."

Title: Supreme Court Ruling Leaves FCC Free to Modify Indecency Policy, Protecting Children from Broadcast Content

Article:

In a unanimous decision, the Supreme Court has ruled in favor of the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) in the indecency case FCC vs. Fox Television Stations, leaving the door open for the FCC to modify its current policy regarding profanity and nudity on television. The ruling, however, does not determine whether the FCC's indecency rules violate the First Amendment.

The court's decision avoids the central question of whether the FCC's indecency rules, which police passing profanity or fleeting glimpses of nudity on air, infringe on the First Amendment. Instead, the court ruled 8-0 that the FCC ran afoul of due process by failing to give the networks fair notice that they had broken the rules, thus letting them off the hook from paying steep fines.

The ruling leaves the FCC "free to modify its current indecency policy in light of its determination of the public interest and applicable legal requirements," according to Justice Anthony Kennedy. The courts, Kennedy added, are also free to review the current policy or any modified policy.

FCC commissioners are now reviewing the decision, with Chairman Julius Genachowski remaining noncommittal about the panel's next steps. In a statement, Genachowski said the commission is reviewing the decision, which appears to be narrowly limited to procedural issues related to actions taken a number of years ago. However, he also assured lawmakers that the FCC will continue to protect young TV viewers in line with the First Amendment principles.

Lawmakers from both parties have expressed support for the continuation of broadcast regulations. "The decision leaves in place the FCC's authority to protect children from indecent programming," said Sen. Jay Rockefeller (D-W.Va.), chairman of the commerce committee. "This is a victory for those of us who believe that we must be doing more, not less, to give the FCC and parents all across America the resources they need to protect their children from indecent programming."

The ruling means Fox and ABC won't have to worry about FCC fines and sanctions in their cases, and it signals that the FCC should go back to the drawing board to tweak its policy. "This is great for the parties, both Fox and ABC; they're done. The commission sanctions are no more," said broadcast attorney Jack Goodman. "In terms of the issue of whether the commission can continue to have an indecency policy at all and whether that indecency policy is constitutional as established, [those] are left for another day."

The case stems from a series of court findings sparked by the FCC's decision to change the indecency rules following rock star Bono's impromptu utterance during his acceptance speech at the 2003 Golden Globe Awards on NBC. During the broadcast, Bono said, "This is really, really f---ing brilliant." The FCC decided in 2004 that broadcasters could be fined for airing a "fleeting expletive." Since the commission changed its rules, it decided not to fine NBC at the time.

Title: U.S. Stock Markets Reach New Highs Amid Easing Trade Tensions and Strong Global Equity Markets

The U.S. stock benchmarks reached new highs on Thursday, with the S&P 500 Index, Dow Jones Industrial Average, and MSCI Emerging Market Index all posting significant gains. The positive movement in the markets was driven by news from China about potential tariff and currency moves that could ease trade tensions.

The S&P 500 Index soared to a record close, led by the technology, health-care, and financial sectors. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also reached a new pinnacle, with 28 of 30 constituents flashing green. Most European and Asian shares also gained, indicating a positive trend in global equity markets.

Trade conflicts that had stocks gyrating earlier in the week have since cooled off. China is reportedly planning to cut the average tariff rate it charges on imports from the majority of its trading partners as soon as next month. On Wednesday, Premier Li Keqiang stated that China's government would not devalue the currency in order to boost its exports amid the trade war.

The yield on 10-year Treasuries held above 3 percent, near its high for the year. The greenback weakened after a report suggested that the U.S. and Canada are unlikely to reach a deal on NAFTA in Washington this week. Jobless data was solid but did little to change the mood. The pound surged after August retail sales came in higher than expected.

Equity markets have so far remained resilient in the face of rising bond yields, suggesting investors are comfortable with the outlook for corporate earnings and global growth even as borrowing costs rise along with trade tensions. Ahead of the Fed meeting next week, some other central banks, such as Norway's policy makers, raised interest rates for the first time in seven years, while the SNB kept deposit rates unchanged.

Elsewhere, emerging-market assets continued to rally off the lows seen earlier this month, with the rand among the leading developing-world currencies as the South African Reserve Bank held its key interest rate at a two-year low. Norway's krone retreated as investors saw the central bank's rate trajectory as dovish, while the Swiss franc strengthened.

West Texas crude dropped after U.S. President Donald Trump resumed his criticism of OPEC on Twitter. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies meet in Algiers this weekend. The ███ Dollar Spot Index decreased 0.4 percent to the lowest in eight weeks, while the Japanese yen sank 0.1 percent to 112.41 per dollar. The yield on 10-year Treasuries rose less than one basis point to 3.07 percent, the highest in more than four months.

Germany's 10-year yield decreased two basis points to 0.47 percent, while Britain's 10-year yield fell two basis points to 1.585 percent. The ███ Commodity Index rose 0.6 percent, approaching a six-week high. West Texas Intermediate crude fell 0.4 percent to $70.80 a barrel, and LME copper fell 0.6 percent to $6,082.00 a metric ton.

Title: Israeli Government Blocks U.S. Reps. Tlaib and Omar: A Controversial Decision Amidst Boycott Concerns

Article:

Israeli officials have decided to block U.S. Reps. Rashida Tlaib and Ilhan Omar from entering the country as part of a planned visit, a reversal that comes amid pressure from President Trump and concerns about their support for boycotts of Israel. The move has sparked a significant outcry from Democratic lawmakers in Washington, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi calling it a "sign of weakness" and Omar accusing Israel of implementing "Trump’s Muslim ban."

The Israeli government defended the decision, suggesting that the lawmakers had ulterior motives with their planned trip. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, explaining the decision at length on his office's Twitter account, said that Tlaib and Omar's itinerary "revealed that they planned a visit whose sole objective is to strengthen the boycott against us and deny Israel's legitimacy."

Netanyahu pointed out that the Palestinian organization that planned the visit, MIFTAH, supports the boycott movement, and that people associated with the group have supported terror against Israel in the past. He also noted that the congresswomen were not interested in meeting with Israeli officials.

The decision was made by Interior Minister Arye Deri and announced earlier Thursday by deputy foreign minister Tzipi Hotovely, despite prior assurances that the congresswomen would be allowed in. "Israel has decided — we won’t enable the members of Congress to enter the country," Hotovely told public broadcaster Kan. "We won’t allow those who deny our right to exist in this world to enter Israel."

Omar and Tlaib were among 17 members of Congress who voted against a resolution condemning the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions (BDS) movement in July. This was after Omar introduced a resolution of her own that encouraged the use of boycotts as a political tool.

Netanyahu confirmed that Deri would consider permitting Tlaib to visit her Palestinian family members if she filed a humanitarian request and promised not to promote boycotts of Israel while she visits.

President Trump cheered the decision, tweeting, "Representatives Omar and Tlaib are the face of the Democrat Party, and they HATE Israel!" This, after he publicly pressured Israel to stand firm in blocking Omar and Tlaib amid earlier reports that the government was considering doing so.

While the U.S. ambassador to Israel put out a statement of support for the decision, Democratic lawmakers and even Israel's Washington allies were critical. Notably, pro-Israel lobby AIPAC tweeted that while they disagree with Omar and Tlaib's positions, "We also believe every member of Congress should be able to visit and experience our democratic ally Israel firsthand."

Democratic lawmakers expressed strong opposition to keeping Omar and Tlaib out. "Banning Congresswomen Omar and Tlaib from entering Israel and Palestine is a sign of enormous disrespect to these elected leaders, to the United States Congress, and to the principles of democracy," presidential hopeful Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., said in a tweet. "The Israeli government should reverse this decision and allow them in."

Another presidential candidate, Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., weighed in before the decision was formally announced. "Israel doesn't advance its case as a tolerant democracy or unwavering US ally by barring elected members of Congress from visiting because of their political views," Warren tweeted, saying it would be "shameful" and "unprecedented."

The Jerusalem Post reported Thursday that Netanyahu met Wednesday with Deri, Foreign Minister Israel Katz, Public Security Minister Gilad Erdan, National Security Council leader Meir Ben-Shabbat, and Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit to discuss the matter.

Before the formal denial, Israeli Channel 13's Barak Ravid reported, according to officials, that Netanyahu had been considering allowing Tlaib and Omar to enter Israel, but only to travel within the territories controlled by the Palestinian Authority. Tlaib and Omar had been scheduled to arrive in Israel on Friday.

Title: FDA Launches Criminal Probe into Vaping-Related Illness Outbreak as Cases and Deaths Continue to Rise

Article:

The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has launched a criminal investigation into the recent surge of vaping-related illnesses, which has reached 530 cases across 38 states and one territory as of September 17, according to a report by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) on Thursday. This represents a significant increase from the 380 cases reported last week.

The CDC reported Thursday morning that seven deaths resulting from vaping-related illness have been confirmed in six states, with more expected. By Thursday evening, the Missouri Department of Health confirmed the first death in Missouri, making it the eighth nationwide.

"We are in desperate need of facts," said Mitch Zeller, director of the FDA's Center for Tobacco Products. Zeller clarified that the criminal probe will not focus on personal use of vaping-related products but will instead investigate the products themselves, their sources, and their usage.

The cause of the outbreak remains elusive, with no consistent product, substance, or brand identified in all cases. Most, but not all, patients reported a history of using e-cigarette products containing THC, a psychoactive chemical found in cannabis.

The FDA has collected over 150 vaping product samples for forensic analysis, testing them for traces of nicotine, THC, and other cannabinoids, opioids, cutting agents, additives, pesticides, poisons, toxins, and more. While vitamin E acetate has been found in some of the FDA's lab samples, no singular compound has been identified in all the samples.

Officials continue to warn consumers against purchasing vapes off the street or modifying vape products. "People are dying," said Dr. Anne Schuchat, principal deputy director at CDC. "We ask you to take these recommendations seriously."

Of the reported cases, about three-fourths of those diagnosed with an illness have been male, slightly over-representative of males in the general vaping population. Young people have been particularly affected, with more than half of those who have gotten sick being under 25, and 2 out of 3 cases being people between 18 and 34 years old.

In an effort to crack the case, Illinois health officials are turning to the public for help. "We are asking Illinois residents who have recently vaped to fill out an online, anonymous survey regarding their vaping habits," said Dr. Jennifer Layden, chief medical officer and state epidemiologist for the Illinois Department of Public Health. No personal information will be collected in the survey, which is being advertised through social media.

As e-cigarette maker Juul faces lawsuits across the country, politicians, businesses, and individuals are taking action against the vaping industry. On Thursday, U.S. Reps. Diana DeGette (D-CO), Raja Krishnamoorthi (D-IL), and Peter King (R-NY) announced the formation of a new congressional caucus aimed at curbing the nation's teen-vaping epidemic.

Last week, President Donald Trump announced plans to ban the sale of flavored vaping products in an effort to discourage young people from using e-cigarettes. Michigan became the first state to ban sales of flavored e-cigarettes in stores and online, citing health concerns related to vaping. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo called for a ban a week later, and other cities are now considering similar measures.

CBS, WarnerMedia, and Viacom announced this week that they will no longer run advertisements for e-cigarettes on their networks. Many young people who previously vaped are taking to social media to warn their peers about the dangers of e-cigarettes, with Miami teen Chance Ammirata, who was hospitalized with a vaping-related illness, posting about his journey with the hashtag "#lunglove."

"The fight has just begun," Ammirata said in a recent post.

Title: European Military Observers Detained in Ukraine May Be Released in Prisoner Swap, Insurgency Leader Says

A pro-Russian insurgency leader in eastern Ukraine has suggested that a team of European military observers, currently detained and suspected of being NATO spies, could be released in exchange for jailed pro-Russian activists. Vyacheslav Ponomarev, self-proclaimed people's mayor of Slovyansk, a city 90 miles west of Russia, described the detained observers as "captives."

According to the Associated Press, Ponomarev stated, "As we found maps on them containing information about the location of our checkpoints, we get the impression that they are officers carrying out a certain spying mission."

Ukraine's state security service issued a statement Saturday claiming that "the official representatives of the OSCE are being held in inhuman conditions" and that "among those detained is a person who needs immediate medical help," according to Russia Today.

The German-led, eight-member team was traveling under the auspices of the Organization of Security and Cooperation in Europe when they were detained. Germany's Defense Ministry said it had lost contact with the team, which included five Ukrainians.

Tim Guldimann, OSCE's special envoy for Ukraine, told German public radio WDR on Saturday that "efforts are being made to solve this issue." He declined to elaborate.

Meanwhile, Ukraine's acting prime minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk met with Pope Francis at the Vatican, but escalating Ukrainian-Russian tensions prompted him to return home instead of staying for the canonization ceremony on Sunday.

Francis gave Yatsenyuk a fountain pen, telling him, "I hope that you write 'peace' with this pen."

In a joint statement released Friday night by the White House, the United States and other nations in the Group of Seven agreed to "move swiftly" to impose additional economic sanctions on Russia in response to its actions in Ukraine. The G-7 nations say they will act urgently to intensify "targeted sanctions." The statement also says the G-7 will continue to prepare broader sanctions on key Russian economic sectors if Moscow takes more aggressive action. The White House says U.S. sanctions could be levied as early as Monday.

Title: FBI Investigates "Targeted Attack" on U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) Offices in Texas

Article:

- The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has classified the shooting incident at the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) offices in San Antonio, Texas, as a "targeted attack" against federal employees.
- The shooting occurred at around 03:00 local time (08:00 GMT) on Tuesday, with several shots fired at the ICE offices and two neighboring buildings.
- According to the FBI, no injuries were reported, and the incident involved shots being fired at the offices on two different floors. The FBI is currently reviewing surveillance footage as part of its investigation.
- ICE has blamed the shootings on "political rhetoric" and "misinformation" about the Trump administration's detention policies.
- Daniel Bible, ICE's director for San Antonio, stated that the shootings "shroud our critical law enforcement function and unnecessarily put our officers' safety at risk."
- Christopher Combs, head of the FBI's San Antonio operations, described the shootings as "cowardly, brazen, violent acts" and said those responsible "did some research" because they "knew what floors ICE was on, and they hit those."
- Bullet holes can be seen in several windows at the buildings located near Brookhaven Drive, north-east San Antonio. A picture tweeted by Ken Cuccinelli, acting head of Citizenship and Immigration Services, shows a bullet hole in a window at one of the offices targeted.
- The building is mainly used for executive and administrative purposes, ICE said.
- According to the Washington Examiner, the shooting is the latest of four recent attacks at ICE facilities across the country. The three previous incidents happened in Washington DC, Tacoma, Washington, and Aurora, Colorado, within days of each other in July.
- Given the current climate, FBI investigators fear there could be more attacks. "We can not allow political discourse to lead us to the point of violence, where federal employees, innocent people doing their jobs, are put in harm's way," Mr. Combs said.

Title: Bernie Sanders Vows to Concede if Biden Secures Plurality of Delegates Ahead of Democratic National Convention

Article:

In a significant development for the Democratic primary race, Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) has announced that he will drop out of the race if, by the time of the Democratic National Convention, former Vice President Joe Biden has a plurality of delegates.

The Democratic primary candidates need a majority (1,991 delegates) to secure the nomination. Projections have shown throughout the primary so far that there is a significant chance that no candidate will get that many. If no candidate gets a majority, the primary goes to a second ballot. Superdelegates, who make up about 15% of all delegates, can vote on the second ballot. Superdelegates include major elected officials, former presidents or vice presidents, and prominent members of the Democratic National Committee.

Sanders' decision to concede the nomination to Biden, even if Biden only has a plurality rather than a majority of delegates, is a move aimed at avoiding a contested convention. Sanders stated, "I think it would be a real, real disaster for the Democratic Party" if a contested convention were to occur. "People would say 'the person who won the most votes didn't get selected.' Not a good idea," Sanders added.

This decision could be seen as Sanders sticking to his dislike of superdelegates and his loyalty to the will of the people. However, it is more likely that Sanders is trying to set a standard for the convention that he hopes Biden will follow if Sanders enters the convention with a plurality.

Currently, Biden has 596 delegates, while Sanders has 531. Biden has gained momentum in the past seven days, winning 581 of his 596 delegates with big wins in South Carolina and on Super Tuesday. If Biden enters the convention with a plurality and Sanders pushes it to the second ballot, Biden would likely win most of the superdelegates and get the nomination anyway because he is the establishment candidate. Sanders conceding would just make that process easier.

However, if Sanders, who is openly hostile to the Democratic establishment, enters with a plurality and Biden pushes it to a second ballot, there is a significant chance that Sanders will have the nomination taken from him. The race for the Democratic nomination is heating up, and the outcome remains uncertain.

Title: Bernie Sanders Outlines Democratic Socialism Ideology, Emphasizing Human Rights in CNN Town Hall Speech

Article:

In a CNN town hall event on Monday night, Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders outlined his vision of democratic socialism, emphasizing the importance of human rights, including a living wage and free college tuition for all Americans.

During the event, moderated by CNN's Wolf Blitzer, Sanders was asked to respond to President Trump's repeated attacks on socialism. Trump, in his State of the Union address earlier this month, declared that "America will never be a socialist country."

Sanders responded by stating that the country is moving in that direction whether the president likes it or not. "If I am elected president, we will have a nation in which all people will have health care as a right, whether Trump likes it or not," the senator said. "We are going to make public colleges and universities tuition-free. We are going to raise the minimum wage to a living wage of at least $15 an hour."

Sanders also addressed climate change, stating that it is a disgrace and an embarrassment that the United States has a president who rejects science and does not understand that climate change is real and caused by human activity.

During the Q&A, a woman in the audience asked Sanders to explain why democratic socialism is preferable to capitalism. Sanders explained that while the United States prides itself on political rights, there are no economic guarantees.

"We don't have guarantees regarding economic rights," he said. "We've got to understand that everybody needs a decent paying job, that people need health care, that people need an education... These are not radical ideas."

Sanders added that democratic socialism means having a civilized society with the understanding that we can make sure that all of our people live in security and in dignity. "So what democratic socialism means to me is having a nation in which all people have the right to a living wage, to health care, to education, and to a healthy and habitable planet," he concluded.

Title: Cruz and Kasich Announce Strategic Partnership to Block Trump's Path to Nomination

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Republican presidential candidates Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas and Ohio Gov. John Kasich announced a strategic partnership on Sunday, a move that both candidates had previously sworn off: an official alliance. The two candidates have agreed to divide some of the remaining primary states, avoiding competition in three states.

Senator Cruz, for instance, largely avoided campaigning in New York, where polls showed he was trailing Trump in the run-up to the April 19 primary, and instead focused on California. Governor Kasich, on the other hand, cut his losses in the South, campaigning in Vermont and Massachusetts instead, where he had better poll numbers, in the week before South Carolina's primary.

This Sunday's announcement marks a new political twist. Both Cruz and Kasich released formal statements to share their strategy with American voters. According to Kasich's campaign, "Keeping Trump from winning a plurality in Indiana is critical to keeping him under 1,237 bound delegates before Cleveland," where the Republican National Convention will be held July 18-21. "We are very comfortable with our delegate position in Indiana already, and given the current dynamics of the primary there, we will shift our campaign’s resources West and give the Cruz campaign a clear path in Indiana."

Cruz and Kasich have been fighting for the #NeverTrump vote since the field shrunk to three candidates last month. However, Cruz was initially fighting for a conventional nomination, while Kasich has long banked on a contested convention. Now, after the probability of a Cruz pre-convention was shrunk to nearly nil by the New York primary, the two candidates share the same #NeverTrump goal: block Trump from reaching 1,237 delegates before the Republican National Convention in July.

"Having Donald Trump at the top of the ticket in November would be a sure disaster for Republicans," said Cruz's campaign manager Jeff Roe in a statement Sunday. "To ensure that we nominate a Republican who can unify the Republican Party and win in November, our campaign will focus its time and resources in Indiana and in turn clear the path for Gov. Kasich to compete in Oregon and New Mexico, and we would hope that allies of both campaigns would follow our lead."

Trump, in response, tweeted, "Lyin' Ted and Kasich are going to collude in order to keep me from getting the Republican nomination. DESPERATION!" and "Lyin' Ted and Kasich are mathematically dead and totally desperate. Their donors & special interest groups are not happy with them. Sad!"

While Cruz and Kasich's strategy is surprising and a first for modern presidential elections, their specific allocation of Indiana, Oregon, and New Mexico might be perplexing. The choice of these three states can't be defended by primary dates. Five Northeastern states hold primaries on Tuesday. Indiana's Republican primary is on May 3, followed by Nebraska and West Virginia before Oregon's primary on May 17. And New Mexico's primary occurs on the last primary voting day for Republicans, June 7.

These three states are not exactly rich with delegates. Indiana has 57 delegates up for grabs, which is not insubstantial but is also less than Pennsylvania's 71 the week before. And on Kasich's end of the agreement, he is looking to gain Oregon's 28 delegates and New Mexico's 24. Of the five GOP primaries on June 7, New Mexico has the least amount of delegates, led by California's 172 delegates and New Jersey's 51.

Instead, the Cruz-Kasich alliance highlights the importance of Indiana. This late in the race, with Trump so close to 1,237, Indiana's 57 delegates could be a game changer. A Cruz win in Indiana is the best prospect for a contested convention.

"[Indiana] is likely to be the biggest battleground in coming weeks, given both the closeness of the race and the huge haul of delegates," explains Politico's Shane Goldmacher last week. "If Trump is to get to 1,237 delegates, he would likely need to win Indiana. Without it, his best mathematical alternative would be either to flip a likely Cruz state – Montana or South Dakota – or to sweep almost all 172 of California's delegates, a tall task."

Despite a polling blackout in Indiana due to a state law that prohibits automated polling, it's looking like a good state for Cruz. The Upshot's demographic-based model has Cruz leading Trump 43 to 40 percent with Kasich trailing at 16 percent. And two anonymous polling groups told Politico last week that Cruz and Trump were in a statistical tie, both with 32 percent. Giving Oregon to Kasich also makes sense for the #NeverTrump duo, as early polls predict Kasich winning that primary over Cruz and Trump.

"It may sound strange, but when you start gaming out the rest of the primary contest, it's hard to avoid the conclusion that [Trump's] quest to reach a majority of delegates before the convention could all turn on Indiana," adds The New York Times' Nate Cohn. "If you divvy up the states by expected results, Mr. Trump wins big in the East and West Virginia, loses the winner-take-all rural Western states, and earns his expected share of proportional delegates in Washington, Oregon, and New Mexico."

This puts Trump 175 delegates short of the nomination. If Kasich needs a contested convention for a chance to win the presidential election, and Cruz winning Indiana is the best chance for a contested convention, then giving Indiana to Cruz is the best option for both sides of the #NeverTrump fight.

Title: President Obama Kicks Off Fiscal Cliff Discussions with Labor Leaders, Aims to Leverage Election Victory for Policy Shaping

Article:

In a bid to steer clear of the looming "fiscal cliff," President Barack Obama convened with labor leaders at the White House on Tuesday. This meeting marks the first of many sessions aimed at avoiding automatic tax increases and spending cuts set to take effect at the start of the new year.

The meeting comes a week after Obama's re-election, demonstrating the President's commitment to translating his electoral success into policy-shaping influence. The 62 million Americans who voted to re-elect Obama in 2012 have a clear understanding of his policy objectives, particularly his stance on raising taxes for the wealthiest Americans.

During the 2012 election, Obama's desire to increase taxes for the wealthy was a recurring theme, whether in stalled budget talks with congressional Republicans or during the lengthy presidential campaign. In his victory speech, Obama highlighted the public's support for his approach, stating, "We found out that the majority of Americans agree with my approach."

Exit polls revealed that 60% of voters believe income taxes should increase, either for the wealthiest Americans or for all. This includes 40% of voters who supported Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney.

Former White House Chief of Staff Rahm Emanuel, now the mayor of Chicago, believes lawmakers should heed these numbers. At Obama's victory celebration last week, Emanuel suggested that the election results could pave the way for the kind of compromise President Clinton achieved with a Republican Congress when he was re-elected in 1996.

Republican House Speaker John Boehner has shown some willingness to collect more tax revenue from the wealthy, provided it can be done without raising tax rates. Obama has expressed encouragement over Boehner's newfound flexibility, but he is not passively waiting for congressional Republicans to align with the majority of voters.

Obama has emphasized the importance of public pressure in moving a reluctant Congress. He suggested he might turn to the public more frequently in the future to exert this pressure. However, Obama acknowledged the challenges in maintaining public focus during lengthy debates over tax policy.

Despite these challenges, Obama remains determined to engage more with the American people in his second term. He told voters in Ohio before the election that their involvement is crucial for the democratic process to function effectively.

These meetings with labor leaders and CEOs are part of Obama's strategy to gather support as he enters negotiations with Congress, not just from his grassroots supporters, but also from the business community. The President's goal is to navigate the fiscal cliff and shape policy in line with the will of the majority of American voters.

Title: Obama Administration Issues Decree on Transgender Student Rights in Public Schools

Article:

In a move to escalate the ongoing national debate on LGBT rights, the Obama administration has announced that it will send a decree to all US public schools, requiring them to allow transgender students access to facilities consistent with their gender identity. This decision comes in response to North Carolina's controversial "bathroom bill" and is aimed at protecting transgender students from discrimination.

The decree, set to be sent on Friday, offers guidelines to school districts across the country on how to ensure fair treatment and appropriate facilities for transgender students. The letter, obtained by ███, does not add new legal requirements but provides extensive guidelines on ensuring trans students' rights.

The letter states that schools may provide separate facilities based on sex, but they must allow transgender students access to such facilities consistent with their gender identity. Schools are also prohibited from requiring transgender students to use facilities inconsistent with their gender identity or to use individual-user facilities when other students are not required to do so.

The decree also makes clear that transgender students must have access to facilities "even in circumstances in which other students, parents or community members raise objections or concerns." The letter emphasizes that accommodating others' discomfort cannot justify a policy that singles out and disadvantages transgender students.

The notice is accompanied by a lengthy document providing examples of policies and emerging practices for supporting transgender students, as well as guidelines on privacy, confidentiality, anti-bullying, and other issues affecting LGBT students.

US Attorney General Loretta Lynch commented, "There is no room in our schools for discrimination of any kind, including discrimination against transgender students on the basis of their sex." She added, "This guidance gives administrators, teachers, and parents the tools they need to protect transgender students from peer harassment and to identify and address unjust school policies."

The announcement comes as the justice department and North Carolina move forward with a high-profile legal battle over the state's bathroom law. The law, HB2, has been criticized for forcing trans people to use restrooms that correspond to the sex assigned to them at birth, which critics say is unenforceable and a clear violation of the US Civil Rights Act.

The fight over trans rights extends beyond North Carolina. A federal appeals court in Virginia recently ruled that barring a transgender boy from using the boys' bathroom was a civil rights violation, and school officials in Chicago and Oregon have recently outlined protections for trans students.

Title: House and Senate Leaders at Impasse as Fiscal Cliff Deadline Looms

Article:

In a high-level telephone conference call, House Republican leaders have called on the Senate to act, leaving open the possibility of bringing last-minute legislation to the House floor if the Senate passes it. The statement, issued on behalf of Speaker John A. Boehner and his top lieutenants, stated that the House would act on any Senate-passed legislation, but the Senate must act first.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, however, has called on House Republicans to pass an existing Senate measure that would prevent tax increases on household income up to $250,000. In a statement, Reid criticized House Republicans for their Tea Party bills and accused them of obstruction.

As of Thursday evening, Senators will return to the Capitol with no immediate legislation to consider. The House is expected to be gaveled into session at 2 p.m., but since Speaker Boehner has not recalled members to Washington, it will likely be gaveled back into recess shortly thereafter.

The focus has shifted to Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader and a deal-making veteran. Democrats are seeking assurances from McConnell that he will not use procedural tactics to delay any potential bill aimed at averting the fiscal crisis.

Don Stewart, a spokesman for McConnell, stated that neither the White House nor Reid's office has reached out to begin negotiations. Democrats argue that McConnell is well aware of their proposed legislation: the Senate bill that passed in July, which extends all the expiring Bush-era income tax cuts on incomes below $250,000, sets the tax rate on dividends and capital gains at 20 percent, and prevents the alternative minimum tax from rising to hit more middle-class taxpayers. Democrats also want to add an extension of expiring unemployment benefits and a delay in across-the-board spending cuts while negotiations on a broader deficit reduction plan are pushed into next year.

Democrats now suggest that Republicans are content to wait until after the January deadline. On Jan. 3, Boehner is likely to be re-elected speaker for the 113th Congress. After that roll call, he may feel less pressure from his right flank against a deal.

The Senate may simply be running out of time. Without unanimous agreement, Reid would have to take procedural steps to begin considering a bill. He could then be forced to press for another vote to cut off debate before final passage. If forced to jump through those hoops, the 112th Congress could expire before final votes could be cast.

Representative Jim Himes, Democrat of Connecticut, said on CNBC on Wednesday, "I think there's some chance that we get a deal done in the early weeks of January, which technically means you're going over the cliff."

Lawmakers from both parties agree that McConnell could be the key to a resolution. He has played the role of adjudicator for Congressional Republicans before, during last year's fight over a payroll tax extension and the battle between Democrats and Republicans over how, or if, to pay for an emergency disaster financing bill.

With days to spare, McConnell must decide whether to allow the Democrats' bill to extend expiring tax cuts onto the Senate floor. If passed without a filibuster, that legislation could force the House speaker's hand and quiet his raucous Republican conference. Alternatively, McConnell, who is up for re-election in 2014 and would like to avoid a primary fight, could stand back quietly and hope that Boehner and Obama manage to put together a deal that saves him the trouble.

If McConnell cannot come to the rescue, there is another hope: Starbucks. Howard Schultz, the company's CEO, asked baristas who work in Washington-area Starbucks to scrawl "Come Together" on coffee cups for the rest of the week to generate enthusiasm for a compromise.

Title: Online Donations Fuel Democratic Advantage in House Races, Countering GOP Advertising Assault

Article:

In the ongoing battle for control of the U.S. House of Representatives, a significant shift in fundraising dynamics is emerging, with hundreds of thousands of online donors pouring money into Democratic campaigns at an unprecedented rate. This surge in online contributions is countering a late-summer advertising assault by the Republicans, who have traditionally relied on their outside-money advantage.

According to a review of TV spending totals, Democrats in nearly 20 districts aired TV ads first to define themselves before facing GOP attacks, while CLF went on the offensive in seven districts. This sustained cash flow has extended Democrats' already formidable edge in the House race. In August alone, Democratic House candidates raised more than $35.8 million online, a sixfold increase from their online total in August 2016.

The influx of funds has been broadly distributed, with 14 Democratic challengers raising at least half a million dollars via ActBlue in August, and another 38 bringing in at least $250,000 online.

Jesse Ferguson, a former Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee staffer and Democratic consultant, commented on the phenomenon, stating, "For a number of years, Democrats searched for our answer to the Koch brothers and found our own billionaire. In reality, it's a 67-year-old grandmother on a fixed income who's donating $25 every month to candidates."

One standout candidate is Abigail Spanberger, a former CIA officer running in Virginia. Spanberger raised $790,000 online in August, and saw a fundraising spike after disclosing that CLF had obtained her confidential security clearance application while conducting research on her employment history.

By the time CLF used the information to attack Spanberger on TV on Sept. 6, the Democrat had already aired nearly 900 positive TV spots in her race against GOP Rep. Dave Brat. Spanberger stated, "Our ads helped set the baseline of who I am, and that was probably very helpful in combating those attacks. The juxtaposition of the visuals of the ads, ours showing me as a normal person and theirs, are just scary."

CLF has continued its attacks, focusing on Spanberger's stint as a substitute teacher at the Saudi-funded Islamic Saudi Academy in Mount Vernon, Va., and labeling it "Terror High." A Republican familiar with polling in the district stated that "the race was trending in the wrong direction, and that ad helped stabilize things."

CLF spokeswoman Courtney Alexander countered, stating, "Democrats have been 'forced to spend whatever they have raised responding to attack ads which are putting Democratic candidates on defense and setting the terms of these races.' She added, "No first-time candidate wants their first ad to be a response ad, and that's what we have seen repeatedly from Democrats across the country as they are forced to scramble to answer for their records as the truth comes out."

However, Spanberger called the ads "ridiculous," adding that the attack has "fallen flat."

Spanberger is just one of many Democrats bringing in big money and pouring it into mass communication with voters. Overall, ActBlue, which surpassed $1 billion raised in 2018 on Aug. 2, had its biggest month ever in August, bringing in $100 million to candidates and progressive organizations. Other top House fundraisers that month included Sharice Davids and Jared Golden.

The money has sprouted after months of groundwork by campaigns and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. The DCCC placed digital staffers in each of its regional political teams for the first time this election, helping campaigns grow online and be prepared to capitalize on viral moments and other opportunities.
