The resulting well-funded campaigns have put House Democrats in an unusual position: They and their allied outside groups are currently outadvertising the GOP in some battlegrounds. Charlie Kelly, executive director of House Majority PAC, the Democratic House super PAC, stated, "Candidates and Democratic groups have been running even or we have an advantage in paid communications on the air in many of the top 25 to 30 districts across the country. Time and time again, Democratic enthusiasm is off the charts."

These August online fundraising totals track with Democratic candidate performance over the past year. A whopping 56 Republican House incumbents raised less money than their Democratic challengers during the second quarter, along with 16 congressmen with less cash on hand than their Democratic opponents.

A Republican consultant working on House races, granted anonymity to speak candidly, stated, "This is the manifestation of a larger problem—the massive enthusiasm gap. Republicans and our outside groups are raising a lot of money, too, but we can no longer say or think we can rely on just our super PACs, because now Democrats have money as well. Everyone has money."

However, the money is no guarantee of success. Amy McGrath, a former combat pilot challenging Rep. Andy Barr (R-Ky.), also caught fire online early by telling a compelling personal story in TV ads. Her first campaign video has received nearly 2 million views on YouTube, and public polling shows the first-time candidate jumped ahead in public polling.

However, CLF aired TV ads featuring a clip of McGrath saying, "I don't know that I'm different than the Democratic Party nationally," then cut to a voter saying, "When I first saw Amy McGrath's ads, I thought she was a moderate, but now we know the truth."

CLF released a polling memo earlier this month, showing that an early lead built by McGrath had evaporated. (A recent poll conducted by The New York Times also shows a tied race.) "Now, 66 percent of voters see her as a liberal, compared to 39 percent in June," the CLF polling memo reads.

Title: West Hollywood City Council Votes to Urge Removal of Donald Trump's Hollywood Walk of Fame Star

Article:

In a unanimous vote on Monday evening, the West Hollywood City Council has expressed its intention to remove U.S. President Donald Trump's star from the Hollywood Walk of Fame. The council, however, has no jurisdiction over the Walk of Fame, which is located in neighboring Hollywood, and can only urge the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce, the entity responsible for the attraction, to take action.

The resolution, announced by West Hollywood Mayor John Duran, states that the individual honored by the star does not align with the values of West Hollywood, one of the country's most liberal communities. The council's decision is based on allegations of sexual harassment made against Trump by several women, which he has denied, and his controversial policy of separating asylum-seeking migrant families at the U.S.-Mexico border.

The star, which has been a focal point for anti-Trump protests since 2015, has been vandalized twice, with men using heavy tools to damage it. Each time, the star has been swiftly repaired. The Hollywood Chamber of Commerce, which manages the Walk of Fame, has never removed a star from the attraction, which honors celebrities from the entertainment industry.

In response to the West Hollywood City Council's request, Leron Gubler, the chamber president, stated that there are currently no plans to remove any stars from the Hollywood Walk of Fame. The council's request will be considered at the chamber's next meeting, according to NBC News.

The Hollywood Walk of Fame accepts nominations for new stars once a year, with the nominee's sponsor required to pay a $40,000 fee for the honor. Trump's star was added in 2007 in recognition of his work in television, including his role as host of NBC's "The Apprentice" and his production of the Miss Universe beauty pageants.

Title: A Decade of Political Correctness: 24 Absurd Moments Defining the 2010s

In the last decade, the concept of political correctness has been a hot topic, with numerous instances being labeled as racist, sexist, offensive, or insensitive. Here, in no particular order, are 24 of the most absurdly politically correct moments of the decade:

1. A college diversity-training course taught that it was culturally insensitive to expect people to be on time, as "time may be considered fluid" in other cultures.
2. A piece in Everyday Feminism argued that "trigger warning" is actually a trigger, as it could "be re-traumatizing for folks who have suffered military, police, and other forms of violence." The recommendation was to use "content warning" instead.
3. A professor was accused of sexual harassment for stating that effort was 10 percent of the grade.
4. A campus survey included a trigger warning to caution college students that it may contain "anatomical names of body parts."
5. University researchers demanded that we accept people who "identify as real vampires" to prevent anti-vampire discrimination.
6. A Seattle-area councilman was concerned about the city hosing poop off of its sidewalks because he thought that it might seem too racially insensitive.
7. A bathing-suit advertisement was criticized for being "sexist" because it depicted a woman in a bathing suit.
8. Some feminists decided that "pussyhats" were both racist and transphobic, due to the fact that not all women have vaginas, and not all vaginas are pink.
9. A professor claimed that the small chairs in preschools are sexist, "disempowering," and "problematic."
10. College students decided against bringing a camel to school for a "Hump Day" event, due to concerns about racism.
11. A school in Seattle reportedly insisted that Easter eggs be called "spring spheres."
12. A group of Berkeley students insisted that they could not take their in-class exam due to their lack of privilege.
13. The phrase "long time, no see" was reportedly declared to be "derogatory" toward Asians.
14. A college newspaper changed its name from "The Bullet" because its editors were concerned that that name was too dangerous.
15. Lecturers were warned that capital letters might scare students and that they should avoid using them.
16. A campus-wide email told white students to stop wearing hooped earrings, because doing so was cultural appropriation.
17. A campus Christian club was found guilty of discrimination for requiring its leaders to be Christians.
18. Oxford University law students were told that they didn't have to learn about rape or violence law if they found it too triggering.
19. A liberal author demanded that "normal people" avoid wearing any kind of red hat, because all red hats can be too scary.
20. Several colleges and universities either canceled or adapted performances of The Vagina Monologues over concerns about excluding women without vaginas.
21. A school in Texas canceled their performance of The Vagina Monologues for another reason: because a white lady wrote it.
22. Evergreen State University told professors to take student protesters' feelings into account when grading them.
23. A lot of college kids were upset about The Vagina Monologues.
24. A liberal author demanded that "normal people" avoid wearing any kind of red hat, because all red hats can be too scary.

Title: Egypt Launches Airstrikes Against ISIS in Libya in Response to Execution of Coptic Christians

Article:

Egypt has launched a series of airstrikes against ISIS targets in Libya in retaliation for the execution of 21 Coptic Christian citizens. The airstrikes, announced on state radio Monday, targeted ISIS weapons caches, training grounds, and camps in Libya.

The Egyptian government described the airstrikes as a means to "avenge the bloodshed and to seek retribution from the killers." In a statement, Egyptian President Abdel Fatah al-Sisi vowed that Egyptians have a "shield to protect and safeguard the security of the country and a sword that amputates terrorism and extremism."

A five-minute propaganda video released by ISIS on Sunday showed the execution of the men, who were paraded onto a beach, each accompanied by a masked jihadist. The video, which was widely circulated on social media, showed the Coptic Christians from Egypt being forced to kneel as one jihadist addressed the camera in English.

"All crusaders: safety for you will be only wishes, especially if you are fighting us all together. Therefore we will fight you all together," he said. "The sea you have hidden Sheikh Osama bin Laden's body in, we swear to Allah we will mix it with your blood."

The men were then forced to lay face-down in the sand and were simultaneously beheaded. The same jihadist speaker then pointed to the sea and said, "We will conquer Rome, by Allah's permission."

The men were not in Libya to fight ISIS. Rather, they were in the country to make a living when they were kidnapped in two separate incidents in December and January from the city of Sirte.

In addition to Egypt's airstrikes, Libya's air force also carried out its own airstrikes in the eastern city of Darna, which an ISIS affiliate took over last year. According to Libyan air force commander Saqer al-Joroushi, there were casualties among individuals, ammunition, and ISIS communication centers. He also reported that roughly 40 to 50 militants were killed.

"More air strikes will be carried out today and tomorrow in coordination with Egypt," he added.

According to the Associated Press, Egypt has already carried out a second wave of airstrikes in Darna. The execution of the 21 Coptic Christians has sparked widespread condemnation and outrage, with many calling for a stronger international response to ISIS's actions.

Title: Nick Sandmann Defends Actions During Controversial Confrontation, Disputes Phillips' Version of Events

In an interview with NBC's "Today," Nick Sandmann, the Covington Catholic High School student at the center of a controversial confrontation with Native American activist Nathan Phillips, defended his actions during the incident.

During the interview, Sandmann asserted that both he and Phillips were exercising their First Amendment rights during the confrontation that took place on Friday. The incident occurred after another protest group, the Black Hebrew Israelites, began taunting the Covington Catholic students. Phillips and his group approached the students, stopping in front of Sandmann.

Sandmann explained that the students had received permission from chaperones to shout school chants to drown out the insults from the Black Hebrew Israelites. He stated that he felt threatened, despite being in a much larger group, because the protesters were adults, and he "wasn't sure what was going to happen."

"In hindsight, I wish we had just found another spot to wait for our buses, but at the time, being positive seemed better than letting them slander us with all of these things," Sandmann said.

Phillips, in other interviews, explained that he went toward the students to defuse what he saw as a tense situation between the Black Hebrew Israelites and the students.

Sandmann also stated that his group should have walked away once the Native American activists came to them, but he "didn't want to be disrespectful to Mr. Phillips" if he was trying to have a conversation.

Sandmann, who can be seen in videos staring back at Phillips with what some have described as a smirk, said he was not intending to be disrespectful. In his view, he was trying to show that he wouldn't be moved to "any further reaction of aggression."

"As far as standing there, I had every right to do so," he said. "I can't say that I'm sorry for listening to him and standing there."

Phillips, who has done several interviews since the incident went viral, disputes Sandmann's version of events. He contends that Sandmann locked eyes with him and approached him.

"I have read the statement from Nick Sandmann, the student who stared at me for a long time. He did not apologize, and I believe there are intentional falsehoods in his testimony," Phillips said.

Covington Catholic High, an all-boys school, closed on Tuesday for safety reasons and reopened on Wednesday, although parents do not have to send their sons to school for the time being.

Title: Rise in Islamophobia in Nepal: A Consequence of India's Hindu Nationalist Agenda and Media Influence

Article:

KATHMANDU, Nepal—Nepal, a country with a long history of religious tolerance, has seen a surge in Islamophobic incidents in recent weeks, with Muslims, who make up about 4 percent of the population, becoming targets of hate speech and rumors. This rise in Islamophobia can be attributed to the influence of India's Hindu nationalist fundamentalists and Islamophobic media, which have exploited the coronavirus pandemic to spread hatred towards Muslims in Nepal.

The rise of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his association with the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh organization and its Hindu nationalist ideology has emboldened the New Delhi establishment to remake Nepal as a Hindu country once again. In 2006, Nepal became a secular country after it ousted the old constitutional monarchy, with a more secular Indian government helping to push former Maoist rebels to a peace deal and into mainstream politics. However, it has been easy for Indian Islamophobia to spread to Nepal, thanks to the number of Hindi speakers there and the wide range of Indian TV available.

Recent incidents in Nepal, such as the false rumors about two Muslim women spreading the coronavirus by spitting on rupee bills, have caused widespread panic and hate speech. The initial quick test of one of the women produced a positive result for COVID-19, but further testing gave negative results, revealing that the initial test was incorrect. The two women had merely dropped the notes accidentally while returning from the bank.

A week earlier, India's right-wing media, particularly Hindi news channels, circulated sensationalized news that Pakistan might have sent coronavirus-infected Muslim men to India via Nepal. The claims were based on an unverified and largely unsourced report sent by the state of Bihar to the Indian Home Ministry, which included false claims that Jalim Miya, a Muslim politician in Nepal, was behind the supposed plot and that the group of men were taking paracetamol to suppress their fevers and pass undetected. Miya explained exasperatedly that there was no such plot and was backed by Nepal's central government.

Nepal's Muslims are worried about the rise in Islamophobia, but they hope their friends and neighbors will stop things from getting worse. They point to the failure of the 1992 riots around the destruction of the Babri Masjid, a mosque built on a site also revered by Hindus in Ayodhya, India, to spread over the border. However, there has been a steady rise in attacks against Nepali Muslims on social media. The majority of Nepalis, however, continue to reject the attempts to whip up hatred, and there have been no reported physical assaults on Muslims.

Hajji Abdullah Miya, a former member of the Hajj Committee of Nepal, told ███: "Especially after the rise of Modi, the attitude towards Muslims in India has changed. In any case, the general tendency to portray Muslims negatively is old in India. India used to spread rumors against the Muslims of Nepal to create animosity with the Indian Muslims. Whether in the name of mosques and madrassas in the Terai border region or on other issues, India has always attacked Nepali Muslims."

Nepal's Muslims are hopeful that their friends and neighbors will reject the attempts to whip up hatred and that the incidents of Islamophobia will subside. The Nepali government and the public must take a stand against the spread of Islamophobia and work towards maintaining religious harmony in the country.

Title: Family of 17-Year-Old Boy Killed in Indian-Administered Kashmir Faces Long Battle for Death Certificate

Article:

In the aftermath of the Indian government's decision to abrogate Article 370, which granted special status to the Muslim-majority region of Kashmir, a 17-year-old boy named Osaib Altaf Marazi made a fatal decision. On August 5, 2019, Osaib left his home in Srinagar, Indian-administered Kashmir, to play cricket with his friends. His body was later found in the nearby Jhelum river.

Osaib's mother, Saleema Bano, has been struggling to cope with her youngest son's death for five months. "He was a beautiful boy," she said. "Everyone asks me to endure, but how can I forget my son who would be in front of my eyes every hour of the day?"

Saleema vividly remembers the day Osaib left home. "I told him to have lunch first and not to go out, but he insisted he would be back soon," she said. That was the last time Saleema saw Osaib.

The events that followed forced the Marazi family to embark upon a traumatic quest to prove Osaib's death and seek a death certificate. After four months of denial, Kashmiri police finally admitted that Osaib's death was the first in the wake of the abrogation of Article 370.

On August 5, roads across Kashmir were blocked, and checkpoints, manned by Indian paramilitary troopers, were set up. A tense atmosphere descended upon the region as phone networks, internet services, and TV channels were blocked. The crackdown seemed designed to prevent Kashmiris from protesting against New Delhi's decision to scrap Kashmir's limited autonomy.

Osaib's older brother, Suhail Ahmad Marazi, was not home on August 5. He later gathered witness accounts of what happened to his brother in the moments before his death. Osaib had been with his friends and, together, they walked a short distance from his home in Palpora village on the outskirts of Srinagar, the main city in the region, when they found themselves surrounded by paramilitary forces.

"They were 10 boys. As they reached the middle of a footbridge, they saw CRPF personnel running after them from both sides. They were scared and jumped into the river," Suhail told ███. "The other boys who were present at the spot told us that Osaib held onto the edge of the bridge for a few seconds before the armed men hit him with a stick on his head and hands and he slipped into the waters. It was a murder."

At home, Saleema was doing chores when boys from the neighborhood came running and knocked at her window. "They said Osaib had been martyred," Saleema recalled, overcome by emotion. "I wait for him every day and call his name every time when I serve the dinner. He was afraid to sleep alone."

Osaib's body was handed over to the family for burial, but the hospital refused to issue a death certificate. Officials at Shri Maharaja Hari Singh hospital in Srinagar asked the Marazi family for a First Information Report (FIR), a police complaint, to certify Osaib's death. It was the start of a months-long battle to secure a death certificate.

"From the hospital, I went to one police station and then another, and both said that they will not be able to register the FIR as the area does not come under their jurisdiction," Suhail said. "It was a helpless situation."

In September, after two child rights activists, Enakshi Ganguly and Shanta Sinha, filed a petition in India's Supreme Court to investigate cases of rights violations involving children in Kashmir, the court tasked the juvenile justice committee with investigating cases involving minors who were being detained in the region.

In the midst of their struggle to prove Osaib's death, his family was shocked by a written submission by police to the juvenile justice committee admitting that they had detained 144 minors. "Osaib Altaf, the incident as reported has been found to be baseless as no such death has been reported to the police authorities as per verification report received from the field formations," the police report said.

The family then approached the lower court to request the FIR. "We approached the court because how can they deny our child's death?" Suhail Marazi said. "While we were mourning at home, every week we had to go to the court as well."

Last month, the police finally submitted a report to the court admitting Osaib's death by drowning. "It is prayed that on 05-08-2019, the deceased Osaib Marazi aged about 24 years allegedly drowned in river Jhelum," said the status report submitted by the Parimpora police station to the court. Osaib's school records show he was 17, not "about 24" as the police claimed. He was a grade 12 student at a local school.

"No one gets justice here, and we do not hope for it either. But we want that we should be provided the death certificate," said Suhail, adding that they will continue to fight for the certificate. "Our neighbor Danish was killed the same way in 2016, and even they did not get any justice. They [the police] have found a new way to kill children in Kashmir."

Authorities in Kashmir, who now come directly under India's interior ministry, have denied any killings took place in the wake of the August 5 decision. However, local human rights group Jammu and Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society (JKCCS) said, in its 2019 human rights review, that six civilians had been killed by the Indian armed forces.

The list included 17-year-old Asrar Firdous Khan from Soura, Srinagar, who was playing cricket with his friends on August 6 when soldiers shot him in the head several times with pellets, according to his family. Asrar's medical records showed his death occurred due to pellet injuries to his skull, but the police refuted that, saying he was killed when a stone was thrown at him. The police did not specify who threw the stone.

While Osaib's family continues to struggle for acknowledgement of his death, Saleema struggles with her pain and longing. "I want to tear my heart open to find my son. It seems the light of my eyes has gone away."

Title: Clinton Campaign Denies Access to Daily Mail Reporter, Stirring Transparency Concerns

In a move that has reignited longstanding concerns about the Clinton campaign's commitment to transparency, the campaign denied access to print pool reporter David Martosko of London's Daily Mail on Monday. The incident occurred during a campaign event in New Hampshire, where Martosko was told he would not be allowed to cover the day's events as a pool reporter.

Martosko, the U.S. political editor for the Daily Mail, arrived at the campaign's breakfast stop in New Hampshire only to be informed that he would not be part of the pool for the day. Pool reporters are responsible for sending reports from the campaign trail to the rest of the press corps.

According to Martosko's report, he was told, "So I'm afraid it's a no. You're not on the list." When asked if the print pooler was being prohibited from getting on either of the pool vans, the campaign's press aide replied, "I'm afraid that's right."

Martosko, denied a ride in the pool van, decided to drive to the first campaign stop in Rochester on his own, hoping that the situation would be resolved during the 75-minute drive.

The Clinton campaign did not respond to a request for comment, but campaign press secretary Nick Merrill provided an explanation to Martosko, which was relayed in a report on The Daily Mail's website. Merrill stated that the campaign's position is that the Daily Mail does not qualify because it has not yet been added to the White House's regular print pool.

Merrill added that the campaign is "trying to follow the same process and system the White House has." He also emphasized that the decision had "nothing to do" with the campaign considering the Daily Mail as foreign press.

The Clinton campaign later stated that the decision was made due to concerns about foreign outlets not being part of the rotation. The campaign is reportedly working to address these concerns and is in touch with the journalists who coordinate the pool.

The incident at the YMCA of Strafford County in Rochester, NH, where the campaign's early childhood education summit was held, added to the confusion. Secret Service agents at the main entrance refused to let Martosko in and advised him to go in through another entrance near a playground.

Upon entering the alternative doorway, another agent asked for Martosko's name and outlet. When he identified himself as a Daily Mail reporter, a voice from behind the door, later identified as the head of Clinton's Secret Service detail, was heard saying, "Oh, no."

The first agent sent Martosko back to the front door, advising that the head of the detail insisted. At the front door again, Martosko was asked to wait while the first agent on duty checked to see if he would be admitted. The answer was a firm "No."

Martosko was advised by that Secret Service agent that he had contacted someone named "Pollard," who personally said no, Martosko could not come in. It's unclear who Pollard is.

Martosko asked if he could come inside to use the restroom, but was advised that the area had been swept already, so he should "hit the woods."

Martosko saw a WMUR-TV truck outside and confirmed with a reporter from a competing local station that there were indeed pool journalists inside from photo and video. With a light rain falling, Martosko went back to his rental car to file this report, after counting about 210 cars in the parking lots and on the street.

Both press pool vans from Manchester were visible outside, along with the now-famous black "Scooby" van and a contingent of New Hampshire state trooper vehicles.

The Clinton campaign has stated that they are working to create an equitable system and have had some concerns expressed by foreign outlets about not being part of the rotation. The journalists who coordinate the pool are in touch with them, and the campaign is simply asking that until they can work all of that out, they send an outlet in keeping with previous precedents.

Title: Fox News Analyst Brit Hume: Mueller Investigation Shifts Focus to Clinton Campaign, Raising Questions About Previous Reporting

Article:

On Tuesday, Fox News Channel's "Tucker Carlson Tonight," network senior political contributor Brit Hume reacted to Tucker Carlson's earlier report that the investigation by special counsel Robert Mueller has expanded to include elements of Hillary Clinton's campaign, Donald Trump's opponent in the 2016 presidential election. Hume suggested that the investigation's focus may now implicate some long-time Washington, D.C. Democrats.

During the discussion, Carlson questioned the fact that an earlier report indicated that Paul Manafort, who was Trump's campaign manager, was working for the Podesta Group on behalf of Russian interests before joining the Trump campaign. Hume noted that the Podesta Group, run by brothers Tony and John Podesta, lies at the heart of the Democratic Party and the Clintons' political endeavors.

Hume expressed surprise that, despite the Podesta Group's central role, journalists had not uncovered the connection between Manafort and the Podesta Group during the 11-month investigation. Hume also suggested that the investigation, initially focused on Russian efforts to influence the election, may now be a broader effort to determine the extent and depth of Russian efforts to influence American policy going back several years.

The discussion also touched on the Uranium One matter, in which the Obama administration's effort to seek a closer relationship with Russia resulted in the sale of strategic materials that could potentially place American security interests at risk. Hume noted that this matter has been known for some time but is coming into sharper focus.

Regarding the dossier that BuzzFeed published, Hume stated that it was paid for by the Democratic National Committee and the Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, and if this is true, it tends to soil the allegations of collusion between the Trump campaign and the Russians even further.

Hume concluded that the tide may now be turning in political and journalistic terms, and the Democrats may not enjoy the outcome of the investigation. Carlson agreed, stating that he would be concerned if he were the Podestas. The discussion ended with Hume thanking Carlson for having him on the show.

Title: Sanders, Buttigieg, and Warren Lead the Pack in New Hampshire Primary, Biden Struggles

Article:

In the New Hampshire primary, Bernie Sanders emerged as the clear winner, bolstered by his strong leads in the state's largest cities. He outperformed his main rivals in Manchester by over 2,000 votes, and in Concord and Nashua by 500 votes each. Pete Buttigieg performed well in communities south of Manchester, in Boston's suburbs, and in college towns such as Hanover, home of Dartmouth College.

Joe Biden, who was once the national front-runner, finished a disappointing fourth in Iowa and fifth in New Hampshire. Elizabeth Warren, the neighboring state's senator who had almost a third of the Democratic vote in an October poll, edged out Biden by less than a percentage point for fourth place.

Sanders, Warren, and Buttigieg, who between them led 20 of the 39 polls of New Hampshire primary voters conducted before the Iowa caucuses, now face a grueling 11-day sprint to the next contest in Nevada and an 18-day wait for the South Carolina primary. Both will have to convince donors and supporters they can regroup and rebuild their campaigns to secure a win.

There were concerning signs for both Biden and Warren in Tuesday's results. Warren, who is known for her detailed policy plans, struggled among those who prioritized electability over plans. Among the 33% of voters who preferred a candidate who agreed with them on major issues, more than a third chose Sanders, and only a small fraction chose Warren. Among the three in five voters who supported replacing America's healthcare system with a single-payer plan, three times as many chose Sanders over Warren.

Both Biden and Warren took steps Tuesday to distance themselves from the New Hampshire results, even before the polls closed. Warren stayed in New Hampshire to concede, offering kind words to Amy Klobuchar and pledging to continue the fight. In a memo to supporters, Warren campaign manager Roger Lau wrote that Warren's candidate remains "the consensus choice of the widest coalition of Democrats in every corner of the country." He said Warren's formidable campaign organization was well-positioned to win delegates across most of the states and districts that will vote on Super Tuesday, and that her ceiling is higher than Biden's, Sanders's, or Buttigieg's.

Each campaign will now have to convince its chief supporters that its candidate still has a path to the 1,990 delegates necessary to win the convention. Without the support necessary to sustain national field organizations and seven-figure television budgets, any candidate's campaign withers and dies; when a candidate loses or falls short of expectations, those financial problems mount even more rapidly.

Both Warren and Biden face challenges moving forward. Warren, who does not lead in polls in Nevada, South Carolina, or most Super Tuesday states, will have to break through for the first time. It is unclear where she will secure her first win.

"The road to the Democratic nomination is not paved with statewide winner-take-all victories. This is not a race for governor, the U.S. Senate, or the state treasurer's office," Lau wrote in his memo. "This is a district-by-district contest for pledged delegates awarded proportionally."

Title: The Evolution of Census-Taking: From Ancient Arrowheads to Modern Data Collection

Article:

The United States is currently in the midst of its decennial census, a process aimed at counting every individual residing within its borders. Over 150 other countries will join in this global census round, with approximately 90 percent of the world's population already accounted for. Despite the impressive scale of this endeavor, the modern census is not technologically spectacular. The American questionnaire asks just seven questions of each person, with a few additional queries for households as a whole.

This contrasts starkly with the complex technological challenges posed by census-taking in ancient times. While it is difficult to pinpoint the first census, it is likely that the idea arose independently in various places and times. For instance, the Scythians, nomadic warriors of the first millennium BCE, used a method that, while rudimentary by today's standards, worked effectively for them. They counted their population by having each individual contribute an arrowhead, with the total number of arrowheads serving as a census count.

Proto-literate societies were also capable of conducting complex censuses. The Inca, who dominated Andean America at the time of the Spanish conquest in the 15th century CE, recorded elaborate census statistics in connection with taxation, despite lacking a written language. They used knotted strings, known as khipu, to encode information. Of the thousand khipu that exist in museums today, two-thirds contain numerical data, and at least 50 are thought to pertain to censuses.

Perhaps the most significant ancient census was that of Rome. The Romans adopted the census during their regal period, shortly before the more familiar republic was declared in 509 BCE. They named the procedure "census" (from the Latin cēnsēre, "to assess"), made it fundamental to their social order, and spread it further as their territory grew.

The censors, the officeholders who conducted the census, determined each Roman citizen's position in an elaborate class hierarchy. This stratification of Roman society, performed every five years, dictated how that citizen and his family lived, from clothing and legal treatment to political power. The census process, in principle, involved each head of household making a declaration, providing personal and property information. The sheer logistics suggest that the count must have taken most of the 18-month term of the censors.

This brief exploration of census-taking throughout history underscores the evolution of this essential process, from the simple method of the Scythians to the more complex systems of the Inca and Romans. The modern census, while technologically unspectacular, remains a crucial tool for understanding and shaping societies.

Title: Secret Service Lapses in White House Security: A Look at Recent Incidents and Their Implications

Article:

In a series of unsettling incidents, the United States Secret Service has come under scrutiny for lapses in security at the White House. The latest incident involved a man, Omar Gonzalez, who managed to breach the White House grounds on September 19, 2014, despite several security measures failing to prevent his intrusion.

On that day, Gonzalez, who was not apprehended until he ran past the staircase leading to the Obama family's living quarters, should have been stopped immediately. However, a plainclothes surveillance team tasked with this duty failed to notice him, as reported by The Washington Post. The attack dog that was supposed to be released did not respond, and the front door of the White House was left unlocked. An alarm box at the entrance was muted due to its annoyance to members of the usher's staff who work nearby. The agent who eventually tackled Gonzalez was off-duty and happened to be passing by at that moment.

In 2011, another equally alarming incident occurred, but was not fully disclosed at the time. A man named Oscar Ortega-Hernandez parked his car approximately 700 yards from the White House and fired a semiautomatic weapon into the upstairs residence area. One of the Obama daughters was home at the time. Some Secret Service officers thought there might have been an attack, but their supervisor decided it was just backfire from a vehicle and ordered them to stand down. It took four days for the Secret Service to understand that there was an armed attack, and only after a housekeeper discovered broken glass and chipped cement.

The President and First Lady, Michelle Obama, were reportedly furious when they were informed of the incident several days later. Several lawmakers noted at a hearing that the damage could have been catastrophic if the attackers had been organized terrorists rather than deranged individuals. Considering President Obama has received three times the number of threats as his predecessors, there should be greater security for this White House.

The budget and size of the Secret Service have fallen in the last few years. In 2011, the agency had about 6,900 staff positions; it now has about 6,600. Its budget fell from $1.9 billion in 2012 to $1.8 billion in 2013, in part due to automatic cuts demanded by Congress, and it has only slightly increased since then. Though money cannot be the only reason for these errors, people inside the agency say the cuts have led to staff burnout, low morale, and unmonitored posts.

President Obama now faces the decision of whether Secret Service Director Julia Pierson is capable of protecting him and his family, as well as upholding the nation's reputation. However, at a minimum, he must insist on an independent, top-to-bottom review of the Secret Service, not one conducted by officials trying to protect themselves or their agency.

Title: California Bill to Limit Vaccine Exemptions Advances, Sparking Debate on Individual Rights and Public Health

Article:

In a move aimed at addressing a recent measles outbreak, a California bill that restricts vaccine exemptions for schoolchildren based on personal beliefs has progressed, though it still faces several hurdles before becoming law. The bill, which allows students to opt out of mandatory vaccinations only if they have a medical condition, was introduced in response to a measles outbreak at Disneyland in late December that has been linked to nearly 150 cases.

Outside the Capitol building in Sacramento on Wednesday, the bill sparked a heated debate between several hundred supporters and protesters. Opponents, some wearing American flags and carrying signs such as "Force my veggies, not vaccines," argue that eliminating the personal belief exemption infringes upon their ability to make informed decisions about their children's health.

Lisa Cadrein, a Los Angeles resident, expressed her concerns about the potential adverse effects of vaccines on her daughter. "I think that everybody should be able to make their own choice," she said. "I am afraid that her big beautiful blue eyes will not focus on me anymore, and she won't be the kid that she is."

However, scientific studies have consistently found no link between vaccines and autism spectrum disorder. Inside the hearing, parents also spoke about protecting their children from those who are not vaccinated.

Democratic Sen. Lois Wolk, a member of the Senate Health Committee, spoke in favor of the pro-vaccine parents. "Our individual rights are not without limits, and in this particular case, your insistence on your right really could harm my children or my grandchildren," Wolk said.

The health committee in California's Senate passed the bill 6-2 on Wednesday. The proposed legislation now has many more hearings before it could become law. Meanwhile, similar legislation to limit families' rights to opt out of mandatory vaccinations has been considered in Washington, Oregon, and North Carolina, but all efforts have stalled.

This story is part of NPR's reporting partnership with Capital Public Radio and Kaiser Health News.

Title: White House Press Secretary Advocates for School Reopening, Cites Study on COVID-19 Risk in Children

Article:

White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany has asserted that "the science is on our side" in the ongoing debate over school reopening amid the COVID-19 pandemic. In a press briefing on Thursday, McEnany advocated for President Donald Trump's push to physically reopen schools, stating that the "science should not stand in the way" of schools reopening.

McEnany's remarks came as Trump has vocally advocated for schools to physically reopen over the past week, threatening funding to schools and saying he would put pressure on governors to reopen schools in their states. However, health experts have pointed to the risk of children contributing to the spread of the coronavirus.

A number of school districts have moved forward with plans that incorporate virtual learning in the fall to reduce the risk of spreading COVID-19, including public schools in Richmond, Va., which announced Wednesday they would have full virtual learning in the fall.

McEnany cited a study published by JAMA Pediatrics, which she argued demonstrates that the risk of critical illness due to the novel coronavirus to children is "far less" than the seasonal flu. She continued, "The science is very clear on this, and we encourage localities and states to just simply follow the science, open our schools."

McEnany emphasized the importance of schools for the wellbeing of students and their parents, stating, "Our schools are extremely important, they're essential, and they must reopen." She also highlighted the potential negative effects of school closures on children, including a lack of reporting of abuse, mental depression, and suicidal ideations.

Trump has forcefully advocated for schools to reopen, arguing that the risk to children remains low. Last week, he stated, "We're going to be putting a lot of pressure on: Open your schools in the fall."

Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis has been praised by Trump for directing schools to reopen in the fall, despite a large surge in coronavirus cases in the state recently. The GOP has scaled back its convention in Florida next month as a result.

The study cited by McEnany on Thursday found that "severe illness in children is significant but far less frequent than in adults" and that preexisting medical conditions seem to be an "important factor" with respect to children who contract the disease.

Trump has been accused of eschewing the advice of public health experts, including by Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan, who penned a scathing op-ed criticizing the president's response to the coronavirus on Thursday. Trump last week criticized the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention guidelines for reopening schools as "very tough" and "expensive."

Title: The New York Times Acknowledges Cautious Approach in 2016 Report on FBI's Trump-Russia Investigation

The New York Times has issued a correction to a 2016 article regarding the origins of the FBI's investigation into potential links between the Trump campaign and Russia. The paper admitted that it had played down the case due to cautious statements from law enforcement officials.

In the closing weeks of the 2016 presidential campaign, The New York Times reported that the FBI had uncovered no "conclusive or direct link" between Donald Trump and the Russian government. The key fact of the article—the FBI's investigation into possible links between the Russian government and the Trump campaign—was published in the 10th paragraph. The article's tone and headline, "Investigating Donald Trump, F.B.I. Sees No Clear Link to Russia," gave an air of finality to an investigation that was just beginning.

The Times' correction disclosed that during the 2016 probe, dubbed "Crossfire Hurricane," at least one government informant met several times with two Trump campaign aides, Carter Page and George Papadopoulos. This has become a contentious point, with Trump's allies questioning whether the FBI was spying on the Trump campaign or trying to entrap campaign officials.

President Trump tweeted yesterday that if it's true, "this is bigger than Watergate!" The paper casts the FBI's judgments—and even misjudgments—in a sympathetic light. The bureau was aggressive in the Hillary Clinton investigation, but cautious on Trump due to political considerations.

The Times narrative suggests that the FBI was just starting to scrutinize possible links between Trump associates and Russia and did not have enough evidence to go public. The paper also notes that anything the FBI did publicly would only give fodder to Trump's claims on the campaign trail that the election was rigged.

Trump yesterday linked to a National Review piece by Andrew McCarthy, who argued that the paper's analysis was "bunk." He said the Hillary probe was a criminal investigation involving her email server, while Trump was subjected to a counterintelligence probe in the hope of turning up evidence to use against him.

The correction comes as the origins of the Trump investigation are under scrutiny, with some arguing that the FBI's actions were politically motivated. The investigation remains a contentious issue, with opinions divided between those who believe the FBI quietly did its job and those who see a bogus investigation that unfairly put Robert Mueller on Trump's trail.

Title: Hillary Clinton Makes History as First Female Presidential Nominee of a Major U.S. Party

Article:

In a historic moment at the 2016 Democratic National Convention, Hillary Clinton became the first woman to accept the presidential nomination of a major U.S. political party. The theme of the evening was "Stronger Together," a slogan that Clinton emphasized throughout her speech.

Clinton's focus was on differentiating herself from her rival, Donald Trump, and highlighting her steady leadership on foreign policy and the economy. Faith, religious liberty, and abortion were largely absent from her speech, but she did mention her Methodist faith and referenced her mother's admonition to "do all the good you can, for all the people you can, in all the ways you can, as long as ever you can."

Chelsea Clinton, her daughter, also made history as the child of two presidential candidates from their respective parties. In her speech, Chelsea expressed her pride in her mother and gratitude for being her daughter.

Hillary Clinton's speech aimed to unite the party, with a special shout-out to Bernie Sanders supporters, some of whom protested her nomination with glow-in-the-dark shirts. She also affirmed her former opponent in the first few minutes of her speech, hoping to appease his supporters.

Throughout her speech, Clinton took aim at Trump, criticizing his campaign and presenting her own vision for the country. She emphasized the importance of unity and cooperation, stating, "We are not a country that says 'never mind.' We say 'let's get it done.'"

Clinton made multiple promises throughout her nearly one-hour speech, including her plan to support local forces in taking out ISIS, creating more good jobs with rising wages in the United States, and working with Sen. Bernie Sanders on education. She also promised to make college tuition-free for the middle class and debt-free for all, and to liberate millions of people who already have student debt.

Clinton also addressed foreign policy, attacking Trump's ability to handle complicated foreign affairs and promising to provide the necessary leadership. She ended the night on a note of promise for the future, telling Americans, "We are stronger together."

Title: Theresa May's Third Brexit Defeat: A Turning Point in Britain's EU Exit Saga

Article:

In a significant development, British Prime Minister Theresa May suffered her third consecutive defeat in the House of Commons on Friday, leaving the country in a precarious yet potentially transformative position regarding its exit from the European Union. The margin of defeat was smaller than the previous two, with a majority of 58 against May's deal, compared to the previous 230 and 149. This latest defeat, in all but name, marked the third "meaningful vote" on the Brexit deal this year, all of which have ended in the same result.

Following the latest defeat, May seemed to hint at a potential fourth attempt at passing her deal. However, this would be an unprecedented move, and many argue that the limit has been reached, as three consecutive defeats effectively signal a clear rejection of the deal. The prime minister's deal, therefore, appears to be dead, and it is time for it to be buried.

The question arises as to why May would willingly subject herself to such repeated humiliation. Several reasons can be attributed to this decision. The prime minister's stubbornness, her questionable strategy, and the erosion of her authority are among the underlying factors.

One reason for the repeated attempts was to keep the Brexit process moving forward. The original deadline set by May for Britain's departure from the EU, on 29 March 2019, was not met due to a series of misjudgments on May's part, including her refusal to engage with remain supporters and the loss of her majority in the 2017 general election. By persisting with her deal, May was attempting to demonstrate to leave voters that, despite obstacles, she was the one driving the Brexit process. However, this strategy has only served to highlight her own failures and weaknesses.

The attorney general had suggested that the primary reason for another attempt was procedural, aiming to move the latest Brexit deadline from 12 April to 22 May to allow for the passage of the final tranche of withdrawal legislation without the UK becoming embroiled in the European parliament elections. With the latest defeat, this is no longer a likely outcome. Instead, Britain now faces a choice between a no-deal exit in two weeks or a much longer delay to Brexit, during which the UK will likely participate in the EU elections. Given the unthinkable dangers of a no-deal exit, the choice must be for a longer delay.

May also had more partisan reasons for her persistence. Last Monday's revolt by MPs, in which they took control of parliament from the government, opened up the possibility that opposition MPs and pro-European Tories might soften the deal, revoke Article 50, or insist on a second referendum. Many Conservative MPs were alarmed by this prospect, and with May also promising to step down if her deal was adopted, more than 40 of her MPs switched their support to a deal they had previously rejected. This tactic, however, was ultimately unsuccessful.

With May's defeat, the way is now clear for a different approach. This week's indicative votes are unfinished business, with new versions to be put before MPs on Monday. The movers have learned from their defeats, something May seems incapable of doing. Two propositions – in favor of a customs union and for a second referendum on the final deal – are very much in play. If the Commons can rally behind these, the EU summit on 10 April should be asked to grant the UK a longer extension of Article 50 to cement a different form of deal, with a public vote on it at the end. It is ironic that May's third defeat may have finally created space for a very different approach from the one she has followed for three wasted years.

Title: Allegations of Secret Deal and Potential Misconduct Surface in Labor Secretary Nominee's Past

Article:

A new report released by a bipartisan group of congressional committees has raised allegations that Labor Secretary nominee Thomas Perez, in his previous role as Assistant Attorney General, made a "quid pro quo" deal with leaders of the city of St. Paul, Minnesota, in 2012. The report, obtained by Fox News, claims that Perez manipulated federal law and potentially cost taxpayers up to $200 million by persuading the city to drop a contentious lawsuit in exchange for the Justice Department staying out of whistleblower cases brought against the city.

The report, titled "How Assistant Attorney General Thomas Perez Manipulated Justice and Ignored Rule of Law," states that Perez's actions were unusual and may have violated his duties of loyalty and confidentiality to the United States. The allegations could impact Perez's pending confirmation hearing, scheduled for this Thursday.

The report details two cases involving the city of St. Paul. The first case, which the Justice Department opted out of, potentially cost taxpayers as much as $200 million, the amount the government could have won had it pursued damages in the case. The department allegedly stayed away from this case to get the city to drop an appeal to the Supreme Court on another matter.

The second case involved St. Paul's appeal to the Supreme Court, where property owners claimed the city made extraordinary efforts, through strict code enforcement, to condemn their properties. The owners argued that reducing the amount of affordable housing for minorities violated the federal Fair Housing Act, a provision known as "disparate impact."

The report concludes that Perez sought to stop the Supreme Court from ruling on the case, as he feared the Court would find the "disparate impact" provision unsupported by the text of the Fair Housing Act. The other end of the alleged deal was for the Justice Department not to get involved in cases against the city of St. Paul that alleged the city received millions in Department of Housing and Urban Development funds but failed to file the requisite paperwork regarding the hiring of low-income workers.

The Obama administration has acknowledged that senior Justice Department attorneys recommended intervening in the case, but characterized the False Claims Act infractions reported by plaintiff Thomas Newell as "particularly egregious." However, they thought the case would be "quite weak and never should have been a serious candidate for intervention."

The Justice Department claims everything was above board, stating that the department held three staff briefings, heard 24 hours of additional testimony, and reviewed 1,400 pages of documents before deciding not to intervene. The department maintains that the litigation decisions made were in the best interests of the United States and were consistent with the department's legal, ethical, and professional responsibility obligations.

Former Justice Department spokeswoman Tracy Schmaler also questioned the use of the term "quid pro quo" to describe what happened, stating, "It's such a loaded term. I think in fact you have almost everybody agreeing nothing inappropriate happened."

Congressional Democrats have put out a statement and memo of their own refuting the details of the report, stating that Perez and others "acted professionally to advance the interests of civil rights and effectively combat the scourge of discrimination in housing." They argue that the decision not to intervene in the suit against St. Paul was based on expert recommendations.

The report's release has sparked a political debate, with some arguing that the allegations against Perez are part of a broader political campaign to undermine legal safeguards against discrimination, while others maintain that the report raises serious questions about Perez's integrity and his ability to serve as Labor Secretary. The confirmation hearing for Perez is scheduled for this Thursday.

Title: A Historical Perspective on the Role of Intelligence Agencies in U.S. Politics: A Look at the Russia Probe Controversy

Article:

In the realm of American politics, the role of intelligence agencies has always been a subject of debate, with the line between politics and intelligence often blurred. This is particularly evident in the ongoing debate about the CIA and FBI's role in the origins of the Russia probe.

Attorney General William Barr's decision to investigate the origins of the Russia investigation has sparked controversy, with Democrats expressing concern over what they perceive as an attempt to shift the narrative from Trump's alleged collusion with Russia to potential abuses of power by the FBI. The investigation led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller failed to prove the collusion allegations, and Barr's attempt to determine whether the unprecedented probe of a presidential campaign was an abuse of power is a significant concern for Democrats who are pursuing the impeachment of President Trump.

CNN crime-and-justice reporter Shimon Prokupecz this week expressed his concern over the Department of Justice's scrutiny of the CIA's work. However, this is not a new phenomenon. The CIA, like other intelligence agencies, has often been the subject of investigation, particularly when its activities are perceived to further a political agenda.

The political ferment of the 1970s and '80s, during which congressional committees led by Democrats such as Frank Church and Otis Pike conducted far-reaching investigations, is a testament to this. The debates about intelligence after the 9/11 attacks and the heated run-up to George W. Bush's Iraq War also highlight the political nature of intelligence.

The political parties have switched sides in this latest controversy, with Democrats defending the intelligence community and Republicans criticizing it. However, this shift in perspective is not unprecedented. In the past, it was Republicans defending the FBI and CIA against Democrats' charges, while today, Democrats are acting as if the agencies are beyond reproach.

Sensible people of either party will always seek to balance deference to the intelligence community's mission with an understanding that all government officials and agencies must be kept on a tight leash lest they abuse their power. The ongoing Russia probe controversy serves as a reminder of the need for transparency and accountability in the intelligence community's activities.

Title: Boehner Pushes for Immigration Reform Amidst GOP Resistance

Article:

In a move that defies the skepticism of some Republican leaders, Speaker John Boehner is persistently advocating for the passage of immigration reform in the House of Representatives. Despite Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell's statement last week that immigration is not a priority for 2014, Boehner has been relentless in his pursuit of the issue.

On Tuesday, Rep. Jeff Denham of California, who has recently met with Boehner on the matter, stated, "Leadership's focus, and my focus, is to get [immigration] done as early as possible." Denham added, "It's part of our conference agenda right now. It doesn't go on the agenda without scheduling bills and scheduling time on the floor."

Boehner's office has released several documents outlining the Republican principles for immigration reform since the GOP retreat last week. These principles include a proposal to eliminate the ability for the administration to arbitrarily decide which laws to enforce.

However, the push for immigration reform is facing resistance within the Republican party. The pushback has caused significant doubt within Boehner's leadership team, particularly for GOP Whip Kevin McCarthy, who represents a highly conservative district with anti-amnesty sentiment. In response, McCarthy's spokesperson stated, "There has been nothing scheduled as of now."

Meanwhile, top amnesty proponents outside Congress, such as Frank Sharry, founder and executive director of America's Voice, have expressed relative satisfaction with the principles and their reception by the GOP. Sharry noted, "This is the party that voted against the DREAM Act in Dec. 2010. Republicans backed Mitt Romney and his call for self-deportation in 2012. And now in early 2014, the House Republicans are saying citizenship for DREAMers and legal status with no special path for the rest. That's a pretty significant shift, it seems to me."

The future of immigration reform in the House remains uncertain, with some members, like Rep. Tom Cotton, stating, "At this point I don't anticipate legislation will come to the floor." However, Boehner's determination to push for reform continues, as he seeks to address the issue as early as this spring.

Title: Jeb Bush Raises Political Profile Amidst 2016 Presidential Speculation

Article:

Washington D.C. is currently experiencing a snowstorm, but the political rumor mills remain active. The possibility of former Florida Governor Jeb Bush making a presidential run in 2016 has been a topic of discussion, amplified by his recent appearances on various media outlets, including NBC's "Today" show.

On Monday, Bush voiced his opinions on current issues such as immigration reform, the 2013 sequester, and other budget crises. His book, "Immigration Wars," outlines his stance on giving illegal immigrants legal status but not a pathway to citizenship. He is also a featured speaker at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) 2013, running from March 14 to 16 in Washington D.C.

During his interview with "Today" host Matt Lauer, Bush expressed optimism about finding a consensus on immigration but emphasized the need to resolve budget matters to focus on immigration reform and energy policy. When asked about a potential 2016 run, Bush neither confirmed nor denied the speculations, stating, "That's way off into the future... I'm not going to declare it today either."

Another potential 2016 contender is New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, who was notably absent from CPAC this year despite being a popular choice. Bush expressed surprise at Christie's exclusion, attributing it to his handling of budget issues related to Hurricane Sandy and his public appearances with President Barack Obama. However, Bush clarified that CPAC's decision had nothing to do with Christie's actions with the President, stating, "I think the issue of castigating the House... that's what I think was the critique. Look, I love Christie. I think Gov. Christie is a part of the future of the Republican Party for sure, and whether he's going to CPAC or not is not really changing that."

This development has Washington abuzz, as Bush is seen as elevating his public profile amidst the growing speculation about a potential presidential run in 2016.

Title: Romney and Trump Engage in Heated Twitter Exchange Ahead of Republican Debate

Article:

In a heated exchange on Twitter, former Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney and current frontrunner Donald Trump have been trading barbs over the latter's tax returns. The war of words between the two began on Wednesday, when Romney, in a Fox News interview, suggested that there might be something amiss in Trump's tax returns.

"We're now, you know, in late February and we still have not seen either Donald Trump's or Marco Rubio's or Ted Cruz's taxes," Romney told Fox's Neil Cavuto. "Frankly, the voters have a right to see those tax returns before they decide who our nominee ought to be."

Romney's comments were specifically directed at Trump's tax returns, which he described as "likely to be a bombshell." Trump, however, has only said that his campaign will "make that determination over the next couple of months."

Trump's response to Romney's comments was swift and scathing. He tweeted, "Mitt Romney, who totally blew an election that should have been won and whose tax returns made him look like a fool, is now playing tough guy — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 24, 2016."

Since that first tweet, Trump has continued to lash out at Romney with a series of personal attacks. He labeled Romney "one of the dumbest and worst candidates in the history of Republican politics" and called him a "dope." He also promised that he was "going to do what @MittRomney was totally unable to do- WIN!"

Trump has also enlisted the help of his Twitter followers, reposting their attacks on Romney. One such tweet read, "@ahernandez85a: @realDonaldTrump Mr. Tough Guy Romney should be backing Trump like Trump backed him last time # NoLoyalty" — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 25, 2016.

The attacks are expected to continue on the Republican debate stage Thursday night, where the remaining five GOP candidates will gather for their last bout before the Super Tuesday nominating contests. The debate will air on CBS at 8:30 PM ET.

Title: Attorney General Eric Holder Faces Congressional Scrutiny Over AP Phone Records, Alleges Shoddy Conduct by Rep. Darrell Issa

Article:

In a heated exchange at a congressional hearing on Wednesday, Attorney General Eric Holder accused Republican Rep. Darrell Issa of shoddy conduct, following allegations that Holder had purposely withheld information from Congress. The hearing, which focused on a series of scandals, including the government's secret collection of AP phone records, saw Holder grilled on his role in the AP case and other allegations.

The exchange between Holder and Issa, who has been a vocal critic of Holder regarding the botched Operation Fast and Furious, took place during a House Judiciary Committee hearing. Lawmakers pressed Holder on the AP case, expressing frustration when Holder repeatedly claimed he was not involved in the decision-making process.

Rep. James Sensenbrenner, a bipartisan lawmaker, questioned Holder about the Justice Department's secret collection of telephone records. Holder responded that he had recused himself from the case because he was a "possessor of information eventually leaked." He also said he was unable to answer questions about why the department failed to negotiate with the AP before obtaining subpoenas, a standard practice in such cases.

Holder testified that all the decisions made in the case fell on Deputy Attorney General James Cole's shoulders. Sensenbrenner suggested having Cole testify before the House Judiciary Committee, but noted that he would be prohibited from discussing any ongoing case, likely yielding few answers.

Rep. John Conyers, a Democrat, expressed concern about the government's actions, but was unable to pull any new information about the AP case from Holder. On Monday, AP President and CEO Gary Pruitt disclosed the government's action in a letter to Holder, calling the collection of phone records at four AP bureaus a "massive and unprecedented intrusion" of the news agency's freedom of press rights.

The AP case has sparked bipartisan outrage, with members of both parties publicly questioning the government's actions. Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus called for Holder's resignation, stating, "Freedom of the press is an essential right in a free society." Holder acknowledged Priebus' calls for his resignation during his opening remarks, but reiterated that he was not behind the subpoena.

In response to the AP case, New York Sen. Charles Schumer plans to reintroduce legislation that would protect journalists from revealing their sources. The bill, which was brought up in 2009, has since stalled in Congress.

Under Holder's command, the Justice Department has prosecuted more government officials for alleged leaks under the World War I-era Espionage Act than all of the AGs who came before him – combined. The Obama administration has been aggressive in going after government workers leaking classified information, with the White House bringing indictments against five workers and the Defense Department pursuing a sixth case against a U.S. Army soldier accused of sending classified documents to the anti-secrecy online group WikiLeaks.

Title: Texas Senator Ted Cruz Announces 2016 Presidential Bid: A Comprehensive Look at His Strengths as a GOP Candidate

Article:

In a move that marks the beginning of the 2016 Republican presidential race, Texas Senator Ted Cruz officially announced his candidacy on Monday. As the first major contender to declare, Cruz presents several compelling reasons that make him a strong GOP candidate for the upcoming election.

1. Early Start: Cruz is expected to launch his campaign immediately, rather than forming an exploratory committee, a strategy often adopted by potential candidates.

2. Tea Party Support: Amy Kremer, former head of the Tea Party Express, told The Associated Press that Cruz's announcement will significantly boost the Republican field, exciting the base in a way not seen in years.

3. Obamacare Opponent: Cruz is known for his vocal opposition to Obamacare. In September 2013, he spoke for over 21 hours on the Senate floor in an attempt to defund the Affordable Care Act.

4. Strong Immigration Stance: Cruz has taken a firm position on immigration, defying GOP leaders to force a vote on opposing President Barack Obama's executive action on immigration, despite the strategy's ultimate failure.

5. Independent Image: Cruz's defiance of party leaders on immigration issues demonstrates his independence, an appealing quality to voters frustrated with Washington's partisan politics.

6. Mainstream Republican Views: Unlike some fellow candidates, Cruz aligns with the mainstream of Republican voters on most issues. For instance, Jeb Bush supports legalization for undocumented immigrants, a stance many Republican activists oppose, while Rand Paul supported normalizing relations with Cuba.

7. Campaigning Skills: Cruz demonstrated his strong campaigning abilities in the 2012 election, defeating David Dewhurst in the Texas GOP primary despite Dewhurst's significant financial advantage.

8. Potential Appeal to Hispanic Voters: Cruz's father was born in Cuba, and he is the first Hispanic U.S. Senator from Texas. This could make him more appealing to Hispanic voters than other GOP candidates.

9. Past Election Analysis: Cruz argues that the GOP needs a strong conservative to win the general election, citing past elections where a more moderate candidate resulted in voter apathy.

10. Bipartisan Appeal: Cruz's campaign could potentially attract disillusioned voters from both parties, as people look for something new and different.

11. Legal Background: Cruz has a strong legal background, having earned his law degree at Harvard University and clerked for Supreme Court Chief Justice William Rehnquist.

12. Campaign Asset: Cruz's wife, Heidi Cruz, is a significant asset in the campaign. She worked on George W. Bush's 2000 presidential campaign, served at the National Security Council under Condoleezza Rice and at the Treasury Department, and most recently was a managing director for Goldman Sachs in Houston. She has taken an unpaid leave to help her husband's campaign.

As the 2016 presidential race unfolds, Cruz's early start, strong Tea Party support, and unwavering conservative stance make him a formidable contender in the Republican field.

Title: Four Major Corporations Explain Payments to Michael Cohen's Shell Company Amidst Allegations of Hush Money

Article:

In the wake of attorney Michael Avenatti's recent claim that a shell company linked to Michael Cohen, Essential Consultants LLC, received large sums from companies potentially influenced by Trump administration decisions, these corporations are now providing explanations for their payments to Cohen.

Essential Consultants LLC, a single-member LLC solely owned by Cohen, has been described in court documents as a real estate consulting company. The company was created and registered in Delaware less than a month before the 2016 election, with no known employees, website, or physical office space.

Here's what the corporations say they paid Cohen's company for:

1. Korean Aerospace Industries, a defense contractor, paid $150,000 to Essential Consultants for "legal consulting concerning accounting standards on production costs." The company claims it was unaware of Cohen's connection to Donald Trump.

2. AT&T paid Cohen $600,000 for "help understanding how the President and his administration might approach a wide range of policy issues, including regulatory reform at the FCC, corporate tax reform, and antitrust enforcement."

3. Swiss pharmaceutical company Novartis paid Cohen $1.2 million for "advice on how the Trump administration might approach certain U.S. healthcare policy matters, including the Affordable Care Act." However, Novartis claims it did not meet with Cohen until a month after the contract was signed and decided not to engage further with him.

4. Columbus Nova, a New York investment firm, paid Cohen $500,000 for "business consulting regarding potential sources of capital and potential investments in real estate and other ventures." Columbus Nova's CEO is the cousin of a Russian billionaire, Viktor Vekselberg, who controls the Renova Group. The Renova Group's website previously listed Columbus Nova as a subsidiary, but the pages have since been taken offline.

In the same period that Essential Consultants was involved in nondisclosure payments to adult film star Stormy Daniels and former Playboy model Karen McDougal, these four entities paid Cohen millions of dollars for advice about accounting standards, telecom reform, tax policy, antitrust law, the Affordable Care Act, and high-end investment opportunities. Additionally, one of the companies that paid Cohen, Novartis, is now downplaying a previously disclosed connection to a Russian billionaire affected by economic sanctions.

Title: Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Refers Michael Avenatti and Julie Swetnick to Justice Department for Criminal Investigation

Article:

In a move that has further escalated the already contentious confirmation battle for Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh, Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley has referred attorney Michael Avenatti and his client, Julie Swetnick, to the Justice Department for criminal investigation. The referral stems from Swetnick's unsubstantiated allegation that Kavanaugh participated in a gang-rape ring while in high school.

The referral comes amidst the heated, partisan battle over Kavanaugh's confirmation, sparked by Christine Blasey Ford's allegation of sexual assault. Avenatti, who publicized Swetnick's claims, presented them to the Committee on September 26 in a sworn statement. However, Swetnick later retracted her claims during an October 1 interview with NBC News, conceding that she never witnessed Kavanaugh spike anyone's drink or participate in gang rape.

In a lengthy letter to Attorney General Jeff Sessions, Grassley outlined his rationale for the referral, stating, "When a well-meaning citizen comes forward with information relevant to the committee's work, I take it seriously. It takes courage to come forward, especially with allegations of sexual misconduct or personal trauma." He further added, "But in the heat of partisan moments, some do try to knowingly mislead the committee. That's unfair to my colleagues, the nominees, and others providing information who are seeking the truth."

Grassley emphasized that the law prohibits false statements to Congress and obstruction of congressional committee investigations. He stated, "I don't take lightly making a referral of this nature, but ignoring this behavior will just invite more of it in the future."

In response to the referral, Avenatti expressed his support, tweeting, "Maybe if Grassley was actually a lawyer that knew something about the law, he would realize what he has done. He just opened up Pandora's box as it relates to Justice Kavanaugh's conduct. It is Christmas in October!" and "Ironically, Senator Grassley now is interested in investigations. He didn't care when it came to putting a man on the SCOTUS for life. We welcome the investigation as now we can finally get to the bottom of Judge Kavanaugh's lies and conduct. Let the truth be known."

The referral marks a significant development in the ongoing controversy surrounding Kavanaugh's confirmation, with the Justice Department now tasked with investigating the allegations made by Swetnick and Avenatti. The outcome of this investigation remains to be seen.

Title: President Trump Discusses a Range of Topics in "60 Minutes" Interview, Including Climate Change, North Korea, and Trust in Kim Jong Un

Article:

In a wide-ranging interview with "60 Minutes" that aired Sunday night, President Donald Trump addressed a variety of subjects, including North Korea, Brett Kavanaugh's Supreme Court nomination process, and the 2016 election. During the interview, Trump engaged in verbal sparring with "60 Minutes" anchor Lesley Stahl, at one point telling her, "In the meantime, I'm the president – and you're not."

The interview also touched on several other topics, including climate change. When asked about the impact of Hurricane Michael, one of the most powerful hurricanes in U.S. history, Trump and Stahl debated the issue.

"I think something's happening. Something's changing and it'll change back again. I don't think it's a hoax, I think there's probably a difference. But I don't know that it's manmade," Trump said.

Stahl pressed Trump on his views on climate change, to which he responded, "I'm not denying climate change. But it could very well go back. You know, we're talking about over millions of years."

When Stahl asked Trump to acknowledge the findings of scientists regarding climate change, he replied, "You'd have to show me the scientists because they have a very big political agenda, Lesley."

Trump also discussed his relationship with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, stating, "I do trust him, yeah, I trust him." However, he added, "That doesn't mean I can't be proven wrong about (denuclearization)."

Stahl also brought up first lady Melania Trump's comments in an ABC News interview last week, in which she said she didn't trust everyone in the White House. Trump agreed with his wife, stating, "I feel the same way. I don't trust everyone in the White House, I'll be honest with you."

The interview also touched on the 2016 election, with Trump stating that there was interference, but not just from Russia. "They meddled. But I think China meddled, too," Trump said when asked if he believed Russia had run interference in the last presidential election.

When asked about the current state of the country and the need for unity, Trump lamented the Democrats' treatment of Brett Kavanaugh during his Supreme Court nomination process and stated, "I don't think they want to heal yet."

To close the interview, Trump was asked about finding his "sea legs" as president. While he initially found it "a little surreal to say I'm President of the United States," he quickly added, "Now, I very much feel like POTUS. I do. I feel like the president."

Title: Understanding the Collapse of the American Health Care Act: A Closer Look at the GOP's Internal Struggles

Article:

The collapse of the American Health Care Act (AHCA) last week has left many questioning the political acumen of President Trump and Speaker Paul Ryan. The good news is that no one can say President Trump didn't try to persuade House Republicans to pass the AHCA. He invited lawmakers to the White House, dispatched his key aides to Capitol Hill, worked the phones, cajoled, charmed, arm-twisted, threatened, but failed to understand the reasons behind the GOP's reluctance to vote for the bill.

President Trump and Speaker Ryan chose to cancel the vote on the AHCA late Friday afternoon. Earlier this week, the loudest argument from Trump was that if House Republicans didn't pass the bill, it could cost the GOP their majority in 2018. This may or may not be true; it's also possible that passing a disappointing replacement could cost the GOP their majority. Either way, Trump went so far as to threaten primary challenges to those who didn't sign on.

However, it wasn't the fear of such threats or nonchalance about keeping their majority that held House Republicans back. Instead, they simply didn't like what was in the bill and didn't have faith that the Senate would improve it or that it would get better in conference committee. At least for now, a significant number of House Republicans fear the consequences of passing an insufficient bill more than the consequences of failing to pass a bill.

Some Republicans felt that the AHCA wouldn't do enough to lower premiums, which many consumers find too high.
