The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) score said that the bill would reduce the costs of insurance eventually, but increase them in the first three years. It's fair to ask whether voters would feel warm to Republicans in fall of 2018 if a GOP replacement plan passed and they still found themselves paying too much for too little care.

Some House Republicans want to repeal Obamacare's requirement that insurance plans cover outpatient care, emergency-room visits, hospitalization, maternity and newborn care, mental-health and addiction treatment, prescription drugs, rehabilitative services, lab services, preventive care, and pediatric services. On the one hand, mandating so much coverage does add to the costs of insurers, raising premiums. On the other hand, consumers like being comprehensively covered.

It appears President Trump cared a lot more about getting a win than about what, exactly, he would be winning. Others contended that the replacement just worked too much like Obamacare to meet their standards. Mo Brooks of Alabama declared, "It doesn't deliver on the promise I made to fully repeal Obamacare." Representative Rick Crawford of Arkansas tweeted that "the bill currently maintains [Obamacare's] overall structure/approach, an approach that cements the federal government's role in health insurance."

Conservative health-policy wonks had their own objections. Avik Roy pointed out that the AHCA "would lead to significant spikes in net insurance premiums for lower-income participants in the individual insurance market, with particular problems for those in their fifties and sixties."

These are thorny issues that involve trade-offs. You can try to sweep away everything that's bad about Obamacare, but there's no way to do that without disrupting millions of voters' lives. You can try to control costs, but that's hard to do without limiting benefits. You can't enact some of Republicans' favorite proposals, such as tort reform and selling insurance across state lines, without either some support from Senate Democrats or the elimination of the filibuster.

As House Freedom Caucus chair Mark Meadows put it, almost no one in his caucus wanted to vote no. They wanted to get to yes but simply didn't see enough good in the bill to make voting for it worthwhile. A strong leader can help sort out conflicting priorities, but there's little sign that President Trump had any interest in that role. Throughout the last days of arm-twisting, there were ominous reports that he was quite passionately attempting to persuade House Republicans to pass the bill, without really understanding what was in the legislation that made them so reluctant to vote for it. An unnamed House GOP aide told CNN that when it came to the details of the legislation, Trump "either doesn't know, doesn't care, or both."

In the Los Angeles Times, Michael Steel, a former GOP leadership aide, offered a bizarre portrait of a president who's somehow simultaneously eager and clueless:

Ryan has learned that his wonky style of communication is wasted on Trump, given the president's lack of interest in policy details, Steel said. But he has come to value Trump's eagerness to exert pressure on wavering Republicans.

It appears President Trump cared a lot more about getting a win than about what, exactly, he would be winning. And that lack of focus on the details helped deny him the victory he wanted so badly.

Title: Obama Chooses Middle Ground in Syria: Limited Strike as Least Bad Option

Article:

In a move that seems to be leaning towards the least bad option, President Barack Obama appears to be preparing for a limited military strike in Syria. This decision comes after the reported use of chemical weapons in the Syrian civil war, which has claimed the lives of over 100,000 people since its outbreak.

The choice of a limited strike, while risky, is seen as less so than doing nothing or attempting regime change, according to Aaron Miller, a veteran U.S. diplomat and scholar at the Wilson Center. If Obama does not act in response to the large chemical weapons attack, he risks being perceived as ineffective, according to Miller.

The decision to intervene militarily in Syria is a complex one, with three main options: do nothing, do everything, or find a middle ground and muddle through. In the case of Syria, the president seems to have chosen the latter, as the administration has been telegraphing its military action more than ever before.

Secretary of State John Kerry's powerful statement of moral outrage and the president's recent PBS interview have created a strong commitment to strike, making it one of the most authoritative commitments to military action in modern warfare. If Obama does not enforce this commitment, he will be severely damaged in terms of foreign policy for the remainder of his term.

Critics of the president's Syria policy, including Sens. John McCain and Lindsay Graham, have repeatedly called for a more robust policy, suggesting that the president's inaction has enabled the ongoing misery in Syria. They argue that Syria poses a major threat to U.S. interests and to allies in the region, and that only a takedown of the Assad regime through supporting the opposition and direct application of U.S. military power will begin to address the problem.

However, President Obama has avoided this approach due to the general problem of an open-ended military commitment and the lack of correlation between the use of U.S. military power and its relation to the end state. The complexity of the Syrian conflict, with more than 1,000 disparate rebel groups, including those allied with al-Qaeda and other Sunni extremists, makes devising a serious military strategy to get rid of Assad a daunting task.

The limited strike that the U.S. is likely to undertake is focused on deterring the Syrians from using chemical weapons again and degrading Assad's military capacity in the process. While this option is far from ideal, it is unlikely to change the arc of the battlefield balance. There are also other downsides, such as the potential for escalation and the risk of undermining American credibility through episodic intervention without a real strategy.

In conclusion, President Obama's decision to intervene militarily in Syria, albeit in a limited capacity, is a complex and risky move. The president, who has been criticized for his reluctance to use military force, is now faced with the realities of the Syrian conflict and the need to respond to the use of chemical weapons. The choice of a limited strike is a calculated risk, aimed at deterring further chemical weapons use and degrading Assad's military capacity, while avoiding the risks and complexities of a more robust intervention.

Title: "Sanders' Electability: A New Perspective on the 2020 Democratic Race"

Article:

In the ongoing 2020 Democratic presidential race, concerns are mounting among some Democrats that Bernie Sanders' potential nomination could lead to a defeat in the general election and a potential party setback. However, a closer look at the polling data suggests a different narrative.

Virtually every national and swing state poll shows Sanders tied with or beating President Donald Trump. For instance, a Quinnipiac Poll last week indicated Sanders' victory in Michigan and Pennsylvania, while a CBS News/YouGov poll showed him beating Trump nationally. A Texas Lyceum poll shows Sanders performing better against Trump in Texas than any other Democrat, losing by just three points.

One factor that sets Sanders apart is his significant social media presence. He has larger followings on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and other platforms than his rivals, and has consistently demonstrated new media sophistication that others lack.

Another crucial factor is Sanders' loyal base. His supporters are not only financially committed, making him the best-funded non-billionaire in the Democratic game, but they also show up at rallies, on social media, and in elections. This level of dedication is something that Trump himself has acknowledged as a significant factor in his own success.

Sanders' self-proclaimed big government socialism, a point of contention for some, has not seemed to deter voters. In fact, 45% of the electorate does not seem to be bothered by Trump's outlandishness, suggesting that Sanders' socialist leanings may not be a deal-breaker for voters.

Peter Hamby, who works for Snapchat and writes for Vanity Fair, argues that the "bed-wetting" Democrats might be misguided in their assessment of Sanders' electability. Hamby suggests that Sanders, in the age of Trump, hyper-partisanship, institutional distrust, and social media, could be the most electable Democrat.

Hamby posits that Sanders, with his Trump-like celebrity status, is well-positioned to win the attention war, a crucial aspect of any presidential campaign. "Running for president has always been about winning the attention war, and the competition for attention has never been more difficult than it is in 2020," Hamby writes.

In conclusion, the 2020 Democratic race remains unpredictable, and it is impossible to know with certainty what voters want or will accept. However, the evidence, particularly the polling data, suggests that Sanders could be the most electable Democrat in the race.

Title: Texas Legislature Passes Controversial Abortion Bill, Prompting Promise of Legal Challenge and Vows of Continued Resistance

AUSTIN, Texas — The Texas Legislature has passed an omnibus abortion bill, one of the most restrictive in the nation, which is expected to face legal challenge and political resistance. The bill, which bans abortions after 20 weeks, requires abortion doctors to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital, and mandates all abortions to take place in surgical centers, was passed unchanged just before midnight on Saturday.

The Republican majority in the Legislature passed the bill despite Democratic opposition, with all but one Democrat voting against it. The bill's passage follows more than 2,000 demonstrators filling the Capitol building in Austin to oppose the measure, with state troopers removing six protesters from the Senate chamber for attempting to disrupt the debate.

Governor Rick Perry, who will sign the bill into law in the coming days, stated, "Today the Texas Legislature took its final step in our historic effort to protect life." Perry added, "This legislation builds on the strong and unwavering commitment we have made to defend life and protect women's health."

Sen. Royce West, a Democrat, vowed, "There will be a lawsuit. I promise you."

Democrats offered 20 amendments to the bill, ranging from exceptions for rape and incest to allowing doctors more leeway in prescribing abortion-inducing drugs. However, Republicans rejected all amendments.

The bill is part of a series of measures championed by anti-abortion groups aiming for a constitutional challenge to Roe vs. Wade, the U.S. Supreme Court decision that guarantees a woman's right to decide on an abortion before the fetus is viable outside the womb.

The 5th Circuit Court of Appeals, to which Texas falls under, has shown a willingness to accept more stringent limits on abortions. Passing the law also appeases Christian conservatives, who make up the majority of Republican primary voters.

However, the measure has sparked protests in Texas not seen in at least 20 years, with thousands of abortion rights supporters flooding the Capitol to draw out normally boring committee hearings and disrupting key votes. Protesters finished a filibuster started by Democratic Sen. Wendy Davis of Fort Worth by jeering for the last 15 minutes of the first special session, effectively killing the bill.

Title: Investigative Report: EPA's Collusion with Environmental Groups Alleged in "Sue and Settle" Controversy

Article:

In a recent U.S. Chamber of Commerce study, it has been revealed that the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has been granting unprecedented access to radical environmental groups during the drafting of environmental regulations, while excluding the industries and people most likely to be affected. This allegation, if true, could have far-reaching implications for millions of Americans.

The study found that the Sierra Club, WildEarth Guardians, the Natural Resources Defense Council, the Center for Biological Diversity, and the Environmental Defense Fund have all had significant influence on EPA policy decisions. These groups have reportedly participated in "closed-door deals" with the EPA 64 times since 2009, with the EPA striking 34 deals with the Sierra Club alone.

The controversy revolves around a legal technique known as "sue and settle," where environmental groups file lawsuits against federal agencies, and the agencies settle the suits in closed-door meetings, often resulting in regulations that are detrimental to industries and job creation. These settlements, which bypass the public comment period, allow the EPA to implement policies favored by the environmental groups and the Obama administration.

Sen. David Vitter (Louisiana Republican) has highlighted a case involving the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and the Center for Biological Diversity over endangered-species rules. The settlement could lead to federal control over private lands in states like New Mexico, Texas, Oklahoma, Colorado, and Kansas, which are major oil and natural gas producers.

Rep. Tim Huelskamp (Kansas Republican) has criticized these settlements, stating, "The bird is so populous that it is hunted in Kansas. This is not about preservation of a species — it’s about federal control of private landowners and limiting the ability to develop and grow rural America."

The "sue and settle" litigation has reportedly taken a toll on industries, consumers, and state treasuries across the nation. For instance, a suit filed by WildEarth Guardians has led to eight states spending millions to comply with EPA regulations to improve visibility in national parks and wilderness areas. The settlement agreement allows the EPA to exert its authority over state haze-mitigation plans, expanding its power base and increasing utility costs for consumers.

A "sue and settle" case involving the Navajo Generating Station could result in electricity costs for Arizonans increasing by an estimated 20 percent annually. A case involving the potential impact of 200 pesticides has been called "the mother of all lawsuits," with the potential to cause "severe economic harm and loss of jobs to tens of thousands of farmers" across the country.

The high costs for consumers are not the only concern. Under federal law, taxpayers are also responsible for covering the environmental groups' legal bills. Between 1995 and 2010, Earth Justice was paid nearly $4.7 million, the Sierra Club received about $967,000, and the Natural Resources Defense Council got more than $252,000.

The EPA's alleged complicity in the "sue and settle" method of promulgating regulations has raised serious questions about the agency's accountability and direction. The apparent collusion between the EPA and environmental groups, as well as the agency's stonewalling of Freedom of Information Act requests, has led to concerns about the EPA's focus on its primary mission: "to protect human health and the environment based on the best available scientific information."

Former Republican member of the House of Representatives, Bob Beauprez, has criticized the EPA, stating, "Science has taken a back seat to a green ideology that puts politics before 'we the people.'" The American Traditions Institute has sued the EPA for failing to respond to a Freedom of Information Act request for details about these questionable alliances.

As the EPA continues to face allegations of collusion and stonewalling, it remains to be seen how these developments will impact the agency's future and its relationship with the industries and people it is meant to serve.

Title: Senate Passes Bipartisan Budget Agreement, but Partial Government Shutdown Looms as House Faces Internal Divisions

Article:

WASHINGTON — The Senate has passed a two-year budget agreement, which, if approved by the House, would increase defense and domestic spending by over $400 billion. However, a partial government shutdown is imminent as Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) blocked the bill from passing before a midnight deadline.

The budget deal, negotiated by congressional leaders and released late Wednesday, hit a snag when Sen. Paul demanded a vote on restoring the 2011 budget caps that limited congressional spending. Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) refused to allow the vote, and Paul refused to back down.

The Senate will proceed to vote on the measure, which includes short-term federal funding through March 23. However, federal funding from the last short-term spending bill expires at midnight. If the Senate approves it, the 652-page budget bill would then go to the House, where it faces stiff opposition from liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans.

The budget agreement eliminates the budget caps, paving the way for Congress to increase defense spending by $165 billion and hike domestic spending by $131 billion over the next two years. The measure includes a major disaster relief package for regions hard-hit by last year's devastating storms and a one-year suspension of the debt limit.

President Trump offered a full-throated endorsement of the deal in a Wednesday evening tweet, saying "Republicans and Democrats must support our troops and support this Bill."

Senate Democratic Leader Charles Schumer (D-N.Y.) and Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) have both championed the agreement as a bipartisan breakthrough that would end the destabilizing cycle of short-term spending bills.

"No one would suggest it's perfect, but we worked hard to find common ground and stay focused on serving the American people," McConnell said Wednesday.

With the backing of the two Senate leaders, the bill is expected to win bipartisan support in that chamber. However, its fate in the House remains unclear, with both Democrats and Republicans facing internal party divisions over the deal.

Defense hawks and moderate Republicans said it's a strong compromise that will provide a much-needed boost to the military. However, conservatives called it a budget-busting proposal that would further sink the country in a sea of red ink.

Democrats are also conflicted because while the deal would increase spending for their favored domestic programs, the agreement does nothing to protect the DREAMers, the undocumented immigrants brought to the U.S. as children.

House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) delivered a record-breaking 8-hour speech on the House floor Wednesday, telling the stories of DREAMers without a break to object to the budget plan's failure to protect those immigrants.

If conservative Republicans in the House oppose the agreement, House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) will need a significant number of Democratic votes to get it passed. However, Rep. Steny Hoyer (D-Md.), the Democratic whip, urged his members to line up in opposition to the deal.

"This package leaves DREAMers isolated, without a path to resolution in the House," Hoyer's notice to House Democrats states.

If it passes both chambers, it would give Congress six weeks to craft a spending bill for the rest of 2018 that meets the new budget targets before the government runs out of money again.

Title: FBI Investigation and the Clinton-Weiner Connection: A Retrospective on the Clinton's 35-Year Political Career

Article:

In the final stretch of the 2016 presidential race, the FBI's investigation into Hillary Clinton's email server has become a significant factor, casting a shadow over her campaign. This article takes a retrospective look at the Clinton's 35-year political career, focusing on their relationship with the FBI and the controversy surrounding Huma Abedin and her husband, Anthony Weiner.

Hillary Clinton, the Democratic Party's presumptive nominee, has kept Huma Abedin, a woman married to a man embroiled in multiple scandals, on her highest-level staff. Anthony Weiner, a former Congressman, has been involved in two scandals, the first of which led to his resignation from Congress and his failed bid for Mayor of New York.

Despite Weiner's scandalous past, Clinton has maintained Abedin on her team. This raises questions about Clinton's judgment, particularly in light of her long-standing commitment to children's advocacy. Some argue that Clinton, with years of child advocacy behind her, should have addressed Weiner's inappropriate behavior and questionable judgment.

The latest controversy involves the discovery of 650,000 emails, many containing classified information, on Weiner's laptop. Former FBI agents have expressed concern that these classified documents may now be in the hands of America's enemies, with the Russians mentioned as a potential threat.

The Clinton-FBI relationship dates back to the 1980s, with FBI Special Agent I.C. Smith questioning Clinton's role in fundraising for her husband, Governor Bill Clinton, in Arkansas. The relationship continued into the 1990s, culminating in 1997 when then-FBI Director Louis Freeh compared his experiences with the Clintons to his 16 years doing organized crime cases in New York City.

This summer, the relationship reached a climax with the investigation into Clinton's email server, led by Director James Comey. Although Comey did not recommend an indictment in July as many observers expected, he did emphatically state that Clinton had lied to the bureau in her testimony and that her handling of classified information was "extremely careless."

The FBI's investigation and Comey's statements have left many questioning Clinton's judgment and her fitness for the presidency. The controversy has also led to comparisons between the Clintons and a "crime family," as described by former assistant FBI director James Kallstrom.

As the election approaches, the FBI's investigation into Clinton's email server has become a significant factor, raising questions about Clinton's judgment and her relationship with the FBI. The investigation, and the controversy surrounding Huma Abedin and Anthony Weiner, has cast a shadow over Clinton's campaign and her 35-year political career.

Title: Supreme Court Upholds Indiana Abortion Remains Law, Sparking Nationwide Debate

Article:

The Supreme Court's recent decision to uphold an Indiana law requiring the burial or cremation of fetal remains following an abortion has reignited the ongoing national debate on abortion. The debate, which has seen a shift in recent years, is increasingly dominated by extremists on both sides.

The political left, once advocating for the Bill Clinton standard of "safe, legal, and rare," has become more comfortable with expanded abortion rights. This shift is evident in the "Shout Your Abortion" movement and abortion-rights-expanding bills in states like Virginia, New York, and elsewhere.

On the other hand, the right has responded with its own extreme counterpart, as seen in the recent Alabama law, which bans abortion except to protect the life of the mother and imposes serious jail time for abortion providers.

However, the debate is not just a political one. It is also a scientific debate, as advancing neonatal research and technology reveals more detail about life in the womb. This challenges the notion of thinking about the fetus as a clump of cells beyond the early weeks of pregnancy.

The challenge is that this advancing science denies us the luxury of self-delusion about the fetus. Yet, it does not necessarily mean that abortion should be outlawed. Instead, it calls for an adjustment in our thinking on the issue.

The silent majority of Americans, often overlooked in the extremist debate, is held hostage by the intractable extremities. As we all know, extremists are fixated on principle and purity, not on pragmatism, compromise, and real-world concerns.

For the moderates, the issue simplifies itself: Banning abortion is out of the question because it will only drive it underground, but most of us can manage our moral discomfort enough to be OK with abortion early in the pregnancy, in cases of rape, incest, and for the life of the mother, and in rare, wrenching cases, later-term abortion to protect the life of the mother.

The phrase "the life of the mother" carries meaning. When supplemented with "the health of the mother," as in the New York law, pro-lifers, understandably, worry about the abuse of the exception.

Meanwhile, a few loose ends remain. If liberals want science to be respected on the climate issue, they must respect the science on abortion as well. They should realize that as gestation advances, a fetus comes closer to being a baby, and elective abortion up to the time of delivery essentially means terminating a human who deserves dignity and has rights.

Similarly, the pro-life community should be more supportive of more freely available birth control and more support for pregnant women, especially from impoverished backgrounds.

In an age of abortion extremism, let's be clear: Either side winning completely is to enter a realm of dystopia. This article is a call for moderation, compromise, and a recognition of the complexity and gravity of the issue at hand.

Title: Lawmakers Call for Trump Administration to Outline Syria Strategy Following Missile Strikes

Article:

Following the U.S. missile strikes in Syria in response to the apparent chemical weapons attack by Syrian President Bashar Assad, lawmakers on Capitol Hill are urging the Trump administration to outline a broader strategy for the region.

Senate Armed Services Chairman John McCain (R-Ariz.) told MSNBC on Friday morning that the strikes were appropriate, but cautioned that the situation in the Middle East is complex and requires a long-term strategy. "It's the end of the beginning, not the beginning of the end," McCain said, quoting Winston Churchill.

McCain added that the Middle East is in chaos, Europe is being destabilized, and the Islamic State is spreading throughout the world. He emphasized that the challenges of Bashar al-Assad and the Islamic State are significant, and there is much more to be done.

Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) also urged the administration to collaborate and elaborate on the strategy moving forward. "In the days ahead, I am committed to working with the administration to continue developing a counter-ISIL strategy that hastens the defeat of ISIL and establishes objectives for dealing with the Assad regime in a manner that preserves the institutions of government in an effort to prevent a failed state," he said.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) said late Thursday that making sure Assad knows that he will pay a price for committing such atrocities is the right thing to do. He added that the Trump administration needs to come up with a strategy and consult with Congress before implementing it.

Senators were scheduled to hold a classified briefing with military and intelligence officials on Friday afternoon. The Senate adjourned for a two-week Spring recess, while the House has already left town for the break.

Some Democrats, as well as at least two Republicans, are questioning the strikes' constitutionality. The military action is reviving debate over Congress's role in the matter and whether the president needs to obtain congressional authorization for any prolonged military engagement in the region.

Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.), who favors a more isolationist foreign policy approach, wrote on Twitter that the president needs Congressional authorization for military action as required by the Constitution. Rep. Justin Amash (R-Mich.) echoed Paul's remarks, stating that airstrikes are an act of war and cannot justify a departure from the Constitution, which vests in Congress the power to commence war.

Rep. Barbara Lee (D-Calif.), a prominent liberal supporter of Congress passing a new authorization for the use of military force (AUMF), characterized the airstrikes as an act of war on Twitter. She tweeted that she was the lone vote against the 2001 AUMF and that Syria strikes are far beyond the scope of this war authorization.

President Trump, like President Barack Obama before him, has launched airstrikes against ISIS targets using the 2001 war authorization Congress passed after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, as legal justification. However, lawmakers are split over whether that justification covers attacks against the Assad government.

House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) said the strike was "appropriate and just" and signaled that he also wants the Trump administration to consult Capitol Hill lawmakers on the matter. "I look forward to the administration further engaging Congress in this effort," he said.

Title: Trump Administration Rolls Back CFPB Auto Lending Guidelines, Sparking Controversy Over Fair Lending Practices

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy and raised concerns about fair lending practices, President Donald Trump on Monday signed legislation that undoes a 2013 effort by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) to discourage discrimination in auto lending. The move marks the first time that lawmakers have successfully used their authority under the Congressional Review Act to kill a regulatory action taken by an agency several years in the past.

The guidelines issued by the consumer bureau outlined steps that lenders should take to address discrimination by auto dealers, who often determine the terms for car loans that they help facilitate for their customers. With the backing of auto dealers and lenders, Republicans who drove the rollback argued that the CFPB should have followed formal rule-making procedures and sought more public feedback before issuing the guidelines. The 2010 Dodd-Frank law prohibits the bureau from regulating auto dealers. The CFPB guidance was addressed to lenders that fall under the bureau's jurisdiction.

CFPB acting Director Mick Mulvaney praised the move to rescind what he called a "misguided" initiative by his predecessor, who was appointed by President Barack Obama. "I am heartened that the people, through their elected representatives, have corrected this instance of Bureau overreach," Mulvaney said in a statement.

Democrats and consumer watchdogs warned that, in addition to encouraging unfair lending practices, the rollback opened a whole new front in Republicans' deregulation drive under Trump that would be felt well-beyond the CFPB. They argue that the move could lead to discriminatory practices in auto lending, particularly against minority groups.

"This controversial abuse of the CRA should never have been allowed to happen in the first place," said Amit Narang, regulatory policy advocate at Public Citizen. "By signing it, President Trump is turning his back on consumers by giving auto dealers license to discriminate against minorities."

Mulvaney, who also serves as the White House budget director, said the bureau will "continue to fight unlawful discrimination at every turn." The CFPB said the process clarified that a number of its other guidance documents may be considered rules subject to the Congressional Review Act and that it will "confer with congressional staff and federal agency partners" to identify additional documents to submit to Congress.

Title: Trump's Strong Economy and Job Approval Ratings: A Potential Path to Reelection

Article:

The recent job creation numbers for November, with 266,000 jobs added and the unemployment rate at a 50-year low, have set a clear path for President Donald Trump's reelection bid in 2020. While the debate continues on whether the economic growth is a result of Trump's policies or external factors, historical trends and current polling data suggest that the economy is a significant factor in presidential elections.

In a CNN poll released last month, Trump's overall job approval was 42%, with 54% disapproving. However, when respondents were asked about Trump's handling of the economy, 52% approved, while 40% disapproved. This is the only area in the poll where a majority of respondents approved of the job Trump is doing.

In response to the positive jobs report, Trump took to Twitter to highlight his economic successes. He wrote, "Without the horror show that is the Radical Left, Do Nothing Democrats, the Stock Markets and Economy would be even better, if that is possible, and the Border would be closed to the evil of Drugs, Gangs and all other problems!"

The phrase "It's the economy, stupid" coined by Democratic strategist James Carville during the 1992 presidential campaign, has proven true once again. Incumbent presidents do not lose often, and when they do, it is usually because the economy is perceived to be weak or faltering.

Historically, presidents such as Jimmy Carter, George H.W. Bush, and Gerald Ford have lost reelection bids due to weak economies. The only other president in the last nine decades to lose a bid for reelection was Richard Nixon, but his loss was due in large part to his decision to pardon the man he replaced in office.

The data shows that it is very difficult to beat an incumbent president unless the economy is seen by a majority of the public to be weakening badly. Voters consistently cite the economy as the most important issue affecting their vote, with 52% saying so in the 2016 election, 59% in the 2012 election, and 63% in the 2008 election.

However, Trump's unique personality and unpredictable behavior could impact his chances of winning a second term. While his approval numbers on the economy have been strong for much of the past few years, his overall job approval numbers have never shown that a majority approve of the job he is doing overall. Additionally, Trump's inability to stay on message could negatively impact his reelection bid.

In conclusion, the strong economy and Trump's job approval ratings on the economy provide a clear path for Trump's reelection bid. However, Trump's unique personality and unpredictable behavior could negatively impact his chances of winning a second term. The economy is Trump's trump card with voters, but he must know how and when to play it effectively.

Title: GOP Faces Moral Dilemma as Roy Moore's Victory in Alabama Senate Race Appears Imminent

Article:

In the final stretch of the Alabama Senate special election, the Republican Party finds itself in a precarious position as Roy Moore, the embattled Senate nominee, appears to be gaining momentum. This development has prompted a series of events, with President Donald Trump endorsing Moore and several senators walking back their initial criticisms of the candidate.

On Monday, President Trump endorsed Moore in a tweet and a phone call, urging him to "go get 'em." This endorsement came after several senators, including Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, called for Moore to step aside following allegations of sexual misconduct. However, McConnell, on Sunday, stated that the people of Alabama will decide who they want to send to the Senate, and the Senate will address the matter appropriately a week from Tuesday.

Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah, who was traveling with Trump in Utah, furthered McConnell's rationalization on Monday. Hatch defended Trump's endorsement of Moore, stating that the President had no other choice, as he needs every Republican he can get to push his agenda through. Hatch also addressed the allegations against Moore, stating that many of the alleged actions were decades ago, making it a decision that has to be made by the people in Alabama.

This shift in stance from establishment Republicans, from condemning Moore to leaving the decision to the people of Alabama, is a stark contrast to their initial reactions to the allegations. The change in position is a result of Moore's unwavering commitment to the race and the potential for a victory, as polling suggests Moore's numbers have bounced back after an initial dip following the allegations.

The logic behind this shift in stance is transparently obvious in Hatch's comments about Moore and the race. Hatch's statement that Trump needs every Republican he can get to push his agenda through implies that any Republican, even one facing allegations of sexual misconduct, is better than any Democrat. This logical leap also calls into question the idea that, if Moore wins, Senate Republicans would move to expel him from the chamber, as suggested by Colorado Republican Sen. Cory Gardner (R).

The potential expulsion of Moore from the Senate raises questions about the long-term consequences of the Republican Party's "winning is everything" strategy. Critics argue that this approach risks sacrificing the party's moral high ground in exchange for a two-seat Senate majority. Mitt Romney, the 2012 GOP presidential nominee, tweeted on Monday night that a Moore victory would be a stain on the GOP and the nation, while Matthew Dowd, who handled polling for George W. Bush's presidential campaign, stated that the party has no moral authority to discuss sexual misconduct in politics if they support Moore.

In conclusion, the Republican Party's stance on the Alabama Senate race raises questions about the party's core principles and the potential long-term consequences of prioritizing short-term gains over moral integrity. The party's approach to the Moore allegations highlights the risk of sacrificing the moral high ground in exchange for a single Senate seat.

Title: Senate Rebukes Trump Administration Over ZTE Deal, Amendment to Defense Bill Aims to Reinstate Penalties on Chinese Telecom Company

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, members of the U.S. Senate are gearing up to deliver a stinging rebuke to President Donald Trump's efforts to normalize trade with China, as they seek to reverse the administration's softening of penalties on the Chinese telecom company, ZTE. The amendment, co-sponsored by Sens. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.), Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.), and Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.), aims to prohibit the entire U.S. government from purchasing or leasing equipment from ZTE and a similar telecom company, Huawei, cited for national security risks.

The amendment, added to the annual defense policy bill, would essentially reinstate the original penalties on ZTE, including a seven-year ban on ZTE's ability to purchase U.S. parts. The amendment also aims to restore penalties on ZTE imposed in March 2017 after the company was caught selling equipment to Iran and making false statements assuring it had disciplined executives.

John Cohen, a former acting undersecretary for intelligence at DHS, stated, "China's intelligence agencies regularly embed eavesdropping and other collection tools in technologies sold by Chinese tech firms. China's intelligence services also collaborate with these Chinese tech firms to achieve other intelligence objectives. Allowing ZTE to resume operation will likely cause great concern amongst those intelligence professionals responsible for protecting our national security."

The administration had previously reached a "definitive agreement" with ZTE, which included a billion-dollar fine and ZTE's agreement to install a new, American-picked compliance board. However, ZTE had already agreed to a $1.2-billion dollar fine in the 2017 penalty package.

Senate Republicans have also expressed displeasure over the president's bellicose language towards Canada during the weekend's G7 meeting. While Canada had already announced retaliatory steel and aluminum tariffs on the U.S., it seemed to be Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's comments at a press conference, in which he said Canada would not be "pushed around," that upset the president and his advisors.

The amendment is expected to pass this week, but it remains unclear whether the White House will weigh in on this latest development. Sen. Van Hollen stated that vetoing the entire National Defense Authorization Act defense policy bill, to which the ZTE amendment has been attached, would represent a massive concession to China.

Senate Republicans are also working on a bill that would check the president's ability to impose tariffs on the basis of national security concerns, as he did in the Canada case, without congressional approval. However, the bill seems to be ineligible due to procedural hurdles related to its economic impact. Some Senate Republicans also have concerns that the bill would violate the president's constitutional authority as head of the executive branch.

Sen. John Thune (R-S.D.) noted that some Republicans are opting to give the administration space to negotiate with Canada and other partners in the near term, and that it would be best not to try to rein in the president's authority at the same time. The amendment to the defense bill is expected to pass this week, but the future of the bill remains uncertain.

Title: Progressive Lawmakers, Led by Ocasio-Cortez, Plan to Leverage Banking Ties to Advance Anti-Second Amendment Agenda

Article:

In a move reminiscent of her grilling of Wells Fargo CEO Timothy Sloan, Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) is reportedly planning to use similar tactics to advance her anti-Second Amendment agenda. According to Politico, Ocasio-Cortez and other progressive lawmakers aim to pressure America's financial institutions into taking a stand on some of the country's most divisive issues, including climate change, gun violence, and immigration.

The lawmakers, who hold seats on the powerful House Financial Services Committee and boast a significant following on social media, intend to confront finance industry executives and discourage them from funding oil pipelines, firearms makers, and private prison companies that operate immigration detention centers. Allied activist groups are amplifying the message.

Ocasio-Cortez admitted to Politico that part of the strategy to bring about the changes she desires is to circumvent Congress. "There's more than one way to skin a cat, and not everything has to be done through legislation explicitly," she said. "We can also use the tools that we have here to pressure change in other ways as well."

If history is any indication, this strategy could prove successful. JPMorgan and Wells Fargo announced earlier this month they would cut ties with prisons following pressure from Ocasio-Cortez and progressive activists. The tactic also worked last year against the National Rifle Association (NRA). In the wake of the Parkland, Florida, massacre, millions of Americans boycotted the NRA, which forced First National Bank to sever ties with the pro-gun organization, which supplied the NRA with its branded credit card.

Karen Shaw Petrou, a managing partner at Federal Financial Analytics, told Politico that banks are particularly susceptible to public pressure. "Banks are acutely sensitive about their reputations because they are in a business acutely susceptible to severe and sudden customer attrition if consumers vote with their wallets," she explained. "As a highly regulated business, banks are also acutely aware of how changing reputations alter their political-risk profile and what Congress can do to them when and if desired."

Title: Global Trends in Civic Engagement: A Look at Community Participation and Trust

Article:

In an ongoing quest to understand the dynamics of civic engagement, researchers worldwide are exploring various methods to measure the extent of community involvement. A recent experiment in Perth, Australia, offers an interesting insight into this phenomenon. Researchers left 300 letters on the streets, half of them pre-stamped and half not. The results showed that 92 of the stamped letters were delivered compared to 42 of the unstamped ones.

The experiment aimed to investigate why certain communities showed higher levels of letter delivery, thereby indicating a higher degree of trust and neighborly connections. The findings could potentially provide valuable insights into what fosters community cohesion and trust.

Similar experiments have been conducted in other parts of the world. For instance, in Birmingham, Alabama, local volunteer groups were given small grants for neighborhood improvement projects, such as graffiti removal, by the national group Love Your Block. This initiative led to a decrease in crime due to the increased social cohesion in these neighborhoods.

Civic engagement encompasses a wide range of activities, from community service to voting or even posting a found letter. At its core, civic engagement is characterized by qualities of hope and trust that extend beyond family and friends. While democratic politics and national elections are often considered the pinnacle of civic engagement, President Obama once emphasized that democracy thrives on civic engagement from the bottom up, not governance by experts from the top down.

In a 2016 survey of 140 countries by Gallup, the global state of civic engagement was assessed. The survey ranked countries based on the proportion of their population inclined to give back to their communities. Surprisingly, the top ten countries on the Gallup index included more than just wealthy countries. Myanmar topped the list, with Sri Lanka and Indonesia not far behind.

The survey also revealed that the most common form of giving back to a community was helping a stranger in need (44%), followed by donating money (27%) and volunteering (20%).

Regardless of the method of measurement, civic engagement is the foundation of social peace and economic prosperity. One potential way to cultivate more of it could be to mirror a community's own actions, perhaps by dropping a few letters on the street to see how many are delivered. This could provide valuable insights into the levels of trust and community engagement in different cities and towns.

Title: U.S. Places Hold on World Health Organization Funding Amidst Criticism of Pandemic Response

Article:

In a move that could have significant implications for global health, President Donald Trump announced Tuesday that the U.S. is placing a hold on funding to the World Health Organization (WHO) for 60 to 90 days, pending a review of the organization's handling of the coronavirus pandemic.

Driving the news: Trump accused the WHO of "severely mismanaging and covering up" the coronavirus crisis, adding that the U.S. "has a duty to insist on full accountability."

At a briefing in the Rose Garden, Trump expressed concerns about the effectiveness of U.S. contributions to the WHO, stating, "With the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, we have deep concerns whether America’s generosity has been put to the best use possible."

The U.S. is the WHO's largest donor, contributing more than $400 million to the organization last year. In contrast, China contributes roughly $40 million a year, or less.

Trump's decision comes amidst a series of criticisms leveled at the WHO for its response to the pandemic, particularly its initial stance on travel restrictions and its deference to China. The President has been vocal about his dissatisfaction, tweeting last week, "The WHO really blew it. For some reason, funded largely by the United States, yet very China centric. We will be giving that a good look."

Trump's national security team has reportedly rallied behind him, believing that the U.S. needed to take action beyond public statements to make the WHO feel the impact of its missteps. The decision, according to officials involved in the internal discussions, provides Trump with someone else to blame and a way to deflect from his own handling of the virus.

The President outlined specific complaints that led to his decision to freeze U.S. funding, including the WHO's alleged failure to obtain, vet, and share information in a timely and transparent manner, its failure to investigate credible reports from Wuhan that conflicted with the Chinese government's official accounts, and its delay in declaring a public health emergency, among other criticisms.

Over the past week, officials within the White House's Office of Management and Budget have been working on a menu of options for how to snub the WHO. The most likely route is to reprogram U.S. funding that was allocated to the WHO, moving it to other international organizations that can administer it for comparable purposes, officials said. A more dramatic, but less likely, approach is to send a rescissions package to Congress, rescinding from the federal budget funds already allocated to the WHO.

United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, to whom the WHO reports, issued a statement, saying, "Now is a time for unity in the global battle to push the COVID-19 pandemic into reverse, not a time to cut the resources of the... WHO, which is spearheading and coordinating the global body’s efforts."

The WHO has yet to respond to the U.S.'s decision.

Title: EPA Administrator Lisa Jackson's Alias Email Account Used for Training Certifications

Article:

In a recent development, documents disclosed late last week reveal that former Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Lisa Jackson used a controversial alias email account, [email protected], for completing various technology training courses, including declaring her as a "scholar of ethical behavior." This revelation comes amidst questions about the EPA's compliance with open-records laws.

The new records, part of a series obtained through open-records requests, suggest that Ms. Jackson used the alias email address more extensively than previously known, including for taking required agency computer training under the fake identity. The EPA states that this practice is not unusual, as Ms. Jackson regularly used the alternate address for conducting agency business.

The records show that the Windsor account was awarded certificates for completing online email records management training, the 2010 "No FEAR Act Training Module," and a cybersecurity awareness training course in 2011, where she scored 83 percent. The alias was also recognized as a "scholar of ethical behavior" each year from 2010 through 2012. Ms. Jackson appears to have taken only one training course under her own name, for cybersecurity awareness in 2010.

Christopher Horner, the researcher and senior fellow at the Competitive Enterprise Institute who made the open-records request, commented, "At least her alter ego was up on the law and ethics of federal record-keeping." Mr. Horner first revealed the existence of the alternate addresses last year in his book "The Liberal War on Transparency."

In a letter to Mr. Horner, EPA official Eric W. Wachter, director of the office of the secretariat, stated that it was not unusual for Ms. Jackson to get certified under her alias, as that was the account she was signed in as when she took the online testing. EPA officials claim that Ms. Jackson kept the secondary address to avoid her main email, which was published on the agency's website, being overwhelmed by a flood of public emails. They also assert that previous administrators, including those under Republican President George W. Bush, also had secondary emails for internal use.

However, Republicans argue that Ms. Jackson took the secondary email further than any of her predecessors, as she did not attach her real name to her secondary account. In response to a request from The ███, EPA officials could not say whether those prior administrators ever got certified under any of their aliases.

In a set of emails released to Mr. Horner earlier this year, Ms. Jackson appeared to be using the email to pretend she really was Richard Windsor. Mr. Horner argues that the secondary email matters because it wasn't clear that EPA was searching those records in response to open-records requests for Ms. Jackson's emails. Mr. Horner said that EPA didn't really begin to produce emails from the Richard Windsor account until after he exposed that address.

EPA contends that it did search the Windsor account as part of open-records requests. However, the agency has acknowledged it has fallen short in many transparency areas. In April, acting Administrator Bob Perciasepe wrote a letter to all agency employees, stating they must do a better job of storing emails and computer instant messages, as required by law. He also said all employees would have to retake training classes.

Title: The Legal Minds Behind the Health Care Reform Law's Constitutional Challenge

Article:

In the upcoming Supreme Court decision on the future of President Barack Obama's health care reform law, several legal minds who have played a significant role in challenging the law's constitutionality will likely leave a lasting impact on the court and their careers.

In 2009, when Congress began debating health care reform, the individual mandate, a requirement for nearly all Americans to buy health insurance, was not a major point of contention. However, a group of conservative legal scholars, including Nicholas Rivkin and Paul Casey, began writing articles, including an op-ed in The Wall Street Journal in September 2009, that suggested the mandate could be the bill's Achilles' heel.

Now, the law's future hangs in the balance due to the mandate, with the potential for it to be significantly altered or even repealed.

Rivkin and Casey, constitutional lawyers at the law firm Baker Hostetler, were the first to publicly question the constitutionality of the mandate. Their op-ed in The Wall Street Journal served as the catalyst that sparked a wave of skepticism.

"We concluded pretty quickly that this kind of mandate was beyond the constitutional power of the federal government," Rivkin said in an interview.

In fact, Rivkin and Casey shared similar reservations when a health mandate was proposed in the early 1990s. When it became clear that the 2010 health law was going to pass with a mandate, several states hired Rivkin and Casey to represent them in a lawsuit against the federal government. This lawsuit, which now includes 26 plaintiff states and the National Federation of Independent Business, was filed the day Obama signed the bill into law.

Rivkin represented some states in the district court and won, with Judge Roger Vinson ruling that the mandate was unconstitutional and that the entire law should fall. Rivkin is confident the Supreme Court will rule against the mandate, arguing that the Obama administration has never defined a "limiting principle."

"Every single judge and justice has asked the government, 'If you can do this mandate, what is it that you can not do?'" Rivkin said. "It's all very fine to say the federal government is denied general police powers, but it's pure verbiage, it's meaningless unless there is this limiting principle."

Bill McCollum, the former Florida attorney general who hired Rivkin and Casey and filed the states' lawsuit against the health law, credits the Rivkin-Casey op-ed with igniting his interest in the issue. McCollum assigned lawyers in the Florida attorney general's office to do their own research and concluded that he wanted to challenge the mandate and the law's expansion of Medicaid.

By early 2010, McCollum, who was working with then-South Carolina Attorney General Henry McMaster, asked his fellow attorneys general if they wanted to join. McCollum reported that he received a significant amount of interest, with one Democratic attorney general coming very close to joining but ultimately deciding against it at the last minute due to political concerns.

McCollum said he always thought the constitutional issue would wind up in the country's highest court, but even he was surprised by just how partisan the suit became.

Title: Trump and Fauci Disagree on School Reopening, Economy, and Coronavirus Response

Article:

In an interview with Fox Business Network's Maria Bartiromo, President Donald Trump expressed his belief that political opponents want a slower reopening of the economy to harm him politically in the November election. The president's comments came in the same interview where he also disagreed with Dr. Anthony Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), on the measures needed to reopen schools.

When asked if he thinks his political opponents want him to keep the economy closed going into the presidential election, Trump responded, "Yeah, I do. I do. I think it's a political thing." When pressed on whether such a move would be putting money ahead of lives, Trump countered, "The people that want to see the right thing happen, they agree with me. We have to get our country open."

Trump also criticized Fauci's stance on reopening schools during a Senate Health Committee hearing earlier this week. Fauci did not necessarily weigh in on whether schools should open, but said it's unlikely a vaccine would be ready in time for the school year.

"So [Dr.] Anthony [Fauci] is a good person, a very good person – I've disagreed with him," Trump said. "We have to get the schools open, we have to get our country open, we have to open our country. Now we want to do it safely, but we also want to do it as quickly as possible, we can't keep going like this… You're having bedlam already in the streets, you can't do this. We have to get it open. I totally disagree with him on schools."

Earlier this week, the White House touted the United States' progress on coronavirus testing, a major benchmark many experts and governors have said is necessary to hit before moving to lift stay-at-home orders and business closures. Trump also noted in the interview that young people tend not to get as sick because of the coronavirus and have lower death rates.

However, this point, when made by Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., in the Tuesday Senate hearing, was a concern for Fauci. "We should be humble about what we do not know," Fauci told Paul. "And I think that falls under the fact that we do not know everything about this virus, and we really got to be very careful, particularly when it comes to children."

Trump also noted in the Wednesday morning interview that Fauci has supported his earlier move to restrict travel from China in the earlier stages of the coronavirus outbreak. Fauci, in Senate testimony, warned of new coronavirus outbreaks if states jump "checkpoints" to reopen.

"He said I saved hundreds of thousands of lives, which is what happened," Trump said. "Everybody disagreed when I did that." Trump also criticized the Chinese government, which knew about the coronavirus outbreak when it signed a trade deal with Trump in January.

Trump's comments come despite conservative reopening guidelines released by his own administration that Fauci emphasized need to be followed in his Tuesday testimony. Fauci warned that prematurely lifting coronavirus restrictions, closing schools and businesses, and limiting travel would lead to "suffering and death" and "turn the clock back instead of going forward."

Title: Republican Presidential Candidates Grapple with Immigration Policy as 2016 Campaign Approaches

Article:

As the 2016 presidential campaign heats up, Republicans are facing a significant challenge in crafting a coherent immigration policy that appeases both their conservative primary voters and the general election's Hispanic voters. The issue, which Hillary Clinton has sought to make a defining one, has left the Republican field divided on the question of how to handle the millions of people in the U.S. illegally.

While Clinton forcefully advocates for a pathway to citizenship for many illegal immigrants, the Republican field features a diverse range of positions. Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, who once supported a path to citizenship, now talks about offering legal status instead. Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, who was an architect of a broad immigration bill that included a citizenship path, now favors a piecemeal approach.

Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker has reversed his stance on the issue, now opposing a pathway to citizenship, a position he once supported. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, a critic of offering citizenship to illegal immigrants, has left unanswered the question of whether they should eventually be allowed to earn legal status. Former Texas Governor Rick Perry and former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee both advocate for tightening border security but are vague about further policy.

An Associated Press-GfK survey released May 6 found that 53% of respondents support a path to citizenship, while 50% expressed support for a path to legal status. Among Republicans, only 4 in 10 support allowing immigrants who arrived as children, along with parents of citizens or permanent residents, to legally remain.

The current stances of GOP candidates also present a campaign issue for Clinton, who said while campaigning this week in Nevada that Republicans' refusal to embrace a pathway to citizenship would relegate millions of people to underclass status.

Republican strategist Andy Puzder, chief executive of CKE Restaurants, warned that the biggest risk for Republicans is using the immigration issue as a cudgel to beat each other up, which could harm their chances in the general election. Javier Palomarez, president and CEO of the U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, noted that immigration is a unifying issue and that any candidate who cannot speak to it will have an uphill climb.

In 2012, only 27% of Hispanics voted for Mitt Romney, a steep decline from the 44% who voted for the re-election of President George W. Bush in 2004. The dynamic is far different within the Republican primary electorate than it is sure to be among general-election voters. For Jeb Bush, past support for a pathway to citizenship looms as a potential obstacle to winning the GOP nomination.

Senator Rubio, who is Cuban-American, helped write the 2013 Senate bill that included a path to citizenship for many illegal immigrants, enhanced border security, and other sweeping changes to the immigration system. Mr. Rubio backed away from the legislation after it died in the House. Now he emphasizes the importance of border security and says nothing can be done to put illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship until Americans are convinced the border is secure.

Mr. Walker earlier supported immigration legislation that offered a chance at citizenship to people here illegally. He has since renounced that position and argued that the jobs of U.S. citizens could be threatened by giving citizenship to illegal residents and even, potentially, by expanding legal immigration.

Responding to Clinton's call for a pathway to citizenship, Mr. Walker said on Twitter that her "full embrace of amnesty is unfair to hardworking Americans & immigrants who followed the law to achieve these rights."

Senator Rand Paul (R-Ky.) a year ago seemed to be signaling openness to granting legal status to undocumented workers, but he ended up voting against the Senate immigration bill that included such provisions, saying it didn't do enough to secure the border.

Senator Cruz opposes citizenship for illegal immigrants, but at a session last week with the Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, he deflected questions about whether he would support a pathway to legal status. Mr. Cruz said politicians should stay focused on advancing policies where there is consensus.

Title: Media's Portrayal of Hillary Clinton as 'Inevitable' Sparks Controversy

Article:

The portrayal of Hillary Clinton as the inevitable Democratic nominee for the 2016 presidential election has been a recurring theme in the media since the 2012 election. This narrative gained momentum following a joint interview with Clinton and then-President Barack Obama on "60 Minutes," and was further reinforced by magazine covers and media polls showing Clinton with a significant lead over potential Democratic challengers.

However, this narrative has recently become the subject of criticism, with some media outlets and political strategists arguing that Clinton's campaign-like efforts, despite her insistence that she has not yet decided to run, are a repeat of the mistakes she made in 2008.

In a story published by Buzzfeed, Obama aides and strategists warn that Clinton is building a machine in lieu of a message, and is lumbering toward the Democratic nomination with the same deep vulnerabilities that cost her the nomination eight years earlier.

White House pollster Joel Benenson is quoted as saying, "I just don't see any strategic value in stories positioning her as inevitable or the pre-emptive nominee, and I don't think people who are out there talking about this help her. And I think she should make that clear."

2012 Obama campaign spokesman Ben LaBolt adds, "Even if it is a well-known candidate—sometimes more so—activists, donors, and voters like to see candidates fighting for every vote."

While it is true that Clinton's top-heavy operation proved the media wrong in 2007 and 2008, and that she does not have a clear message, her status as a potential first female president, wife of a controversial ex-president, and a political persona that overshadows all possible rivals, even an incumbent vice president, sets her apart from other front-runners.

Clinton's recent appearance with Univision, where she spoke about her relationship with her daughter Chelsea, is an example of her campaign-style efforts. However, she took no questions from reporters, which has been a point of criticism.

Despite the controversy surrounding her media portrayal, Clinton remains the frontrunner in early polls, leading every major GOP contender by at least 15 points. However, the validity of these polls is questionable, as they are often meaningless in the early stages of an election cycle.

In conclusion, the media's portrayal of Hillary Clinton as the inevitable Democratic nominee has sparked controversy, with some arguing that her campaign-like efforts are a repeat of the mistakes she made in 2008. However, Clinton's unique status as a potential first female president, wife of a controversial ex-president, and a political persona that overshadows all possible rivals, may make it difficult for her to muffle the media's narrative of inevitability.

Title: White House Warnings of Sequester's Impact on Air Travel and Government Services Spark Controversy

The Obama administration's warnings of the potential consequences of upcoming spending cuts, known as the sequester, have sparked debate and concern among lawmakers and the public. In recent days, officials have issued dire warnings of increased forest fires, workplace deaths, and even chicken shortages.

On Tuesday, Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood warned of significant air travel delays across the country as air traffic controllers may be forced off the job due to budget cuts. LaHood suggested that smaller airports, such as the airport at golfing paradise Hilton Head, South Carolina, might have to reduce hours of operation or even temporarily close.

The administration's warnings have raised questions about the impact of the automatic spending cuts set to go into effect on March 1 and the government's ability to find relatively modest savings without cutting essential services.

The Department of Transportation's budget for 2013 is $74.2 billion. The automatic spending cuts would slice $1 billion out of its budget, equating to a cut of less than 1.4 percent. It is worth noting that even if the cuts go into effect, the Department of Transportation will spend more money this year ($73.2 billion) than it spent last year ($72.6 billion).

At a White House briefing, Secretary LaHood was asked if there were other ways to cut without telling air traffic controllers to stay home. LaHood responded, "This has to be a part of it. DOT has 55,000 employees. The largest number of those employees are at the FAA, and the largest number of those employees are controllers, and they're all over the country. There has to be some impact in order to save a billion dollars. A billion dollars is a lot of money."

Another fact lost amidst the dire warnings is that although the cuts go into effect on March 1, most of the impact will not be felt until weeks or even months after that. On March 1, the federal government will give employees 30 days notice that they may have to take unpaid leave (furlough). The first furloughs can not happen until March 31 at the earliest. For employees of the Department of Transportation, the most they will be asked to take is one unpaid day off every two weeks.

Press Secretary Jay Carney insisted at the White House that the administration is not exaggerating when it warns of more forest fires, chicken shortages, and long air travel delays. "I think all of those things come from reduced, you know, numbers of people fighting fires, you know, reduced numbers of people doing inspections of our food, reduced numbers of people, you know, engaging in air traffic control," Carney said. "I mean, those are just the facts."

For more information on the potential consequences of the spending cuts, readers are encouraged to review the Administration's list of 57 Terrible Consequences of the spending cuts compiled by Chris Good of ███.

Title: Donald Trump Jr. Met with UAE and Saudi Arabian Representatives in 2016, Offered Help to Campaign

WASHINGTON (AP) - Donald Trump Jr., the eldest son of U.S. President Donald Trump, met with an envoy representing the crown princes of the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia in August 2016. The meeting was first reported by the New York Times on Saturday and was later confirmed by an attorney representing Trump Jr.

The meeting, held on Aug. 3, 2016, was a chance for the envoy to offer help to the Trump presidential campaign, according to The New York Times. The newspaper said the meeting was arranged by Erik Prince, the founder and former head of private military contractor Blackwater, who also attended the meeting. Joel Zamel, a co-founder of an Israeli consulting firm, was also in attendance.

Alan Futerfas, Trump Jr.'s attorney, said on Saturday that nothing came of the meeting. "Prior to the 2016 election, Donald Trump Jr. recalls a meeting with Erik Prince, George Nader, and another individual who may be Joel Zamel," Futerfas said in an emailed statement. "They pitched Mr. Trump Jr. on a social media platform or marketing strategy. He was not interested and that was the end of it."

A company connected to Zamel also worked on a proposal for a "covert multimillion-dollar online manipulation campaign" to help Trump, utilizing thousands of fake social media accounts, the New York Times report said.

The envoy, Lebanese-American businessman George Nader, told Trump Jr. that the crown princes of Saudi Arabia and the UAE were eager to help his father win the 2016 presidential election, the paper said.

Since 1974, the United States has barred foreign nationals from giving money to political campaigns and it later barred them from donating to political parties. The campaign financing laws also prohibit foreign nationals from coordinating with a campaign and from buying an ad that explicitly calls for the election or defeat of a candidate.

The Saudi and UAE embassies in Washington did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

The Wall Street Journal last month reported that investigators working for U.S. Special Counsel Robert Mueller had met with Zamel, and that Mueller's team was looking into his firm's work and his relationship with Nader.

Mueller is investigating whether Russia meddled in the presidential election and if Moscow colluded with the Trump campaign, as well as whether Trump committed obstruction of justice by trying to thwart the U.S. Department of Justice probe. Trump has denied any collusion with Russia and has called the Mueller investigation a "witch hunt."

The New York Times report said the meetings are an indication that other countries besides Russia may have offered help to Trump's presidential campaign. Mueller's investigators have questioned witnesses in Washington, New York, Atlanta, Tel Aviv, and elsewhere regarding possible foreign help to the campaign, the report said.

Peter Carr, a spokesman for Mueller's team, declined to comment on the report.

Zamel's attorney, Marc Mukasey, said in a statement to AP that his client "offered nothing to the Trump campaign, received nothing from the Trump campaign, delivered nothing to the Trump campaign, and was not solicited by, or asked to do anything for, the Trump campaign."

"Media reports about Mr. Zamel's engaging in'social media manipulation' are uninformed," Mukasey added. "Mr. Zamel's companies harvest publicly available information for lawful use."

Kathryn Ruemmler, Nader's lawyer, told the paper that her client "has fully cooperated with the U.S. special counsel's investigation and will continue to do so."

Erik Prince, who is also the brother of U.S. Education Secretary Betsy DeVos, could not be immediately reached for comment.

Title: U.S.-China Trade Negotiations Resume Amidst Ongoing Disagreements and Uncertainty

President Donald Trump has criticized China for its alleged lack of commitment to purchasing American agricultural products, accusing the nation of "ripping off" the U.S. as trade negotiations resumed in Shanghai following a three-month hiatus. Trump's comments come as the two nations engage in another round of talks aimed at resolving their ongoing trade dispute.

In a series of tweets on Tuesday, Trump stated, "China is doing very badly, worst year in 27 -- was supposed to start buying our agricultural product now -- no signs that they are doing so." He further added, "That is the problem with China, they just don’t come through."

Trump's remarks were made as he departed the White House for Jamestown, Virginia. He also told reporters, "We’re either going to make a great deal or we’re not going to make a deal at all."

Trump also mentioned that he had recently spoken with Chinese President Xi Jinping, but did not provide details about the conversation or its substance. Trump asserted that Beijing is willing to make concessions in trade talks, but he is unsure if he will accept them, and that the decision on reaching a deal ultimately rests with him, not his Chinese counterparts.

China's state media refuted Trump's comments without directly naming him. The People's Daily, the Communist Party's flagship newspaper, said in a commentary that China has no intention of "ripping off" the U.S. and has not done so. The U.S., it said, seemed to have forgotten that it had pledged to "restart negotiations on a basis of equality and mutual respect," instead only hoping to threaten China into making concessions, a tactic that will ultimately fail.

Stocks slid earlier in the day after Trump's criticism of China, with the S&P 500 Index closing lower for a second consecutive day. China's imports of U.S. soybeans dropped to the lowest level since at least 2004.

Trump also warned that if he is re-elected in 2020, China faces a much tougher deal. He said, "They always change the deal in the end to their benefit," adding, "They should probably wait out our Election to see if we get one of the Democrat stiffs like Sleepy Joe." This is a reference to Democratic presidential candidate, former Vice President Joe Biden.

The trade talks between the world's largest economies are taking place amidst a two-day Federal Reserve meeting that started on Tuesday. The U.S. central bank is expected to lower interest rates for the first time in more than a decade, partly due to trade war concerns slowing business investment.

U.S. delegates, including Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, arrived in Shanghai to begin another round of talks with their Chinese counterparts. The Americans attended a dinner at the Fairmont Peace Hotel on Tuesday evening, and talks are scheduled to continue on Wednesday in China's bustling port city.

Expectations for a breakthrough in the trade talks remain low. The two sides are further apart than they were three months ago, when negotiations broke down, and each side blamed the other for derailing attempts to reach a deal. China is pushing for compromise in the talks, with state media underlining this week that the U.S. should meet it "halfway."

The outcome of the Shanghai talks will help determine whether China will resume negotiations from a draft text agreed before the impasse in May, or wait for the 2020 election, or propose a different approach. Michael Pillsbury, director of the Center on Chinese Strategy at the Hudson Institute, said on Tuesday, "This could be real suspense."

It remains unclear what triggered Trump's latest outburst. U.S. soybean exports to China slumped in the first half of the year to the lowest level in more than a decade, while pork sales in June slipped from a month earlier. China has said the purchase of American farming products will be contingent on the U.S. following through on Trump's pledge to allow American companies to resume sales to Huawei Technologies Co. Speaking to reporters at an event in Sao Paulo on Tuesday, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross said he has received more than 50 applications for special licenses for companies to do business with Huawei, and that he and Trump met with "supply chain" representatives last week. The administration put the Chinese telecommunications giant on a trade blacklist in May, which means American firms need a special license issued by the Commerce Department to ship to the company.

Title: Unconventional Pre-Rally Scene: Alex Jones and a Pile of Manure

Article:

In an unexpected turn of events, a bizarre incident involving Infowars' Alex Jones and a pile of manure marked the prelude to President Donald Trump's rally in Houston, Texas, on October 22, 2018.

Journalist Elizabeth Nolan Brown, who was in the vicinity of the Cruz/Trump rally, reported that she encountered Jones, huffing away from the area with a small entourage of men in MAGA hats. As she turned to ask if he had just had a confrontation with protesters, she witnessed Jones taking to the middle of the street to shout at the pile of manure, addressing it as if it were Beto O'Rourke, the Texas Democrat challenging sitting Republican Sen. Ted Cruz in the upcoming midterm elections.

The main event, however, was the rally itself, where President Trump, who earlier in the day had referred to Cruz as "Beautiful Ted," gave a speech that focused more on his administration's achievements and his political opponents than on Cruz. The pre-Trump speakers also seemed to prioritize criticizing O'Rourke over praising Cruz.

One notable point in the president's speech was his emphasis on the confirmation of Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh and his administration's record number of Supreme Court justices appointed in "less than two years."

In a separate development, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is taking action against a website, Aid Access, that has been shipping abortion-inducing drugs from a pharmacy in India to women in the U.S. for the past six months. The FDA claims that the site, run by founder Rebecca Gomperts, is illegally importing the drug mifepristone, which is used in approximately one-third of all first-trimester abortions, and can only be distributed at pre-approved clinics, hospitals, and private practices. The FDA allows personal use of imported medicines, but the distribution of mifepristone is subject to a strict protocol that prevents it from being sold online or in retail pharmacies.
