Title: Obama's "Captive Nations Week" Proclamation Amidst Syria Crisis Sparks Controversy

Article:

In the midst of mounting criticism over his handling of the political and humanitarian crisis in Syria, President Barack Obama signed a "Captive Nations Week" proclamation on Monday. The order, which has been a routine practice by presidents since Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1959, does not directly address the Syrian conflict.

In the proclamation, the president declared, "As individuals rise to demand their universal rights, the United States stands with them in pursuit of equality, justice, and freedom." He further stated, "And as long as there are people who live in the darkness of oppression, America will remain their steadfast friend, linked by a common dream and our common ideals."

The Syrian crisis, where forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad have reportedly killed nearly 15,000 civilians in 16 months of open revolt against the regime, is not mentioned in the proclamation.

Critics, such as Douglas Feith, a former undersecretary of defense in the administration of President George W. Bush, have accused the Obama administration of a timid response to the Syrian crisis. In an article published in the Wall Street Journal on Monday, Mr. Feith stated, "The Obama administration has neither promoted humanitarian'safe zones' on Syria's Turkish border, nor provided arms to the rebels. It has not helped establish a no-fly zone, nor has it supported NATO military strikes against Assad's forces."

Russia, a key ally of the Syrian regime, accused the West of attempting to use blackmail to secure a new U.N. Security Council resolution that could allow the use of force in Syria. Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov told reporters that the Kremlin has no intention of supporting a British proposal to enact U.N. sanctions to resolve the crisis.

The U.S. has consistently supported sanctions, which the Obama administration has stepped up as the crisis has deepened. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton also worked with the U.N. Security Council and U.N. envoy Kofi Annan on a June 30 accord calling on Syrians to come up with a political transition.

A mandate for a U.N. observer force expires on July 20, and Mr. Lavrov accused the West of using the deadline as a bargaining chip. "To our great regret, there are elements of blackmail," Mr. Lavrov said. "We are being told that if you do not agree to passing the resolution under Chapter 7 of the U.N. Charter, then we shall refuse to extend the mandate of the monitoring mission."

Mr. Feith criticized the president for ceding U.S. sovereignty to the United Nations in the debate. "By refusing to act on Syria, the president is missing an opportunity to advance U.S. security interests in the Middle East, while benefiting Iran, the principal sponsor of the Assad regime," Mr. Feith said. "And by suggesting that America lacks international legal authority to act, he is undermining U.S. sovereignty."

In the "Captive Nations" proclamation, Mr. Obama said, "America renews our abiding ties to all peoples who struggle to claim their inalienable rights." He further stated, "As strongly as my administration condemns tyranny, we embrace emerging democracies and welcome the chance to work with those who seek to restore their people's liberty."

Title: Bipartisan Call for International Investigation into China's Handling of COVID-19

Article:

A bipartisan push for accountability regarding China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic has emerged on Capitol Hill, with a proposed resolution calling for an international investigation into the Communist Chinese Party's (CCP) response to the virus. The resolution, introduced by Representative Elise Stefanik (R-NY) in the House of Representatives and Senator Josh Hawley (R-MO), aims to investigate the CCP's actions and the role their cover-up played in the global spread of the pandemic.

The resolution asserts that the CCP intentionally concealed information about the virus, with knowledge of its existence as early as December, while ordering laboratories to destroy samples and silencing doctors. This alleged cover-up, according to the resolution's proponents, led to the deaths of thousands of people worldwide, including hundreds of Americans.

Senator Hawley stated in a release, "Since day one, the Chinese Communist Party intentionally lied to the world about the origin of this pandemic. It is time for an international investigation into the role their cover-up played in the spread of this devastating pandemic. The CCP must be held to account for what the world is now suffering."

Representative Stefanik, in a statement, emphasized the need for China to be held accountable for the harm caused by their actions. "There is no doubt that China’s unconscionable decision to orchestrate an elaborate coverup of the wide-ranging and deadly implications of coronavirus led to the death of thousands of people, including hundreds of Americans and climbing. This Resolution calls for China to provide compensation for the harm, loss, and destruction their arrogance brought upon the rest of the world," she said.

The proposed legislation seeks to investigate the CCP's knowledge of the virus and their decision to withhold this information, as well as to condemn the widespread harm caused by the Chinese government. While Democrats have so far refused to concede any criticism toward the CCP for their role in the spread of the virus, the resolution's proponents argue that the communist regime must be held accountable for their intentional negligence.

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Condemns Rep. Don Young's Use of Offensive Term, Amidst Sensitive Immigration Debate

Article:

In a significant turn of events, House Speaker John Boehner, a Republican from Ohio, has publicly condemned the use of the term "wetbacks" by Rep. Don Young, a senior member of the Republican Party from Alaska, during a radio interview. The remark, followed by a swift apology from Young and Boehner's statement that the comment was "beneath the dignity of the office he holds," comes at a particularly sensitive time for the Republican Party in its relationship with Hispanic voters.

The GOP is currently grappling with calls for changes in immigration law, with more party leaders now backing a so-called path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants, a stance opposed by many conservatives. The November elections saw Latinos voting overwhelmingly for President Obama, and the party is attempting to navigate this complex issue.

Young, in the interview with an Alaska radio station, used the term "wetbacks" to describe Hispanic migrant workers who used to pick tomatoes on his father's family ranch. He stated, "My father had a ranch. We used to hire 50 or 60 wetbacks and — to pick tomatoes. You know, it takes two people to pick the same tomatoes now. It's all done by machine."

In a subsequent statement, Young, who is 79 and has spent four decades in Alaska's only U.S. House seat, said, "I meant no disrespect" in using the term, a slur for Mexicans crossing illegally into the United States. The Alaska Dispatch reported the apology:

"During a sit-down interview with Ketchikan Public Radio this week, I used a term that was commonly used during my days growing up on a farm in Central California. I know that this term is not used in the same way nowadays and I meant no disrespect. Migrant workers play an important role in America's workforce, and earlier in the interview, I discussed the compassion and understanding I have for these workers and the hurdles they face in obtaining citizenship. America must once and for all tackle the issue of immigration reform."

Title: Justice Department Declines to File Federal Civil Rights Charges Against NYPD Officer Involved in Eric Garner's Death

The Justice Department on Monday declined to file federal civil rights charges against Officer Daniel Pantaleo, the New York Police Department (NYPD) officer involved in the chokehold death of Eric Garner in 2014. The decision comes one day before the fifth anniversary of Garner's death and the expiration of the statute of limitations.

Garner, a 43-year-old father of six, was ruled a homicide in August 2014. His dying words, "I can't breathe," on July 17, 2014, became a national rallying cry for demonstrations about police treatment of minorities.

Eric Garner's mother, Gwen Carr, after a meeting with federal prosecutors in Brooklyn, expressed her disappointment, stating, "The Justice Department has failed us."

In August 2014, a Staten Island grand jury chose not to indict Officer Pantaleo on any state criminal charges four months after Garner's death.

Attorney General William Barr made the decision, which was based on the Eastern District of New York's recommendation not to prosecute over the department's civil rights division's recommendation to move forward with a prosecution.

The decision was made after the Justice Department determined it could not establish the willful intent requirement, and it did not seek to analyze elements like whether Pantaleo's actions were not permissible or even reasonable under NYPD or other law enforcement policies.

Patrolmen's Benevolent Association (PBA) President Patrick J. Lynch stated, "In both cases, a careful review of the facts led investigators to the truth, although Mr. Garner’s death was an undeniable tragedy, Police Officer Pantaleo did not cause it."

Lynch further added, "Scapegoating a good and honorable officer, who was doing his job in the manner he was taught, will not heal the wounds this case has caused for our entire city." The PBA believes that if the NYPD decides the disciplinary case on the facts, free of improper political influence, Officer Pantaleo will be fully exonerated of any wrongdoing.

Title: Twin Bombings Near Iranian Embassy in Beirut Leave 20 Dead, Raise Concerns Over Lebanon's Stability

Article:

Two explosions near the Iranian embassy in Beirut, Lebanon, on Tuesday have left at least 20 people dead and over 100 injured, according to various reports. The Iranian cultural attache, Ebrahim Ansari, was among the casualties. The attacks, which some observers are linking to the ongoing Syrian civil war, have raised concerns over deepening sectarian divisions across the region.

The incidents occurred in the Jnah district, home to the Iranian embassy, following a double suicide bombing. One attacker detonated explosives on foot, while another did so in a car, as reported by The Los Angeles Times. Television images showed dark smoke, several fires, and blazing cars.

The perpetrators of the attack, reportedly the Lebanese Sunni jihadi group the Abdullah Azzam Brigades, have claimed responsibility, according to the BBC. The group is said to have sent a "clear message."

The area has been targeted by a series of attacks in recent months, with Lebanon as a whole experiencing cross-border rocket attacks, deadly car bomb attacks, sectarian clashes, and roadside bomb attacks against suspected Hezbollah vehicles, as reported by The ███.

Lebanon's Prime Minister, Najib Mikati, stated that the aim of the blast was to "stir up the situation in Lebanon and use the Lebanese arena to convey messages."

Iran and Hezbollah, Lebanon's largest political group, are major backers of the Syrian government of President Bashar al-Assad. Hezbollah's leader, Hassan Nasrallah, recently announced that the group would continue to send its militiamen to Syria to fight alongside government forces, drawing condemnation from anti-Assad groups in both Lebanon and Syria.

Lebanese officials have declared a policy of neutrality in the Syrian war, aiming to avoid their nation being drawn into Syria's civil war. Many in Lebanon fear the Syrian conflict could destabilize Lebanon's fragile, multi-sectarian democracy, still brittle following Lebanon's own 15-year civil war, which ended in 1990.

The attacks took place amidst the Syrian government's aggressive pushback against rebel fighters on three fronts, including one in the region of Qalamoun along the Lebanese border, as reported by The New York Times.

The potential outcomes of the Syrian conflict remain uncertain, with experts suggesting that if there is one outright "winner," it could critically affect Lebanon's stability. If the Assad regime manages to cling to power and reduce the threat posed by the rebels, Hezbollah will remain strong in Lebanon, and the cross-regional alliance between the Shiite group and its backers in Damascus and Tehran will endure. Conversely, if the Assad regime falls and is replaced by a Sunni regime that moves closer to Saudi Arabia and the Sunni Gulf, Hezbollah will be isolated from Iran and will feel dangerously vulnerable.

Despite the attacks and bombings on Lebanese soil, it is not yet clear if Syria is tipping Lebanon toward its own civil war.

Title: AOC Discusses Vice Presidency, Sanders Endorsement, and Language in Spanish-Language Interview

In a recent interview with Noticias Telemundo, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., expressed her desire to serve as vice president, acknowledging, however, that she is five years short of the constitutional age limit for the position. The 30-year-old freshman congresswoman delivered a keynote address at Sen. Bernie Sanders' Spanish-language town hall in Las Vegas on Sunday, where she endorsed him for the White House in October.

During the interview, Ocasio-Cortez, whose mother is Puerto Rican, emphasized the importance of preserving her Spanish language skills. She had previously expressed nervousness about hosting the town hall in Spanish due to her limited use of the language.

"If we are first- or second-generation, it is important that we cultivate our language," Ocasio-Cortez said. "I must speak and practice more to improve my own Spanish. Our language is the link with our families and our communities."

Ocasio-Cortez also reflected on her political journey, from working as a waitress and bartender in a taqueria to her current role as a congresswoman. She emphasized that her values remain the same, focusing on fighting for working families, healthcare, education, and fair wages.

"Last year I worked in a taqueria, as a waitress and as a bartender, and now I am a congresswoman," she said. "That is a huge change. But my values are the same. And we are saying the same thing we were saying last year: that we must fight for working families, for health insurance, for education for all children and a fair salary."

Ocasio-Cortez also took the opportunity to reiterate her support for Sen. Sanders, mentioning her previous work as a community organizer for him during the last presidential campaign. She could play a key role in helping Sanders secure Nevada's large Latino vote, differentiating him from fellow progressive Sen. Elizabeth Warren.

Title: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry Issues Blunt Warning to Russian President Vladimir Putin Over Ukraine Crisis

Article:

In a stern warning to Russian President Vladimir Putin, U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry on Thursday evening urged Putin to reverse his actions in Ukraine or face "grave" and "costly" consequences from the international community. Kerry's statement, delivered in the State Department briefing room, marked the most detailed and direct warning from U.S. leaders regarding the ongoing crisis in Ukraine.

Kerry outlined a list of covert and destabilizing actions he said Russia has pursued against Ukraine over the past week, including disciplined paramilitary groups occupying Ukrainian government buildings, arrests of undercover Russian intelligence agents, and the kidnappings and murders of local Ukrainian officials and journalists.

President Obama, on a four-nation tour of Asia, also weighed in on the crisis, raising the prospect of tougher economic sanctions from the West and stating, "We are ready to act." Obama's comments came in response to Putin's Thursday warning that Ukraine would face "consequences" for moving against pro-Russia separatists in eastern Ukraine.

Appearing to presage deeper Russian intervention, Putin said Russia would "have to react to such developments." Ukrainian security forces, attempting to clear roadblocks and take back barricaded government buildings in eastern Ukraine, killed as many as five separatists on Thursday.

Kerry's statement, which sounded like a final warning shot, emphasized that Russia's destabilizing activities and covert actions in Eastern Ukraine had started even as the U.S., Russia, the European Union, and Ukraine were meeting in Geneva last week to forge a stabilization plan to end the Ukraine standoff. However, while the government in Kiev was doing everything it had agreed to under the plan, Kerry said, Russia was stepping up activities designed to undermine and provoke the Kiev government.

Kerry also offered statistics suggesting the Russian economy is already hurting from sanctions imposed over the Crimea annexation and cited some Russian officials acknowledging the blow sanctions have already struck, in particular to foreign investment and the confidence of foreign investors in considering Russia in the current climate.

However, some analysts are less confident that the "international community" will be united in imposing a new round of broader sanctions on sectors of the Russian economy. Experts considering sanctions at a Washington forum sponsored by the Center for Strategic and International Studies on Thursday underscored that Western Europe remains reliant on Russian energy and is likely to find it difficult to replace that energy in time for next winter.

Some also note that the European Union is not united on imposing broad sector sanctions, and that some Europeans could be sympathetic to a Russian claim, if it moved into Ukraine, that it acted to restore order where a civil war threatened.

"I can imagine the Russians claiming they acted to stop the unrest and reestablish order, and if they take that to the Germans and maybe some others, that could fall on some sympathetic ears, and we could see some breaks in a united Western front," says Nikolas Gvosdev, a specialist in Russian security affairs at the Naval War College in Newport, R.I. "That would put Obama in a tough spot."

Title: U.S. Urged to Provide Diplomatic Support for Guaidó, Avoid Military Intervention in Venezuela

Article:

The political crisis in Venezuela has reached a critical point, with the left supporting Juan Guaidó, the self-proclaimed interim president, but urging against U.S. military intervention. The Maduro regime, which has been accused of destroying democratic institutions, devastating the economy, and causing widespread social unrest, has not touched Guaidó, recognizing the risks of detaining the man whom many world governments recognize as the legitimate president of Venezuela.

Tensions escalated this week as Guaidó led a military uprising, with the U.S. and other countries expressing support for the opposition. The U.S. has promised a "significant response" if Guaidó is harmed, but many argue that military intervention is not the solution.

"The U.S. should refrain from intervening militarily, but should continue providing decisive diplomatic, and even logistical, support," said a spokesperson for the left. "The Venezuelan people have international moral support for their cause and the promise of aid to rebuild, but they're on their own against a regime backed by Cuba, Russia, China, and Iran."

The spokesperson also warned against the U.S. government taking a role in the foreign crisis, stating, "It's dangerous to encourage that hope — because it may induce them to take unwise risks, and because it could lead us to plunge into another country where our interests, like our understanding, is minimal."

The situation in Venezuela has led to a massive exodus of Venezuelans, with the United Nations estimating that there will be more than 5 million refugees by the end of this year, comparable to the exodus caused by the Syrian civil war.

As the crisis continues, the focus remains on whether the military will abandon the Maduro regime and join the opposition. Officers and soldiers who join the revolt will be at risk if the government prevails, but those who are loyal to Maduro can expect that if he falls, the new government will find it more urgent to bring them on board than to punish them.

The outcome of the crisis in Venezuela remains uncertain, but many believe that the Venezuelan people will ultimately prevail if they continue to show up against the odds. "They've already proven their country is worth fighting for," said the spokesperson. "It will be their fight to win or lose."

Title: US Senate Passes Tax Cuts Bill, Marking First Major Legislative Victory for President Trump

Article:

In a historic vote, the US Senate has passed a sweeping tax cuts bill, marking President Donald Trump's first significant legislative victory. The bill, which saw a 51-49 vote after a series of amendments in a marathon session, is set to be the biggest tax overhaul since the 1980s.

The package, which was passed despite warnings of a potential $1tn increase in the budget deficit, includes significant cuts in corporation tax. The corporate tax rate would be permanently lowered from 35% to 20%, while future foreign profits of US-based firms would be mainly exempt from tax.

The bill's passage comes after a contentious debate, with Democrats criticizing the bill for allegedly benefiting the wealthy and big business. Middle-class taxpayer benefits, according to a Senate Joint Committee on Taxation, have sunset clauses, while corporations are set to receive permanent tax cuts.

The House of Representatives passed a similar bill last month and will now have to merge their legislation with the Senate's version before it can be signed into law by the president. The final draft of the bill underwent several changes to bring reluctant Republicans on board.

The tax cuts bill is a significant victory for President Trump, who has faced challenges in getting major legislative movement in Congress, including his promise to repeal and replace Obamacare. The president's tenure has also been marked by an independent investigation into Russian attempts to influence the 2016 US election and possible collusion with his campaign team. On Friday, former national security adviser Michael Flynn became the Trump administration's most senior member to be charged in the investigation.

The Senate, a seemingly insurmountable roadblock for the Republican agenda for much of this year, has at last given its assent to a major piece of legislation. The hope is that a booming economy will give Republicans a chance to run on their tax policy when they stand before voters next November. The fear was that yet another failure would have led to a revolt among the party's big donors and traditional business constituencies.

The tax cuts bill is not without controversy, with some opponents highlighting a measure that would end a requirement introduced under Obamacare for most taxpayers to buy health insurance or face a fine. According to the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office, scrapping the mandate would push up insurance premiums and lead to 13 million people losing cover by 2027.

There were some last-minute changes, including a $10,000 property tax deduction as requested by Senator Susan Collins, one of the Republicans who had been reluctant to back the bill. After the vote, Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer said his opponents would pay the price at the ballot box in mid-term elections next year.

`` My Republican friends will ultimately pay consequences for this bill in 2018 and beyond. The Republican party will never again be the party of tax cuts for middle-class people, '' he warned. He also expressed concerns about the bill's potential impact on social security and medical provision.

Independent Senator Bernie Sanders was among the most vocal critics, declaring during the debate that the American treasury was "being looted." However, Republican Senate majority leader Mitch McConnell, who succeeded in bringing dissenting party members into line, said the legislation would prove to be "just what the country needs to get growing again." He brushed aside complaints that it was pushed through without proper scrutiny.

Republican Senator Bill Cassidy also praised the bill, saying "working families and middle-income families across the nation will be better off." The only Republican senator who refused to back the legislation was Bob Corker. "I am not able to cast aside my fiscal concerns and vote for legislation that... could deepen the debt burden on future generations," he said.

Title: Congressional Delegation Visits Tornillo Tent City, Urges Shutdown of Immigrant Teen Facility

AUSTIN, Texas — A bipartisan group of five Democratic members of Congress, led by Rep. Beto O'Rourke (D-Texas), toured a remote tent city in West Texas on Saturday where they estimated approximately 2,700 immigrant teenagers are being held at a daily cost of around $1 million.

The lawmakers, who included U.S. Sens. Mazie Hirono (D-Hawaii), Jeff Merkley (D-Oregon), Tina Smith (D-Minnesota), and California Rep. Judy Chu, urged the nonprofit running the facility, BCFS Health and Human Services, not to renew its federal contract, which expires on December 31. This move could potentially close the camp, although the request seems unlikely to succeed.

O'Rourke, who has been mentioned as a potential 2020 presidential candidate following his close Senate race against Republican Sen. Ted Cruz in a deep-red state, was joined by the other lawmakers. O'Rourke stated that they were not allowed to speak to the children in a meaningful way during the tour.

"They kind of nodded their heads, but what are they going to say when everyone around them is watching?" O'Rourke said after the tour. "But there was something in the look on their faces that we saw, the way that they weren't really engaged in the sports that they were playing out on those fields."

Chu added, "We need to shut it down. It is inhumane. It is a child prison. It has no right to exist."

O'Rourke made no mention of his potential White House aspirations after his fourth visit to the camp, which is located just outside Tornillo. He noted the area was about an hour's drive from his native El Paso, which borders Mexico at the westernmost tip of Texas.

"It's in a remote location on purpose so that the American people do not know what's happening here," O'Rourke told reporters.

The lawmakers stated that 2,700 boys and girls between the ages of 13 and 17 were being held at Tornillo. They described touring the tents housing the teens but could only ask light questions. O'Rourke said he asked a few of them what countries they were from—Guatemala and Honduras, they said—and received assurances that the conditions were "OK."

Tornillo opened as a temporary facility in June, amid what President Donald Trump's administration described as an emergency situation on the U.S.-Mexico border. Since then, the contract keeping it open has been renewed, and the number of kids being held inside has grown, although determining the rate of growth has proven difficult.

The lawmakers said BCFS Health and Human Services, the contractor running the facility, told them that the tent city has cost taxpayers $144 million since opening, or about $1 million a day.

The Democrats said they urged BCFS Health and Human Services to refuse to renew its contract with the U.S. government. However, even if that happened, the lawmakers said they weren't sure where the children being held at Tornillo would be transferred as a result.

The Associated Press previously reported that the Trump administration waived FBI fingerprint checks for caregivers and experienced short-staffing of mental health workers at Tornillo.

O'Rourke said Saturday that the contractor told him that a recent agreement with Texas now allows for state background checks, but that the facility still doesn't have the capacity to do FBI fingerprint checks.

The lawmakers said many of the teens have family already in the United States who would like to take them. However, federal authorities have begun fingerprinting and conducting background checks on would-be "sponsors," resulting in 170 apprehensions on possible immigration violations.

They also said that even with the added scrutiny, the contractor said 1,300 children have relatives ready to take them but have remained at Tornillo due to unexplained federal delays.

O'Rourke stated that public pressure could force federal authorities to close Tornillo, but in the meantime, federal policies mean the country is "turning our backs on these people."

Title: Trump's New Negotiating Strategy Yields Government Reopening, Causes Internal Democratic Discord

Article:

In a three-day government shutdown that ended Monday night, President Donald Trump adopted an uncharacteristic low-profile approach, avoiding public appearances, leading to frustration among Democrats. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., even taunted the president, stating, "The great deal-making president sat on the sidelines."

However, it was Schumer who ultimately had to concede and lead his party in a retreat on the shutdown. Many Democrats attributed their failure to the White House's new strategy. Politico reported that the stand-back-and-watch approach was effective, putting pressure on Senate leaders to reach an agreement to reopen the government without Trump's direct involvement, resulting in a victory for the president.

In his new book, "Media Madness: Donald Trump, The Press, And The War Over the Truth," Fox News "MediaBuzz" host Howard Kurtz reports that Trump aides have coined a term for Trump's penchant for going against advice: "Defiance Disorder." The phrase refers to Trump's seeming compulsion to do the opposite of what his advisers are strongly urging, leaving his team to handle the fallout.

As negotiations to keep the government open stalled on Friday, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., called Trump and urged him not to engage with Democrats like Schumer to strike a grand bargain. McConnell advised, "Make them come to you." Trump agreed, and the new strategy proved successful.

Senate Republicans were forced to take charge, and House Republicans were able to communicate that they had voted to keep the government open, while Democrats were refusing to do so due to prioritizing immigrant rights. The shutdown strategy failure also sparked a mini-civil war within the ranks of congressional Democrats.

Rep. Luis Gutiérrez, D-Ill., a strong advocate for immigrants, criticized his Senate colleagues, stating, "They blink, they just do, and it's unfortunate." Rep. Gwen Moore, D-Wis., expressed her discontent, questioning, "How do we know the Senate isn't screwing us?" House Minority Whip Steny Hoyer of Maryland, the second-ranking Democrat in House leadership, confirmed her sentiment.

Every confrontation between Congress and the White House is unique, but after a year in office, Trump aides now believe they have new tools in their negotiating arsenal. One White House aide told a reporter, "No one is saying Trump won't be Trump, and he knows how to pivot and attack better than anyone. But he is also figuring out that timing is everything, and you sometimes have to wait and let your adversaries trip over themselves."

Democrats may soon realize that the 71-year-old Trump has learned new tactics and may surprise them again in the run-up to November's midterm elections.

Title: Romney Shifts Focus to Domestic Issues After Foreign Policy Controversy

Article:

In a bid to refocus his campaign on domestic issues, Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney addressed a crowd in Virginia on Thursday, emphasizing the nation's economy and military strength. The event followed a controversy over Romney's criticism of President Obama's handling of the unrest in Libya and Egypt, which had sparked a debate over Romney's foreign policy remarks.

At the rally in Fairfax, Virginia, Romney began his speech by expressing his condolences for the four American diplomats who lost their lives in the recent attacks. "We're in mourning for Ambassador Chris Stevens and the three other embassy staffers killed," Romney said, "We've lost four of our diplomats across the world. We're thinking about their families and those that they've left behind. What a tragedy to lose such wonderful people that have been so wonderful and [we] appreciate their service to the country."

Romney largely avoided the controversy surrounding his claims that the Obama administration's statements, made through the embassy in Egypt, were akin to an apology. The Republican nominee faced criticism, including from fellow Republicans, for his aggressive response to the unfolding international incident.

During the speech, a heckler interrupted Romney, asking, "Why are you politicizing Libya?" The crowd attempted to drown out the heckler with chants of "Mitt" and "U-S-A!" Romney responded, "I would offer a moment of silence, but one gentleman does not want to be silent, so we're going to keep on going."

President Obama, meanwhile, traveled to Golden, Colorado, where he spoke about improving the economy. However, he also vowed to find those responsible for the death of Ambassador Chris Stevens. "I want people around the world to hear me: To all those who would do us harm, no act of terror will go unpunished. It will not dim the light of the values that we proudly present to the rest of the world. No act of violence shakes the resolve of the United States of America," Obama said.

On Thursday, Libyan officials informed the U.S. that four people were in custody in connection with the attack.

In his speech in Virginia, Romney reiterated a general vision of a United States "that's strong, that helps lead the world... As we watch the world today sometimes it seems that we're at the mercy of events instead of shaping events, and a strong America's essential to shape events."

Title: Vandalism Reported at Catholic Church in New Haven, Connecticut, Part of Ongoing Trend of Church Desecration in the U.S.

Article:

A Catholic church in New Haven, Connecticut, has become the latest target in a series of church vandalism incidents across the United States. Pastor John Paul Walker of St. Mary's Parish, which comprises both St. Mary's Catholic Church and St. Joseph's Catholic Church, announced in a Thursday Facebook post that St. Joseph's Church was vandalized sometime between 9 p.m. Wednesday and 6 a.m. Thursday.

The Archdiocese of Hartford also confirmed the incident, stating in a Facebook post that "a person or group of persons had painted anarchist and satanic symbols on the doors of St. Joseph Church in New Haven."

Pastor Walker wrote in his post that this incident, along with similar incidents in cities such as Chattanooga, Queens, Boston, Sacramento, and Ocala, is part of a trend of desecrating Catholic spaces across the nation. "The underlying motive of these sacrilegious attacks is clear: to intimidate and instill fear in the hearts of those who worship Christ," he stated.

Pastor Walker expressed resilience in the face of the vandalism, stating, "The Catholic faith has survived for over 2,000 years and is not about to yield now." He added, "Therefore, we remain unafraid and resolute in our faith, and we will pray for a conversion of the hearts of those who wish to terrorize us."

The New Haven police did not immediately respond to requests for comment from ███ News Foundation on the matter.

This latest incident follows the vandalism of a statue of the Sacred Heart of Jesus at Sacred Heart Church in Calgary, Alberta, on Tuesday around 1:30 a.m., as confirmed by Fr. Wilbert Chin Jon of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Calgary to ███ News Foundation on Thursday. Numerous other statues of the Virgin Mary have also been vandalized throughout the country.

Title: New Poll Shows Slip in Trump's Job Approval Rating Amid Economic Concerns and Recession Fears

Article:

A new poll conducted by ███/Washington Post shows a decline in President Donald Trump's job approval rating, with six in ten Americans expressing concerns about a potential recession and higher prices due to the ongoing trade war with China. The poll, produced for ABC by Langer Research Associates, indicates that Trump's approval rating has dropped from a career-high 44% in July to 38% currently, marking a significant decrease in public support.

The poll reveals that Trump's handling of the economy has slipped by 5 percentage points, from 51% approval in midsummer to 46% now. Moreover, only 35% approve of his handling of trade negotiations with China, and 60% are concerned that the trade dispute will raise the cost of goods they purchase.

The overall rating of the U.S. economy, at 56% positive, has decreased from 65% last fall in this poll. Notably, 60% of respondents see a recession as very or somewhat likely in the next year, which is close to the 69% who expressed similar concerns in November 2007, just before the Great Recession.

The poll also shows that Trump receives far more criticism than praise for his economic stewardship, with Americans expressing a 3-1 margin (43-16%) that his trade and economic policies have increased rather than decreased the likelihood of a recession in the next year.

Economic attitudes are found to be highly partisan, with 90% of Republicans rating the economy positively, compared to 52% of independents and 33% of Democrats. However, the poll suggests that negative economic attitudes pose a risk to Trump, particularly among Republicans who are concerned about the impact of the trade dispute with China and those who see a recession as likely.

The statistical analysis, known as regression, supports this result. Controlling for demographics, partisanship, and political ideology, seeing a recession as more likely, being concerned about paying more due to the trade dispute with China, and holding more negative views of the economy overall are found to be the strongest predictors of Trump's approval rating.

Economic anxiety is nearly as high in the red states Trump won in 2016 as in the blue states, with 58% of respondents in red states seeing a recession as very or somewhat likely, compared to 63% in blue states. Trump's approval rating is underwater in the red states, at 43%, compared to 32% in the blue states.

The poll also reveals a significant decline in Trump's approval among various demographic groups, including a 10-point drop among urban residents, 9-point drop among college graduates, and 8-point drop among women. Trump's approval rating among whites has also decreased slightly, to 48%, compared to 25% among Hispanics and just 10% among blacks.

Two other shifts this month indicate that Trump appears increasingly isolated in a core support group, white men who don't have a college degree. They give him 69% approval, but he has lost 12 points among non-college white women, to 42%, and 15 points among college-educated white men, to 34%.

The poll was conducted between September 2-5, 2019, among a random national sample of 1,003 adults. The results have a margin of sampling error of 3.5 points, including the design effect. The partisan divisions are 28-24-37% Democrats-Republicans-independents. The survey was produced for ███ by Langer Research Associates of New York, New York, with sampling and data collection by Abt Associates of Rockville, Md.

Title: Senate Considering Additional Sanctions on Iran Nuclear Program: A Look at the Historical Role of Congress in American Foreign Policy

Article:

In the heart of Washington, discussions are underway regarding potential actions if Iran fails to comply with its commitments in the Geneva agreement or refuses to dismantle its nuclear program entirely. The Senate is contemplating further sanctions that would empower the President, should diplomatic efforts falter, to take decisive and swift action to pressure Iran into a mutually acceptable agreement with the West.

This move is not without precedent, as the President previously sought Congressional legislation on the use of force to curtail Syria's chemical weapons capabilities just a few months ago. Historically, the Senate has played a significant role in shaping American foreign policy, from its early approval of the Alaska Purchase in 1867, the United Nations in 1945, and the Marshall Plan in 1948, to Senate authorization for World War I, World War II, and both Persian Gulf Wars.

Key Senators, such as J. William Fulbright, Chuck Percy, Jacob Javits, John Kerry, Joe Biden, and Hillary Clinton, have all left indelible marks on American foreign policy. Given this historical context, one might wonder why President Obama has not welcomed Congressional legislation imposing additional sanctions to bolster his efforts to dismantle the Iranian nuclear program.

The rationale behind these additional sanctions is rooted in the strategic implications of a nuclear-armed Iran. With Iran nearing the capability to detonate an atomic bomb, it would significantly elevate its status in the Middle East and pose a threat to countries it perceives as hostile, such as Israel, Saudi Arabia, and the UAE.

Domestically, the nuclear program enjoys broad support among Iranians, with 80% in favor. Nuclear weapons would also deter any Western attempts, as in 1941 and 1953, to overthrow the regime.

A nuclear Iran could trigger an arms race in the Middle East, with several countries likely acquiring nuclear weapons. This would embolden radical Islamist forces in the region while discouraging more moderate, pro-American states, potentially feeling threatened by their own survival.

By 2020, according to a dated report, Iran may possess Intercontinental Ballistic Missiles (ICBMs) capable of reaching the East Coast of the United States. Before then, Iran may be able to target Western and Central Europe with nuclear weapons. Consequently, the diplomatic effort to dismantle the Iranian nuclear program is crucial to American national security.

Tough sanctions have already shown effectiveness, bringing Iran to the negotiating table for the first time. Iran remains vulnerable to economic sanctions due to the poor state of its economy. A United Nations study ranked Iranian GDP per capita 82nd in the world, below that of Botswana. A World Bank study showed the ease of doing business in Iran is 152nd in the world, below that of Liberia. Another World Bank study showed that in getting electricity, Iran ranks 166th in the world, below that of Swaziland. A new round of sanctions will ensure that Iran will have to choose between total economic destitution (with likely political unrest as a consequence) or giving up its nuclear program.

History has shown that the mullahs in Iran have surrendered under extreme duress. In 1987, Grand Ayatollah Khomeini ended the war against Iraq when he realized that further massive casualties would not lead to victory. In 2003, Grand Ayatollah Khamenei slowed down the nuclear program when the American army took Baghdad. This new round of sanctions will provide President Obama with the leverage to ensure that Iran will have no choice but to dismantle its nuclear weapons program.

Title: U.S. Accuses Qatar of Cheating on Airline Trade Deal, Raising Concerns for Future Trade Negotiations

Article:

In a move that could have far-reaching implications for future trade negotiations, the United States has accused Qatar of cheating on an airline trade deal. The allegations come as President Donald Trump continues to push for fair trade deals, with China being the latest target of his tariff strategy.

The U.S. claims that Qatar, a U.S. ally and host to the largest American military base in the Gulf, is using a subsidiary airline, Air Italy, to bypass the terms of an Open Skies agreement signed in January 2018. Under the agreement, an airline is not supposed to use government subsidies to establish lower fares in competition with U.S. carriers.

Qatar Airways, the state-owned airline, is reportedly providing financing and operating losses for Air Italy, which has been offering bargain-rate flights from Milan to several U.S. cities. The airline's crew uniforms, financial statements, and top executives are all linked to Qatar Airways.

U.S. carriers and their advocates on Capitol Hill, including Senators Ted Cruz and Bob Menendez, are urging the Trump administration to take action against Qatar. If Qatar Airways continues to use Air Italy as a proxy, it could send a message to other major U.S. trading partners that they can cheat on trade deals without consequences.

The Qatar incident comes as the U.S. imposes additional tariffs on selected goods from China, Europe, Mexico, and Canada, a move that has been criticized by supporters of free trade. The stock market dropped 500 points after the new China tariffs were announced.

The tariff strategy, while controversial, is part of Trump's efforts to protect American intellectual property and push for fair trade deals. However, the long-term success of this approach remains to be seen, and critics argue that tariffs lead to higher prices for U.S. consumers and protect inefficient markets from the need to innovate and increase productivity.

As the U.S. and Qatar navigate this trade dispute, the focus is on accountability and the message it sends to other trading partners. The outcome could shape the future of U.S. trade negotiations and the balance between free trade and protectionism.

Title: Indictment Alleges Negligence in Jeffrey Epstein's Death, Citing Failure to Perform Mandatory Checks

Article:

In a recent development, an indictment has been filed against two correction officers, Tiffany Noel and Thomas Morrow, for alleged negligence in the death of convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The indictment, unsealed on Thursday, details the officers' failure to perform mandatory checks on Epstein on the night of his death.

On August 9, the day before Epstein was found dead, his cellmate was transferred out in a "routine, prearranged transfer," the indictment stated. That evening, Ms. Noel and Mr. Thomas were both working overtime shifts. Ms. Noel, a correction officer since 2016, and Mr. Thomas, who started in 2007, were supposed to check on inmates every half-hour.

According to the indictment, Epstein was escorted into his cell by Ms. Noel and another guard shortly before 8 p.m. Inmates were locked in their cells for the night by 10 p.m. However, between 10:30 p.m. and 6:30 a.m., the indictment alleges that Ms. Noel and Mr. Thomas were not monitoring the inmates as required. Instead, they reportedly sat at their desk, browsed the internet, and moved around the common area. They also allegedly signed "count sheets" stating they had checked on inmates multiple times overnight when they had not.

The indictment further states that when Ms. Noel and Mr. Thomas entered Epstein's cell the next morning, they found him unresponsive with a noose around his neck. When a supervisor arrived, the guards admitted they had not performed their duties as required.

"We did not complete the 3 a.m. nor 5 a.m. rounds," Ms. Noel reportedly said, according to the indictment. Mr. Thomas is quoted as saying, "She's not to blame, we didn't do any rounds."

In response to the allegations, Kathleen Hawk Sawyer, the director of the Bureau of Prisons, stated that the agency is taking the matter "very seriously" and that the allegations of misconduct will be "responded to appropriately."

This development in the Epstein case adds a new layer of complexity to the circumstances surrounding his death, which has been ruled a suicide by the medical examiner. The indictment against Ms. Noel and Mr. Thomas is a reminder of the importance of diligent oversight in correctional facilities and the potential consequences of negligence in carrying out such responsibilities.

Title: White House Prepares for Proactive Presidential Agenda in State of the Union Address

Article:

In an exclusive interview with NPR's Steve Inskeep on Morning Edition, White House Senior Advisor John Podesta revealed that President Obama will announce an executive order during his State of the Union address tonight, raising the minimum wage for workers on new federal contracts. This move marks a shift in the President's approach to executive orders, signaling a more proactive presidency.

Podesta stated, "Across a wide range of topics, including retirement security, moving forward on his climate change and energy transformation agenda, there's a lot that he has the authority to do." He added that where the White House and Justice Department agree that Obama can, he will take such executive actions in the coming year.

The executive order will increase the minimum wage from the current federal minimum of $7.25 an hour to $10.10 an hour. This change will apply only to new federal contracts, and not to renewals of existing agreements. Podesta also mentioned that the President will renew his push for an increase in the federal minimum wage for all workers during the State of the Union address.

In addition to the minimum wage issue, Podesta hinted at other topics the President will address, including the bilateral security agreement with Afghanistan, the economy, and the administration's plans for the coming year to keep the recovery going.

The State of the Union address is scheduled to begin shortly after 9 p.m. ET. NPR will provide live blogging and a stream of the speech and its coverage. Stay tuned for more updates as the time approaches. For more previews of the State of the Union address, check this post from It's All Politics.

Title: Putin Claims Convincing Trump on Russia's Non-Involvement in U.S. Election

Article:

Russian President Vladimir Putin stated on Saturday that he believes he successfully convinced President Donald Trump that Russia did not interfere in the 2016 U.S. presidential election during their first face-to-face meeting on Friday. The meeting, which took place on the sidelines of the G20 summit in Hamburg, Germany, was overshadowed by allegations of Russian meddling and unsubstantiated claims of Trump campaign collusion.

During the meeting, Russian meddling was the first topic Mr. Trump brought up, and Mr. Putin reiterated his denials that Moscow was involved. "He asked many questions on that subject," said Mr. Putin. "I answered those questions as best I could." Mr. Putin gave his assessment of Mr. Trump's reaction at a press conference in Hamburg.

The meeting, initially scheduled for 30 minutes, lasted for 2 hours and 15 minutes, and the two leaders also discussed a Syrian cease-fire agreement, Russia's disputed annexation of Crimea, and the fight against ISIS and radical Islamic terrorism. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who attended the meeting, said Mr. Trump pressed Mr. Putin about election interference and a "very robust and lengthy exchange" ensued.

"The president pressed President Putin on more than one occasion regarding Russian involvement," he said. "President Putin denied such involvement."

Mr. Putin also expressed optimism about the potential for cooperation between the two countries on various issues. "As for personal relations, I think that they are established," said Mr. Putin. "I think that if we continue building our relations like during our conversation yesterday, there are grounds to believe that we'll be able to — at least partially — restore the level of cooperation that we need."

Mr. Trump has faced criticism for expressing doubt about Russian interference in the election, despite several U.S. intelligence agencies believing Russia was responsible. Mr. Trump said Thursday that he believed Russia was involved but that other countries or individuals could also have been involved. The interference included the spread of disinformation during the campaign, as well as hacking into emails at the Democratic National Committee and Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton's campaign officials, exposing embarrassing information.

There has been no evidence that the efforts impacted the outcome of the election, but Democrats have pointed to Russian interference to delegitimize the Trump presidency. The meeting between Mr. Trump and Mr. Putin is the first of what is expected to be several high-level discussions between the two leaders.

Title: The Iowa Caucuses: A Turning Point for the Presidential Race, as Governors Fade and the Next President Emerges from a Different Pool

Article:

The Iowa caucuses have left the presidential race in a state of flux, but one thing is clear: the next president will not be a governor. This revelation is surprising, as just a year ago, the Republican governors were considered the party's most promising candidates.

The reasoning behind this prediction was simple: if Jeb Bush, the former two-term Florida governor with a strong job performance, was not the nominee, the voters would likely turn to governors like Wisconsin's Scott Walker, the conservative fiscal reformer, or Bobby Jindal of Louisiana, the policy expert. If these candidates failed to gain traction, a second tier of popular and talented governors, including Ohio's John Kasich, Texas' Rick Perry, New Jersey's Chris Christie, and former Arkansas governor Mike Huckabee, were ready to step in.

However, like the snow that blanketed Washington, these state CEOs have all but disappeared. Scott Walker, poof, gone. Mr. Jindal, bye-bye. Mike Huckabee, adios amigos. The remaining candidates, Mr. Bush, Mr. Kasich, and Mr. Christie, combined for about as many votes in Iowa as surgeon Ben Carson, who finished in fourth place. These three are the walking dead of the race, pinning their hopes on a strong showing in New Hampshire. Only Mr. Kasich of Ohio appears to have a shot.

So, what happened? In a year when politicians are widely distrusted, their experience became a liability. Even their successes were dismissed. John Kasich's impressive record of balancing budgets in the 1990s and as governor for five years was met with skepticism from conservatives, who saw him as having been around too long.

Jeb Bush, easily the most qualified for the Oval Office, having masterfully run the fourth-largest state with more people than most nations, was dismissed by voters who felt he wasn't conservative enough. The governors ran lousy campaigns and sounded tone-deaf to voter rage.

The art of politics is finding common ground and making deals, as demonstrated by Ronald Reagan, who was a steadfast conservative but made deals that benefited the country and the cause of freedom. The ultimate victory is getting the other side to vote with you.

As the race moves forward, it remains to be seen if the next president will be one of the three remaining candidates, all of whom have never governed. One hope is that they will choose a governor as their running mate, as governors have a proven track record of effective leadership and policy implementation. The talent pool runs deep in the state capitals.

Title: House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Sets Final Deadline for Trump Tax Returns, Potential Legal Showdown Ahead

In a move that could lead to a legal showdown between the House of Representatives and the Trump administration, House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Richard Neal (D-Mass.) has set a final deadline of April 23 for the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) to hand over President Trump's tax returns. The administration, led by Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, is currently studying the legal questions involved, and if the documents are not provided or a resolution to the dispute is not reached by the deadline, a court battle could ensue.

The administration missed an initial April 10 deadline, with Mnuchin citing consultations with the Department of Justice regarding the law and the legitimacy of Neal's request. Under the U.S. tax code, Neal is entitled to request any taxpayer's returns, and the Treasury Department is required to furnish them.

In a letter to IRS Commissioner Charles Rettig, Neal asserted that the law clearly entitles him to receive the six years of business and personal returns of Trump that he requested. Neal's letter stated that the IRS, Treasury, and Justice should not question or second-guess the motivations of the Committee or its reasonable determinations regarding its need for the requested tax returns and return information.

If the IRS fails to comply with Neal's April 23 deadline, he may issue a subpoena or seek to enforce the law in a federal court. The legal question would extend beyond the language of the statute and consider the extent of constitutional constraints on legislative inquiries.

Matthew Leas, an IRS spokesman, declined to comment on Neal's letter. Mnuchin stated that Treasury officials are working diligently on resolving the legal issues, and emphasized the potential implications of the IRS becoming weaponized, citing the Nixon administration as an example.

Trump has broken with decades of precedent by refusing to release his tax returns, citing an ongoing audit. Although no law prevents Trump from revealing his returns at any time, he has said he would release them after the audit is complete. Neal has used the president's argument against a voluntary release as his rationale for a mandatory handover of the returns, arguing that the committee needs to determine if the IRS is conducting the audits properly.

A subsequent committee vote would be required to publicly release all or part of the returns. The administration has not formally denied Neal's request, but White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney and Trump's personal lawyer, William Consovoy, have expressed opposition to the request.

Title: Wall Street Endures Fourth Consecutive Day of Triple-Digit Moves, Led by Tech Sector

Article:

In a significant turn of events, the stock market experienced its fourth consecutive day of triple-digit moves on Thursday, with the blue-chip Dow Jones Industrial Average closing down nearly 265 points, or 1.5%. The Dow ended the day at 16,945.80, marking a decline below the 17,000 mark.

The Standard & Poor's 500 index also saw a drop of 1.6%, finishing at 1,965.99. The tech-heavy Nasdaq composite experienced the worst losses of the day, ending down 1.9%, or 88.47 points, at 4,466.75. The decline in the Nasdaq was primarily driven by a 3.8% drop in Apple shares, which closed slightly below $98.

The Dow had gained 154 points on Wednesday, but all its other triple-digit moves since setting a new closing high on Friday have been on the downside. This was the same day Alibaba Group, the biggest-ever initial public offering, debuted on the New York Stock Exchange. Both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 have been down for the fourth day of the past five sessions.

Thursday's drop was attributed to increasing concerns about the global economy and a growing backlash against issues consumers are reporting with Apple's latest software updates and its new product launches, the iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus.

The rising volatility on Wall Street is causing concern after the stock market enjoyed a long run of relatively uneventful trading earlier in September. A measure of volatility known as the "fear gauge" jumped 25% on Thursday.

Analysts are worried about the buildup of complacency among investors and the approach of what could be a disappointing third-quarter earnings season, which could mean more trouble in the weeks ahead. However, the damage is relatively minor, given that the Dow and S&P are both down roughly 2% from the record highs they set last week.

Apple (AAPL) was a standout as its shares fell for a second straight day and dropped below $100 again after glitches with the tech giant's new phones and operating system came to light.

Fixed-income investments appeared to benefit from the flight out of stocks. The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note, which moves opposite its price, fell to 2.51% from 2.57% Wednesday as investors sought the relative safe haven of U.S. Treasuries.

In economic news, durable goods orders plunged 18.2% in August, largely due to a sharp drop in aircraft orders. Orders for durable goods excluding the volatile transportation category rose 0.7%.

Applications for unemployment benefits rose 12,000 to a seasonally adjusted 293,000 last week. Despite the rise, applications remain near pre-recession levels.

Asian markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei index jumping 0.3% to 16,734.14 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index falling 0.6% to 23,768.13. European markets were trading lower, and losses accelerated after Wall Street's decline, with Britain's FTSE 100 dropping 1% and Germany's DAX falling 1.6%.

Title: Alternate Campaign Reality: The Rise of Unskewed Polls and the Romney Lead

Article:

In an unusual turn of events, a parallel universe has emerged within the Republican political sphere, where Mitt Romney is leading in nearly every national poll released in September. This contrasts sharply with the reality portrayed by private polls among working Republican political operatives, who see Romney trailing in the race against President Obama.

This alternate campaign reality is most evident on television, talk radio, and the Internet, where swing-state polls showing Romney losing are not just inaccurate but part of a deliberate plot, according to some conservative pundits. Dick Morris, a former advisor to Bill Clinton and now a conservative commentator, predicted on Fox News last week that the GOP ticket would win in Florida, Ohio, Virginia, Nevada, and Pennsylvania. In public polls right now, Romney is losing in each of those states. Morris attributes the discrepancy to inaccurate polling data.

Rush Limbaugh, a conservative talk radio king, goes a step further, suggesting a more sinister motive behind the media and university polls. He claims that these polls are designed to depress and suppress Republican voters, with the intention of convincing the public that the election is already over.

The divide between Republican consultants and conservative media figures is not new, but the Internet has allowed this alternate campaign reality to flourish in a way that is both striking and depressing to political professionals and pollsters. One website, unskewedpolls.com, adjusts public polling data by including more Republicans in samples. The results: Romney leads in nearly every national poll released in September.

While arbitrarily reweighting polls is considered wildly unscientific, this has not stopped Republicans like Limbaugh and even Texas Governor Rick Perry from endorsing the site. Perry tweeted last week, "Always nice to get unfiltered, or in this case ‘unskewed,’ information."

As the election approaches, the divide between the real and alternate campaign realities continues to widen, raising questions about the role of media, polling, and information in shaping public opinion and voter behavior.

Title: "President Trump's Legal Team Leans Against Interview with Mueller's Team, Potential Supreme Court Battle Looms"

Article:

In a significant development in the ongoing investigation led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, President Donald Trump's attorney, Rudy Giuliani, has indicated that the president's legal team is leaning against agreeing to an interview with Mueller's team. This potential showdown could mark a historic moment in the investigation, which has been a significant point of contention for the White House amidst other pressing issues such as international trade and the summit with North Korea's Kim Jong Un.

Critics view Mueller's investigation as a serious distraction, while his supporters argue that he needs to complete his work. The investigation has been ongoing, yet there have been no charges related to the Trump campaign's alleged collusion with Russia.

A key figure in the investigation, former FBI director James Comey, is expected to face scrutiny in an upcoming report by the Justice Department inspector general. According to ABC, the draft report alleges that Comey was "insubordinate" for his behavior during the Hillary Clinton email probe. Comey played a significant role in initiating Mueller's probe, having leaked some of his conversations with President Trump in the hope of sparking a special counsel investigation into Russia, which eventually transpired.

The investigation has raised numerous questions, including the question of whether the president could pardon himself, a topic that has divided legal experts. However, the most pressing issue remains whether the president will agree to an interview with Mueller's team. In an exclusive interview with Pat Robertson on The 700 Club, Giuliani stated, "We're leaning toward not [agreeing to testimony]. But look, if they can convince us that it would be brief, it would be the point, there are five or six points they have to clarify. And with that, we can get this over, this long nightmare for the American public over."

If Mueller subpoenas Trump to testify, Giuliani's team would not passively accept it, potentially leading to a protracted legal battle that could reach the Supreme Court. The full interview with Rudy Giuliani on The 700 Club is available for viewing.

Title: "John W. Dean Reflects on Watergate: A Retrospective on the Mother of All Modern Political Scandals"

Article:

In an exclusive interview with CNN, John W. Dean, former counsel to the president during the Nixon White House, discusses his latest book, "The Nixon Defense: What He Knew and When He Knew It." Dean, who also writes a biweekly column for Verdict at Justia.com, invites viewers to watch his interview with Wolf Blitzer in the 6 p.m. hour Wednesday and see the story of Watergate on CNN's "The Seventies" at 9 p.m. ET Thursday.

Dean, who was in the midst of the Watergate scandal as White House counsel, emphasizes the complexity and historical significance of the Watergate scandal, which is considered the mother of all modern political scandals. He notes that, four decades later, there is no American scandal as well-documented as the Watergate scandal, nor is there any scandal that has left a deeper scar on American politics.

Dean explains that, over the past 40 years, he has devoted considerable time to studying the Watergate scandal, as the record has slowly surfaced in testimony, autobiographies, diaries, with the release of contemporaneous documents and secret tape recordings, investigative files of the FBI, the Watergate-related grand juries, a Senate Watergate committee, and a House impeachment committee, among other sources.

Dean warns that, as a nation, we easily forget our history, and asks if we want to repeat the mistakes of the 1970s, particularly Watergate. The Watergate scandal began on June 17, 1972, with the arrest of five burglars dressed in business suits, wearing surgical gloves, and carrying suitcases filled with electronic bugging equipment. The burglars were later identified as the director of security for the Committee to Reelect the President, and suspicion immediately focused on the Nixon White House.

Dean recounts his own role in the Watergate scandal, admitting that he made mistakes, such as returning to Washington from a trip to the Philippines when he had planned to spend a few days in San Francisco. He explains that, by the end of the day on June 19, 1972, he understood why the White House was assisting in the cover-up, as he learned that the same men involved in the Watergate break-in had undertaken an earlier operation for the White House by breaking into and ransacking the files of a psychiatrist treating Daniel Ellsberg, who had leaked the Pentagon Papers a year earlier.

Dean notes that, while he has never found any evidence that Nixon knew in advance of or ordered the Watergate break-in, he does know that Nixon had ordered an earlier break-in at the Brookings Institution when he believed they had a copy of the Pentagon Papers. He also reveals that Nixon's secret recordings of his conversations during those first few days after the arrests at the Watergate show that had the Watergate burglars not been arrested, they would have gone on to their true mission that night, which was to break in and bug the campaign headquarters of Nixon's Democratic opponent, Sen. George McGovern of South Dakota.

Dean concludes by emphasizing that Watergate did not really end with Nixon's resignation and departure from the White House on August 9, 1974. Rather, it played out for many months more in headline-grabbing events during the cover-up trial of his top aides, including former chief of staff H.R. "Bob" Haldeman, former top domestic affairs adviser John D. Ehrlichman, and former attorney general John N. Mitchell, who would be found guilty of perjury and obstruction of justice on January 1, 1975. Dean emphasizes that, while these men claimed at the time they were innocent men wrongly convicted, the record now shows that each of them quietly admitted to Judge John J. Sirica that in fact they had committed the offenses a jury had found them guilty of beyond a reasonable doubt.

Dean's interview with CNN and the series on the 1970s, titled "The Seventies," are informative, engaging, and accurate, uncovering video footage of the events long buried in archives, bringing to life memorable moments from these historic events.

Title: US Calls for De-escalation as G7 Imposes Fresh Sanctions on Russia over Ukraine

The United States has accused Russian military aircraft of entering Ukrainian airspace on multiple occasions, escalating tensions in the eastern part of the country. The Pentagon has called on Russia to "de-escalate the situation."

The statement came as the Group of Seven (G7) industrialized nations agreed on Saturday to swiftly impose new sanctions on Russia over Ukraine. The G7's joint statement expressed concern over Russia's lack of concrete actions in support of the Geneva accord and committed to act urgently to intensify targeted sanctions.

Talks are underway to secure the release of international observers seized by separatists in Ukraine. Russia has tens of thousands of troops deployed along its border with Ukraine, with pro-Moscow separatists occupying official buildings in a dozen eastern towns.

Russia has accused the West of wanting to "seize" Ukraine. In a statement on Friday, Pentagon spokesman Col. Steven Warren said Russian aircraft had entered Ukrainian airspace several times in the past 24 hours. He called on Moscow to take immediate steps to de-escalate the situation.

Last week, Ukraine and Russia struck an agreement in Geneva, calling for separatists to leave official premises and give up their arms. However, pro-Russian activists have refused to comply with the demands.

The G7's joint statement said Russia had taken "no concrete actions in support of the Geneva accord." The statement also committed to act urgently to intensify targeted sanctions and measures to increase the costs of Russia's actions. White House sources told reporters that sanctions could be in place as early as Monday, but it is unclear what form they will take.

On Friday, Ukraine's interior ministry said armed separatists had seized seven representatives from the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), as well as five Ukrainian army personnel and a bus driver. Pro-Russian leaders in Sloviansk confirmed the bus had been stopped near the town of Sloviansk and were checking the identities of those on board.

The self-proclaimed mayor of Sloviansk, Vyacheslav Ponomaryov, said at least one passenger had been carrying maps showing separatist checkpoints in the area, which suggested "their involvement in espionage." Last weekend, Mr. Ponomaryov broadcast an appeal to President Putin asking for Russian troops to protect the city from "fascists" after three of his men died in a gunfight.

Tensions have risen in recent days as Ukraine launched military raids to try to regain occupied buildings. At least two separatists have been killed in the raids, which Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov described as a "bloody crime." Mr. Lavrov repeated the accusation made previously by Moscow that Ukraine was waging a war against its own people.

Unrest in Ukraine began last November over whether the country should look towards Moscow or the West. Last month, Russia annexed Ukraine's mainly ethnic-Russian Crimean peninsula, following a referendum in the region that backed joining the Russian Federation but which the West and Kiev deemed illegal.

Title: Trump's China Policy: A Closer Look at the Challenges and Opportunities

Article:

As President Donald Trump meets with Chinese leader Xi Jinping, the looming threat of a trade war between the two largest economies continues to dominate discussions. The potential consequences of such a conflict, as warned by rival candidate Jeb Bush and President Xi himself, could lead to a global depression. However, the focus on the potential negative outcomes may overlook the deep-seated flaws in the global trade system, particularly those related to China.

For years, China has been integrated into the global trade system, with the expectation that it would adhere to the same rules as other nations. Trade experts argue that China has not lived up to these expectations, repeatedly violating both the letter and spirit of global trade rules.

Trump's election win, in part, was fueled by his critique of trade policies that he believes harm American workers. While outside experts may not share the president's broad brush approach, some argue that a tougher stance toward China is necessary. A damaging trade war may not be the most likely outcome, and the "just be patient" strategy carries its own risks.

Robert Atkinson, an economist who studies the ties between global trade and national economic performance, argues that China is a unique challenge due to its size and its determination to leverage its market power to gain a leadership role in advanced industries. When Beijing doesn't play by the accepted rules, the damage to other nations, including the US, is considerable.

Under President Barack Obama, the office of the US Trade Representative ramped up its engagement on alleged violations by China. The USTR's annual report covering 2016 lists settlements reached with China last year over subsidies, taxes, or other policies in industries including aircraft, autos, financial information, wind power, and green technologies.

However, critics of China's trade policies argue that much more needs to change. One of the biggest sore spots is the way foreign companies doing business in China are pressured to transfer knowledge to Chinese partner firms in industries such as aerospace. The World Trade Organization prohibits such demands, yet the Chinese arrangements are, in practice, hard to prosecute.

As Trump and Xi met at the Trump-branded Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida, there were few early signs of either progress or breakdown. The White House statement said the US president "noted the challenges caused by Chinese government intervention in its economy and raised serious concerns about the impact of China's industrial, agricultural, technology, and cyber policies on United States jobs and exports."

The outcome of Trump's policy toward China remains uncertain. His trade team is still in the process of being assembled, and some of his appointees differ in tone. One crucial decision will be how much to seek a broader international coalition to press China. Trump has voiced a penchant for bilateral dealing and dealmaking, but many experts argue that working with allies is more effective than working alone.

Atkinson argues that the goal isn't to block China's development but to insist on a rule-of-law system under which all parties can benefit. Coupled with innovation policies to maintain America's dynamism at home, such a strategy could avert the potential loss of key industries. "When we have pushed the Chinese in the past, in a respectful but firm way with our allies, we have prevailed," Atkinson says.

Title: Iowa Caucus Results Signal Long-Lasting Tension Within the Democratic Party

Article:

The narrow victory of Hillary Clinton in the Iowa Democratic caucus has set the stage for a potentially prolonged conflict between the Clinton establishment and the party's younger, more progressive base. The results, which saw Clinton edging out Bernie Sanders by a margin of 0.3 percentage points, have been described as a statistical tie, with the final delegate count decided by six coin tosses that have sparked controversy among Sanders' supporters.

Clinton's victory, while technically a win, has been met with skepticism and disappointment from both the media and Sanders' camp. The nature of the victory has left Clinton in a precarious position, as she cannot celebrate her "win" without appearing ungracious and grasping. Her supporters have been quick to oversell the victory, further antagonizing Sanders' supporters, many of whom are already hostile towards Clinton.

The Iowa caucus results have also dealt a significant blow to the Democratic Party, as the close margin of victory has all but sealed Clinton's nomination and effectively closed the door on any potential saviors entering the race. The ghost of Eugene McCarthy, who challenged President Johnson in the 1968 New Hampshire primary, has been invoked as a reminder of the potential impact of a left-wing challenger on the party.

The close results in Iowa have left the Democratic Party with a difficult road ahead, as Clinton and Sanders are set to face off in the New Hampshire primary on February 9th. The party will need to unite in order to take on the eventual Republican nominee in the general election, but the tension between the two candidates and their respective bases could make that a difficult task.

Jonah Goldberg, an American Enterprise Institute fellow and National Review contributing editor, is a member of ███'s Board of Contributors. In addition to its own editorials, ███ publishes diverse opinions from outside writers, including its Board of Contributors. To read more columns like this, go to the Opinion front page.

Title: US Increases Troop Presence on Southern Border, Deploys Additional 2,000 Soldiers

Article:

The United States is set to augment its military presence on its border with Mexico, with an additional 2,000 troops to be stationed, according to a Pentagon announcement. This brings the total number of troops stationed on the southern border to approximately 4,300.

The soldiers will assist border-patrol agents, carry out surveillance work, and install miles of razor wire. The move comes as President Donald Trump continues his battle with Congress over funds for a proposed wall along the border. Trump argues that such a barrier is necessary to curb illegal immigration.

The president's insistence on including wall funding in the US budget led to the longest government shutdown in US history. He recently struck a temporary deal to reopen government departments but has threatened to initiate another shutdown or declare a national emergency if his demands are not met. The current agreement expires on 15 February.

Trump is expected to address the issue in his annual State of the Union speech on Tuesday. Initially, the US defense department announced that 3,750 extra soldiers would be sent to the border, with many replacing troops already there. The first deployments took place in November.
