According to a Pentagon statement, these additional units will be deployed for 90 days, and the force composition will be evaluated to meet the mission of protecting and securing the southern border. Their tasks will include a mobile surveillance capability through the end of September 2019, as well as the emplacement of approximately 150 miles of concertina wire between ports of entry.

Last Thursday, President Trump tweeted that extra forces were being sent to the border to stop migrants he described as traveling in "caravans" and threatening an "invasion." He reiterated his claims on Sunday, tweeting, "If there is no wall, there is no security."

Trump has repeatedly described the situation on the Mexican border as a "crisis," although his critics have dismissed the use of troops as a political stunt. However, it is worth noting that Trump is not the first US president to send troops to the border with Mexico. President Barack Obama sent some 1,200 National Guard soldiers to guard the boundary, while President George W. Bush deployed about 6,000 troops to help Border Patrol agents in what was called Operation Jump Start.

In related news, officials in Texas recently revealed that nine migrants on hunger strike at an immigration detention center were being force-fed. Immigration officials are using plastic nasal tubes to feed some of the men, but relatives claim this is causing severe nosebleeds and vomiting. The detainees have refused food in protest against conditions at the El Paso Processing Center. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) says a federal judge authorized the force-feeding last month.

Title: Hillary Clinton's Email Practices During Tenure as Secretary of State Under Scrutiny

Article:

In a report by the State Department's Inspector General (IG), it has been found that Hillary Clinton, during her tenure as Secretary of State, disregarded cybersecurity guidelines when she used a private computer server for official communications. The IG's report criticizes Clinton for not preserving federal records and not complying with the Department's policies that were implemented in accordance with the Federal Records Act.

The report states that Clinton should have printed and filed any federal records she created and received on her personal account with the related files in the Office of the Secretary. Furthermore, Clinton should have surrendered all emails dealing with Department business before leaving government service. However, she or members of her team deleted about 30,000 of these emails before an investigation of her practices began.

The IG's report also mentions that Clinton stonewalled requests by the government for access to her server, which was in her Chappaqua, N.Y., home, with another discovered at an unsecured location in a Denver bathroom closet. Marcel Lazar, a Romanian computer hacker known as "Guccifer," has claimed to have hacked into Clinton's servers. The possibility of Chinese and Russian hackers accessing Clinton's emails also exists.

Clinton has claimed that she only used private email for her daughter's wedding and yoga classes. However, high-ranking government officials are aware of the regulations governing their tenure while in office and their responsibilities for the handling of records once they leave it. The FBI is currently investigating whether Clinton's failure to comply with the State Department's policies on records will lead to an indictment.

Clinton has invoked the "everybody has done it" defense, but this is not entirely accurate. The Wall Street Journal editorial notes that former Secretary of State Colin Powell's use of private email was limited, and he never set up an unsecure server in his home, as Clinton did.

The IG's report also refutes Clinton's defense by stating that notification is required when a user suspects compromise of a personally owned device containing personally identifiable information. However, the IG found "no evidence" that Clinton or her aides complied with this requirement.

For years, the Clintons have been accused of skirting laws and practicing disinformation, obfuscation, changing the subject, non sequiturs, and other tactics to block their enrichment or achieve political goals. This time, it is crucial that Hillary Clinton is not allowed to evade accountability for her actions, and her incidents of malfeasance should not be rewarded by being elected as the President of the United States.

Title: President Obama to Deliver Major Economic Speech in Midwest, Avoids Detroit Bailout Discussion

Article:

President Barack Obama will embark on a tour of the Midwest this week, delivering a significant speech on economic revival in Galesburg, Illinois, and Warrensburg, Missouri. The tour will commence with an address at Knox College in Illinois, where the president will outline his vision for rebuilding an economy that prioritizes the middle class and those striving to join it.

According to White House senior adviser Dan Pfeiffer, the speech will mark the beginning of a series of speeches that will detail the president's plans for economic recovery. Pfeiffer stated that the president aims to shift the focus from political point-scoring and rekindle discussions on issues that directly impact the middle class.

The speech is also intended to help the president regain control of his second term, which has been marred by scandals such as Benghazi, secret surveillance, and the misuse of Internal Revenue Service powers. Pfeiffer noted that the president believes that Washington has neglected the most pressing issue facing the country, and that too many in Congress are more concerned with political games and fabricated scandals.

The president will discuss economic measures he intends to implement, actions Congress should take, and initiatives that private industry can undertake to bolster the economy. He will also set the stage for upcoming budget and debt limit debates with Congress.

Detroit's financial woes, however, have dominated economic news in recent days. The city filed for Chapter 9 bankruptcy protection last Thursday, grappling with significant unfunded pension obligations for its unionized employees and other fiscal challenges. Despite calls for federal intervention, the White House has indicated that it will not provide financial aid to Detroit.

Vice President Joe Biden expressed uncertainty about the administration's ability to help Detroit, while White House press secretary Jay Carney stated that resolving insolvency issues is a matter for local leaders and creditors.

During his re-election campaign, President Obama emphasized his role in saving Detroit's auto industry with an $80 billion federal bailout in 2009. However, the president has resisted calls for a similar bailout for Detroit, opting instead to focus on infrastructure spending, universal preschool programs, and the economic benefits of comprehensive immigration reform during his Midwest tour.

The White House chose Knox College as the location for the president's speech due to its historical significance, as it was the same place where he delivered his first economic speech on a national stage in 2005, as a U.S. senator.

Title: Moderate House Republicans Break Ranks, Call for End to Government Shutdown

Article:

In a move that could signal a shift in the ongoing government shutdown standoff, some House Republicans facing tough reelection battles in 2014 are advocating for compromise and an end to the government shutdown. The focus of their ire is the ongoing fight over defunding the Affordable Care Act, or Obamacare.

Representatives Scott Rigell of Virginia, Pat Meehan of Pennsylvania, and Jon Runyan of New Jersey, who represent moderate districts, have expressed their desire for a clean Continuing Resolution (CR) to reopen the government.

Rigell, whose military-heavy district in the Hampton Roads area was narrowly carried by President Barack Obama in 2012, stated, "Republicans fought the good fight. The fight continues but is not advanced by a government shutdown that damages our economy and harms our military."

Meehan, whose suburban Philadelphia district was carried by Mitt Romney by a slight margin, said, "I came to Washington to fix government, not shut it down. At this point, I believe it's time for the House to vote for a clean, short-term funding bill to bring the Senate to the table and negotiate a responsible compromise."

Runyan, whose south central New Jersey district was carried by Obama by four percentage points, said, "Enough is enough. Put a clean (CR) on the floor and let's get on with the business we were sent to do."

Joining Rigell, Meehan, and Runyan in their call for a compromise are New York Rep. Peter King and Pennsylvania Rep. Charlie Dent, who have been vocal in their efforts to convince the House GOP to abandon its fight.

New Jersey Rep. Frank LoBiondo, who represents an Atlantic City-area seat that Obama won by eight percentage points, has indicated his displeasure with the House GOP's course of action. The 10-term congressman was quoted in the Philadelphia Inquirer as saying, "At a certain point, if the strategy is not going to get us a result or a conclusion, I'm not going to go along with it...I want to see a result. The bigger fight's coming on the debt limit."

Another endangered Republican, Illinois Rep. Rodney Davis, stopped short of calling on his party to throw in the towel but stressed that he wanted to reach an agreement. Davis, a freshman incumbent who represents a district that is nearly evenly divided between Democrats and Republicans, said, "Like most of those I represent, I remain opposed to Obamacare, but a government shutdown is absolutely unacceptable."

The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee (DCCC) has not been idle in this matter. On Tuesday, the DCCC launched an automated call campaign blasting vulnerable Republicans, including Davis, over the shutdown. The call targeting Davis stated, "While you were sleeping, Congressman Rodney Davis shut down the government. You heard that right. But even worse – Congressman Davis is still getting paid – and he's just not listening to our frustration."

In response, the DCCC labeled Davis as a member of the "Too Little, Too Late Caucus." This development comes as the DCCC and the Republican National Committee (RNC) have been engaged in a series of attacks over the shutdown, with the RNC accusing the DCCC of playing politics and the DCCC accusing the RNC of hypocrisy.

As the shutdown enters its second week, the pressure on both parties to find a solution is mounting. The potential for a default on U.S. debt obligations looms large if a deal is not reached by October 17, when the U.S. Treasury Department has estimated that the government will run out of cash to pay its bills. The stakes are high, and the clock is ticking.

Title: The American Health Care Act: A Step Toward Repeal and Reform, Despite Conservative Criticism

Article:

From the moment the Republican Party unveiled the American Health Care Act, the first iteration of what would evolve into the Obamacare repeal and replace legislation, conservatives have expressed dissatisfaction. The editors of Investor's Business Daily succinctly summarize the general right-wing reaction as: "Republicans have labored to produce a plan that replaces Obamacare with...Obamacare."

However, the editorial's assertion that the bill supports the key elements of Obamacare is disputable. In fact, the bill addresses several issues that conservatives have long criticized in the Affordable Care Act.

First and foremost, the American Health Care Act repeals the unconstitutional individual mandate, effective after December 31, 2015. This means that no American who failed to buy coverage last year will owe the Internal Revenue Service a penny in penalties, fines, taxes, or whatever Chief Justice John Roberts is currently calling them.

Similarly, the job-killing employer mandate will be retroactively repealed. Employers will no longer have to hold off hiring new workers to avoid hefty fines for not providing health insurance coverage that neither they nor their employees can afford.

The bill also eliminates numerous stealth taxes imposed by Obamacare. For example, it eliminates the tax on over-the-counter medications. Prior to Obamacare, individuals could pay for over-the-counter medication on a pre-tax basis using a Flexible Spending Account (FSA). The Affordable Care Act abolished that. The bill repeals Obamacare's cap on FSA contributions, which were unlimited before the advent of President Obama's "signature domestic achievement." This cap was particularly hard on parents of special needs children, many of whom used FSAs to pay for special needs education.

The much-maligned GOP plan also eliminates the high medical bill tax. Before "reform," people who incurred high medical bills received a deduction for medical expenses exceeding 7.5 percent of adjusted gross income. The Affordable Care Act increased that percentage to 10 percent. The much-maligned Republican plan also reduces Obamacare's HSA tax. Prior to Obamacare, early withdrawals from an HSA were taxed at 10 percent. The American Health Care Act takes that back down to 10 percent. The plan also eliminates the medical device tax, a natural-born job killer.

The list goes on, yet conservatives and libertarians are voicing complaints about provisions like the 30 percent premium surcharge that the bill would allow insurers to charge patients who wait until they are ill to buy coverage. However, such comparisons between this surcharge and the individual mandate are misleading. The individual mandate requires individuals to buy health insurance simply because they are alive, an assault on personal liberty. The GOP plan's much-discussed premium surcharge is an incentive based on an individual's choices. The former eliminates personal choice altogether. The latter incentivizes intelligent choices.

Moreover, while conservatives complain about the bill, they should consider that it does two things for which they have long been clamoring: it defunds Planned Parenthood and it reforms Medicaid. The benefits of the former are obvious—the taxpayers will no longer be forced to fork over hundreds of millions to the world's most notorious abortion mill and purveyor of infant body parts. Anyone who objects to the crimes against humanity committed by Cecile Richards and her army of abortionists should be celebrating this bill.

Likewise, they should beat the drum for the Medicaid provision. As House Speaker Paul Ryan put it in a press conference yesterday:

"It has a Medicaid per capita block grant, that's the biggest entitlement reform anybody has seen here for decades. It nearly doubles the amount of money people can contribute to health savings accounts, that is fundamental part and a crucial part of conservative healthcare policy."

However, it would appear that a lot of conservatives would rather have 100 percent of nothing than the partial repeal offered by the American Health Care Act. They carp about tax credits and inaccurately conflate them with Obamacare's unworkable system of subsidies. They claim the bill leaves the law's Byzantine regulations in place. And it is true that this plan isn't perfect. But perfect isn't one of our choices. If conservatives hold out for full repeal and cling to the fantasy of a free market replacement plan, there is a real danger that Obamacare will never be repealed.

Title: Al Qaeda Claims Responsibility for Charlie Hebdo Attack, French Authorities Investigate Paris Kosher Market Siege

Article:

In a video released on Wednesday, Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) claimed responsibility for last week's deadly attack on the French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo. The attack, which left 12 people dead, was years in the making, according to an AQAP leader in the video. The leader claimed U.S.-born cleric Anwar al-Awlaki was the mastermind behind the attack. Al-Awlaki, who was a spokesman for AQAP before his death in a U.S. drone strike in Yemen in 2011, is believed to have had ties with the gunmen who attacked the magazine.

Intelligence analysts have been trying to piece together whether the gunmen who attacked Charlie Hebdo met al-Awlaki on trips to Yemen. The new video's claim could bolster this theory. AQAP did not claim responsibility for Friday's deadly siege at a kosher grocery store in Paris, but praised it.

French security services have identified a suspected accomplice in that attack, according to the French newspaper Le Parisien. Police sources cited by the newspaper said one line of investigation is that the accomplice, a man from a Paris suburb, may have driven gunman Amedy Coulibaly to the kosher supermarket, where Coulibaly later shot dead four people. Coulibaly was killed in a police raid to end the siege. Said and Cherif Kouachi, the brothers who authorities say were behind the Charlie Hebdo attack, are also dead.

Charlie Hebdo's new edition hit newsstands Wednesday, a week after authorities say terrorists Said and Cherif Kouachi burst into its newsroom and gunned down staffers. The cover features a cartoon of the Prophet Mohammed crying. All 3 million copies sold out quickly, but more copies are coming soon, the magazine said.

The claim of responsibility for the deadly attack on the magazine came in a video showing AQAP commander Nasr Ibn Ali al-Ansi, with pictures of the Kouachis in the background. Al-Ansi praised the attack, saying it was revenge for Charlie Hebdo's depictions of Mohammed. Al-Ansi blamed not only Charlie Hebdo, but also France and the United States.

U.S. authorities said they think the video is authentic. But they were not ready to say that AQAP helped carry out the assault. "We're not there yet. There are good indicators that the group was behind the attack, but the intelligence community is still assessing," a senior administration official told CNN.

Investigators believe Cherif Kouachi left Yemen with as much as $20,000 from AQAP to carry out attacks, a U.S. official said. Le Parisien's report said investigators identified Coulibaly's suspected accomplice using keys for a motorbike discovered in an apartment they raided over the weekend. Also found inside the apartment, according to Le Parisien: a stash of weapons, explosives, and two ISIS flags. Coulibaly purportedly told authorities before he was killed that he belonged to ISIS.

With France on its highest level of alert, 10,000 troops have deployed across the country. Thousands of police officers are on patrol, including hundreds assigned to protect Jewish schools. Since the attacks, dozens of cases have been opened in France against people accused of expressing support for terrorism since the attacks, the Justice Ministry said. It's unclear how many people are blamed for the 54 infractions. The cases include investigations involving phone threats, cyberattacks, and Facebook posts, the ministry said. Some are in prison awaiting trial, some have already been convicted, and some have been released with a notice of a court date, ministry spokesman Pierre Rance said.

Title: Political Campaigns Employ Personalized and Targeted Approaches in Fundraising Efforts

Article:

In a bid to connect with potential donors on a more personal level, political campaigns are resorting to increasingly personalized and desperate-sounding fundraising emails. One such email, with a subject line reading "Need to reach you," mimics the tone of a plea from a friend or family member in distress.

Bill Scheel, a member of the campaign team for Arizona Democratic gubernatorial candidate Fred DuVal, acknowledges this trend towards personalization. "We want to be as personal as possible," he told FoxNews.com. "It's all part of a tremendous science that is now very important to campaigns."

However, Scheel clarifies that the DuVal campaign draws the line at sending "doom and gloom" emails, citing an example from this summer by the Tea Party Patriots, which began with the line, "The tears are starting to flow." Scheel believes such messages send the wrong message and are not in line with the positive and upbeat tone of their campaign.

Former Bush campaign and White House aide Taylor Griffin argues that the use of technology extends beyond subject lines to include email content and all of social media. He highlights the power of Facebook in crafting narrowly focused messages to potential voters based on their Internet profiles, including their shopping habits and websites visited.

Griffin also points out that campaigns typically hire firms that specialize in voter contact, phone canvasing, culling voter rolls, and acquiring membership lists. Strategists give the example of sending a pro-gun message to potential voters listed in the membership rolls of a Second Amendment advocacy group.

One email that particularly resonated with message-weary voters this year began with the subject line, "Would You Like Us to Leave You Alone?" This email, sent eight days before election night by the Conservative Campaign Committee, started with a compelling narrative of a long-time female conservative, described as a "true patriot" but tired of the constant stream of emails. However, the message eventually transitioned into a standard fundraising pitch.

Scheel understands the frustration such emails may cause, which is why the DuVal campaign and others allow recipients to unsubscribe. He also notes that too many unopened or rejected emails can create problems for campaigns with Internet watchdogs. "It's not to our advantage to keep sending emails that people won't open," Scheel said.

Title: GOP Healthcare Reform Bill in Jeopardy as Key Senators Express Opposition

Article:

In a significant turn of events, two Republican lawmakers have admitted that the initial GOP bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, is likely "dead." President Trump's proposal to solely repeal the law appears to be a "non-starter."

Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) expressed his doubts in a televised interview on CBS, stating, "I think my view is it's probably going to be dead." If Democrats are included in the process, he said, it does not mean they control the proposal. Instead, it means they can have amendments considered, and even when they lose, they are part of the democratic process.

Sen. Bill Cassidy (R-La.), speaking on a Sunday talk show, expressed uncertainty about the future of the healthcare reform. "We don't know what the plan is. Clearly, the draft plan is dead. Is the serious rewrite plan dead? I don't know," he said.

Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) also signaled pessimism, expressing concerns about the potential loss of the Senate majority if they fail to pass healthcare legislation. He added that the party should be "ashamed" for not being able to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act.

President Trump, in a tweet on Sunday, urged Republicans to follow through on their pledge to get rid of the health care law. "For years, even as a 'civilian,' I listened as Republicans pushed the Repeal and Replace of ObamaCare. Now they finally have their chance!" Trump tweeted.

At least 10 GOP senators have expressed opposition to the initial bill drafted by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.). With Republicans holding a 52-48 majority and Democrats standing united against the bill, just three GOP defections will doom it. The weeklong July 4 recess only raised more doubts among senators as many heard from constituents angry about the GOP bill and the prospect of rising premiums.

McConnell last week said he would introduce a fresh bill in about a week, aiming to scuttle and replace much of former President Barack Obama's health care law. However, McConnell also acknowledged that if the broader effort fails, he may turn to a smaller bill with quick help for insurers and consumers and negotiate with Democrats.

Sen. Ted Cruz's (R-Texas) plan, which aims to lower premiums for healthy people, has drawn support from the White House and some conservatives in the House. However, his proposal has limited appeal to Republican moderates, with Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) telling Iowa Public Radio that it may be "subterfuge to get around pre-existing conditions."

Cruz, on Sunday, sought to dismiss Grassley's criticism as a "hoax" being pushed by Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer. Cruz insisted that people will be able to get the coverage they need at an affordable price, casting his plan as a compromise to unify the Republican party on a GOP health bill.

"When it comes to repealing Obamacare, what I think is critical is that Republicans, we've got to honor the promise we made to the voters that millions of Americans are hurting under Obamacare," Cruz said. "In my view, failure is not an option."

Title: New Book by Gabriel Sherman Provides Controversial Insight into Fox News and Roger Ailes

Article:

A new book titled "The Loudest Voice in the Room," written by New York Magazine contributing editor Gabriel Sherman, is set to be published on January 21. The book promises to offer a fresh perspective on Fox News, drawing on over 600 interviews with individuals who have interacted with Roger Ailes, the network's founder and former CEO.

In anticipation of potential backlash, the book's publisher and author are already preparing a countermeasure. A new website has been launched to promote the book and serve as a source for fact-checking and combating misinformation throughout the book's release.

The website features caricatures of key figures in Ailes' world, including Rupert Murdoch, "The Mogul," and "Champ," described as Ailes' guard dog. The book's release coincides with USA Today's publication of "The Unbeatable Roger Ailes," an article focusing on Fox News' 2013 ratings triumphs.

Despite the competitive landscape, Fox News' audience outpaced both MSNBC and CNN combined in 2013. However, it's worth noting that the cable audience, despite its political influence, is not particularly large. The average Fox prime-time audience in 2013 was little over a million people, while MSNBC's 2013 non-election-year prime-time viewership was 640,000, and CNN's was 568,000.

"The Loudest Voice in the Room" has been in the works for over two years. Sherman did not interview Ailes for the book, and Ailes granted nearly unprecedented access to Zev Chafets for his biography. In August, after Brian Lewis, a senior adviser to Ailes, was fired, Sherman speculated that it meant Ailes was "more isolated than ever before" — a claim that Fox News executives quickly refuted.

The book's release is expected to stir controversy and provide a unique insight into the inner workings of Fox News and its influential figurehead, Roger Ailes.

Title: Iowa Democrats Show Resistance to Clinton's Presidential Bid, Raising Questions for 2016 Campaign

Article:

In the 2008 presidential race, it was the state of Iowa that thwarted Hillary Clinton's presidential aspirations. The energetic caucus-goers in Iowa, known for their preference for non-establishment ideals, voted for Barack Obama and John Edwards over Clinton, forcing her to earn the party's nomination. Now, as Clinton prepares to mount a new campaign for the presidency, she faces a similar challenge in Iowa.

According to a report in Monday's Wall Street Journal, county Democratic officials in Iowa have expressed reservations about Clinton's ability to win a general election and her fundraising ties to Wall Street firms and corporations, which remain a target of liberal ire. Many county officials have expressed a desire to see senators such as Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Bernie Sanders of Vermont enter the race, though they are split over whether any could gain traction and overtake Clinton.

Jennifer Herrington, chair of the Page County Democrats in southwest Iowa, stated, "My heart wouldn't be in it for Hillary to the extent that it might be if it was a different candidate. I admire Hillary, she'd be a great president, but you know, she isn't my first choice I guess."

Iowa's Democratic electorate mirrors its Republican counterpart. In 2012, Mitt Romney came in a narrow second place behind former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum, and for much of the evening, it looked like Romney had shocked the political world by emerging from Iowa victorious. However, for all of Romney's 24.5 percent of the Iowa vote, another three-quarters backed a non-establishment candidate.

A narrow loss for Clinton in Iowa could spell disaster for her second presidential bid, but that prospect seems remote. The Clinton machine has, thus far, been able to fend off top-tier challengers. However, the discontent with Clinton is palpable, and her support in the polls could be an artificial result of standing alone on the presidential stage.

Democrats who want to see Clinton challenged in a primary are also smartly laying the foundations to blame her for a 2016 defeat if a challenge does not materialize. Local Democrats note that the energy, donations, and political infrastructure acquired during a contested primary also become critical tools to use in the general election. Without those, the Democratic nominee is likely to be at a disadvantage when the vibrant and ideologically diverse GOP concludes its primary contest.

While the argument that a party that undergoes a contested primary is a stronger party is a valid contention, Clinton is unlikely to welcome a serious challenge. Memories from Iowa in 2008 are still fresh, and anti-Clinton forces, too, seem resigned. Those disaffected liberals who are prepared to accept her coronation are also preparing to consign the name Clinton to history's dishonorable scrap piles should she lose. It would be a bitter irony that the name Clinton, one which for the last 20 years has been associated with reviving the moribund Democratic brand, might soon become synonymous with its destruction.

Title: Financial Challenges for Churches During Holy Week Amidst COVID-19 Pandemic

Article:

As the traditional Holy Week commences with Palm Sunday tomorrow, many churches across the United States are grappling with the impact of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. With most churches closed due to government decrees or voluntary shutdowns, the usual Sunday collection plates have disappeared, leading to a financial crisis for churches that heavily rely on donations from worshippers for their survival.

In response, the Archdiocese of Newark, New Jersey, has set up an online GoFundMe donation page, allowing anyone to contribute to specific parishes or a more general "Parishes in Need Fund." Cardinal Joseph W. Tobin stated, "Our parishes face increased risk of financial shortfalls due to the COVID-19 pandemic and its effects on everyday life."

Holy Week is a significant source of donations for these churches, with a substantial portion of the funds used to support charitable work. The priests and clergy use these donations to aid hungry families, pay rent, and fund various other charitable activities.

Bishop Robert Casey of the Archdiocese of Chicago expressed concern, stating, "It's a homecoming time for us, but it's also a very important fundraising time that allows us to continue with our mission and our ministries. This Holy Week will be especially worrisome for our parishes."

In addition to funding charitable activities, donations are crucial for payroll, church employees, and third-party employee contracts, including maintenance workers and cleaning staff. Father Paul Vigil of St. Timothy's Catholic Church in Los Angeles emphasized the Archdiocese of Los Angeles's efforts to avoid furloughs and layoffs during this time.

With many families struggling financially, the churches are facing a tough time asking for donations. Father Vigil said, "The last thing we want to do is lay off anyone or furlough especially during this time."

Despite the challenges, the historic generosity of the American people is expected to help churches navigate through this pandemic. The churches will continue their mission, seen as God's work on earth, with enough devout believers to carry on. As always, they will survive, having weathered depressions, wars, and now, a pandemic, the latest challenge they face.

Title: Assessing the Assassination of Qassim Suleimani: A Historical Perspective on U.S. Assassination Policy

Article:

In the aftermath of the targeted assassination of Iranian Maj. Gen. Qassim Suleimani, a high-ranking official of a foreign government, questions have arisen regarding the legality and morality of the U.S.'s actions. This article aims to provide a historical perspective on the United States' assassination policy, tracing its evolution from the 1970s to the present day.

The assassination of Qassim Suleimani, carried out last week, has been labeled a state-sponsored murder. This act, however, is not a new phenomenon in U.S. foreign policy. The United States has a long history of attempting to skirt the assassination ban, a policy put in place following the disclosures by the Church Committee in the 1970s, which revealed the CIA's secret attempts to assassinate foreign leaders, most notably Cuba's Fidel Castro.

In the 1970s, the assassination ban was not an accepted practice in a democracy that aspired to serve as a role model for the world. However, the reform-minded era now seems antiquated in a nation whose greatest military innovation in the 21st century has been the targeted killing of individuals by remote control.

The Clinton administration initiated this pattern in 1998, in response to the bombings of two U.S. embassies in East Africa by Al Qaeda. The White House launched cruise missile strikes against what they claimed were terrorist training camps near Khost, Afghanistan. The primary target was Osama bin Laden. In this instance, the Clinton administration's lawyers prepared a euphemism-laden opinion to provide legal cover for their actions, marking the beginning of a long pattern.

After 9/11, political concerns about the assassination ban were largely set aside due to the overwhelming public support for the new, so-called global war on terror. However, the government's lawyers still sought legal authorization for counterterrorism strikes. This authorization came in the form of the Authorization for Use of Military Force (AUMF), a congressional legislation passed just days after 9/11, which has provided the basic legal authorization for counterterrorism strikes ever since.

Armed with the AUMF and other legal backstops, the Bush and Obama administrations began to kill at will. This campaign, which has claimed countless innocent lives and destabilized nations, has been almost entirely counterproductive. It has made Americans numb to endless war. However, the U.S. gained public and legal support for targeted killings only for what it described as the asymmetric fight against terrorism, targeting suspected terrorists, or "non-state actors."

The Trump administration's assassination of Qassim Suleimani, a high-ranking official of a foreign government, marks a departure from this pattern. Suleimani was not a "non-state actor." He was the head of the Quds Force, the elite external operations arm of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, which operated with impunity throughout Iraq under his leadership. He ran Iran's ground campaign against ISIS in Iraq, in parallel to the American air campaign, and employed Shia militias and their ruthless tactics to defeat the cult-like group.

In conclusion, the assassination of Qassim Suleimani raises questions about the United States' assassination policy and its adherence to international law. As the U.S. continues to grapple with these issues, it is crucial to understand the historical context that has led to this moment.

Title: Trump's Policy Stances: A Mixed Bag of Traditional Republican and Democratic Ideologies

Article:

As the 2016 presidential race heats up, Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee, is facing a challenge in winning over skeptical Republicans. In several key policy areas, Trump's views align more with the Democratic Party, particularly on trade and social issues, creating a complex political landscape for the billionaire businessman.

Trump's policy positions are not easily categorized within traditional Republican orthodoxy. He has expressed opposition to environmental and corporate regulations, advocates for lower tax rates, and maintains a firm stance on abortion rights. However, his views on trade, social security, and foreign policy diverge significantly from the GOP's established positions.

Trade, for instance, is a contentious issue for Trump. While he claims his views are not dissimilar from the rest of the Republican Party, he has vowed to renegotiate or abandon existing trade deals, such as the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) and the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP). Trump's stance on trade is shared by Democratic candidate Bernie Sanders.

On social security, Trump's position aligns with that of Hillary Clinton. He has stated that he has no plans to scale back benefits or raise the qualifying retirement age, a stance that puts him at odds with House Speaker Paul Ryan, who has advocated for fundamental changes to entitlement programs.

Trump's tax plan, which calls for lowering the top tax rate for the wealthiest Americans and slashing the corporate tax rate, has been criticized as disproportionately benefiting the rich. Trump now appears to be distancing himself from his own tax plan, stating that it was a starting point for negotiations and that he would like to see the middle class benefit more from any tax law changes.

Trump's foreign policy stance is also a departure from traditional Republican views. He has advocated an "America First" approach, which some of his advisers describe as a "third way." Clinton, on the other hand, has advocated for a "smart power" approach that combines diplomatic, legal, economic, political, and cultural tools to expand American influence.

In the foreign policy arena, Trump has sought to portray Clinton as a hawkish candidate who is quick to lead the country into conflict. He has also criticized international alliances, such as NATO, questioning the structure that sees the U.S. paying for most of its costs.

Trump's policy positions, particularly on trade and social security, have created a complex political landscape for the 2016 presidential race. As the general election approaches, it remains to be seen how Trump will navigate these differences and appeal to both Republican and Democratic voters.

Title: St. Louis Couple Surrenders Rifle to Police After Confrontation with Protesters

A husband and wife who gained national attention after brandishing firearms at protesters outside their St. Louis home have turned over a rifle to police following a search warrant execution. The incident occurred on Friday, as authorities investigated the June 28 confrontation between the couple and a group protesting police brutality and the city's mayor's actions.

The couple, Mark and Patricia McCloskey, were caught on video armed with a rifle and a handgun as they confronted the protesters in their affluent St. Louis neighborhood of Central West End. Images and videos of the confrontation circulated on social media during the Black Lives Matter protests that took place across the country following the death of George Floyd.

In a video of the incident, Mark McCloskey is heard yelling, "Get the hell out of my neighborhood. Private property. Get out."

The St. Louis Metropolitan Police Department (SLMPD) stated in a Saturday statement that detectives executed a search warrant at the McCloskey residence. According to the statement, seized as evidence from the residence was a Colt, semi-automatic,.223 caliber rifle.

Attorney Joel Schwartz, who is now representing the McCloskeys, told NBC News in a phone interview that the McCloskeys' home was not searched by police, and they voluntarily surrendered the rifle. The second weapon was turned over to the previous lawyer, Schwartz said.

Schwartz maintained his clients' innocence and stated they were "law-abiding citizens who were well within their rights." The attorney added that the couple regrets their actions but did not break any laws. The St. Louis Circuit Attorney's Office said the matter remains under investigation.

In a June statement, police described the McCloskeys as "victims" of trespassing and fourth-degree assault. According to police, the McCloskeys stated they were on their property when they heard a loud commotion coming from the street. When they went to investigate, they observed a large group of subjects forcefully breaking an iron gate marked with "No Trespassing" and "Private Street" signs.

Demonstrators were in the neighborhood to protest against police brutality and Mayor Lyda Krewson, a Central West End resident who had released the names and addresses of activists who want to defund the police. Krewson has since apologized.

Daniel Shular, a freelance photojournalist who was at the protest, previously told NBC News that he did not see anyone break the gate leading to the neighborhood and recalled seeing people simply walk through an open gate.

"I kind of turned around to take some pictures of people coming through the gate, then I turned back around, and by then, he had his long gun in his hand," he said. "And the woman came out with a pistol and started pointing it with her finger on the trigger at everybody."

Shular said he saw at least one armed protester but added, "It's not super out of the ordinary for the protests here."

Albert Watkins, the previous attorney for the McCloskeys, said last month that his clients are supporters of the Black Lives Matter movement and became fearful because white protesters were acting aggressively.

Title: Univision's Controversial Coverage of President Trump's Mount Rushmore Speech Sparks Debate

Article:

In a divisive turn of events, Univision, a broadcast network known for its advocacy on immigration issues, has been criticized for its coverage of President Donald Trump's Independence Day eve address at Mount Rushmore. The Trump campaign labeled the network's reporting as biased, comparing it to MSNBC, while Univision's coverage more closely resembles a hybrid of TeleSur and Al-Jazeera, as it is owned by the National Council of La Raza.

The network's coverage of Trump's Rushmore speech was criticized for its framing of the event as a "campaign rally" and the omission of significant portions of the president's speech. Anchor Arantxa Loizaga reported that the event, which issued 7,500 tickets, lacked social distancing and face masks, and that Trump's speech further divided the nation during a time of social, economic, and health crises. However, the network omitted Trump's mentions of Washington, Lincoln, Roosevelt, and Jefferson, as well as his proposed National Garden, and his denunciations of the radical left's attempts to erase history.

Senator Tammy Duckworth's (D-IL) subsequent reaction to the speech, dismissing Trump as spending all his time "talking about dead traitors," only makes sense if all she watched was Univision's report. This suggests that Univision's reporting may have influenced Duckworth's perspective.

Univision's coverage of Tucker Carlson's subsequent criticism of Duckworth's willingness to have a "conversation" on the erasure of George Washington is also noteworthy. Carlson's criticism came after Duckworth told CNN that she supported a "national dialogue" over the request to eliminate monuments to such personalities as George Washington, a slave owner, in the midst of the debate over symbols and racism.

Univision's reporting, in this instance, has been criticized for enabling the move to erase America's founding. There is no mention of the movement to erase American history, or of the broader effort to cancel America's Founding. There is no mention of the violent mobs that have endeavored to vandalize statues of George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, and Frederick Douglass. Univision, in an attempt to stoke racial grievance, seems to focus on the side of the monument debate that best suits their interests.

Title: ESG Investing Proves Profitable Amidst COVID-19 Crisis: A Shift Towards Ethical Corporate Practices

Article:

In the wake of the global coronavirus pandemic, a new wave of corporate behavior is emerging, signaling a shift towards a more communal and sustainable approach. This change in ethos is reflected in the growing emphasis on Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) practices, a code of conduct that has gained traction in the business world in recent years.

Companies are adopting measures such as furloughing workers instead of firing them, donating equipment, and contributing to their communities in various ways. They are also suspending dividends to shareholders and postponing executive bonuses.

Intriguingly, research by Bloomberg Intelligence and RBC Capital Markets indicates that investors who have purchased stocks in companies with strong ESG performance have outperformed other broad indexes this year. Moreover, Bank of America reports an ongoing influx of money into ESG mutual funds.

This trend suggests that, as the economic tide recedes, corporations that prioritize long-term sustainability over short-term profits, and address issues like climate change and inequality, are proving to be more financially viable. In other words, doing good is proving to be profitable.

Looking ahead to the post-COVID-19 world, Barclays estimates that the use of ESG by investors may accelerate. The crisis is viewed as a prelude to potential economic shocks in the future, such as climate change. Investors are increasingly looking to corporations to aid in our collective resilience.

Amidst the current investor panic, there appears to be a growing appreciation for ethical values in companies over bottom-line profits. The virus crisis seems to be lifting many codes of behavior. Could this mark a significant shift in capitalism?

Title: White House Deputy Director of Communications Discusses Economic Gains for Non-College Graduates and Blue-Collar Workers under Trump Administration

In an interview on SiriusXM's "███ Sunday" with host Matt Boyle, White House Deputy Director of Communications Adam Kennedy discussed the economic gains made by Americans without college degrees and those with a military background under President Donald Trump's administration.

Kennedy highlighted the House of Representatives' passage of the United States-Mexico-Canada Trade Agreement (USMCA) and the broader economy. He emphasized the administration's focus on prioritizing American families and workers in their policy initiatives.

One of the key points Kennedy made was the significant economic benefits for blue-collar workers, particularly in the manufacturing sector. He stated that non-supervisory positions, or those who are on the factory floor, have experienced the highest wage gains. The USMCA, according to Kennedy, will further strengthen and accelerate this growth by implementing tougher labor standards for manufacturing, thereby discouraging factories from moving to Mexico.

Kennedy also mentioned that Republicans are united in their opposition to the Democrats' impeachment push against the president. In response to a question about a potential Senate impeachment trial, Kennedy expressed the belief that a bipartisan opposition in the Senate is more likely, with Republicans remaining united in their support for the president.

The interview concluded with Kennedy noting the Republicans' strong unity and the Democrats' apparent division on the impeachment issue. "███ Sunday" broadcasts live on SiriusXM Patriot 125 from 7 p.m. to 10 p.m. Eastern (4 p.m. to 7 p.m. Pacific).

Title: Tacoma Gun Sales Tax: A New Frontier in the Gun Regulation Debate

Article:

Tacoma, Washington, is poised to become one of a select few U.S. cities to impose a high tax on gun sales, marking a new phase in the ongoing debate over local governments' authority to regulate firearms. The proposed tax, which would collect $25 per gun sale to fund violence prevention programs, is modeled on a law in neighboring Seattle that has already been upheld by the state supreme court.

The tax, which would also apply to ammunition, has sparked controversy, with opponents arguing it could drive gun shops out of the industrial port city of 215,000 residents. In Seattle, lawmakers projected $300,000 to $500,000 in annual gun taxes, but last year only received $77,642 due to gun stores relocating.

Dan Davies, co-owner of Mary's Pistols in Tacoma, expressed concern, stating, "It'll put us out of business; there's no ifs, ands, or buts about it."

Ryan Mello, the Tacoma councilman behind the measure, counters these concerns, predicting the tax will generate between $30,000 and $40,000 annually for violence prevention programs while making gun purchases less appealing.

The proposed tax has drawn opposition from major pro-gun groups, including the National Shooting Sports Foundation, the firearms-industry trade association. Lawrence Keane, the senior vice president of government relations and public affairs for the National Shooting Sports Foundation, expressed concern that the tax could set a precedent for other cities to follow.

Aero Precision, a gun parts manufacturer with around 400 employees in Tacoma, has stated its opposition to the tax and threatened to explore other options if the tax is implemented. Gun store owner Sergey Solyanik moved his business from Seattle to Lynnwood due to the city's gun tax, citing lower prices outside the city.

The National Rifle Association (NRA) has been a significant force in the passage of so-called gun pre-emption laws, or laws that limit local authorities' ability to regulate guns. Cities across the country have attempted to circumvent these prohibitions with limited success.

In Pittsburgh, restrictions on semiautomatic rifles like the AR-15 model used in a 2018 mass shooting at a synagogue were met with a lawsuit backed by the NRA and have since been put on hold. Last week, a Washington state judge ruled that Edmonds, a municipality north of Seattle, cannot enforce a new city law requiring gun owners to keep their guns locked up at home.

Cook County in Illinois, home to Chicago, passed a gun tax in 2013, and Seattle followed in 2015. Tim Burgess, a former Seattle city council member, introduced the tax as a means to fund a gun violence research and prevention program at a local hospital, Harborview Medical Center.

In 2017, the state supreme court ruled in favor of Seattle and against the NRA, the NSSF, and the Second Amendment Foundation, stating that the tax's primary purpose is not to regulate firearms but "to raise revenue for the public benefit."

Title: GOP Lawmakers Remain Silent on Trump's Call for Foreign Interference in Elections

Article:

In the aftermath of the release of a rough transcript of a call in which President Donald Trump urged Ukraine's president to investigate the Bidens, a notable silence from Republican lawmakers has been observed on television. This silence has been particularly evident on MSNBC, with none of the 53 Republican senators appearing on the network since the call's release, according to a source. Similarly, only four of 197 Republican House members have appeared on MSNBC, with one of them not running for reelection.

CNN has reported a similar trend, with only seven Republican House members appearing on the network during this time period, but no senators. The lack of response from Republican lawmakers has become a story in itself, with CNN displaying the names of the lawmakers in a graphic that read, "GOP Lawmakers Silent On Trump's Call For China To Dig Up Biden Dirt."

One Republican senator, Ron Johnson, broke the silence on Sunday's "Meet the Press," but the interview quickly went viral due to its contentious nature. Host Chuck Todd became visibly exasperated with Johnson after the senator deflected questions about Ukraine to talk about emails by former FBI agent Peter Strzok, a recurring character in the conservative media narrative of a "deep state" out to get Trump.

The tense exchange between Todd and Johnson was met with praise for Todd's aggressive handling of the interview, with New York University journalism professor and media critic Jay Rosen tweeting, "I view @ MeetThePress almost every week. Today his tone — I mean his voice itself — was different, as if the gravity of events had sunk in and his patience with denial had run out."

Another GOP senator, Roy Blunt of Missouri, visited CBS' "Face the Nation" on Sunday, where host Margaret Brennan asked if it were "appropriate to ask for a foreign government to interfere in the election." Blunt suggested the president was joking when he called on China to investigate the Bidens, a response echoed by stalwart Trump defender Rep. Jim Jordan on ABC's "This Week."

Republican lawmakers have successfully dodged questions in the past about Trump's conduct, such as an outrageous tweet or offensive remark. However, impeachment is not a matter that can be easily dismissed, and the silence from Republican lawmakers has become a story in itself after two weeks of revelations, including explosive text messages among diplomats and Trump's shocking call on the White House lawn for China to investigate the Bidens.

Some Republican lawmakers have criticized the Syria decision, while also blasting the NBA for apologizing to China after the general manager of the Houston Rockets expressed support on Twitter for pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong. However, the idea of China interfering in the sanctity of the NBA is offensive to them, while the same standard for American elections results in the sound of crickets, according to CNN's Jake Tapper.

As the impeachment inquiry moves forward, it remains to be seen if more Republican lawmakers will break their silence and speak out against Trump's actions. The silence of these lawmakers has raised questions about their willingness to stand up for the principles of free and fair elections and their allegiance to the president.

Title: President Obama Participates in Reddit AMA, Breaks Site Record, and Launches "Internet 2012" Bus Tour

Article:

In a move that underscores the increasing role of technology and social media in political campaigns, President Barack Obama took part in a Reddit "Ask Me Anything" (AMA) session today, becoming the latest high-profile individual to engage with users on the popular social media and forum site.

The session, which began at 4:00 p.m. ET, saw the president fielding hundreds of questions within minutes. The site experienced temporary downtime, returning an error message when users attempted to log in or update. The authenticity of the president's participation was confirmed by the Obama campaign with a tweet and a photo of the president at his computer.

During the AMA, the president discussed a range of topics, including internet freedom, the space program, the most challenging decision of his first term (the surge in Afghanistan), and the White House beer ("it's tasty").

Reddit founder Alexis Ohanian expressed his excitement about the event in a quick email to ███, stating, "I'm thrilled, obviously, but what makes this even more exciting is that President Obama is doing this AMA from Charlottesville, VA - the same place where 7 years ago, Steve Huffman and I started the company that'd create Reddit. (We were undergrads at UVA)."

In addition to the AMA, Reddit and Ohanian have launched an "Internet 2012" bus tour. The bus will travel from Denver to Danville, Kentucky, where organizers will speak with Americans, including students and startup founders, about their internet usage and legislation surrounding it.

After an hour, Obama had amassed hundreds of comments and questions on Reddit. The site remained operational, at least for some users, with the president's closing comment being, "If you want to know what I think about this whole reddit experience - NOT BAD!"

Title: FOX Business Network to Host GOP Debate in Charleston, South Carolina

Article:

The FOX Business Network will host the sixth Republican debate of the 2016 presidential campaign on Thursday, January 14, at 6 P.M. ET in Charleston, South Carolina. The debate, which will feature seven candidates in the main event, is set to take place at the North Charleston Coliseum and Performing Arts Center.

The debate's location is significant, as it is less than 10 miles from the Emanuel AME Church, the site of last June's mass shooting. Gun control is expected to be a topic of discussion, given President Obama's mention of it in Tuesday's State of the Union Address and South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley's revisiting the incident in her Republican response.

The debate's venue is situated near the Cooper River and a bustling container-ship and car-carrier operation, which has transformed Charleston from a Navy town to a thriving hub of maritime commerce. This provides an opportunity for questions about the global economy.

The debate's format could potentially see a more civil and focused discussion among the candidates, as there are only seven participants in the main event. The debate will be the second time the Fox Business Network has hosted a Republican debate, and it may be the first time an evening with the Republicans does not devolve into pouting, posturing, and crosstalk.

The debate will follow Sunday's Democratic debate, which will be carried by NBC. The Republican candidates will be vying for the support of South Carolina's conservative electorate, which is the most conservative of the four stops on the February primary circuit.

The debate's format will allow for each candidate to present their views on various issues, including gun control, the global economy, and foreign policy. The debate is expected to provide insight into the candidates' positions and their ability to articulate their views in a clear and concise manner.

In the spirit of the Low Country, here are six things to watch for during the debate:

1. The candidates' responses to President Obama's State of the Union Address, particularly on issues such as the situation in Iran, the emphasis on guns, and the use of the term "Muslim" in relation to hate crimes.
2. The potential for a heated exchange between candidates Ted Cruz and Donald Trump regarding Cruz's Canadian birth and any undisclosed loans from Goldman Sachs.
3. The candidates' positions on social issues, such as abortion and same-sex marriage, and their appeal to the conservative electorate in South Carolina.
4. The candidates' strategies for appealing to moderate voters in the upcoming primaries, particularly in New Hampshire.
5. The candidates' positions on foreign policy, particularly in relation to the Middle East and North Korea.
6. The candidates' ability to present a clear and concise message, particularly in relation to their economic plans and their ability to create jobs.

The debate is expected to be a lively and informative event, providing insight into the candidates' positions and their ability to articulate their views in a clear and concise manner. The debate will be an important event in the 2016 presidential campaign, and it is expected to be closely watched by voters across the country.

Title: Defense Cuts Threaten Political Reputations as Sequester Looms

Article:

The impending automatic spending cuts, colloquially known as the sequester, are not only a pressing policy concern but also a potential political liability for lawmakers representing defense-heavy districts. The $1.2 trillion in defense and domestic spending cuts could not only trigger another recession, but also pose a threat to the re-election prospects of lawmakers who support the cuts.

From the Navy shipyards of Norfolk to the aerospace industry hangars in Southern California, and in the corporate towers of defense contractors within the Beltway, the sequester is not just an urgent policy matter, but a political issue that could impact the 2013 elections.

Republicans, who are advocating for the elimination of the sequester and the sparing of the Pentagon, are already targeting Democrats who insist on new tax revenues as part of any deal to roll back military cuts.

Rep. Mike Coffman (R-Colo.), a veteran of the first Gulf War and the Iraq War, stated, "Any member of Congress that would defend the sequester and not come up with an alternative or [insist on revenues], I think that in a competitive district, that they would be open to attack for cutting defense too deeply."

A study showed that deep defense cuts would cost 1 million jobs nationwide, with significant impacts in California, Virginia, and Florida. In the tossup race between Democratic Rep. Mark Critz and Republican Keith Rothfus in Pennsylvania's 12th Congressional District, Rothfus has criticized Critz for rejecting GOP proposals to shield the Pentagon cuts, despite both parties having issues with the package of cuts, which affects domestic safety net programs.

The looming sequester leaves Democrats in a difficult position, as they must balance honoring last year's debt limit deal, which put the defense cuts trigger into law, and protecting jobs in their home district. The projected military cuts have made for easy targeting by Republican operatives, who are trying to portray some Democrats as willing to eliminate stable defense-oriented jobs.

The National Republican Congressional Committee has criticized Democratic lawmakers like Reps. Larry Kissell of North Carolina, Bill Owens of New York, and John Barrow of Georgia for rejecting plans to save cuts from hitting Forts Bragg, Drum, and Gordon.

"These Democrats are already on record opposing common-sense reforms that would avoid these devastating cuts to local jobs and America's military," said Paul Lindsay, an NRCC spokesman.

Rep. Bobby Scott (D-Va.) agrees with Republicans on at least this point: that these cuts would be cataclysmic. The sequester's impact on jobs and the economy, as well as its political implications, will likely be a significant factor in the upcoming elections.

Title: FDA Approves Emergency Use of Ebola Blood Testing Kit as Survival Rates in West Africa Improve

The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has granted emergency approval for a new diagnostic kit to test blood for the Ebola virus, as doctors report a survival rate in one hard-hit area that has climbed to about 70 percent. The FDA's announcement came on Wednesday, following a day-earlier posting of the approval on its website.

This latest move is part of a series of emergency authorizations issued since October, following the federal government's declaration that the ongoing health crisis necessitates the use of testing methods that have not undergone the ordinary regulatory approval process. The approval was based on a 2006 determination by then-Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff that the Ebola virus poses a material threat against the United States population sufficient to affect national security.

The United States has seen four confirmed cases of the virus so far, including three healthcare workers and one man, Thomas Eric Duncan, who died in Texas after contracting the virus in Liberia. On Wednesday, Liberia's U.N. peacekeeping mission reported its fourth Ebola case. A U.N. spokesman stated in a statement that the infected worker was from Liberia and was transferred to an Ebola treatment unit.

The 2014 Ebola outbreak in West Africa was the largest outbreak of the disease in history, killing over 7,500 people in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone, according to figures released Wednesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). However, doctors are reporting signs of improvement, with survival rates in Sierra Leone dramatically increasing.

In a letter published online Wednesday by the New England Journal of Medicine, several doctors described 581 cases they dealt with at an Ebola treatment center in Sierra Leone's capital, Freetown, in late September. About 31 percent of the patients died, including 38 people who were dead upon arrival. But even those numbers appear to be improving. Among patients admitted since November 5, the mortality rate was less than 24 percent.

The figures compare to a 74 percent death rate for 106 patients who were treated in the eastern Sierra Leone town of Kenema in May and June, when some health workers were on strike and the response to the outbreak was in crisis mode. The spread of the outbreak has slowed significantly, according to the CDC, which gave a worst-case scenario estimate of as many as 1.4 million cases by mid-January if the region did not receive more aid. Last month, the agency said that prediction would not happen.

"There's been real momentum and real progress," CDC Director Thomas Frieden said Monday after his second trip to Ebola-stricken countries. "The challenge is not to let up."

The article is based in part on wire service reports.

Title: Conservative Republicans Challenge Boehner's Government Funding Plan, Threaten to Derail Vote

Article:

A group of conservative Republicans in the House of Representatives is once again causing problems for the Republican leadership, as they have expressed dissatisfaction with a government funding plan outlined by Speaker John Boehner during a closed-door meeting on Tuesday.

Instead of a spending bill that keeps the government funded through September with a chance to review the Department of Homeland Security's funding in March, the lawmakers want to pass a much shorter resolution.

Rep. John Fleming (R-La.) said, "I think a lot of us, in discussion, we don't see the purpose of having a long CR. Why not do it the first day we're in session? I'm not sure it's going to pass the way they are proposing it. I think it's likely they are going to have to improve it if they want it to pass."

Conservative Republicans estimate the number of Republican "no" votes to be near 30 to 40, which could derail a vote on the government funding bill if Democrats oppose the measure.

Senate conservatives are also beginning to pressure House leaders over their plan to fund the government and symbolically disapprove of the president's immigration action. GOP Sens. Jeff Sessions of Alabama, David Vitter of Louisiana, and Mike Lee of Utah have criticized the House GOP leadership's plan.

Sen. Mike Lee (R-Utah) laid out a detailed roadmap to taking on the executive action in a statement to Breitbart News, arguing for a short-term continuing resolution that blocks funding for the executive action.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) gave a tepid endorsement of the House leadership's plan on Tuesday, while Senate GOP Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) has largely deferred to the House, emphasizing that there will be no shutdown.

Missing from this drama, for now, is Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), who was central to the movement to defund Obamacare in October 2013, which eventually led to a lengthy government shutdown. On Tuesday, Cruz declined to speak about the House's bill and referred a reporter to his press office, which did not respond to questions.

Across the Rotunda, House conservatives are beginning to converge around the idea of a shorter-term CR that strictly limits funds to the Department of Homeland Security, the agency tasked with implementing Obama's immigration executive actions.

Rep. Mark Meadows (R-N.C.) said, "For me, something that is shorter term allows us to hopefully deal with a Senate that is more negotiable. I'm probably leaning no [on the current House plan]."

The atmosphere could be better for Republicans in January, as the Senate will then be controlled by the GOP, increasing the likelihood that any long-term spending legislation passed in the House could be put to a vote in the Senate. Plans floated by conservatives include passing a CR that keeps the government open just until the first week of the next Congress in January.

Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio), a leading conservative in the House, said on Tuesday that "the cavalry is coming" and that he preferred to deal with the larger funding issues next year. Outspoken Rep. Tim Huelskamp (R-Kan.), who has built a reputation around opposing Republican leadership, also backed a proposal that would only temporarily extend government funding.

"For me, it's generally in appropriations the shorter the better," the Kansas Republican said.

Title: Election 2018: Senate and House Outcomes Hinge on Modest Turnout Shifts

Article:

As Election Day draws near, the anticipated outcomes for the Senate and House of Representatives remain largely unchanged from the past six months. In the Senate, the Republican party is more likely to gain seats, while in the House, the Democratic party is favored to win control, but not by a significant margin.

The general expectations are influenced by geography and historical trends. The Senate's Republican advantage is due to the need for Democrats to defend numerous seats in traditionally GOP-leaning states. Conversely, the Democrats are expected to perform well in the House due to the historical pattern of the party out of power gaining ground in midterm elections.

However, the wide range of possible outcomes is a testament to the close nature of many races. As of Wednesday, there are six highly competitive Senate races, with five (Arizona, Florida, Indiana, Missouri, and Nevada) being pure toss-ups, and Montana slightly favoring the Democrats with Jon Tester's re-election bid in a Republican-leaning state.

ScottRasmussen.com, conducting private research for the Auto Alliance and the National Retail Federation, has examined three different turnout models for these six races. The results indicate that a slight increase in Republican turnout could result in a GOP sweep of the competitive races, giving them a 56-44 majority in the Senate. Conversely, a slight increase in Democratic turnout could lead to a 50-50 Senate.

The House of Representatives faces a similar dynamic, with the Democrats needing to pick up 23 seats to win control. ScottRasmussen.com currently projects a Democratic gain of 12 seats, with 33 seats too close to call. The Democrats need to win 11 of these 33 races, but the outcome is not guaranteed.

The Generic Congressional Ballot polling shows the Democrats with a 7-point advantage. If they win the popular vote by this margin on Election Day, they would be favored to win most of the 33 competitive races. However, a slight shift in the popular vote could have a significant impact, with the Republicans potentially keeping their majority if they boost turnout and narrow the gap, or the Democrats enjoying a large night and gaining up to 45 seats if the popular vote shifts in their favor.

In conclusion, the final outcome of Election 2018 will be determined by modest changes in voter turnout. The elections will hinge on who decides to show up and vote, emphasizing the importance of every individual's participation in the democratic process.

Title: Twitter's Policy Allows Chinese Officials to Spread Coronavirus Conspiracy Theories Without Violation

Article:

Chinese state officials are not in violation of Twitter's terms of service when they use the platform to spread propaganda and conspiracy theories regarding the origins of the coronavirus pandemic, a Twitter representative has confirmed.

According to a report by The Daily Beast, a company representative stated that direct interactions with public figures, comments on political issues, or foreign policy discussions are generally not in violation of Twitter's rules. This policy seems to allow world officials to engage in disinformation without consequence.

The representative's anonymity was requested, and a Twitter spokeswoman confirmed the report to the ███ News Foundation but did not provide a reason for not going on the record.

The policy was applied to recent examples of Chinese officials using Twitter as a propaganda tool, as reported by The Daily Beast. One such example is a tweet by Chinese senior official Lijian Zhao on March 12, where he suggested that the United States was trying to covertly inject the virus into China.

Zhao's tweet read, "When did Patient Zero appear in the United States? How many people are infected? What is the name of the hospital? It may be that the US military brought the epidemic to Wuhan." Zhao also falsely stated that Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Director Robert Redfield was "arrested" before floating the conspiracy theory to his 317,000 followers. Redfield was not apprehended.

Furthermore, Zhao tweeted on Sunday, suggesting that some CDC patients were misdiagnosed as having the flu during the 2019 flu season. He implied that patient zero may have originated in the United States.

Health officials have stated that the virus began in China's Wuhan region and expanded geometrically from there, contradicting Zhao's suggestions.

Twitter has also allowed other instances of misinformation to persist on its platform. For example, Tesla CEO Elon Musk told his Twitter followers on March 20 that children are "essentially immune" to coronavirus, a claim that Twitter previously stated was impermissible. However, Twitter appeared to backtrack after Musk's comment, stating that the tweets did not violate its rules at the time.

The company stated, "We reviewed the Tweets, and they don't violate our rules at this time. Please continue to share anything you think we should take a closer look at—we'll continue to rely on trusted partners, such as health authorities, to flag content that is harmful."

Title: Delegate Suggests GOP Convention Freely Allows Delegates to Vote According to Personal Preference

Article:

In an interview with Morning Edition on Thursday, Curly Haugland, a Republican National Committeeman from North Dakota, suggested that the upcoming Republican National Convention in Cleveland could allow delegates to vote according to their personal preference, rather than being bound by primary results or candidate preferences.

Haugland, who has previously expressed this view, argued that party rules do not bind delegates to vote for a specific candidate. He contends that even delegates who are "pledged" to Donald Trump or other contenders due to state primary results are, in reality, free to vote as they wish.

Haugland's interpretation is based on the GOP's convention Rules 37 and 38. He interprets these rules to mean that delegates may "vote their conscience." While the rules do not explicitly state this, Rule 37 is a detailed explanation of the procedure for roll call votes, and Rule 38 does say that no delegate may be "bound" by the "unit rule," meaning that delegates from a state cannot all be forced to vote the same way.

Haugland's interpretation is not a unanimous view. It is more widely accepted that delegates currently pledged to Trump, Ted Cruz, John Kasich, or others must support them at least on the first ballot. However, if no candidate receives a majority, delegates would necessarily vote differently on later ballots to resolve the impasse.

Another of Haugland's points is indisputable: "When the convention convenes," he said, "the delegates adopt their own rules, which have not been adopted yet." There is a standard template for conventions, but delegates could tweak the template, changing the game in any way they want. The only real constraint is that their actions would be publicly known and therefore open to criticism.

The latitude afforded delegates explains why it is considered significant that Senator Ted Cruz has outmaneuvered Trump in several states, ensuring that as many delegates as possible are Cruz supporters.

Haugland's personal goal is to adopt a rule that assures delegates the chance to choose from a wide range of alternatives, including candidates such as Jeb Bush or Marco Rubio who have suspended their campaigns.

Title: CDC Outlines Ebola Policies: Voluntary Home Quarantine for High-Risk Individuals

Article:

In a move to address the ongoing Ebola outbreak in West Africa, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has outlined updated guidelines for monitoring individuals entering the United States from the affected regions. The new policies, announced Monday, emphasize voluntary home quarantine for those at the highest risk of Ebola transmission.

The CDC's best practices, detailed in a press call Monday afternoon, are designed for four categories of individuals who are not exhibiting symptoms. These guidelines cover both international travelers and those who may have had domestic contact with the virus.

Individuals at the highest risk, such as healthcare workers who experienced a needle stick while treating Ebola patients, will be asked to remain under voluntary home quarantine and receive daily, in-person checks by a health official for 21 days.

Healthcare workers returning from Africa will be included in the "some risk" category, which involves daily direct monitoring but allows for more freedom of movement, on a case-by-case basis.

CDC Director Tom Frieden did not directly address the policies implemented by states like New York and New Jersey, but expressed concern over certain policies that might increase stigma towards healthcare workers and give a false impression of Ebola's infectiousness.

Frieden stated, "If we turn them into pariahs instead of recognizing the heroic nature of the work they're doing, then they may be less likely to identify themselves as health workers—and thus go unmonitored—and less likely to go help [Africa] in the first place."

Virginia also announced enhanced monitoring plans for individuals entering the country from the affected West African regions on Monday. Some considered at high risk will face a quarantine at home, with daily check-ins by health officials.

Last week, the CDC announced that all individuals entering the United States from the West African countries would be required to provide detailed contact information, monitor their temperature twice daily, and report the results to local health officials daily. This measure began in six states on Monday and will be expanded nationwide.

The quarantined nurse, Kaci Hickox, who was detained in New Jersey despite testing negative for Ebola and having no symptoms, had retained a civil rights attorney and threatened to sue New Jersey over her detention. Hickox, who had spent a month treating patients in Sierra Leone with Doctors Without Borders, had emerged as a prominent figure in the opposition to mandatory 21-day quarantines announced Friday night in New York and New Jersey.

Title: Covington Catholic High School Students Allege Threats and Doxxing Following Viral Video Incident

Article:

In the aftermath of a viral video showing a confrontation between Covington Catholic High School student Nicholas Sandmann and Native American elder Nathan Phillips in Washington D.C., two students from the school have come forward with allegations of threats and doxxing.

Sam Schroder, a senior at Covington Catholic, and Grant Hillmann, another senior, released a video statement Monday evening detailing the alleged threats against them, the school, and their families. Schroder stated that the threats ranged from school burnings, bombings, and school shooting threats, to more personal attacks such as doxxing, where their identities and contact information were made public online.
