The students claimed that the threats have escalated to such an extent that police have been stationed at the school, and students are fearful of attending classes the following day. Schroder expressed his concern, stating, "It's really scary. I know a lot of people are scared to go to school tomorrow and won't be attending because of what could happen."

Both Schroder and Hillmann alleged that they, as well as other students and their parents, have been doxxed. Hillmann stated, "I, myself, wasn't even present but I am very vocal about defending my school and my peers, and I have been doxxed on three separate occasions."

The students also accused several media outlets of blatantly lying about the encounter and claimed that the coverage had a significant impact on their community. Hillmann stated, "Several outlets blatantly lied about the encounter and the coverage affected our community greatly."

Nick Sandmann, the student featured in the viral video, was wearing a "Make America Great Again" hat and was seen seemingly smirking at Phillips, a tribal leader and U.S. veteran, who was beating a drum in front of him during a D.C. protest. In a statement released Sunday, Sandmann claimed he was attempting to "diffuse" the situation by smiling and that Phillips had "singled [him] out for a confrontation."

Phillips, on the other hand, claimed he saw "hatred" in the "beastly young men" who surrounded Sandmann and cheered him on during the encounter. The incident has sparked a heated debate, with many calling for further investigation and others defending the actions of the students.

Title: AI Adjustments and Oversight in a Pandemic: A Closer Look at Machine Learning Models and Their Resilience

Article:

In the face of the ongoing global crisis, it has become evident that traditional worst-case scenarios in machine learning models may not fully prepare for the unprecedented events that have unfolded. This is according to Sharma, who suggests that more AI systems should be trained on historical events such as the Great Depression, the 1987 Black Monday stock market crash, and the 2007-2008 financial crisis. "A pandemic like this is a perfect trigger to build better machine-learning models," he says.

However, it is impossible to prepare for everything. As David Excell, founder of Featurespace, a behavior analytics company, points out, problems arise when a machine-learning system doesn't see what it expects to see. Despite this, Featurespace's AI has not been significantly impacted during the pandemic. People are still buying goods from Amazon and subscribing to Netflix, but they are not making large purchases or spending in new places, which can raise suspicions. "People's spending behavior is a contraction of their old habits," says Excell.

The firm's engineers have only had to adjust for a surge in purchases of garden equipment and power tools, says Excell. These are the kinds of mid-price anomalous purchases that fraud-detection algorithms might pick up on. "I think there is certainly more oversight," says Excell. "The world has changed, and the data has changed."

Another AI company, Phrasee, is also taking a hands-on approach. It uses natural-language processing and machine learning to generate email marketing copy or Facebook ads on behalf of its clients. To ensure the tone is appropriate, its AI generates numerous possible phrases, which are then run through a neural network that selects the best ones. However, because natural-language generation can go awry, Phrasee always has humans check what goes into and comes out of its AI.

When COVID-19 hit, Phrasee realized that more sensitivity was required and started filtering out additional language. The company has banned specific phrases, such as "going viral," and doesn't allow language that refers to discouraged activities, such as "party wear." It has even culled emojis that may be read as too happy or too alarming. And it has also dropped terms that may stoke anxiety, such as "OMG," "be prepared," "stock up," and "brace yourself." "People don't want marketing to make them feel anxious and fearful—you know, like, this deal is about to run out, pressure pressure pressure," says Parry Malm, the firm's CEO.

Amazon, as a microcosm for the retail industry as a whole, has made subtle behind-the-scenes adjustments to meet demand. As Amazon and the 2.5 million third-party sellers it supports struggle to meet demand, it is making tiny tweaks to its algorithms to help spread the load. Most Amazon sellers rely on Amazon to fulfill their orders. Sellers store their items in an Amazon warehouse, and Amazon takes care of all the logistics, delivering to people's homes and handling returns. It then promotes sellers whose orders it fulfills itself.

However, in the last few weeks, Amazon has flipped that around, says Cline. To ease demand on its own warehouses, its algorithms now appear more likely to promote sellers that handle their own deliveries. This kind of adjustment would be hard to do without manual intervention, says Cline. "The situation is so volatile," he says. "You're trying to optimize for toilet paper last week, and this week everyone wants to buy puzzles or gym equipment."

The tweaks Amazon makes to its algorithms then have knock-on effects on the algorithms that sellers use to decide what to spend on online advertising. Every time a web page with ads loads, a super-fast auction takes place where automated bidders decide between themselves who gets to fill each ad box. The amount these algorithms decide to spend for an ad depends on a myriad of variables, but ultimately, the decision is based on an estimate of how much you, the eyeballs on the page, are worth to them.

There are lots of ways to predict customer behavior, including not only data about your past purchases but also the pigeonhole that ad companies have placed you in on the basis of your online activity. But now, one of the best predictors of whether someone who clicks an ad will buy your product is how long you say it will take to deliver it, says Cline. So Nozzle is talking to customers about adjusting their algorithms to take this into account. For example, if you think you can't deliver faster than a competitor, it might not be worth trying to outbid them in an ad auction. On the other hand, if you know your competitor has run out of stock, then you can go in cheap, gambling that they won't bid.

All of this is possible only with a dedicated team keeping tabs on things, says Cline. He thinks the current situation is an eye-opener for a lot of people who assumed all automated systems could run themselves. "You need a data science team who can connect what's going on in the world to what's going on the algorithms," he says. "An algorithm would never pick some of this stuff up."

With everything connected, the impact of a pandemic has been felt far and wide, touching mechanisms that in more typical times remain hidden. If we are looking for a silver lining, then now is a time to take stock of those newly exposed systems and ask how they might be designed better, made more resilient. If machines are to be trusted, we need to watch over them.

Title: Migrant Caravan Nears U.S. Border, President Trump Threatens Border Closure

Article:

A small group of approximately 150 migrants, carrying white flags bearing the message "La paz y Dios" or "Peace and God are With Us," have moved within 500 feet of the U.S.-Mexico border, according to a report Thursday. The migrants, who are seeking asylum, are approaching the U.S. near Baja, California.

The migrants are using the white flags to demonstrate their peaceful intentions. They plan to present themselves as asylum seekers at the border. The San Diego Union-Tribune reported that Mexican federal police have set up a barrier near a pedestrian crossing and urged the migrants to apply for jobs in Tijuana. The police claim there are thousands of job opportunities in the city.

President Trump on Thursday warned that he may close the border with Mexico if his administration determines that Mexico has lost control of the situation. The Union-Tribune reported that Mexican federal police, dressed in riot gear, prevented the caravan from getting closer to the U.S.

Carlos Lopez, a Honduran leading the small group, told the paper that the conditions in Mexico are dire. He stated that there are sick children and women, and that the migrants are forced to remain outside in the elements. Those already in Tijuana have resorted to camping out in tents, sleeping on dirt fields, or under bleachers, or are staying in overcrowded shelters as they wait to determine their next steps.

"The whole world is watching what is happening here," Lopez said.

The larger caravan, which contains about 6,219 Central Americans, is currently in Mexico. The federal government estimates the number of migrants could grow to 10,000 in the coming weeks or months. President Trump has labeled the caravan a national security threat and has stated that it will not enter the U.S.

On Monday, a judge barred President Trump from enforcing a ban on asylum for those who cross the U.S. border illegally – a decision the administration said would cause " countless illegal aliens to pour into our country."

The migrants who have traveled for over a month can now see a bridge that separates them from the U.S.

Speaking to reporters while in Florida for the holiday, Trump threatened to close the U.S. border with Mexico for an undisclosed period of time if his administration determines that its southern ally has lost "control" on its side. Trump also said he has given the thousands of active-duty troops he sent to the border before the Nov. 6 midterm elections the "OK" to use lethal force against migrants "if they have to." He added that Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen, whom he has faulted for not being tough enough on immigration, is "in there trying."

Title: "The Redeeming Power of Christmas: The Extraordinary Life of John Newton, Author of 'Amazing Grace' "

Article:

In the heart of the bustling cities, the silence that has fallen upon malls and main streets during the holiday season serves as a stark reminder of the tranquility that the Christ child born in a manger 2,000 years ago brought to the world. This peace, this redemption, is vividly illustrated in the incredible life of John Newton, an English slaver who was born 300 years ago.

Born into a seafaring family in Liverpool, Newton's mother, a godly woman, instilled in him a sense of faith that would remain with him throughout his life, even as he strayed far from the path of righteousness. After his mother's death when he was just 7 years old, Newton's life took a dark turn. He was involved in the slave trade, a life that he himself described as "big with mischief."

His life at sea was marked by hardship, cruelty, and near-death experiences. He was flogged, left for dead on an African island, and endured years of captivity and abuse. Yet, it was during these darkest moments that Newton's faith, though battered and bruised, remained a beacon of hope.

It was not until he was rescued and returned to London that Newton encountered the preaching of George Whitefield and the influence of John Wesley. It was then that he was born again, finding solace and redemption in the Gospel.

Before his death at the age of 82, just days before Christmas in 1807, Newton penned the words that would become the most beloved hymn of Christendom: "Amazing Grace." A testament to the mercy and grace of God, Newton's hymn continues to resonate with people around the world, a reminder of the transformative power of faith and the redemption that can be found even in the darkest of times.

Wesley Pruden, editor in chief emeritus of The ███, reflects on the life of this remarkable man, "The wanton sinner, the arrogant blasphemer, the mocker of the faith of others was at last driven to his knees. His prayer was like the cry of ravens, which yet the Lord does not disdain to hear." Indeed, the story of John Newton serves as a powerful reminder of the transformative power of faith and the redemption that can be found in the Christmas message.

Title: Scaramucci Purges Old Tweets Aligning with Trump Administration's Agenda

Article:

In a move towards full transparency, Anthony Scaramucci, the newly appointed Communications Director for President Donald Trump, has begun deleting tweets from his account that do not align with the administration's agenda. Scaramucci, a New York financier who joined the Trump administration's press team amid a West Wing shake-up, announced his intention to delete old tweets on Saturday afternoon.

"Full transparency: I’m deleting old tweets. Past views evolved and shouldn’t be a distraction. I serve @POTUS agenda and that’s all that matters," Mr. Scaramucci tweeted.

As of yet, Mr. Scaramucci has not disclosed which specific tweets will be removed. However, a few tweets from 2012, including ones advocating for "common sense" gun laws and complimenting Hillary Clinton, Trump's former campaign rival, were no longer available within hours of his announcement.

On August 6, 2012, Mr. Scaramucci tweeted, "We (the USA) has 5% of the world's population but 50% of the world's guns. Enough is enough. It is just common sense it apply more controls." He also said, "I hope she runs, she is incredibly competent," of Clinton four months earlier, roughly three years before Trump entered the 2016 race.

Another tweet, dated March 11, 2016, stated, "It's possible to combat climate change without crippling the economy. The fact many people still believe [climate change] is a hoax is disheartening." This tweet, too, has since been deleted.

Scaramucci was named White House Communications Director early Friday, filling a role that has been vacant since Mike Dubke's departure in May. Sean Spicer resigned as spokesman Friday "to give the President and the new team a clean slate," he told CNN.

In the past, Scaramucci has spoken critically of Trump, but he acknowledged Friday that the president was aware of his earlier remarks. "One of the biggest mistakes I made, because I was an inexperienced person in the world of politics. I was supporting another candidate. I should have never said that about him," Mr. Scaramucci said of his previous comments.

"I love the president and I’m very, very loyal to the president. And I love the mission that the president has," Mr. Scaramucci said. The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment Saturday.

Title: Economist Stephen Moore Compares Protesters to Civil Rights Icon Rosa Parks, Sparks Controversy

Article:

Economist Stephen Moore, a member of President Donald Trump's council tasked with reopening the country, has drawn criticism for comparing right-wing protesters who oppose coronavirus safety measures to civil rights icon Rosa Parks.

In a YouTube video posted by a libertarian think tank this week, Moore discussed plans for a "drive-in" protest in Wisconsin against the state's stay-at-home order issued by Gov. Tony Evers (D). Evers extended the order this week until May 26.

"They're going to shut down the Capitol. Shh. Don't tell anybody," Moore said of those protesting the order. "This is a great time for civil disobedience. We need to be the Rosa Parks here and protest against these government injustices," he added later.

Moore made similar comments in an interview with The Washington Post published Friday. "I think there's a boiling point that has been reached and exceeded," he told the newspaper. "I call these people the modern-day Rosa Parks—they are protesting against injustice and a loss of liberties."

The remarks drew pushback from some on social media, with Democratic congressional candidate Scott Huffman from North Carolina tweeting, "Could you have imagined the outcome if Rosa brought a gun to the bus?" Conservative commentator Bill Kristol called the remark "at once strikingly stupid and deeply offensive."

During an interview on CBS News on Friday, Moore maintained that the Trump administration has waited too long to reopen the economy. "I think actually think we should have started this a week or two ago," Moore said. "I think we lean way too much in the direction of keeping the economy shut down to try to save every life, not realizing that we're causing huge hardship for citizens—again, people at the bottom and businesses—and we're going to suffer a big loss of living standards because of this."

Protesters against their states' stay-at-home orders took to the streets in several states this week, with plans for a "Freedom Rally" announced for April 24 in Wisconsin after the governor extended his state's stay-at-home order this week. In the YouTube video, Moore said he had been in talks with the protest organizers and noted that an unnamed donor had pledged to "pay the bail and legal fees" for anyone who gets arrested during the rally.

"We're going to see a lot more of [the protests]," Moore said. "So this is a great time, gentleman and ladies, for civil disobedience."

Many health experts and state leaders, such as New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo (D), have repeatedly stressed that more widespread testing is needed before the country can reopen safely. Moore's plan to support the protests comes after Trump on Thursday rolled out a three-phase strategy to reopen parts of the country. However, Trump took to Twitter on Friday, issuing a series of tweets calling to "LIBERATE" Minnesota, Michigan, and Virginia, all states that are currently under stay-at-home orders with Democratic governors.

Title: Cindy McCain Urges Nation to Honor Late Husband's Legacy, Join the Arena of Service

Article:

In a poignant tribute last week, Cindy McCain, wife of the late Senator John McCain, called upon the nation to honor her husband's memory by emulating his lifelong commitment to service and a greater cause.

Addressing the nation, McCain emphasized the essence of her husband's message: the need for unity, guided by the core values of liberty, equal justice, and respect for human dignity. She highlighted John McCain's unwavering courage, integrity, and his daily efforts to demand the best for our armed forces, support freedom fighters, and advocate for human rights.

Whether in uniform or on the Senate floor, John McCain was a relentless advocate for others, fighting for the rights of native American communities, demanding accountability for human rights abuses, and championing the cause of liberty against dictators worldwide.

Cindy McCain urged the nation to recognize the kind of leadership John McCain represented and the kind of country they aspire to be. She emphasized that each individual must take action, whether by leading, supporting, contributing, or donating, to fight for a greater cause.

In the wake of her husband's passing, Cindy McCain has found a new home and mission at the McCain Institute for International Leadership. Through this institution, she aims to carry forward the legacy John McCain built, fighting for the values that defined his life.

Cindy McCain invited the public to support the McCain Institute and join her in the arena, fighting for a greater cause in the spirit of her late husband. As a trustee of the McCain Institute, she expressed her gratitude for the outpouring of support and kind messages following John McCain's passing and encouraged the nation to honor his memory by joining her in the arena.

Title: Virginia Attorney General Decides Not to Defend State's Same-Sex Marriage Ban

Article:

Virginia Attorney General Mark Herring announced on Thursday that he will not defend Virginia's ban on same-sex marriage when it goes before a federal judge next week. The decision has sparked varying reactions from Virginians.

Herring, who has been in office for less than two weeks, had little choice but to act quickly on the issue as a lawsuit challenging the ban is set to be heard in Norfolk next week. In an interview with NPR's MORNING EDITION, Herring stated that he believes the anti-gay marriage law violates the 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. He also pointed to another Virginia law that once limited marriage, in that case multi-racial marriage, which the U.S. Supreme Court struck down.

"The court did not say that there was a right to interracial marriage. It said that everyone, all individuals have the right to marry. And all individuals means all individuals," said Herring.

Backers of the prohibition on gay marriage see it differently. Kirk Cox, the Republican majority leader of the Virginia House of Delegates, stated that the attorney general has a constitutional and statutory obligation to enforce and defend the duly adopted laws and constitution of Virginia. Cox added that the attorney general's decision demonstrates a great deal of disrespect for that obligation, as well as the legislative and democratic processes for which those laws are adopted.

Virginians had varying reactions to Herring's decision. Interviewed outside a diner in Crozet, near Charlottesville, Mary Linn was unhappy. "I'm absolutely negative on that. Don't want it, because I'm a Christian and the Lord says that's a no-no. That's the reason. And what I try to do is to live my life according to the Bible," said Linn.

Retiree Stan Gray stated that he is ambivalent on the issue of same-sex marriage. "I consider myself not involved in that particular fight. It doesn't bother me one way or the other. I think there are a lot of good reasons for them to be allowed to get married. And there's a lot of history that says we're better off without it. But it doesn't bother me. I can accept either decision," said Gray.

In 2006, the referendum that banned same-sex marriage was approved by 57 percent of the state's voters. However, in keeping with national trends, a recent Quinnipiac poll showed 50 percent of Virginians surveyed now support allowing gays and lesbians to marry.

Democratic State Senator Adam Ebbin, who is the first openly gay member of the Virginia General Assembly, stated that he's glad his state is, in his view, coming around on the issue. "We have a conflicting history of both being the birthplace of civil liberties and the Bill of Rights. And at the same time, being the state that resisted interracial marriage and integrating one of our colleges and desegregating our schools. So it's good to be proud of being a Virginian today," said Ebbin.

Herring's decision not to defend Virginia's ban on same-sex marriage in court comes after several federal judges have overturned similar bans, including in Utah and Oklahoma. Pennsylvania's attorney general also refused to defend that state's ban, a case now making its way through the courts. In all, more than a dozen states have lawsuits challenging laws forbidding same-sex marriage. And in the end, it's likely to be an issue that's finally decided by the U.S. Supreme Court.

Title: Cyber Attacks on Federal Agencies: A Growing Concern as Human Error and Espionage Threaten National Security

Article:

The number of cyber attacks on government systems has seen a significant increase, with a 35 percent jump in the past three years, according to a CNN review of cyber attacks against federal agencies. This alarming trend has been highlighted by experts who warn that espionage is happening at a rate never seen before.

In 2014, there were almost 61,000 cyber attacks and security breaches across the entire federal government, according to a recent Obama administration report. This number represents a 35 percent increase from 2010, where the number of cyber incidents involving government agencies was roughly 34,000, according to a report by the Government Accountability Office.

The threat is not limited to government secrets; personal information accessible through government computer systems is also at risk. Last July, hackers hit the Energy Department and took personally identifiable information from over 100,000 people, according to a post-mortem report by the department's inspector general. The data included names, dates and places of birth, social security and bank account numbers, and information about their education and disabilities. The hack cost the government almost $4 million in credit monitoring fees and lost productivity.

The uptick in security breaches is not due to a lack of spending, experts say. In fact, the Obama administration report showed that federal government agencies spent $10 billion on information security. However, human error and a patchwork of different systems are the biggest culprits, with billions of dollars in security unable to stop an employee from clicking a malicious link.

"There is no patch for a stupid user," said Denise Zheng, a deputy director at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, who once oversaw a government cyber warfare program.

Another troubling incident happened last January when hackers hit the Army Corps of Engineers and took sensitive information about the nation's 85,000 dams. That data included their location, condition, and potential for fatalities if the dams were to be breached, according to a report by Sen. Tom Coburn, the ranking Republican on the Senate Homeland Security Committee.

Experts warn that the threat is global, with adversaries paid to try to get inside systems 24/7. "We don't have a malware problem. We have an adversary problem," said Tony Cole, vice president of the cyber security firm FireEye.

As the number of cyber attacks continues to rise, experts call for a unified response to deter future attacks and hold those responsible accountable. "We need to have a response whether it's an industry or a government response so that folks understand there is a penalty here," Zheng said. "If they go unpunished, the message that sends is detrimental."

Title: Justice Department Drops Case Against John Edwards, Will Not Pursue Retrial

Article:

The Justice Department has decided to drop its case against former Democratic presidential candidate John Edwards, opting not to retry him on campaign finance charges. The decision comes shortly after a jury was unable to reach a verdict in the high-profile case.

Government lawyers have requested Judge Catherine Eagles to dismiss the case with prejudice, meaning they will not attempt to re-establish the case. Approximately two weeks ago, a federal jury in Greensboro, North Carolina found John Edwards not guilty on one campaign finance charge. The jury was unable to reach a decision on five other counts that covered payments Edwards received from friends to support his pregnant mistress.

Several jurors stated that they did not believe the government's central witness, Andrew Young, an aide who idolized Edwards and later grew disillusioned with him.

Assistant Attorney General Lanny A. Breuer of the Justice Department's Criminal Division issued a statement regarding the decision:

"We knew that this case – like all campaign finance cases – would be challenging. But it is our duty to bring hard cases when we believe that the facts and the law support charging a candidate for high office with a crime. Last month, the government put forward its best case against Mr. Edwards, and I am proud of the skilled and professional way in which our prosecutors from the Criminal Division's Public Integrity Section and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of North Carolina conducted this trial. The jurors could not reach a unanimous verdict on five of the six counts of the indictment, however, and we respect their judgment. In the interest of justice, we have decided not to retry Mr. Edwards on those counts."

Edwards' lawyers released a statement, which reads in part:

"While John has repeatedly admitted to his sins, he has also consistently asserted, as we demonstrated at the trial, that he did not violate any campaign law nor even imagined that any campaign laws could apply. We are confident that the outcome of any new trial would have been the same. We are very glad that, after living under this cloud for over three years, John and his family can have their lives back and enjoy the peace they deserve."

Title: A Reflection on the State of Political Civility: Lessons from the Past and the Pursuit of a More Civil Discourse

Article:

In the wake of the passing of George H.W. Bush, the nation has been swept up in a wave of nostalgia for a time when politics were kinder and gentler. Some hope that Bush's legacy will usher in a new era of civil discourse, a respite from the often contentious and divisive political climate that currently dominates the landscape.

Recently, a panel of scholars, moderated by a commentator from National Public Radio, discussed the decline in civility and mutual respect in public discourse. The panel, which included a representative from CNN, explored the reasons behind the high levels of negativity in political discourse and the impact it has on society.

Arthur Evans, from the National Institute for Civil Discourse, noted that negativity often makes it difficult for people with differing opinions to engage in meaningful dialogue, as it leaves little room for error. He explained that this, in turn, reinforces the idea that the only way to discuss issues is in an extreme manner.

The idea that politicians of the past may hold valuable lessons for us is a complex one. John Adams and Thomas Jefferson, two of the most eminent politicians of their time, engaged in a highly contentious presidential campaign in 1800. Their mudslinging campaign left buckets of blood on the floor, as they accused each other of being everything from hermaphroditical to cowardly.

Despite their bitter campaign, Adams and Jefferson were able to nurture a friendship that survived the election. This friendship, like that between Bush and Clinton, serves as a reminder that civility in politics is a worthy goal, but that bashing and negativity are often seen as necessary evils in the pursuit of victory.

Winning the election is, after all, what politics is all about. Successful politicians understand the rough wisdom of Leo Durocher's famous quote, "Nice guys finish last." The friendship between Adams and Jefferson, despite their contentious campaign, survived, and they were able to put their differences aside and work together in the years that followed.

Civility in politics is a noble pursuit, but it is a difficult one. The stakes are high, and negativity and bashing are often seen as necessary tools in the pursuit of victory. The hope is that, in the spirit of George H.W. Bush, we can find a way to engage in civil discourse while still maintaining the competitive spirit that drives politics.

Title: Hillary Clinton Apologizes for 'Deplorables' Comment, Stands Firm on Criticism of Trump

Article:

In a statement released on Saturday, Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton expressed regret for her characterization of half of Donald Trump's supporters as "deplorables" during a fundraiser in New York on Friday.

Clinton stated, "That's never a good idea. I regret saying 'half.' That was wrong." She went on to say, "I won't stop calling out bigotry and racist rhetoric in this campaign."

Clinton's initial remark sparked a quick response from the Trump campaign, with senior communications adviser Jason Miller stating, "This was Clinton, as a defender of Washington's rigged system, telling the American public that she could care less about them."

In her statement, Clinton also criticized Trump for hiring a major advocate of the so-called "alt-right" movement to run his campaign and for giving a national platform to hateful views and voices. She added, "It's deplorable that Trump has built his campaign largely on prejudice and paranoia."

The former secretary of state also addressed the other "basket" of Trump supporters, describing them as people who feel that the government has let them down and are desperate for change.

The Trump campaign's response to Clinton's apology was swift, with campaign manager Kellyanne Conway urging Clinton to make amends and sparring with a Clinton aide on Twitter. Conway tweeted, "Come to an event; talk to real people who are not donors."

Clinton's fundraiser on Friday night also featured a performance by singer Barbra Streisand, who performed a parody of her song "Send in the Clowns" as a critique of Trump.

Trump responded to Clinton's apology on Saturday afternoon, stating, "Isn't it disgraceful that Hillary Clinton makes the worst mistake of the political season and instead of owning up to this grotesque attack on American voters, she tries to turn it around with a pathetic rehash of the words and insults used in her failing campaign?"

Title: Washington's Budget Impasse: A Study in Juvenile Petulance and Contemptible Games

Article:

In the lead-up to the looming mandatory budget cuts set to take effect on March 1, the nation's capital is bracing for an impending crisis, reminiscent of an asteroid hurtling towards Earth. The Defense Department, first responders, and the National Park Service are among the entities warning that their respective sectors will face drastic cuts, potentially leading to catastrophic consequences.

However, the question arises: When did the preservation of nature become contingent on federal funding? The Grand Canyon, for instance, may cease to be a natural wonder if the National Park Service experiences a slight reduction in funding. Yet, it is essential to step back and question the indispensability of man to nature, rather than focusing on the potential perils of nature without federal funding.

The current budget standoff is a conflict of interest, as one would expect no public servant to admit that their work is less vital to the nation. The federal government, in its self-proclaimed importance, is holding the American people hostage with their own money, threatening to withhold essential services if their demands are not met.

Washington's behavior is akin to a tantrum, a study in juvenile petulance. The American people have learned to do with less in the past six years, enduring higher taxes, increased fuel costs, job losses, smaller paychecks, shrinking homes, and failed businesses. Yet, the federal government, under both Republican and Democratic administrations, has grown its budget by $1.7 trillion over the past decade.

Washington now boasts the third-largest concentration of high-income households in the United States, surpassing Silicon Valley in average income less than a year ago. The city's elites are known for their extravagant lifestyles, with frequent golf vacations, ski trips, and high-end dining experiences. During his tenure at Citigroup, the current Treasury Secretary, Jack Lew, received a nearly $1 million bonus before the company accepted a taxpayer-funded bailout.

In such a context, a true leader, a president, would call for government austerity measures, asking the government to tighten its belt by 2%, mirroring the sacrifices made by American citizens. Instead, President Barack Obama directs his lieutenants to issue threats against the very people who pay their salaries. If Congress does not expand the instruments of redistribution deemed necessary by the president, he warns of harsh, arbitrary cuts that would devastate education, energy, and medical research, slow the recovery, and cost hundreds of thousands of jobs.

This budget impasse, with its threats and contemptible games, is a stark reminder of the need for leadership and a return to serving the American people. The American people should demand a president who leads by example, who asks the government to tighten its belt and make these cuts as painless as possible, rather than engaging in a dangerous game of political brinkmanship.

Title: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry Declares ISIS's Actions Against Minorities as Genocide

Article:

In a significant development, U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry declared today that the Islamic State (ISIS) is responsible for committing genocide against Christians, Yazidis, and Shia Muslims. This announcement was made on the same day that a congressional deadline urging the Obama administration to make its own judgement was set to expire.

Earlier this week, the House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved a resolution 393-0, stating that the actions taken by ISIS against religious and ethnic minorities in Iraq and Syria constitute genocide.

Speaking from the State Department briefing room, Kerry stated, "Da'esh is genocidal by self-proclamation, by ideology, and by actions in what it says, what it believes, and what it does."

The U.S. military intervened in Iraq in August of 2014 to halt the ISIS massacre of the Yazidis, an ancient ethnic minority living in the Sinjar area. This intervention led to the formation of an anti-ISIS coalition and the ongoing military effort. ISIS, primarily composed of Sunni Muslims, has targeted Shia Muslims, a group it labels as disbelievers.

Kerry further elaborated, "One element of genocide is the intent to destroy an ethnic or religious group in whole or in part." He added, "Da'esh kills Christians because they are Christians, the Yazidis because they are Yazidis, [and] Shia because they are Shia."

The impact of this declaration remains uncertain. While there are legal definitions associated with the term, there are no legal obligations to enforce a response. The last time a U.S. administration declared genocide during an ongoing conflict was in 2004 when Colin Powell determined it applied to the actions of the Sudanese government in Darfur. However, this did not compel the U.S. to act.

Secretary Kerry did not indicate any policy shift in the ongoing U.S.-led effort to degrade and defeat ISIS.

Title: Senator John McCain Urges Donald Trump to Apologize for Prisoner of War Remarks, Condemns Rift in Republican Party

Article:

In an interview on CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday, Senator John McCain of Arizona called on Donald J. Trump to make amends for his derogatory comments about prisoners of war, particularly those who were incarcerated during the Vietnam War. McCain, who was the Republican presidential nominee in 2008, expressed deep concern over the tone of the Republican presidential race and emphasized the need for Trump to express his appreciation for veterans.

During the interview, McCain reiterated his support for Trump as the Republican nominee for president but expressed dismay at Trump's belittling remarks about prisoners of war. Last summer, Trump mocked McCain for having been captured and imprisoned during the Vietnam War, stating that he preferred "people who weren't captured."

McCain, who was a prisoner of war for over five years, told CNN that he was personally unaffected by Trump's ridicule but that he could not abide the affront to veterans in general. When asked if he would appear on the campaign trail with Trump, McCain said "a lot of things would have to happen" first.

"I think it's important for Donald Trump to express his appreciation for veterans—not John McCain, but veterans who were incarcerated as prisoners of war," McCain said. "When he said, 'I don't like people who were captured,' then there's a body of American heroes that I'd like to see him retract that statement—not about me, but about the others."

McCain's comments add to the already extraordinary pressure on Trump to mend his relationships across the Republican Party and win over a range of party leaders he has alienated in the 2016 campaign. One of McCain's closest friends in the Senate, Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, has already announced that he will not vote for Trump under any circumstances.

McCain's comments also highlight the rift that has opened in the Republican Party, with many party leaders and members of Congress distancing themselves from Trump. The senator noted the personalization of the 2016 race, where "people's integrity and character are questioned."

Noting the divide between party leadership and voters in Trump's constituency, McCain said, "There is some distance, if not a disconnect, between party leadership and members of Congress. And many of the voters who have selected Donald Trump to be the nominee of the party."

The senator's comments underscore the challenges facing the Republican Party as it attempts to unify ahead of the general election. The party's leaders will need to find a way to bridge the gap between themselves and the voters who have chosen Trump as their nominee, particularly older, white, blue-collar workers who see no job prospects.

Title: Declining Importance of Religious Beliefs in U.S. Presidential Candidates: A Shift in American Voters' Priorities

Article:

In a significant shift in American political landscape, the importance of a presidential candidate's religious beliefs is declining, according to a new study by the Pew Research Center. The study, released on Wednesday, reveals that two-thirds of Evangelicals are planning to vote for Donald Trump, while two-thirds of religiously unaffiliated individuals, often referred to as "nones," are supporting Hillary Clinton.

The study shows a 10 percentage point drop in the number of Americans who want a president with strong religious beliefs, down to 62 percent from 2008. This trend is evident among both Republicans and Democrats, with an 8-point drop for the former and a 13-point drop for the latter.

The reasons for this decline differ for each side. For Republicans, Evangelicals are willing to support less-religious candidates to maintain political influence, while the growing "nones" of the Democratic Party are emphasizing secular morality over traditional religion.

Greg Smith, co-author of the study, comments, "For two election cycles now, we've seen a steady decline in the number of Americans who care if the president has strong beliefs. Maybe the attitudes of some religious groups are changing, but more so, the religious composition of the entire country is changing."

Evangelicals, who often face the dilemma of choosing a purist candidate versus one with broader appeal, are making concessions to support Donald Trump, despite his lack of religiosity and past lifestyle. James Dobson, an evangelical leader, recently referred to Trump as a "baby Christian," and religious leader Ralph Reed stated, "We accept him for who he is now" because he has shown a commitment to Christian ways.

On the Democratic side, the rise of the "nones" appears to be having an effect. In 2012, 25 percent of Americans claimed no religious preference, compared to 7 percent in the late 1980s. This shift could be due to the intense fusing of theological doctrine and politics among religious conservatives, suggesting that inactive liberals who used to identify with a religion may have quit doing so.

Moreover, Democrats are increasingly viewing morality outside of religiousness. Bernie Sanders, who was among the strongest supporters of the "nones" in the primary, was drawn to his vision of a society that takes better care of all, from free college to healthcare to a higher minimum wage. Sanders was also seen as a plain speaker whom they could trust.

However, "nones" have been slow to warm to Clinton's campaign, with concerns about her email misuse and connections to Wall Street. This indicates a focus on the moral character of their candidate, a desire for Clinton to present herself as well-motivated morally.

In conclusion, this election cycle is witnessing a curious situation in which Democrats appear to be more concerned about the morality of their candidate than Republicans. This shift in American voters' priorities could have significant implications for future elections.

Title: Nine California Students Sue State Over Teacher Tenure and Seniority Laws

Article:

In a landmark case set to go to trial on Monday in Los Angeles Superior Court, nine California public school students are challenging the state's laws on teacher tenure, seniority, and other protections that they argue keep underperforming educators in the classroom. The lawsuit, which is part of a growing nationwide effort to hold teachers more accountable for their work, is expected to conclude in March.

The case, sponsored by an educational reform group, is the latest battle in a contentious debate over union-backed protections for teachers. The nonjury trial will examine the alleged dysfunction and arbitrariness of the current system, which plaintiffs claim is due to outdated laws that restrict school administrators' ability to dismiss ineffective teachers.

"The system is dysfunctional and arbitrary due to these outdated laws that handcuff school administrators," said Theodore J. Boutrous, the lead attorney on the case.

Across the nation, states have been weakening teaching job protections, including tenure, to provide administrators with more flexibility to fire underperforming teachers. The changes come as states replace automatic "satisfactory" teacher evaluations with those linked to teacher performance and base teacher layoffs on performance instead of seniority.

Teachers' unions argue that the changes lower morale, deny teachers due process, and unfairly target older teachers. They also claim that the evaluations are too dependent on standardized tests and that eliminating such protections erases a vital support system for a profession already losing talented individuals to higher-paying private sector positions.

The California Teachers Association and the California Federation of Teachers have intervened in the lawsuit, asking the court to dismiss the case filed against the state, including Governor Jerry Brown, Superintendent of Public Education Tom Torlakson, and the Department of Education.

"It is deceptive and dishonest to pretend that teacher due process rights are unfair to students," said California Federation of Teachers President Josh Pechthalt, the parent of a ninth-grade student in the Los Angeles Unified School District. "Students need a stable, experienced teaching workforce. They won't have one if this lawsuit succeeds in gutting basic teacher rights."

The lawsuit seeks to declare unconstitutional five statutes within the state education code, including the one on tenure, three others that outline the steps to dismiss a teacher, and the fifth that mandates the last-hired, first-fired rule, which the lawsuit's attorneys say disadvantages young, talented teachers.

The plaintiffs are students primarily from the Los Angeles and Bay areas, supported by a nonprofit organization called Students Matter that fights for education equality. Los Angeles Unified School District Superintendent John Deasy, who oversees the nation's second-largest school district, will be called to testify by the plaintiffs, Boutrous said.

Plaintiff attorneys claim that teachers too often obtain tenure by simply showing up for work—after about 18 months in California. After tenure, bad teachers are allegedly almost impossible or too expensive to fire, Boutrous said.

"The school system knowingly puts kids in classrooms with teachers who are grossly substandard," Boutrous said, adding that it was crucial to turn to the courts because "the political system can't fix this."

Many districts send substandard teachers to disadvantaged schools instead of dismissing them because those schools are seen as less desirable places to work by experienced teachers, who can have priority where they are assigned, Boutrous said.

The California teacher unions argue that they support improving teacher evaluations and streamlining the dismissal process. However, they contend that these changes should be the work of the Legislature, not the courts.

Laura Lacar, a high school teacher in the ABC School District, fears the law could expand beyond what happens in the classroom. "It would be very scary to me, if this lawsuit succeeds, to think that I might not have a job next year, not for anything I've done in the classroom, but because my principal didn't like me, or my clothing, or something I'd said," Lacar said.

Declaring the laws unconstitutional will allow the Legislature to craft legislation that works, the lawsuit's attorneys say. Karen Martinez, who lives in San Jose, said her daughter, Daniella, a plaintiff, reached the third grade unable to read before a teacher helped her. "I'm hoping with all my heart that we win this case, so California can change a system that is clearly failing so many children," Martinez said. "To me, it's common sense: appreciate and reward the teachers who are doing great, and hold accountable the teachers who are failing our kids."

Terry Moe, a senior fellow at Stanford University's Hoover Institution who has researched teacher unions and their impact on public education, said there's a long way to go, even in states that have adopted new laws. "Unions can make life difficult for administrators in coming years," Moe said. "The political pressure on the ground is strong. It's going to be really difficult to follow through on these new laws and put a dent in teacher tenure and really do away with the role of seniority."

Title: Trump's Praise for Confederate General Robert E. Lee and the Evolution of Presidential Admiration

Article:

In a recent speech, former President Donald Trump praised Confederate General Robert E. Lee, echoing a sentiment that has been a part of his rhetoric since before his presidency. Trump's admiration for Lee, a divisive figure in American history, has been a recurring theme, particularly in his efforts to preserve Confederate statues and stoke cultural divisions.

Trump's praise for Lee, however, is not a new phenomenon. Presidents, particularly in the 20th century, have often lauded Lee as a symbol of Southern honor, duty, and sacrifice, aiding sectional reconciliation. This trend can be traced back to President Woodrow Wilson, who, as a southerner, held a deep personal affection for Lee.

Wilson, who was 13 when Lee visited Augusta, Georgia, cherished the memory of standing by Lee's side as a young boy. After leaving the presidency, Wilson wrote a hagiographic portrait of Lee, portraying him as a "national hero" and a figure "unapproachable in the history of our country."

Trump's admiration for Lee, like Wilson's, is not without controversy. Critics argue that Trump's understanding of the Civil War is limited, with a tendency to downplay the role of slavery. However, the significance of Trump's continued praise for Lee lies in the evolution of presidential admiration for a figure whose cause, as General Ulysses S. Grant noted, was "one of the worst for which a people ever fought, and one for which there was the least excuse."

In the 21st century, Trump's praise for Lee has been used to fuel cultural divisions, most notably during the violent protests against the removal of a Lee statue in Charlottesville in 2017. Trump's equivocations at a press conference following the protests, where he declared there were "very fine people on both sides," have been widely criticized.

As the 2022 midterm elections approach, Trump's former Virginia campaign chair, Corey Stewart, has made defending Lee's statues a central theme of his Senate campaign. This has led to speculation about whether Trump might distance himself from praise for Lee, a move that would be unprecedented in modern American politics.

In conclusion, Trump's continued praise for Robert E. Lee underscores the enduring significance of the Confederate general in American history and politics. The evolution of presidential admiration for Lee, from Woodrow Wilson to Donald Trump, highlights the complex and often problematic relationship between the nation's leaders and the legacy of the Civil War.

Title: World Leaders Gather in Paris to Address Climate Change: Implications of 2-Degree and 4-Degree Temperature Increases

Article:

World leaders are convening in Paris this month in a final attempt to mitigate the most devastating effects of climate change. Climatologists now warn that even the best-case scenario, assuming immediate and drastic emissions reductions, will result in a planetary temperature increase of at least 2 degrees Celsius in the coming decades.

This seemingly small temperature rise has significant consequences. Rising temperatures will destroy plant and animal habitats and reduce yields of essential food crops. More people will be exposed to the devastation of floods and droughts.

However, if the nations involved in the Paris talks fail to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, temperatures could increase by almost 6 degrees Celsius this century, according to the Committee on Climate Change, an independent advisory body to the U.K. government on climate issues.

The effects of a warming planet are already being felt in Alaska, which is warming at twice the rate of the rest of the U.S. Rising temperatures have thawed permafrost in some areas, leaving coastlines vulnerable to storms and tidal activity. Shishmaref, a remote village located 30 miles outside the Arctic Circle, is losing as much as 9 feet of land per year—sections of coastline that simply erode into the sea.

Plant and animal habitats face a dire threat from a warming climate. An increase of 4 degrees Celsius in average planetary temperatures could result in severe habitat loss for almost two-thirds of plant species and one-third of mammal species.

Crop yields are also at risk. A 2-degree increase could result in a 60% reduction in maize and spring wheat yields, while a 4-degree increase could lead to a 40% reduction. Similarly, species losing at least half their habitat could include 60% of plant species and 40% of mammal species.

More people will be exposed to the threats caused by a warming planet, even if nations meeting in Paris curtail carbon emissions. Vulnerable populations living near water or in arid regions will face significant disruptions to their way of life as flooding and severe drought become more common.

By 2050, an estimated 2 million to 13 million people each year will be exposed to coastal flooding, roughly equivalent to the population of New Orleans and southern Louisiana. River flooding could affect about 130 million to 250 million people each year, encompassing the entire South and part of the Northeast in the U.S., as well as the entire East and Midwest. Water stress could impact 1.5 billion to 2 billion people each year, affecting almost five times the U.S. population, or six times the U.S. population if protections do not evolve.

Human activity since the industrial revolution has led to a significant increase in carbon dioxide emissions, a greenhouse gas contributing to rising global temperatures. If carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise at their current rates, Earth's temperatures could increase dramatically in future decades, leading to catastrophic and irreversible climate change. The 10 largest emitters produced about 26.4 gigatons of carbon dioxide in 2013.

Countries responsible for two-thirds of global emissions have made commitments to reduce their greenhouse gas production. China, the world's largest carbon producer, has pledged to peak its carbon emissions by 2030. The United States, the second-largest emitter, aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 26 to 28% relative to 2005 levels by 2025. The European Union aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% relative to 1990 levels by 2030.

The race is on to mitigate the worst effects of climate change. The choices made in the coming years will determine the fate of countless species and the livelihoods of millions of people worldwide.

Title: IRS Acknowledges Inappropriate Targeting of Conservative Groups During 2012 Election

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) admitted on Friday that it inappropriately flagged conservative groups for additional review during the 2012 election to determine if they were violating their tax-exempt status. The acknowledgment came from Lois Lerner, who heads the IRS division that oversees tax-exempt groups, at a conference sponsored by the American Bar Association.

Lerner confirmed that organizations were singled out because they included the words "tea party" or "patriot" in their applications for tax-exempt status. She stated that some groups were asked for their list of donors, a practice she described as "wrong, incorrect, insensitive, and inappropriate."

Jenny Beth Martin, national coordinator for Tea Party Patriots, called the IRS's actions "disturbing, illegal, and outrageous abuse of government power." Republican lawmakers, who had previously complained about the suspected harassment, seized on the acknowledgment. Senate GOP Leader Mitch McConnell called for a "government-wide review" to ensure "these thuggish practices" are not in use elsewhere. House Republican Leader Eric Cantor later stated that the House would investigate.

The IRS, in a hastily arranged conference call following the conference, attempted to offer a fuller explanation of what happened. The IRS stated that protocol was changed at the Cincinnati office in response to the rising number of applications for 501(c)(4) groups. This classification grants tax-exempt status to social welfare groups. The agents tried to "centralize work" in response to the applications, leading to problems the agency claims have since been fixed.

Lerner acknowledged that some of the letters sent were "far too broad" and that asking for donors is "generally not what we do." She stated that mistakes were made, and some people did not use good judgment, while claiming the reviews were not partisan.

During the election, numerous conservative groups complained that they were being harassed by the IRS. They accused the agency of frustrating their attempts to become tax-exempt by sending them lengthy, intrusive questionnaires. The forms, which the groups made available at the time, sought information about group members' political activities, including details of their postings on social networking websites and about family members.

In all, about 300 groups were singled out for additional review, Lerner said. Of those, about a quarter were singled out because they had "tea party" or "patriot" somewhere in their applications. Lerner stated that 150 of the cases have been closed, and no group had its tax-exempt status revoked, though some withdrew their applications.

As the news unfolded, reactions were swift and harsh. Many conservative groups condemned the IRS for the additional scrutiny, while IRS officials offered apologies and stated that they have since fixed the situation. The IRS's inspector general is currently investigating the matter.

Title: McCarthy Advocates Senate Approval for Any Future Nuclear Deals, Citing Iran Agreement as Precedent

Article:

In a recent interview with MSNBC, House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy suggested that any potential deal with North Korea regarding its nuclear program should be submitted to the Senate for approval as a treaty. McCarthy argued that this approach would ensure the deal's longevity and counter concerns about the uncertainty it may create in international negotiations.

The California Republican criticized the Obama administration's handling of the Iran nuclear deal, which was not treated as a treaty but rather an executive agreement. This, according to McCarthy, made it easier for President Trump to withdraw the U.S. from the deal earlier this year.

McCarthy emphasized the durability of treaties, stating, "The one thing I have found, if it's going to be long-standing, I think treaties are longer standing and supportive from administration to administration."

The House Majority Leader also disputed the notion that the U.S.'s withdrawal from the Iran agreement has complicated negotiations with North Korea. He argued that it would be illogical to negotiate with North Korea to dismantle its nuclear program while allowing Iran to develop its own weapons in the future.

McCarthy compared President Trump's approach to that of President Reagan in dealing with the Soviet Union. According to McCarthy, Trump is willing to engage in negotiations when they are productive, but is also prepared to walk away when they deviate from the desired outcome, a strategy he believes was effective in the case of the Iran nuclear deal.

Title: IRS Commissioner Defends Actions Amidst GOP Criticism in Congressional Hearing

Acting IRS Commissioner Steven Miller faced a grilling from Republican lawmakers on Friday during a congressional hearing, as they accused the agency of systemic abuse in targeting conservative groups seeking tax-exempt status.

In the first hearing investigating the IRS's controversial practice, Miller apologized for the "foolish mistakes" made by employees trying to streamline their workload selection process. However, he strongly refuted Republican claims that the agency is politicized and maintained that the practice of flagging key terms in applications for tax-exemptions is legal.

Miller also defended a civil servant under heavy GOP criticism for working in the agency's scandal-ridden tax-exempt division before helping implement the health care overhaul. He insisted that he did not mislead Congress, stating that he answered questions as they were asked, despite not disclosing the targeting program in response to repeated inquiries from Republican lawmakers.

The four-hour hearing left Republicans dissatisfied and eager for more information. House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Dave Camp (R-Mich.) expressed that Miller's answers were "not very complete," and stated that the investigation would continue.

Miller stepped down as IRS Commissioner on Wednesday at the request of Treasury Secretary Jack Lew. President Barack Obama announced on Thursday that Daniel Werfel, the current controller of the Office of Management and Budget, would succeed Miller as acting IRS commissioner next week.

Two things became clear during the hearing: the IRS did not inadvertently announce the targeting program last year, and Republicans are determined to broaden the scope of their investigation.

Miller indicated that agency officials had discussed how to address the controversial targeting program before Lois Lerner, the director of the agency's tax-exempt division, was scheduled to appear at an American Bar Association conference on May 10. Her comments revealing the agency's targeting of groups using terms like "tea party" or "patriot" sparked a week-long controversy.

Republicans are also expanding their investigation to include other IRS actions that have long been a source of frustration for conservatives, such as the disclosure of confidential donor information for the National Organization for Marriage and the leak of applications conservative groups submitted for tax-exempt status.

Miller maintained the agency's stance that no one at the IRS informed the White House of its activities.

Miller's testimony did little to quell the Republican outrage that has persisted throughout the week.

CORRECTION: An earlier version of this story incorrectly reported that Miller called Lois Lerner a "superb civil servant." Those comments referred to another IRS employee.

Title: Obama's Middle East Visit: Focus on Peace, Security, and Youth Engagement

Article:

As President Barack Obama embarks on a week-long tour of the Middle East, his first visit to Israel since assuming office, the White House has downplayed expectations, emphasizing the president's aim to foster cooperation among regional leaders towards peace and democracy.

The President's journey commences in Jerusalem on Wednesday, where he will endeavor to strengthen his relationship with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, following the latter's recent re-election and the formation of a new Israeli government. The coalition government, established on Friday, includes centrist Yesh Atid and pro-settler Jewish Home parties, marking the first exclusion of ultra-Orthodox Jewish parties in a decade.

White House Press Secretary Jay Carney stated on Saturday that President Obama looks forward to working closely with the prime minister and the new government to address the region's challenges and advance shared interests in peace and security. Key issues include ongoing peace negotiations between Israeli and Palestinian leaders and the effort to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons.

The White House's strategy appears to be one of lowered expectations, creating space for open and honest peace talks between both sides, potentially including discussions on the conditions necessary to return to the negotiating table. Josh Earnest, the White House deputy press secretary, confirmed on Friday that the administration remains willing to play a facilitating role.

However, Earnest noted that face-to-face talks may prove difficult if leaders continue with unilateral actions, such as Israeli settlement construction in East Jerusalem and the West Bank.

In addressing the Iran issue, Ben Rhodes, Obama's deputy national security adviser, stated that the president has been clear: he prefers a peaceful resolution but has established a "red line" – no nuclear weapons for Iran. Netanyahu has questioned Obama's commitment to containing Iran's nuclear ambitions, including military action, and has publicly expressed support for Republican challenger Mitt Romney during the 2012 presidential campaign.

The centerpiece of Obama's visit will be a speech in Jerusalem to an audience primarily of Israeli students, part of the president's effort to engage with the Israeli public, particularly young people. Cultural stops include the Holocaust memorial Yad Vashem, the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, and an Iron Dome battery, a component of the missile defense system for which the U.S. has provided funding.

In the West Bank, Obama will meet with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas and Prime Minister Salam Fayyad in Ramallah. The president and Fayyad will visit a Palestinian youth center, another attempt to reach the region's young people.

Obama will make a 24-hour stop in Jordan, a vital U.S. ally, where the president's focus will be on the ongoing violence in neighboring Syria. Over 450,000 Syrians have sought refuge in Jordan, straining refugee camps and aid organizations.

For much of Obama's first term, White House officials saw little reason for the president to visit the region without a realistic chance for a peace accord between Israelis and Palestinians. However, with the president's one attempt at a U.S.-brokered deal thwarted in his first term and the two sides now more divided, the White House has revised its approach.

Beyond Mideast peace, Netanyahu and Obama share similar regional objectives, including ending the violence in Syria and managing the political instability in Egypt, which has a long-standing peace treaty with Israel.

Obama's visit to Israel may quell criticism in the U.S. that his failure to travel there during his first term indicated a lack of support for the Jewish state compared to his predecessors. Republican lawmakers frequently leveled this criticism during the 2012 presidential campaign, despite Republican President George W. Bush not visiting Israel until his final year in office.

In his talks with Jordan's King Abdullah, Obama will also aim to bolster the country's efforts to liberalize its government and counter an Arab Spring-style movement similar to those that have toppled leaders elsewhere in the region.

The president's final stop will be at Petra, Jordan's ancient city.

Title: U.S. House Judiciary Committee Delays Vote on Impeachment Articles, Citing Transparency

Article:

WASHINGTON ( ███ ) - The U.S. House Judiciary Committee has delayed a late-night vote on impeachment articles against President Donald Trump, with the committee chairman, Jerry Nadler, announcing a Friday vote at 10 a.m. ET (1500 GMT). The unexpected move has caused a rescheduling headache for Republican leaders and sparked criticism from both parties.

The committee, which had been expected to approve two articles of impeachment late on Thursday, is now set to make Trump the third president in U.S. history to be impeached. The Democratic-controlled House is expected to vote next week on the impeachment articles, a move that could lead to Trump's trial in the Senate.

The delay in the vote has been attributed to a desire for transparency, with House Judiciary Democrat Mary Gay Scanlon stating, "The American people deserve to see the vote."

The extended hearing, which lasted over 14 hours, was marked by a series of amendments proposed by Republicans, led by Doug Collins, the top Republican on the panel. These amendments, which had no hope of passage, led to hours of debate and discussion on a range of topics, from natural gas drilling to the state of the economy.

The delay and the prolonged hearing have caused frustration among both parties. Republican leaders, who had planned to travel home on Friday, now face schedule changes, while Democrats, who had expected to wrap up the hearing early in the evening, are criticized for the extended meeting.

If the House impeaches Trump, who is charged with abuse of power and obstruction of Congress, he would then go on trial in the Senate. The Republican-led chamber is unlikely to vote to find the president guilty and remove him from office.

Title: Alabama Senate Race: Jones and Moore's Electoral Strategy and the Impact of Write-in Candidates

Article:

As the Alabama Senate race heats up, both candidates, Doug Jones and Roy Moore, are focusing on their respective voter bases to secure a victory. For Jones, energizing the African-American community is crucial, while Moore is relying on his longtime base of rural white voters.

If rural white voters decide to stay home due to the sexual misconduct allegations, it could significantly complicate the Republican's electoral math. These small-population counties, stretching across the state's northern tier and just above the Gulf Coast, are expected to report early. Moore's performance in these counties will be a significant indicator of his ability to withstand Jones' expected success in Alabama's cities, which typically report later.

If Moore manages to achieve the marks he reached in his Republican runoff victory in September, with over 60% in several rural counties, he is likely to claim victory. However, if write-in candidates perform well, it might not be necessary for a candidate to secure 50% of the vote to claim victory.

In Alabama, it is challenging for a Democrat to capture over 50% of the vote. However, Jones may not need a majority to win Tuesday. Senator Richard C. Shelby, a Republican and the state's longest-serving lawmaker, used a national television interview Sunday to remind Alabamians that he had written in the name of another Republican rather than supporting Moore. His example could encourage others in the party to do the same.

There are two notable write-in candidates. Lee Busby, a Republican and a retired Marine colonel from Tuscaloosa, has announced a write-in bid. Additionally, a significant number of votes are expected to go to Nick Saban, the University of Alabama football coach, who is widely considered one of the most important figures in the state.

The more Republicans or independents who write in the name of a third candidate, the lower the threshold Jones needs to reach. Depending on the number of write-ins, he could potentially win even if he only captures 48% of the vote. The Alabama Senate race is shaping up to be a closely watched contest, with the outcome likely to hinge on voter turnout and the impact of write-in candidates.

Title: Republican Presidential Race: Trump Accuses Establishment of Exploiting Country as GOP Rivals Plot Against Him

Article:

In a heated exchange with Sean Hannity during a special town hall event on Wednesday, Republican presidential front-runner Donald Trump accused GOP lawmakers opposed to his campaign of exploiting the country. The billionaire businessman's comments come as a growing movement among the party establishment, including some of his former rivals, seeks to slow down Trump's march to the Republican convention.

Trump's remarks were in response to a conference held by the conservative American Enterprise Institute at Sea Island off the coast of Georgia over the weekend, where one of the topics reportedly discussed was stopping Trump from securing the Republican nomination. The conference was attended by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, House Speaker Paul Ryan, and other key Republican congressmen.

"I know all these people," Trump told Hannity. "These are people that are taking advantage of our country. They don't want to have strong borders. They want stuff flowing across the borders. They don't want to have taxation when countries treat us unfairly because they benefit from that."

Trump also accused politicians of prioritizing the interests of their donors over the country's needs. "Politicians will do what's right for the people that gave them the money, not what's right for the country," Trump added later in the interview.

Former GOP presidential candidate Jeb Bush is also reportedly meeting with Trump's rivals on Thursday ahead of a GOP debate in Florida, fueling speculation that he may be preparing to endorse a candidate challenging Trump. Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, meanwhile, has denied reports that he is considering dropping out of the race before next week's Florida primary.

Rubio told Megyn Kelly of Fox News that he has never discussed dropping out with anyone on his team or anyone else. "I'm the only one who can beat Donald Trump in Florida," Rubio said. A poll released Wednesday showed Rubio trailing Trump by 23 percentage points among likely Republican voters in Florida.

Rubio also dismissed the possibility of forming a so-called "unity" Republican ticket with Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, Trump's closest challenger in the delegate race. "At some point we're all going to be on the same team," Rubio said. "We're all going to be on the same team, I hope."

Cruz, for his part, walked back his earlier opposition to a possible convention fight between himself and Trump if neither man reaches the required 1,237 delegates during the primaries. "Look, Reagan and President Gerald Ford battled it out at a contested convention [in 1976]," Cruz said. "That's what conventions are for." However, Cruz restated his opposition to a so-called brokered convention, calling it "a fever dream of the D.C. establishment" and warning of "an open revolt" among Republican voters if it came to pass.

Cruz also took aim at Trump and Rubio over immigration reform and the so-called "Gang of Eight" bill in 2013. "When Marco Rubio stood with Barack Obama and [Sen.] Chuck Schumer and [then-Senate Majority Leader] Harry Reid... I stood with millions of Americans," Cruz told Kelly. "Not only was Donald Trump nowhere to be found, he was funding the Gang of Eight. He gave $50,000 to five of its members."

Cruz also accused Rubio of lowering the tone of the campaign, saying, "I have no views whatsoever on any part of Donald Trump's anatomy." Rubio, for his part, told Kelly that he regretted a remark he made about Trump's hands during a campaign stop in Virginia.

Ohio Gov. John Kasich, who has staked his campaign's future on victory in next Tuesday's Ohio primary, told Fox News' Greta Van Susteren that he would "probably not" pick up enough delegates in other contests to overtake Trump, but noted that voters had only "picked about half the delegates [so far] this year... anything is possible." A poll released Wednesday showed Kasich leading Trump by five percentage points among likely Republican voters in the Buckeye State.

"We're going to win Ohio," Kasich told Van Susteren. "That's not even a question for me. It's about what we do after that and all the places we have to go. But we're not taking it for granted."

The Republican race remains tight, with Trump leading Cruz by 99 delegates following Tuesday's contests. Cruz has 359 delegates, while Trump has 458. Rubio is a distant third with 151 delegates, and Kasich has 54. The next primary is in Florida on Tuesday, March 15.

Title: Boston Marathon Bombing Suspect Dzhokhar Tsarnaev Pleads Not Guilty to 30 Charges

A federal court in Boston saw the first public appearance of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the main suspect in the Boston Marathon bombing, since his arrest on April 19. Tsarnaev, 19, pleaded not guilty to 30 charges stemming from the bombing, including the use of a weapon of mass destruction.

Tsarnaev, who appeared disheveled and fidgety, entered the courtroom wearing a partially unbuttoned orange jumpsuit and a black t-shirt. He looked over his right shoulder several times, displaying a crooked smile to two sisters in Muslim garb seated in the courtroom. The arraignment was his first public appearance since his arrest.

Judge Marianne Bowler presided over the hearing, with 30 victims of the bombing and their family members present. Tsarnaev's public defender, Judy Clarke, attempted to enter a single "not guilty" plea on Tsarnaev's behalf for all counts in the indictment. However, Bowler asked that Tsarnaev speak for himself and that all the charges be read aloud.

Flanked by his two attorneys, Tsarnaev repeated the words "not guilty" seven times as prosecutors read the charges against him. Each of the 30 counts could bring a life-in-prison sentence, with 17 being eligible for the death penalty if the government decides to seek capital punishment.

Tsarnaev's brother, Tamerlan Tsarnaev, was killed in a shootout with police following a massive manhunt three days after the bombings. Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was captured the next day, wounded and bloodied from the shootout, after a Watertown homeowner noticed blood on his dry-docked boat. Police found the suspect hiding inside.

Authorities say the brothers were inspired by al-Qaeda publications and that Dzhokhar Tsarnaev left a confession in the boat justifying the bombings as payback for U.S. military action in Muslim countries. He wrote that the U.S. government was "killing our innocent civilians."

"I don't like killing innocent people," he said, but also wrote, "I can't stand to see such evil go unpunished... We Muslims are one body, you hurt one you hurt us all."

Tsarnaev's arrest stunned those who knew him as a likable high school athlete in Cambridge, Mass., where he lived with his older brother after his parents left for Russia. The indictment also said that, sometime before the bombings, Tsarnaev downloaded Internet material from Islamic extremists that advocated violence against the perceived enemies of Islam.

Three people—Martin Richard, 8, Krystle Marie Campbell, 29, and Lingzi Lu, 23—were killed by the bombs, which were improvised from pressure cookers. Authorities say the Tsarnaevs also killed Massachusetts Institute of Technology officer Sean Collier days later while they were on the run.

Title: House Democrats Prepare for Potential Showdown with Trump Administration as New Majority Takes Office

Article:

As the new Democratic majority takes office, House Democrats are gearing up for a potential confrontation with the Trump administration, with a list of at least 85 potential investigation and subpoena targets compiled by Representative Zach Basu. The incoming House Intelligence chairman, Adam Schiff, has indicated that the president is expected to resist the committees' requests, leading to potential legal battles that could reach the Supreme Court.
