The power struggle between the presidency, Congress, and the Supreme Court will be tested in the coming months, as top Democrats plan to explore possible grounds for impeachment, with a public report by Robert Mueller serving as a catalyst. Tom Steyer, a liberal activist who spent over $100 million during the campaign to build support for impeachment, has stated that establishment leaders who are delaying impeachment discussions are the "outliers."

Two of the most powerful incoming chairs, Adam Schiff and Nita Lowey, have outlined their plans for investigations that extend beyond Russian interference in the 2016 elections. Schiff, the top Democrat on the Intelligence Committee, aims to release transcripts of interviews conducted during the committee's own Russia probe, which contain possible contradictions with other testimony and facts, potentially placing witnesses in legal jeopardy.

Schiff stated, "I want to make sure that Bob Mueller has the advantage of the evidence that we've been able to gather. But equally important: that Bob Mueller is in a position to determine whether people knowingly committed perjury before our committee." Real questions about contradictions between the testimony of Roger Stone, a close ally of the Trump campaign, and emails that have surfaced since then, have been raised by Schiff.

Schiff also expressed a desire to investigate potential leverage the Russians may have over the president. "We're going to want to look at what leverage the Russians may have over the president of the United States," he said.

Incoming House Appropriations Chair Nita Lowey of New York has also signaled her readiness for investigations, including probes of James Comey's firing, Attorney General Jeff Sessions' ouster, the Muslim travel ban, family separation policy at the border, discussions of classified information at Mar-a-Lago, administration dealings with North Korea and Saudi Arabia, and more.

Trump has already signaled confrontation, stating at his post-election news conference that if Democrats investigate him, the result will be "a warlike posture." When asked if he would investigate the Democrats, Trump replied, "Oh, yeah. Better than them."

For 225+ years, federal courts have upheld the Constitution's mandate of Congress as an equal branch of government, providing checks and balances on the executive. As House Democrats assume power, they have a high hand in enforcing these checks and balances.

Title: GOP Candidates Tap into Narrative of Victimhood Among Social Conservatives

Article:

In the race for the Republican presidential nomination, several candidates are tapping into a narrative of victimhood and oppression that has become prevalent among social conservatives. This narrative portrays the forces of secularism as a threat to religious freedom and Christianity, with candidates warning of a potential criminalization of Christianity in the United States.

In a speech at Jerry Falwell's Liberty University, Jeb Bush stated, "There are consequences when you do not genuflect to the latest secular dogmas." Bobby Jindal has claimed that the left wants to "essentially outlaw firmly held religious beliefs that they do not agree with." Marco Rubio has warned that opposing same-sex marriage could lead to the argument that the teachings of mainstream Christianity are hate speech. Mike Huckabee has gone so far as to say, "We are moving rapidly toward the criminalization of Christianity."

While it may seem extreme to suggest that the United States, a majority-Christian country with a strong tradition of religious freedom, is on the verge of rounding up Christians and imprisoning them for their beliefs, many on the religious right view this as a real possibility. This perception is fueled by the rapid change in public opinion and laws on gay rights, as well as the secularization of American society over the past several decades.

According to data from the Pew Research Center, in 2014, Christians made up 70.6 percent of the American population, down 8 points from just seven years before. Meanwhile, the population of the "unaffiliated" - atheists, agnostics, and people who do not identify with any religion in particular - has grown to 23 percent of the public. The trend is particularly pronounced among millennials, with only 56 percent identifying as Christian and 35 percent being unaffiliated.

The narrative of victimhood and oppression provides social conservatives with a sense of nobility and heroism, as they see themselves as courageous revolutionaries fighting for their principles and God's desires. This narrative may become louder as social progress continues, particularly if the Supreme Court rules in favor of gay marriage in the coming weeks. While liberals may dismiss this rhetoric, it is a sincere belief held by many conservative Christians, and its impact on the political landscape remains to be seen.

Title: Lugar Center Releases Bipartisan Index, Highlights Rising Political Polarization in Congress

Article:

The Lugar Center, a bipartisan think tank founded by former Indiana Senator Richard Lugar and Georgetown University's McCourt School of Public Policy, has released its inaugural Bipartisan Index, revealing a significant increase in political polarization in the last two sessions of Congress.

The index ranks members of Congress based on their collaboration across party lines, using data from bill sponsorships and co-sponsorships during the last two Congresses. The rankings are designed to provide an objective measure of bipartisan cooperation in policy-making.

According to a press release from the Lugar Center, as reported by Real Clear Politics, Lugar stated, "The Bipartisan Index offers the public an objective way to measure how frequently their members of Congress are cooperating with the other party on matters of policy." He further added, "We hope this ranking will incentivize members of Congress to be more bipartisan when writing legislation and making co-sponsorship decisions."

The Lugar Center, which focuses on issues such as nonproliferation of weapons of mass destruction, global food security, foreign assistance effectiveness, global development, energy security, and enhancing bipartisan governance, plans to release lifetime rankings of each member of Congress dating back to 1993 later this year.

However, the 112th and 113th Congresses were the most partisan since 1993, according to the Lugar Center. In an interview with USA Today, Lugar expressed concern, stating, "This is not a situation to be celebrated, it's one to be turned around."

The Lugar Center's analysis compared lawmakers in the last Congress to a historical average to determine whether they ranked above or below average in bipartisanship. Only a little over one-third of those serving from 2013-2014 were ranked as bipartisan, according to USA Today. Top scorers in the Senate included Republican Susan Collins of Maine and Democrat Joe Manchin of West Virginia, while those ranked as least bipartisan included Republicans Ted Cruz of Texas and Tim Scott of South Carolina.

In the House, GOP Reps. Christopher Gibson and Peter King of New York ranked most bipartisan, while Reps. Tim Huelskamp, R-Kan., and Donna Edwards, D-Md., were least bipartisan.

The scores of presidential candidates in the Senate were all in the bottom half of the index, according to Real Clear Politics, including Florida Republican Sen. Marco Rubio, Kentucky Republican Sen. Rand Paul, Cruz, and independent Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders.

Lugar told USA Today, "Right now, most citizens are unhappy with the lack of progress in Congress, the lack of legislation moving forward or — worse still — such tie-ups that the government may shut down or be threatened with being shut down from time to time."

The trend of increasing political polarization has been noted before. CQ Roll Call has found that partisanship and polarization are driving legislative behavior more than in any other period since at least the start of the Eisenhower administration, according to USA Today. The Washington Post, reporting last month, showed that starting in the 1990s, "the parties began pulling apart from each other, like a single cell dividing into two," and that "in the 2000s, there are hardly any links between the parties at all."

Title: Alabama Senate Race: Roy Moore's Loyal Base Remains Steadfast Amidst Controversy

Article:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala. – Despite the recent allegations of sexual misconduct, Roy Moore, the Republican nominee for Alabama's Senate seat, continues to maintain a loyal base of supporters. These supporters, who have long backed Moore in statewide races for chief justice, governor, and senator for two decades, are standing by him.

Johnny Williams, a 77-year-old retired bus charter company owner, expressed his unwavering support for Moore. "I've seen him fighting at those fires, and I just believe in him," Williams said in an interview.

The allegations against Moore have led to a loss of support from some conservatives in recent weeks. However, Moore's famously loyal supporters, like 68-year-old Ann Eubanks of Birmingham, are not abandoning him. Eubanks, who leads a tea party group, stated, "I am a policy voter. I refuse to send a far-left liberal Democrat to Congress. There's too much at stake in this country at this point with the balance of the Senate at critical mass."

Eubanks cited future Supreme Court nominations, repealing Obamacare, building the wall, and immigration proposals as issues that President Trump will need every vote he can muster in the Senate. "It's way bigger than Roy Moore," Eubanks said. "It is the direction of our country."

However, Moore is facing challenges in winning over the support of other Alabama voters who typically vote Republican. In a Waffle House in Birmingham, 66-year-old Richard Barnett, the general manager of a metals and welding company, expressed his disapproval of Moore. "The last Democrat I voted for is Jimmy Carter," Barnett said, stating he would likely write-in Sen. Luther Strange, who lost to Moore in the primary, instead.

Barnett expressed no faith in Moore's ability to represent the majority of people and noted the lack of public support for Moore in his community. "You see no Roy Moore signs. You see some for Doug Jones. It's very, very unusual," Barnett said.

At another table in the diner, a mother from Alabaster, who identified herself as Sandra, was having breakfast with her husband. She expressed her support for President Trump but was undecided about her vote on Tuesday. "Deep down, I wish Luther Strange had been the candidate," she said.

Winning over these undecided voters could be the key to Moore's victory. Aware of this, Moore's campaign was jubilant after President Trump held a rally Friday night just 25 miles away from the Alabama state line in Pensacola, Florida, to encourage people to vote for Moore.

However, not everyone is enthused about the election. At the Waffle House, one waitress, named Nona, expressed her disinterest in the election. As she cleared plates of hashbrowns and eggs, Nona said she couldn't bring herself to vote for any of the candidates on Tuesday. She stated the behavior Moore has been accused of is "not Christian."

Title: Commemorating Martin Luther King Jr.'s Dream: A Call to Action on the 50th Anniversary of His Speech

Article:

On Saturday, tens of thousands of people gathered at the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial and the National Mall in Washington D.C., marking the 50th anniversary of King's iconic "I Have a Dream" speech. The event was a poignant tribute to a generation of activists who endured hardships to fight for African American equality, but also a call to action, emphasizing that the struggle for justice is far from over.

Martin Luther King III, the eldest son of the civil rights leader, underscored the importance of continued progress, stating, "This is not the time for nostalgic commemoration. Nor is this the time for self-congratulatory celebration. The task is not done. The journey is not complete. We can and we must do more."

Eric Holder, the nation's first black attorney general, highlighted the significant impact of the marchers, stating that without them, he would not have held his position, nor would President Barack Obama have been in office. Holder emphasized that the dream of Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. still remains unfulfilled for gays, Latinos, women, and the disabled.

Rep. John Lewis, the only surviving speaker from the 1963 March on Washington, spoke passionately against a recent Supreme Court decision that weakened the Voting Rights Act. Lewis, who was a leader of the 1965 march that ended in violence, urged the crowd to stand up for voting rights, stating, "I gave a little blood on that bridge in Selma, Ala. for the right to vote. I am not going to stand by and let the Supreme Court take the right to vote away from us."

Organizers anticipated approximately 100,000 participants in the event, a precursor to the actual anniversary of the Aug. 28, 1963, march that drew some 250,000 to the National Mall. Speakers frequently addressed issues such as high unemployment among blacks, the acquittal of George Zimmerman in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin, and the importance of addressing climate change.

The event took place in a post-9/11 Washington that was significantly different from the one civil rights leaders visited in 1963. Security measures, such as metal barriers and police presence, were in place to ensure the safety of the attendees. President Barack Obama, former Presidents Bill Clinton and Jimmy Carter, and churches and groups will join him on the anniversary day to speak from the steps of the Lincoln Memorial.

Joseph Lowery, who co-founded the Southern Christian Leadership Conference with King, urged the crowd to continue working towards King's ideals, stating, "We've come to Washington to commemorate, and we're going home to agitate." The event served as a powerful reminder that the struggle for equality and justice is a continuous journey, and that the dream of Martin Luther King Jr. remains a guiding light for future generations.

Title: Senate Judiciary Committee Advances Gun Trafficking Bill, Debates Assault Weapons Ban and Background Checks

In a significant move towards gun control legislation, the Senate Judiciary Committee has advanced a bill making gun trafficking a federal crime, marking the first key vote on gun laws since the tragic shootings at a Connecticut elementary school in December.

The committee is currently debating four pieces of legislation, including bills banning assault weapons and high capacity magazines, requiring background checks for nearly all gun purchases, and providing more funding for schools to buy video cameras and other safety equipment.

The trafficking bill, known as the "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act," was approved by a 11-7 vote, with Sen. Charles Grassley of Iowa being the only Republican to support the measure.

The committee is expected to vote in favor of all four bills, which would then be considered by the full Senate. However, the bills' prospects after that are uncertain, with the Senate and House being controlled by different parties.

The Democratic-controlled committee is considering the "assault weapons ban of 2013," sponsored by Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.), the "stop illegal trafficking in firearms act," put forward by Committee Chairman Pat Leahy (D-Vt.), Sen. Charles Schumer's (D-N.Y.) "Protecting Responsible Gun Sellers Act of 2013," which would expand background checks for gun buyers, and the "School Safety Enhancements Act of 2013" from Sen. Barbara Boxer (D-Calif.).

Given the political dynamics, gun-control supporters are focusing on one element of President Obama's package they see as low-hanging fruit: an expansion of the criminal background check system for gun purchases. The bills would also face uphill battles in the Republican-controlled House.

We will update with news about the committee votes as they happen.

Title: New Polls Suggest Close Race as Obama and Romney Prepare for First Presidential Debate

Article:

Washington, D.C. (CNN) - As the first presidential debate between President Barack Obama and Republican nominee Mitt Romney approaches, a new poll indicates that the race remains tight, with most Americans viewing the GOP challenger as the underdog in the upcoming showdown.

According to a poll conducted by ABC News and The Washington Post, 55% of likely voters believe President Obama will win the debate, while 31% believe Romney will emerge victorious. This finding aligns with a CNN/ORC International poll conducted after the Democratic convention earlier this month, where 59% of likely voters said Obama would do a better job in the October debates, compared to 34% who favored Romney.

The new survey's findings on the debate question are consistent with the current state of the election, as a CNN Poll of Polls, which averages all three surveys, puts Obama at 49% and Romney at 46% among likely voters. A new poll by Politico and George Washington University also released Monday shows 49% support for Obama and 47% for Romney among likely voters nationwide.

The two new surveys follow a Fox News poll released last week, which indicated a five-point advantage for the president. The ABC News/Washington Post poll was conducted from September 26-29, with 1,001 adults nationwide, including 929 registered voters and 813 likely voters, questioned by telephone. The survey's sampling error for likely voters is plus or minus 4 percentage points. The Politico/George Washington University Battleground poll was conducted from September 24-27, with 1,000 adults nationwide questioned by telephone. The survey's overall sampling error is plus or minus 3.1 percentage points.

As the candidates prepare for Wednesday's debate in Denver, Colorado, Vice President Joe Biden and Rep. Paul Ryan of Wisconsin, Romney's running mate, will face off once in the vice presidential debate.

Meanwhile, both candidates are campaigning ahead of the debate. Ann Romney is set to rally in Colorado, while President Obama is preparing for the debate across town. In a recent development, Romney criticized Obama's foreign policy in his weekly podcast.

The first of three debates between Obama and Romney will take place on Wednesday, with the remaining debates scheduled for October 16 in Hempstead, New York, and October 22 in Boca Raton, Florida. The vice presidential debate is scheduled for October 11 in Danville, Kentucky. The election will take place on November 6.

Title: Centrist Strategy Propels Gay Rights Movement to Mainstream Success

Article:

John Avlon, a CNN political analyst, asserts that the success of the gay rights movement, particularly the push for same-sex marriage, is a historic achievement. In an interview with CNN, Avlon highlights the strategic shift in the movement, which has skillfully positioned itself as a bipartisan and centrist issue.

Avlon argues that the progress on gay rights serves as a model for reaching consensus on other contentious issues. He points out that while the Supreme Court has yet to deliver its decision on same-sex marriage, the sea change in public opinion over the past decade is undeniable.

In recent weeks, prominent figures like Hillary Clinton, Jon Huntsman, and Rob Portman have publicly declared their support for marriage equality. While more Democrats than Republicans support same-sex marriage, the divide is increasingly generational rather than partisan. A majority of Republicans under the age of 50 now support marriage equality, including over 60% of evangelicals under 30.

Avlon credits activists like Evan Wolfson and Andrew Sullivan, as well as former San Francisco Mayor Gavin Newsom, for their early advocacy. The movement to encourage gays and lesbians to come out has also played a significant role in breaking down barriers and fostering greater compassion and recognition of civil rights.

However, the mainstreaming of marriage equality also reflects a strategic shift. Instead of relying on street theater tactics that often alienate more people than they attract, the movement has focused on building bridges beyond the base. This means outreach to Republicans and making counter-intuitively conservative arguments for same-sex marriage.

Ted Olson, the former Bush administration solicitor general, is a prime example of this strategic shift. Olson teamed up with David Boies, his opponent in the Bush v Gore Supreme Court case, to argue that California's Proposition 8 banning same-sex marriage was unconstitutional. Their partnership represents an understanding of the vital center as a dynamic way of solving problems and creating new coalitions.

The ads run in favor of marriage equality, such as those by the Respect for Marriage coalition, emphasize the essentially conservative institution of marriage, leading to societal stability and reduced dependence on the government. The 131 Republicans who signed on to the amicus brief in support of the freedom to marry, including prominent members of the Bush administration and the Romney campaign, also reflect this shift.

Avlon concludes that the shift in public opinion overturns centuries of established thought about marriage influenced by culture and religion. The rapid change is a reflection of the durability and flexibility of our democracy. He suggests that the centrist model used by the gay rights movement can be replicated as we try to call a ceasefire in the culture wars and actually start to solve problems through the process of addition rather than division.

Title: Trump Legal Team Prepares Answers for Mueller's Special Counsel Inquiry on 2016 Election Investigation

Article:

NEW YORK - President Donald Trump's legal team is reportedly preparing responses to questions from the U.S. special counsel, Robert Mueller, who is investigating Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. presidential election. This development, first reported by CNN, indicates progress in the ongoing talks between Mueller's team and Trump's legal team regarding the president's potential answers in the investigation.

According to a source familiar with the matter, the question of a potential interview has not been definitively settled. However, the source told the news outlet that Mueller is willing to accept written answers to questions without a commitment from Trump's lawyers over what comes next.

Trump attorney Rudy Giuliani had stated last month that Mueller wanted the president to commit to a follow-up interview to any written questions, a position that Trump's legal team was resisting. In an interview on Tuesday, Giuliani told the same news outlet, "We are not prepared to agree to more questions until the first group of questions are asked, answered, and somebody can explain to us why that isn't enough."

Giuliani reiterated that Trump would be willing to answer questions on whether his campaign had colluded with Moscow to influence the 2016 election, but not whether he had acted to obstruct the Russia probe. In an NBC News interview last year, Trump tied his decision to fire FBI Director James Comey to the investigation into Russian election meddling. At the time of his firing, Comey was leading the probe.

U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that Russia interfered in the election to try to tip it toward Trump and away from his Democratic challenger, Hillary Clinton. Moscow has denied any interference, while Trump has denied any collusion with Russia and any obstruction of justice.

Title: Biden and Obama Continue Push for Assault Weapons Ban Despite Senate Setback

Article:

In the face of a seemingly stalled assault weapons ban in the Senate, Vice President Joe Biden and President Obama are persisting in their efforts to have the legislation passed. Despite Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid's statement that he does not have the 40 votes necessary for the ban to pass as a standalone bill, Biden remains optimistic.

In an interview, Biden expressed his determination to see the ban pass, citing the success of the first assault weapons ban in 1994, which was attached to the Biden Crime bill. He emphasized that the ban had initially been declared dead several times before its eventual passage.

Biden, who was instrumental in the passage of the 1994 ban, along with Senator Dianne Feinstein and others, believes that the process may not unfold in a single step. He pointed to the history of the ban's inclusion in the Biden Crime Bill, which initially had 100,000 provisions removed, only to be reinstated and eventually separated as the Brady Bill for background checks.

Biden's confidence stems from his past experience with the issue, and he expressed his belief that the will of the people will eventually prevail. He urged continued vigilance, suggesting that the Department of Justice, ATF, and other regulatory agencies will play a key role in the ongoing fight for gun safety regulations.

Vice President Biden was in New York today, attending an event with NYC Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who also called for more gun control measures, despite Senator Feinstein's inability to garner Democratic support for her assault weapons legislation. The fight for gun control regulations continues.

Title: Political Campaigns Adjust Schedules, Tone in Response to Colorado Shooting

Article:

In the aftermath of the tragic mass shooting in Aurora, Colorado, which left at least 12 people dead and numerous others injured during a midnight showing of The Dark Knight Rises, both major U.S. presidential campaigns have revised their schedules and adopted a more somber tone.

President Barack Obama, who had planned to hold Florida campaign rallies in Fort Myers and Orlando, canceled the Orlando event and transformed the Fort Myers appearance into a brief, solemn gathering. The president, addressing the crowd, emphasized the need for prayer, reflection, and unity in the face of such a devastating event.

"There are going to be other days for politics. This is a day for prayer and reflection," Obama said, urging the audience to observe a moment of silence for the victims and their families. The president underscored the importance of cherishing life and focusing on love and compassion in the face of adversity.

Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, also adjusted his campaign schedule. Speaking at what was initially planned as a campaign event in Bow, New Hampshire, Romney expressed his condolences and called for unity and compassion in the wake of the tragedy.

"Today is a moment to grieve and remember, and to reach out and to help, to appreciate our blessings in life," Romney said. "Each one of us will hold our kids a little closer, linger a bit longer with a colleague or a neighbor, reach out to a family member or friend."

Both the Obama and Romney campaigns temporarily suspended their political ads in Colorado out of respect for the victims and to avoid any appearance of insensitivity in a crucial battleground state. The issue of gun control, which has not been a significant campaign topic, is now likely to emerge in the national discourse.

New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg, in response to the shootings, called on both candidates to outline their plans for combating gun violence in the United States. The political landscape, for the time being, has shifted from campaign rhetoric to a call for unity, compassion, and reflection.

Title: Trust Deficit: Ebola Crisis in the U.S. and the Questionable Information from Government Officials

Article:

As the Ebola crisis unfolds within the United States, a growing sense of distrust towards the government has emerged. The American people, who traditionally have a general faith in their government, are questioning the credibility of the information provided by federal officials regarding the Ebola outbreak.

On Sept. 16, President Obama held a news conference about Ebola at the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) in Atlanta. After the president stated, "We have to act fast. We can't dawdle on this one," he declared the Ebola situation in West Africa as "spiraling out of control" and then assured the public that the chances of Ebola coming to America were "extremely low." However, on Sept. 20, Liberian Ebola carrier Thomas Eric Duncan arrived in the United States, just four days after the president's comments that it would likely not happen.

The honesty and transparency expected from government officials include admitting when there may be potential problems in the future. President Obama's refusal to suspend flights into the United States from Ebola-infected countries likely contributed to the virus' arrival in the country.

The CDC's reassurances about Ebola, often delivered by Director Tom Frieden, were finally exposed on CNN. During a discussion with CNN's Sanjay Gupta, Dr. Frieden was asked to reassure viewers that Ebola was not "highly contagious." Dr. Frieden complied, stating, "It's not like the flu, not like the common cold, it requires direct physical contact." However, when a news anchor mentioned that if someone with Ebola sneezes on you, it's a different story, Dr. Frieden was compelled to admit that existing CDC guidelines warn that standing within a three-foot radius of someone with Ebola poses a risk of infection.

The CDC's misleading information about Ebola's contagion, usually delivered by Dr. Frieden, was finally exposed on live TV, showing federal officials not being completely honest with the public. This incident, along with other instances of misinformation, has led to a growing distrust of government officials and the mainstream media.

The American people have faced numerous life-threatening crises throughout history, from world wars to debilitating viruses, and have always come together, faced reality, and defeated the enemy. However, politicians have a different reason to keep information from the public: each failure of the system exposes their incompetence. The many scandals of the Obama presidency could benefit from a healthy dose of light brought by curious reporters who are still interested in investigating and finding the truth, regardless of which politicians it exposes.

Title: Bipartisan Backlash Against Rep. Ilhan Omar's Remarks on Israel and AIPAC

Article:

Rep. Ilhan Omar, D-Minn., found herself at the center of a controversy Sunday evening as members from both parties criticized her for suggesting that a prominent lobbying group, the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC), pays members of Congress to support Israel.

Omar, who made history as the first Somali-American woman elected to Congress in November, responded to a Twitter post by journalist Glenn Greenwald criticizing House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., for threatening to take action against Omar and another freshman lawmaker, Rashida Tlaib, D-Mich., over allegedly anti-Semitic remarks.

McCarthy had told reporters on Friday, "I think when they stay silent, they are just as guilty... I think this will not be the end of this, and if they do not take action then I think you will see action from myself. It’s unacceptable in this country, especially when you sit back and think about and listen to what this country went through in World War II."

Greenwald accused McCarthy of targeting Omar and Tlaib for their numerous criticisms of Israel, to which Omar responded, "It's all about the Benjamins, baby," quoting a 1997 rap song by Puff Daddy. She then doubled down when challenged by Batya Ungar-Sargon, the opinion editor of The Forward newspaper.

"Would love to know who @IlhanMN thinks is paying American politicians to be pro-Israel, though I think I can guess," Ungar-Sargon tweeted. "Bad form, Congresswoman. That's the second anti-Semitic trope you've tweeted."

In response, Omar tweeted "AIPAC!" referring to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, which has been accused by progressives of agitating for a conflict with Iran.

AIPAC responded Sunday evening, tweeting, "We are proud that we are engaged in the democratic process to strengthen the US-Israel relationship. Our bipartisan efforts are reflective of American values and interests. We will not be deterred in any way by ill-informed and illegitimate attacks on this important work."

Another freshman Democrat, Max Rose of New York, tweeted that Omar's statements "are deeply hurtful to Jews, including myself."

"When someone uses hateful and offensive tropes and words against people of my faith, I will not be silent," Rose said in a statement. "... At a time when anti-Semitic attacks are on the rise, our leaders should not be invoking hurtful stereotypes and caricatures of Jewish people to dismiss those who support Israel. In the Democratic Party - and in the United States of America - we celebrate the diversity of our people, and the Gods we pray to, as a strength. The congresswoman's statements do not live up to that cherished ideal."

Jewish groups have also condemned Rep. Rashida Tlaib over her ties to radical pro-Hezbollah, anti-Israel activists.

House GOP conference chair Liz Cheney, R-Wyo., slammed Omar's remarks and called for House Democrat leaders to remove Omar from the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

Zudhi Jasser, a physician and President of the American Islamic Forum for Democracy, took Cheney’s call a step further, arguing that removing Omar from the House Foreign Affairs Committee would be a “good first step, followed by a swift sanction against @IlhanMN for bigotry unfit for the US Congress with removal from all committees. Ignoring this would bring the “bigotry of low expectations” to a new low for Muslims.”

The Republican Jewish Coalition called on House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., to take action against Omar and asked rhetorically if other House Democrats would “care to comment on the outrageous anti-Semitism being spewed by one of your fêted members?”

House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer, D-Md., has yet to comment on the matter.

Former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley, who repeatedly accused the global body of anti-Israel bias during her tenure, tweeted that Omar's statements "CAN NOT be tolerated in our own Congress by anyone of either party. In a time of increased anti-Semitism, we all must be held to account. No excuses."

Chelsea Clinton tweeted, "We should expect all elected officials, regardless of party, and all public figures to not traffic in anti-Semitism."

Meghan McCain, daughter of late Arizona Senator John McCain, lauded Clinton for calling out anti-Semitism "on all sides, in all spaces, no matter how uncomfortable."

Left-wing historian and Politico Magazine contributing editor Joshua Zeitz tweeted, "I'm one of those American Jews who opposes the occupation [of the West Bank and Gaza Strip] and laments Israel's anti-democratic drift, and does not regard the country as especially central to my Jewish identity. And I knew exactly what the congresswoman meant. She might as well call us hook-nosed."

Clinton later promised that she would "reach out" to Omar on Monday after another user said she was "disappointed" that Clinton was "piling on."

"I would be happy to talk," Omar tweeted at Clinton in response. "We must call out smears from the GOP and their allies. And I believe we can do that without criticizing people for their faith. I look forward to building an inclusive movement for justice with you."

Sunday marked the latest in a long line of statements by Omar that critics have slammed as anti-Semitic. In 2012, she tweeted that "Israel has hypnotized the world, may Allah awaken the people and help them see the evil doings of Israel. # Gaza # Palestine # Israel." She did not apologize for posting the tweet until last month.

In January, Omar argued in a Yahoo! News interview that Israel could not be considered a democracy and compared it to the Islamic theocracy in Iran.

"When I see Israel institute laws that recognize it as a Jewish state and does not recognize the other religions that are living in it, and we still uphold it as a democracy in the Middle East I almost chuckle because I know that if we see that any other society we would criticize it, call it out," she said. "We do that to Iran, we do that to any other place that sort of upholds its religion. And I see that now happening with Saudi Arabia and so I am aggravated, truly, in those contradictions."

Title: Jeb Bush Clarifies Immigration Stance Amidst 2016 Presidential Speculation

Article:

In a series of Sunday talk show appearances, former Florida Governor Jeb Bush has vigorously denied allegations that he has shifted his views on immigration reform, as other potential 2016 Republican candidates maneuver their positions on the contentious issue.

During his interviews, Bush reaffirmed his support for a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants, aligning himself with a bipartisan group of senators working on a bill. However, his new book, "Immigration Wars: Forging an American Solution," suggests a path to residency rather than citizenship for the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants already in the country.

On "Fox News Sunday," Bush stated, "I support a path to citizenship, so long as the path for people that have been waiting patiently is easier and costs less, the legal entrance to our country, than illegal entrance."

Sen. Lindsey Graham, a member of the "Gang of Eight," had previously criticized Bush's stance, stating it "undercuts" their efforts. But Bush clarified that he had discussed the issue with Graham and that they share the same views, despite earlier support for a pathway to citizenship in his career.

The immigration debate is a delicate issue for the Republicans, as they strive to distance themselves from President Obama's policies while avoiding alienating Latino voters. Senators Marco Rubio of Florida and Rand Paul of Kentucky, both potential 2016 nominees, have criticized a leaked framework for immigration reform that included a path to citizenship. Rubio, whose parents emigrated from Cuba, supports a pathway to citizenship for those currently in the country illegally, a stance Bush said he aligns with.

Bush dismissed suggestions that his recent statements and book are part of political maneuvering for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination, stating, "That's the Washington world, the world of everything has to have a personal political ambition, motive. That's not the case." The book, he explained, was written last year when the immigration debate's tone was significantly different.

The ongoing immigration debate continues to be a significant issue in American politics, with both parties seeking to address the complex and contentious matter in a manner that balances legal immigration, border security, and the status of undocumented immigrants already residing in the United States.

Title: Colorado Lawmakers Advance Firearm Restrictions Amidst Intense Debate and Protests

Article:

In a highly charged atmosphere, Colorado lawmakers have advanced firearm restrictions, as the debate over the proposed measures intensified on Monday. Hundreds of gun rights supporters, who filled the state Capitol and circled the building with car horns blaring, called for the preservation of Second Amendment rights. Inside, the husband of former U.S. Rep. Gabrielle Giffords, and victims of mass shootings in Connecticut and a suburban Denver movie theater, pleaded for more gun controls.

The state, known for its politically moderate stance, is at the center of the national debate on gun violence in the wake of recent mass shootings, including the attack at a suburban Denver movie theater last summer, which evoked memories of the Columbine High School shooting of 1999 for many in the state and across the nation.

Lawmakers are considering a package of gun control measures, including plans that would limit ammunition magazines to 15 rounds and expand background checks to include private sales and online purchases. Both measures cleared Democratic-controlled committees on 3-2 party-line votes but still need approval from the full Senate, which could debate the bills as soon as this week.

Retired astronaut and Navy captain Mark Kelly, the husband of Gabrielle Giffords, told lawmakers that he and his wife support the Second Amendment, but he said the right to bear arms should not extend to criminals and the mentally ill. Kelly compared the different background check requirements for private and retail sales to having two different lines at the airport, one with security and one without.

"Which one do you think the terrorist is going to choose?" he asked.

Giffords, a former Democratic congresswoman from Tucson, Ariz., was severely wounded in a mass shooting in January 2011 while meeting with constituents.

Gun control opponents argue that the proposals will not reduce violence. They suggest lawmakers should focus on strengthening access to mental health services for people who could be dangerous to communities.

The bill hearings were at times testy, and included some outbursts from the audience. After one bill passed, someone leaving the committee yelled "That sucks!" to lawmakers.

"I've never seen such unprofessional behavior," Democratic Sen. Irene Aguilar told the audience at one point.

Meanwhile, gun rights advocates complained that lawmakers limited testimony time, and many did not have a chance to speak on proposals.

The commotion at the Capitol underscored the attention the debate has generated nationally from gun rights groups, such as the National Rifle Association, to victims' families and White House officials.

Several bills before state senators have already cleared the House. With Democrats controlling both chambers of the state Legislature, some of the proposals have a strong chance of passing.

Other measures that picked up initial Senate approval would place new restrictions on gun ownership by people convicted in domestic violence cases, and another requires gun buyers to pay for their own background checks.

The state's Democratic governor, John Hickenlooper, supports magazine limits and expanded background checks. He has not indicated where he stands on other measures, including whether he supports a proposal that would hold sellers and owners of assault weapons liable for shootings by such firearms.

Gun rights supporters walked the Capitol halls wearing stickers that read, "I Vote Pro-Gun." Several dozen people outside the Capitol waved American flags as light snow fell, and a small plane flew overhead carrying a banner with a message for the governor, "HICK: DO NOT TAKE OUR GUNS!"

One of the nation's largest producers of ammunition magazines, Colorado-based Magpul, has threatened to leave the state if lawmakers restrict the size of its products. Its founder said smaller magazines can be easily connected to each other, and the company fears it would legally liable if people were to do that.

About 20 Colorado sheriffs opposed the expanded background checks and the magazine limits. Standing shoulder-to-shoulder in front of lawmakers in committee, they said that both bills were unenforceable.

"This bill just doesn't make any sense from our perspective," Pueblo Sheriff Kirk Taylor said about the bill to limit magazine sizes.

Victims who have lost relatives to gun violence say it's time for legislators to take action. Tom Sullivan, whose son Alex was among the 12 killed in the Aurora, Colo., theater shooting, was among the people urging lawmakers to pass magazine restrictions.

"He was enjoying the movie one second, and then the next second he was dead," Tom Sullivan said.

Jane Dougherty, whose sister, Mary Sherlach, was a psychologist killed in the shooting rampage at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., has been lobbying Colorado lawmakers to pass new gun laws. She said she does not understand gun owners who worry the bills are putting a burden on their rights.

She said the Connecticut shooter used "the same type of weapon that we use in war" to "slaughter these babies" and asked lawmakers for stricter gun laws.

"We can not wait for yet another massacre to transpire," Dougherty said.

Title: Biden Reverses Stance on Abortion Funding Amidst Intensifying Criticism from Democratic Rivals

Article:

In a significant shift of position, former Vice President Joe Biden has reversed his long-standing support for the Hyde Amendment, a law that restricts federal funding for abortions. The change comes amid mounting criticism from his fellow 2020 Democratic presidential candidates.

At a Democratic gala on Thursday, Mr. Biden denounced the Hyde Amendment, stating his belief that healthcare is a fundamental right. He added that he made "no apologies" for his previous stance but emphasized that his current views are incompatible with the amendment's implications.

The Hyde Amendment, passed in 1976, prohibits the use of federal funds for most abortions, particularly for women receiving federal assistance through Medicaid. This amendment has been a contentious issue, as it effectively blocks a significant number of low-income women from accessing abortion services, which can often cost several hundred dollars.

Senators Elizabeth Warren and Beto O'Rourke were among those who had recently criticized Biden's stance. In response, Biden, speaking at a Democratic National Committee gala in Atlanta, stated, "If I believe health care is a right, as I do, I can no longer support an amendment that makes that right dependent on someone's ZIP code."

Biden is a practicing Roman Catholic who has previously stated his personal opposition to abortion but believes his religious beliefs should not be imposed on others. This policy change, while drawing criticism and support, may not necessarily be a political liability, given that Biden's support comes from more moderate Democrats and independents.

This shift in stance comes amid a wave of conservative state legislatures enacting restrictions on abortion or outright bans, as seen in Alabama's recent ban on almost all abortions. Biden cited these restrictions as one of the reasons for his policy change.

The Hyde Amendment has been a topic of debate among the 24 candidates running for the 2020 Democratic nomination. Several candidates, including Bernie Sanders, Cory Booker, and Jay Inslee, have expressed support for repealing the law this week.

In response to Biden's change in stance, both O'Rourke and Warren directly criticized his viewpoint. Warren felt that the amendment was discriminatory, stating, "It's just discrimination against poorer women." O'Rourke, on the other hand, called Biden's viewpoint "absolutely wrong," adding, "Perhaps he does not understand who the Hyde Amendment hurts the most, lower income communities, communities of color."

The four female senators running for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination - Warren, Kamala Harris, Kirsten Gillibrand, and Amy Klobuchar - have co-sponsored a measure to revoke the Hyde Amendment. They also tweeted criticisms of the law this week, but did not name Biden.

This policy change could potentially impact Biden's electability, as his support stems largely from the perception that he is a winning candidate who can stand up to and defeat Donald Trump. However, too many fumbles could strip away this veneer of electability.

Title: Iran Protests Escalate as Tensions Rise in Region Following Downed Ukrainian Plane, Arrest of British Ambassador

Article:

In the aftermath of the downing of a Ukrainian passenger plane last week, Iranian leaders' apologies have failed to quell the growing anti-government protests that have swept across the country. The airliner disaster occurred hours after Iran launched missile attacks on Iraqi military bases housing U.S. troops, in retaliation for a drone strike at Baghdad airport that killed Iranian commander Qasem Soleimani.

On Sunday, eight Katyusha rockets hit Iraq's Balad Air Base, north of Baghdad, wounding four Iraqi air force officers, according to an Iraqi military statement. No American or coalition forces were at the base when the rockets struck, a U.S. military official told CNN.

In Iran, demonstrators are calling for Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei to step down and for those responsible for downing the plane to be prosecuted. Protests have now spread to other cities, including Shiraz, Esfahan, Hamedan, and Orumiyeh, according to Reuters.

U.S. President Donald Trump tweeted his support for the demonstrators, saying his administration will "continue to stand by you." Likewise, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu voiced his support for the protesters and called on European powers to increase pressure on the Iranian regime.

Iran previously denied U.S. claims that the country had shot down the plane before admitting the mistake on Saturday. Iranian President Hassan Rouhani said his country "deeply regrets this disastrous mistake" and his "thoughts and prayers go to all the mourning families." Iranian Foreign Minister Javad Zarif blamed the disaster on "human error" and "US adventurism."

The protests came as Iran faces fresh criticism abroad for the temporary arrest Saturday of British Ambassador Rob Macaire. On Sunday, Macaire was summoned to the Iranian foreign ministry. According to the semi-official Tasnim news agency, Macaire was arrested while in the middle of a crowd of protesters in front of Tehran's Amir Kabir University. He was accused of instigating and directing radical and destructive demonstrations, and later released.

UK Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab called Macaire's arrest a "flagrant violation of international law" -- a sentiment echoed by the German and French foreign ministries. Iranian officials said Macaire was released as soon as his identity was confirmed.

The downed plane's victims included 57 Canadians, and the country's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau told a press conference Saturday that, "what Iran has admitted to is very serious." "Canada will not rest until we get the accountability, justice, and closure that the families deserve," Trudeau said.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky tweeted that Iran's admission was a "step in the right direction." Iranian authorities are in possession of the two flight data recorders, also known as black boxes, which Ukrainian investigators got access to on Friday. They have yet to start examining the information, but have said it included communications between the pilot and Tehran flight control.

Title: President Trump Prepares for Tulsa Rally Amidst Anticipated Protests and Safety Measures

Article:

In a tweet on Friday, President Donald Trump signaled a tougher approach towards protesters and "anarchists" in Tulsa, Oklahoma, ahead of his comeback rally this weekend. The President's tweet comes as a preemptive measure against individuals who may stir up unrest in the deep-red city, contrasting with the response in Democratic-led cities across the country.

The tweet did not distinguish between protesters advocating for racial justice and those who have caused property damage or disrupted cities following the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis police custody. White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany later clarified that the President's reference to "anarchists" and looters pertained to those who engage in violent activities.

Tulsa Mayor G.T. Bynum, a Republican, agreed not to impose a previously ordered curfew on rally attendees, as per the President's tweet. The Oklahoma Supreme Court also denied a local attempt to block the rally, stating that the petitioners did not establish a "clear legal right" to cancel the event.

The Trump campaign anticipates tens of thousands of people to attend the rally at the Bank of Oklahoma (BOK) Center, with the campaign implementing safety measures such as temperature checks, hand sanitizer, and masks at the entrance. However, wearing masks is optional.

Ms. McEnany stated she does not plan to wear a mask at the rally, citing her regular testing. The President is aiming to rejuvenate the economy post-lockdown and overhaul policing in the wake of George Floyd's death, while also positioning himself as a "law and order" candidate who will not tolerate violent protests.

However, the President continues to face criticism over his actions during the June 1 clearing of mostly peaceful protesters from Lafayette Park near the White House. It remains uncertain whether similar incidents will occur in Tulsa. Community organizers plan to observe the Juneteenth holiday in the historic Greenwood district, which was once known as Black Wall Street before a 1921 massacre.

Ross Baker, a political professor at Rutgers University, commented on the President's actions, stating, "This is all about his own morale, which has been flagging since the Lafayette Square episode." Baker added, "The president has been rattling his cage. He is desperate to break out of the physical confines of the White House and draw energy from an adoring crowd, which he is certain to get in Tulsa where there is little chance of large counter-demonstrations."

Title: Man Armed with Rifle Dies in Shootout with Police at Washington Immigration Detention Center

A 69-year-old man identified as Willem Van Spronsen, a resident of Vashon Island, was killed in a shootout with police early Saturday morning at the Tacoma Northwest Detention Center in Washington state. The privately run facility, operated by the GEO Group, houses migrants pending deportation proceedings and has previously held individuals separated from their families under the Trump administration's "zero tolerance" policy.

According to the Tacoma Police Department, the incident occurred at approximately 4 a.m. when Van Spronsen set a vehicle on fire, attempted to ignite a large propane tank, and set buildings ablaze. Police found him armed with a rifle, a satchel, and flares.

Upon arrival, four police officers called out to Van Spronsen, and shots were fired. Loretta Cool, a police spokesperson, stated that all four officers discharged their weapons, but she did not provide specific details of the incident. The officers were not wearing body cameras, but the area is covered by surveillance cameras from the detention center. It is unclear whether Van Spronsen fired at the officers.

After the gunfire, officers took cover, contained the area, and set up medical aid a short distance away. Officers then located Van Spronsen and determined he had been shot and was dead at the scene. No law enforcement officers were injured.

Authorities are still investigating the incident, and questions remain about the motives behind Van Spronsen's actions. Deb Bartley, a friend of Van Spronsen, told the Seattle Times that she believes he intended to provoke a fatal conflict and that his attack on the detention center was a suicide mission.

Van Spronsen had a history of activism and was previously accused of assaulting a police officer during a protest outside the detention center in 2018. He pleaded guilty to obstructing police and was given a deferred sentence.

The GEO Group, which runs the detention center, released a statement expressing gratitude for the quick action by the Tacoma Police Department and stating that baseless accusations about the treatment of detainees at its facilities have led to dangerous situations for employees. The company also emphasized the modern amenities available at the Tacoma facility, including air conditioning, recreational activities, a bed for every individual, and medical care available at all hours.

Last year, a federal judge ruled that Washington state could pursue a lawsuit seeking to force the GEO Group to pay minimum wage for work done by detainees at the detention center. In November, a Russian asylum-seeker who conducted a hunger strike to protest the conditions at the detention center died by suicide.

The investigation into the incident is ongoing, and more information is expected to be released in the coming days.

Title: U.S. Intelligence Community Defends ISIS Assessment Amidst Political Controversy

Article:

In a memo to staff obtained by Fox News, the Director of National Intelligence, James Clapper, praised his analysts for their work in monitoring and assessing the Islamic State (ISIS) over the past two years. This praise comes amidst a heated debate following President Obama's comments on CBS's "60 Minutes" over the weekend, where he suggested that the intelligence community may have underestimated the threat posed by ISIS.

The ensuing controversy has led to a round of finger-pointing, with the White House walking back President Obama's comments, stating that he did not intend to blame the intelligence community. However, the White House is disputing accusations from Republican lawmakers and intelligence officials that Obama ignored ISIS warnings for months.

Rep. Michele Bachmann (R-Minn.) told Fox News that lawmakers on the House Intelligence Committee, of which she is a member, had been warning the administration for years about the seriousness of the ISIS threat.

Clapper's memo to staff, sent on Tuesday, highlights the intelligence community's efforts to monitor and assess ISIS over the past two years. He wrote, "I'm proud of the [intelligence community's] efforts over the past two years to monitor, assess and call attention to the expansion of ISIL, and I know the president has found that work to be critical to developing his strategy."

Clapper noted that both he and President Obama were in agreement about the difficulty in predicting the "will" of Iraqi security forces to fight. He wrote, "Despite all we understood about the capabilities of ISIL and the Iraqi Security Forces, we have no intelligence tool that could have predicted the ISF's sudden collapse in northern Iraq and the resultant ease with which ISIL forces captured territory."

Clapper's claims about the intelligence community's diligence in assessing the ISIS threat could fuel concerns that the White House was not taking those assessments seriously enough. House Intelligence Committee Chairman Mike Rogers (R-Mich.) has faulted "policy makers" for not confronting the threat.

When asked about Clapper's role on Wednesday, Rogers suggested that President Obama may have missed key intelligence briefings. "James Clapper has a tough job overseeing 16 intel agencies. I am more concerned about the president and the missed intel briefings," Rogers told Fox News.

Intelligence officials have told Fox News and other outlets that they were drawing attention to the ISIS threat for months but were ignored by the White House. On Tuesday, White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest pointed to Clapper's memo to rebut one anonymous quote to that effect in The New York Times.

"He put out a message to the intelligence community that directly contradicts the anonymous individual who's quoted in the New York Times," Earnest said, reading passages from Clapper's memo and saying the memo was "consistent" with Obama's comments on "60 Minutes."

Clapper previously admitted that U.S. analysts both underestimated the Islamic State and "overestimated" the ability of the Iraqi army to fight them. However, the memo on Tuesday did not acknowledge underestimating ISIS, as Obama said on "60 Minutes."

Title: Obama to Address United Nations, Warns Iran on Nuclear Ambitions and Pays Tribute to Ambassador Chris Stevens

In a significant address to the United Nations General Assembly today, President Barack Obama will issue a stern warning to Iran regarding its nuclear program, emphasizing the United States' resolve to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons.

According to excerpts released by the White House, President Obama will say, "America wants to resolve this issue through diplomacy, and we believe that there is still time and space to do so. But that time is not unlimited." He will further state, "Make no mistake: a nuclear-armed Iran is not a challenge that can be contained. It would threaten the elimination of Israel, the security of Gulf nations, and the stability of the global economy."

The President's address comes in the wake of the September 11 attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi, Libya, where Ambassador Chris Stevens lost his life. In his speech, Obama is expected to pay tribute to Ambassador Stevens.

President Obama's address is one of many speeches scheduled this week, as world leaders gather for the annual opening of the United Nations General Assembly. The U.N. webcasts its proceedings, and updates will be posted as the President and other leaders address the assembly.

The President's speech, of course, takes place amidst the ongoing U.S. presidential campaign. Republican candidate Mitt Romney, in a statement on Monday, criticized President Obama's foreign affairs leadership, particularly in reference to the killing of the U.S. ambassador in Libya and the ongoing crisis in Syria.

Both Obama and Romney are also scheduled to address the Clinton Global Initiative today. The week ahead promises to be a busy one for diplomacy, with Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu among the other leaders who will be speaking.

Title: International Community Rallies to Aid in Search for Abducted Nigerian Schoolgirls as Boko Haram Expands Terror Tactics

Article:

In the aftermath of the mass abduction of hundreds of schoolgirls by the militant group Boko Haram, Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan has vowed that the group's actions will be the terror group's undoing. The abduction, which occurred on April 14 from an all-girls school in rural northeastern Nigeria, has sparked international outrage and a concerted effort to locate the missing girls.

According to U.S. Navy Rear Adm. John Kirby, U.S. intelligence believes the 276 girls have been split up, making the search for them more challenging. This sentiment is echoed by former UK Prime Minister Gordon Brown, the U.N.'s special envoy for global education, who emphasizes the importance of finding the girls before they are dispersed across Africa.

The girls have not been seen since their abduction from the Government Girls Secondary School in Chibok. Another kidnapping occurred on Sunday night, with villagers in Warabe accusing Boko Haram militants of taking at least eight girls between the ages of 12 and 15.

Shehu Sani, a former negotiator between Boko Haram and the government, believes the group targeted the girls to force concessions from the Nigerian government. Sani suggests that the group may be seeking the release of its followers from prisons.

The Nigerian government has been under fire for its response to the abduction, with critics claiming that government officials failed to take action in the hours and days following the girls' disappearance. President Jonathan, who waited three weeks before speaking to the nation on the matter, and his security ministers have defended the response, stating that efforts were underway but could not be disclosed publicly.

In response to the crisis, the United States, United Kingdom, China, and France have offered assistance in the search for the girls. The United States is sending a team of law enforcement experts and military advisers, while France will send a "specialized team" to help. The British government is also sending a small team, and China has promised to provide any intelligence gathered by its satellite network.

Seven members of the U.S. military are scheduled to arrive in Nigeria on Friday to join a team of advisers supporting the Nigerian efforts to rescue the girls. There are currently no plans to send U.S. combat troops, according to Rear Adm. Kirby.

Nigerian security chiefs have appealed to the public for help in locating the missing girls. The chief of defense, Air Marshal Alex S. Badeh, called on members of the immediate community to provide security agencies with useful information that will lead to the rescue of the girls.

Boko Haram, which translates to "Western education is sin" in the local Hausa language, has been known to kill Muslim clerics who dare criticize them. The United States has branded Boko Haram a terror organization and has put a $7 million bounty on its leader, Abubakar Shekau.

The Nigerian government has offered a reward of about $310,000 for information leading to the girls' rescue. The search for the missing girls must expand to neighboring countries, including Niger, Cameroon, and Chad, according to Gordon Brown. The international community remains hopeful that the girls will be found and returned to their families.

Title: U.S. Government Shutdown Enters 12th Day as Trump and Congressional Leaders Fail to Reach Agreement on Border Wall Funding

Article:

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - A meeting between U.S. congressional leaders and President Donald Trump on Wednesday failed to produce an agreement to end the partial government shutdown now in its 12th day, as the president continued to demand $5 billion in funding for a border wall with Mexico, a demand fiercely opposed by Democrats.

Congressional leaders are expected to return to the White House on Friday to resume talks, signaling the shutdown will likely stretch into the weekend. The White House convened the meeting to try to convince Democrats that funding a wall on the southern border was a pressing security need. Instead, Democratic leaders cut off Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen's presentation and tried, unsuccessfully, to press Trump to accept their offer.

"It just was not a credible presentation," Senator Dick Durbin said of the briefing. He added that Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi, who is expected to be elected House speaker on Thursday, insisted the conversation focus instead on the shutdown.

Pelosi said the House would proceed with plans to hold votes on Thursday, when they formally take control of the chamber from Trump's fellow Republicans, on legislation that would end the shutdown without providing the wall money sought by Trump.

"We're asking the president to open up government," Pelosi told reporters outside the White House after the meeting.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said afterward on the Senate floor that the chamber would not vote on the legislation, calling it a "political sideshow" and "total nonstarter."

Democrats say they want to fund most of the government through September, but allow for another month to negotiate wall funding by only partially funding the Department of Homeland Security, which is responsible for the wall. Schumer said Trump conceded that Republicans would lose leverage if they allowed the rest of the government to be funded.

"We asked him to give us one good reason... why you should continue your shutdown of the eight Cabinet departments while we are debating our differences on homeland security. He could not give a good answer," Schumer told reporters after the meeting.

In a tweet on Wednesday evening, Trump called the meeting "important" and said he would continue talks with Democrats "to pass a bill that secures our borders, supports the agents and officers on the ground, and keeps America Safe."

Trump's demand for $5 billion in funding for a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border triggered the shutdown affecting about a quarter of the federal government and 800,000 federal workers. Before meeting with lawmakers, Trump said the shutdown would last for "as long as it takes" as he pushes for wall money as part of any legislation to reopen agencies shuttered when their funding lapsed on Dec. 22.

"It could be a long time, or it could be quickly," Trump told reporters on Wednesday during a Cabinet meeting. "We know that we have a challenge along the border. We want to solve that issue. We want to make sure we open this government up. And I think at the end of the day, the president, listening to him, he wants to solve this as well."

Pelosi noted that the legislation being presented in the House had previously won backing in the Senate, which will remain in Republican hands in the new 2019-2020 Congress that convenes on Thursday.

But McConnell said previously that Senate Republicans would not approve a spending measure Trump does not support.

Trump made the border wall a key part of his presidential campaign. Before meeting with the Democrats, Trump called the border a "sieve," rebutted Pelosi's complaint that a wall was immoral, provided an estimate of the U.S. illegal immigrant population far higher than the figures most experts cite and made disputed comments about progress toward building a wall.

The visit by Pelosi and Schumer was their first to the White House since their sharp exchange with Trump in the Oval Office on Dec. 11 during which the president told them he would be "proud to shut down the government for border security."

The $5 billion Trump is seeking would cover only a portion of the money needed for a border wall, a project estimated to cost about $23 billion. Trump had said Mexico would pay for the wall, but Mexico has refused.

Title: West Point Graduation Ceremony Held Amidst COVID-19 Outbreak, 1.5% of Graduating Class Tests Positive

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy and concern, the United States Military Academy at West Point held an in-person graduation ceremony on June 13, despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The event, which was attended by President Donald Trump, resulted in 1.5% of the graduating class testing positive for the virus.

Army spokesperson Emanuel L. Ortiz confirmed the positive cases in an emailed statement, stating that none of the affected students were symptomatic, and no cadet contracted the virus through person-to-person contact while under the Army's care.

The decision to hold an in-person ceremony was met with criticism, as many believed it was unnecessary and potentially dangerous. In March, as West Point leaders discussed whether to return students currently on spring break to campus, President Trump announced his intention to attend the ceremony, a move that reportedly took academy officials by surprise and required them to improvise their plans.

Secretary of Defense Mark Esper addressed Naval Academy graduates virtually last month, and even the Air Force Academy, which kept seniors on campus during the outbreak, welcomed Vice President Mike Pence for a commencement event with social distancing protocols in place and no spectators. However, Trump's insistence on a more traditional ceremony, with the potential for a larger audience, has been a point of contention.

Lt. Gen. Darryl Williams, the academy's superintendent, stated that returning cadets would be "segregated the entire time" into five cohorts, with no cohort intermingling for 14 days. "They'll eat separately, they'll live separately," he said.

The Army has struggled to justify Trump's decision, which required hundreds of future soldiers to return to a region of the country that has been hit especially hard by the coronavirus. Ryan McCarthy, the Army's top civilian leader, stated that cadets would have needed to return to campus anyway "to begin the process of the physicals they need, to take all of their clearance procedures, to clear barracks, get their personal items." However, this process could have been spaced out in a way that would have ensured greater safety for cadets.

The decision has caused an uproar on the West Point Parents Facebook group, with many expressing concern over the potential risks associated with the ceremony. "PLEASE PLEASE do NOT let your children go back for graduation. It's not worth their health or yours," one person wrote. Others have contextualized Trump's mandate by comparing it to typical orders from a commander in chief, including those that send cadets off to war.

The West Point graduation ceremony has become a contentious issue, with some viewing it as a necessary part of the military tradition, while others see it as a potential health risk in the midst of a global pandemic. As the United States continues to grapple with COVID-19, the decision to hold an in-person ceremony at West Point will likely remain a topic of debate.

Title: Reddit Faces Allegations of Censorship After Quarantining 'European' Subreddit

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy and accusations of censorship, administrators at the popular online forum Reddit have quarantined a subreddit titled 'European.' The subreddit, which is a community dedicated to specific topics, was set to private on May 12, 2016, with a note stating, "You must be a moderator or approved submitter to visit." The note also urged visitors to continue their discussions on Voat, another online forum.

The allegation of censorship comes amidst recent debates about bias in social media. This accusation followed anonymous claims that contractors at Facebook deliberately suppressed conservative news on the site's Trending Topics section. Facebook has since denied any political bias, stating there is "no evidence" of the alleged activity.

Reddit, in response to FoxNews.com's inquiry, stated that the 'European' subreddit violated the forum's content policy. The statement explained, "Quarantines on Reddit are rare - there are thousands of vibrant conversations flourishing on the site every day." It added, "Subreddits are quarantined only when the content is clearly offensive to the broader Reddit community."

The quarantine aims to prevent the content from being accidentally viewed by those who do not wish to do so. "A subreddit is quarantined when there are concerns that its content is extreme and could be offensive to people outside of that community," explained Reddit. "The quarantine process doesn’t end the conversation; it adds an opt-in measure so that people have the choice to join the conversation," it added.

Restrictions on a quarantined subreddit include requiring an explicit opt-in, requiring an account with a verified email address, no use of custom images, and the removal of revenue generation.

The 'European' subreddit quarantine has prompted a mixed reaction elsewhere on Reddit. Some users claim that racist views were expressed on the subreddit, while others argue that it hosted a range of opinions and emphasize the importance of open dialogue.

With over 277 million unique visitors last month, Reddit uses teams of volunteers to moderate subreddits. The forum updated its content policy last year, consolidating multiple rules and policies into a single set of guidelines.

Recently, a blogger, who uses the name Curious Gnu, analyzed a Reddit dataset of 4.6 million comments and noted that 78 percent of Reddit threads with over 1,000 comments mention Nazis or Hitler. The blogger found that around 2.6 percent of comments in the 'European' subreddit mentioned Nazis or Hitler, a slightly higher percentage compared to the 'AskHistorians' and 'history' subreddits.

This incident, along with the ongoing debate about bias in social media, highlights the challenges of maintaining a balance between free speech and offensive content on these platforms.

Title: Justice Department Increases Investigations into Classified Information Leaks by 27 Ongoing Probes

Article:

In a significant development, the Justice Department has revealed that it is currently conducting 27 open investigations into leaks of classified information with a "political motive." This number is three times higher than the number of such investigations in the three years prior, as stated by Attorney General Jeff Sessions during his testimony before the House Judiciary Committee on Tuesday.

Sessions, in his testimony, described the current state of leaks as reaching "epidemic proportions." He explained that these investigations include cases where the leaks occurred before President Trump took office and cases that occurred after.

Rep. Ron DeSantis (R-Fla.) questioned Sessions about accountability for leaking information against the Trump administration with a political motive. Sessions responded by referring to the case of former National Security Agency contractor Reality Winner, who leaked a classified intelligence report containing "Top Secret Level" information.

Sessions stated, "It can not be allowed to continue and we will do our best effort to ensure it does not continue."

The increased investigations come amid pressure from the White House, with President Trump criticizing Sessions in July for being "weak" on such issues. Following the president's comments, Sessions held a press conference with Director of National Intelligence Dan Coats, calling for an end to the leaks.

In July, a report from the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee revealed that the Trump administration was facing an "alarming" and "unprecedented" cascade of media leaks that posed a potential danger to national security. The report estimated that the administration has dealt with roughly one leak per day.

The report also stated that leaks flowed about "seven times faster" under the Trump administration than during the first 126 days of both Obama's and George W. Bush's presidencies.

In July, the Senate report also revealed that Reality Winner, the accused leaker, had expressed a desire to "resist" the Trump administration. Winner was an avid supporter of Sen. Bernie Sanders' presidential campaign.

Title: US Designates North Korea as State Sponsor of Terrorism, Escalating Tensions

Article:

In a move that escalates tensions between the United States and North Korea, President Donald Trump has designated North Korea as a state sponsor of terrorism. The announcement was made during a Cabinet meeting on Monday, with Trump stating, "Should have happened a long time ago." The administration will unveil new sanctions against North Korea on Tuesday.

The designation places North Korea alongside Iran, Sudan, and Syria as the only countries on the state sponsors of terrorism list. This classification bars them from receiving US development assistance, bans defense sales to them, restricts exports of items that could potentially be used for military purposes, and imposes tougher financial restrictions.

The decision comes as part of Trump's "maximum pressure campaign" to punish and isolate North Korea for its continued development of missiles capable of reaching the US mainland with a nuclear weapon. However, the actual support for terrorism, the primary reason for a country to be placed on the list, is debatable.

Administration lawyers noted that North Korea had to commit more than one act of terrorism to warrant placement on the list. The Trump administration officials assert that the February assassination of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's estranged half-brother in Malaysia was an act of terrorism. However, there is no agreement as to whether the brutal death of Otto Warmbier, a 23-year-old US citizen released by North Korea this summer who returned home in a coma, constituted terrorism.

North Korea was previously on the state sponsor of terror list, but was removed during talks aimed at getting the country to halt its nuclear program under President George W. Bush. The move is unlikely to stop North Korea's nuclear program, as the country has shown no interest in giving up its nuclear arsenal and continues to improve its missile and nuclear programs despite heavy sanctions.

The designation is unlikely to change North Korea's behavior in any meaningful way, as the country has no interest in giving up its nuclear program and is already heavily sanctioned by the US, China, and Europe. The move may inflict further financial pain on North Korea, but it is unlikely to achieve Trump's ultimate goal of stopping North Korea's nuclear program.
