Title: Candidates' Post-Election Actions and Calls for Electoral System Reforms

Article:

In the aftermath of the 2016 presidential election, Green Party candidate Jill Stein has raised over $4 million in three days for a recount in three critical Rust Belt states, citing a "hack-riddled election." Meanwhile, Republican Governor Pat McCrory of North Carolina, who trails his opponent, Attorney General Roy Cooper, by more than 7,000 votes, has alleged fraudulent votes in the election.

Stein's recount efforts are focused on Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, and Michigan, where Trump's victory margin remains narrow. A team of researchers, including J. Alex Halderman, director of the University of Michigan Center for Computer Security and Society, found discrepancies in some key Wisconsin counties won by Trump. However, election experts, such as Nate Silver of FiveThirtyEight, have suggested that the results are better explained by demographics rather than hacking.

In North Carolina, Governor McCrory's allegations of fraud have faced pushback. Preliminary analyses suggest that a list of supposedly fraudulent voters was largely inaccurate, with most of the names listed as ineligible found to be valid voters. County election boards, run by Republicans, have also found little evidence of voter wrongdoing.

The actions of Stein and McCrory, despite being on opposite sides of the political spectrum, highlight the divisiveness of the 2016 election and the need for increased public confidence in the electoral system. Some election experts argue that regular audits of voting machines would provide safeguards against hackers and improve voter peace of mind.

J. Alex Halderman, in a Medium post, wrote that examining the physical evidence in these states, even if it finds nothing amiss, will help allay doubt and give voters justified confidence that the results are accurate. Halderman has demonstrated that some American voting machines can be hacked.

The Clinton campaign has remained silent on Stein's recount gambit, with some suggesting that the hacking complaints are ironic given the Democrats' condemnation of Trump's claims of a "rigged" election. The Clinton campaign's silence has led some to view Stein's protest as a way to channel liberal anger towards a hopeless goal and feed into a narrative that American democracy is fragile.

However, others argue that statistical audits of electronic voting results in key states should be a routine safeguard, not just an emergency measure. Andy Greenberg, writing in Wired, suggests that such audits would help ease serious, lingering doubts about America's much-maligned electoral security.

In North Carolina, Governor McCrory's allegations of fraud have faced pushback, with some accusing him of trying to steal the election by invoking a state law that allows the legislature to anoint a governor in a "contested" election and bars anyone from suing in state courts over such a decision.

The willingness to invoke the potential of fraud has, to some extent, dovetailed with emerging cyberthreats to ring fresh alarm bells about the US voting system. At the very least, recent hacks of the Democratic Party and state voter registration systems suggest that those keen to disrupt the US system are probing its defenses.

Reforms suggested to improve the electoral system include bolder safeguards against insider wrongdoing, more federal funding to upgrade aging voting machines, and, critically, automatic paper-trail audits. About 70 percent of US voting machines leave a paper trail, but randomized checks are done only upon request.

"It is vital that we protect voters from the real threats to the integrity of elections," Myrna Perez, a law professor at the New York University School of Law, wrote in a Brennan Center report from earlier this year. "Fortunately, it is possible to protect election integrity without disenfranchising eligible voters."

Title: Trump and Pence Seek Momentum Shift Ahead of Second Presidential Debate

Article:

As the second presidential debate between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton approaches, Mike Pence, the Republican vice presidential nominee, is under pressure to deliver a strong performance in an attempt to build on the momentum created by his vice presidential debate victory over Tim Kaine.

Pence's performance at the vice presidential debate on Tuesday was widely seen as a success, with the Indiana governor outperforming his Democratic counterpart. This victory comes at a crucial time for the Trump campaign, which has been struggling in recent weeks due to an ineffective debate performance, a feud with a former Miss Universe, damaging tax revelations, and a steady slide in opinion polls.

At a rally in Henderson, Nevada, on Wednesday, Trump praised Pence, saying, "Mike Pence did an incredible job. I'm getting a lot of credit because that's really my first so-called choice; that's really my first hire, as we would say in Las Vegas."

The stakes are high for Trump as he prepares to face Clinton in St. Louis on October 9. Tobe Berkovitz, a Boston University professor who specializes in political communications, said, "How many times have all the pundits been interviewed saying, 'Trump is finally finished'? That must have happened 10 times. The problem now is the clock is running down. We'll be at four weeks, three weeks, two weeks. Can he pull the rabbit out of the hat one more time?"

With the second debate now of increased importance, there are reports that the Trump team is taking a more focused approach to debate preparations. New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie, an early Trump supporter and skilled debater, is reportedly involved in the debate preparations.

However, some Republicans are skeptical about how much ground Trump can make up at this stage. GOP strategist and Hill contributor Matt Mackowiak said, "Now it's up to him. It's like coaching versus playing. Coaches can prepare you and they can have the right play calls. But at the end of the day, the player on the field has to go do it. So far, Trump has fallen short. He really needs to win decisively on Sunday."

Numerous recent polls show the scale of the challenge Trump faces. A new poll from Monmouth University shows him trailing Clinton by 2 percentage points in Ohio, a state that has been one of the most favorable battleground states for the GOP nominee. Another new survey, from WRAL-TV and Survey USA, shows Trump trailing in North Carolina by 2 points. A national poll from Reuters/IPSOS gives Clinton a 6-point edge.

The data forecasting site FiveThirtyEight gives Clinton a 76.2 percent chance of prevailing in its "poll-only" forecast as of Wednesday evening, her highest rating by that measure since late August. However, the polls of the race have swung wildly before.

Clinton has twice led the RealClearPolitics national polling average by more than 6 points—in mid-June and early August—only to have Trump narrow those leads down to virtually nothing. Some Clinton critics maintain that she could yet be pushed off track by an external event, such as an unforced error or damaging disclosures from an organization such as WikiLeaks, which published embarrassing emails between Democratic National Committee staffers as the party's convention began this summer in Philadelphia.

However, a WikiLeaks news conference earlier this week failed to live up to the hype that surrounded it, casting doubt on whether the organization can follow through on its threats. Republicans also warn that Trump and his supporters can't depend on a lucky break. The nominee himself, they say, needs to wrest back the initiative from Clinton.

"Hope is not a strategy," said Mackowiak. "More of the same is not going to change the trajectory of the race. He needs to demonstrate at this next debate that he is prepared to be president—and that he can force Hillary Clinton back on defense."

In 2012, President Obama gave a lackluster performance at his opening clash with GOP nominee Mitt Romney and fell sharply in the polls afterward. However, Vice President Biden acquitted himself well against Romney's running mate, future Speaker Paul Ryan, and Obama was much improved when he met Romney a second and third time.

Sunday's debate will be in a town-hall format, but there is no consensus among insiders as to whether that helps or hinders Trump. Some backers suggest it will make it easier for Trump to feed off the energy of the crowd. Skeptics counter that televised town halls are technically challenging, in terms of tone and body language, and that a small, mostly quiet audience creates a very different atmosphere from the rambunctious rallies where Trump thrives.

But what if Trump surpasses expectations and reels in Clinton's lead one more time? "He would be the turnaround master of the decade if he pulls that off," said Berkovitz.

Title: Trump's Military Pardons Spark Controversy Over War Crimes and Military Discipline

Article:

In a series of controversial moves, President Donald Trump granted clemency to three military figures accused of war crimes on November 15, arguing that the decisions would give troops the confidence to fight without worrying about potential legal overreach. However, Defense Secretary Mark Esper fired the Navy's top official, Navy Secretary Richard Spencer, on Sunday, alleging that Spencer proposed a deal with the White House behind his back to resolve the case of Eddie Gallagher, one of the military figures pardoned.

The pardons have sparked criticism from both sides, with critics arguing that they undermine military discipline and send a message that U.S. forces will be allowed to get away with anything.

"War crimes are not difficult to discern... The actions these men were accused of most definitely qualify as war crimes," said one critic, citing instances of killing civilians and prisoners. "By sanctioning illegal behavior, the president has not strengthened our armed forces. By undercutting a military justice system that enforces those guiding principles, the president has not strengthened our armed forces. Instead, he endangers the safety of our troops, giving our adversaries a green light to similarly mistreat men and women who serve honorably in our military," the critic added.

Trump's actions have been criticized for undermining principles that have long served as a bedrock for the armed forces, and for damaging the nation's moral compass. "A nation has to know that military action being taken in its name follows morally defensible rules - that soldiers do not, for instance, kill unarmed civilians or prisoners," said another critic. "To excuse men who have so flagrantly violated those rules - to treat them as heroes, even - is to cast the idea of just war to the winds."

The president's interventions in these cases and those of two other service members undercut military leadership and dishonor the men and women who serve their country while upholding - not abandoning - its values. The SEAL team, in particular, has been shaken by a series of scandals in recent years, prompting Navy officials to take a tougher stance on ethical issues. Restoring to service someone who was turned in by members of his unit who wouldn't tolerate his behavior sends precisely the wrong message.

The damage was compounded on Sunday with news that Navy Secretary Richard V. Spencer was being forced out. The commander in chief's corrupting influence is ever widening. Through these pardons, and his earlier unprecedented interventions as these cases were making their way through the justice system, the president has undermined principles that long have served as a bedrock for our armed forces.

The president may feel like he's righting a wrong, but he's damaging the nation's moral compass. The president has the undisputed power to pardon. Indeed, he should use it more often in cases where guilt or a fair trial are in genuine doubt. But that power can not be exercised without a cost, in this case injury to the morality of a nation that once held its own to account.

Traditionally, presidents do not micromanage military personnel decisions at this level. It's bad for morale and can prove disruptive to the chain of command. The SEALs are the best judge of who should or shouldn't be counted in their ranks. We should leave them to conduct their business in accordance with the rules.

Title: Republican Senators Oppose Motion to Dismiss Impeachment Charges Against Trump

Article:

WASHINGTON - Republican members of the U.S. Senate have expressed opposition to any attempt to dismiss the impeachment charges against President Donald Trump without a trial. The Democratic-led U.S. House of Representatives is expected to formally send the charges to the Senate this week, where Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has vowed to help acquit his fellow Republican.

Trump appeared to reverse his position on how the Senate should proceed, writing on Twitter that a full trial would give the Democrats who pursued impeachment undeserved credibility and signaling support for dismissal of the charges with no trial. However, Republican senators have shown little interest in a motion to dismiss the House charges.

"There is almost no interest" among Republican senators for a motion to dismiss the House charges, Republican Senator Roy Blunt told reporters on Monday. Republican Senator Mitt Romney also stated that he will not be supporting a motion to dismiss, and that the allegations made against Trump are serious and deserve consideration.

Senator Susan Collins, among a handful of Republicans whom Democrats hope to persuade to back their call for witness testimony, told reporters that she and a small group of colleagues were discussing a trial format that would allow lawmakers to vote on whether to include witnesses after hearing from each side and having the opportunity to pose questions.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi delayed sending the two articles of impeachment passed by the House on Dec. 18 to the Republican-led Senate, preventing McConnell from holding a quick trial right away that cleared the president. The House charged Trump with abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. The impeachment charges stem from Trump's request that Ukraine investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a leading contender for the Democratic nomination to face Trump in the Nov. 3 presidential election.

House Democrats will discuss on Tuesday morning how to move forward, with the chamber possibly voting to send the charges to the Senate later that day. Pelosi said the delay was meant to convince the U.S. public of the need to call witnesses in the Senate trial after Trump's administration blocked some current and former officials from cooperating in the House impeachment inquiry.

McConnell has yet to say definitively how the Senate will conduct the trial. He has not committed to allowing any witnesses or new documents in the proceedings and instead could steer the process toward a quick acquittal. McConnell has left open the possibility of deciding on witness testimony later in the trial. He has said he sees no chance of the Senate convicting Trump.

The Senate, which could open a trial rapidly after receiving the charges from the House, plans to meet daily except on Sundays each week to conduct the proceedings, likely beginning each day at noon EST (1700 GMT) and working until either 5 p.m. or 6 p.m. EST (2200 or 2300 GMT), according to congressional aides. The Senate is expected to vote to acquit Trump, even though some moderate Republicans have bristled over McConnell's reflexive support for the president. Conviction and removal of Trump would require a two-thirds majority of those present in the 100-member chamber.

Title: Hillary Clinton Addresses Election Loss, Media Coverage, and Future Plans in Commencement Speech at Wellesley

In a candid and reflective speech at the Wellesley College commencement ceremony, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton acknowledged her role in her 2016 presidential campaign's missteps while attributing her election loss to factors largely beyond her control.

"I take responsibility for every decision I made, but that's not why I lost," Clinton stated.

The former first lady criticized the media coverage of her campaign as "unprecedented" and pointed to "weaponized information" from fake news sites as significant factors in her unsuccessful bid for the presidency. Clinton recounted instances where her warnings about Russian interference in the election were dismissed, and the media failed to cover the issue adequately.

"Over the summer, we went and told anyone we could find that the Russians were messing with the election, and we were basically shooed away," Clinton said. "We couldn't get the press to cover it."

Clinton also addressed the media's coverage of her private email scandal, stating, "They covered it like it was Pearl Harbor." She emphasized that the email controversy was one of the primary issues that affected her campaign, but she had no control over Russian interference.

Clinton further criticized social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter, stating that they have been "victimized by deliberate efforts to shape the conversation and push it towards conspiracies, lies, false information."

In her speech, Clinton admitted her imperfections as a candidate, stating, "I never said I was a perfect candidate, and I certainly have never said I ran perfect campaigns—but I do not know who is, or did." She acknowledged that there were things her campaign could have done differently but suggested that such reflections could be applied to any campaign.

Looking ahead, Clinton revealed that she is getting involved with political action organizations, including "Onward Together," which she founded this month. "I'm not going anywhere," she said. "I have a big stake in what's happening to this country."

Clinton's speech provided a rare glimpse into her thoughts on her election loss and her plans for the future, offering insights into the former secretary of state's reflections on her political career and her continued engagement in American politics.

Title: Google's Algorithm Prioritizes Relevance and Quality Over Political Ideology, but Inequalities in Media Resources Remain

Article:

In a recent statement, Google has emphasized its commitment to optimizing search results based on relevance and high-quality content, rather than political ideology. However, the question arises: what if relevance and quality are not evenly distributed across the media landscape?

To illustrate this point, let's consider some markers of relevance (timeliness, impact, keyword density) and quality (originality, sourcing, depth). Applying a ranking algorithm to the work of mainstream media, which includes major networks, newspapers, and digital sites that adhere to traditional journalistic values, would result in these outlets ranking higher due to their larger staffs, better-trained journalists, and deeper roots in the field.

For instance, The New York Times and The Washington Post, with their combined thousands of journalists, generated over a billion dollars in subscription revenue last year. In contrast, many right-wing outlets are embedded within advocacy groups, such as The Daily Signal from the Heritage Foundation, or are small blogs lacking the human resources for original reporting. Outlets like HotAir, which was cited by Bolyard, have only four editors (one of whom is pseudonymous), while The Blaze, another outlet mentioned by Bolyard, is reportedly down to fewer than 50 employees. The Weekly Standard, another right-wing media organization, appears to have an editorial staff of only 35.

Left-leaning outlets like Salon and DailyKos should not expect to compete with The New York Times in Google placement for similar reasons. Furthermore, some right-wing media organizations do not adhere to the standards of journalism as recognized by the mainstream media, peddling conspiracy theories or engaging in ethically questionable reporting practices.

Google's concept of relevance is caught in a loop between what people want and what they think it provides. Google sees pages as relevant if people engage with them, but people trust Google to serve up relevant content, so they engage with what Google shows them. Defining quality among journalism experts is challenging, and while some indicators of credibility have been laid out, Google has had a difficult time defining what journalistic value means in machine-readable terms.

While some things can be measured (e.g., the number of fresh quotes in a story from new sources, the number of links to other high-quality sites, the amount of time readers spend with a story, or the variety of readers engaging with a story), none of these indicators are foolproof measures of quality. The algorithm will rank many great stories poorly, and the system can, to a limited extent, be gamed. It's far from perfect.

In conclusion, while Google's commitment to prioritizing relevant and high-quality content is commendable, the inequalities in media resources and the challenges in defining and measuring quality remain significant issues in the digital age.

Title: Empowering Local Communities: A Guide to Investigating Local Police Departments and Advocating for Change

Article:

In the wake of ongoing protests against racism and police violence, many individuals are seeking ways to effect change in their local communities. While the focus is often on large cities, it's crucial to remember that every resident, regardless of location, can contribute to the cause. Here's a guide on how to investigate your local police department, educate yourself, and advocate for change.

Before diving in, it's essential to collaborate with local black-led activist groups. Avoid duplicating efforts and instead, learn about their initiatives and find out how you can support them.

If you aim to abolish, defund, or reform the police, gathering information and building support is crucial. An essential part of this process is shedding light on the actions of the police in your community.

Investigative reporter Andrew Ford, from ProPublica, offers insights into this process. While you don't need a job at a media outlet to start asking questions and making public records requests, Ford emphasizes the importance of understanding the laws and policies that govern police operations in your area.

To begin, ask your department for their policies on practices of concern, such as restraining suspects, the use of pepper spray, or Tasers. You may also need to request rules set by a county or state authority. Request written copies, and if necessary, file a formal public records request. If there is no existing written policy, this might be worth questioning.

Another crucial policy to investigate is the records retention policy. This information includes what records must be kept, and for how long. These may include police reports, use-of-force reports, 911 call recordings, and body camera footage.

The Reporters' Committee for Freedom of the Press provides a clickable map with body camera policies for many cities, and a list of state laws on 911 call recordings, to help you get started.

These tools will help you understand the actions of the police in your area. Don't forget to also check with your local government—the town council, perhaps—for information about how they spend their budget and how much of it goes toward policing. Then, gather with other residents, make a plan, and work together to make your town safer.

For those seeking ways to advocate for black lives, here's a list of resources to guide your efforts.

Title: U.S. Deploys F-22 Stealth Fighters to South Korea Amidst North Korea's War Threats

Article:

The United States has sent two F-22 stealth fighter jets to South Korea to participate in joint military exercises, following North Korea's declaration that the Korean Peninsula is in a "state of war." The Pentagon confirmed to Fox News that the F-22 Raptors were deployed to Osan Air Base in South Korea from Japan on Sunday, supporting ongoing U.S.-South Korean military drills.

According to Pentagon spokesman George Little, the exercise, known as Foal Eagle, is part of the air component of the ongoing drills. The Supreme People's Assembly of North Korea, led by Kim Jong Un, held its annual spring parliamentary session on Monday, following a ruling party declaration that nuclear bomb building and a stronger economy are the nation's top priorities.

North Korea's recent threats, including vows of nuclear strikes on South Korea and the U.S., have been a recurring theme in the lead-up to the session. In a statement released Sunday, U.S. military in South Korea urged North Korea to exercise restraint. "North Korea will achieve nothing by threats or provocations, which will only further isolate North Korea and undermine international efforts to ensure peace and stability in Northeast Asia," the statement said.

On Saturday, North Korea stated that its armed forces would strike U.S. bases in its mainland, as well as in Hawaii and Guam. Kim Jong Un also threatened to shut down the border factory complex, the last major symbol of inter-Korean cooperation, according to the Associated Press.

Analysts believe that North Korea's threats are part of an effort to provoke the new government in Seoul to change its policies toward Pyongyang and to secure diplomatic talks with Washington in order to receive more aid. The White House has stated that the U.S. is taking North Korea's threats seriously, but has also noted Pyongyang's history of "bellicose rhetoric."

On Thursday, U.S. military officials revealed that two B-2 stealth bombers dropped dummy munitions on an uninhabited South Korean island as part of annual defense drills that Pyongyang sees as rehearsals for invasion. Hours later, Kim ordered his generals to put rockets on standby and threatened to strike American targets if provoked.

Military analysts have stated that a full-scale conflict between North and South Korea is extremely unlikely, as the Korean Peninsula has remained in a technical state of war for 60 years. However, the North's continued threats toward South Korea and the United States have raised concerns that a misjudgment between the sides could lead to a clash.

In addition to the military exercise, the U.S. will strengthen its defenses against a potential North Korean missile attack by adding more than a dozen missile interceptors to the 26 already in place at Fort Greely, Alaska. Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel made the announcement.

Title: Apple Unveils Apple Pay, Apple Watch, and HealthKit Amid Privacy Concerns

Article:

In a move to redefine the market for 'wearables', Apple has launched new products focused on mobile payments and health and fitness, with an emphasis on security and privacy. The tech giant unveiled Apple Pay, a mobile payment system, and the long-awaited Apple Watch, which comes with a set of sensors for fitness tracking and heart rate monitoring.

Apple CEO Tim Cook introduced Apple Pay, a system that could potentially disrupt the credit card industry. The system allows users to complete transactions by holding their phone up to a retail sensor and using the Touch ID to authenticate the payment. Apple Pay uses Near Field Communications technology and Touch ID fingerprint identification to ensure secure transactions.

Following the introduction of Apple Pay, the company unveiled the Apple Watch, which comes in three styles and various colors. The device can detect heartbeats, set fitness goals, and reward users for achieving fitness milestones. Jony Ive, Apple's lead designer, said, "You can share something as personal as your own heartbeat."

The Apple Watch is part of Apple's strategy to redefine the market for 'wearables', devices that people use to track their fitness and health. The company sees potential for these devices to become an integral and profitable part of the U.S. health care system.

However, the introduction of Apple Watch and HealthKit, an application framework open to third-party developers, raises privacy concerns. With the HealthKit app, consumers can wear their health and fitness information on their sleeves with the new Apple Watch. Apple has implemented strict guidelines to address these concerns, including a ban on storing information in iCloud and a promise not to sell data to data brokers.

The launch of these new products comes a week after a website published nude celebrity photos from Apple phones, sparking concerns about privacy and security. Apple contends that its iCloud was not hacked, but rather thieves individually hacked victims' personal ID passwords.

Apple's focus on security and privacy is a response to growing consumer concerns about retail hacks and breaches. The company emphasizes that it does not store credit card numbers, collect any retail transaction information, or share data with anyone. Apple Pay is estimated to make about $12 billion a day and more than $4 trillion a year.

In the mHealth space, Apple is not the first player, but the company is aiming to be better than most. Morgan Reed, executive director of the Association for Competitive Technology, said, "eHealth is going to be huge; $2.7 trillion of the American economy is spent on health care and hundreds of billions on health IT, and Apple wants a piece of that."

Title: Ferguson Faces Unrest: Businesses Destroyed, Residents Arrested, and Mayor Criticizes State's Response

Article:

In the aftermath of the recent unrest in Ferguson, Missouri, business owner Rob Chabot expressed his dismay, stating, "They abandoned us completely." Chabot's Mobile Eye Care Solutions is located along South Florissant Road, the epicenter of the violence that erupted on Monday. Ferguson Mayor James Knowles III also voiced his criticism of the state's response, stating, "Unfortunately, as the unrest grew and further assistance was needed, the National Guard was not deployed in enough time to save all of our businesses."

According to police reports, there were 21 fires in and around Ferguson by Tuesday afternoon, at least 150 gunshots, and damage to 10 police cruisers. In some instances, firefighters were forced to retreat from battling fires due to gunfire and objects being thrown.

The law enforcement's response has been questioned, with some criticizing their approach as too tame, while others defend it as an attempt to allow protesters to demonstrate peacefully. St. Louis County Police Chief Jon Belmar and other officials defended their response, stating that they took steps to de-escalate the situation but that the magnitude of the violence was beyond their control.

Chief Belmar explained that the initial, hands-off tactics by the police were intended to allow protesters to demonstrate peacefully, but he admitted that the situation ultimately grew so unstable that it required a more forceful approach. He also acknowledged that despite months of preparation and training, and a buildup of manpower, equipment, and technology, he had not foreseen the chaos that ultimately unfolded.

Among the more than 60 people arrested on various charges including second-degree burglary and arson, most were Missouri residents, a shift, some here said, from the unrest of the summer. The ongoing investigation is expected to provide more insights into the causes and motivations behind the violence.

Title: FTC Issues Information Requests to Tech Giants Over Small Mergers Amid Antitrust Investigations

Article:

WASHINGTON - The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has issued special orders to five major tech companies - Alphabet Inc's Google unit, Amazon.com Inc, Apple Inc, Facebook Inc, and Microsoft Corp - to provide information on mergers that were too small to report to antitrust regulators, the FTC announced on Tuesday.

The requests come as the Justice Department, the FTC, state attorneys general, and the House Judiciary Committee are all investigating the big tech platforms for potential anti-competitive behavior. The tech companies are accused of using their market dominance to protect their market share or to expand into adjacent markets.

FTC Chairman Joe Simons declined to rule out an enforcement action based on the results of the study, stating, "All options are on the table." The tech giants did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

The agency asked for information about deals that were done between January 1, 2010, and December 31, 2019. The orders require each company to identify transactions that were too small to report to the FTC and the Department of Justice, which assess mergers to ensure they comply with antitrust law.

"The commission plans to use the information obtained in this study to examine trends in acquisitions and the structure of deals, including whether acquisitions not subject to (antitrust) notification might have raised competitive concerns," the statement said.

The tech industry has faced criticism from both political sides, with Republicans expressing concerns about the alleged suppression of conservative voices on social media and Democrats expressing concerns about increasing consolidation.

Senator Elizabeth Warren, a presidential candidate, has explicitly called for federal regulators to undo "ant-competitive mergers," including Amazon's purchases of Whole Foods and Zappos, Facebook's purchase of WhatsApp and Instagram, and Google's acquisitions of Waze, Nest, and DoubleClick.

Alphabet spent $1 billion on an unspecified number of small acquisitions in 2019, according to securities filings. Many of these acquisitions were companies working on artificial intelligence research and cloud computing services, areas in which Google is trying to innovate quickly and has sought to bolster hiring.

Apple has mostly made small deals valued at less than $500 million over the past decade, acquiring small companies working on key technologies such as augmented reality displays, camera sensors, and artificial intelligence software.

In fiscal 2019, Microsoft made 19 small acquisitions for a total of $1.6 billion, mostly in cash. Microsoft has sought to consolidate its position in the business software market, with major acquisitions such as the LinkedIn social network for business professionals and the code repository site GitHub. Since acquiring LinkedIn - which also fielded rival offers from Microsoft's competitor Salesforce Inc - Microsoft has begun integrating LinkedIn's social network data with Microsoft products such as its Outlook email program.

Title: US Vice President Reaffirms U.S. Commitment to Baltic States' Security Amidst Tense Relations with Russia

Article:

In a clear show of support, US Vice President Mike Pence has reiterated Washington's commitment to the security of the Baltic states during a visit to Estonia. Addressing Nato allies, Pence stated, "An attack on one of us is an attack on us all."

The remarks were made amidst growing tensions between the United States and Russia, following Moscow's decision to reduce the number of US diplomatic staff in retaliation for new US sanctions against Russia. The Baltic states - Estonia, Lithuania, and Latvia - have grown increasingly wary of Russia since it annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.

Pence's visit to Estonia follows President Donald Trump's reassurance of the US's commitment to the key Nato principle of mutual defense, which had been a subject of doubt after Trump did not mention it during his visit to Nato's Brussels headquarters in May. However, Trump re-committed the US to it during a Washington press conference in June and more symbolically at a speech in Poland in early July.

After meeting the presidents of all three Baltic states, Mr. Pence said, "The message of President Donald Trump to them was: 'We are with you.'" He further added, "Under President Donald Trump, the United States stands firmly behind our Article 5 pledge of mutual defense."

Russia is preparing to hold large-scale military exercises with its ally Belarus in the next month. The US Vice President's visit to the region comes as Moscow announced that 755 staff must leave US diplomatic missions in Russia, in retaliation over new sanctions imposed for Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014 and Russian interference in the US election.

Reacting to the move, Mr. Pence said, "We hope for better days, for better relations with Russia." He continued, "Recent diplomatic action taken by Moscow will not deter the commitment of the United States of America to our security, the security of our allies."

The US is currently holding its biggest ever joint military exercises with Georgia, a country which fought a war with Russia in 2008 and seeks to join Nato. Mr. Pence is scheduled to attend the drills in Georgia on Tuesday and will later go to Montenegro, Nato's newest member.

In Estonia, the US vice-president also warned that Moscow continued to "seek to redraw international borders by force, undermine democracies of sovereign nations and divide the free nations of Europe, one against another."

Title: US Actor Jussie Smollett Charged with Filing False Police Report in Alleged Hate Crime Incident

Article:

In a significant turn of events, US actor Jussie Smollett, known for his role in the television series Empire, has been charged with filing a false police report in connection with a reported hate crime incident that occurred in January.

Smollett, 36, had previously claimed he was the victim of a homophobic and racist attack in Chicago. However, police suspect that the actor may have paid two Nigerian brothers to stage the incident. The brothers, Ola and Abel Osundairo, are reportedly cooperating with the investigation.

The brothers, who are both acquainted with Smollett, were held for nearly 48 hours after they returned to the US last week. They were released without charges, but their testimony is said to have "shifted the trajectory of the investigation."

A lawyer for the brothers, Gloria Schmidt, stated, "They manned up and said: 'You know what? We're going to correct this.'"

On Wednesday, CBS Chicago obtained footage that appeared to show two individuals purchasing materials, including ski masks, that were allegedly used by Smollett's attackers.

Smollett turned himself in to Chicago police early on Thursday and is currently in custody. He faces felony charges for disorderly conduct and filing a false police report.

If found guilty, Smollett could face up to three years in prison and may be required to reimburse the police for the cost of their three-week-long investigation.

In a statement, Smollett's legal team said, "Like any other citizen, Mr. Smollett enjoys the presumption of innocence, particularly when there has been an investigation like this one where information, both true and false, has been repeatedly leaked."

Smollett had initially claimed that he was attacked late at night in downtown Chicago by two white men who hurled racial and homophobic insults at him. They allegedly assaulted him, poured a chemical substance on him, and put a rope around his neck. The attackers also reportedly said, "This is Maga country," apparently referring to President Donald Trump's "Make America Great Again" slogan.

The actor, who is gay, said he had been "forever changed" by the alleged incident. An outpouring of support followed, including from Oscar winner Viola Davis and supermodel Naomi Campbell.

Title: Coordinated Editorials Across 300 U.S. Newspapers Defend Freedom of the Press

Article:

In a historic show of unity, more than 300 newspapers across the United States ran editorials on Thursday, advocating for the importance of a free press and defending it against recent attacks. The coordinated effort was led by the Boston Globe, with participants ranging from large publications like the New York Times to small local newspapers with circulations as low as 4,000.

The Boston Globe's editorial board wrote, "The principle of a free press has protected journalists at home and served as a model for free nations abroad. Today it is under serious threat." The board cited a recent poll showing that 48 percent of Republicans and 29 percent of Americans overall agreed with President Trump that the news media is the enemy of the people. Forty-three percent of Republicans and 26 percent of Americans said the president should be able to close news outlets for bad behavior.

The Globe's editorial board went on to say, "To label the press 'the enemy of the people' is as un-American as it is dangerous to the civic compact we have shared for more than two centuries." The board emphasized the role of a free press in holding the powerful accountable and ensuring accurate information for citizens.

Newspapers across the country added their own perspectives to the discussion. The Chicago Tribune wrote, "A free press is the foundation of our democracy. It is the guardian of the people's right to know, the watchdog of the powerful, the voice of the voiceless and the conscience of the nation." The Dallas Morning News stated, "A free press is the cornerstone of our democracy, a beacon of truth in a world too often shrouded in darkness."

President Trump responded to the editorials on Twitter Thursday morning, stating, "The Fake News Media is the Opposition Party. It is very bad for our Great Country.... BUT WE ARE WINNING!" He also tweeted, "The Boston Globe, which was sold to the Failing New York Times for 1.3 BILLION DOLLARS (plus 800 million dollars in losses & investment), or 2.1 BILLION DOLLARS, was then sold by the Times for 1 DOLLAR. Now the Globe is in COLLUSION with other papers on free press. PROVE IT!"

The coordinated editorials serve as a reminder of the crucial role of a free press in a democratic society and the importance of upholding the principles of truth, transparency, and accountability.

Title: Americans Divided on Political Discourse, with Majority Viewing Trump as Negative Influence

Article:

A new survey has shed light on Americans' attitudes towards the tone and nature of political debate in the United States, with large majorities agreeing that the discourse has become more negative, less respectful, less fact-based, and less focused on issues. The survey, conducted this spring, found that 85% of U.S. adults believe political debate has become more negative and less respectful, while 76% say it has become less fact-based and 60% say it has become less focused on issues.

The survey also found that President Donald Trump is a major factor in people's views about the state of the nation's political discourse. A majority (55%) say Trump has changed the tone and nature of political debate for the worse, while fewer than half as many (24%) say he has changed it for the better. One-in-five Americans say he has had little impact.

The survey also found that Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents overwhelmingly (84%) say Trump has changed political discourse for the worse, while about half of Republicans and Republican leaners (49%) say he has changed it for the better. The survey also found that eight-in-ten or more Democrats say Trump's comments often or sometimes make them feel concerned, confused, embarrassed, exhausted, angry, insulted, and frightened. While Republicans are considerably less likely to report these negative reactions to Trump's rhetoric, about six-in-ten (59%) say they are at least sometimes concerned by his comments, while about half say they are at least sometimes confused (47%) or embarrassed (53%).

The survey also found that most Americans have strong feelings about what is acceptable for elected officials to say in political debate. Most agree that it is fine for an elected official to say their opponent is uninformed on the issues. However, 41% say it is never acceptable to say their opponent is anti-American, and another 31% say this is rarely acceptable. Among Republicans, just 25% say it is never acceptable to accuse an opponent of being anti-American, while 53% of Democrats say this is out of bounds.

The survey also found that Americans broadly agree that elected officials should avoid using heated language because it could encourage violence. Nearly three-quarters of Americans (73%) say this, while just a quarter believe that elected officials "should be able to use heated language to express themselves without worrying about whether some people may act on what they say."

The survey also found that while majorities in both parties say officials should avoid heated language, this view is more widely held among Democrats (83%) than Republicans (61%). Republicans believe that the national climate for political discourse is more hospitable to Democrats than for the GOP. Nearly two-thirds of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (64%) think that "Democrats in this country are very comfortable to freely and openly express their political views," but only about a quarter (26%) think Republicans around the nation experience that same level of comfort.

The survey also found that most Americans say there is not consensus in the public on what constitutes racist or sexist language. About six-in-ten Americans (61%) say people generally don't agree about what is considered to be racist language, while 38% believe that people do agree on this. Views about agreement over sexist language are roughly the same.

The survey also found that about two-thirds (65%) of Republicans and Republican leaners say people generally do not agree over the definition of racist language; 58% of Democrats and Democratic leaners say the same. Black people are somewhat more likely than whites and Hispanics to say people agree about what is considered racist language, although blacks, whites, and Hispanics are all more likely to say people do not agree on what kind of language is racist than to say that there is broad agreement.

Title: Trump's Trade War Escalation: A Closer Look at the Economic Impact and Misinformation

Article:

In escalating his trade war, President Donald Trump persists in his argument that tariffs are a pure win for the U.S. and a loss for China. However, a new study by economists from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Columbia University, and Princeton University reveals that the costs of tariffs are being borne by Americans.

Trump has vowed to impose a blanket tariff of 25% on everything Americans buy from China. This would mean raising tariffs from 10% on $200 billion worth of goods by the end of the week and hitting an additional $325 billion in Chinese products with the same penalty "shortly."

In a tweet on Sunday, Trump stated, "For 10 months, China has been paying Tariffs to the USA of 25% on 50 Billion Dollars of High Tech, and 10% on 200 Billion Dollars of other goods. These payments are partially responsible for our great economic results."

However, this notion of a transfer of wealth from China to the U.S. isn't happening. The burden of Trump's tariffs on imports from China and other countries falls entirely on U.S. consumers and businesses that buy imports. By the end of last year, the study found, the public and U.S. companies were paying $3 billion a month in higher taxes and absorbing $1.4 billion a month in lost efficiency.

Money from tariffs is going into the federal treasury, but it's mostly, if not entirely, coming from U.S. businesses and consumers, not China. It's not a driver of economic growth but rather a risk to it. That's why the stock market dropped Monday.

A coalition of U.S. trade organizations representing retail businesses, tech, manufacturing, and agriculture sharply disputed Trump's statement. "For 10 months, Americans have been paying the full cost of the trade war, not China," it said. "To be clear, tariffs are taxes that Americans pay, and this sudden increase with little notice will only punish U.S. farmers, businesses, and consumers."

Trump invariably describes the U.S. trade deficit as money "lost" to other countries, an equation that ignores the value to Americans of what they've bought. He's now making the converse case that a tax on imports, paid by Americans, somehow enriches them.

In another tweet on Monday, Trump claimed, "Puerto Rico has been given more money by Congress for Hurricane Disaster Relief, 91 Billion Dollars, than any State in the history of the U.S." However, this statement is not true. The money that Congress has allocated to Puerto Rico for hurricane relief so far is nowhere close to $91 billion.

According to the White House, Trump's $91 billion estimate includes about $50 billion in expected future disaster disbursements that could span decades, along with $41 billion already approved. Actual aid to Puerto Rico has flowed more slowly from federal coffers, about $11 billion so far. The expected $50 billion in additional money is speculative, based on Puerto Rico's eligibility for federal emergency disaster funds for years ahead, involving calamities that haven't happened.

The White House's $91 billion figure for Puerto Rico, even if correct, would not be the most ever provided for hurricane rebuilding efforts. Hurricane Katrina in 2005 cost the U.S. government more than $120 billion—the bulk of it going to Louisiana.

Title: Christie Vows Cooperation in State of the State Address Amid Ongoing Scandal Investigation

Article:

In his annual State of the State address, New Jersey Governor Chris Christie pledged cooperation with all inquiries into the ongoing scandal surrounding the alleged political retribution involving the George Washington Bridge controversy. The speech, which usually receives little attention outside the state, took on national interest due to the ongoing investigations into the use of Superstorm Sandy relief funds and the alleged orchestration of traffic gridlock near the country's busiest bridge.

For a governor known for his assertive leadership style, Christie adopted a conciliatory tone in his speech, emphasizing bipartisan efforts and working together. He sought to refocus the political focus away from the bridge controversy by citing the successes of his first term and calling for cooperation from the Democratic-led state Assembly and Senate.

Christie acknowledged the controversy in his opening remarks, accepting ultimate responsibility while reiterating that he was unaware of the alleged actions. "Mistakes were clearly made, and as a result, we let down the people we are entrusted to serve," Christie told state legislators gathered in Trenton for the speech.

The governor's administration will cooperate "with all appropriate inquiries" into the controversy to "ensure this breach of trust does not happen again," Christie said. He then shifted the focus away from the issue, stating that the scandal "does not define us or our state" and will not delay "the work that needs to be done to improve the people's lives in New Jersey."

Instead, Christie emphasized economic successes of his first term and called for cooperation from the Democratic-led state Assembly and Senate. In a span of 10 paragraphs, he used the word "we" 17 times in describing specific achievements such as job creation and economic growth.

Outlining a conservative agenda of no additional taxes and more law enforcement, the recently re-elected governor also proposed education reforms and programs to help drug offenders rejoin society. The most emotional moment came when Christie told the story of Craig Hanlon, a former drug addict from his hometown now working as a practicing attorney. Hanlon, who was seated near the front, stood up and hugged the governor to a lengthy ovation.

By tradition, legislators stood and applauded when Christie arrived, and he received repeated ovations when citing accomplishments of his first term and outlining new proposals. However, the bridge controversy remains prominent for the early frontrunner for the Republican presidential nomination in 2016.

Last week, the New Jersey State Assembly committee investigating the matter made public more than 2,000 pages of documents suggesting politics was behind the unannounced lane closures on the New Jersey side of the bridge last September that caused traffic gridlock in Fort Lee. The documents suggest that top Christie aides orchestrated the traffic mess to punish that town's mayor for not endorsing their boss, and that they allegedly tried to stonewall media inquiries into the matter.

Christie has fired one top adviser for her apparent role in the scandal, and other key advisers have left their jobs. He has repeatedly apologized for being "blindsided" by what his aides and appointees were doing.

After Christie's reference to the controversy in Tuesday's speech, a top Democrat in the New Jersey legislature who heads an investigating panel rejected the governor's insistence he knew nothing about the lane closures. "I find that a little hard to believe," Assemblyman John Wisniewski told CNN.

Wisniewski described relations between New Jersey Democrats and Christie as "very difficult," saying the governor "set lines in the sand" and "said it's my way or the highway." "Bipartisan means both sides give. That's not how this governor operates," Wisniewski said.

Meanwhile, the assembly's GOP leader said he believed that Christie knew nothing about what happened. "If a governor lies about what he knows, that's troublesome. That did not happen here," Jon Bramnick said.

Federal officials are also looking at whether Christie improperly used Superstorm Sandy relief funds to produce tourism ads promoting the Jersey shore's recovery that starred him and his family. In the new inquiry, federal auditors will examine New Jersey's use of $25 million of the funds for the marketing campaign, New Jersey Democratic Rep. Frank Pallone told CNN.

In a statement on Monday, Christie's office said the "Stronger than the Storm" campaign was part of an "action plan" approved by the Obama administration and developed with the goal of showing that the New Jersey shore was open for business just several months after the storm that devastated parts of the mid-Atlantic in October 2012.

A separate statement Tuesday by the federal Housing and Urban Development agency described the probe as a routine audit "and not an investigation of the procurement process." While political observers say the bridge scandal is not good for Christie, the Sandy investigation has the potential to be much more damaging to his national image since it was his signature achievement following the storm.

On Tuesday, Christie did not specifically mention that audit by the HUD inspector general, a watchdog over federal spending. In what might have been an ironic reference to Sandy funding, Christie praised the cooperative spirit in the state that helped its recovery from the storm, seeming to describe his own challenges now. "Let that spirit of Sandy be a powerful lesson to all of us, that when times are most difficult, cooperation and progress are possible," Christie said. "Indeed, I tell you, they're necessary."

Title: North Korea's Kim Jong Un Emerges from Seclusion, Sparks New Mystery over Cane Use

Article:

North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has reappeared in public after a six-week absence, quelling rumors of his ill health, deposition, or worse. However, a new enigma has surfaced: the reason for the cane.

In images released by state media on Tuesday, Kim, last seen at a Sept. 3 concert, was seen smiling broadly and leaning on a walking stick while touring the newly built Wisong Scientists Residential District and another new institute in Pyongyang, part of his regular "field guidance" tours. The North did not disclose the exact date of the visit or address Kim's health.

The appearance of Kim allows the country's extensive propaganda machinery to continue its primary function—glorifying the third generation of Kim family rule. It also temporarily suppresses rumors of a coup and serious health issues.

Before Tuesday, Kim missed several significant events he typically attends, and he was described in an official documentary last month as experiencing "discomfort." Archive footage from August showed him overweight and limping, leading South Korean media to speculate that he underwent ankle surgery. Some experts suggested he was suffering from gout or diabetes.

A South Korean analyst stated that Kim likely broke his media silence to dispel external speculation about his control and to evoke sympathy from the domestic audience by portraying a leader who works through pain. The appearance may be a form of "emotional politics meant to appeal to the North Korean people's sympathy," said Cheong Seong-chang, at the private Sejong Institute in South Korea.

It is the first time a North Korean leader has been seen relying on a cane or crutch, South Korean officials said. Kim's father, Kim Jong Il, who reportedly suffered a stroke in 2008 before dying of a heart attack in late 2011, was seen limping but never with a walking stick, nor was the country's founder and Kim Jong Un's grandfather, Kim Il Sung, said Lim Byeong Cheol, a spokesman from Seoul's Unification Ministry.

Cheong noted that Kim appeared in the recently released images to have lost about 22 pounds compared to pictures from May. He speculated that since Kim was holding a cane on his left side, he may have had surgery on his left ankle.

Kim "appears to want to show people that he's doing fine, though he's indeed still having some discomfort," Cheong said. The South Korean government has consistently seen no indications of major problems.

In deciding to resume his public activity before fully recovering from his condition, Kim aimed to swiftly quell rumors that his health problems were severe enough to jeopardize his position as North Korean leader, said Lim, the government spokesman.

"The cane aside, he looked to be in good health," Lim said.

Bruce Cumings, an expert on Korea at the University of Chicago, stated in an email that Kim's recent absence was, in part, "probably an attention-getting device—and it certainly works."

"The North has been on a diplomatic offensive in Europe and elsewhere, it feels isolated—and is, if we're talking about relations with Washington—all this puts them back on the front page," Cumings wrote.

Title: Romney Proposes "Choose-Your-Own-Deduction" Tax Reform Plan Ahead of First Presidential Debate

Article:

In the run-up to the first presidential debate between Mitt Romney and President Obama, the Republican nominee has begun to outline specifics for his tax reform plan, which he describes as a "choose-your-own-deduction" approach. In an interview with Fox Denver affiliate KDVR, Romney detailed his plan, aiming to counter the Obama campaign's argument that he is withholding details of his tax-cutting strategy while maintaining deficit neutrality.

Romney suggested that taxpayers could select the deductions they wish to claim, with a $17,000 cap on the total amount. He explained, "As an option, you could say everybody's going to get up to a $17,000 deduction; and you could use your charitable deduction, your home mortgage deduction, or others—your health care deduction, and you can fill that bucket, if you will, that $17,000 bucket that way."

Romney added that higher-income individuals might have a lower cap. A Romney campaign aide later clarified that the $17,000 cap could change, and that the tax rate cut could be offset by imposing a dollar cap on personal exemptions and reducing health care tax preferences.

The exact cost of the 20% tax rate cut remains undisclosed by the Romney campaign, but a source familiar with deficit-reduction discussions on Capitol Hill suggested it could amount to up to $1.7 trillion over ten years. A Romney campaign aide described this figure as "possible."

Romney spokesman Kevin Madden stated that the ideas for offsetting the tax rate cut are merely suggestions that may be considered during negotiations with Congress. Romney may present his "bucket" list proposal during Wednesday night's debate in Denver.

The Obama campaign has criticized Romney for withholding details of his tax-cutting plan, stating, "Romney has never explained how he would pay for his massive new tax cut for the wealthiest." Stephanie Cutter, Obama's deputy campaign manager, released a memo Wednesday morning, asserting, "Romney won't name which deductions he'll eliminate, asking voters to trust that he'll work it out with Congress after the election."

Both campaigns have managed expectations for the debate, with Obama's advisers claiming Romney has practice from the primary season, while Romney's advisers note that Obama is the only one on stage with general election debate experience.

The debate, one of three this month, is a significant opportunity for both candidates, as a well-phrased response could boost their standing in the polls, while an awkward moment could have the opposite effect. Romney, who is competitive with Obama in national polls but has been slipping in key battleground states, may particularly benefit from the debate.

Cutter attempted to preempt several potential arguments by Romney in her lengthy memo Wednesday morning. "For the next four years, President Obama has laid out real and achievable goals, and a specific path to get there, restoring middle-class security and creating jobs and long-term economic growth," she wrote. "Mitt Romney comes to this debate in a different position. He does not have any specific plans to move us forward—only tired repeats that will take us back."

The debate, which will be broadcast at 9 p.m. EDT, is expected to offer a blend of choreography and spontaneity, with both candidates having spent hours rehearsing with proxy opponents while knowing to expect the unexpected. The debate will cover topics related to the economy, health care, the role of government, and governing. The next debates are scheduled for October 16 and October 22, with the lone vice presidential debate taking place on October 11.

Title: Facebook Announces Overhaul of Privacy Tools in Response to Criticism and New Regulations

Article:

Facebook, the social media giant, has announced a significant overhaul of its privacy tools in response to intense criticism following the Cambridge Analytica data scandal and in compliance with new EU regulations. The revamp aims to make it easier for users to find and edit the personal information the company holds.

In a blog post, Facebook's chief privacy officer, Erin Egan, acknowledged the damage caused by the Cambridge Analytica revelations and emphasized the need for improved privacy settings and user understanding of how Facebook works and the choices they have over their data.

The changes include a "simplified" settings menu, a new privacy shortcuts menu, and revised data download and edit tools. The new settings menu aims to make it clearer what each control involves by regrouping the controls and adding descriptions. The privacy shortcuts menu consolidates the most critical controls into a single place, making it faster for users to review their posts, limit ad targeting, and other actions.

The revised data download and edit tools offer a new page called "Access Your Information," allowing users to review past interactions with the site, including "likes" and comments, with the option to make deletions. Users will also be able to download specific categories of data, such as photos, from a selected time range, rather than a single large file.

Although not mentioned in the blog, the BBC understands Facebook also intends to make the link to fully delete an account more prominent. The changes are set to take effect before the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which comes into force on 25 May, tightening data handling requirements and imposing harsher penalties for breaches.

Facebook insists the move to give people greater visibility of their privacy settings and an easier way to delete data has been in the works for months, but the company acknowledges the urgency of the situation. "Facebook recognizes it's clearly lost people's trust and it needs to get to work on regaining that," said Stephen Deadman, Facebook's global deputy chief privacy officer.

However, the question remains whether Facebook should be more proactive in warning users about the data they are sharing, such as sending alerts to those who are likely unaware that their phone contacts are still being uploaded to the company. The revamped system, while a step towards greater transparency and control, may still require more nudging for busy users to take back control of their privacy settings.

The announcement comes amidst a fresh dispute with New Zealand's privacy watchdog, which has accused Facebook of being in breach of local laws. The social media company has been criticized for refusing to provide data about a dispute involving one of its citizens, prompting the privacy commissioner's statement. Facebook has responded, expressing disappointment with the commissioner's request for access to private data belonging to several people and criticizing the privacy commissioner for criticizing the company's efforts to protect user privacy.

Title: U.S. Supreme Court Upholds Texas Abortion Restrictions, Sparking Controversy

Article:

In a 5-4 vote, the U.S. Supreme Court has declined to block controversial Texas abortion restrictions, allowing key parts of the law to remain in effect while a lawsuit challenging the restrictions moves forward. The decision has led a dozen abortion clinics in Texas to cease performing the procedure.

The four liberal justices who voted in favor of a request by Planned Parenthood to block the ruling by the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals expressed their dissent, stating they would have overturned the appeals court's Oct. 31 ruling that allowed the law to take effect.

The Texas abortion law, which has been deemed some of the strictest in the country, includes provisions requiring doctors to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital. This requirement, according to the appeals court, may increase the cost of accessing an abortion provider and decrease the number of physicians available to perform abortions.

However, the appeals court panel maintained that the U.S. Supreme Court has held that having "the incidental effect of making it more difficult or more expensive to procure an abortion can not be enough to invalidate" a law that serves a valid purpose, one not designed to strike at the right itself.

The Texas Attorney General's Office expressed satisfaction with the Supreme Court's ruling, stating that the regulations further the state's interest in protecting the health and safety of Texas women. Republican Texas Gov. Rick Perry also expressed approval, stating that the decision would better protect women from "shoddy abortion providers operating in dangerous conditions."

The appeals court panel left in place a portion of a previous judge's order that prevents the state from enforcing the U.S. Food and Drug Administration protocol for abortion-inducing drugs in cases where the woman is between 50 and 63 days into her pregnancy. The appeals court's order is temporary until it can hold a complete hearing, likely in January.

The restrictions gained notoriety when Democratic state Sen. Wendy Davis launched a nearly 13-hour filibuster against them in June. The law also bans abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy and beginning in October 2014 requires doctors to perform all abortions in surgical facilities.

During the trial, officials for one chain of abortion clinics testified that they've tried to obtain admitting privileges for their doctors at 32 hospitals, but so far only 15 accepted applications and none have announced a decision. Hospitals with religious affiliations and those fearing protests are among those that have declined to grant privileges. Many have requirements that doctors live within a certain radius of the facility or perform a minimum number of surgeries a year that must be performed in a hospital.

Fox News' Shannon Bream and The Associated Press contributed to this report.

Title: China's COVID-19 Statistics: A Closer Look at Transparency and Accuracy

Article:

As the global COVID-19 pandemic continues to spread, the number of confirmed cases in China, the epicenter of the outbreak, has significantly decreased. However, the official figures reported by the Chinese government have been met with skepticism due to the country's history of secrecy and cover-ups.

The National Health Commission of the People's Republic of China, responsible for tracking statistics during the crisis, has been publishing daily updates since late January. Initially, the number of confirmed cases of the COVID-19 virus skyrocketed, with the commission reporting 1,287 cases on January 25, which increased to 17,205 in just over a week. At that point, the commission reported that 189,583 people had been identified as having had close contact with infected patients.

The commission also acknowledged on January 26 that "More than 5 million people have left Wuhan due to the Spring Festival and epidemic." Given the timing and the scale of the annual festival, which typically generates nearly 3 billion trips, the "epidemic" was poised to sweep the nation of 1.3 billion people.

However, against all odds, the National Health Commission of China reported no new domestically acquired cases, attributing every new case as "imported" by those returning to China. Over the last half of March, despite the massive dispersion of Chinese citizens from the epicenter of the virus, Wuhan, the commission has reported barely one new domestically acquired case per day.

Despite compelling reasons for incredulity at China's official figures, the United Nations published an article titled "China shows COVID-19 Coronavirus can be ‘ stopped in its tracks.' " The article is based on an interview with a "WHO Representative in the country, Dr. Gauden Galea."

Dr. Galea has been in Beijing during the course of China's battle with COVID-19, except for a quick trip to Wuhan on January 21-22 before the city was even locked down, and the outbreak was still muted. The U.N. article goes on to say, "At the time, there was no overwhelming demand on the health services, though the situation had changed when Chinese and international health experts conducted a joint mission a month later."

Various media organizations have similarly relied on China's numbers for some pretty dramatic headlines. On March 18, The New York Times declared, "China Hits a Coronavirus Milestone: No New Local Infections." While the article notes in passing that Chinese "officials initially concealed and mismanaged the outbreak," it goes on to flatly assert that "Beijing’s sledgehammer approach... worked to quickly lower the number of infections."

Eight days later, the Times, again based on China's "confirmed" numbers, told the world that, "The U.S. Now Leads the World in Confirmed Coronavirus Cases." While the article says that "The Times is engaged in a comprehensive effort to track the details of every confirmed case in the United States, collecting information from federal, state, and local officials," apparently, the Times applied considerably less rigor to acquire information on China.

On Monday, however, came news that China's numbers have indeed been incomplete. The Wall Street Journal reported that "China said more than 1,500 people who were infected with the virus but haven’t shown symptoms weren’t included in its national tally of confirmed cases." This change so late in China's experience with the virus raises further questions about China's transparency, especially in light of some of the drastic measures the Communist government took early on to hush up the extent and seriousness of the epidemic.

In light of these developments, it is crucial for the media and international health authorities to view any data coming out of China with a more skeptical eye, as the past indicates that the Chinese government will continue to hide the true consequences of the COVID-19 outbreak in that country as best it can.

Title: Four U.S. Governors Express Opposition to Recreational Marijuana Legalization

Article:

In a discussion on CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday, four governors - two Republicans and two Democrats - expressed their opposition to the legalization of recreational marijuana, stating that their respective states would not be following the examples set by Colorado and Washington.

Texas Governor Rick Perry, a Republican who is considering a 2016 presidential bid, was the first to voice his opposition, stating a firm "no." Perry, who has previously advocated for lowering penalties for marijuana use, believes that current policies in Texas have helped decrease the state's prison population.

"The idea that a kid has one marijuana cigarette and you send him to prison, where they can learn to really be a hardened criminal, is not thoughtful public policy," Perry told CNN's chief political correspondent, Candy Crowley.

Indiana Governor Mike Pence, another potential White House candidate, also expressed his opposition to legalization. Pence, a Republican who took office last year, stated, "That's been my position for a long time and will continue to be."

Democratic Governor Dan Malloy of Connecticut said his state has decriminalized small amounts of marijuana and has moved forward with medical marijuana, but he believes that this is the extent of their marijuana policy. "They are two distinct issues," Malloy said. "Let's not be enticed on that road because of money. It just does not make sense."

Colorado has seen a surge in tax revenues from marijuana sales, but Malloy cautioned against using taxes as an incentive for legalization.

Missouri Governor Jay Nixon, a Democrat, also indicated that his state was not heading towards pot legalization but acknowledged that some in his state are starting to open up about medical marijuana. "I think our legislature might consider that, but I think to move beyond that at this point is a bridge too far," Nixon said. "That bridge has not yet been built."

The discussion on marijuana legalization is ongoing, and the positions of these governors highlight the complexities and nuances of the issue as it continues to evolve in the United States.

Title: Obama's Off-Record Remarks on Hispanic Vote and Grand Bargain Promises Spark Controversy

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, President Barack Obama's off-the-cuff remarks during a previously off-record interview with the Des Moines Register's editorial board have stirred controversy, with the President suggesting that his re-election chances hinge on the Republican Party's perceived alienation of the Hispanic community.

During a 30-minute conversation, Obama made two pledges for a second term, expressing confidence that Washington could strike a "grand bargain" on deficit reduction and immigration reform in the coming year. He also took a swing at the Republican Party on the latter issue, stating that the Republican nominee and the party have "alienated" the fastest-growing demographic group in the country, the Latino community.

The Romney campaign responded by casting doubt on the President's editorial board comments, pointing to Obama's failure to pass comprehensive immigration reform despite promises made in 2008. Spokesman Alberto Martinez stated, "It's a fascinating glimpse into how President Obama has taken the Hispanic community for granted for the past four years."

The rest of the Des Moines Register interview focused on policy matters, with Obama discussing his plans for the economy, education, and energy development, while vigorously defending his term to date. The President also defended the health care bill as a measure aimed at treating the economy.

The transcript of the interview was published after editor Rick Green revealed that the White House had demanded the conversation be kept off the record. Green stated that the White House did not provide a reason for the "unusual condition" of the call. Following the complaint, campaign officials released a transcript to the newspaper, which it then published.

Campaign spokeswoman Jen Psaki offered a brief explanation for the move, stating that the call was meant to be a personal check-in with the publisher and editor, and that the specifics of the conversation could not be shared because it was off the record.

Green had written that, after the off-record conditions were initially made, the newspaper "immediately lobbied his campaign staff in Des Moines for a formal, on-the-record call," but was told the decision "came from the White House."

Green noted that Mitt Romney met with the editorial board "literally" in a barn in Iowa on Oct. 9, and the audio from that conversation was posted online. Green stated that the initial snub would not impact the newspaper's decision on an endorsement, writing, "That would be petty and ridiculous. We take far too seriously what's at stake this election and what our endorsement should say."

Title: U.S. Job Growth Slows in May, Suggesting Labor Market Losing Momentum

Article:

WASHINGTON - The U.S. job market showed signs of slowing down in May, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 138,000, according to the latest Labor Department report. The employment gains in the prior two months were revised down, indicating a potential weakening of the labor market despite the unemployment rate falling to a 16-year low of 4.3 percent.

The report revealed that the manufacturing, government, and retail sectors lost jobs last month. The economy created 66,000 fewer jobs than previously reported in March and April. The job gains for May could still be sufficient for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates at its June 13-14 policy meeting, as the economy needs to create 75,000 to 100,000 jobs per month to keep up with growth in the working-age population.

Economists at JPMorgan and California State University Channel Islands suggested that the labor market is tightening and the Federal Reserve will likely continue to raise interest rates. However, the details of the employment report were weak, with 429,000 people dropping out of the labor force and a drop in employment in the household survey.

Average hourly earnings rose 4 cents or 0.2 percent in May, leaving the year-on-year increase in wages at 2.5 percent. Job growth has decelerated from the 181,000 monthly average over the past 12 months as the labor market nears full employment.

Economists believe that companies might be holding off hiring due to political uncertainty in Washington, as the probability that President Donald Trump's economic agenda, including tax cuts and infrastructure spending, could be imperiled by political scandals.

The modest payrolls gain could temper expectations of a sharp acceleration in economic growth in the second quarter after gross domestic product increased at a tepid 1.2 percent annualized rate at the start of the year. While consumer spending picked up in April, the trade deficit widened 5.2 percent to $47.6 billion.

There was some good news in the employment report, with a broad measure of unemployment falling two-tenths of a percentage point to 8.4 percent, the lowest since November 2007. The spread between the jobless rate and this broad unemployment gauge was the smallest since early 2008. However, the labor force participation rate fell two-tenths of a percentage point to 62.7 percent.

Manufacturing employment fell by 1,000 jobs last month, with payrolls in the automobile sector dropping 1,500 amid declining sales.
