Construction payrolls rose 11,000 last month after decreasing by 1,000 jobs in April. Retail employment fell 6,100, declining for a fourth straight month, with department stores shedding 3,700 jobs. Nonstore retailers, including online merchants, hired 2,900 workers last month. Government employment decreased 9,000 last month, with state and local governments accounting for all the decrease.

Title: Indiana Primary: A Crucial Test for Ted Cruz as Trump Aims for Victory

Article:

In the ongoing race for the Republican presidential nomination, Tuesday's Indiana primary presents a significant challenge for Texas Senator Ted Cruz, who is seeking to halt Donald Trump's relentless march towards the nomination. With Indiana being one of the last opportunities for Cruz to alter the course of the race, his campaign has intensified its efforts in the state, securing the support of the state's governor and announcing retired technology executive Carly Fiorina as his running mate.

Despite these efforts, Cruz's aides have expressed pessimism ahead of Tuesday's voting, anticipating a less-than-stellar performance. However, Cruz remains resolute, stating, "I am in for the distance, as long as we have a viable path to victory."

Trump, on the other hand, has devoted more time to campaigning in Indiana than in most other states, underscoring his eagerness to put Cruz away and focus on Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton. While Trump cannot clinch the nomination with a big win in Indiana, a strong showing would make his path to the nomination significantly easier.

"Indiana is very important, because if I win that's the end of it. It would be over," Trump said during a campaign stop in Indianapolis.

The Republican primary race has defied expectations, with Trump, initially dismissed as little more than an entertainer, securing victories in every region of the country. This includes a string of six straight wins on the East Coast.

Meanwhile, in the Democratic primary, Clinton and Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders faced off in Indiana's primary on Tuesday. While the stakes are lower in the Democratic race, Clinton holds a commanding lead over Sanders, having secured 91 percent of the delegates she needs to win the nomination. This means she can still win the nomination even if she loses every remaining contest.

Sanders, who faces a difficult path to overtake Clinton, is focusing on convincing superdelegates to back him over the former secretary of state. Superdelegates are Democratic Party insiders who can support the candidate of their choice, regardless of how their states vote. They favor Clinton by a nearly 18-1 margin.

Neither Clinton nor Sanders planned to spend Tuesday in Indiana. Sanders was making stops in Kentucky, which holds a primary in mid-May, while Clinton moved on to Ohio, a key general election battleground.

As the race heats up, both Clinton's and Trump's teams are gearing up for the general election. Clinton's team has started deploying staff to states that will be crucial in November and is also raising money for the fall campaign. Trump, on the other hand, lags behind Clinton in general election preparations, despite hiring more staff to round out his slim team.

A showdown between Clinton and Trump would pit one of Democrats' most popular and highly-regarded figures against a first-time political candidate who is deeply divisive within his own party. Cruz and other Republicans have argued that Trump would be roundly defeated in the general election, denying their party the White House for a third straight term.

However, Trump is the only Republican left in the race who can secure the 1,237 delegates needed for the nomination through regular primary voting. Cruz, as well as Ohio Governor John Kasich, who trails significantly in the delegate count, must try to block Trump in Indiana and the handful of other remaining states to push the race toward a contested convention.

In an abrupt strategy shift, Cruz and Kasich announced an alliance of sorts in Indiana. The Ohio governor agreed to stop spending money in Indiana to give Cruz a chance to compete head-to-head with Trump. Cruz has pledged to do the same for Kasich in Oregon and New Mexico, which vote in the coming weeks.

However, this strategy, which appeared to unravel even as it was announced, may have backfired. A recent NBC News/Wall Street Journal/Marist poll found that nearly 6 in 10 Indiana primary voters disapproved of the Cruz-Kasich alliance.

"After they made the alliance, their numbers tanked," Trump said Monday. "That's what happens when politicians make deals."

Title: Dueling Reports on Benghazi Attacks Released Amidst Partisan Tensions

Article:

The release of two competing and contradictory reports on the 2012 attacks on a diplomatic outpost and CIA annex in Benghazi, Libya, has added to the ongoing controversy surrounding the incident. The attacks, which resulted in the death of four Americans, including U.S. Ambassador Chris Stevens, have been the subject of a two-year investigation by members of the House from both political parties.

The primary objective of the investigation has been to examine the actions of senior U.S. military and civilian officials, including then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, to determine if more could have been done to prevent the loss of life. The panel's five Democrats released their report on Monday, preceding the majority Republicans' findings, which were released on Tuesday.

In the Democratic report, the U.S. military and the former secretary of state are cleared of any wrongdoing. The report states that the U.S. military could not have done anything differently on the night of the attacks to save the lives of the four Americans who perished. The report also notes that the State Department's security measures were "woefully inadequate," but that Mrs. Clinton never personally turned down a request for additional security.

In contrast, the Republican report, led by House panel chairman Rep. Trey Gowdy of South Carolina, states that the U.S. was slow to send help to the Americans in Benghazi "because of an obsession with hurting the Libyans' feelings." The report also accuses the Obama administration of "misleading the public over the incident and failing to protect U.S. personnel."

The Republican report, obtained by The Topeka Capital-Journal, labels Benghazi as the "wild east" and criticizes Clinton for her role in the incident. The report also questions whether street protests precipitated the attacks, stating that a number of eyewitnesses remained in constant contact with Washington during the attack, but none of them mentioned a protest.

The reports could have political repercussions for presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Clinton, as the Benghazi investigation has already uncovered her use of a private email server to conduct government business, now the subject of an FBI investigation.

The White House and the investigating panel are also at odds regarding whether President Obama should answer questions already submitted by the panel for the president's consideration. The Democrats' report states that the cause of the attacks "remains unclear to this day," quoting testimony by David Petraeus, the former CIA director, who says, "To be candid with you, I am not sure that the amount of scrutiny spent on this has been in the least bit worth it."

Title: Obama Administration Issues Directive on Transgender Students' Bathroom Access in Schools

Article:

In a significant move, the Obama administration has issued a directive to public schools across the nation, clarifying the rights of transgender students to use bathrooms and locker rooms that correspond with their chosen gender identity. The directive, formulated by leaders in the Education and Justice Departments, is a clear indication of the administration's stance that gender identity is a civil rights issue.

The directive, which is in line with Title IX, a federal law that prohibits discrimination based on sex in education programs or activities that receive Federal financial assistance, requires schools to allow transgender students to use facilities that match their chosen gender identity, regardless of any discrepancies in their education records or identity documents.

"There is no room in our schools for discrimination of any kind, including discrimination against transgender students on the basis of their sex," said Attorney General Loretta Lynch in a statement accompanying the directive.

The directive does not require students to present a medical diagnosis for the change in gender identity. Schools are obligated to treat students according to their chosen gender identity.

The Human Rights Campaign, a civil rights organization for lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender individuals, commended the move. "This is a truly significant moment not only for transgender young people but for all young people, sending a message that every student deserves to be treated fairly and supported by their teachers and schools," said HRC President Chad Griffin in a statement.

The directive comes at a time when the definition of gender identity is a topic of societal debate, with some conservatives viewing gender as purely biological and set at birth, while many in the lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender community see gender identity as more fluid and personal. This debate has reached a peak this week in North Carolina, where the state is embroiled in a legal battle with the federal government over its so-called bathroom bill.

On Monday, the Justice Department sued North Carolina over its bathroom law, HB2, or the Public Facilities Privacy and Security Act, stating that the legislation is discriminatory. HB2 includes measures that prohibit public school students from using school facilities consistent with their chosen gender identity. The lawsuit advises the state to confirm it will not be moving ahead with the legislation.

"This action is about a great deal more than bathrooms, this is about the dignity and respect that we accord our fellow citizens," said Attorney General Lynch when announcing the federal lawsuit.

North Carolina responded with a countersuit, claiming that the state was given an unrealistic amount of time to comply with the federally-imposed compliance deadline.

Title: Virginia Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli Challenges Court Ruling on Virginia's Anti-Sodomy Law, Sparking Debate on Protecting Minors

Article:

In a move that has sparked debate and raised questions about the protection of minors, Virginia Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli has challenged a recent court ruling that found Virginia's "Crimes Against Nature" statute, which banned oral and anal sex, unconstitutional. The case in question involves a 47-year-old man, William Scott MacDonald, who was convicted of soliciting a minor to commit a felony.

A three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 4th Circuit ruled on March 12 that the statute violates the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. One judge dissented, agreeing with a lower court that the Supreme Court's ruling in Lawrence v. Texas on sodomy laws applied only to consenting adults.

Cuccinelli's office has filed a petition asking for the full 15-judge court to reconsider the panel's decision. LGBT advocates have expressed disappointment, saying the law is unconstitutional and anti-gay. However, Cuccinelli's spokeswoman, Caroline Gibson, stated that the case is not about sexual orientation but about protecting a 17-year-old girl from a 47-year-old sexual predator.

Cuccinelli's position in the case has been criticized by his opponent, former Democratic National Committee chairman Terry McAuliffe, who is running against Cuccinelli for the gubernatorial seat. McAuliffe's campaign has accused Cuccinelli of focusing on divisive issues rather than the economy.

Virginia's unemployment rate is 5.6 percent, and the state enjoys a substantial budget surplus thanks to the stewardship of Virginia's current governor, Bob McDonnell. McAuliffe and Virginia Democrats hope voters will ignore McDonnell's successful record of governance, which is why they are eager to harp on the culture wars, even when there is no basis for doing so.

The Cuccinelli campaign has responded to McAuliffe's criticisms, stating that the case is about prosecuting a 47-year-old man who solicited sexual acts from a 17-year-old girl. The campaign also noted that Cuccinelli was elected by Virginia's voters to be the chief law enforcement officer in the state and that his job entails duties, one of which is doing what it takes to protect high school girls from much older sexual suitors.

The debate over Cuccinelli's position in the case has sparked a national conversation about the protection of minors and the interpretation of sodomy laws. As the gubernatorial race heats up, it remains to be seen how the issue will impact the election and the public's perception of Cuccinelli's stance on social and criminal justice issues.

Title: President Obama Urges Optimism, Calls for Dialogue on Race Relations and Gun Violence in Wake of Dallas Shooting

Article:

In a press conference held in Warsaw, Poland, President Barack Obama called for optimism and dialogue on race relations in the United States following the fatal shootings of two black males by police and the subsequent shooting of five Dallas law-enforcement officials by a black Army veteran. The president emphasized that the actions of a few should not define the entire nation and that race relations have not regressed to the levels of the 1960s.

Obama reiterated his commitment to addressing the issue of race relations, stating that he has revived the task force formed after the shooting of unarmed black teen Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, two years ago. The task force will include police officers, community and civil rights activists, and others who will discuss next steps.

The president acknowledged the decrease in violent crime in the U.S. over the past five, ten, and fifteen years, but also emphasized the need to address gun violence. He called for stricter gun control measures, stating that it is important to make it harder for people to carry out their anger with weapons.

Obama also addressed the Dallas sniper, Micah Johnson, stating that he was a "demented individual" and that his actions do not represent the values of the American people. He declined to label the attack as a hate crime, stating that it is difficult to interpret the motives of mass shooters.

The president expressed sympathy for police officers in gun-filled communities, acknowledging the challenges they face in engaging with potentially armed individuals. He also emphasized the need to address the issue of gun violence in order to ensure the safety of both police officers and civilians.

In addition to discussing race relations and gun violence, Obama also addressed other global issues, including Brexit, ISIS, NATO, and the European Union. He called for a sensible and orderly process for Britain's exit from the EU and emphasized the importance of maintaining close friendships and commercial partnerships with both the UK and the EU.

Overall, President Obama's message was one of optimism, urging Americans to work together to address the challenges facing the nation, particularly in the areas of race relations and gun violence. He emphasized the need for dialogue and cooperation in order to build a better future for all Americans.

Title: Romney Outraises Obama in May Fundraising, Collecting $76.8 Million vs. $60 Million for Obama

In a significant development for the upcoming presidential election, Mitt Romney's campaign has surpassed President Barack Obama's fundraising efforts in May, collecting a total of $76.8 million, according to a statement from the Romney campaign. This figure represents a nearly $17 million advantage over Obama's $60 million, as announced by the president's campaign on Thursday.

The Republican fundraising haul, the first full month that Mr. Romney and the Republican National Committee were in partnership, nearly doubled the amount collected in the prior month. This substantial increase was followed by the Republican National Committee linking its operations and fundraising efforts with the Romney campaign.

"It is clear that people aren't willing to buy into 'hope & change' again," said Spencer Zwick, Mr. Romney's national finance chairman. "Voters are making an investment because they believe that it will benefit the country."

The Obama campaign and the Democratic National Committee ended May with $107 million in cash, according to the Romney campaign's statement. The Democrats' joint fundraising operation had raised $43.6 million in April, about the same amount as Mitt Romney raised that month.

Aides to Mr. Obama said they were not overly concerned about the fundraising gap, stating that some Republican donors likely gave the maximum they could in May and will not be able to give again in the coming months. However, the financial comparisons underscore the concern that Mr. Obama's campaign has expressed to supporters over the past several months about the need for stepped-up financial contributions.

Democrats have warned that despite the president's fundraising prowess, he could be outspent during the upcoming months as Mr. Romney's spending is supplemented by historic levels of fundraising by outside political groups, particularly "super PACs."

The Obama campaign's announcement comes two days after Republicans succeeded in beating back the recall of Scott Walker, the governor of Wisconsin, who had a significant lead over his opponent in campaign cash. Mr. Obama held a fundraiser with Hollywood celebrities, including George Clooney, in early May, just after he announced his support for same-sex marriage. The event reportedly raised $15 million for Mr. Obama's campaign.

The average donation for the Obama campaign was just over $50, according to the campaign's announcement. The $60 million includes money raised directly by his campaign and by the Democratic National Committee.

Title: Low Gas Prices: A Boon for Consumers, but a Potential Threat to Economic Stability

In recent weeks, gasoline prices have been on a steady decline, dropping to an average of approximately $3 per gallon. This downward trend has contributed to a minimal increase in the Consumer Price Index (CPI), with the index barely inching up 0.1 percent last month and a 12-month CPI rise of 1.7 percent.

However, some economists express concern that persistently low energy prices could lead to deflation, a phenomenon last seen during the Great Depression of the 1930s. Deflation, considered the nightmare scenario by economists, is characterized by a prolonged and severe fall in the general price level of goods and services.

To illustrate the potential consequences of deflation, imagine a factory owner who must purchase parts and raw materials, pay workers a certain wage, and repay loans. If prices start falling, the factory owner may struggle to afford loan repayments, meet contractual obligations with workers, or sell products at a profit, even as competitors slash their prices. This downward pressure creates a vicious cycle that can lead to a broad decline in the value of businesses, homes, and other investments.

The root cause of the current downward price pressure can be traced back to weak economic growth in both Europe and China. As consumers and companies in these regions cut their energy and goods purchases, global prices fall. Central bankers and policymakers worldwide are taking measures to stimulate growth and prevent further price declines.

In the United States, the Federal Reserve, which sets interest rates, aims to maintain a 2 percent inflation rate. Given the deflationary winds blowing from Europe, the Fed is likely to hold off on raising interest rates until the CPI shows a significant increase.

For most Americans, the current economic situation means that wages and prices are stagnant, while interest rates remain low. While the danger of deflation looms, the drop in energy prices has been a boon for consumers, who can now afford cheaper car loans and gasoline. This increased purchasing power could potentially stimulate the economy by boosting travel and consumer spending.

Many Americans are already reaping the benefits of lower gas prices. Macy Gould, a resident of Lexington, Kentucky, who graduated from college in May, was thrilled to refuel for about $2.83 a gallon over the weekend. "Spending less on gas is a real help to me," she said, expressing her relief at the lower costs.

In conclusion, while low gas prices have provided immediate relief for consumers, the potential threat of deflation remains a concern for economists. The Federal Reserve and policymakers worldwide are taking steps to prevent further price declines and maintain economic stability. For now, consumers can enjoy the benefits of lower gas prices, but it is essential to remain vigilant and adapt to the evolving economic landscape.

Title: President Obama Stands Firm on Debt Ceiling, Gun Control, and Cabinet Appointments

Article:

In a press conference on Monday, President Barack Obama reiterated his stance on the debt ceiling, gun control, and his cabinet appointments. The event, marking the end of his first term, focused primarily on these three key issues.

Regarding the debt ceiling, President Obama emphasized the necessity of increasing the limit to meet the country's financial obligations. He stated, "The issue here is whether Washington will pay its bills." He underscored the importance of upholding the nation's financial responsibility, stating, "We are not a deadbeat nation."

On the gun control issue, the president reaffirmed his commitment to curbing gun violence in the wake of the mass shooting at an elementary school in Newtown, Connecticut. He pledged, "If there is a step we can take that will save even one child from what happened in Newtown, we should take that step."

President Obama also addressed the ongoing debate about his cabinet appointments, particularly the criticism of his decision to appoint only men to his second-term cabinet. He responded, "Wait until my selections are complete before they rush to judgment."

The president's comments on the debt ceiling were met with contrasting views from Republican leaders. House Speaker John Boehner stated, "The American people do not support raising the debt ceiling without reducing government spending at the same time."

The debt limit debate, sequester, and a budget resolution are set to be revisited when Congress reconvenes later this month. These discussions are a result of the failure of Washington to reach a long-term solution to the country's debt and deficit issues following the November elections.

Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell urged Obama and his allies to address spending issues, stating, "The debt limit debate is the perfect time for it." McConnell also described the country's debt and deficit as a "huge, huge problem."

The president argued that he has already reduced federal spending by $1.2 trillion over the past two years and is open to further discussions about cuts, including potential reductions in Medicare. However, he maintained that raising the debt ceiling does not authorize more spending, but rather pays for bills that have already been incurred.

The debate over the debt ceiling, gun control, and cabinet appointments will continue to shape the political landscape in the coming weeks as the new Congress and administration work to address these critical issues.

Title: The Controversial Exclusion of CNN's Jim Acosta: A First Amendment Battle and a Symbiotic Relationship

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, CNN reporter Jim Acosta, who has been a frequent target of criticism from President Donald Trump and White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders, has been barred from White House grounds. This move, however, raises questions about the long-standing relationship between Acosta and the White House, as the two have regularly engaged in heated exchanges during press conferences over the past 22 months.

If Acosta's behavior was indeed offensive to the White House, one would expect Sanders and Trump to avoid calling on him during press conferences. Instead, they routinely sought his presence, counting on his tendency to speak extensively and dominate the microphone during question-and-answer sessions. The White House's apparent enjoyment of Acosta's theatrical style, despite their public displays of exasperation, suggests a symbiotic relationship, with Acosta serving as a public platform for their anti-press narrative and the White House using him as a punching bag.

The dramatic exchanges between Acosta and the White House have been beneficial for both parties. For those who appreciate reporters who lecture rather than ask questions and view White House briefings as a bloodsport, the Acosta-Trump clashes provide an engaging spectacle, making CNN a preferred cable news destination.

Acosta's forced exile and the subsequent lawsuit filed by CNN demanding the return of his "hard pass" have cast him as a free speech martyr. In the lawsuit, lawyer Theodore J. Boutrous, a prominent figure in the First Amendment bar, cites case law that appears to prevent the White House from arbitrarily banning reporters from White House press facilities "for less than compelling reasons." Even Fox News Channel's legal analyst Andrew Napolitano predicts a quick resolution in CNN's favor.

The initial reason given for Acosta's ban, that he had placed his hands on a White House intern during a press conference, has been disputed. Today, Sanders shifted her argument, accusing Acosta of not surrendering the microphone when approached by the intern. However, Sanders acknowledges that Acosta's resistance to yielding the floor was not a unique occurrence, leading to questions about the fairness of his sudden exclusion without a prior warning.

The daily White House briefings, under Trump's management, have become more about political theater than genuine news generation. The constant bickering between Sanders and the press corps and her obfuscations have overshadowed the journalistic purpose of the briefings. While they can provide valuable connections to hard-to-find facts and secure administration on-the-record statements, real news often requires relying on reporters like Maggie Haberman who spend little time in the daily briefings, waiting for news to emerge.

Like many episodes of The Trump Show, the martyrdom of Jim Acosta provides an entertaining sideshow. While Acosta may be more of a nuisance than a true newshawk, his return to the White House briefing room can be advocated for in good conscience, as being a nuisance is often part of the job. Moreover, Sanders and Trump seem to miss his presence.

Title: Fourth GOP Senator Opposes Trump's Nomination of Herman Cain for Federal Reserve, Potentially Jeopardizing Confirmation

Article:

WASHINGTON - The expected nomination of former pizza chain executive Herman Cain to the Federal Reserve appears to be in jeopardy after a fourth Republican senator voiced opposition, potentially denying Cain the support needed for confirmation in the post.

In a statement on Thursday, Senator Kevin Cramer stated, "If I had to vote today, I would vote no." If all of the Senate's Democrats and the two independents aligned with them were to vote against Cain, he would fall short of the majority support he needs.

According to ABC News, citing sources familiar with the matter, Cain is expected to withdraw his name from consideration in the coming days. Cain declined comment on the report.

Senators Mitt Romney, Lisa Murkowski, and Cory Gardner, all Republicans, have each reportedly said they would vote against Cain if he is nominated. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell withheld comment on Thursday on whether he would support Cain, saying he would wait to see "who is actually nominated."

Economists and critics have expressed concerns about loyalists of President Donald Trump serving on the traditionally nonpartisan central bank. Cain has been a public advocate of many of Trump's policies, as has Stephen Moore, another person Trump has said he wants to nominate. Neither nomination has been formally sent to the Senate.

On Facebook earlier this week, Cain said the reason he was under attack as a nominee was because he is a conservative. Cain's bid for president in 2012 was derailed by accusations of sexual harassment that he has repeatedly denied.

White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow said earlier on Thursday that Trump intended to proceed with his plan to name Cain to the Fed's board of governors.

"I like Herman Cain," Trump told reporters on Wednesday. "As to how he's doing in the process, that I don't know... Herman is a great guy, and I hope he does well."

The president nominates members to the Fed's seven-member board of governors. He elevated Jerome Powell to chairman a year ago but has frequently criticized him for the Fed's interest rate increases. The nominations must be approved by the Senate. The central bank's other top policymakers head the Fed's 12 regional banks and are chosen by local boards of directors, not the president.

Related Coverage:
- U.S. Senate leader McConnell notes Republican worries over Cain serving on Fed
- Trump has slammed the central bank's 2018 rate hikes for thwarting economic growth and publicly pressed policymakers to change course.
- Central bank independence from short-term politics is seen as important to prevent influence that could lead to runaway debt, hyperinflation, and financial instability. The issue is a topic of conversation at the meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank in Washington this week.
- "Undermining central bank independence would be dangerous," Tobias Adrian, director of the International Monetary Fund's monetary and capital markets department, said in an interview on Wednesday with Bloomberg News.

Title: Secretary of State John Kerry Advocates for Peaceful Resolution on Korean Peninsula, Amidst Escalating Tensions

Article:

Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Tokyo today, concluding the final leg of his Asia trip, with a focus on finding a peaceful resolution to the ongoing tensions on the Korean peninsula. The U.S. diplomat met with Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida, reiterating the Obama administration's commitment to a diplomatic approach, while expressing concerns about North Korean provocations in the region.

During the meeting, Kerry stated that the U.S. would not rule out direct talks with North Korea, but only under the condition that Pyongyang takes steps towards denuclearization and agrees to negotiate in a responsible manner. Kerry emphasized the potential for peace, stating, "We can find a way to resolve these differences at the negotiating table."

The visit to Japan comes as North Korea has increased its rhetoric towards Tokyo, with the regime singling out Japan as the potential first target in the event of a war on the Korean peninsula. In response, Japanese Foreign Minister Kishida stated that Japan is prepared for such contingencies, including potential missile launches, but will continue to pursue a "dialogue and pressure" policy.

Kerry's visit follows meetings with Chinese President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Keqiang, during which both parties reaffirmed their commitment to working towards the denuclearization of North Korea. In a joint statement, Kerry and Chinese State Councilor Yang Jiechi expressed concern over the current situation and agreed on the need for China to pressure North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and calm tensions on the peninsula.

In North Korea, celebrations for the 101st birthday of founder Kim Il Sung continued, with Pyongyang hosting an international marathon. However, the government has not ceased its threats towards the outside world, denouncing South Korean President Park Geun-hye's offer of dialogue as a "cunning ploy" and an "empty shell."

The ongoing U.S.-South Korea military exercises and the recent shutdown of the Kaesong Industrial Complex have further escalated tensions in the region. Analysts have speculated that North Korea may launch a mid-range Musudan missile before the April 15 celebration, while the whereabouts of North Korean leader Kim Jong-un have raised further concerns.

In an effort to defuse tensions, South Korean President Park Geun-hye offered peace through dialogue, a move welcomed by Kerry, who has repeatedly expressed his support for bilateral talks. Kerry stated, "I think she's shown great courage in her willingness to take [talks] in that direction, provided she has a willing partner."

As the situation on the Korean peninsula remains volatile, the international community continues to watch closely as diplomatic efforts are made to find a peaceful resolution to the ongoing tensions.

Title: U.S. Delegation to Sochi Winter Olympics Includes Openly Gay Athletes, High-Ranking Officials Absent

The United States will send a delegation to the upcoming Winter Olympics in Russia, but it will not include any members of President Barack Obama's family or active Cabinet secretaries. Instead, the delegation will feature openly gay athletes, including tennis legend Billie Jean King and figure skater Brian Boitano, who will attend the games' opening ceremonies on February 7.

The White House announced Tuesday that the delegation will also include former Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano, White House aide Rob Nabors, and the U.S. ambassador to Russia. Speed skaters Bonnie Blair and Eric Heiden, as well as openly gay hockey player Caitlin Cahow, will also attend the games.

The selection of this delegation is intended to send a message that the United States is a diverse nation, according to White House Press Secretary Jay Carney. This is the first time in more than a decade that the President, vice president, first lady, or former president has not attended an Olympic opening or closing ceremony.

The absence of high-ranking U.S. officials amounts to a snub to Russia, whose relationship with the United States has fractured over the past year. The admission of NSA leaker Edward Snowden, wanted on espionage charges in the United States, was granted temporary asylum in Moscow, and Russian President Vladimir Putin has used Russia's veto on the United Nations Security Council to block action in Syria.

Obama canceled a meeting with Putin that was scheduled for September, though the two met as part of a larger group of world leaders at the Group of 20 conference in St. Petersburg. Fueling the rift between the nations are new laws in Russia banning gay "propaganda" -- a law critics say is so vague that anyone can be prosecuted for wearing a rainbow T-shirt or holding hands in public with someone of the same sex.

Carney noted on Wednesday that the selection of gay athletes was not the first time Obama had voiced concern over the Russian policy. "That's not a message we would wait to send through this manner," Carney said. "We have been very clear -- the President has been very clear that he finds it offensive, the anti-LGBT legislation in Russia."

Obama told Jay Leno in August that he had "no patience for countries that try to treat gays or lesbians or transgender persons in ways that intimidate them or are harmful to them," and during his visit to Russia earlier this year, Obama met with the leaders of Russian social activist groups.

Title: Governors Grapple with Health Care Decisions as Supreme Court Ruling Leaves Questions Unanswered

Article:

As governors from across the nation convened in Williamsburg, Virginia, this weekend, health care was a primary focus of their discussions. With the Supreme Court's recent decision on the federal health law, states now have new options regarding the expansion of their Medicaid programs.

Republican governors, in particular, expressed surprise by the Supreme Court's ruling, which declared the health law constitutional but allowed states to opt out of significantly expanding their Medicaid programs for individuals earning more than approximately $15,000 per year.

"A lot of us, certainly on the Republican side, believed it would be found unconstitutional," said Utah Gov. Gary Herbert. "So I think it's just added more confusion to the issue rather than settling the issue." He added that the November election would likely provide more clarity on the implications moving forward.

Virginia Gov. Bob McDonnell, the meeting's host, declined to reveal his state's plans for Medicaid expansion, citing the need for more information. "I don't think it's responsible for my state to make a decision now because there's still more information we need," he said.

Democratic governors, on the other hand, generally favor Medicaid expansion. Delaware's Jack Markell, the incoming chairman of the National Governors Association, argued that the decision is a financial analysis rather than a political one. "This is not political. This is a financial analysis of what does it mean to cover, in our case, an additional 30,000 people," he said, emphasizing that the expansion would be a good deal for Delaware taxpayers.

While Republicans view the Supreme Court decision as adding confusion, Democrats, like Maryland's Martin O'Malley, believe it should have ended the debate. "I think most governors understand that the Supreme Court's decision was a final and clear ruling," O'Malley said.

Some Democratic governors were more critical of their Republican counterparts, with Vermont's Peter Shumlin accusing some of them of being disingenuous by calling for the repeal of the health law while declining to state whether they would accept the federal Medicaid funding that results from it.

O'Malley of Maryland anticipates that many Republican governors will eventually accept the federal funding for economic, if not political, reasons. "Once the posturing of the election is past, I think that a lot of these governors are going to have a hard time going home to their doctors, nurses, hospitals, and explaining to them why they are passing up an opportunity to transform these dollars into better economic uses for job creation in their states," he said.

However, for Republican governors like Nebraska's Dave Heineman, the issue is about more than just state-specific interests. "They all say it's free federal money. No, it's not. That's our tax dollars," Heineman said. "It's costing every one of us."

Behind the scenes, governors seemed to agree on one point: there are still many questions they need the federal government to answer as the health law's implementation progresses.

Title: Supreme Court to Hear Landmark Digital Privacy Case Involving Microsoft and Overseas Emails

Article:

The Supreme Court has agreed to hear a significant case on digital privacy, pitting the federal government against tech giant Microsoft in a dispute over emails stored overseas. The justices are already set to consider whether law enforcement can access, without a warrant, cellphone location data held by wireless service providers, making this term a crucial one for the intersection of technology and the law.

The Microsoft case stems from a 2013 incident where U.S. prosecutors demanded Microsoft turn over emails linked to a drug-trafficking case, which were stored only on Microsoft servers in Ireland. Microsoft complied with information it had stored in the United States but sued to block the warrant, arguing that U.S. law enforcement could not seize evidence held in another country.

In 2014, U.S. District Judge Loretta Preska ordered Microsoft to hand over the emails. However, last year, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 2nd Circuit in New York reversed the decision and ruled in Microsoft's favor.

By agreeing to hear the case, the justices are taking on an issue they could have left alone, as there is no split among federal appeals courts. This is also true in the cellphone location data case.

Congress is currently considering legislation that would clarify some aspects left unaddressed by the Stored Communications Act of 1986, which did not address communications held overseas. Microsoft President and Chief Legal Officer Brad Smith argued that the court should have waited for Congress to act, stating, "The current laws were written for the era of the floppy disk, not the world of the cloud."

The Trump administration urged the high court to take on the case, arguing that the appeals court decision "is interfering with the ability of state and local law enforcement agencies to investigate and prosecute crime in their jurisdictions." Thirty-three states supported this argument, stating that the appeals court decision "is interfering with the ability of state and local law enforcement agencies to investigate and prosecute crime in their jurisdictions."

Microsoft, on the other hand, argued that Congress is the appropriate forum to address the issue, noting that the Justice Department proposed a legislative fix before appealing the lower court ruling to the Supreme Court. The company warned that the nation's technology sector would be harmed "if it becomes the conduit through which U.S. law enforcement can seize the private communications of every U.S. service provider’s customers, no matter where in the world those customers are located or their data is stored."

Title: Texas Governor Rick Perry Joins Other Republican Governors in Refusing to Expand Medicaid under ACA

Article:

In the aftermath of the Supreme Court's decision last month that the expansion of Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act (ACA) is optional, several Republican governors have pledged to opt out. On Monday, Texas Governor Rick Perry joined the ranks, stating that Texas will not participate in Medicaid expansion.

Perry's decision aligns with other GOP state executives who have declined to offer Medicaid to individuals with incomes up to 133% of the federal poverty level. This year, that equates to approximately $15,000 for an individual or $25,000 for a family of three.

During an interview on Fox News, Perry stated, "We're not going to participate in any exchanges. We're not going to expand Medicaid. We're just not going to be a part of, again, socializing health care in the state of Texas. And going in direct conflict with our Founding Fathers' wishes and freedom, for that matter."

Perry and his colleagues argue that they are rejecting the health law for primarily ideological reasons. The states' reluctance stems from the fact that, when it comes to Medicaid, the states do not appear to be on the hook for significant financial contributions.

According to Jeff Goldsmith, a health policy analyst who teaches public health at the University of Virginia, the ACA provides 100% coverage for people newly eligible for Medicaid by the federal government in the initial years, and 90% in subsequent years. This compares to the rest of the Medicaid program, where the federal government pays an average of just under 60%.

However, states' concerns extend beyond the newly eligible population. Dennis Smith, secretary of the Wisconsin Department of Health Services and former head of the federal Medicaid program under President George W. Bush, notes that this year, his state put over a billion dollars into its existing Medicaid program. "And that took up literally almost the entire new revenues available to the state—meaning revenues not just for health care, but also intended for education, transportation, law enforcement, and everything else," he says.

Even with enhanced federal match rates, Wisconsin faced a $600 million budget shortfall. "So states just don't have the dollars, even with those enhanced federal match rates," Smith says.

Another concern for many state leaders is the so-called "woodwork effect." When major parts of the health law go into effect in 2014, they worry it will bring out of the woodwork the millions of people who are already eligible for Medicaid but are not currently enrolled.

When some people look to see if they can get health insurance through one of the health exchanges, they may discover a cheaper option. "They will find out that they're actually eligible for Medicaid," says Bruce Lesley, president of First Focus, an advocacy group for children and families.

However, many of those people signing up for Medicaid will not be part of the newly eligible expansion group, whose bills will be largely paid by the federal government. They'll be regular old Medicaid beneficiaries, and states will have to pay up to half their costs.

Goldsmith says what has state officials most worried is how easy it will be for these currently eligible but unenrolled Medicaid recipients to sign up. "It won't be an in-person visit, it won't be a 'bring six forms of ID,'" he says. "There will be an expedited—lubricated, if you will—process to get people onto the rolls, and I think that's the part that's giving state budget officers serious indigestion at this point."

Goldsmith says state officials he's talked to worry that Medicaid, already the largest piece of almost every state budget, could end up dwarfing everything else. "The health and human services secretary of Louisiana told me that at full implementation, 48% of the citizens of his state would be on Medicaid," he says. "And I strongly suspect that [as] you go across the Southern tier of the United States, you'll see a lot of those states in the 30s. A third of their citizens eligible for or potentially enrolled in Medicaid."

This has some states looking at cutting back their Medicaid programs even now. Wisconsin's Dennis Smith, who used to run the federal Medicaid program, says he reads the Supreme Court decision as allowing that.

However, the Obama administration disagrees. Last night, it sent a letter to all the nation's governors, noting that "the Court's decision did not affect other provisions of the law." An administration official confirmed that included the requirement that states maintain current eligibility levels until the year 2014.

Health advocate Lesley, a former Capitol Hill staffer, agrees with the administration. "Our reading of the Supreme Court ruling is [that] the opinion by Justice Roberts...cites basically a specific section of the law and basically changed the idea that the Medicaid expansion can no longer be a mandatory thing, but now is optional," Lesley says. "However, what it did not touch on was this idea of requiring states to maintain coverage. So we believe that that is absolutely still in place."

Title: "Negotiations with Iran Remain Tough as Deadline Approaches: Kerry and Zarif Discuss New Approaches, but Agreement Remains Elusive"

Article:

As the deadline for the nuclear talks between Iran and the P5+1 nations approaches, Secretary of State John Kerry has expressed concerns about the possibility of reaching an agreement. In a news conference on Monday night, Kerry stated, "Is it possible in the end we won't reach an agreement? Yes, it is."

Kerry acknowledged the complexity of the negotiations, stating, "These talks are not going to get easier just because we extend them. They are tough, they've been tough, and they are going to stay tough."

Officials have been tight-lipped about the new approaches being explored with Iran, only indicating that experts from the Energy Department's national laboratories will be studying them to determine if they, in combination with other steps, would provide at least a year's warning if Iran were to pursue a nuclear weapon.

The potential steps could involve Iran committing to ship some of its nuclear stockpile to Russia, disconnecting some of the country's centrifuges in a way that would take considerable time to reverse, and imposing limits on output that can be verified by international inspectors. A European diplomat involved in the discussions described the process as having "a lot of moving parts," and the question is what it adds up to.

Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif stated late Monday that the new ideas do not represent a proposal by either side but rather a compilation of ideas exchanged between the two parties. Zarif reiterated his commitment to maintaining the secrecy of the negotiating room and expressed concern about leaks emerging from the discussions, which have been numerous and have made it difficult to reach a deal.

Kerry praised Zarif, describing him as a creative diplomat who must navigate Iran's complex political landscape and is uncertain about how far the country's supreme leader will allow him to go. The Iranian leaders came to power promising an end to sanctions that have reduced Iran's oil revenue by approximately 60 percent, devalued its currency, and made overseas financial transactions nearly impossible.

Title: Republican Senators Urge White House to Reject Union's Call for ObamaCare Subsidy Extension for Employer-Covered Workers

Article:

A group of thirty-one Republican senators have penned a letter to President Obama, urging the rejection of union demands to extend ObamaCare subsidies to workers who already have coverage through their jobs. The senators' letter, sent on Thursday, follows a report in a major newspaper that unions are seeking access to federal subsidies due to concerns that other provisions of the health care law could increase the cost of their health care plans.

The senators' letter comes in response to a statement by a Treasury official that the issue is "the subject of pending regulations." However, the senators argue that this statement disregards the clear language of the law.

"We respectfully, but strongly, disagree," the lawmakers wrote. "The statement made by Treasury simply ignores the letter of the law."

The senators point out that several provisions in the health care law could potentially increase the cost of coverage, such as the elimination of caps on benefits. Unions, like many employers across the country, have expressed concern that the increase in up-front coverage costs could lead to the dropping of health coverage by unionized employers.

However, the senators argue that workers with an employer-based plan are not eligible, under the law, to receive subsidies intended for those who do not have insurance through their jobs.

"The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) is not ambiguous, in fact it is explicit, on this point," the lawmakers wrote. "Any consideration of expanding access to subsidies therefore is not subject to regulation, but a change in the law."

The senators cite a Congressional Research Service report that states that employer-sponsored coverage would "generally" make an employee "ineligible to receive a premium subsidy."

The subsidies, along with most major provisions of the health care law, are set to go into effect next year. According to the report, 20 million people are covered in plans run by unions and employers.

The letter to Obama was signed by Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, and Sen. John Barrasso, R-Wyo.

"Concerns about rising premiums are driven by policies in (the health care law)," they wrote. "Rather than considering a diversion of subsidies not remotely contemplated in the statute, perhaps the concerns being raised by union plans should be cause to revisit the taxes, fees and other policies that drive premium increases."

Title: Baltimore's Ongoing Protests: A Look at Police Brutality and the Human Toll

Article:

In the heart of Baltimore, protests have been ongoing, sparked by the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old African-American man who sustained severe spinal injuries while in police custody. While the city's Mayor and a diverse city council have been in place, the issue of police brutality remains unresolved.

According to a report by The Baltimore Sun, the city paid out $5.7 million to victims of police brutality between 2011 and 2014. However, the more startling figure is that over the past four years, more than 100 people have won court judgments or settlements related to allegations of brutality and civil-rights violations.

The victims of police brutality in Baltimore are not just young men; they include a 15-year-old boy riding a dirt bike, a 26-year-old pregnant accountant who had witnessed a beating, a 50-year-old woman selling church raffle tickets, a 65-year-old church deacon rolling a cigarette, and an 87-year-old grandmother aiding her wounded grandson.

One such victim is Venus Green, a former teacher with two college degrees who spent her retirement years as a foster parent for needy children. On one day, her grandson ran up to her crying for an ambulance. When paramedics and police responded to the emergency call, a white officer became hostile. Green's grandson was accused of lying, and the officer refused to help him. Green, with no criminal record, pleaded with the officer, but he became violent, shoving her against the wall, handcuffing her, and throwing her to the ground.

The officer, who is not identified in the lawsuit, wanted to go into the basement, but Green demanded a warrant. Her grandson kept two dogs downstairs, and she feared they would attack. The officer unhooked the lock, but Green latched it. He shoved Green against the wall, she hit the wooden floor, and he continued to assault her.

After pulling Green to her feet, the officer told her she was under arrest. Green complained of pain, but the handcuffs remained. An African-American officer then walked in the house, saw her sobbing, and asked that the handcuffs be removed since Green wasn't violent. The cuffs came off, and Green didn't face any charges. But a broken shoulder tormented her for months.

The city paid Green $95,000 in a settlement. This case is just one of the many that highlight the human toll of police brutality in Baltimore. The full article, which includes the stories of other victims, can be found here.

Title: Obama Advocates for Direct Peace Talks Between Israelis and Palestinians, Urges Flexibility and Trust-Building

Article:

RAMALLAH, West Bank — In a joint appearance with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas on Thursday, President Barack Obama emphasized the need for direct negotiations between Israeli and Palestinian leaders, without preconditions, to push through obstacles to peace.

During his first trip to Israel and the Palestinian territories as president, Obama reiterated that the resolution to the conflict requires both parties to work through the process, even in the presence of "irritants" on both sides.

In what may have been a signal to Abbas to be more flexible, Obama cited the complex politics in Israel as part of the reason finding a resolution to the conflict is difficult.

Obama outlined the American role going forward as one of helping "build confidence, rebuild a sense of trust." The meeting between the two leaders was preceded by a morning launch of rockets from the Hamas-controlled Gaza, two of which landed in southern Israel. The issue of Israeli settlements in the West Bank and the end to violence were central topics during the meeting.

Obama discussed the issue of settlements at length during his meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday, the first day of his trip. The president opposed settlement-building and reiterated that America's position is that continued settlement activity is not constructive or appropriate.

However, Obama kept his distance from Abbas' position that ending settlements should be a precondition for peace talks, and was more restrained on the topic than in 2009, when he stated that America "does not accept the legitimacy of continued Israeli settlements."

Obama also addressed Israel's security concerns, referencing them on several occasions and using the Thursday morning attack as an example. He emphasized the need for both parties to work towards a peaceful resolution, while acknowledging the complexities and challenges that come with the conflict.

Title: Bob Costas Clarifies Anti-Gun Remarks, Sparks Debate on American Gun Culture

Article:

In a recent interview on the O'Reilly Factor, NBC sportscaster Bob Costas attempted to clarify his controversial anti-gun comments made during a Sunday Night Football broadcast. The comments, which were met with heavy criticism, were made in response to the tragic shooting incident involving NFL player Jovan Belcher.

During the interview, Costas, who has been accused of shifting focus and making excuses, emphasized that his comments were not his own but were a paraphrase from a column by Jason Whitlock. However, Costas's attempt to distance himself from the comments was met with skepticism, as he had explicitly stated during the broadcast that he was quoting Whitlock.

Costas also faced criticism for his comments being perceived as an attack on gun rights. He attempted to argue that his comments were not about gun control, but this claim was met with disbelief, as Costas's statement that "we have too many guns" was widely interpreted as a call for stricter gun control measures.

Costas also drew criticism for using the shooting in Aurora, Colorado, as an example to support his argument. He suggested that if the theater had allowed patrons to carry guns, the tragedy could have been prevented. However, both Costas and O'Reilly failed to mention that the theater was a gun-free zone, and the shooter had a history of mental health issues that authorities had failed to address.

Costas's comments also sparked debate about the two distinct gun cultures in America. He argued that America has a deep-rooted gun culture that is rooted in American history and the Second Amendment, with the majority of gun owners using firearms for collection, personal protection, hunting, and sport. However, Costas's comments were met with criticism for oversimplifying the complex issue of gun culture in America.

In conclusion, the interview sparked a heated debate about gun culture in America, with many criticizing Costas for his lack of understanding of the issue and his attempt to use the Aurora shooting to score political points. Many also criticized Costas for his failure to acknowledge the complexities of gun culture in America and the need for a nuanced approach to the issue. It remains to be seen whether Costas will continue to address the issue in the future.

Title: Senate Approves Funding Bill, Shifts Money for Slaughterhouse Inspections but Rejects White House Tours Restoration

Article:

In a significant bipartisan move, the U.S. Senate voted on Wednesday to fund the government through the remainder of the fiscal year, averting a potential government shutdown. The bill, which now returns to the House for final approval, includes a provision to maintain full-time slaughterhouse inspectors, but it does not restore funding for White House tours.

The 73-26 vote reflects a growing consensus in Congress that the government shutdown showdowns of the past two years have not benefited either party. The bill, which funds basic operations through September 30, does not reverse the level of sequester cuts but does reallocate funds to restore military tuition assistance programs and food inspections.

Without additional funding, federal inspectors would have been furloughed, potentially causing a significant disruption in U.S. meat production. Industry officials had predicted that a furlough would result in a 2 billion pound decrease in beef and pork production and a 3 billion pound decrease in poultry production.

Senators unanimously approved the addition of funds for food inspections, with Sen. Christopher A. Coons (Delaware Democrat) stating, "It was important that Congress act to prevent a potential crisis from developing in our nation's food supply."

In a separate vote, senators declined to undo President Obama's decision to cancel White House tours, which was one of the casualties of the budget sequesters. Sen. Tom Coburn (Oklahoma Republican) proposed an amendment to restore White House tours by cutting $8 million from spending on national heritage areas in the National Park Service budget. However, the amendment was defeated in a 54-45 vote, with nearly every Republican voting to reopen the White House and almost all Democrats voting to support President Obama's decision.

Sen. Jack Reed (Rhode Island Democrat) led the opposition, arguing that the amendment would hurt economic development in their home states. The debate over the amendment highlighted a partisan divide, with Sen. Tom Coburn accusing his colleagues of focusing on the wrong issues due to election-year politics.

With the 2013 spending bill now cleared, the Senate will turn its attention to the 2014 budget. The House has already begun debating the 2014 budget, with Republicans defeating three Democratic alternatives on Wednesday. The main Democratic substitute was rejected in a 253-165 vote, with even 28 Democrats balking at the tax and spending increases. The final vote on the conservative plan was 132-104, with 14 Democrats and 118 Republicans voting against it, and just 104 Republicans voting for it.

Title: Congressional Response to the Khashoggi Incident: A Delicate Balance of Power and Diplomacy

Article:

The suspected death of journalist Jamal Khashoggi has sparked a wave of criticism towards Saudi Arabia on Capitol Hill, with lawmakers from both parties expressing their concern over the incident. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has stated that there will likely be a response, but the nature and timing of any action remain uncertain.

The U.S. and Saudi Arabia have a long-standing, complex relationship, with shared interests in the Middle East. However, the Khashoggi incident has led to calls for action from senators such as Lindsey Graham, who has urged the U.S. to impose sanctions on Saudi Arabia, and Patrick Leahy, who has criticized the U.S.'s perceived deference to the Saudis.

The immediate future of U.S.-Saudi relations may be uncertain, as both houses of Congress are currently in recess until November 13. The midterm elections are likely to delay any action, as volume of criticism does not always equate to proportional action in Congress.

One potential tool at Congress's disposal is the 2012 Magnitsky Act, which allows for the imposition of sanctions on foreign powers responsible for extrajudicial killings, torture, or detention. Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Bob Corker and the committee's top Democrat, Bob Menendez, have called on the Trump Administration to launch an investigation and make a determination under the Magnitsky Act.

If the Administration finds evidence of human rights abuses, the U.S. can impose sanctions. However, the four-month investigation period may extend into the new Congress, which will likely tackle any potential discipline for Saudi Arabia in 2019.

The Khashoggi affair has also raised questions about the Trump Administration's stance on violence against journalists, as President Trump has been criticized for making light of physical violence against the press. The complexities of the U.S.-Saudi relationship and the upcoming midterm elections may delay any significant action on the Khashoggi front for months.

The Khashoggi incident has sparked impassioned conversations on Capitol Hill, but the language and potential action would be more intense if Congress were in session now. The new Congress will grapple with this issue after January 3, 2019. By then, it is quite possible that lawmakers may have moved on to address the next international crisis.

Title: The Gun Control Debate: A Closer Look at the Landscape and the Parkland Students' Demands

Article:

The ongoing battle to reshape America's gun control laws is a complex and contentious issue, with the aftermath of the Marjory Stoneman Douglas high school shooting serving as a catalyst for change. The students who survived the tragic event are spearheading a movement to redefine the gun control debate, with their message resonating across the nation.

Emma González, a senior at the school, addressed politicians on Sunday, stating, "You're either with us or against us." In a powerful speech to gun control advocates the day before, she vowed, "We are going to be the last mass shooting."

Often perceived as a stalemate dominated by the National Rifle Association (NRA), the American gun control debate is not as one-sided as it may seem. There has been more action and more gun violence prevention victories than many realize. Here is the landscape the Parkland students face as they demand new congressional action on gun control laws:

- Approximately 55-75 million Americans own guns, but the NRA only claims 5 million members, representing less than 10% of America's total gun owners.
- Three percent of American adults own half the country's guns, with most gun owners having just one or two. However, a small group of super-owners, who collectively own half of the country's 256 million guns, own an average of 17 each.
- Seventy-two percent of American adults have shot a gun, even though only 20-30% personally own a firearm. In contrast, 44% of American adults say they personally know someone who has been shot, either accidentally or intentionally.
- Twenty-nine percent of gun owners say the NRA has too much influence over gun laws, according to a recent Pew survey. However, overall, 55% of American adults say that the NRA has the "right amount" of power or even "too little" power over American gun laws.
- Most gun control legislation being debated now is compatible with the Second Amendment. The Supreme Court's 2008 Heller decision, a pro-gun-rights ruling, made it unconstitutional to completely ban Americans from keeping handguns in their homes for self-defense.
- Completely banning military-style rifles would not significantly reduce the number of gun violence victims, as most are killed with ordinary handguns. According to the best available data from the FBI, only 3.55% of gun murders were committed with any kind of rifle from 2010 to 2014.
- Most American gun control groups agree that fighting for universal background checks on gun sales is the law that would do the most good. They have shifted their focus away from banning assault weapons to closing the loopholes in the federal background check system, which currently allows private sales between individuals with no background check.
- Many gun control advocates worry the current movement is too moderate, and that it needs a more radical left flank. The NRA is often pushed to more extreme positions by smaller groups with even more hardline second-amendment views.
- There are dramatic racial, economic, and geographic disparities in American gun violence. Black children 17 and under are 10 times more likely to be murdered with a gun than white children. About half of America's gun murder victims each year are black. The census tracts that saw the worst gun violence in 2015 represented about 1.5% of the country's total population, but 26% of the total gun homicides.

The Parkland students' demands for gun control reform are a testament to their resilience and determination. As the landscape of the gun control debate continues to evolve, it is essential to approach the issue with a nuanced understanding of the facts and the complexities involved.

Title: Analysis: RealClearPolitics Poll Average Suggests Donald Trump May Have Reached Polling Ceiling

Article:

In a recent analysis, Kevin Drum of Mother Jones suggests that the RealClearPolitics poll average indicates that Donald Trump may have reached his ceiling in the Republican primary race. According to Drum, Trump's poll numbers peaked at 24.3 percent on August 5 and have since plateaued and fallen to 22.0 percent.

Drum's analysis is supported by a chart accompanying his piece, which shows a clear flattening of Trump's poll numbers since August 5. However, the trend lines at Pollster, the poll aggregator now run by The Huffington Post, do not show the same level of flattening, but do suggest that Trump's momentum has slowed significantly.

The difference between the trend lines can be attributed to the inclusion of several polls by Pollster that RealClearPolitics does not, including online polls that give Trump a lead as high as 32 percent. Additionally, there seem to be some differences in how the poll averages themselves are calculated.

Despite these differences, the trends are generally identical, and they do suggest that while Donald Trump continues to lead the Republican field, his numbers are at least flattening. This trend is likely to continue for the next several weeks before the next Republican debate, due to the slow end-of-summer news cycle and the fact that we're unlikely to see any real movement in the polls before the next debate unless one of the candidates stumbles significantly or we start seeing major ad buys.

Drum predicts that 25 percent will end up being the peak of Trump's support, but he admits that he's risking an egg-on-your-face moment if he turns out to be wrong. However, even if Drum is right, that doesn't mean that Trump will be fading from the scene any time soon. In a field this large, poll numbers in the range of 20-25 percent still make you a frontrunner, and therefore the focus of the race.

If these numbers were to continue for the next six months or more, then 20-25 percent would mean winning primaries and caucuses, which obviously won't mean as much in the early stages of the race when delegates are being apportioned on a proportional basis rather than winner-take-all. Additionally, with a virtually unlimited personal fortune, Trump can stay in the race as long as he wants to, and he is largely immune from many of the pressures that would otherwise force a candidate from a race. That, combined with fairly decent poll numbers, puts Trump in a position that most candidates would love to be in.

Republicans may not like to hear it, but Donald Trump is going to be around for a while.

Title: "5 Key Points to Observe in Obama's Final State of the Union Address: Legacy, Bipartisanship, and a Boost for Clinton's Campaign"

Article:

In the final State of the Union address of his presidency, President Barack Obama will deliver a thematic and future-oriented speech on Tuesday night, aiming to leave a lasting impression on the American public. Here are five things to watch for in the address:

1. A Shift in Tone and Focus:
The White House has promised that this speech will differ from Obama's past State of the Union addresses, focusing on thematic, future-oriented ideas rather than a laundry list of legislative proposals. The president has emphasized that the speech will focus on the "big things that will guarantee an even stronger, better, more prosperous America for our kids."

2. Prioritizing Legislation:
While major legislative achievements may be challenging with a hostile Congress, the president is expected to reiterate his calls for a minimum wage hike and tax reform to free up funds for infrastructure investment. However, more realistic goals include the approval of the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement and a criminal justice system overhaul.

3. Legacy Shaping:
This valedictory speech will allow Obama to frame his accomplishments in the most positive light. He will highlight the recovery of the auto industry, improving employment, his initiatives on climate change, gun background checks, and the reopening of relations with Cuba. The guests joining First Lady Michelle Obama in the House chamber have been selected to represent the arc of Obama's presidency.

4. Aiding Clinton's Campaign:
In his last State of the Union address, Obama framed the election in terms of economic debate, focusing on inclusive growth. This economic focus aligns with Hillary Clinton's campaign, and the president is expected to emphasize this in his speech. Additionally, expect to hear Obama touch on hot-button issues that resonate with the Democratic base, such as climate change, gun control, immigration reform, or gay rights.

5. Bipartisan Olive Branches:
The president will likely extend olive branches to the Republicans on potentially bipartisan issues like the Trans-Pacific Partnership and criminal justice system overhaul. This is an attempt to foster bipartisanship and leave a positive legacy.

The State of the Union address often has a short shelf life, but a well-received speech can deliver a political boost. President Obama is hoping this speech will help improve his approval ratings, which have been in the mid-40s for months, and potentially aid Hillary Clinton's campaign and his own legacy.

Title: Fact-Checking the Clinton-Kaine Theory on the Causes of the Great Recession

Article:

In the recent vice-presidential debate, Tim Kaine, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, reiterated a new economic theory put forth by Hillary Clinton in the first presidential debate: that the Bush tax cuts of 2003 contributed to the Great Recession. This argument, however, lacks support from mainstream economic theories and empirical evidence.

Neither Clinton nor Kaine mentioned traditional explanations for the Great Recession, such as government-subsidized housing or excessive financial leverage on Wall Street. Their argument is novel, and it requires fact-checking.

Mainstream economic theories, including Keynesian, classical, and monetarist, do not support the view that tax relief can cause recessions in the short-run. The Keynesian view argues that deficit-financed tax cuts, such as those passed in 2003 under Bush, should provide stimulus to the economy by encouraging spending. Tax cuts provide stimulus through boosting post-tax incomes, thus giving people more money to spend, which creates more economic activity and income for others.

Many economists argue that tax cuts which benefit the poor and middle-class deliver a bigger jolt to the economy, as such individuals tend to spend a higher fraction of their incomes. The Bush tax cuts of 2003 reduced rates for all tax brackets, but even if they had been geared solely to the rich, Keynesian theory would suggest that they would produce a stimulative impact on the economy, although a significantly diminished one.

The classical and monetarist views argue that only permanent reductions in taxes have a positive impact on wealth in the long-run. The Bush tax cuts expired after eight years, so classical and monetarist economists could debate whether they count as a temporary fiscal shock or not. But neither school believes that tax cuts have a negative effect on economic activity.

The only plausible economic theory that could support the Kaine-Clinton argument is that deficit-financed tax cuts create recessions by expanding public debt to the point of fiscal insolvency, as happened in Greece. However, that's not what happened in the Great Recession of 2008–2009.

Empirical work on the impact of tax cuts in isolation suggests that they almost always boost consumption and economic activity to varying degrees. University of Michigan economist Matthew Shapiro has found that over the last decade, tax cuts ranging from the initial tax-rate reductions enacted in 2001 under President Bush to the 2009 payroll-tax cuts under President Obama boosted economic activity to varying degrees.

It's important to note that income and wealth inequality are a separate matter. Few argue (and rightly so) that any of these tax cuts are self-financing. Quite the opposite: The continuing trend whereby the government takes in less than it spends has led to perennial deficits for 15 years. Perhaps such deficits could create fiscal drag on growth in the future, but that will only come in the form of higher taxes and lower growth, which again goes to show that tax cuts do not directly spur recessions.

The Clinton campaign's flawed theory of the Great Recession bears many resemblances to the false argument spouted by Bernie Sanders in the primaries: that the repeal of Glass-Steagall created the financial crisis. Both theories propagate a lie, in Sanders' case, the debunked idea that reinstating Glass-Steagall would have broken up the investment banks or commercial lenders that nearly brought down the system.

While Sanders could ultimately be dismissed as a radical with no shot at power, Hillary Clinton may very well be our next president. When she argues that tax cuts cause recessions, her argument can't be allowed to stand. It's the latest in a series of political maneuvers meant to slander the other party at the expense of honest policy discussion, and she shouldn't be allowed to get away with it.

- Jon Hartley is an MBA candidate at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, an economics contributor for Forbes, and the co-founder of Real Time Macroeconomics LLC.

Title: Federal Judge Overturns Trump's Attempt to Open Arctic and Atlantic Oceans to Oil and Gas Leasing

A federal judge in Alaska has overturned U.S. President Donald Trump's attempt to open vast areas of the Arctic and Atlantic oceans to oil and gas leasing. The decision, issued late Friday by U.S. District Court Judge Sharon Gleason, leaves intact President Barack Obama's policies that put the Arctic's Chukchi Sea, part of the Arctic's Beaufort Sea, and a large swath of the Atlantic Ocean off the U.S. East Coast off-limits to oil leasing.

Trump's attempt to undo Obama's protections was "unlawful" and a violation of the federal Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, Gleason ruled. Presidents have the power under that law to withdraw areas from the national oil and gas leasing program, as Obama did, but only Congress has the power to add areas to the leasing program, she said.

The Obama-imposed leasing prohibitions "will remain in full force and effect unless and until revoked by Congress," Gleason said in her ruling. Trump's move to put offshore Arctic and Atlantic areas back into play for oil development came in a 2017 executive order that was part of his "energy dominance" agenda. The order was among a series of actions that jettisoned Obama administration environmental and climate-change initiatives.

The Trump administration has proposed a vastly expanded offshore oil leasing program to start this year. The five-year Trump leasing program would offer two lease sales a year in Arctic waters and at least two lease sales a year in the Atlantic. The Trump plan also calls for several lease sales in remote marine areas off Alaska, like the southern Bering Sea, that are considered to hold negligible potential for oil.

Obama had pulled much of the Arctic off the auction block following a troubled offshore Arctic exploration program pursued by Royal Dutch Shell. Shell spent at least $7 billion trying to explore the Chukchi and part of the Beaufort. The company wrecked one of its drill ships in a grounding and managed to complete only one well to depth. It abandoned the program in 2015 and relinquished its leases.

In a separate case, Gleason delivered another decision on Friday that blocks the Trump administration's effort to overturn an Obama-era environmental decision. Gleason struck down a land trade intended to clear the way for a road to be built through sensitive wetlands in Alaska's Izembek National Wildlife Refuge. The Obama administration, after a four-year environmental impact statement process, determined that the land trade and road would cause too much harm to the refuge to be justified.
