Trump's then Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke broke the law when he summarily reversed the Obama policy without addressing the facts found in the previous administration's study of the issue, Gleason ruled.

Title: Georgia Special Election Highlights Nationalized Local Elections and the Power of Party Affiliation

Article:

The Georgia special election taking place on Tuesday, in a word, is extraordinary. The contest to determine the 435th in seniority in Congress' lower chamber has garnered an unprecedented amount of media coverage, visits from major political figures, and over $50 million, making it the most expensive House race in American history. However, the outcome of this election will not significantly impact the fate of either the Republican or Democratic parties, either this year, next year, or in 2020.

The Georgia special election serves as a microcosm of what we can expect in 2018 and 2020: the nationalized local election. Despite the fact that there are not hundreds of other races happening simultaneously (though there is also a special election in South Carolina, which has received minimal attention), the closeness of the contest and the district's significance has drawn national attention and resources.

The candidates, Jon Ossoff (Democrat) and Karen Handel (Republican), have not been eager to portray the election as a referendum on President Trump or the national parties. However, the reality is that a vote for Handel is a vote for the GOP agenda, while a vote for Ossoff is a vote for the Democratic agenda.

The two candidates have focused on local issues, but their party affiliations are the most significant factors determining their legislative priorities. Ossoff, if elected, will be a reliable Democratic vote, while Handel, if elected, will be a reliable Republican vote. This is not to say that the candidates will not represent the interests of their district, but rather that their ability to influence federal policy will be limited.

In conclusion, the Georgia special election serves as a reminder that voters are not just choosing a representative for their district, but also for their party. As Americans head to the polls in the coming years, they will likely treat local elections as referendums on the national parties, their agendas, and the President. This is an appropriate response, as the outcome of these elections will have national implications.

Title: Republican Leaders Gather to Discuss Immigration Reform Strategy as Bipartisan Bill Faces Opposition in House

Article:

In a bid to address the ongoing immigration reform debate, Republican leaders will convene on Wednesday afternoon to strategize with their members. However, the prospects for comprehensive immigration reform in the House appear dim, with many top Republicans predicting a slow, drawn-out demise for the issue.

The Republican Party, determined to rectify their 2012 mishap with the Hispanic community, now face the possibility of exacerbating the situation. The reality, according to these Republicans, is that most House members are white conservatives representing predominantly white districts, whose constituents show little interest in the immigration reform advocated by figures like Marco Rubio, Bill O'Reilly, and Karl Rove.

The House plans to adopt a piecemeal approach, with a border-security bill slated for this month, followed by one or two reform items per month in the fall. However, after numerous listening sessions, it is clear that even smaller, popular pieces of reform will be a tough sell.

Rep. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.) recently held a town meeting where immigration was a topic of discussion. Out of 100 attendees, 25 spoke out, and every one of them advocated for avoiding any immigration reform resembling the Senate-passed bill.

"Our constituents don't trust our government," Cotton said, expressing his reluctance to pass even necessary reforms like a better tracking system for people in the country on visas, due to concerns they could become a "Trojan horse in a conference committee for a package that puts legalization first and enforcement later."

Top Republican and Democratic leaders on Capitol Hill are increasingly pessimistic about reaching a deal this Congress. The Senate-passed bill, which was supported by only 13 of Rubio's fellow Republican senators, has faced criticism from conservative publications like the National Review and Weekly Standard, and private GOP headcounts show only a small fraction of House Republicans would ever vote for anything approximating the Senate deal.

Rep. Steve King (R-Iowa), a prominent member of the House's anti-immigration reform caucus, held a well-attended meeting on Monday to argue against the bipartisan bill. King contends that the Senate's immigration plan would benefit "elites who want cheap labor, Democratic power brokers, and those who hire illegal labor."

"It would hurt Republicans, and I don't think you can make an argument otherwise," King said. "Two out of every three of the new citizens would be Democrats." While some may dismiss King's views as extreme, they represent a mainstream perspective among House Republicans.

Title: The Conservative Dilemma: Rebuilding Family and Community Beyond Government Intervention

Article:

In the aftermath of the 2018 midterm elections, the Republican Party faces a significant challenge: the need to re-engage Americans in family and civic institutions outside of government. The Democrats' sweeping victories in the House, their near-minimum Senate losses, and their success in down-ballot races suggest a shift in the political landscape that may challenge the optimism of some Republican pundits.

This shift has led some Republicans to advocate for a new, policy-based form of Trumpism, one that recognizes the bifurcation of opportunity based on education and the breakdown of the nuclear family. Ross Douthat, now of the New York Times, and Reihan Salam, now of ███, have been at the forefront of this movement, arguing that strong families and communities are crucial for the prosperity and upward mobility of working-class Americans.

Their arguments have been echoed by Oren Cass of the Manhattan Institute, author of the new bestseller "The Once and Future Worker." Cass argues for a focus on a labor market in which workers can support strong families and communities, which he believes is the central determinant of long-term prosperity.

However, a fundamental question arises: is government intervention truly likely to lead to the revitalization of family and community? Do families and communities rebuild themselves on the basis of economic policy, or must the preconditions for economic thriving be in place first? When those preconditions are undermined, does prosperity naturally fade away?

These questions go to the heart of our politics and raise another serious question: can political conservatism survive the growth of government-led intervention designed to shore up fundamental institutions? When it comes to government intervention, what is the limiting principle? If we believe government can rebuild the labor market according to Cass's prescriptions, or rebuild families according to Douthat's and Salam's, where is the line drawn?

Constitutional philosophy suggests that Douthat, Salam, and Cass are correct when it comes to the world they seek to build: safe, stable, culturally solid, community-oriented. However, constitutional philosophy also suggests that the institutions that hold up such a world cannot be created by government. Churches do not thrive because government subsidizes them; families do not thrive because government subsidizes them.

This means that conservatism's fundamental challenge these days is extra-governmental: convincing Americans to re-engage with family and civic associations outside of government, which cannot effectuate such re-engagement itself. Conservatives can focus on removing governmental disincentives toward family and community and work. They can also focus on removing cultural disincentives toward institution-building. This is where the culture war matters: fighting the Left's constant focus on breaking down family structure, disdain for stay-at-home mothers, disparagement of religious Americans, and distaste for American cultural solidarity.

However, the moment conservatives try to build Trumpism around a policy of government do-gooderism, they run into the problem they seek to alleviate. Americans value family and community because they have values, not because family and community must be made more economically valuable. If we rely on material incentives to prop up our most vital social institutions, those institutions are likely to continue disintegrating—and to take the economic freedom we hope to promote in the end with them.

Title: Harvey Weinstein Arraigned, Charged with Rape and Sexual Assault, Faces up to 25 Years in Prison

Article:

-Start of Article-

Disgraced film producer Harvey Weinstein was released on a $1 million bail following his arraignment on Friday, after being charged with rape, criminal sex act, and other sex crimes stemming from encounters with two women. The charges were announced in Manhattan court.

Weinstein, who has been accused by more than 80 women of sexual misconduct, surrendered to the New York Police Department and the Manhattan District Attorney's office on Friday morning. At the arraignment, Weinstein agreed to wear an electronic monitoring device, paid for at his own expense. He is only allowed to travel in New York state and Connecticut, and must seek permission to travel to other states.

Weinstein has received a grand jury notice and will have until May 30 to decide whether to testify or not. The victim has received an order of protection and will remain anonymous.

Weinstein turned himself in at NYPD's 1st Precinct around 7:30 a.m. ET, carrying books including Something Wonderful: Rodgers and Hammerstein's Broadway Revolution and Elia Kazan about the stage and film director. Weinstein was noticeably struggling to walk, and left the station before 9 a.m. in handcuffs, headed to court for his arraignment.

As Weinstein headed into the courthouse, he was questioned by the crowd. "You sorry, Harvey?" someone shouted. "What can you say?" was also raised. In reply, Weinstein softly shook his head and answered "No."

Weinstein has consistently denied any allegations of non-consensual sex. His lawyer, Benjamin Brafman, said Friday that he would fight to get the charges dismissed, saying they are factually unsupported and constitutionally flawed.

Brafman issued a statement to ███ following Friday's proceedings, reiterating his client's stance. "Mr. Weinstein has always maintained that he has never engaged in non-consensual sexual behavior with anyone. Nothing about today's proceedings changes Mr. Weinstein's position. He has entered a plea of not guilty and fully expects to be exonerated."

Police expressed their gratitude to Weinstein's accusers. "The NYPD thanks these brave survivors for their courage to come forward and seek justice," a statement read. "The arrest and ensuing charges are the result of a joint investigation between the NYPD and the Manhattan District Attorney’s Office."

Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance Jr. also thanked Weinstein's claimants for their courage in a statement shared to Twitter on Friday. "Thank you to the brave survivors who have come forward, our office’s tireless prosecutors, and our dedicated partners at @NYPDNews," he shared before urging those with additional accounts or information to reach out.

When discussing the accusations facing his client, Brafman reminded reporters Friday his job isn't "to defend behavior; my job is to defend something that is criminal behavior."

"Mr. Weinstein did not invent the casting couch in Hollywood," he declared, "and to the extent that there is bad behavior in that industry, that is not what this is about. Bad behavior is not on trial in this case; it’s only if you intentionally committed a criminal act, and Mr. Weinstein vigorously denies that."

Friday's events come nearly eight months after The New York Times exposed three decades of alleged sexual misconduct ranging from harassment to rape from accusers including Ashley Judd, Rose McGowan, Salma Hayek, Lupita Nyong'o, and Gwyneth Paltrow. Weinstein decamped to Arizona to seek treatment soon afterward.

Weinstein has been under investigation for months in New York, Los Angeles, and London.

Several of the actresses who have made allegations against Weinstein, including McGowan and Annabella Sciorra, applauded his impending arrest on social media.

"The justice system has been something very elusive," McGowan said. "I hope in this case it works. Because it’s all true. None of this was consensual."

Weinstein became a larger-than-life figure in Hollywood as co-founder of the "mini-major" studios Miramax (started in 1979) and The Weinstein Company (2005), producing and distributing awards-friendly films such as Oscar best-picture winners The Artist and The King's Speech.

The domineering studio head amassed tremendous influence with his strong personality, his ability to identify and champion artistic projects, and his track record of Oscar success—the latter cemented when Weinstein's Shakespeare in Love was a shock best-picture winner over Steven Spielberg's heavily favored Saving Private Ryan in 1999.

The Weinstein scandal has triggered a cascade of accusations against Kevin Spacey, Louis C.K., Louis C.K., Charlie Rose, Matt Lauer, and Morgan Freeman, among others.

-End of Article-

Title: Mike Huckabee Affirms Independent Presidential Bid, Dismisses Notion of Bowing Out for Jeb Bush or Mitt Romney

Article:

In a recent interview on ABC's "This Week," former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee, who previously expressed consideration for stepping aside from a potential 2016 presidential run if his friend Jeb Bush entered the race, has now stated unequivocally that he will not withdraw his candidacy for any contender, including Bush or Mitt Romney.

Huckabee, who finished second to John McCain in the 2008 Republican presidential nomination race, winning the Iowa caucus and several Southern primaries, expressed his intentions for the 2022 presidential race this spring. He announced his departure from his political talk show "Huckabee" on the Fox News Channel in early March to focus on another presidential run.

The former governor, who is part of a crowded field of potential GOP contenders, including Bush and 2012 Republican nominee Mitt Romney, pushed back against those who have discouraged Romney from another White House bid, arguing that Romney's loss to President Obama in 2012 did not necessarily indicate an inability to connect with voters.

"It's wide open. Anyone could be a contender," said Huckabee. "One of the things about politics, when you're actually there, you realize that you are on a high wire and there is no net under you. On any given day, your campaign can implode for something that happens inadvertently or intentionally."

Huckabee continued, "So you never say that someone is not a contender, that they can't make it. I hear that all the time about a lot of different people. Nobody knows. Voters will make that decision, and that's the way it ought to be."

Title: Police Accountability and Reform: A Look at the Challenges and Solutions in the United States

Article:

In the wake of the death of George Floyd, a black man who died while being arrested, the issue of police brutality and accountability has once again taken center stage in the United States. The events unfolding on the streets, marked by tear gas, mass arrests, and curfews, echo similar confrontations that occurred nearly six years ago in Ferguson, Missouri, following the shooting of Michael Brown.

At ███, we have been reporting on the complexities of police reform since our inception in 2014, and the stories we have covered remain relevant in the face of ongoing challenges. This article aims to provide context and shed light on the intricacies of police accountability, reform, and the role of the military in policing.

When a police officer is accused of misconduct or brutality, the process varies depending on the jurisdiction. In more than a dozen states, police officers enjoy their own Bill of Rights, which can mean that an officer under investigation does not have to answer questions for up to 10 days, and the department is still required to pay salary and benefits. This blurred line becomes even more apparent in joint task forces, where federal agencies like the U.S. Marshals recruit local police departments to track down fugitives or fight terrorism. In such cases, the local officers assigned to these task forces may not be bound by their own department's rules, such as wearing a body camera.

Reforming troubled police departments is a complex issue with a long history. A deep dive into the Kerner Commission Report, published in the aftermath of the race riots of the 1960s, reveals the shortcomings of federal attempts at police reform. More recently, we have explored the U.S. Department of Justice's tactic of suing local police departments to enact change through consent decrees, a strategy that has been largely set aside under recent Republican administrations. Alternatively, a local department can voluntarily adopt federally recommended reforms. However, the results often fall short, as evidenced by the experiences of residents in low-income and middle-class neighborhoods in Cincinnati, a city once celebrated for its successful federal intervention.

To better understand the root causes of police violence, we have spoken to a range of individuals who have immersed themselves in the issue. David Simon, creator of the acclaimed television series "The Wire," highlighted the role of the drug war in transforming policing in cities like Baltimore, where Freddie Gray was killed in police custody, sparking mass protests. Bryan Stevenson, author of "Just Mercy" and founder of the Equal Justice Initiative, delved into the historic role of the police in enforcing white supremacy in America. We have also spoken to individuals with searing personal encounters, such as Erica Garner, whose father, Eric Garner, died in Staten Island after a New York Police Department officer put him in a chokehold.

Another contributing factor to excessive use of force by police is the increasing militarization of many police departments. For decades, the Defense Department has been transferring surplus military equipment to local law enforcement agencies, often for free and with little scrutiny. This equipment includes grenade launchers, machetes, and bayonets, many of which were deployed in Ferguson, where police used weapons of war against protesters. The Obama administration banned the program following the waves of protest sparked by police tactics in Ferguson; President Donald Trump reinstated it.

In addition to the equipment, the militarization of police is not just a matter of hardware; in fact, as a Marshall Project story showed, nearly one-fifth of police officers have served in the military, where their training and experience can distort their relationships with the communities they serve.

As the nation grapples with the ongoing issue of police brutality and accountability, it is essential to stay informed and engaged. To learn more about the reporting on policing, consider subscribing to our email newsletters.

Title: NBC's Chuck Todd Addresses Media Bias Perceptions in Interview with Breitbart

Article:

In a recent interview with conservative news site Breitbart, NBC's "Meet the Press" host Chuck Todd took a veiled shot at media executives with political backgrounds, including Fox News chief Roger Ailes, ABC's George Stephanopoulos, and potentially himself.

During the interview, Todd expressed his view that political operatives involved in news executive roles can contribute to perceptions of media bias. He specifically referred to Fox News chief Roger Ailes, who was a media consultant for Republican presidents Richard Nixon, Ronald Reagan, and George H.W. Bush. However, Todd himself served as a staffer on Democratic Senator Tom Harkin's 1992 presidential bid, and ABC's George Stephanopoulos, the host of "This Week" and Todd's direct competitor on Sunday mornings, was a senior advisor to Democratic president Bill Clinton.

In the Breitbart interview, John Nolte stated that conservatives view the media as a whole as a branch of the Democratic Party aiming to undermine them. Todd responded, "That's a mindset I can't do anything about. There are some practitioners in the media that view things as a campaign. Look, it doesn't help when any former political operative is involved as a news executive in any form. It's all winning and losing."

Todd's decision to speak to Breitbart, an aggressively conservative news and opinion site, reflects an effort to broaden the show's outreach. "This is a step in the rehabilitation of my business," Todd said at the top of the interview. "Talk to the critics. Talk to the skeptics."

Todd's predecessor, David Gregory, had not been as eager to engage with conservative critics. In an interview with The Huffington Post earlier this year, he stated, "I just made a decision... There are haters out there. I'm not going to engage those people, because they're not looking to have a dialogue with me over Twitter."

Chuck Todd's ratings have been declining since he took over, with a drop each week. It remains to be seen whether his efforts to engage with conservative media will help improve his show's performance.

Title: Debate on Tax Reform: A Look at the Proposed Revenue Sources for Democrats

Article:

The recent tax proposal by Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has ignited a debate among Democrats regarding the source of new revenue for the government. With the federal budget deficit projected to surpass $1 trillion in 2019 and expected to rise in the coming years, the need for additional revenue is undeniable.

Ocasio-Cortez, the young and outspoken Democratic representative from the Bronx, has sparked headlines with her suggestion of tax rates as high as 70 percent to finance a "Green New Deal." However, it's crucial to clarify that Ocasio-Cortez did not propose taking 70 percent of anyone's income. Instead, she suggested applying the rate only to earnings beyond $10 million, meaning those affected would pay a much lower share of their income overall.

Historically, the top tax rate exceeded 90 percent during the 1950s. However, due to deductions and tax avoidance, "taxes on the rich were not that much higher" then, according to the conservative Tax Foundation. The top rate remained 70 percent as late as 1981, the first year of Ronald Reagan's presidency. Despite this, the most affluent 1 percent paid a far lower average rate of 30.5 percent, according to a Tax Policy Center analysis.

In the 2016 presidential campaign, self-described socialist Sen. Bernie Sanders proposed a 54.2 percent tax for incomes above $10 million, while Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton suggested 43.6 percent for those earning above $5 million.

With little prospect of success under President Donald Trump, the new House Democratic majority has avoided the issue in its initial legislative agenda. However, the party's growing field of 2020 presidential candidates won't have that luxury.

The only formally declared Democratic candidate, former Rep. John Delaney of Maryland, wants to finance infrastructure projects by raising the recently enacted 21 percent top corporate rate to 25 percent. Sen. Kamala Harris of California has proposed curbing income inequality by rolling back all the Trump tax cuts in favor of expanded tax credits for modest earners.

"You've got to ask, 'What constitutes a fair share in this economy?'" Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren told me in a recent interview. She declined to specify what she favors, but other proposals include eliminating the "step-up" valuation that lets some inherited assets avoid capital gains taxes, and capping tax deductions for the wealthy.

The amount of revenue Democrats need depends on the new programs they ultimately pursue. Analysts have priced Sen. Bernie Sanders' "Medicare for All" plan at $32 trillion, while Sen. Sherrod Brown backs a far less expensive Medicare "buy-in" for 55 and over.

Republican resistance casts doubts on the prospects for new taxes in any event. Former Fed chairman Alan Greenspan warns a 70 percent top income tax rate would prove a "terrible mistake" by dampening economic activity. As the party of limited government, the GOP opposes most new programs however they're paid for.

With the demographic tidal wave of baby boomer retirements, the 2019 deficit will exceed the entire Medicare budget, and the government projects the number of Americans 65 and older will jump 50 percent to 77 million in 15 years. This underscores the need for both parties to address the issue of revenue generation, according to Douglas Holtz-Eakin, who advised President George W. Bush. He prefers taxing consumption instead of income on economic grounds, though any new taxes will strain America's polarized political system.

"We will need all the economic growth we can get, we need to control spending, and we need to raise revenue," Holtz-Eakin said, recounting advice he recently gave House Republicans. "It's going to be ugly."

Title: Texas-led Coalition Grows to 26 States in Challenge to President Obama's Executive Amnesty

Article:

In a significant development, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton announced on Monday that Nevada and Tennessee have joined the state's legal challenge of President Barack Obama's executive amnesty, bringing the total number of states involved in the lawsuit to 26.

In a statement, Attorney General Paxton expressed pride in leading a coalition that now represents a majority of the United States. He stated, "The momentum against the President's lawlessness continues to build with Tennessee and Nevada joining the effort to protect our states from the economic and public safety implications of illegal amnesty."

The lawsuit, which was first filed in December, argues that Obama's amnesty would create a new wave of illegal immigration that would burden state governments. During a hearing on January 15th, Texas attorney Andrew Oldham told the presiding judge, Andrew Hanen, "This is the second time they’ve done it in two years. Maybe they’ll do it again in 2016."

The Obama administration's lawyer, Kathleen Hartnett, disputed this claim, insisting that new arrivals will not come "on the expectation of receiving deferred action because they will be turned away." However, Judge Hanen, who presided over a 2013 case, is not likely to accept this argument. In the 2013 case, Hanen predicted that Obama's lax border enforcement policies would lead to a wave of illegal immigration.

The states are asking Judge Hanen to issue an injunction that would stop Obama from granting work permits before the program begins in May. If the amnesty does stand, it is estimated to cost taxpayers billions in tax credits every year.

The full list of 26 states suing Obama over his executive amnesty includes Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Indiana, Kansas, Louisiana, Maine, Michigan, Mississippi, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Utah, West Virginia, Wisconsin, and Texas.

Title: Cancellation of Freedom Rally in San Francisco: Joey Gibson Accuses City Leaders of Hypocrisy Over Violence Concerns

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Joey Gibson, leader of the Patriot Prayer group, cancelled his planned peaceful rally in San Francisco's Crissy Field on Saturday, citing concerns over potential violence from antifa and By Any Means Necessary activists. The rally, which was set to feature a diverse array of speakers, was intended to be a day of freedom, spirituality, unity, peace, and patriotism.

During a press conference on Facebook Live, Mr. Gibson expressed his belief that the event would have resulted in a "huge riot," stating, "That's a fact. A bunch of supporters, a bunch of antifa communists, normal liberals would have all been mixed together. It would have been a huge riot, and it would have been a disaster."

The cancellation of the Freedom Rally follows the cancellation of a separate right-of-center event in Berkeley, titled "No to Marxism in America," which was also called off due to fears of violence. In response, thousands of residents attended a "unite against hate" march at Civic Center Plaza, carrying anti-Trump signs and a large rainbow banner that read, "Rise and Resist!"

San Francisco Mayor Ed Lee applauded the counterprotesters during a Saturday press conference, stating, "The people of San Francisco have demonstrated our determination to protect the freedom of peaceful expression as well as public safety."

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi had called on the National Park Service to reconsider Patriot Prayer's permit, describing the event as a "white supremacist rally." In response, Ms. Pelosi stated, "Reason has prevailed because the people of San Francisco have demonstrated our determination to protect the freedom of peaceful expression as well as public safety."

However, Mr. Gibson accused Ms. Pelosi and Mayor Lee of stoking unrest by labeling the event as a white supremacy rally, despite most of the scheduled speakers not being white and Mr. Gibson himself being half-Asian. He also accused Democrats of hypocrisy on protester violence, stating, "You have a mayor who says that we’re hateful, we’re violent, he doesn’t bring up any specific examples, but he doesn’t mention one word about antifa. Not one word."

Throughout the day, Mr. Gibson claimed he was menaced by antifa and By Any Means Necessary activists who followed the Patriot Prayer organizers and used Twitter to announce their whereabouts. He described these activists as individuals who "dress like ninjas, who run around, they want to burn stuff down, they want to commit violence, they want to use bike locks, they want to use clubs with nails through them."

Mr. Gibson, who started Patriot Prayer earlier this year to support President Trump, has since focused on fighting extremism on the left and the right to promote peace and unity. His rallies in Portland and Seattle have attracted members of white-nationalist groups like Identity Evropa, which Mr. Gibson said he has tried to discourage.

The Southern Poverty Law Center, which does not list Patriot Prayer as a hate group, has criticized the rallies for drawing the "alt-right" while crediting Mr. Gibson for speaking out against white supremacists and neo-Nazis. Mr. Gibson concluded, "At the end of the day, I just want a small government, and then there will be no tyrants. And we will be free people in a free society who can respect one another."

Title: Harvard's Admissions Practices Under Scrutiny for Alleged Discrimination Against Asian Americans

Article:

In an unexpected turn of events, one of the most prestigious educational institutions in the United States, Harvard University, is facing allegations of racial discrimination against Asian American students. The target group this time is not blacks or Jews, as it was in past years, but Asian Americans.

After years of legal battles, millions of dollars in legal fees, millions of records examined, and hundreds of hours of depositions and testimony, Harvard's once opaque admissions policies have been laid bare. The revelations are far from flattering.

Harvard's admissions process evaluates student applicants in three main areas: academic performance, extra-curricular achievements, and "personal qualities." While these criteria might seem fair on the surface, they are not applied equally.

Asian American applicants consistently outperform white students, Latinos, and African Americans in the first two criteria - academics and extra-curricular activities, which can be objectively assessed. However, Harvard justifies its lower acceptance rates for Asian American students with the help of the third criterion - "personal qualities," which include subjective factors like "likability," "maturity," "integrity," and "effervescence."

According to Harvard's own internal reports, Asian American applicants are systematically marked lower on this personality scale by Harvard admissions officers who rarely meet or interview applicants. However, the personality ratings given to Asian students by Harvard's own alumni interviewers, who actually meet the applicants in person, are significantly higher.

In other words, Harvard artificially and fraudulently downgrades Asians on "personal qualities" to achieve the desired number of admissions. Economist Peter Arcidiacono of Duke University concluded that with the same application profile in terms of test scores, extracurricular activities, and personality factors, an Asian American male applicant would only have a 25% chance of admission - versus 32% if white, 77% if Hispanic, and 95% if black.

In 2013, Asian Americans made up 19% of the incoming freshmen class. According to Harvard's own Office of Institutional Research, if the personality factors had not been rigged, that percentage would have been 43%.

Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 guarantees that "No person in the United States shall, on the ground of race, color, or national origin, be excluded from participation in, or be denied benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any program or activity receiving federal financial assistance."

Each year, Harvard takes hundreds of millions of dollars from the federal government. In the landmark case Grutter v. Bollinger, the Supreme Court upheld the University of Michigan Law School's affirmative action policies, deciding that race could be used as a "plus factor" to achieve diversity, but never as a quota. Yet, by placing strict limits on the percentage of Asian American applicants it will admit, racial quotas are exactly what Harvard is using.

One strongly suspects this quota system is not limited to Harvard. In the last ten years, Asian American students have been limited to an 18-22% presence across the Ivy League. Or maybe that's just a coincidence.

Writing for the majority in Grutter v. Bollinger in 2003, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote that the Court "expects that 25 years from now, the use of racial preferences will no longer be necessary to further the interest approved today." With less than a decade to go, the Ivy League shows no indication that it's giving up on those racial preferences. Instead, these colleges have doubled down. Objective standards regarding admissions continue to be increasingly disfavored as the illegal goal of racial balancing is advanced.

This racial balancing is justified by the left's desire to achieve "racial diversity" - its insistence on seeing every person only through the prism of race, as if the most important thing any of us has to offer is the color of our skin.

Not long ago, that was called "racism." It's still called racism. It needs to end, once and for all - for the sake of deserving Asian American students, for the sake of Harvard's own integrity, and for the sake of the American principle that the rules must be the same for everyone.

Chief Justice of the Supreme Court John Roberts said it best: "The way to stop discrimination on the basis of race is to stop discriminating on the basis of race." It's time we did just that. I'm Lee Cheng, of the Asian American Legal Foundation, for ███.

Title: A Second Look at Mitt Romney's 2016 Presidential Prospects: A Retrospective Analysis of the 2012 Election

Article:

In the aftermath of the 2012 presidential election, many have written off Mitt Romney as a potential candidate for 2016. However, one analyst offers a different perspective, arguing that Romney could potentially mount a successful campaign if he learns from past mistakes and adapts to the current political climate.

The analyst points to three key moments during the 2012 election that, in their view, could have significantly altered the outcome. The first is the response to Hurricane Sandy, where the analyst suggests that Romney should have visited affected areas on the East Coast, surveying the damage, and delivering a major policy speech on rebuilding the nation's infrastructure. This, they argue, would have shown Romney's leadership and empathy, as well as created jobs and stimulated the economy.

The second moment is the second presidential debate, where Romney was criticized for his response to the Benghazi attack. The analyst contends that Romney missed an opportunity to go on the offensive and challenge the administration's handling of the situation, instead of appearing defensive.

The third moment is the GOP's perceived tone-deafness on cultural issues, such as global warming, the environment, and alternative energy. The analyst argues that Romney, if advised correctly, could position himself as a modern, forward-thinking candidate who is in touch with the concerns of younger voters and the media.

In conclusion, the analyst suggests that Romney, with the right advice and a willingness to embrace the cultural issues of the day, could mount a successful campaign in 2016. They argue that Romney has the potential to be a Reagan-like figure, galvanizing the nation and winning over voters who may have been turned off by the GOP in the past. However, it is important to note that this is just one perspective, and the outcome of a potential 2016 campaign would depend on a multitude of factors, including the candidate's personal appeal, the state of the economy, and the political climate of the time.

Title: Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker Proposes Alternative to ObamaCare, Seeks Federal Approval

Article:

In a move to address the perceived issues with the Affordable Care Act (ObamaCare), Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker has proposed a plan that would allow the state's poor and uninsured to purchase health coverage directly from insurers, bypassing the online exchange established by the Affordable Care Act. This proposal, which has garnered bipartisan support in the Wisconsin state house, is now awaiting approval from the Obama administration.

Walker's plan, if implemented, would continue to channel federal subsidies to Wisconsin's uninsured population, but would provide them with the flexibility to choose their insurance providers. The governor argues that this approach is about accessibility and affordability, and not about the government playing a heavier role in health care decisions.

However, the proposal faces opposition from the Obama administration, with President Obama stating that Republicans often criticize the Affordable Care Act but fail to offer viable alternatives. In a White House speech on Dec. 3, the President claimed that Republicans have yet to present a credible alternative to the current health care system.

Despite this criticism, several Republican politicians have proposed alternatives to the Affordable Care Act. These proposals, according to Ed Haislmaier of The Heritage Group, a conservative think tank, are consumer-driven, with individuals making their own health care choices rather than relying on a government-driven plan that caters to their needs.

Supporters of the Affordable Care Act argue that Republican counter-proposals lack the reach of the current system, with economist Jonathan Gruber stating that he has yet to hear a Republican alternative that covers as many uninsured individuals or offers evidence-based solutions to the health care cost crisis.

The debate continues as both sides strive to find a solution that addresses the needs of the uninsured and the concerns of the American people.

Title: House Judiciary Committee to Vote on Subpoenas for Mueller Report and Witnesses' Testimony

Article:

The House Judiciary Committee is set to vote on subpoenas this week, seeking the full, unredacted Russia report from Special Counsel Robert Mueller, as the Justice Department appears to be missing the April 2 deadline for the report's release. The Judiciary panel plans to vote on subpoenas on Wednesday, a day after the deadline.

Chairmen of several House committees requested the full, unredacted report last week, following Attorney General William Barr's release of a four-page summary outlining the report's principal conclusions. Barr stated in a letter to the House and Senate Judiciary committees on Friday that a redacted version of the full 300-page report would be released by mid-April, "if not sooner."

The planned committee vote, announced Monday morning, would not automatically issue subpoenas but authorize House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler (D-N.Y.) to send them if he decides to do so.

"As I have made clear, Congress requires the full and complete special counsel report, without redactions, as well as access to the underlying evidence," Nadler said in a statement. "Attorney General Barr has thus far indicated he will not meet the April 2 deadline set by myself and five other committee chairs, and refused to work with us to provide the full report, without redactions, to Congress."

The vote comes as Democrats are escalating their battle with the Justice Department over the amount of the report they will be able to see—a fight that could potentially end up in court. Democrats have stated they will not accept redactions and will likely be unhappy with the amount of information provided by Barr when the department releases the report in the coming weeks.

In addition to the Mueller report, the panel will also vote Wednesday to authorize subpoenas related to a number of President Donald Trump's former top advisers, including strategist Steve Bannon, Communications Director Hope Hicks, Chief of Staff Reince Priebus, White House Counsel Donald McGahn, and counsel Ann Donaldson. Donaldson served as McGahn's chief of staff before both left the administration.

The five were key witnesses in Mueller's probe of possible obstruction of justice, and were sent document requests by the Judiciary panel last month. Nadler expressed concern about reports that documents relevant to Mueller's investigation "were sent outside the White House," potentially waiving executive privilege rights that would block document production.

"To this end, I have asked the committee to authorize me to issue subpoenas, if necessary, to compel the production of documents and testimony," Nadler said.

Nadler sent requests to 81 people connected to Trump's political and personal dealings as he launched a wide-ranging investigation into possible obstruction of justice, public corruption, and abuses of power.

Barr stated in the letter on Friday that he is scrubbing the report to avoid disclosing any grand jury information or classified material, in addition to portions of the report that pertain to ongoing investigations or that "would unduly infringe on the personal privacy and reputational interests of peripheral third parties."

Democrats say they want all of that information, even if some of it cannot be disclosed to the public. They are citing precedents from previous investigations involving presidents and information disclosed about the Russia investigation to Republicans last year when they held the House majority.

If the committee does issue subpoenas, the path forward is uncertain. If the administration decides to fight, lawmakers could ask federal courts to step in and enforce a subpoena—a fight that could, in theory, reach the Supreme Court. Generally, such disputes are instead resolved through negotiations.

The Democrats could also formally ask Mueller to send the Judiciary committee evidence that could be used in possible impeachment proceedings against Trump. However, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, backed by the majority of her caucus, has said she is not currently supportive of impeachment.

Barr wrote in his summary that the special counsel did not find that Trump's campaign "conspired or coordinated" with the Russian government to influence the 2016 presidential election. He said Mueller reached no conclusion on whether Trump obstructed the federal investigation, instead setting out "evidence on both sides" of the question.

Barr himself went further than Mueller in his summary letter, declaring that Mueller's evidence was insufficient to prove in court that Trump had committed obstruction of justice to hamper the probe.

Democrats say they want to know much more about both conclusions and they want to see the evidence unfiltered by Barr.

"Judiciary Democrats have escalated from setting arbitrary deadlines to demanding unredacted material that Congress does not, in truth, require and that the law does not allow to be shared outside the Justice Department," said Georgia Rep. Doug Collins, the top Republican on the Judiciary committee.

Title: Major Republican Presidential Candidates Gather for Debate in New Hampshire

Article:

The next Republican presidential debate is set to take place tonight at St. Anselm's College Institute of Politics in Manchester, New Hampshire, and will be broadcast on ABC. The debate coverage is scheduled to begin at 8 pm Eastern, although it remains uncertain if the debate will commence immediately or slightly later. Viewers can watch a live stream of the event online at ABCNews.go.com.

After skipping the last GOP debate and losing the Iowa caucuses, Donald Trump has confirmed his attendance at this debate. Joining him will be Iowa caucus winner Ted Cruz and Iowa "media winner" Marco Rubio, whose strong performance in the caucuses has boosted his chances of securing the nomination in the eyes of political elites. Ben Carson, who finished fourth in Iowa and whose campaign has been in decline for months, will also be present, although his campaign appears to be nearing its end.

In addition to these candidates, there are three others—Jeb Bush, John Kasich, and Chris Christie—who are hoping for a strong showing in Tuesday's New Hampshire primary to keep their campaigns alive. Bush, Kasich, and Christie, who are all establishment-friendly candidates, are considered rivals to Rubio, who performed significantly better in Iowa. Expect these candidates to make a final effort to undermine Rubio during tonight's debate.

On the other hand, the debate offers Rubio a significant opportunity to outshine his establishment rivals before the New Hampshire primary. If Rubio outperforms Bush, Kasich, and Christie in the Granite State, they are likely to exit the race soon, paving the way for Rubio to emerge as the mainstream Republican alternative to Trump and Cruz. If Rubio falters in New Hampshire, however, the race may remain uncertain for a while longer.

Since the GOP field has narrowed, there will be no undercard debate for candidates who are not polling as well this time around. Unfortunately, Carly Fiorina missed ABC's polling cutoff to qualify for this debate, making her and former Virginia governor Jim Gilmore the two remaining candidates who will be excluded.

Title: The Influence of Individual Voting in the American Electoral College: A Neutral Analysis

Article:

In the midst of the heated 2016 presidential race, an intriguing conversation unfolded between a libertarian-leaning American and a journalist. Despite the American's support for Hillary Clinton, the journalist expressed his intention to vote for the Libertarian Party's candidates, Gary Johnson and William Weld. The American responded, "Opportunity cost is Trump gets elected."

This conversation highlights the unique nature of the American Electoral College system, where an individual's vote, even in states with a significant influence, may not determine the outcome of the presidential race. In South Carolina, where the journalist resides, a vote for Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump would not tip the scale in their favor, as the outcome would have already been decided in other states.

The Electoral College system makes it highly improbable for a single vote to sway a state's electoral outcome. In the closest state presidential election of the last half-century—New Mexico in 2000—the final margin for Al Gore was 366 votes, and even that did not determine the national winner.

Assuming that one lives in a red or blue state, their vote becomes insignificant in determining the election's outcome. According to the prediction site FiveThirtyEight, states like Florida, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin have a combined estimated 44.8% chance to decide the election. When other swing states such as North Carolina, Virginia, Colorado, Minnesota, Georgia, Nevada, and Iowa are accounted for, the states with as much as a 2% chance to determine the outcome are eliminated, leaving 67% of the U.S. population in a "safe harbor."

In this context, Americans cast their presidential endorsements with less research and consideration than they would for choosing a smartphone data plan or their next Pokemon Go venue. This phenomenon is known as "rational ignorance."

However, the Electoral College system allows Americans to exercise their judgment worry-free, as their vote will not change the nation's fate. Voting for third-party candidates, in this sense, can be seen as a guilt-free option.

Moreover, voting for minor parties can help put the system on notice that the Big Two political party choices are being rejected. The classic example is the Socialist Party, which garnered a mere 2% of the total votes in the 1932 election but influenced the New Deal's policies in the following decade.

In the 2016 campaign, the journalist, living in a non-swing state, is insulated from liability by the Electoral College. With two major party candidates deemed undesirable, voting for the Libertarians, who have an exceedingly slim chance of victory, will be the least complicated choice. This choice will allow the journalist to indulge their conscience without the burden of determining the nation's fate.

Title: Trump and Pence Unveiled as Republican Ticket in New York City

Article:

In a whirlwind 48 hours that saw a leaked vice presidential pick and late-night calls from Donald Trump in search of an escape hatch, the presumptive Republican nominee and Indiana Governor Mike Pence shared the limelight on Saturday in a joint appearance at the Hilton hotel in midtown Manhattan.

The event, which was initially scheduled for a rollout of Trump's vice presidential pick but was ultimately unceremoniously announced on Twitter, took place at the same location where Ronald Reagan announced his 1980 presidential bid, with all the pomp and circumstance of a long-awaited union.

Trump, in a 30-minute address, focused on bashing his Democratic opponent, Hillary Clinton, and weighed in on recent global conflicts, including the attempted military coup in Turkey. He praised the Turks, expressing hope that the situation would improve.

"Indiana Governor Mike Pence was my first choice," Trump said, despite reported struggles to choose between an establishment-pleasing pick and two men with whom he had better rapport. The rollout, which was accompanied by a website redesign to include Pence's face and a new logo, sounded like any other Trump address.

Pence, a disciplined, conservative Republican with close-cropped white hair and a strong mandible, represented a stark contrast to Trump. He read from prepared remarks with designated moments for applause, addressing policy differences and on-the-fence Republicans who may have struggled to accept a former reality television star as their party's standard-bearer.

Pence told the crowd that Trump had called him with the decision on Wednesday night, countering the narrative Trump presented to the media on Thursday, during which time he claimed he hadn't made his "final, final decision."

"These are good people," Pence said of Trump and his family. "And Trump will make a great president of the United States of America."

The two men's policy differences have played out on social media, with Pence tweeting his support of the Trans Pacific Partnership in 2014, something that Trump is adamantly against. In December 2015, Pence tweeted that calls to ban Muslims from entering the U.S. were offensive and unconstitutional, in response to an initial proposal from Trump. However, during his first interview as Trump's vice presidential pick, Pence expressed support for Trump's call to temporarily suspend immigration from countries where terrorist influence and impact represent a threat to the United States.

Before the two men appear together once again at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland next week, the governor is returning to Zionsville, Indiana on Saturday for what is billed as a "Welcome Home Rally" according to the Trump campaign. Trump will not be in attendance.

Roger Stone, a one-time adviser for Trump, praised the event, texting The ███ after the event, "It was strong. A winning ticket!" Michael Caputo, an adviser who resigned from Trump's campaign last month, echoed Stone's remarks, stating, "Pence's speech was solid, exceptionally well written and delivered expertly. I think he made perfectly clear what he can do for this ticket. His speech was a rousing call to arms for Republicans and a full volume defense of Donald Trump. Mission accomplished."

Title: House Republicans Vote to Cancel Obama's Deportation Amnesties: A Constitutional and Political Battle

Article:

In a highly charged and symbolic move, the House of Representatives voted Thursday to repeal President Obama's executive actions on deportation, which granted temporary legal status and work permits to over 4 million undocumented immigrants. The vote, which was met with strenuous opposition from Democrats, was framed by House Speaker John A. Boehner as an attempt to uphold the rule of law and the Constitution.

During the debate, Boehner read 22 quotes from President Obama denying he had the power to act unilaterally on immigration matters. The president had exercised this power last year when he announced the amnesty for more than 4 million illegal immigrants and a smaller amnesty for Dreamers, or young adults brought to the U.S. as children.

"We do not take this action lightly, but there is simply no alternative," Boehner said from the House floor. "This is not a dispute between parties, or even branches of government. The president's overreach is an affront to the rule of law and the Constitution itself."

Democrats, in turn, accused Republicans of mean-spiritedness, with Representative Linda T. Sanchez of California, chairwoman of the House Hispanic Caucus, saying, "As a country, we're better than this. Shame on you."

The vote to repeal the November amnesty was 237-190, with seven Republicans joining Democrats in opposition. The vote to repeal the amnesty for Dreamers was less popular, passing on a 218-209 vote with 26 Republicans joining all Democrats in opposition.

White House officials and immigrant rights advocates fear the votes could send illegal immigrants back into the shadows. However, Cecilia Munoz, Mr. Obama's domestic policy director, said the White House will make it clear to illegal immigrants that the president will not be deterred.

"At the end of the day, we are confident we are going to be implementing these executive actions," she said.

The courts could have the final say, as several challenges have been filed, including one in Texas, where 25 states have sued, arguing that they will have to fund billions of dollars worth of services to illegal immigrants if the president's plans are allowed to stand. A judge will hold a hearing Thursday on the states' request for an injunction.

Wednesday's fight was part of the debate on a bill to fund the Homeland Security Department and its immigration enforcement mission through the end of the fiscal year. That bill cleared the House on a 236-191 vote.

President Obama has vowed to veto the bill because it includes provisions repealing his amnesties, and Senate Democratic leaders said they will lead a filibuster to prevent the bill from reaching the president's desk. This would leave homeland security funding in limbo, with a Feb. 27 deadline looming.

Rank-and-file House Republicans acknowledged Wednesday that they aren't sure about the next step. "I don't know that there is a Plan B," said Rep. Peter T. King, a New York Republican who voted for the amendment to repeal the November amnesty but against the plan to scrap the Dreamer amnesty. "It's a work in progress."

Mr. King said there are six weeks to go before the deadline, which gives all sides a chance to work out an agreement. House and Senate Republicans will gather Thursday and Friday in Pennsylvania for a policy retreat, where immigration is bound to take up much of the discussion.

Rep. Mario Diaz-Balart, a Florida Republican who opposed both amnesty amendments, said the effort was a waste because Republicans don't have the votes to override a presidential veto.

"I wish that wasn't the case. I wish President Obama was not in the White House," he said.

All sides said Wednesday's votes were momentous political statements and served as a signal of how much the immigration debate has changed over the past year. House Republicans entered their annual policy retreat last year with Mr. Boehner announcing principles for tackling immigration, including legalizing the Dreamers and figuring out a solution for the rest of the illegal immigrant population. This year, Mr. Boehner led the charge to repeal the amnesty for Dreamers and to step up enforcement of immigration laws.

Republicans said the moves should be seen as statements on the Constitution and separation of powers, not as attacks on immigrants. Democrats, however, said Hispanic voters won't see it that way.

Rep. Luis V. Gutierrez, an Illinois Democrat who has been a staunch advocate for legalizing illegal immigrants, chided Republicans for backtracking on Mr. Boehner's stance to legalize Dreamers.

"One year later, you want to take away from 600,000 Dreamers their right to live in this country. What happened? What happened?" Mr. Gutierrez said.

He vowed to make sure Hispanic voters punish Republicans for the votes: "The fruits of your action today will ultimately anger and outrage and [ mobilize ] the immigrant community throughout this nation."

Democrats pointed to missives from the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops, the AFL-CIO, and Hispanic rights groups who all blasted the amendments. The bishops said deporting illegal immigrants would fracture families, and labor unions said the moves were "anti-immigrant."

Title: U.S. Job Market Shows Modest Growth in August, Unemployment Rate Decreases

Article:

The U.S. job market showed a slowdown in August, with the economy adding 96,000 jobs, down from 141,000 jobs in July, according to the Department of Labor's report released on Friday. The unemployment rate also decreased to 8.1%, from 8.3% in July.

Economists polled by CNNMoney had expected 120,000 jobs to be added in August, and the unemployment rate to remain unchanged. The unemployment rate fell largely because 368,000 people stopped looking for work, many of them young people. Just 63.5% of the working-age population was either employed or actively looking for work, a 30-year low.

"These numbers are not very strong," said Joseph LaVorgna, chief U.S. economist at Deutsche Bank. "The job market is improving, but only gradually." At least 150,000 jobs need to be created each month to simply keep pace with the growing population.

In addition to the large number of people leaving the workforce, LaVorgna said two other disappointing signs were that the number of hours people worked remained flat and wages were stagnant. The Labor Department also revised down the job numbers for the two previous months, resulting in 41,000 fewer jobs created than originally reported.

"Clearly, it's disappointing, but it's not horrible," said Scott Brown, chief economist at the investment management firm Raymond James. "We're not losing jobs."

Employment in restaurants and bars increased by 28,000, a sign that people may have more disposable income. Professional and technical service jobs rose by 27,000, and the health care industry added 17,000 jobs. In August, manufacturing was particularly hard hit, shedding 15,000 jobs. The government continued to shed jobs, losing another 7,000 positions.

The weak numbers could also increase the chances that the Federal Reserve will take more action to boost the struggling economy. The overall job market still has a long way to go to recover from the financial crisis. Three years after the recession ended, roughly 12.5 million Americans remain unemployed, and 40% of them have been so for six months or more.

Title: NLRB's Position on Micro-Unions Threatens U.S. Manufacturing Jobs, Critics Argue

Article:

In a move that has raised concerns among critics, the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) has stated that employers' concerns about the proliferation of small bargaining units being detrimental to their operations are "irrelevant" under U.S. labor law. This position was put forward by Acting General Counsel Lafe Solomon in a brief to the Fourth Circuit, defending the Obama-era Board's controversial decision, Specialty Healthcare, which changed 76 years of Board law.

The decision, made in 2011, authorized unions in all industries to represent bargaining units of as few as two or more employees doing the same job in the same location. The Board's decision threatens an undue proliferation of bargaining units, a concern that Congress, state labor boards, and other nations have warned about for years.

Since its inception in 1936, the NLRB has recognized that an undue proliferation of bargaining units causes unnecessary work stoppages and is inconsistent with the long-term goals of collective bargaining. The Board has favored larger units and sought to avoid a multiplicity of smaller units.

During Senate debate in 1974 on extending the Board's jurisdiction to cover non-profit health care institutions, Senator Harrison A. Williams (D-NJ) recognized this fact. He applauded the NLRB and said that, as a rule, it has "generally tended to avoid the unnecessary proliferation of bargaining units."

In 1989, the NLRB proposed adopting a rule that would make a single facility unit presumptively appropriate. In its Notice of Proposed Rulemaking, the NLRB stated that the employees' desire for a single facility unit (as opposed to the employer's desire for a multi-facility unit) "might be outweighed by concerns over disproportionate, unjustified costs and undue proliferation of units."

Congress has consistently taken a position against undue proliferation. During the debates over expanding the Board's jurisdiction to include non-profit health care institutions, Congress expressly cautioned the NLRB against an undue proliferation of bargaining units that would cause unnecessary work stoppages and threaten patient care.

The Board's brief, however, draws from this caution the preposterous conclusion that a multiplicity of bargaining units in all other industries is an "irrelevant" consideration under U.S. labor law.

Critics argue that the Board's position threatens American manufacturing jobs, as the proliferation of small bargaining units can lead to unnecessary work stoppages, increased costs, and labor instability. The Board's actions have been criticized for contributing to a chill on job creation and undermining the long-term goals of collective bargaining.

The political leadership at the NLRB reflects the priorities of the President who appointed it. The same Acting General Counsel whose office authored this brief filed suit to stop The Boeing Company from building new Dreamliner aircraft in the $1 billion plant Boeing built for that purpose in South Carolina. The same NLRB that authorized micro-unions has issued decision after decision that have radically changed Board law to benefit unions without regard for their impact on workers and businesses.

Title: President Obama Remains Optimistic on Obamacare Popularity Despite Public Disapproval

Article:

In an interview with The New York Times, President Barack Obama expressed his belief that the Affordable Care Act, commonly known as Obamacare, will gain public approval as it is implemented. Despite polls indicating that the majority of Americans dislike the health care law, Obama maintains that once individuals are required to purchase health insurance or face a penalty, they will come to appreciate the law.

However, the President acknowledged the challenges in changing public opinion, stating, "Until we're getting outspent four to one and people are just uncertain about what all this means for them, we're going to continue to have some polls like that." He further explained that more speeches explaining the law would not be enough to change public sentiment, and instead, the success of the law would be the deciding factor in its popularity.

Despite the President's optimism, it appears that a new PR campaign may not be enough to sway public opinion. Obama stated, "Over the course of six months to a year, as people sign up, and it works, and lo and behold, the people who already have health insurance are not being impacted at all other than the fact that their insurance is more secure and they are getting free preventive care, and all the nightmare scenarios and the train wrecks and the'sky is falling' predictions that come from the other side do not happen, then health care will become more popular."

However, critics argue that Americans are well-informed about the potential implications of Obamacare and that the penalty may not be worth it for many. The President's optimism seems to be based on the assumption that the law will function as intended and that the negative predictions about its implementation will not come to pass.

Title: ObamaCare Enrollment Data Suggests High Number of Previously Insured Americans

Article:

A significant number of the more than 2 million Americans who signed up for health insurance under ObamaCare by the end of December were already enrolled in employer-sponsored plans or had previously bought their own coverage, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal on Friday.

Early data from insurers, brokers, and consultants indicate that the marketplaces are popular with consumers who were previously covered elsewhere, raising questions about the Affordable Care Act's intent to expand coverage to millions of uninsured Americans.

A survey by management consulting firm McKinsey & Co. found that only 11 percent of consumers who purchased new coverage under ObamaCare were previously uninsured. The survey was based on a sampling of 4,563 consumers between November and January.

HealthMarkets Inc., an insurance agency that signed up about 7,500 people in exchange plans, reported that 65 of its enrollees had prior coverage. Fifteen percent of enrollees had their individual plans canceled, and 40 percent switched over from previous individual plans.

David M. Cordani, chief executive of insurer Cigna, told The Wall Street Journal that one of the objectives of the law was to address the uninsured problem in the country. However, some insurers said the early data on newly insured consumers is falling short of expectations.

Insurers in Michigan expected 400,000 of the state's 1.2 million uninsured people to join private plans this year, according to an analysis provided by Michigan-based Priority Health. As of the end of December, only 76,000 people had signed up, many of whom were previously covered, according to the report.

Geoff Bartsh, vice president for policy at Minneapolis-based Medica Health Plans, told The Journal, "I don't know we're growing the number of people with insurance here, so much as we're just adding complexity."

Federal health officials told The Journal they do not yet know the number of people who have signed up for coverage through the exchanges who had insurance when they enrolled. Consumers have until the end of March 31 to purchase plans under ObamaCare.

Aaron Albright, a spokesman for the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, said, "We are in the middle of a sustained six-month open-enrollment period, and we have seen a strong interest in the product overall across the range of demographics so far."

According to the report, adults ages 55-64 were the most heavily represented in the signups, accounting for 33 percent of the total. Nationwide, the premiums paid by people in that demographic do not fully cover their medical expenses. Some are in the waiting room for Medicare, which starts at age 65.

Young adults from 18 to 34 are only 24 percent of total enrollment, the Obama administration said Monday in its first signup figures broken down for age, gender, and other details. Enrolling young and healthy people is important because they generally pay more into the system than they take out, subsidizing older adults.

Title: Democratic Lawmakers Call for Gun Control Measures in Response to School Shootings

Article:

In the aftermath of the tragic school shootings in Connecticut, Democratic lawmakers and Independent Senator Joe Lieberman have called for a renewed discussion on gun control, including a ban on military-style assault weapons and a comprehensive review of the nation's approach to mental health care.

Following the shooting that left 20 children aged 6 or 7 dead, several Democratic lawmakers and Senator Lieberman have emphasized the need for a deeper examination of the recent spate of mass shootings and potential preventive measures. The last significant gun control legislation, a 10-year ban on assault weapons, was enacted in the early 1990s, but since its expiration in 2004, stricter gun laws have not gained widespread support, with politicians expressing concerns about facing opposition from powerful gun-rights lobby groups.

Gun-rights advocates have remained largely silent on the issue since the shooting, with the exception of Senator Joe Manchin, a lifelong member of the National Rifle Association, who has called for a discussion on gun policy and a move towards gun regulation. Manchin, a conservative West Virginia Democrat, has expressed support for New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg's proposal to ban the sale of assault weapons.

President Barack Obama, during a Sunday night service in Newtown, Connecticut, did not specifically address gun control but vowed to engage citizens, including law enforcement, mental health professionals, parents, and educators in an effort to prevent future tragedies. He questioned whether the nation was prepared to accept such violence as the price of freedom and urged citizens to take action.

Senator Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., suggested that the nation could be at a "tipping point" for gun control, with the potential for significant action on the issue. Schumer, along with other Democrats and Senator Lieberman, has proposed banning the sale of new assault weapons and making it more difficult for mentally ill individuals to obtain weapons. Lieberman has also suggested creating a new commission to examine gun laws, the mental health system, and the role of violence in media.

Senator Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., has announced plans to introduce legislation next year to ban new assault weapons and large-capacity magazines. Feinstein expressed confidence in reinstating the ban despite strong opposition from the National Rifle Association and similar groups.

Mayor Bloomberg has suggested that President Obama could use executive powers to enforce existing gun laws and support legislation like Feinstein's. Bloomberg stated that it was time for the president to lead and outline the necessary steps to address gun violence.

Gun-rights activists have been largely absent from the Sunday talk shows, with only Representative Louie Gohmert, R-Texas, appearing to defend the sale of assault weapons and argue that violence is lower in cities with lax gun laws. However, gun-control advocates dispute this claim, citing studies that show states with the strongest gun laws have lower gun death rates.

In response to the shooting, the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence has called for a renewed commitment to gun control and a reevaluation of the role of guns in society. The organization has emphasized the need for comprehensive solutions that address both gun control and mental health care.

Title: Tragedy Strikes Chabad of Poway Synagogue: Community Mourns, Heroism Recounted, and Anti-Semitism Under Scrutiny

Article:

WASHINGTON – The tranquility of Southern California was shattered this weekend with a deadly shooting at a synagogue near San Diego. On Sunday night, hundreds gathered for a vigil where Rabbi Yisroel Goldstein, a survivor of the attack, recounted the harrowing events that unfolded.

"Unfathomable," said Rabbi Goldstein, "I faced death face to face."

The attack at Chabad of Poway left one fatality, 60-year-old Laurie Kaye, and three injured, including Rabbi Goldstein himself. The youngest victim was eight-year-old Noya Duhan, who had recently moved from southern Israel where her village was subject to rocket attacks from Gaza.

Rabbi Goldstein believes the shooting would have been much worse had it not been for a "miracle" – the shooter's gun jammed. The rabbi also credits members of his congregation for risking their lives to stop the shooter, identified as 19-year-old John T. Earnest.

Oscar Stewart, an off-duty border patrol agent, described his actions in the aftermath of the shooting. "He dropped his weapon and he ran out, and I chased him out of the sanctuary," Stewart said.

Police eventually arrested Earnest about a mile from the synagogue. In an open letter posted online under Earnest's same name, he expressed his desire to kill Jews and praised the gunmen accused in both the Pittsburgh synagogue shooting and recent mosque attacks in New Zealand. Police say Earnest was also being investigated in connection to an arson attack at a California mosque.

President Trump called Rabbi Goldstein to offer his condolences and also condemned the shooting at a weekend rally in Wisconsin. "We forcefully condemn the evil of anti-Semitism and hate which must be defeated," said Trump.

Following the shooting, the World Jewish Congress called out the New York Times for publishing a cartoon in its international edition showing Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu leading a blind President Trump. The World Jewish Congress tweeted, "The @nytimes has crossed a red line today by publishing a cartoon infused with anti-Semitic tropes."

Following fierce backlash, the New York Times retracted the cartoon and issued an apology.

With anti-Semitism on the rise in America and worldwide, Michael Rydelnik, an expert on anti-Semitism at the Moody Bible Institute, told ███ News, "It's like a contagious disease that always under the surface and sometimes it spurs up into epidemic proportions and then sometimes it recedes."

Earnest has been charged with murder and will also likely face federal hate crime charges.

Title: Pelosi-Trump Tensions Escalate as Shutdown and Security Concerns Collide

Article:

In a series of escalating events, the ongoing standoff between Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi and President Donald Trump has taken a new turn, with the border security debate and security concerns for high-ranking officials at the center.

Democrats are grappling with the need to assert their stance on border security, acknowledging that they have, to some extent, allowed President Trump to dictate the narrative. Representative Ro Khanna, a Democrat from California, stated, "People want to ensure that it's clear that the Democrats do stand for border security, and not allow the president to determine how we talk about it. We can't cave to his vision for a wall, because of everything that it represents, but we also want to show that we're for something."

The issue arose during a Democratic caucus meeting this week, as Pelosi briefed rank-and-file lawmakers about her latest criticism of Trump over the government shutdown. Her letter requesting a delay or cancellation of the State of the Union address this month due to the security measures required by federal workers working without pay, was met with Trump's response to prevent Pelosi from using a military plane for her trip.

Trump's letter detailing this step also disclosed Pelosi's itinerary, which was kept confidential due to security reasons, particularly when it involves travel to war zones and high-ranking leaders like the speaker, who is second in line to the presidency.

Pelosi addressed reporters at the Capitol, stating, "You never give advance notice of going into a battle area—you just never do." She added, "The people around him, though, should have known that. That's very dangerous."

After rushing to salvage the trip by making alternative travel arrangements to fly commercial, Pelosi eventually canceled the trip due to a heightened State Department threat assessment and concerns about leaks compromising the safety of those involved.

A White House official on Friday denied the charge, stating that there was no way for Pelosi to keep her trip a secret and that any suggestion of a leak "is a flat-out lie."

The latest developments underscore the growing tensions between the two leaders, as they navigate the complexities of the government shutdown and security concerns for high-ranking officials.

Title: Obama and Pena Nieto to Discuss Immigration and Security Issues at White House Meeting

Article:

In a bid to address the ongoing issue of illegal immigration and border security, President Barack Obama will meet with Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto at the White House on Tuesday. The discussion will primarily focus on the implementation of Obama's immigration action and border security measures.

According to a senior administration official, the leaders' agenda will include strategies to prevent a renewed surge of migrants this year and to minimize the number of people attempting the dangerous journey across the U.S.-Mexico border. The official also clarified that illegal immigrants already in the U.S. who aid their relatives in crossing the border will not be eligible for Obama's new deportation amnesty.

Mexican consulates are expected to play a significant role in informing Mexican immigrants about who qualifies and who does not qualify for the executive actions. The administration official stated that illegal immigrants from Mexico account for two-thirds of those who are eligible for deportation relief under Obama's action.

The official highlighted the progress made in strengthening the border with Mexico, attributing it to the cooperation between the U.S. and Mexico. The administration official also noted that the number of illegal immigrants entering the country is at a historical low, with the last such low recorded in the 1970s.

In addition to immigration and border security, the two leaders are expected to discuss other security issues, including the ongoing drug wars and the recent massacre of 43 students in Iguala. Human Rights Watch has urged President Obama to press his Mexican counterpart to investigate and prosecute abuses by Mexican security forces.
