The White House stated that the meeting will emphasize the importance of expanding dialogue and cooperation between the United States and Mexico on economic, security, and social issues, as well as underscoring the deep cultural ties and friendship that exist between the two countries.

Title: Obama Demonstrates Skillful Oratory in State of the Union Address, Yet Challenges Persist in Policy Implementation

The State of the Union address, a test of a president's political acumen, is not won by a strong hand or a weak one, but by the deftness of the player. This year, President Obama, facing a challenging political landscape, demonstrated a skilled performance in his fifth State of the Union address.

The president's hand was far from a powerhouse. Pre-speech coverage was dominated by low approval ratings and a dismal national mood. Despite improving macroeconomic indicators, the personal impact was minimal, and the "right-direction-wrong-track" poll question was decidedly pessimistic. The president's fifth year in office was marked by a series of setbacks, including the failure of gun control measures, the stalling of immigration reform, and the tumultuous rollout of Obamacare. On the foreign front, geopolitical challenges in Syria, Afghanistan, Iraq, Egypt, and South Sudan overshadowed potential breakthroughs, such as the Iran nuclear talks.

However, the president was not without cards to play. Congress, with an even lower public approval rating than the White House, bore the brunt of the public's disapproval following the federal government's partial shutdown in October. Polls showed strong public support for policies such as a higher minimum wage, extended benefits for the long-term unemployed, and new rules on immigration – precisely the policy fronts on which the president planned to press forward against strong Republican resistance.

In this downbeat context, and with the president's less-than-stellar public performances in recent months, expectations for this State of the Union were not high. Yet, the president, in his one-hour address to the nation, proved himself a skilled orator. He was brisk and confident, delivering a well-prepared speech that focused on "inequality of opportunity" rather than income inequality, as he had telegraphed.

The president also managed to avoid addressing several contentious issues, such as the National Security Agency scandal, the ongoing Obamacare rollout, and the immigration deportations that have angered immigrants' rights groups. Instead, he touched on various constituency buttons on issues such as climate change and environmental damage, and once again gave primacy to revamping the immigration laws.

In sum, the Obama who delivered the speech was a nimble and adaptable player. However, it is the tragedy of this presidency that, to date, he has not been nearly as adept at the less-dramatic business of actually dealing with Congress, the federal bureaucracy, the media, or any of other power centers – including foreign governments.

In recent weeks, the president has added new staff in critical positions, including senior adviser John Podesta, a veteran of Bill Clinton's later years in the White House, and new faces in the legislative affairs office. There is some cause for hope that these new players will help the president extend his talent for presentation to produce more successes in policymaking.

Title: Dallas Court Finds Former Officer Amber Guyger Guilty of Murder in the Death of Botham Jean

Amber Guyger, the former Dallas police officer who was charged with the killing of Botham Jean in his own apartment last year, was found guilty of murder on Tuesday, according to The Dallas Morning News. The verdict came after a trial that began on September 23, 2019.

The jury's decision followed a trial in which the facts of the case were largely uncontested, but the verdict hinged on the interpretation of the "Castle Doctrine," a legal principle that allows for the use of deadly force when one is threatened in one's own home.

On the evening of September 6, 2018, Guyger, who was returning home after a long shift, mistakenly entered Jean's fourth-floor apartment, which was directly above her own. Finding the door unlocked, she shot the 26-year-old accountant, who was eating a bowl of ice cream, because she assumed he was an intruder.

Guyger was initially arrested on a manslaughter charge, which was later upgraded to a murder charge after review by the district attorney's office. She testified as the first witness for the defense last Friday, expressing remorse for the incident.

The lead investigator on the case, Texas Ranger David Armstrong, testified that in interviewing 297 of the 349 residents at the South Side Flats apartment complex where Guyger and Jean lived, 46 had accidentally entered the wrong floor and attempted to unlock their doors. Of those 46, 38 were from the third and fourth floors.

Prosecutors argued that Guyger acted rashly in her use of deadly force by not calling for backup and that she missed several signs she was on the wrong floor because she was distracted by sexually explicit messages from a fellow police officer with whom she was having an extramarital affair.

After the verdict was announced, attorneys for the Jean family held an impromptu press conference to praise the decision. Attorney Ben Crump said, "This verdict is for Trayvon Martin, it's for Michael Brown, it's for Sandra Bland, it's for Tamir Rice, it's for Eric Garner, it's for Antwon Rose, it's for Jemel Roberson, for EJ Bradford, for Stephon Clark, for Jeffrey Dennis, Genevieve Dawes, for Pamela Turner."

Jean's mother rejoiced as cheers broke out outside the courtroom when the verdict was announced. "God is good. Trust him," she said. Guyger remained standing until the jury left after announcing the decision, then fell into her chair.

Title: Dallas Jury Convicts Former Police Officer Amber Guyger of Murder in High-Profile Case

Article:

In a landmark decision, a Dallas jury found former police officer Amber Guyger guilty of murder on October 1, 2019, for the shooting of Botham Jean in his own apartment. The verdict came after a trial that drew national attention and highlighted the complexities of police shootings and the application of self-defense laws.

The jury's verdict is significant, not only because it brings justice to the tragic death of Jean, but also because it may signal a shift in the interpretation of self-defense laws in cases involving police officers. The jury's decision came despite a controversial jury instruction that allowed Guyger to argue the "Castle Doctrine," a Texas law that permits the use of force if another person is unlawfully and with force entering one's home. However, in this case, Guyger was the intruder, and Jean, the rightful occupant, had the legal right to use force against her.

The verdict is a potential turning point in the application of self-defense laws in police shooting cases. In many jurisdictions, officers are required to demonstrate that they used deadly force based on a "reasonable" belief that the suspect posed a threat of deadly force or serious bodily harm. However, in numerous cases, juries have applied an unwritten code that grants officers broad deference for their actions, often finding that any expression of fear by an officer justifies a shooting.

This unwritten code has led to questionable outcomes in cases such as the first trial of South Carolina officer Michael Slager, who shot an unarmed man fleeing, and the acquittal of the officer who shot Philando Castile during a traffic stop. In the Castile case, the officer's fear was partially based on the fact that Castile was smoking marijuana in the presence of a child, exposing him to secondhand smoke.

In the Guyger case, she argued the fear defense, claiming she felt "pure fear" upon entering Jean's apartment and believing he was going to kill her. However, her actions, which included immediately opening fire on an unarmed man, were not deemed reasonable by the jury.

The verdict in the Guyger trial is a crucial step towards ensuring that police officers are held accountable for their actions and that the law is applied equally to all individuals, regardless of their profession. It serves as a reminder that the use of force should be a last resort, not a first reaction, and that the fear of an individual, no matter their profession, should not be used to justify unreasonable actions.

Title: Democratic Operative Arrested for Alleged Battery on Nevada GOP Campaign Manager

Article:

A Democratic operative working for American Bridge 21st Century, a political action committee founded by David Brock and funded by liberal billionaire George Soros, was arrested Tuesday following an alleged battery incident involving the female campaign manager for Nevada GOP gubernatorial nominee Adam Laxalt.

Kristin Davison, the campaign manager for Nevada Attorney General Adam Laxalt, claimed that the operative, Wilfred Michael Stark III, 50, grabbed and yanked her arm, refusing to let go, leaving her "terrified and traumatized" and with visible bruises on her neck and arms.

According to the Laxalt campaign and local law enforcement, Stark was arrested by the Las Vegas City Marshals on Tuesday evening and is currently in custody at the Las Vegas city jail. The city marshal's office stated that the arrest was classified as a citizen's arrest, as the incident did not occur in the presence of the marshals.

The incident reportedly took place after a campaign event in East Las Vegas on Tuesday evening. Davison told reporters that a "very large man," later identified as Stark, "burst into the room" where Laxalt and she were speaking with a camera.

Davison alleged that Stark was physically aggressive, pushing her and members of her staff, screaming, and attempting to question Laxalt. Davison and her team left the room and entered an open one, but Stark reportedly followed and continued to be aggressive.

Davison claimed that, in the private room, Stark grabbed her right arm, twisted it behind her back, and contorted it. She was scared and tried to pull away, but Stark allegedly grabbed tighter and pulled her closer to him. Stark also reportedly pulled her head into his chest, bruising her neck, and held her there for several minutes.

Davison stated that she was screaming "stop—you're hurting me" during the incident. The Laxalt campaign described the incident as a "new low" in Nevada politics and accused the left of encouraging violence.

Stark has a history of arrests, including an incident earlier this year when he was arrested for allegedly assaulting the female press secretary for Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke. The latest confrontation took place after a campaign event in East Las Vegas on Tuesday evening.

American Bridge, the political action committee Stark works for, did not respond to requests for comment regarding the incident. It is unclear whether Stark was on the job for American Bridge during the confrontation, but he lists himself as a reporter for the group on his LinkedIn page.

Stark also has a record of arrests while working for American Bridge. In 2017, he was arrested for disorderly conduct at an event in Virginia while covering then-GOP gubernatorial candidate Ed Gillespie. He was found guilty of disorderly conduct in February of this year. The incident with Zinke's press secretary, Heather Swift, occurred in March at the Longworth House Office Building after a budget hearing before a House committee. Stark allegedly approached Swift and reportedly "used his full body to push" her as she tried to leave the room. Swift, who called the incident "terrifying," told police that she decided to press charges to help obtain a "stay-away order" against him.

"It's shocking to me that anyone in this business, no matter which party or issue you're working on, would keep someone on their payroll who has been consistently arrested for violence," Davison told reporters. "This is a terrifying incident."

American Bridge was founded in November 2010 by David Brock, who also founded liberal watchdog group Media Matters. The group's largest donor is liberal billionaire Soros, who donated more than $2 million between 2015 and 2016. Soros is still involved with the group, most recently donating $300,000 in February and $80,000 last year.

Title: Kavanaugh and Blasey Deliver Prepared Remarks Ahead of Senate Hearing

In the lead-up to the highly anticipated Senate Judiciary Committee hearing, both Judge Brett Kavanaugh and Dr. Christine Blasey Ford have released prepared remarks detailing their accounts of the alleged sexual assault incident that occurred in the 1980s.

Judge Kavanaugh, in his prepared remarks, acknowledged his past behavior, stating, "I drank beer with my friends, usually on weekends. Sometimes I had too many. In retrospect, I said and did things in high school that make me cringe now." He emphasized, however, that the allegations against him are "far more serious than juvenile misbehavior."

Dr. Ford, in her prepared remarks, expressed her apprehension about coming forward, stating, "I am here today not because I want to be. I am terrified." She plans to testify that it is her civic duty to share her account of the incident involving Judge Kavanaugh during their high school years.

In a significant development, Dr. Ford will assert that their friend groups had intersected during her freshman and sophomore years of high school, and they had attended parties together. This statement appears to counter the defense strategy of Judge Kavanaugh and his Republican allies who have questioned Dr. Ford's memory of the assailant's identity.

Other significant disclosures include the release of handwritten calendar notations from Judge Kavanaugh's high school days, affidavits from Dr. Ford's friends and husband, and a copy of the polygraph test administered in August. The polygraph test indicated no deception.

As the hearing approaches, supporters of both Dr. Ford and Judge Kavanaugh have prepared letters attesting to their integrity. Protesters have also organized rallies, and shadowy threats have been reported to key players involved in the drama. The hearing is set to take place on Thursday, September 27.

Title: Fox News Anchor Shepard Smith Debunks Uranium One Allegations Against Hillary Clinton

Article:

In a surprising turn of events, Fox News anchor Shepard Smith on Tuesday evening debunked the long-standing Uranium One allegations against former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, sparking fury among some Fox viewers. The segment, which delved into the complexities of the Uranium One deal, involved a comprehensive unraveling of the accusations that Clinton, while serving as Secretary of State, smoothed a deal involving US uranium mining, Russia, and the Clinton Foundation.

The story resurfaced this week due to the pressure on Attorney General Jeff Sessions to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the old allegations. Sessions, during a congressional hearing on Tuesday, hinted that there was no basis to do so. However, Smith's detailed and fact-based segment, albeit from an anchor who has previously been critical of Fox News's tendency to stoke stories that bolster President Trump and weaken Clinton, has left many in Fox's conservative audience questioning the validity of the claims.

One outraged Fox viewer took to Twitter, stating, "Get Shepard Smith off of Fox. He's arrogant and doing his own spin. Nobody knows how deep the left's conspiracy goes, and Shepherd Smith has ZERO inside info because nobody trusts him. OUT!"

In a lengthy segment, Smith outlined the original accusations, made in a book by a journalist for right-wing news website Breitbart, and Trump's use of these accusations to boost support during the campaign. He then took apart the claims, starting with the allegation that Clinton approved the sale of a Canadian company with large uranium mining interests in Wyoming to the Russian nuclear agency, in exchange for $140 million in donations to the Clinton Foundation from nine people involved in the business deal.

Smith explained that the deal required the approval of a committee formed from the heads of nine federal government agencies, and that President Obama, due to the national security implications of Russia holding any US uranium interests, under rules written during the Reagan administration, had the power to block the deal. Smith also pointed out that Clinton did not intervene to approve the deal and did not have the power to approve or block it.

Furthermore, Smith noted that none of the uranium mined in Wyoming by the Canadian company was exported to Russia, and the vast bulk of the donations to the Clinton Foundation were made by a man who had already sold his stake in the uranium company in 2007, years before the Russian deal went through and about 18 months before Clinton became Secretary of State.

As the segment progressed, Smith appeared to stumble over his script several times, acknowledging the complexity of the story and the potential backlash from viewers with a different political perspective. Despite this, Smith's segment provided a detailed and factual account of the Uranium One deal, challenging the narrative that has been perpetuated by some media outlets and political figures.

In conclusion, Shepard Smith's segment on Fox News provided a comprehensive and factual account of the Uranium One deal, debunking the long-standing allegations against Hillary Clinton. The segment, while likely to be met with resistance from some viewers, offers a more nuanced and accurate portrayal of the deal's complexities and the role of the Clinton Foundation in the process.

Title: Virginia Navigator Program Seeks $495,000 for Healthcare Market Outreach

Article:

The Virginia navigator program has requested a funding of $495,000, which represents approximately a third of the total navigator funds allocated for the state. This funding would cover the costs of seven and a half full-time navigators, necessary equipment, informational materials, marketing, and ongoing outreach events in five counties.

The federal government's allocation of funds for navigators in states operating their own insurance markets was not initially anticipated, resulting in a limited $54 million budget - transferred from a fund for public health prevention programs. The healthcare law had set aside significantly more money for states that built their own markets, assuming most would do so.

To address this funding gap, other organizations will also be involved in educating the uninsured and assisting with enrollment in health plans through the new markets. In total, about 1,200 community health centers nationwide, which provide medical care for the uninsured, have received a combined $150 million in federal funds for outreach and enrollment. Virginia's health centers received $2.5 million.

In addition to navigators, insurance agents or brokers, and insurance companies selling plans through the markets, will also play a role in the enrollment process. Northern Virginia Family Service plans to enlist a network of partner organizations, many of whom already work with the uninsured, to help with outreach and enrollment or provide space and other resources.

Christine Barber, a senior policy analyst at Community Catalyst, a consumer advocacy group, stated, "Other local groups may have funding or be in a position to get volunteers to do some of this work. Everyone is anxious to know who the navigators are so that other groups can partner with them, know who to refer people to, know how to flesh out their coalitions and their outreach."

Navigators, who will also assist small businesses and their employees in learning about and enrolling in health plans offered through the new markets, are prohibited from recommending specific health plans or receiving compensation from an insurance company. They will receive at least 20 hours of training and must pass a certification test.

Title: Shift in Strategy: Obama and Romney Focus on Mobilizing Core Voters in Tight Presidential Race

Article:

In the final stretch of the 2012 presidential election, both candidates, President Barack Obama and former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney, are focusing more on energizing their respective bases than on persuading undecided voters. This shift in strategy has led to a series of harsh exchanges between the candidates, with each accusing the other of divisive and negative campaigning.

The race has taken a more partisan turn, with the economy and qualifications giving way to ideology and personality. For months, Mr. Romney attempted to appeal to voters who were disappointed with President Obama but not necessarily angry at him. However, after a summer of attacks from the Democrats, Mr. Romney is now returning the scorching fire in an attempt to expand his support among Republicans who are eager to see President Obama out of office in November.

According to strategists from both parties, the traditional balance between motivating core supporters without scaring off independent voters may be different in this election cycle. A series of recent polls in six swing states showed that only 5 percent of voters are undecided, and only about 1 in 10 likely voters who have chosen a candidate are open to switching.

Joel Benenson, the chief pollster for President Obama's re-election campaign, stated, "There is a smaller slice of undecided voters out there than usual." He added, "Republicans may think that their only chance of winning this is by maximizing their base, but I don't believe this election is a base election."

For President Obama, there may be more opportunities to capture moderate voters who oppose the direction taken by Representative Paul Ryan, chairman of the House Budget Committee, and other House Republicans. However, Mr. Obama still needs to persuade some centrists that he can be trusted with the deficit and the economy and that he is not culturally out of step with them.

The strategic shifts by the candidates mirror a bigger change in the nature of the race. It is no longer solely a referendum on President Obama's economic record; rather, it is a choice between the future of Medicare, the popular health insurance program for retirees, and the role and scope of government.

The Romney campaign is testing whether it can expand the successful Republican coalition from 2010, when the party, on the basis of an anti-Obama and very conservative message, won control of the House and expanded its strength at all levels of government. It is not simply a base strategy, aides said, but a plan to capitalize on the rejection of President Obama's approach that they say is coursing through the country.

Neil Newhouse, the pollster for Mr. Romney, stated, "We're going to be able to make a very compelling argument to people in the middle that we need a change and Obama isn't the change they signed up for." He added, "When you really probe, people are upset with spending, the deficit, and the debt. It goes beyond jobs and the economy, and there is a sense things are out of control."

For Mr. Romney, several benefits of selecting Representative Ryan as his running mate have already become clear. He has finally drawn praise from conservatives, including those who have long been tepid. And he has become a stronger and more confident campaigner with a partner at his side, advisers say, who has an easygoing style that could help improve Mr. Romney's connection to voters.

The Romney campaign is taking pains to track down and quash any criticism in Republican circles about any potential downsides of Representative Ryan on the ticket, including that the campaign debate over Medicare is fraught with risk for other candidates in the party.

Interviews with nearly a dozen Republicans on Congressional and Senate campaigns said in near unison that they worried that the economic focus of the race had been overshadowed. It is a question that may not be answered until Election Day. Will a surge of conservative enthusiasm for the Republican ticket outweigh any potential falloff among voters who supported President Obama in 2008 and are open to changing their minds this year?

Title: U.S. Rep. Michael Grimm Indicted for Alleged Tax Fraud and Employment of Undocumented Workers

Article:

In a shocking turn of events, U.S. Representative Michael Grimm, a former FBI agent, has been indicted on over 20 charges, including wire fraud, perjury, and obstruction of justice. The charges stem from a health food restaurant, Healthalicious, that Grimm ran from 2007-2010.

At a press conference on Monday, Loretta Lynch, the U.S. Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, described the alleged conduct as "breathtaking." She accused Rep. Grimm of "succumbing to the allure of easy money and cheating his way to success."

The indictment alleges that Grimm paid some employees exclusively in cash and others partly in cash and partly through checks. This method allowed him to hide over $1 million in profits, thereby evading federal and state taxes, paying less for workers' compensation insurance, and hiring undocumented immigrants.

The indictment claims that Grimm concealed over $1.3 million in Healthalicious' gross receipts and employees' wages, fraudulently depriving the federal and New York State governments of sales, income, and payroll taxes.

Rep. Grimm is facing twenty criminal charges, all of which fall into the following nine categories: Obstructing and Impeding the Due Administration of the Internal Revenue Laws, Aiding and Assisting in the Preparation of False and Fraudulent Tax Returns (3-5). The indictment also accuses Grimm of lying under oath during a deposition for a lawsuit brought by former employees of Healthalicious who alleged they were being paid less than minimum wage.

In addition to the larger money-hiding scheme, Grimm "knowingly hired and knowingly continued to employ workers who did not have legal residency status and accordingly did not have valid authorization to work inside the United States," the indictment concludes.

Rep. Grimm's attorney, William McGinley, has denied the allegations, accusing the government of a "politically driven vendetta against Congressman Grimm and not an independent search for the truth."

The indictment threatens the political career of the sophomore lawmaker, who has faced a litany of ethics complaints and calls for his immediate resignation from watchdog groups like Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington. The indictment is a significant blow to Grimm's reputation as a key moderate voice in the House Republican conference.

Title: Senate Fails to Repeal Obamacare, Leaving Healthcare Law in Place

Article:

In a dramatic early-morning showdown on the Senate floor, the seven-year Republican quest to repeal the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, came to a halt on Friday. The bill to repeal key elements of the healthcare law was defeated 51-49, with three Republican senators joining Democrats in opposition. The vote dealt President Donald Trump a significant political setback.

Senator John McCain, the 80-year-old senator and 2008 Republican presidential nominee, cast the deciding vote. McCain, who is currently undergoing treatment for brain cancer, joined fellow Republicans Susan Collins and Lisa Murkowski in voting against the legislation.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, whose reputation as a master strategist was diminished, said on the Senate floor after the vote, "It's time to move on."

Speaker of the House of Representatives Paul Ryan said fellow Republicans should not give up on healthcare, but cited other pressing issues that needed attention, including major tax-cut legislation sought by Trump.

The Senate's inability to repeal Obamacare raises questions about the Republican Party's ability to govern, as they control the White House, Senate, and House of Representatives. Trump has not had a major legislative victory after more than six months in office, and his administration is mired in investigations into contacts between his election campaign and Russia and high-level White House staff infighting.

The legislative agenda now includes spending bills for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 to avoid a government shutdown and raising the U.S. debt limit.

Trump expressed dismay at the bill's failure, saying, "I said from the beginning, let Obamacare implode and then do it (pass legislation). I turned out to be right. Let Obamacare implode."

Some lawmakers are urging a bipartisan effort to buttress the existing healthcare system. With the partisan divide as wide as ever in Washington, it remains to be seen if a bipartisan approach can get off the ground.

McCain said the defeated bill did not offer meaningful reform and that its defeat presents "an opportunity to start fresh" on legislation crafted by lawmakers in both parties.

Top congressional Democrats urged a bipartisan effort to fix problems in the Obamacare law without repealing it. "Change it, improve it, but don't just take a knife and try to destroy it and put nothing in its place," top Senate Democrat Chuck Schumer said.

Democratic Senator Bill Nelson said he was working with Republican Collins on a bipartisan effort on healthcare.

The failure to repeal Obamacare leaves the healthcare law in place, which must be overseen by an administration that is hostile to it. This leaves health insurers unsure of how long the administration will continue to make billions of dollars in Obamacare payments that help cover out-of-pocket medical expenses for low-income Americans.

The Blue Cross Blue Shield Association, which represents insurers across the country, said it would work to ensure a smooth open enrollment period from Nov. 1-Dec. 15 and stabilize the individual insurance market under Obamacare for the long term.

Shares of health insurers, which had fought against the bill's proposed repeal of the mandate that Americans obtain insurance, were up. Aetna Inc rose 0.9 percent, Anthem Inc gained 2.3 percent, and Humana Inc edged up 0.2 percent.

On Wall Street, shares of hospitals were mostly higher because of the dwindling prospects for big cuts in the Medicaid insurance program for the poor and disabled. Community Health Systems Inc rose 2.2 percent, HCA Healthcare Inc gained 0.6 percent, and Tenet Healthcare Corp edged up 0.1 percent. Republicans have long denounced Obamacare - which expanded Medicaid and created online marketplaces for individuals to obtain coverage - as an intrusion by government on people's healthcare decisions.

Veteran House Republican Tom Cole said he thought there were "a number" of other Republican senators who were uncomfortable with the Senate's healthcare legislation but were able to vote "yes" knowing McCain's vote would kill it.

Republican Senator Lindsey Graham, a close friend of McCain, met on Friday with Trump to discuss Graham's proposal to take tax money raised by Obamacare and send it back to the states in the form of healthcare block grants, the senator's office said.

Title: Shift in State Immigration Policies: A Cautious Approach Amid Changing Political Climate

Article:

The immigration debate in Washington may be heating up, but the fervor of two years ago has cooled in the states, where the push for broad "omnibus" immigration bills has given way to a more cautious approach due to shifting political currents and court decisions.

Immigrant-rights groups are now taking the offensive, passing laws such as Colorado's recent bill granting in-state college tuition rates to illegal immigrants and Illinois' law allowing driver's licenses for illegal immigrants.

Arturo Vargas, executive director of the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials, commented, "There has been a general reaction by folks to the impact that the Latino vote had in November—that people are thinking twice about the actions they take. Most of these pieces of legislation had been supported by Republican legislators, and I think people are thinking twice about whether this is a strategy the party wants to pursue."

Two years ago, the momentum was on the opposite side. Congress was stalemated, leaving conservative states to push ahead with their own laws aimed at managing illegal immigration, which they claimed cost them hundreds of millions of dollars and potentially endangered safety.

Arizona, in 2007, pioneered a law requiring all businesses to use the government's voluntary electronic worker verification system, followed by the 2011 enactment of SB 1070, a law imposing state criminal penalties for illegal immigrants and mandating police to check the status of those suspected of being in the country illegally.

South Carolina, Alabama, Georgia, and Indiana also passed similar laws. The Supreme Court upheld the worker verification law in 2011 and last year issued a significant ruling allowing the police checks to continue, though it struck down the state criminal penalties for illegal immigration. The court also warned it could revisit the police checks if the law is implemented in a discriminatory manner.

Now, many states are waiting to see what the courts and Congress will do next. Ann Morse, who runs the National Conference of State Legislatures' immigrant policy project, stated, "Interest in immigration is still high at the state level, but there are no longer the big omnibus bills."

Some states are debating new verification requirements for state services or for voting. However, where there is clear momentum, it appears to be on the immigrant-advocacy side. Colorado's General Assembly passed a bill earlier this month granting illegal immigrants in-state tuition rates for state colleges, and lawmakers there introduced another bill to repeal a 2006 law requiring police to cooperate with federal immigration agents.

Other states have moved to grant driver's licenses to the young adult illegal immigrants who received tentative legal status last year from President Obama. Several Republican attorneys general told The ███ last month that they consider immigration a national issue and want to see Washington take the lead.

Colorado Attorney General John W. Suthers said, "We have to look to the federal government to take the charge on immigration reform. The Arizona case and others are kind of mapping out what the states can do and what the federal government has to do."

However, Kris Kobach, the secretary of state in Kansas who was also a leading architect of Arizona's crackdown law, said he still sees an appetite to act. "I don't think the atmosphere in the state legislatures has changed at all," he said. "I think what we saw in 2011 and 2012 was the states that were the low-hanging fruit were already primed and ready to do something active. They've already taken steps, and are happy with those steps, and other states are moving to follow them."

Mr. Kobach argued that President Obama's move to grant legal status to illegal immigrant young adults last year created confusion for states, causing chaos about what other benefits they should be entitled to. "The Obama administration, through its illegal executive amnesty, is trying to have it both ways. They recognize that they have no power to grant lawful immigration status to illegal aliens, yet at the same time they are trying to tell the states to go ahead and give these illegal aliens driver's licenses," said Mr. Kobach, the lead attorney on a lawsuit by federal immigration agents challenging the policy.

He added that given President Obama's moves and the debate in Congress, state lawmakers who want to see a crackdown realize that the states are their only avenues for action. "The events since the start of the year have made it clear to state leaders that the only serious efforts to enforce the law are going to be at the state level," Mr. Kobach said. He also suggested that his home state of Kansas could repeal its in-state tuition rates for illegal immigrants.

Title: Senate Reaches Bipartisan Agreement on Gun Control Measures Following 14-Hour Filibuster

Article:

In a historic move, the United States Senate has agreed to hold votes on tighter gun control measures following a 14-hour filibuster led by Senator Chris Murphy (D-CT) on Thursday. The filibuster, which began on Wednesday, was a response to the mass shooting at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Florida.

Senator Murphy, who spearheaded the filibuster along with several colleagues, announced in the early hours of Thursday that a deal had been struck with Republican leaders to hold votes on key measures. These measures include expanding background checks and banning gun sales to individuals on the terror watchlist.

Senator Murphy tweeted, "I am proud to announce that after 14+ hours on the floor, we will have a vote on closing the terror gap & universal background checks." He further added, "This is one step. The fight is far from over. But there are millions of voices calling for change. And we can not stop pushing #Enough."

Senator Murphy had promised at the outset that he would remain on the Senate floor "until we get some signal, some sign that we can come together" on gun control. As the filibuster continued, updates and messages of support were posted on social media with the hashtags #enough and #holdthefloor.

The Connecticut senator evoked the Newtown school shooting in his state in 2012 in a plea that came as the presumptive Republican presidential candidate, Donald Trump, said he would meet with the National Rifle Association (NRA) about the terror watchlist and gun purchases.

The election-year fight over gun control pits strong proponents of the second amendment right to bear arms against those arguing for greater restrictions on the ability to obtain weapons. The Orlando shooter, Omar Mateen, was added to a government watchlist of individuals known or suspected of being involved in terrorist activities in 2013, but was removed from the database 10 months later.

The Senate has not made any significant changes to federal gun laws in nearly a decade. In April 2007, Congress passed a law to strengthen the instant background check system after a gunman at Virginia Tech who killed 32 people was able to purchase his weapons because his mental health history was not in the instant background check database.

Senator Murphy is seeking a vote on legislation that would let the government bar sales of guns and explosives to people it suspects of being terrorists. Senator Dianne Feinstein (D-CA) offered a similar version of the amendment in December, but the Republican-run Senate rejected the proposal on a near party-line vote. Senator Murphy also wants a vote to expand background checks.

Separately, Everytown for Gun Safety, a gun control group backed by former New York mayor Michael Bloomberg, is working on a compromise with Senator Patrick Toomey (R-PA), a Republican in a tough re-election race this year who has sought compromise in the past on gun control measures. By the end of the day, Toomey had introduced legislation that would direct the attorney general to create a new list of suspected terrorists who could be barred from buying weapons. However, Democrats immediately rejected that idea, saying it would create too much of a backlog.

Title: Trump Administration Exempts Keystone XL Pipeline from 'Buy American' Executive Order

Article:

In a move that balances business interests and infrastructure development, the Trump administration has decided to exempt the Keystone XL pipeline from the executive order requiring new pipelines to use American steel. The decision was made on the grounds that the pipeline is already under construction and, therefore, not covered by the executive order.

Speaking to reporters onboard Air Force One, White House spokeswoman Sarah Huckabee Sanders explained, "The Keystone XL Pipeline is currently in the process of being constructed, so it does not count as a new, retrofitted, repaired, or expanded pipeline."

The Keystone XL pipeline, first proposed in 2008, has been a contentious issue for over a decade. The Obama administration rejected the project, which would carry bitumen from the oilsands of Alberta to refineries on the Gulf Coast of the US, on environmental grounds in 2015. However, an executive order by Trump in January paved the way for construction on the pipeline to recommence.

The decision to allow the pipeline to proceed is seen as a triumph of business-friendly ideas over populist calls to "buy American and hire American." Forbes contributor Tim Worstall, senior fellow at the Adam Smith Institute, wrote in an opinion piece, "What we want is the pipeline that can be used at the least overall cost."

The Keystone XL pipeline is expected to add $5.7 billion to the economies of Oklahoma and Texas while the southern leg of the pipeline was under construction, according to the Institute for Energy Research. The southern section of the pipeline, which does not cross an international border and so did not require State Department approval, is already operational.

The Trump administration's decision to exempt the Keystone XL pipeline from the 'Buy American' executive order may be a temporary demonstration of pragmatism rather than a shift in policy. The move has been welcomed by supporters, who see it as a win for business and good economics. However, American steel will be a feature of future pipelines, according to White House spokeswoman Sanders.

The Canadian government has also praised the decision, with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's office calling it a "recognition that the integrated Canadian and US steel industries are mutually beneficial." The move may also potentially persuade TransCanada to drop a $15 billion NAFTA complaint against the US, which it brought after construction was suspended earlier this week.

Title: Mass Layoffs Across U.S. Industries: A Look at the Impact of Regulatory Burdens and Economic Policies

Article:

In recent weeks, a series of mass layoffs have been announced across various U.S. industries, with employers citing regulatory burdens and economic policies as primary factors. Last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported 1,316 "mass layoff actions" (affecting 50 workers or more) in September, with over 122,000 workers affected overall.

The slowest period of earnings growth since the third quarter of 2009 has reportedly contributed to the recent layoff activity. Ohio-based auto parts manufacturer Dana Holding Corp. warned employees of potential layoffs due to economic concerns, with President and CEO Roger Wood specifically mentioning the burden of increased taxes on small businesses and the need to offset costs from new laws and regulations.

One such regulation is the Affordable Care Act, or Obamacare. Dana Holding Corp., which employs some 24,500 workers, will incur approximately $24 million in additional U.S. health care expenses over the next six years due to Obamacare. The firm's Toledo area corporate offices recently laid off seven white-collar employees, with more expected.

Similarly, Consol Energy announced its intent to idle its Miller Creek surface operations near Naugatuck, W.Va., affecting 145 employees at the end of the year. The company attributes the impasse in permit approval process, primarily due to Obama's Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), as the cause for the layoffs.

In August, Robert E. Murray, founder and CEO of Murray Energy Corporation in Ohio, blasted the White House's anti-coal agenda for the layoffs and closure of his company's mine. Murray explained that the many regulations imposed by the Obama administration have closed 175 power plants.

The medical device industry has also been impacted by the impending 2.3 percent medical device excise tax. Companies such as Stryker, Covidien, Zoll Medical Corp., and Cook Medical Inc. have announced layoffs and plant closures due to the tax.

The heads of Koch Industries, Westgate Resorts, and ASG Software Solutions have also informed their employees of the negative impact of Obama's economic policies. Left-wing groups have criticized the executives for exercising their political free speech, but the White House has been accused of bribing federal defense contractors to delay federally mandated layoff disclosures before the election.

The administration's efforts to suppress truth and manipulate information have been a recurring theme, as seen in the past attempts to punish companies for disclosing the costs of Obamacare taxes on their bottom lines. The administration's bully tactics and economic policies continue to face criticism from various sectors of the U.S. economy.

Title: Common Core Faces Increased Public Opposition as Supporters Vow to Revamp Campaign

Article:

In a recent development, the Common Core standards have faced a significant setback as two national polls released this week indicate a decline in public support for the academic standards. The polls, conducted by Education Next and Phi Delta Kappa International, reveal a growing skepticism towards the Common Core, with a majority of respondents expressing opposition to its implementation in their local communities.

The Education Next poll, published by the conservative Hoover Institution, found a drop in support for the Common Core from 65% to 53% in the past year. The poll also showed that when the term "Common Core" was replaced with "standards for reading and math that are the same across the states," support for the standards increased to 68%, demonstrating a significant shift in public perception.

The Phi Delta Kappa International poll, released Wednesday, found that 80% of Americans have heard about the Common Core, with nearly half stating they know a fair amount about the standards. However, the familiarity has led to distrust, with 60% of respondents opposing the use of the Common Core to guide instruction in their community.

The opposition to the Common Core is driven by concerns about local control and teacher flexibility in the classroom. Over three-quarters of naysayers cited local teachers' lack of support for the standards as a reason for their opposition, and a majority expressed concern about the standards limiting teachers' flexibility.

In response to the growing opposition, Common Core supporters have vowed to revamp their campaign. On Friday, they will unveil their first step, which involves Latino evangelical pastors from across the country rallying their congregations behind the Common Core. The guest speaker at this event will be former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee, who has previously criticized the Common Core as a symbol of top-down federal intrusion into local schools.

Despite the challenges, Common Core backers have received some positive news from Louisiana, where a district judge recently rejected Governor Bobby Jindal's effort to repeal the standards by executive order. However, in Ohio, the Legislature is considering a bill to join the five other states that have repealed the standards in recent months.

The new polls highlight more than a year of high-profile opposition to the Common Core from various groups, including parent activists, tea party organizations, and politicians such as Jindal and Huckabee. The polls suggest that the public debate over the Common Core may be shifting, and Common Core supporters will need to address the concerns of the American public to regain support for the standards.

Title: Trump-Putin Meeting: U.S. President Accepts Russia's Denial of Election Interference, Sparks Controversy

Article:

In a high-profile meeting between President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin, the U.S. President appeared to accept Putin's denials of any election interference, a move that has sparked controversy and raised concerns about the integrity of the U.S. election process.

According to reports, Trump accepted Putin's denials at face value, despite the fact that the entire U.S. intelligence community believes the Kremlin mounted a sophisticated campaign to help Trump win the White House. This development is the most significant takeaway from the Trump-Putin meeting, as it gives the appearance that the Trump administration accepts that the Kremlin did not interfere in the election.

Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov revealed that Trump told Putin that some in the United States were "exaggerating" how much Russia affected the election's outcome, effectively dragging Moscow into Trump's partisan wars at home. The meeting took place amidst speculation about whether Congress would pass sanctions on Russia as punishment for its election meddling. Trump acknowledged the possibility of sanctions, but also expressed a desire to move past the issue.

The meeting's outcome was a win for Putin, as he got Trump to buy into his narrative on election interference and offer a weak endorsement of upcoming sanctions. The lack of preparation on Trump's part may have contributed to the outcome, as he reportedly had no notes or talking points, while Putin came prepared with notecards listing perceived American sins against Russia.

The meeting also resulted in a ceasefire in Syria's southwest, but it remains unclear what the ceasefire will achieve, as most of the fighting is in Syria's east and north. The ceasefire's effectiveness is also questionable, as much of the country's southwest has already been flattened.

Overall, the meeting has raised concerns about the U.S. President's approach to Russia and the election meddling issue. Critics argue that Trump may have done more damage by meeting with Putin than he would have done by staying home. The meeting has also sparked a renewed debate about the U.S. relationship with Russia and the extent of Russian involvement in the 2016 U.S. election.

Title: Whistleblower Lawyers Express Safety Concerns Amidst Calls for Identity Disclosure

Article:

In a letter sent to acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire, the lawyers for the intelligence official who filed a whistleblower complaint against President Trump have expressed "serious concerns" for their client's safety. The letter, signed by the whistleblower's lead attorney, Andrew Bakaj, and dated Saturday, was made public on Sunday.

The letter, as reported by NBC News, stated that recent events have heightened concerns that the whistleblower's identity will be disclosed publicly, potentially putting the individual in harm's way. The letter did not specify the events that led to this concern, but it is believed to be in response to President Trump's call for the person who provided the whistleblower with information to be identified.

Bakaj acknowledged that it was the unidentified whistleblower's source of information whom Trump's comment targeted. However, he wrote that the distinction does nothing to assuage their concerns for their client's safety. The lawyer also claimed that "certain individuals" had offered a $50,000 bounty for information about their client's identity.

The Washington Examiner, a conservative news outlet, reported last week that two right-wing activists had offered the sum for "credible information corroborating" the person's identity. On Sunday, the president suggested in a tweet that he wants the whistleblower to be outed.

The lawyers also called on lawmakers to speak out for whistleblower protections and insist that retaliation against the official—whether direct or implied—would not be tolerated, according to Business Insider. The letter stated that they expected the situation to worsen and become even more dangerous for their client and any other whistleblowers as Congress seeks to investigate this matter.

CBS News has reported that the whistleblower, identified by the New York Times as a CIA officer, was already under federal protection. However, Mark Zaid, a lawyer from Compass Rose Legal, tweeted that CBS "completely misinterpreted the contents of our letter," saying the legal team had not yet reached an agreement with Congress regarding contact with their client.

Rep. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.), chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, told ABC's "This Week" on Sunday that he expected the whistleblower to testify "very soon" once security measures were implemented to protect the person's identity. Last week, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced that the House would launch a formal impeachment inquiry in light of a July 25 phone call between Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.

A rough summary of the conversation revealed Trump's apparent efforts to get Ukraine to dig up dirt on former Vice President Joe Biden and his son Hunter, who served on the board of a Ukrainian gas company. On Thursday, the complaint by the whistleblower, who believed Trump was "using the power of his office to solicit interference from a foreign country" in the 2020 election, was released to the public.

The intelligence community inspector general, Michael Atkinson, deemed the Aug. 12 complaint "credible" and of "urgent concern" and passed it on to Maguire, who testified before the House Intelligence Committee. Maguire said that both the whistleblower and the inspector general "acted in good faith throughout" and "have done everything by the book and followed the law."

Title: The Struggle for Identity: Kamala Harris' Exit and the Divide in the Democratic Party

Article:

The Democratic Party is grappling with an identity crisis, as evidenced by the recent withdrawal of Senator Kamala Harris from the 2020 presidential race. For years, Harris was known as the "female Obama," but her campaign faltered in the primary race, with critics pointing to her attempt to appeal to both progressive and centrist factions within the party.

The Democratic primary has crystallized into a contest between the party's two wings, with candidates aligning on either side of the ideological and attitudinal divide. Harris, in an attempt to bridge the gap, was dismissed as an impostor by both camps.

The first group, personified most intensely by former Vice President Joe Biden and Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Indiana, are the Adjusters. They believe that the world was a good place in October 2016, and that removing President Donald Trump from office represents a necessary course correction that will allow the country to proceed upon the path that Barack Obama had outlined during his presidency. "We made a mistake," they say. "Let's just fix it and get back to normal."

The other movement is led by the Revolutionaries, with Senators Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders at the forefront. They see removing Trump from office as only the first step, which must be followed by sweeping, even radical change. Revolutionaries see Obama as an incrementalist and dismiss the Clintons as sellouts. They call for a much more dramatic overhaul, but one that unnerves risk-averse establishment Democrats who worry that such an ambitious agenda could drive centrist voters to Trump.

In addition to Biden and Buttigieg, the ranks of the Adjusters have recently been swelled by the addition of former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg and former Massachusetts Governor Deval Patrick to the race. Senators Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota and Cory Booker of New Jersey are part of this faction as well, as are the lower-tier candidates Michael Bennet, the Colorado senator, and John Delaney, a former Maryland congressman. All face a similar challenge of trying to excite primary voters with some variation of a more cautious agenda.

The rest of the primary candidates are Revolutionaries. Along with Warren and Sanders, nontraditional alternatives such as entrepreneur Andrew Yang, Rep. Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii, and impeachment activist Tom Steyer occupy this space as well, along with fading options like former Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julian Castro and author Marianne Williamson. They might differ on the specifics of their policy prescriptions, but all advocate for a much more fundamental shift in the priorities of their party and the country.

Harris was the only Democratic candidate who made a serious effort to talk to voters in both groups. Lacking the skills of Obama and the experience of Bill Clinton, she was unable to convince either Adjusters or the Revolutionaries that she was one of them. Rejected by both, she now returns to the Senate, where the upcoming impeachment trial gives her the opportunity to burnish her credentials for a spot on the ticket or a Cabinet post.

Though Harris has left the race, the divide in her party remains. Just as in 2016, when many Sanders supporters stayed home instead of voting, or chose Trump or third-party candidates, a similar temptation will exist in 2020 if a moderate becomes the Democratic nominee. Conversely, the late Bloomberg and Patrick entries reflect growing worries in the party's centrist establishment wing about Democratic prospects in the general election.

The eventual nominee will not defeat Trump unless the Adjusters and Revolutionaries are able to put aside their differences. Harris' greatest contribution to her party this year may be to serve as a reminder of what could happen if that unity is not achieved.

Title: Obama Cautions on Syria Chemical Weapons Use, Awaits Conclusive Proof Before Taking Action

Article:

In a recent development, President Barack Obama has expressed caution over the reported use of chemical weapons in Syria, emphasizing the need for conclusive evidence before taking any action. The Washington Post first reported on Tuesday that there were indications of small-scale chemical munitions use in Syria, a claim that the Assad regime has been known to possess.

At a press conference in Washington on Tuesday, President Obama stated, "What we now have is evidence that chemical weapons have been used inside of Syria, but we don't know how they were used, when they were used, who used them; we don't have chain of custody that establishes what exactly happened."

The President reiterated his stance that before responding, he needs solid proof that Syrian President Bashar al-Assad had deployed these weapons - a point he emphasized during the news conference. "When I am making decisions about America's national security and the potential for taking additional action in response to chemical weapon use, I've got to make sure I've got the facts," Obama said.

The President also warned against rushing to judgment without solid evidence, stating, "If we end up rushing to judgment without hard, effective evidence, then we can find ourselves in the position where we can't mobilize the international community to support what we do."

Despite the lack of conclusive proof of chemical weapons use, officials have reported that the Pentagon has prepared a range of options for President Obama, including airstrikes, commando raids, and the enforcement of a no-fly zone over Syria. The administration is also reportedly looking for ways to increase aid to the rebels.

President Obama has previously resisted calls to arm the rebels, including from David H. Petraeus, the former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, and former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton. A proposal by Petraeus to provide arms to carefully vetted members of the opposition was shelved last fall, though several officials expect it to be revisited.

Title: Iranian Cyberattacks: Iran's Advancing Capabilities and Potential Escalation in Cyber Warfare

Article:

Over the past year, Iranian hackers have been targeting the presidential campaign of former U.S. President Donald Trump, telecom companies, infrastructure systems, and more than 200 oil, gas, and heavy machinery companies worldwide. According to James A. Lewis, a cybersecurity expert at the Center for Strategic Studies in Washington, these hackers have developed the capability to disrupt critical infrastructure and have the ability to wipe data. The question now is what services, such as pipelines or dams, they may target next.

Iran is not yet at the top of the league of countries with the ability to cause widespread destruction via cyberattacks, Mr. Lewis and other experts said. However, Tehran has made significant strides since 2009, when a classified intelligence assessment concluded that it had the motivation but lacked the skills and resources to inflict harm.

Since 2010, when an Iranian nuclear facility was the target of a joint American-Israeli cyberattack, Iran has embraced such attacks as part of its strategy of asymmetrical warfare. While the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps may never match the West in conventional warfare, its specialized teams have learned how much destruction they can cause to vulnerable systems, according to American intelligence assessments and private security researchers.

Over the past five years, American officials and cybersecurity experts have tracked Iranian hackers as they have significantly advanced their capabilities beyond wiping data to sophisticated attacks on financial networks, internet infrastructure, energy companies, and critical infrastructure sites like the Bowman Dam in Westchester County and the Energy Department's Idaho National Engineering Laboratory near Idaho Falls.

"They now have the ability to do serious harm," Mr. Lewis said. "As the conflict with the U.S. continues, they're going to be tempted. Expect to see a lot more testing of how far they can get into company networks, universities, federal networks, and smaller government networks in towns and cities."

In response to the killing of Maj. Gen. Qassim Suleimani in an overnight airstrike at the Baghdad airport, Iranian leaders issued strident calls for revenge against the United States on Friday. The potential for escalation in cyber warfare between the two nations remains a significant concern.

Title: New Book Alleges Hunter Biden's Business Deals with Foreign Governments and Oligarchs

Article:

In a new book titled "Profiles in Corruption: Abuse of Power by America's Progressive Elite," author Peter Schweizer alleges that Hunter Biden, son of the 2020 presidential candidate Joe Biden, forged business deals with individuals and entities tied to the governments of Russia, China, and Kazakhstan, reportedly earning him hundreds of millions of dollars.

The book, which has been reviewed by ███, details how Hunter Biden and his business partners, including Devon Archer, were deeply involved with an entity called the Burnham Financial Group. According to the book, Hunter and Archer used Burnham to make foreign deals with governments and oligarchs.

One of those oligarchs included Nurlan Abduov, the associate of another Kazakh oligarch, Kenges Rakishev. Rakishev is the son-in-law of the former vice prime minister of Kazakhstan, Imangali Tasmagambetov. Tasmagamvetov was also formerly the defense minister, and is now the Kazakh ambassador to Russia.

The book alleges that an account Hunter regularly received funds from showed money arriving from a firm run by Rakishev in 2014. Additionally, Archer is said to have acted as a backchannel between Kazakhstan and then-Secretary of State John Kerry, according to the book.

Furthermore, the book claims that Burnham had business deals with two mysterious Chinese companies - Kirin Global Enterprises Limited and Harvest Global Investors. Kirin Global Enterprise Limited was an investment vehicle run by Xiangyao (or Yaojun) "Larry" Liu and Guo Jianfeng, according to Schweizer. Harvest Global Investors was a Chinese investment firm linked to the government in Beijing.

Burnham also had a financial relationship with Russian Oligarch Yelena Baturina, a billionaire with extensive political connections in Moscow and links to Russian organized crime, according to Schweizer. Archer reportedly said Baturina invested $200 million into "various investment funds" with which he was involved.

The book also alleges that Burnham was involved in a $60 million fraudulent bond scheme to rip off union pension funds and the poorest Indian tribe in America, the Oglala Sioux. In May 2016, Archer was arrested in New York and charged with "orchestrating a scheme to defraud investors and a Native American tribal entity of tens of millions of dollars."

Although Hunter Biden was not charged, Schweizer writes, "his fingerprints were all over Burnham." The legitimacy that his name and political status as the vice president's son lent to Burnham was brought up repeatedly during the trial, he writes. That status was used as a means of both recruiting pension money into the scheme and alleviating investors' concerns, he writes.

Hunter Biden had an office at Burnham's New York City offices on Fifty-Seventh Street, and during the trial, numerous witnesses came forward describing Hunter's involvement with the firm, according to the book.

Schweizer writes that these deals have long been a pattern with the Biden family, including Hunter Biden: "With the election of his father as vice president, Hunter Biden launched businesses fused to his father's power that led him to lucrative deals with a rogue's gallery of governments and oligarchs around the world."

Title: Focusing on the Core Questions: The Benghazi Committee's New Evidence and the Unanswered Questions Surrounding the 2012 Attack

Article:

As the House Select Committee on Benghazi prepares for a hearing on Thursday, the focus is not on Hillary Clinton's emails but on the fundamental questions surrounding the 2012 attack in Benghazi. The committee, established to investigate the events leading to the death of four Americans, has been criticized for its credibility, with fellow Republicans and others questioning its motives.

The central question that the committee should address is not what former special forces Americans were doing in Benghazi, but rather, what were the Americans doing in Benghazi in the first place? Consulates and embassy annexes are typically for diplomatic activities such as issuing visas and handling lost luggage. However, it is clear that this was not the purpose of the former special forces Americans in Benghazi.

Key questions that the committee should focus on include: Who was Ambassador Stevens supposed to meet in Benghazi, and who was responsible for his security? Which Libyan militia groups were the U.S. partnering with, and who vetted them? The committee should delve into the events that transpired in the weeks leading up to the attack, particularly why Ambassador Stevens' repeated calls for more security were ignored.

Another question that has been circulating is whether the Benghazi attack was a gun-running operation to take Qaddafi's abandoned weapons and turn them over to Syrian rebels. If this is true, were the American contractors running guns? Were the U.S. working with and arming Libyan rebels who turned out to be Al Qaeda-type terrorists? If so, not only was this a questionable decision, it was potentially illegal.

The committee should also question why there was no rescue mission mounted while our men were under attack. Furthermore, they should ask who decided to lie about the events on September 11, 2012 being a planned terrorist attack and instead of using the lame excuse that they were the result of a YouTube video sparking a demonstration that got out of hand.

The committee has new evidence, including Ambassador Stevens' own emails, which may make it difficult for any witness to dodge the questions. The most fundamental question of all is whether the fiasco of the Libyan war was another example of the Obama administration's alleged love affair with moderately radical Islamists. Has the Obama administration been willfully blind to the dangers posed by all radical Islamists in Libya, Egypt, Syria, Iraq, and Iran?

The nation's business was put on hold for over a year during the Watergate scandal, and it is crucial for the committee to rise above politics and serve the nation's business. The integrity of the Watergate Committee members, both Republican and Democrat, played a significant role in the system working, and the same should be expected of the Benghazi Committee. The committee's findings will provide much-needed clarity on the events that transpired in Benghazi on September 11, 2012.

Title: Norway Mosque Shooting: Suspect Charged with Terrorism and Murder

Article:

In a shocking turn of events, a 21-year-old Norwegian citizen, allegedly identified as Philip Manshaus, has been charged with terrorism and murder following a shooting at a mosque near Oslo on Saturday. The incident, which left one woman dead at his home and three men injured at the Al-Noor Islamic Center, has sent shockwaves through Norway and beyond.

According to local police, Manshaus, who was reportedly wearing body armor and heavily armed, opened fire at the mosque after breaking through a glass door. A 65-year-old worshipper, who sustained injuries during the confrontation, managed to overpower the gunman. The shooting could have been more devastating if the suspect had arrived a few minutes earlier, as there were more than a dozen people inside the mosque just 10 minutes before the incident.

Authorities found the body of Manshaus' 17-year-old stepsister at his home in Baerum, west of Oslo. He has been charged with the murder of his stepsister and is facing an attempted murder charge for the mosque shooting.

The shooting is being investigated as a terrorist act due to the gunman's apparent intent to instill fear. However, authorities emphasize that there is no evidence linking Manshaus to a larger network. Reports suggest that the suspect held far-right views, including admiration for Vidkun Quisling, Norway's leader who collaborated with the Nazis during World War II.

Hours before the attack, a user with the same name as the alleged gunman posted on the 4chan messaging board, expressing admiration for the gunman who killed 51 people at two New Zealand mosques earlier this year. The post included a meme that described that gunman as a "saint" and praised the alleged El Paso, Texas, shooter for "reclaiming his country."

In response to the attack, Prime Minister Erna Solberg stated, "Norway should be safe. All places of worship shall be safe." As Muslims celebrated the beginning of Eid al-Adha on Sunday, many non-Muslims stood outside mosques in Oslo to stand guard.

This story has been updated with new information since its initial publication.

Title: FBI Background Checks for Firearm Purchases Decline After Record High in December

Article:

Following a record-breaking high in December, the number of FBI background checks run through the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) has decreased year-over-year for the first time since October 2011. The decline in checks, which serve as a proxy for gun sales, suggests a waning fervor for gun purchases following the Connecticut school shooting and subsequent government push for new gun control measures.

In June, 1.3 million checks were performed, a significant drop from the 2.7 million in December and a decrease of about 20,000 compared to the same month last year. This marks the first year-to-year drop in checks since October 2011.

David Chipman, a former agent for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives and an adviser to the gun control advocacy group Mayors Against Illegal Guns, attributes the decline to a saturation of gun purchases. "It seems that those motivated by fear to purchase a firearm over the past several months have acquired all of the guns they desire or can afford," he said.

NICS checks surged by nearly 500,000 in November compared to the previous year, reaching the 2 million mark for the first time. In December, they increased by over 900,000, hitting an all-time high of 2.7 million. John Hudak, a fellow at the Brookings Institution who studies gun issues, attributes the surge to a sense of threat and the need to satisfy that threat.

"People felt a threat. The need created by that threat was then satisfied. The shock and horror has died down in pretty dramatic fashion over the past few months," Mr. Hudak said.

The desire for guns, according to Mr. Hudak, fit into the psyche of the moment. "At the same time, there was another type of fear or threat: The government would somehow stop gun sales," he said. "An irrational fear, but a fear nonetheless."

The defeat of a gun control bill in the Senate in mid-April, despite months of administration lobbying and President Obama's extensive use of the public "bully pulpit," supports this theory.

NICS checks are not a one-to-one correlation to gun sales, as some checks are performed on active concealed carry permits and other nonsale actions. However, the number of checks is a fairly decent, though imperfect, proxy for the number of guns sold.

The National Sports Shooting Foundation, the trade group for the guns and ammunition industry, keeps its own adjusted tally every month to account for such checks that don't translate directly into sales. According to Mike Bazinet, a spokesman for the group, low numbers in the middle of the year aren't out of the ordinary.

By the group's metric, the adjusted June figure of 872,025 is actually an increase of 3 percent over June 2012 and the 37th straight month of year-over-year monthly increases. "Our retailers are telling us that their firearms inventories are still lean (there are regional variations), although the ammunition shortage seems to be easing somewhat in many parts of the country," Mr. Bazinet wrote.

Josh Horwitz, executive director of the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence, cautions against reading too much into any comparisons with figures from December, stating that December is always the biggest month. Year-over-year, he pointed out, the number of checks increased from January through May and were basically flat in June, adjusting for permit checks.

"Months always vary in a pattern. They vary in the same way," he said.

The decline in NICS checks might signal to some that the issue is fading from the public eye, but President Obama and groups like Mr. Horwitz's have vowed not to let that happen. Immediately after the Newtown shooting, Mr. Obama rolled out an ambitious gun control package that included bans on semi-automatic rifles and high-capacity magazines and near-universal background checks. That package ultimately devolved into a compromise measure that would expand background checks to sales online and at gun shows. Even that measure failed to pass the Senate.

Mr. Obama and others, however, have reassured advocates that they will revisit the issue. "The American people are there," Vice President Joseph R. Biden said last month. "In the meantime, the president is going to continue to take every executive action within his power to make schools safer for our children, churches safe places to worship, and significantly work on reducing the number of gun deaths in America. No matter how long it takes, we're determined to do something about it."

Title: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's Chief of Staff and Communications Director Depart from Congressional Office Amid Controversy

Article:

In a series of departures from her Congressional office, Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez's Chief of Staff, Saikat Chakrabarti, and Communications Director, Corbin Trent, are leaving their roles. Chakrabarti will step down by Friday, while Trent will remain as Congressional spokesman until the end of the month before transitioning to Ocasio-Cortez's 2020 campaign.

Chakrabarti will take on a new role as head of New Consensus, a nonprofit climate change group that promotes the Green New Deal. Trent, who has been a controversial figure due to his aggressive tactics, will continue his role in the 2020 campaign as a spokesperson.

The Intercept first reported the departures, which were later confirmed by The Washington Post. The aides' actions, particularly those of Chakrabarti and Trent, have been criticized for making life difficult for Ocasio-Cortez in Washington.

Chakrabarti's controversial remarks, such as his tweet likening moderate Democrats to "new southern Democrats" and his criticism of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, have been widely criticized. He also drew criticism for his remarks about Rep. Sharice Davids, a Native American Democrat from a formerly red Kansas district, which were seen as racially charged.

Trent's negative press stemmed from his use of profanity in a tweet in June, where he called out a potential Republican challenger. The tweet, which included the F-bomb, generated negative press for Ocasio-Cortez.

Both aides joined Ocasio-Cortez's team after working on her successful primary campaign, where they were leaders of the Justice Democrats, an insurgent group that aimed to replace Democratic incumbents with progressives. The finances surrounding Justice Democrats have also generated bad press, with three Federal Election Commission complaints filed by conservative groups.

In a statement, Trent painted a positive picture of his departure, saying, "We are extraordinarily grateful for his service to advance a bold agenda and improve the lives of the people in NY-14." Ocasio-Cortez also expressed her gratitude, stating that Trent was "shifting to our campaign side so we can work on some ambitious comms projects we've been looking forward to working on."

Title: Honduras Signs "Safe Third Country" Agreement with U.S., Aiming to Redirect Migrants Seeking Asylum

Article:

NEW YORK ( ███ ) - Honduras has entered into a bilateral agreement with the U.S. government that could potentially redirect migrants crossing through the country towards the United States to seek asylum in their home countries or third countries, in the latest move to curb migration from Central America.

The agreement, announced on Wednesday, follows similar deals signed by El Salvador on September 20 and Guatemala on July 26. The specifics of the implementation of these agreements have yet to be disclosed by the respective governments. (For links to the El Salvador and Guatemala deals, please click on: tmsnrt.rs/2ldjzJI and tmsnrt.rs/2niarEz, respectively.)

A senior U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) official, speaking on condition of anonymity, stated that the Honduras deal aims to allow migrants to seek protection as close to their home as possible. The official declined to be named.

The Trump administration has implemented a rule, announced on July 16, that bars most migrants from gaining U.S. asylum if they did not seek safe haven in a country they transited through first. This rule, which shares similar objectives with the agreements, has faced legal challenges. A federal court initially blocked the rule from taking effect, but the U.S. Supreme Court, on September 11, allowed it to be implemented while the court challenges are ongoing.

The majority of migrants arriving at the U.S.-Mexico border are from the three northern triangle countries, and many present themselves to border officials to request asylum in the United States.

President Donald Trump has made reducing the growing number of asylum claims, which have led to lengthy backlogs in U.S. immigration courts, a top priority of his administration. The administration has implemented various measures to discourage migrants from applying.

However, immigrant advocates argue that sending people seeking refuge back to the region from which they fled, even if not to their home country, violates international commitments intended to protect vulnerable migrants from being returned to danger. The three countries have limited asylum offices that may struggle to handle a large number of claims, they contend.
