Honduran President Juan Orlando Hernandez has faced scrutiny over a court filing document related to the upcoming drug trafficking trial in New York of his brother, Juan Antonio “Tony” Hernandez. The president has denied any wrongdoing.

In a speech on Wednesday before the UN General Assembly, Hernandez reaffirmed his political reputation, addressing what he called "smears" from "criminals" and others, without directly referring to the allegations against him.

Title: Bipartisan Outcry Over Justice Department's AP Phone Records Investigation Raises Questions About Attorney General Eric Holder's Future

Article:

Speculation is mounting in Washington over whether the ongoing Justice Department investigation into Associated Press phone records could lead to the resignation or dismissal of Attorney General Eric Holder. In a series of comments, political analysts and journalists have suggested that the controversy could be the final straw for Holder, who has been embroiled in numerous controversies throughout his tenure.

Jill Lawrence of the National Journal wrote that Holder "could be the one that finally convinces [President Obama] that it is time to go." Esquire blogger Charles Pierce added, "He should be gone. This moment. Not only is this constitutionally abhorrent, it is politically moronic." Dan Kennedy, a journalism professor at Northeastern University, tweeted, "It is 8:42. The AP phone story broke at 7:50. Why is Eric Holder still attorney general?"

The political stakes for the White House are high, with the administration facing multiple controversies, including its handling of the attack on the US consulate in Benghazi and the IRS's investigation of conservative political organizations. "The rule of three... means the president's credibility is truly on the line right now," NBC's First Read observed.

The controversy over the seizure of the AP's phone records is unique in that it has garnered bipartisan criticism. On Monday, the AP, a highly influential news cooperative that serves print, broadcast, and online news outlets, announced that the Justice Department had secretly obtained two months of phone records for reporters and editors in New York, Washington, and Hartford, Conn. The government seized records for more than 20 separate phone lines that were used by more than 100 reporters in April and May 2012.

AP President and Chief Executive Officer Gary Pruitt wrote to Holder, calling the Justice Department operation a "massive and unprecedented intrusion" into how news organizations do their work. "There can be no possible justification for such an overbroad collection of telephone communications," Mr. Pruitt said.

At a press conference Tuesday afternoon, Holder said he recused himself from the decision to subpoena the AP's phone records, and that the decision had been made by Deputy Attorney General Jim Cole, who is handling the case. Holder said he stepped aside because he had been interviewed in the investigation into who provided information for a May 7, 2012, AP story about a foiled terror plot that targeted the US. The attorney general said the leak his department was investigating "put the American people at risk."

The Justice Department released a statement defending its actions, saying, "We take seriously our obligations to follow all applicable laws, federal regulations, and Department of Justice policies when issuing subpoenas for phone records of media organizations.… Because we value the freedom of the press, we are always careful and deliberative in seeking to strike the right balance between the public interest in the free flow of information and the public interest in the fair and effective administration of our criminal laws."

Sen. Patrick Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who heads the Senate Judiciary Committee, issued a statement, saying, "I am very troubled by these allegations and want to hear the government's explanation."

On Monday, White House Press Secretary Jay Carney issued a statement distancing the White House from the investigation. "We are not involved in decisions made in connection with criminal investigations, as those matters are handled independently by the Justice Department." On Tuesday, however, he offered Holder some support: "The president has confidence in the attorney general."

When Holder was asked about his future last month on the Tom Joyner Morning Show, he responded, "I don't know," when asked if he would stay the full four years of Obama's second term. He added, "I'm happy. I'm still enjoying what I'm doing and still want to be done. I'm still the president's wing man, and I'm here with my boy."

Title: Ted Cruz Announces Carly Fiorina as Vice Presidential Running Mate Amidst 2016 Republican Race

Article:

In a surprising move, Republican presidential candidate Ted Cruz announced former GOP primary rival Carly Fiorina as his choice for vice president on Wednesday, amidst the ongoing 2016 race. The announcement, made in the critical primary state of Indiana, was met with immediate skepticism from the Trump campaign, who labeled it as a sign of desperation.

Cruz, while acknowledging the early announcement as "unusual," defended the decision, stating that "nobody is getting to 1,237 delegates," the number needed to clinch the nomination, and voters should "know what [they] will get."

"After a great deal of time and thought, after a great deal of consideration and prayer, I have come to the conclusion that if I am nominated to be president of the United States that I will run on a ticket with my vice presidential nominee, Carly Fiorina," Cruz said.

The potential pairing, if successful, would offer the possibility of electing the first Hispanic president and the first female vice president. Fiorina, in accepting Cruz's offer, expressed her readiness to "fight."

"I’ve had tough fights all my life," Fiorina said. "Tough fights don’t worry me a bit."

Cruz's selection of a vice presidential candidate in April, while he is well behind in delegates, follows a pattern of somewhat unconventional campaigning, including an early embrace of Trump and kicking off his campaign without first forming an exploratory committee.

Fiorina, who began her career as a secretary and receptionist, quickly rose up the business ranks and was named in 1999 as the chief executive officer for Hewlett-Packard, becoming the first woman to lead a Fortune 20 company. Her tenure at HP, however, drew criticism for alleged deals with Iran and the laying off of 30,000 employees.

Fiorina's career as a political candidate began when she tried to unseat California Sen. Barbara Boxer during an unsuccessful 2010 bid. Boxer, in response to the pairing, mocked the suggestion, stating, "The best way to describe that ticket is mean and meaner."

While most presidential candidates wait until they have the nomination sewn up to announce a running mate, Cruz's selection of a vice presidential candidate in April, while he is well behind in delegates, follows a pattern of somewhat unconventional campaigning. The battle for the GOP nomination continues, with Trump leading Cruz in pledged delegates, 954-562. The Republican Convention is scheduled for July.

Title: Education Secretary Arne Duncan Urges Action on Gun Violence, Calls for Restrictions on High-Powered Firearms

Article:

In a poignant speech at Washington D.C.'s Neval Thomas Elementary School on Friday, Education Secretary Arne Duncan called for a united front among school leaders, politicians, Second Amendment advocates, and others to address the issue of gun violence in America.

"I ask, I beg, and I plead - let us make real and rapid progress on that front," Mr. Duncan said, emphasizing the need for personal involvement in the matter.

Mr. Duncan, a member of President Obama's task force on gun violence and mental health, spoke publicly for the first time since the tragic shooting in Newtown, Connecticut, last week. He highlighted the complex factors that led shooter Adam Lanza to take 26 lives at Sandy Hook Elementary School, but emphasized that limiting access to high-powered firearms remains the simplest and easiest solution.

"I can't help but wonder what he might have done, how this might have been different, if he didn't have access to those guns," Mr. Duncan reflected, recalling his experience with gun violence during his tenure as chief of Chicago public schools.

"Maybe he just would've been punching his pillow, and his mother would still be there...and there would be 26 families in Newtown, Connecticut, who would be celebrating the holidays instead of attending funerals. Unfortunately, it's too late for them, but it's not too late for America," he added.

Mr. Duncan's address coincided with the National Rifle Association's first press conference since the Newtown massacre, an anticipated event that will provide insights into the potential challenges for gun-control proponents in enacting stricter laws. Advocates now seek a reinstatement of the assault weapons ban, the closing of the so-called "gun show loophole," and limits to high-capacity ammunition clips, similar to those used by Lanza at Sandy Hook.

"Reasonable people should be able to agree on these restrictions," Mr. Duncan concluded.

Title: Senate Judiciary Committee Hearing: A Study in Contrasts and Hypocrisy

Article:

The Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on Thursday was a complex and contradictory event, showcasing both progress and regression in the American political landscape. The hearing, which featured the testimonies of Christine Blasey Ford and Judge Brett Kavanaugh, highlighted the evolving roles of women in politics, as well as the enduring challenges they face.

On one hand, the Republican senators displayed a level of respect towards Dr. Ford, hiring a female prosecutor to question her and largely avoiding the derogatory language that marred Anita Hill's testimony in 1991. However, the hearing also felt strikingly outdated, with a woman's emotional testimony often overshadowed by the righteous indignation of a white man.

Dr. Ford came across as deferential, nervous, and deeply concerned with accuracy. Her testimony was specific and poignant, detailing the impact the alleged assault had on her life, including installing a second front door on her house due to her post-traumatic anxiety. Judge Kavanaugh, on the other hand, was portrayed as an angry and bullying figure, prone to yelling, weeping, and exploiting political anger.

The Republican senators' self-presentation was oddly tense, carefully avoiding the appearance of grilling Dr. Ford. They called her "credible" and even complimented her appearance, but showed little interest in her testimony. The hearing was, as Chairman Chuck Grassley put it, a mere courtesy.

The hollowness of the proceedings put a fine point on our new political reality. The norms have changed, and even the Republican party has realized it can't score points by personally attacking sexual assault victims. However, the party is still able to indulge in hypocrisy, pretending to respect Dr. Ford's words without acknowledging their impact on Kavanaugh's nomination.

The cracks in the right's approach are showing, though. The most telling moment came a day later, on Friday, when two sexual assault survivors emotionally confronted Senator Jeff Flake in an elevator. This raw and painful encounter revealed the real power of women's voices, and it prompted Flake to call for an FBI investigation.

The Kavanaugh affair is, as we all know, about much more than a US Supreme Court seat; it is a referendum on the political power of women. And as dark as the hearing was, Friday's turn of events offered a bracing reminder: The right knows it has a woman problem. It may not want to listen to the voices on its threshold, but they are only getting louder.

Title: Trump Administration Alters U Visa Policy, Increasing Deportation Risk for Immigrants Cooperating with Criminal Investigations

Article:

The Trump administration has implemented a new policy regarding U visas, a class of visa granted to immigrants who cooperate with criminal investigations. The change allows for the potential deportation of immigrants while they are waiting for their U visas, a move that immigration attorneys argue will discourage immigrants from reporting serious crimes and reflects the administration's broader efforts to deport as many immigrants as possible from the United States.

The revised Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) directive, released on Aug. 2, allows ICE to grant permission for people to stay in the country as they await their U visas. However, it also permits ICE to deport pending U visa applicants at its discretion.

Applications for U visas can take up to four years to process, and the government issues 10,000 per year, with no limit on the number of visas that can be issued to spouses and children of applicants or to parents of applicants who are themselves under 21. The directive reserves the right for ICE to "review the totality of the circumstances, including any favorable or adverse factors, and any federal interest (s) implicated and decide whether a Stay of Removal or terminating proceedings is appropriate."

ICE states in the directive that it will "exercise its discretion" in determining whether to grant stay of removal requests, but cautions that the agency "no longer exempts classes or categories of removable aliens from potential enforcement."

In a statement to ███, an ICE spokesperson defended the change as necessary due to the volume of applications. "As the number of U visa petitions submitted increased, this process became burdensome on both agencies and such determinations didn’t reflect a qualitative assessment of any assistance provided to law enforcement," the spokesperson said.

Immigration attorneys argue that the new directive will have a chilling effect on immigrants who are victims of crimes and are seeking protection. Eileen Blessinger, a Falls Church, Va.-based immigration attorney, told ███ that the new directive will make immigrants less likely to report crimes because "by applying, you’re essentially reporting yourself to ICE but now there’s a risk that ICE might pick you up."

Cecelia Friedman Levin, senior policy counsel at ASISTA Immigration Assistance, told ███ that the new ICE policies impacting the U visa program contravene the purpose that Congress created these protections for. "What we see here with new ICE policies that impact the U visa program is that some of these changes really contravene the purpose that Congress created these protections for," she said.

Kristian Ramos, communications director at the immigrant advocacy group Define American, told ███ that the change was indicative of the administration's general handling of long-standing immigration policy. "This administration's reckless changing of long-standing laws has very human casualties," Ramos said.

The new policy has already had real-world consequences for some immigrants. Blessinger told ███ that her firm had a client who had been deported twice before whose daughter was a victim of child sexual abuse and who had cooperated with the investigation. The man was able to file for a U visa, which was eventually approved, and will be able to stay in the United States and continue to cooperate with the sexual abuse investigation. If he had applied for the U visa under the terms of the new ICE directive, however, he could have been deported.

Another of Blessinger's clients is a Salvadoran immigrant and victim of domestic violence who came to the U.S. in 2004 and has been detained in Caroline Detention Facility in Fort A.P. Hill, Va. after failing to appear in court in El Paso, Texas, after receiving a notice to appear that Blessinger said did not include her hearing's date or time. "She missed the court hearing and got a deportation order and the motion to reopen was denied, but while it was pending we were able to get U visa certification signed off saying she was a victim of domestic violence and cooperated with the investigation," Blessinger told ███. "She’s not a criminal, she’s someone that in the past would be released on an ankle bracelet."

The U visa was created in 2000 by a bipartisan majority in Congress with two important purposes: to be a tool for law enforcement to investigate or prosecute criminal activity, and to provide protection for immigrant survivors in coming forward and seeking protection. The new ICE directive, however, has raised concerns that it will make it more difficult for immigrants to seek protection and cooperate with law enforcement, potentially leading to an increase in unreported crimes and a decrease in the number of immigrants who are able to seek protection.

Title: California Teacher Tenure Ruled Unconstitutional: Implications for Education Reform and Future Litigation

Article:

In a landmark ruling, Los Angeles County Superior Court Judge Rolfe Treu declared California's teacher tenure rules unconstitutional on Tuesday, citing the state's failure to provide equal education opportunities for all students. The ruling, which is subject to an inevitable appeal, could have far-reaching implications for education reform and potential litigation in other states.

The case, Vergara v California, centers around the employment protections afforded to K-12 teachers, often characterized as due process. These protections make it difficult for school officials to dismiss teachers based on performance, and compensation schemes are typically linked to seniority. The ruling, however, found that California's teacher tenure system violates constitutional equality guarantees, as it disproportionately affects minority students by housing ineffective teachers in heavily minority schools.

Teachers unions, predictably, contest the ruling, with many liberals viewing the anti-tenure movement as a thinly-veiled union-busting tactic. Conversely, education reformers, who typically advocate for performance-based compensation and job security, view the ruling as a step towards a more equitable education system.

The legal logic behind the ruling is noteworthy, as it employs a disparate impact theory, a left-wing approach to anti-discrimination policy that is often met with skepticism by conservatives. The specifics of the case revolve around the difficulty of transitioning from the general idea of merit-based employment decisions to the need for specific operational rules.

Reformers favor using value-added models, which track student test scores and measure teacher performance based on student progress. Critics argue that these models are unstable and unreliable, and that test-based incentive programs may lead to cheating and "teaching to the test." Proponents, however, point to the correlation between teacher performance and adult life outcomes, such as college attendance, socioeconomic status, and retirement savings.

For now, the ruling has no immediate consequences, as Treu issued a "tentative decision" in anticipation of appeal. The case will be appealed to the California Supreme Court, and if that court rules in favor of the plaintiffs, there will be significant changes in California education. If not, the status quo will remain.

California is just one of 50 states, and the success of this lawsuit could encourage reform groups to file similar litigation in other states. Expect more education-related litigation in the near future.

Title: Mitt Romney Reflects on His Presidential Campaign and the State of the Nation

Article:

In an exclusive interview, Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican nominee for president, discussed his campaign, the state of the nation, and the differences between the America he saw in 2008 and the one he sees now.

Romney, who is set to clinch the nomination on Tuesday in Texas, reflected on his campaign's upward momentum, attributing it to an increased sense among voters that the country is on the wrong path and a growing sense that he has proven himself. "We went through those 37 or 38 contests and won the must-win states," Romney said. "In some cases we started off 10 points behind. And we hustled, worked hard, and convinced the voters."

The economic downturn, which had not occurred during his 2008 primary, is now the central issue, with a "much higher degree of anxiety" among voters today, Romney said. He is struck by the number of people who are employed but in legitimate fear of being let go and by the number of people who have made investments for their retirement and seen them go down.

Before rallies and town meetings, Romney always tries to have private, off-the-record meetings with voters. He sits down with five or six couples or individuals and asks them to tell him about their lives. The stories he hears suggest a degree of anxiety that is not reflected in the statistics.

Romney keeps a campaign journal on his iPad, writing every two or three days to remember what it was like and to capture "the feelings—the ups, the downs, the people I meet and the sense I have about what's going to happen." He writes to reflect on the campaign and to capture the feelings of the people he meets.

When asked about his feelings towards politics, Romney said, "What I love are the political rallies and town meetings. I love the interchange with individuals that are probing and pushing." He added, "I like competition, and I think the game is like a sport for old guys. I mean, you know, I can't compete in competitive sports very well, but I can compete in politics, and there's the—what was the old ABC 'Wide World of Sports' slogan? 'The thrill of victory and the agony of defeat.' The only difference is victory is still a thrill, but I do not feel agony in loss."

Romney was asked about his mood and whether he wakes up in a good mood or has to work his way into it. "Depends on the day," he said. "Depends on the issue." He added, "The only time I'm unhappy is if I've done something that hurt the prospects for the success of our effort."

When asked for an example of a mistake he regrets, Romney mentioned his "I like to be able to fire people" comment. He explained that he meant those, such as health-insurance companies, that provide inadequate services. "I have to think not only about what I say in a full sentence but what I say in a phrase," he said. "In the current media environment, you will be taken out of context, you'll be clipped, and you'll be battered with things you said."

Romney believes we are in a unique time in American history, a "different time than any other time before it." He believes the country is at an inflection point, where the course of the nation has changed, and that the outcome of the election will determine whether the country will continue on a path towards government dominance or return to economic vitality. "I think America is going to decide whether we will put ourself on a path toward Europe—whether we will become another nation dominated by government, where citizens are dependent on government for the things they want in life, where opportunity is sacrificed, where military strength is depleted to pay for government promises, where unemployment is chronically high and wage growth chronically low," Romney said. "That, in my view, is the course the president has put us upon." If Barack Obama is re-elected, Romney believes it will be very difficult to get off that path. If he is elected, he promises "a period of economic vitality" that will leave the world "surprised." Not only the world, but "America is going to see a vitality we had not expected."

Title: Inspector General Report Finds Former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe Lacked Candor, Violated FBI Policy

Article:

In a damning report released on Friday, the Justice Department's inspector general found that former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe had improperly leaked information to a reporter and lied to both his superior, then-Director James Comey, and to FBI agents investigating his behavior. The report could potentially harm McCabe's credibility and ongoing investigations.

The report, which had been circulating within the government for weeks, was used to justify McCabe's firing earlier this year, just days before he was set to retire and collect his pension. The inspector general's report concluded that McCabe lacked candor, including under oath, on multiple occasions in connection with describing his role in connection with a disclosure to the Wall Street Journal. This conduct, the report found, violated FBI Offense Codes 2.5 and 2.6.

The report also revealed that McCabe authorized leaks to a Wall Street Journal reporter while trying to shape the narrative surrounding his role in the investigation into Hillary Clinton's secret emails. The 2016 leak confirmed the existence of an investigation into the Clinton Foundation, a probe the FBI had avoided confirming. The leak was deemed inappropriate because it was done "to advance his personal interests," the audit found.

In addition, McCabe lied to Mr. Comey, then to FBI agents and the inspector general in May and July 2017. In a follow-up interview late last year, he "contradicted his prior statements," the audit concluded.

The report also delved into several other thorny issues of the 2016 campaign, including an Aug. 12, 2016, call to McCabe from a high-ranking Justice Department official who complained that the FBI's investigation into the Clinton Foundation was too "overt," particularly in the middle of a presidential campaign.

The justice official, who was not named in the report, confirmed the general tenor of the call to investigators, but denied he was trying to pressure the FBI to stop the probe.

The report is likely to fuel President Trump's complaints about the FBI, the special counsel Robert Mueller's probe into his own behavior and that of his 2016 campaign, and Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who is overseeing Mr. Mueller.

The new report is expected to fuel President Trump's ongoing disinformation campaign, according to Rep. Jerrold Nadler, the ranking Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee. The report justifies McCabe's firing, according to Rep. Trey Gowdy, Republican South Carolina and chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee. The report is also expected to fuel the House Judiciary Committee's ongoing investigation into the FBI's decisions related to the 2016 election.

Sen. Dianne Feinstein, ranking Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee, argued that McCabe's actions should be viewed in the context of him trying to defend himself and his wife "against false press reports." She also criticized the timing of McCabe's firing, stating that it casts a "tremendous shadow over the integrity of this process."

Neither the FBI nor the Justice Department had a comment on the report.

Title: Bloomberg News Imposes Restrictive Policy on Presidential Campaign Investigations Amidst Founder's Presidential Bid

Article:

In a move that has sparked controversy and raised questions about journalistic independence, Bloomberg News, the global news service founded by Michael Bloomberg, has issued an edict to its staff, prohibiting investigations into the former New York mayor's presidential campaign and that of his Democratic competitors.

The policy, announced by editor-in-chief John Micklethwait, states that "We will continue our tradition of not investigating Mike (and his family and foundation)" and extends this prohibition to his Democratic rivals. This decision has been met with criticism, as it appears to favor Bloomberg while potentially disadvantaging his opponents, including Joe Biden, Bernie Sanders, Cory Booker, and others.

The policy has been a point of contention within the organization, with some former employees expressing their dissatisfaction. Kathy Kiely, former political editor, resigned in 2016 due to the same policy when Bloomberg was considering a presidential run. She stated, "I felt that we were not able to follow this story aggressively, and that I thought compromised us as an organization." Megan Murphy, Bloomberg's former Washington bureau chief, called the policy "ridiculous" and "not journalism."

The policy also affects Bloomberg Opinion, with top editors Tim O'Brien and David Shipley taking leaves to join the Bloomberg campaign. The editorial board has been suspended, and the section will refuse to publish any outside op-ed on the 2020 campaign.

Despite the restrictions, Bloomberg News has assigned a reporter to cover the campaign, writing about speeches, policies, and polls. The initial story on the launch described the candidate as offering a "mix of moderate policy stances and experience in business, government, and philanthropy as the way to beat President Donald Trump."

Micklethwait defends the policy, stating that he doesn't want to lay down too many rules, allowing for flexibility in changing circumstances. He also notes that if Bloomberg wins the nomination, they will reassess the situation.

This situation recalls the era of William Randolph Hearst using his newspapers to promote his 1904 presidential bid. However, Bloomberg's company dwarfs Hearst's early 20th-century enterprise.

Other media companies examine their owners or corporate parents with little fuss, reporting on figures like Jeff Bezos and Amazon, Disney, and CNN's corporate ties. It remains to be seen how this short-sighted move will impact Bloomberg News' reputation for journalistic independence.

Title: An Analysis of Political Tribalism: A Look at the Reinvention of Maxine Waters and the Ongoing Divide in American Politics

Article:

In the complex world of American politics, two recent articles have shed light on the deep-rooted issue of political tribalism. The first, published by The Daily Beast, delves into the transformation of Congresswoman Maxine Waters, a figure once labeled as one of the nation's "most corrupt." The second, a column by Dennis Prager titled "Why Conservatives Still Attack Trump," attempts to unravel the reasons behind the persistent resistance from many Republicans towards President Trump.

Beginning with Waters, the article highlights her recent standing ovations following her sharp attacks on Trump. This development not only exposes the hypocrisy of those who claim to resist Trump on constitutional and ethical grounds but also serves as a warning against aligning oneself with individuals who disregard the norms they claim to uphold.

The article further criticizes those who advocate for overturning the Citizens United ruling and allowing the state to ban political speech, arguing that they have little basis for lecturing about free expression. Similarly, it questions the integrity of those who, in the past, have proposed abandoning Fifth Amendment protections to confiscate guns or whose opposition to spying on American citizens is contingent on the sitting president.

The article then turns to the ongoing anti-Trump sentiment, suggesting that it reduces political discourse to a simple dichotomy of "Never Trump" versus "Always Trump," which the author argues is detrimental to the democratic process. The author criticizes the hysterical response to Trump's actions, particularly in relation to the Paris Agreement, and argues that this response undermines the traditional checks and balances of American governance.

In the second article, Dennis Prager addresses the persisting resistance from conservatives towards Trump. Prager argues that this resistance stems from a lack of understanding that the survival of the United States hinges on a set of ideals and laws, not on the competence of the Trump administration. He encourages Republicans to "please report for duty," urging them to support the president for the greater good, while acknowledging the president's flaws.

Prager's column also addresses the issue of political tribalism, arguing that there are a few reasons why some conservatives remain anti-Trump. He suggests that the primary reason is the lack of recognition of the ongoing civil war in the United States, with the survival of the country at stake.

However, the article questions Prager's assertion, suggesting that if the survival of the United States hinges on the Trump administration's competence, then the civil war is already lost. If, on the other hand, it hinges on a set of ideals and laws, then there is no obligation to follow any individual, even the president.

In conclusion, both articles highlight the deep-rooted issue of political tribalism in the United States, with each side presenting compelling arguments for their respective positions. The articles serve as a reminder of the importance of upholding the democratic process, respecting the Constitution, and recognizing the flaws in both political parties. It is a call for Americans to move beyond tribalism and work towards a more unified and functional political system.

Title: Hong Kong International Airport Canceled Flights Amidst Ongoing Pro-Democracy Protests, Chinese Authorities Label Protests as "Beginning to Show the Sprouts of Terrorism"

Article:

Hong Kong International Airport, one of the world's busiest airports, suspended all flights on Monday following a large-scale demonstration by pro-democracy protesters occupying the main terminal. Chinese authorities have likened the protest to "terrorism."

According to an official statement, the protests "seriously disrupted" airport operations. Only flights that were already boarding or had been cleared for landing were allowed to use the airport's runways. All other flights were canceled.

The ongoing protests in Hong Kong, which have been ongoing for over two months, have called for democratic reforms and an investigation into police conduct. The city's government, which is supposed to operate independently from communist China's influence, introduced an extradition bill that critics argue would threaten the liberties granted to the city and allow for extradition to mainland China.

The bill was temporarily suspended following protests, but the demonstrations have evolved from a specific focus on the extradition proposal to a broader demand for greater freedoms and a check on the perceived use of excessive force by authorities.

On Monday, China used the strongest language yet to condemn the protesters, with the Cabinet's Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Office in Beijing stating that the protests are "beginning to show the sprouts of terrorism" and constitute an "existential threat" to the population of Hong Kong.

"One must take resolute action toward this violent criminality, showing no leniency or mercy," said a statement from spokesperson Yang Guang. "Hong Kong has reached an inflection point where all those who are concerned about Hong Kong's future must say 'no,' to lawbreakers and 'no' to those engaged in violence."

Earlier on Monday, Hong Kong police displayed water cannons that could potentially be used in future demonstrations. Amnesty International has warned that the misuse of these cannons within the densely-populated city's confined spaces could lead to serious injuries.

Hong Kong is a former British colony that has been part of China since 1997, but benefits from autonomy under a "one country, two systems" approach. This structure allows the city certain democratic rights that are not afforded to people on the mainland, but in recent years, some people have accused the Communist Party-ruled central government of gradually eroding their freedoms.

Political scientist Ma Ngok at the Chinese University of Hong Kong told the South China Morning Post that heavy-handed tactics from police have alienated the population.

"They have lost confidence in the police enforcing the law fairly and would question the legitimacy of all their actions," he said. "They no longer think it's reasonable to blindly obey the law when there is no punishment for the officers' wrongdoings."

Title: Iowa's Democratic Primary: A Closer Look at the Competition Between Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders

Article:

In the lead-up to the Iowa caucuses, two prominent Democratic candidates, Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, have been garnering significant support at rallies held at the Iowa State Fair. Both candidates share similar progressive ideologies, advocating for universal healthcare, taking on Wall Street, and raising the minimum wage.

However, the question on many voters' minds is whether the presence of two popular progressives could potentially split the vote on the left, benefiting a centrist candidate such as former Vice President Joe Biden.

Sherma Mather, a 50-year-old visitor from Richmond, Virginia, expressed her concerns, stating, "Of course it concerns me." Early opinion polls have consistently shown Biden in the lead, with either Sanders or Warren in second place.

The combined support for Sanders and Warren surpasses Biden's, which some progressives argue indicates a shift towards the left within the Democratic Party. Adam Green, co-founder of the Progressive Change Campaign Committee, an advocacy group that supports Warren, described the two as a "1-2 punch" with a "gravitational pull" on the rest of the field.

Twenty-four Democrats are currently competing for the party's nomination, with the Iowa caucuses still six months away. Sanders and Warren have maintained that they are friends, not rivals, and have thus far avoided criticizing each other.

Recent polls show Warren gaining ground in Iowa, with 21% of the vote in a Monmouth University poll, trailing Biden by just seven percentage points. Sanders, on the other hand, has dropped to 9% in the state, according to the same poll. Sanders' campaign advisers have criticized the poll's methodology, claiming that his supporters were undersampled.

Nationally, the situation is more favorable for Sanders, with the most recent ███/Ipsos poll showing Sanders in second place by a wide margin over Warren.

Alexis Johnson, a 33-year-old resident of Des Moines, expressed her support for Sanders, stating, "It's going to Bernie or Biden, I feel like." However, Misty Cornelius, a 38-year-old Des Moines resident, expressed a preference for Warren, stating, "Bernie has been stigmatized. Warren is a fresh face."

Despite their similar ideologies, Warren and Sanders present distinct personas on the campaign trail. Warren, drawing upon her working-class roots, positions herself as a sort of prairie populist, while Sanders talks more in terms of leading a "movement."

Patrick Murray, the polling director at Monmouth, noted that while there is ideological overlap, Warren's recent surge has her pulling support away from virtually every other candidate, not just Sanders. Sanders' campaign, on the other hand, views Biden as their primary challenge, as both are courting the same working-class and union voters who gravitated towards Trump in 2016.

Biden's status as a front-runner has been somewhat undermined by several gaffes, including a controversial remark about poor kids being just as bright and talented as white kids.

U.S. Senator Kamala Harris of California ranks third in the state in the Monmouth poll with 11% support. After Iowa, Sanders and Warren will face off in New Hampshire, which holds the first Democratic primary later in February.

Both Sanders and Warren's campaigns are focused on convincing large swaths of voters that a progressive Democrat can win the election against Trump, according to the Progressive Change Campaign Committee's Green. "Many'electability voters' are parked in Joe Biden's column," Green said, "but that perception is changing."

Title: Trump, Kudlow Dismiss Recession Concerns, Maintain Optimistic Outlook on Economy

Article:

In a series of interviews over the weekend, President Donald Trump and his top economic adviser, Larry Kudlow, expressed optimism about the U.S. economy, downplaying concerns of a potential recession. The comments come after a steep drop in the financial markets last week.

President Trump told reporters as he returned to Washington from his New Jersey golf club that he does not believe the country is heading towards a recession. "I don't think we're having a recession," Trump said. "We're doing tremendously well. Our consumers are rich. I gave a tremendous tax cut and they're loaded up with money."

Kudlow, who also played down fears of a looming recession, predicted the economy will perform well in the second half of 2019. In Sunday television interviews, he said that consumers are seeing higher wages and are able to spend and save more. "No, I don't see a recession," Kudlow said. "We're doing pretty darn well in my judgment. Let's not be afraid of optimism."

The strong economy is crucial to Trump's reelection prospects. Consumer confidence has dropped 6.4% since July. The president has spent most of the week at his golf club in New Jersey, with much of his tweeting focused on talking up the economy.

Kudlow acknowledged a slowing energy sector, but said low interest rates will help housing, construction, and auto sales. He also defended the president's use of tariffs on goods coming from China. Before he joined the administration, Kudlow was known for opposing tariffs and promoting free trade during his career as an economic analyst. Kudlow said Trump has taught him and others that the "China story has to be changed and reformed."

"We can not let China pursue these unfair and unreciprocal trading practices," Kudlow said.

Democratic presidential candidate Beto O'Rourke said the U.S. needed to work with allies to hold China accountable on trade. He expressed concerns that Trump's trade war could drive the global economy into a recession.

"This current trade war that the president has entered our country into is not working," O'Rourke said. "It is hammering the hell out of farmers across this country."

Last month, the Federal Reserve reduced its benchmark rate – which affects many loans for households and businesses – by a quarter-point to a range of 2% to 2.25%. It's the first rate cut since December 2008 during the depths of the Great Recession. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stressed that the Fed was worried about the consequences of Trump's trade war and sluggish economies overseas.

"Weak global growth and trade tensions are having an effect on the U.S. economy," he said.

Breaking with historical norms, Trump has been highly critical of Powell, placing blame for any economic weakness on the nation's central bank for raising interest rates too much over the past two years.

Peter Navarro, who advises Trump on trade policy, shared that sentiment. "The Federal Reserve chairman should look in the mirror and say, 'I raised rates too far, too fast, and I cost this economy a full percentage point of growth,'" Navarro said.

Navarro also said that U.S. consumers are not affected by the administration's trade war with China, though tariffs are taxes paid by U.S. importers, not by China, and are often passed along to U.S. businesses and consumers through higher prices. Kudlow himself told Fox in May that U.S. consumers and businesses ultimately end up paying the tariffs that the administration imposes on billions of dollars of Chinese goods.

Trump acknowledged at least a potential impact when he paused a planned 10% tariff hike for many items coming from China, such as cellphones, laptops, video game consoles, some toys, computer monitors, shoes, and clothing. "We're doing (it) just for the Christmas season, just in case some of the tariffs could have an impact," the president told reporters in New Jersey.

Navarro would not go even that far, saying Sunday "there's no evidence whatsoever that Americans consumers are bearing any of this."

Kudlow was interviewed on NBC's "Meet the Press" and "Fox News Sunday." O'Rourke spoke on NBC, and Navarro appeared on CNN's "State of the Union" and CBS' "Face the Nation."

Trump's trade war with China has been a target of criticism by Democrats vying to challenge him in 2020. "There is clearly no strategy for dealing with the trade war in a way that will actually lead to results for American farmers or American consumers," said Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Indiana, a Democratic presidential candidate. He said on CNN that it was "a fool's errand" to think tariff increases will compel China to change its economic approach.

Title: Justice Department Seeks Stay of Court Order on Emergency Contraceptive Access for Minors

Article:

In a significant turn of events, the Justice Department will appear before a federal judge on Tuesday, aiming to suspend a recent ruling that would make emergency contraceptives available to teenage girls without a prescription in the coming days.

U.S. District Court Judge Edward Korman of New York has set a new timeline for his order to make the morning-after pill Plan B One-Step available to all ages, with the implementation delayed until Friday, five days later than the initially cited Monday.

In a letter, Judge Korman has granted the plaintiffs until Monday to formally respond to the notice of appeal the Justice Department filed earlier this week. The ongoing debate over minors' access to the morning-after pill is testing the loyalty of groups traditionally among the biggest supporters of President Obama.

In 2011, Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius decided to maintain age restrictions on the pill, a decision that women's rights groups have criticized. They argue that access to emergency contraception is suitable for all ages.

Pro-life groups, who typically criticize the Democratic president, have welcomed the decision to fight Judge Korman's ruling, although they are not entirely satisfied with the FDA's decision on Tuesday to allow girls as young as 15 to obtain the drug without a prescription, a change from the prior age limit of 17.

The Obama administration asserts that the FDA's lowering of the age is due to an application from the pill's maker, Teva Women's Health Inc., and is not related to the pending federal case. However, attorneys from Justice have noted the 15-year-old threshold now covers all the girls involved in the case, a move the plaintiffs' attorneys find suspicious.

Judge Korman has indicated he will give the government two opportunities to halt his ruling's implementation. "The parties are also advised that, in the event that I deny a stay pending appeal, I will grant a stay to allow the defendants to seek a stay from the Court of Appeals," his letter said.
